site_title: Carnival’s Princess brand revises 2025 world cruise routes amid Red Sea tensions
summary: Carnival's Princess brand is revising its 2025 world cruise routes due to Red Sea tensions. The company will no longer visit the Middle East and Asia, instead offering new port stops in Africa and Europe. The Island Princess will depart from Sydney in February, traveling via South Africa to end its journey at Malta, while the Crown Princess will also travel via Africa. This change comes after Carnival announced in March it would not sail through the Red Sea region for the rest of 2024 and early 2025 due to persisting hostilities.

site_title: McDonald's sales miss estimates as customers cut back spending
summary: McDonald's reported lower-than-expected quarterly sales growth of 1.9% globally, missing analyst estimates of 2.35%. The company attributed the decline to consumers cutting back on spending, with consumers becoming "more discriminating with every dollar they spend". International sales were also affected by the Middle East conflict, while same-store sales in the US grew 2.5%, lower than last year's 12.6% growth.

images.alt_text: The addition of Krispy Kreme is the latest change to McDonald’s bakery lineup.

On Friday, system outages plagued McDonald’s locations across some of its biggest global markets, including Japan, Australia and the UK, forcing many stores to temporarily take only cash or shut down entirely.

site_title: PayPal lifts 2024 profit forecast as spending stays resilient, margins improve
summary: PayPal has raised its full-year adjusted profit forecast, citing robust consumer spending and improving operating margins. Total payment volumes increased 14% to $403.9 billion in the first quarter, while net revenue climbed 10% to $7.7 billion. The company expects 2024 adjusted profit to increase by "mid-to-high single-digit percentage" and second-quarter revenue to grow 7% on a currency-neutral basis. Operating margins improved 84 basis points to 18.2% in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: PayPal has faced setbacks of its own with PYUSD.
PayPal has faced setbacks of its own with PYUSD.

site_title: Proposed rules on shareholder-requisitioned meetings can reduce uncertainty
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has proposed new rules requiring listed issuers to facilitate shareholder-requisitioned meetings, aiming to reduce uncertainty and support shareholders' ability to exercise their fundamental rights. The rules, which build on existing legislation, set clearer expectations on timelines and actions for issuers and requisitionists, and may help avoid protracted delays. However, the effectiveness of the rules depends on strong enforcement, and experts suggest considering neutral parties to assist with facilitative actions and revising legislation to allow shareholders to call meetings.

images.alt_text: “Companies need to hear what the market is asking for. At the same time, the market needs to reward the companies that listen and act. We have already seen some evidence of this,” says SGX RegCo's Tan Boon Gin.
SGX RegCo is enabling the convening of general meetings to empower shareholders to drive change and exercise market discipline

site_title: DBS can resume non-essential activities, but 1.8 times multiplier on its assets stays
summary: DBS Bank has been allowed to resume non-essential activities after a six-month pause, but it must maintain a 1.8 times multiplier on its risk-weighted assets for operational risk. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) cited "substantive progress" in addressing service disruptions experienced by customers in 2023, but will continue to monitor the bank's progress. DBS has made improvements in technology risk governance, system resilience, and incident management. The bank's focus on strengthening technology resiliency and enhancing digital service availability remains unchanged.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of the DBS logo pictured on March 5, 2024.
DBS will also be allowed to acquire new business ventures during this period, or reduce the size of its branch and ATM networks in Singapore.
The disruption of DBS and Citi banking services over the weekend has led to some merchants not receiving customer payments even by Monday.
PayNow’s potential to break in unexpected ways threaten its integrity as a payment platform because transactions on the network do not fail gracefully.

site_title: Japan may have spent 5.5 trillion yen on Apr 29 intervention, BOJ data suggests
summary: Japan's central bank, the Bank of Japan (BOJ), may have spent approximately 5.5 trillion yen ($52 billion) on April 29 to intervene in the currency market, according to data. The yen had fallen to a 34-year low of 160.245 per US dollar before rapidly recovering. Former top currency diplomat Mitsuhiro Furusawa suggests it was "highly likely" the authorities intervened to prop up the currency. Analysts point to differences in Japanese and US government debt yields as the main force behind the yen's slide, which has depreciated over 10% against the US dollar this year.

images.alt_text: Japan's vice-finance minister for international affairs Masato Kanda's comments come a day after Japan’s currency surged as much as five yen against the dollar in what traders cited as intervention.
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Japanese Yen and U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo
The greenback bought 160.17 yen in morning trade, fanning speculation that Japanese authorities would step in to support their currency.

site_title: URA prepares massive site in Sengkang to house new residential estate
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has prepared a massive site in Sengkang for a new residential estate, Fernvale North, which will provide commercial and recreational amenities to residents. The 5-hectare site, bounded by several roads, will be near two LRT stations and Sengkang Riverside Park. URA plans to support housing demand in the area with a mix of residential and commercial developments, including a small park and a place of worship. Analysts expect around 8,000 to 10,000 new homes in the area, with prices ranging from S$102,000 to S$442,000 for BTO flats.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of private properties in Singapore.

site_title: Temasek-backed PsiQuantum to build first commercial quantum computer
summary: Temasek-backed PsiQuantum plans to build the world's first commercial quantum computer in Brisbane, Australia, with a target launch by 2027. The utility-scale quantum computer will feature cabinets with hundreds of silicon chips and is expected to perform billions of computational steps without errors. The project will involve building increasingly larger and more sophisticated systems, and PsiQuantum has secured US$620 million in funding from the Australian and Queensland governments. This technology has the potential to ignite the next industrial revolution and unlock innovation in fields such as material science, drug discovery, and logistics.

site_title: Singapore’s chance to become a global leader in sustainable aviation fuel
summary: Singapore aims to become a global leader in sustainable aviation fuel, with a passenger levy and mandate to use 1% sustainable aviation fuel by 2026. This move is expected to unlock thousands of high-quality jobs and boost the economy by billions of dollars. The country's growth in the aviation sector, with Asia's passenger numbers set to double by 2040, presents an opportunity for Singapore to demonstrate regional leadership. By accelerating domestic production, Singapore can capitalize on the growing global demand for sustainable aviation fuels and establish itself as a key player in the industry.

images.alt_text: Aviation industry observers say the proposed levy by Singapore to fund sustainable jet fuel use will have a minor effect on ticket prices.
Sandboxing of carbon capture and utilisation should be done on an industrial scale to quicken progress, Surbana Jurong’s Tan Wooi Leong says.

site_title: CSE Global records S$186.2 million in Q1 new orders, up 16.7%
summary: CSE Global secured S$186.2 million in new orders in Q1, a 16.7% increase from the previous year. The growth was driven by stronger demand for electrification and automation solutions in the infrastructure and energy industries. The company's order book stands at S$719.3 million as of March 31. CSE's CEO, Lim Boon Kheng, expects order intake momentum to remain robust in 2024, driven by urbanization, electrification, and decarbonization trends.

images.alt_text: CSE Global, a mainboard-listed automation solutions provider, plans to evaluate investment opportunities in the US, Australia and New Zealand.
CSE group managing director Lim Boon Kheng expects the project to contribute positively to CSE’s financial performance for the 2024-2025 financial years.

site_title: Australian budget airline Bonza collapses, passengers stranded
summary: Australian budget airline Bonza has entered voluntary administration, suspending all flights and stranding passengers. The airline had been struggling since its launch 15 months ago with limited market share, controlled by US investment firm 777 Partners. Regulatory filings show Bonza's fleet had been repossessed by creditors, and an advisory firm has been appointed as administrator. The Australian government is working to ensure stranded passengers reach home safely, with Qantas and Virgin Australia offering assistance.

images.alt_text: Alan Joyce, chief executive officer of Qantas Airways Ltd., speaks during a news conference in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday, Aug. 24, 2023. Qantas ordered dozens more long-range Boeing Co. and Airbus SE jets in a bid to keep pace with a post-pandemic travel boom that's delivering record profits. Photographer: Lisa Maree Williams/Bloomberg
Virgin Australia chairman Ryan Cotton said Australia’s second-biggest airline was days away from finalising a capital return.
Rex, best known for flying small propeller-driven aircraft between regional towns, is fast building out a new jet division plying busy domestic routes including Sydney-Melbourne.

site_title: Malaysian fast food operator QSR shelves IPO plans amid boycott campaign: sources
summary: Malaysian fast food operator QSR has indefinitely shelved plans to list on the local stock exchange due to boycott campaigns over Israel's military offensive in Gaza. The boycott, fueled by concerns over Western brands' perceived links to Israel, has affected businesses such as KFC Malaysia, which has temporarily closed outlets. QSR's IPO plans, which could have raised up to $500 million, have repeatedly stalled since 2017. The Employees Provident Fund and CVC Capital Partners have paused the sale of their combined 44% stake in QSR due to the boycott campaigns.

images.alt_text: Empty boxes and a deserted shop lot are all of what remains of a former thriving KFC outlet in Jalan Sultan, Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: Hong Kong vies with US in Bitcoin ETF market
summary: Hong Kong has launched a batch of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) investing directly in cryptocurrency, marking potential competition for US Bitcoin products. The move aims to restore Hong Kong's reputation as a modern financial center, with officials hoping the crypto pivot will attract Chinese investors. The new ETFs saw a combined $11 million in trading volume in their first session, a far cry from the US$4.6 billion in total volume recorded by US spot-Bitcoin products. Officials expect $300 million in combined first-day inflows, with possible sources including Chinese wealth parked in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Branding for Bitcoin cryptocurrency on the window of a crypto exchange kiosk in Warsaw, Poland, on Thursday, March 14, 2024. Bitcoin extended a retreat from its latest record high amid an intensifying debate about whether the bull run in cryptocurrencies is evidence of speculative froth in global markets. Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

site_title: TikTok shop tops 500,000 US sellers after 2023 e-commerce launch
summary: TikTok announced that its e-commerce platform has surpassed 500,000 US sellers, more than doubling the number from three months earlier, by the end of 2023. Worldwide, the platform had over 15 million sellers in December, with the company removing 2 million sellers for policy violations and 1 million for violating guidelines. TikTok aims to create an engaging shopping experience, and has spent over $400 million on platform safety and governance. The company faces scrutiny over its parent company's Chinese origins, with the US Congress requiring ByteDance to divest its stake in TikTok.

images.alt_text: TikTok fuels growth for more than seven million businesses in the US.

site_title: JPMorgan promotes about 150 in Asia, EMEA to managing director
summary: JPMorgan Chase has promoted approximately 150 employees in Asia and EMEA to managing director positions as part of a global promotion round. This move comes as the US banking giant continues to revamp its leadership in the region. In EMEA, women took a third of the promotions, and several key executives are leaving or retiring, including Filippo Gori and Grace Lin. The promotions are seen as a sign of the bank's efforts to address recent challenges, including lower net interest income due to deposit margin compression and lower deposit balances.

site_title: Abu Dhabi wealth fund ADQ attracts strong demand for 2-part bond issue
summary: Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund ADQ has attracted strong demand for its inaugural dollar-denominated bond sale, with an order book of nearly US$10 billion. The fund received US$78.15 billion from the Abu Dhabi government and US$39.21 billion in funding for equity investments. The bond sale, to be sold in two tranches, has price guidance of 85-90 basis points over US Treasuries for the five-year tranche and 95-100 basis points for the 10-year portion. This marks ADQ's first debt sale since 2021 and diversifies its funding sources for future acquisitions.

images.alt_text: puzzle, money, business
The Fed has yet to move, but just the expectation of far fewer rate cuts in 2024 than earlie anticipated is enough to cause bond prices to fall and yields to rise.

site_title: More than 800 Hyundai, Kia EVs in Singapore to undergo recall for electronics fault
summary: Hyundai and Kia have issued a recall for 814 electric vehicles in Singapore due to a potential electronics fault in the charging system, which may cause the vehicles to lose power. The affected models include the Hyundai Ioniq 5, Ioniq 6, and Kia EV6. The recall is a result of a global issue affecting around 170,000 Hyundai and Kia EVs in South Korea and 150,000 in the US. Owners will be notified and will undergo a free inspection and update at a workshop.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man rides a scooter past a Hyundai automobile showroom in Mumbai, India, February 9, 2022. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas//File Photo
The automaker faces lawsuits and investigations into crashes involving its Autopilot and Full Self-Driving driver-assistance systems, which are not fully autonomous.
The inflators that NHTSA is seeking to have recalled have been used in vehicles from 2000 through early 2018 produced by 12 automakers.
FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the Ford Halewood transmissions plant in Liverpool, Britain, December 1, 2022. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo

site_title: Japfa posts US$12.4 million Q1 profit, reversing from year-ago loss of US$43 million
summary: Japfa, an agri-food company, posted a US$12.4 million profit for the first quarter of 2024, reversing a US$43 million loss in the same period last year. The company's Indonesian and Vietnamese businesses drove the improvement, with higher prices, sales volumes, and lower costs contributing to the growth. Revenue grew 11.6% year-over-year to US$1.1 billion, and gross profit surged 134.9% to US$181.8 million. Japfa's operating profit also turned positive, marking an about-turn from a US$28.6 million loss in Q1 2023.

images.alt_text: 总部设在新加坡的佳发公司（Japfa）是印尼和东南亚最大的家禽生产商之一，在印尼每个月生产5000万只鸡。
Japfa says it is inappropriate to comment on matters that are not actions of the company or the board.
Japfa swung back into the black for the six months ended Dec 31, 2023, posting a net profit of US$22.8 million, compared to a net loss of US$35.9 million in the corresponding year-ago period.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx ends lower as auto giants weigh; investors parse inflation data
summary: European stocks closed lower on Tuesday, weighed down by a 4.3% drop in the automobile sector and a possible merger between Spanish banks BBVA and Sabadell. Despite this, data showed the eurozone economy rebounded in the first quarter, with inflation steadying and unemployment at record lows. The Stoxx 600 index slipped 0.7% to 504.89, nearly 14% away from its record high. Investors also assessed US monetary policy and eurozone yields ticked higher.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 0.1 per cent higher on Monday after logging its first weekly gain in four weeks on Friday.

site_title: Canada's economic growth misses estimates, boosting chances of rate cut
summary: Canada's GDP grew 0.2% in February, missing estimates, and likely remained muted in March. This data supports the Bank of Canada's consideration of lowering interest rates, which have been at a 23-year high of 5%. Economists expect the central bank to cut rates in June, citing an economic slowdown and cooling inflation. The Canadian dollar weakened, and money markets increased the odds of a rate cut in June to nearly 60%.

site_title: Huawei profit surges 564% as it eclipses Apple in China
summary: Huawei reported a net profit of 19.6 billion yuan (S$3.68 billion) in the March quarter, a 564% surge, and 37% sales growth to 178.5 billion yuan. The company's smartphone shipments rose 70% in the first quarter, surpassing Apple's iPhone sales in China, which fell 19%. Huawei's resurgence is seen as a result of its ability to sustain production of advanced semiconductors despite US sanctions, with its new Pura 70 smartphone series selling out within two days of launch.

images.alt_text: Huawei is now Beijing’s most important weapon in a battle over semiconductors that’s poised to shape the world economy for decades to come.

site_title: German unemployment rises more than expected, labour office says
summary: Germany's unemployment rate rose by 10,000 in seasonally adjusted terms in April, exceeding expectations of a 9,000 increase. The jobless rate remained unchanged at 5.9%. There were 701,000 job openings in April, 72,000 fewer than the previous year. Despite this, the labour market remains "robust," according to the Federal Labour Office.

site_title: China Evergrande to delay 2023 annual results; shares remain suspended
summary: China Evergrande Group has delayed publishing its 2023 annual results, citing a need to "ascertain the current state of affairs" as its liquidators take time to prepare financial statements. The company's shares remain suspended from trading, exceeding the required three-month deadline for preliminary annual results. The delay comes after a Hong Kong court ordered the liquidation of Evergrande, the world's most indebted developer, in January, further impacting confidence in China's fragile property market.

site_title: US reforms green law to speed clean energy, infrastructure permits
summary: The US White House has reformed the environmental review process under the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA), aiming to speed up approval of major projects such as power transmission and semiconductor manufacturing. The reforms, the second and final phase of adjustments, set clear deadlines and task agencies to coordinate the process. The changes are seen as a response to former President Trump's 2021 overhaul of NEPA, and have been praised by environmental campaigners. The reforms do not compromise the environmental and health benefits, according to the Council for Environmental Quality.

images.alt_text: Since the start of 2022, the combined number of fossil-fuel loans provided by Citizens Financial, BOK Financial, Truist Securities, Fifth Third and US Bancorp has risen more than 70 per cent on an average annualised basis.
The rule requires reporting of Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions - which cover direct emissions and those for energy purchased to run operations - when those emissions are “material,” or significant.
US households recycle just a fraction of the items they could, according to new research.

site_title: Climate philanthropy key to South-east Asia’s green transition
summary: Climate philanthropy is crucial for South-east Asia's green transition, as many regional climate projects lack commercial capital. The region needs $2.8 trillion in infrastructure financing, primarily for clean energy and climate research. Philanthropic giving can draw in private investors, especially commercial investors that wouldn't participate otherwise. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's chief sustainability officer, Gillian Tan, has urged philanthropists to contribute to blended finance, a mechanism that combines risk-tolerant investors with more private capital. Several philanthropic organizations, including the South East Asia Clean Energy Facility, aim to crowd in private investments for clean energy projects in the region.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

The report gleaned insights from 24 philanthropies, which granted more than US$3.7 billion last year, including at least US$1.9 billion to climate and nature globally and US$580 million to climate and nature in Asia.
Capital is not flowing to where it needs to be, said MAS' chief sustainability officer Gillian Tan.

site_title: Taiwan economy grows at fastest pace since 2021 on chip boom
summary: Taiwan's economy grew 6.51% in Q1, its fastest pace since 2021, driven by a boom in exports of AI-related technologies, including semiconductors and servers. GDP reached NT$5.46 trillion (S$230 billion). However, economists predict growth will slow in the coming quarters due to a higher base of comparison with last year's figures, following tepid forecasts from chip giants and a net outflow of US$4.9 billion from local shares in April.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cargo trucks work inside a container yard in Keelung, Taiwan, January 7, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Wang

site_title: Restaurant Brands tops estimates as Burger King overhaul pays off
summary: Restaurant Brands International (RBI) surpassed Wall Street expectations for quarterly results, driven by a revival in demand at Burger King and continued strength at Tim Hortons. The company's total revenue of $1.74 billion and profit beat estimates. RBI's US and Toronto-listed shares rose 1% in early trade. The company plans to invest $300 million in modernizing Burger King outlets in the US and provide incentives to top-performing operators to support outlet remodels. Quarterly comparable sales at US Burger King outlets rose 3.9%, edging past analysts' estimates.

images.alt_text: QSR announced this week that KFC Malaysia has temporarily closed outlets in the country due to challenging economic conditions, with local media reports attributing the closures to the boycott campaign.

A McDonald's is seen in Tysons, Virginia, on February 5, 2024. McDonald's reported higher quarterly profits Monday, although comparable sales growth slowed as it cited a blow from war in the Middle East. The big restaurant company, which has enjoyed robust revenues as inflation drove customers to the chain, still achieved sales increases, but not as big as inflation has moderated. Global comparable sales grew 3.4 percent in fourth quarter, down from 8.8 percent in the third quarter and below the annual average. McDonald's reported its Q4 US sales growth at 4.3%, under the 4.45% increase Wall Street anticipated. (Photo by ANDREW CABALLERO-REYNOLDS / AFP)
Empty boxes and a deserted shop lot are all of what remains of a former thriving KFC outlet in Jalan Sultan, Kuala Lumpur.
FILE PHOTO: The Burger King company logo stands on a sign outside a restaurant in Bretigny-sur-Orge, near Paris, France, July 30, 2020. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo

site_title: Lufthansa, Air France-KLM to cut costs after tough first quarter
summary: European airline groups Lufthansa and Air France-KLM reported wider first-quarter losses due to strike action, capacity limits, and cancellations, despite a recovery in travel demand since the Covid-19 lockdowns. To stem heavy losses, Lufthansa will cut operating costs, pause new projects, and increase scrutiny on administrative staffing. Air France-KLM will also tighten spending, including a freeze on hiring support staff and a vow to stabilise operations. The airlines expect strong summer demand to help recover losses, but some analysts question whether this will be enough to lift them out of their financial troubles.

images.alt_text: Airbus expects to deliver 800 passenger planes this year, up from 735 last year, but still below the 863 it delivered in 2019 before the Covid pandemic.

site_title: China says Hamas and Fatah express will for reconciliation
summary: China's foreign ministry says Hamas and Fatah have expressed a willingness to seek reconciliation through dialogue, following unity talks in Beijing. The two Palestinian groups, which have been at odds since 2007, agreed to continue talks to achieve Palestinian unity. China's efforts to promote internal unity have been met with gratitude from both sides. The development comes as Israel waits for Hamas to respond to proposals for a Gaza truce, and the US welcomes any efforts leading to stability and security in the region.

images.alt_text: Israeli officials are worried that the International Criminal Court (ICC) could issue arrest warrants against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and other top officials for alleged violations of international humanitarian law in Gaza.

A pro-Israel counter-protester walks with an Israeli flag near protesters attending a demonstration in support of Palestinians in Gaza, at UCLA in Los Angeles, California, April 28, 2024. Israel’s government has come under intense pressure from global allies to reach a ceasefire in the war that humanitarians say has brought Gaza to the brink of famine.

site_title: Sri Lanka’s key inflation rate rises to 1.5% in April
summary: Sri Lanka's key inflation rate rose to 1.5% in April, up from 0.9% in March, driven by a 2.9% increase in food prices and a 0.9% rise in non-food items. Despite this, prices remain low due to a 22% reduction in power tariffs implemented in March. Experts expect inflation to hover around 5% in the medium term, following a record high of 70% in September 2022, which was triggered by the country's financial crisis.

images.alt_text: “The country has not fully exited the crisis, there is no space available for any slippages from the committed path,” the Central Bank of Sri Lanka says.
FILE PHOTO: A worker carries a sack of vegetables at a market in Colombo, Sri Lanka June 1, 2023. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte/File Photo

site_title: Parkway Life Reit Q1 DPU up 4% to S$0.0379
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 4% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0379 for Q1 2024, driven by higher distributable income from Singapore hospitals and Japanese nursing homes. However, gross revenue and net property income declined 2.7% and 2.8% respectively due to depreciation of the Japanese yen. The Reit's interest costs increased 4.4% due to capital expenditure and higher interest costs, but are not expected to impact distributions. The company's balance sheet and capital structure remain strong, with no long-term debt refinancing needed until March 2025.

images.alt_text: The research team continues to like the Reit for its strong earnings visibility.

DPL Kawasaki Yako in Japan is among the properties in Daiwa House Logistics Trust's portfolio. The Reit could be affected by Japan's recent interest rate hike, given that all its loans are in Japanese yen, says one analyst.
Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks over the five trading sessions through to Feb 8.

site_title: Strained Chinese cities struggle to pay home-buying subsidies
summary: China's real estate downturn is affecting cities' ability to lease land to developers, a key revenue source. Homebuyers in cities like Weifang, Zibo, Shangqiu, and Zigong are struggling to receive subsidies promised by authorities, including 100,000 yuan in Weifang. The delay in subsidy payments may delay the property market's recovery, with households perceiving local governments as cash-strapped. The issue has been raised by 150 people across 50 cities, with officials citing Covid-19, economic downturn, and tax cuts as reasons for the delays.

images.alt_text: China will “make flexible use” of tools to step up support for the economy and lower overall borrowing costs, a meeting of the 24-member decision-making body led by President Xi Jinping agreed.
Many Chinese property developers have defaulted since the sector slipped into a debt crisis in mid-2021.
State-backed Vanke is China’s second-biggest property developer by sales and is facing short-term liquidity pressures and operational difficulties.
Vanke, the country’s second-largest developer by sales last year, has seen its stock and bonds slide over concerns about its financial condition.
Shenzhen-based Kaisa has been working on an offshore debt restructuring for two years after defaulting on its US$12 billion of offshore debt in late 2021.
Cifi’s proposal comes at a time when many Chinese developers are still struggling with rising debt as property sales in China remain sluggish.
This is the second time for Country Garden to stretch payments on the three bonds, which were issued by its main onshore unit.
The average coupon in April on new debt fell to just 2.83 per cent – the lowest level in data going back to 1999.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals rise for sixth month to highest since 2022
summary: UK mortgage approvals rose for the sixth consecutive month, with 61,325 home loans authorized in March, the most since September 2022. This marks a continuation of the housing market recovery, driven by a brighter economic outlook and increased affordability. However, a recent increase in borrowing costs has raised questions about the sustainability of the recovery, with mortgage rates now averaging 5.9% for a two-year fixed-rate mortgage. Economists had expected a slight increase in mortgage approvals, but the actual figure exceeded forecasts.

images.alt_text: The highest interest rates in 16 years and a surge in inflation over the past two years has drained consumer finances.
The Bank of England’s credit conditions survey published on Thursday (Apr 11) showed that lenders increased the availability of home loans in the first quarter after a rise in demand from borrowers.
Two stalled sales in London’s office market are a sign of its stultified nature, amid higher interest rates and concerns around a trend towards hybrid working.
For London's prime properties, which account for the top 10 per cent of rents, rates are forecast to grow by 2.9 per cent this year.
Almost half of UK house hunters are set to accelerate their purchase plans this year to beat any potential rebound in prices.

site_title: Walmart to shut all health centers in US over lack of profitability
summary: Walmart plans to close all 51 of its US health centers and shut its virtual health care operations within 30-90 days due to lack of profitability. The company cited increasing labor and operating costs, as well as reimbursement challenges from insurers and payers. Walmart will instead focus on its existing pharmacies and Vision Centers, which offer similar services. This decision reverses plans to nearly double US health center locations in 2024, and comes as other retailers, such as Walgreens and Amazon, have also faced challenges in providing healthcare services.

images.alt_text: Ibotta, whose investors include Walmart, will disclose proposed terms for its initial public offering (IPO) in a later filing.

(FILES) A shopper pushes a cart through the parking lot of a Walmart on the morning of Black Friday in Wilmington, Delaware, on November 25, 2022. Walmart raised its full-year forecast on August 17, 2023, following a jump in quarterly profits, pointing to solid increases at US stores and e-commerce. The big retailer, which has been seen as well positioned amid inflation because of its reputation for value, enjoyed another quarter of growing sales. (Photo by Samuel Corum / AFP)
The talks come at a time Walmart is increasingly monetising its reach and troves of shopper data to sell ads on its properties.

site_title: Amazon results beat estimates, revenue forecast misses
summary: Amazon reported quarterly results above Wall Street's expectations, driven by growth in cloud-computing and artificial intelligence. The company's revenue forecast for the current quarter came in below expectations, but it still beat analyst estimates. Amazon's cloud-computing revenue rose 17% to $25 billion, while its AI efforts are expected to increase capital spending. The company's shares rose less than 2% after the report, despite a 3.3% drop in the regular session. Amazon's net income more than tripled to $10.4 billion, and its advertising business helped drive results.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Microsoft offices in Issy-les-Moulineaux near Paris, France, February 9, 2024. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo

Galena the cat travelled to California from Utah in an Amazon box. Its owner Carrie lark says she thinks that Galena got into the box while her husband was packing up some returns, by jumping inside when he left to fetch some tape to seal it up.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts upgrade iFast’s rating on higher growth expectations
summary: Analysts CGS International and DBS Group Research have upgraded their ratings on iFast Corporation, citing stronger growth expectations driven by the company's ePension division. The upgrades result in price targets of S$9.10 and S$9.57, respectively, with DBS Group Research attributing the increase to a lower weighted average cost of capital. Analysts project improving sequential net profit growth and a higher return on equity ratio, with the ePension division seen as a key growth driver for the company.

images.alt_text: Lim Chung Chun, chairman and chief executive of iFast Corporation. The group expects to see “robust” growth rates in revenues and profitability overall in 2024, as compared to 2023.
iFast is trading significantly higher on Thursday morning after reporting a surge in its fourth quarter net profit.
Lim Chung Chun, chairman and chief executive of iFast. The group expects to see "robust growth rates" in revenue and profitability in 2024.
iFast's third-quarter results released on Wednesday beat the research team’s expectations.

site_title: Tesla axes most of Supercharger team in blow to other automakers
summary: Tesla has eliminated nearly its entire Supercharger organization, a move that will slow the growth of its vast network of public charging stations. The decision, made by CEO Elon Musk, comes after a 10% staff cut in mid-April and affects Rivian, Ford, and other automakers that rely on Tesla's charging infrastructure. The job cuts leave executives at these companies confused and concerned, particularly as they prepare for the busy summer driving season.

images.alt_text: Rival Chinese automakers and suppliers such as Xpeng and Huawei Technologies have been seeking to gain an advantage over Tesla by rolling out similar software.

site_title: The demise of Scottish nationalism is a boost for the UK’s future
summary: Scotland's First Minister Humza Yousaf has resigned, marking the end of the Scottish National Party's (SNP) nearly two-decade rule. This development is seen as a boost to the UK's future, as Scottish independence would damage the country's standing on the world stage. Losing the Scottish tax base and UK's overseas aid budget would make it harder for the UK to meet its new defense spending plan. The UK's voice in international forums, including the UN, would also be eroded. A new administration is expected to take over, with an election to be held in 2024 or 2026, potentially paving the way for a more stable future for the UK.

images.alt_text: Scotland's First Minister Humza Yousaf said he was quitting as head of the pro-independence Scottish National Party (SNP) and first minister of Scotland’s devolved government after a week of chaos triggered by his scrapping of a coalition agreement with Scotland’s Greens.

British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak speaks during Prime Minister's Questions, at the House of Commons in London, Britain, January 10, 2024. UK Parliament/Jessica Taylor/Handout via REUTERS THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. MANDATORY CREDIT. IMAGE MUST NOT BE ALTERED.
The number of Leave voters from 2016 who now think Brexit was a mistake has hit the highest level so far, at 22 per cent, according to a YouGov opinion poll.

site_title: L'Occitane's billionaire owner Geiger to take firm private in US$1.8 billion deal
summary: L'Occitane International, a Hong Kong-listed skin-care firm, is to be taken private by its billionaire owner Reinold Geiger in a US$1.8 billion deal. Geiger's investment holding company, L'Occitane Groupe, will pay HK$34 for each share not already owned, representing a 15.3% premium to the stock's last close. The deal values the company at US$6.4 billion and comes as several Hong Kong-listed companies explore take-private options due to market volatility.

images.alt_text: The private equity firm has been considering a bid for L’Occitane and has conducted preliminary due diligence.

site_title: WHO warns of bird flu risk spreading to cows outside US
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned of a risk of the H5N1 bird flu virus spreading to cows in other countries through migratory birds. Despite deeming the public health risk low, the agency urges vigilance. The virus has been confirmed in 34 dairy cattle herds in nine US states and one person in Texas. The WHO praises the US for sharing the virus genetic sequence early, enabling global monitoring and preparedness measures.

images.alt_text: Cows in an open field near Tavis Air Force Base in Solano County, Calif., on Aug. 24, 2023. A company called Flannery Associates has been purchasing large amounts of land in the area. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

site_title: Hong Kong’s negative equity mortgage cases rise to 20-year high
summary: Hong Kong's negative equity mortgage cases rose 27% in the first quarter to a 20-year high, reaching 32,073 cases valued at HK$165.3 billion, according to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority. This represents a 20% decline from their 2021 peak due to higher mortgage rates, talent outflow, and a weak market outlook. Despite this, mortgage delinquency ratio remained unchanged at 0.09%. Property prices dropped 1.8% in the January-to-March quarter.

site_title: Glencore now sees FY trading division profit between US$3 billion-US$3.5 billion
summary: Glencore expects its trading division profit to be between $3 billion and $3.5 billion for the full year, at the top end of its long-term guidance. The miner's copper production fell 2% in the first quarter to 239,700 metric tons. Despite a potential copper shortage and rising prices, Glencore left its production forecast unchanged. Copper consumption is expected to rise as economies shift to renewable energy and electric vehicles. Glencore's trading division will benefit from a high commodity price environment, but its main competitor BHP is considering an improved bid for Anglo American, which could impact copper prices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of commodities trader Glencore is pictured in front of the company's headquarters in Baar, Switzerland, July 18, 2017.  REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Samba, Gazelle shoes help drive Adidas sales while North America lags
summary: Adidas reported a strong first-quarter result, driven by 14% sales growth in Europe and 8% in China, thanks to the popularity of its "terrace" shoes such as Samba and Gazelle. However, North America sales declined 4% year-on-year due to excess stock and price cuts. The company's gross margin increased by 6.4 percentage points to 51.2%, and CEO Bjorn Gulden stated that the lifestyle business is driving sales, with demand for terrace shoes still growing.

images.alt_text: Adidas sales growth is being driven by strong demand momentum in “terrace” retro styles, such as Samba, Gazelle and Campus, as well as strength in performance categories.

site_title: Yen falls after suspected intervention on Monday; eyes on Fed
summary: The Japanese yen dropped 0.35% to 156.90 per dollar on Tuesday, reversing its sharp gains from Monday, which were attributed to suspected intervention by Japanese authorities. The currency briefly fell to 156.50 before recovering. Japanese officials may have spent around $35.05 billion supporting the currency on Monday. The Bank of Japan left its monthly bond-buying plan unchanged for May, and the US Federal Reserve is expected to hold interest rates steady in its upcoming meeting. The dollar strengthened against a basket of currencies, while the euro and Chinese yuan also saw declines.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Japanese Yen and U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Stellantis misses forecasts with 12% revenue drop in Q1, sees stronger H2
summary: Stellantis' net revenue fell 12% to 41.7 billion euros in Q1, missing analyst expectations. The company cited lower volumes, an unfavourable product mix, and foreign exchange dynamics as factors. However, CFO Natalie Knight expressed confidence in the company's new model roll-out plan, which includes 18 electric vehicles, and expects a double-digit margin on adjusted operating income and positive industrial free cash flow in 2024.

images.alt_text: Stellantis says the agreements are on a strictly voluntary basis, and mostly aimed at employees close to retirement age or willing to take new professional opportunities.
Stellantis said last year it was buying a 21 per cent stake in Leapmotor in a US$1.6 billion deal that would give it a fresh shot at China.
Under that deal, Stellantis would have exclusive rights to build, export and sell Leapmotor products outside China, a first for a legacy Western automaker.
FILE PHOTO: People attend a Stellantis presentation at the New York International Auto Show, in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., April 5, 2023. REUTERS/David 'Dee' Delgado/File Photo

site_title: US consumer confidence at lowest level since 2022
summary: US consumer confidence fell to 97.0 in April, its lowest level since July 2022, due to concerns about the labour market and future business conditions. The index dropped below the anticipated 104.0 reading, marking the third straight month of decline. Consumers are worried about elevated price levels, especially for food and gas, and job availability. Despite this, optimism about the present situation continues to outweigh concerns, but a deteriorating trend in sentiment could persist, potentially slowing spending and growth.

images.alt_text: Shoppers carry Uniqlo bags in the SoHo neighborhood of New York, US, on Friday, March 8, 2024. The US Census Bureau is scheduled to release retail sales figures on March 14. Photographer: John Taggart/Bloomberg

site_title: Thai economic growth slows in March due to soft demand, tourism
summary: Thailand's economic growth slowed in March due to weaker demand and tourism, expanding about 1% on a quarterly and annual basis. The Bank of Thailand maintained its full-year growth outlook of 2.6%, citing a high base from 2023 and constraints on spending. Exports fell 10.2% year-over-year, while imports rose 5.2%. The central bank expects volatility in the baht to decrease, but may weaken further in the second quarter. Thailand's finance ministry revised its growth forecast to 2.4% for this year, but still expects 3.3% if a stimulus plan is deployed in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Thai finance ministry said the economy was still stable despite the downward revision, and said disbursement of the recently approved fiscal budget would help drive growth.

Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin speaks during a presser regarding the government’s proposed 10,000 baht digital wallet scheme at Government House in Bangkok on April 10, 2024. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

The policy received Cabinet approval on Tuesday, clearing another hurdle for the government to roll out the stimulus plan, which would give 10,000 baht to each of 50 million Thais to spend in their communities in a six month period.
The Bank of Thailand left its key interest rate unchanged for a third straight meeting on April 10.

site_title: Microsoft to invest US$1.7 billion in cloud, AI in Indonesia: CEO
summary: Microsoft is investing $1.7 billion in Indonesia over four years to enhance its cloud computing and AI infrastructure, supporting the country's digital transformation efforts. The investment, led by CEO Satya Nadella, aims to develop cutting-edge AI infrastructure, providing a platform for developers to train their AI models. Microsoft will also expand its digital training programs to provide AI skills to 2.5 million people in South-east Asia, including 840,000 in Indonesia, by 2025.

images.alt_text: Across the US, utilities are preparing for historic increases in electricity demand led by data centres and AI.
Microsoft chief executive officer Satya Nadella says: “Artificial intelligence is the most transformative technology of our time, and we must ensure it is deployed safely and responsibly.”
Systems based on AI have the potential to revolutionise industries from healthcare to logistics, but replacing human judgment with machine learning carries risks.
With the losses on Thursday, Meta has erased more than US$170 billion in market capitalisation.
Microsoft said sales in the January to March period rose by 17 per cent from a year earlier to US$61.9 billion, with net profit up by 20 per cent to US$21.9 billion.

(FILES) This photograph taken in Mulhouse, eastern France on October 19, 2023, shows the logo of the social media video sharing app Tik Tok reflected in mirrors. The US Senate on Tuesday approved legislation requiring the wildly popular social media app TikTok to be divested from its Chinese parent company ByteDance or be shut out of the American market. The measure was part of a $95 billion foreign aid package, including military assistance to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan, which has now cleared Congress and heads to President Joe Biden's desk. (Photo by SEBASTIEN BOZON / AFP)
LSEG said total income, excluding recoveries, in the first quarter was £2.089 billion (S$3.6 billion), with gross profit of £1.893 billion.
Meta’s latest technology is being rolled out in more than a dozen English-speaking countries, including Australia, Canada, Singapore and the United States.
FILE PHOTO: Microsoft offices in Issy-les-Moulineaux near Paris, France, February 9, 2024. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo

site_title: Fast-fashion giant Shein wants to sell skincare, toothpaste and toys, too
summary: Fast-fashion giant Shein is expanding its platform to sell a wide range of products, including skincare, toothpaste, and toys, to build credibility and compete with Amazon. The company has already partnered with brands such as Colgate-Palmolive and Hasbro and has a marketplace in nine European countries, with plans for a stock market listing later this year. Shein aims to attract well-known Western brands to endorse its platform and compete with Amazon and AliExpress.

images.alt_text: From the end of August, Shein will have to apply the tougher rules under the Digital Services Act (DSA).
Shein has successfully penetrated a global market that spans over 150 countries, but concerns have been raised about its business practices and ethics.
What sets Shein apart from rivals is a hyper-efficient supply chain and product development process, analysts say.
Shein is seeking Beijing’s nod to go public in a listing that will likely face tough scrutiny from US regulators.

site_title: Abandoned seafarers: an unacceptable face of the shipping industry
summary: A significant rise in abandonment cases has been reported on the IMO and ILO abandonment database, with 142 new cases in 2023, up from 109 in 2022 and 85 in 2020. Abandoned seafarers often face unpaid wages, lack of basic necessities, and medical care. The IMO has established a task force to review and update the abandonment database, while the International Transport Workers Federation (ITF) has reported over $12 million in unpaid wages owed to crew members. The ITF attributes the rise to unscrupulous shipowners, shell companies, and ineffective flag states, with some flag states linked to the "shadow fleet" operating outside regulations.

images.alt_text: The IMO has so far not addressed the possibility of offsetting greenhouse gas emissions from ships with carbon capture ashore.

site_title: AIA launches wealth centre targeting high-net-worth clients
summary: AIA Singapore has launched a wealth centre at Six Battery Road, targeting high-net-worth (HNW) clients with a one-stop hub offering wealth management services. The centre provides access to experts in legal, tax, and trusts, aiming to attract wealth across Asia to Singapore. The move is seen as a strategic focus to bolster the country's position as a premier financial centre, leveraging its advanced infrastructure and regulatory framework. The centre's launch is in response to the projected surge in Asia's affluent population.

site_title: Bank of Japan upbeat on consumption, service price outlook
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) released its quarterly outlook report, expressing optimism about Japan's economy, citing rising service prices and wage hikes that will boost household income. The BOJ expects household spending to increase gradually, with inflation staying near its 2% target in the next three years. The central bank's governor, Kazuo Ueda, stated that sustained wage gains must translate into higher service prices for inflation to durably hit its target. This suggests the BOJ may hike rates later this year, although the timing is uncertain.

images.alt_text: The latest outlook, coming after a series of disappointingly high inflation readings in the US along with better-than-anticipated economic activity, is revamping the investment landscape.
As widely expected, the Bank of Japan maintained its short-term interest rate target at a range of 0-0.1 per cent in a unanimous vote.
The core consumer price index in Tokyo, a leading indicator of nationwide figures, increased 1.6 per cent in April from a year earlier, slowing from a 2.4 per cent gain in March.
Early on Friday, one dollar bought 155.58 yen, compared with 155.74 the previous day - a level not seen since 1990.

Service price moves are closely watched by the Bank of Japan as a key indicator of whether wages and inflation are rising in tandem, which it set as one of the prerequisites for raising interest rates.
Governor Ueda has not ruled out responding to exchange rates with a policy move if the impact on prices is seen to be “non-negligible”.

site_title: The Fed’s quantitative easing programme has cost too much
summary: The US Federal Reserve's quantitative easing programme, which aimed to stimulate the economy, has been deemed too costly, with estimated losses potentially exceeding $500 billion. The programme, which included buying Treasury and mortgage securities, had benefits such as lowering long-term interest rates and providing economic stimulus, but also led to overstimulating the housing market, contributing to regional banking turmoil, and incurring significant interest expenses. The Fed's prolonged asset purchases, slow phase-out, and delayed rate hikes are identified as key mistakes that drove up costs, and officials are advised to learn from these mistakes in the review of next year's monetary policy framework.

images.alt_text: The latest outlook, coming after a series of disappointingly high inflation readings in the US along with better-than-anticipated economic activity, is revamping the investment landscape.

US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell’s remarks, the most explicit so far about plans to slow a process that has seen about US$1.4 trillion of bonds roll off the Fed‘s balance sheet, was seen by several Wall Street analysts as a signal that a tapering plan will be unveiled as early as the Fed‘s next meeting on April 30-May 1.

site_title: Brokers’ take: KGI initiates Winking Studios with ‘outperform’, S$0.34 target price
summary: KGI Securities has initiated coverage on Winking Studios with an "outperform" rating and a target price of S$0.34, citing robust performance growth in FY2023. Analyst Alyssa Tee expects revenue growth to continue, driven by the gaming market and inorganic expansion plans. Gross profit margins are also seen as a positive indicator of operational efficiency and profitability. Despite increased operating expenses, Tee remains optimistic about the company's financial health and strategic trajectory.

images.alt_text: UOBKH expects Winking Studios to ride on the booming game art outsourcing industry.
The acquisition is in line with Winking Studios' business strategy.
Johnny Jan, chief executive and executive chairman of Winking Studios, says it is the first gaming-related company to list on the SGX.

Winking’s chairman and CEO Johnny Jan said: “We believe our status as a Singapore-listed company elevates our profile on the world stage, enhances our brand equity and provides us greater leverage to expand our geographical footprint and seize a larger market share.”

site_title: Oil eases on higher US crude output, hopes of Israel-Hamas ceasefire
summary: US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 0.9% to $81.93, extending losses from Monday, due to rising US crude production and hopes of an Israel-Hamas ceasefire. Brent crude futures for June settled down 0.6% to $87.86, while the July contract fell 0.9% to $86.33. Oil prices eased after a 1% drop on Tuesday, amid expectations of a potential ceasefire.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for June settled at US$88.40 a barrel, falling US$1.10, or 1.2 per cent.

site_title: Turning today’s challenges into opportunities
summary: Investors can navigate current market challenges by adopting a dual strategy of defense and offense. A diversified, all-weather portfolio serves as a defensive anchor, while targeted, opportunistic investments can exploit market dislocations. Key opportunities include: 1) buying euro-denominated investment grade bonds due to a potential earlier European rate cut cycle; 2) hedging against inflation and geopolitical tensions with US Treasury inflation-protected bonds and US energy stocks; 3) investing in US equities with a focus on communication services and technology; 4) India large-cap equities with a mid-teens earnings growth expectation; and 5) China non-financial high-yield state-owned enterprises with attractive dividend yields and low valuations.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., April 25, 2024. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

If Powell pivots yet again during Wednesday’s press conference and cancels rate-cut plans, or worse, hints that the central bank may have to return to its hiking ways to nip inflation in the bud, there will be more blood shed in the stock market.

site_title: Prudential’s Q1 new business profit down 2% at S$743 million
summary: Prudential Singapore reported a Q1 new business profit of S$743 million, down 2% from the same period last year. Annual premium equivalent sales rose 4% to S$1.63 billion. Despite strong sales in Hong Kong, the company's Chinese mainland joint venture CPL saw a 17% decline in Q1 APE sales. However, Prudential highlighted continued business momentum, with growth in markets such as Thailand, Taiwan, and Africa, and a 28% increase in APE sales in these segments. CEO Anil Wadhwani said Q1 results provide a "sound base" for FY2024 new business growth.

images.alt_text: Lin Yong, chief executive of Haitong International Securities Group at the company's Singapore office which opened on 22 January 2014. Located at Prudential Tower in Cecil Street, the Singapore unit has a start-up capital of $5 million.

Photo Service 'Best of the Week': Skyscrapers including 20 Fenchurch Street, also known as the "Walkie-Talkie," left, stand on the skyline of the City of London with Tower 42, the Leadenhall building, also known as the "Cheesegrater," center, and 30 St Mary Axe, also known as 'the Gherkin,' right, in London, U.K., on Wednesday, March 5, 2014. U.K. stocks declined, after the FTSE 100 Index posted its biggest rally in eight months, as investors awaited data on jobs and services from the U.S. Photographer: Matthew Lloyd/Bloomberg

Digital innovation will further fuel cross-border and cross-sectoral financial interconnections, requiring collaboration among central banks and regulators to achieve an appropriate regulatory baseline to oversee the use of AI and ML, Bank of Spain governor Pablo Hernandez de Cos says.
Singapore office demand has stayed relatively resilient in recent years but some tenants are now paring space in the CBD to save costs.
The ECB has grown increasingly active in its efforts to get lenders to treat ESG risks – particularly climate change – as financially material.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit posts 10.2% drop in indicative Q1 DPU to 3.505 euro cents
summary: Cromwell E-Reit posted a 10.2% drop in indicative Q1 DPU to 3.505 euro cents, citing higher finance costs due to higher interest rates. Income available for distribution fell 10.2% to 19.7 million euros, with gross revenue and net property income also down year on year. The Reit remains ahead in its disposal programme, with its net gearing at 39.7% and no debt maturing until November 2025.

images.alt_text: Grandinkulma, located in Vantaa, Finland, is one of two properties divested by Cromwell E-Reit.
Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust is now left with five office assets in Poland.
Cromwell E-Reit's distribution will be paid on Mar 28 after record date on Mar 5.
Artist's impression of Via Nervesa 21 in Milan, Italy, after redevelopment. The property is now largely completed, says Cromwell European Reit's manager.
Cromwell European Reit's Haagse Poort office building. Declines across the Reit’s overall portfolio value as at end-2023 largely comes from its office assets.

site_title: Google to pay up to US$6 million to News Corp for new AI content, The Information reports
summary: Google will pay News Corp up to US$6 million annually for developing new AI-related content and products, as part of a longstanding partnership. The agreement aims to license archived content for training chatbots, similar to deals between OpenAI and other news publishers. A News Corp spokesperson denied an existing AI content licensing deal with Google, while Google did not comment on the arrangement. This partnership highlights the growing importance of AI content in the media industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo for Google LLC is seen at their office in Manhattan, New York City, New York, U.S., November 17, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Five-room resale flat in Bukit Merah goes for record S$1.59 million
summary: A five-room resale flat in Bukit Merah's Tiong Bahru View project has sold for a record S$1.59 million, surpassing the previous record of S$1.569 million set in January 2024. The 112-square-metre flat has a 99-year lease commencing from January 2016 and is located on the 35th floor of block 9B Boon Tiong Road. The transaction, facilitated by PropNex Realty, indicates a continued increase in million-dollar resale flats in Singapore, with 43 HDB flats in Tiong Bahru View sold for at least S$1 million since July 2018.

images.alt_text: Condominiums and HDB flats as viewed from CapitaSpring on Feb 9, 2022.
The number of HDB flats changing hands in March falls 3.3 per cent.
HDB observes resale prices showing signs of stabilising.
Luqman Hakim, chief data and analytics officer at 99.co, says the price growth in February 2024 is "much more modest" compared to the previous month.

site_title: Dying salmon trouble Norway’s vast fish-farm industry
summary: Norway's massive fish-farm industry is struggling due to a record 16.7% mortality rate among its 63 million salmon, resulting in nearly $2 billion in lost income. Some dead or ill fish are being sold to consumers, often labeled as "superior," despite concerns over animal welfare and the industry's image. Experts blame aggressive industrialization, inadequate spacing, and new technology for the issue, with the industry aiming to halve mortality rates by 2030.

images.alt_text: Picture taken on May 27, 2019 show dead salmon floating in the water at the Mortenlaks fish farm at Rinoya Island in Lodingen, Northern Norway. They're hailed for their omega-3 fatty acids and micronutrients, but Norway's famed salmon are not in the best of health themselves at the fish farms where they are bred. Almost 63 million salmon -- a record -- died prematurely last year in the large underwater sea pens that dot the fjords of Norway, the world's biggest producer of Atlantic salmon. (Photo by Berit Roald / NTB / AFP) / Norway OUT / TO GO WITH AFP STORY by Pierre-Henry DESHAYES

site_title: Mercedes earnings drop on model changeovers, EV slump
summary: Mercedes-Benz reported a 34% drop in adjusted group earnings before interest and tax to 3.6 billion euros in the first quarter, due to model changes and sluggish demand for electric vehicles. The company attributed the decline to high costs of model upgrades and supply bottlenecks affecting production of its GLC and E-Class vehicles. Despite this, Mercedes expects sales to increase in the coming quarters, with the share of its most expensive vehicles rising in the second half of the year, particularly in China and the US.

images.alt_text: The logo of Mercedes-Benz is seen outside a Mercedes-Benz car dealer in Brussels, Belgium June 1, 2023. REUTERS/Yves Herman

site_title: Asia’s first spot Bitcoin and Ether ETFs gain in Hong Kong debut
summary: Hong Kong has launched its first spot Bitcoin and Ether exchange-traded funds (ETFs), marking the first launch in Asia. The three Bitcoin ETFs gained over 2% in their debut, while the three Ether ETFs were largely flat. The launches come three months after the US introduced its first spot Bitcoin ETFs. Hong Kong's debut is seen as a milestone in the city's ETF market, but regulators have warned of the risks associated with cryptocurrency investments.

images.alt_text: The level of demand for the funds will provide clues on whether Hong Kong’s push for a tightly regulated digital asset hub is gaining traction.
The applications come in the wake of the US$53 billion amassed by US Bitcoin ETFs this year, including offerings from BlackRock and Fidelity Investments.

Hong Kong is set to be Asia’s first to accept cryptocurrency products as a mainstream investment tool, and the products have also received official regulatory approval from the Securities and Futures Commission.
Hong Kong already permits crypto-futures based ETFs and three have listed so far:

site_title: Ninja Van axes more than 20 employees in tech team in Singapore
summary: Ninja Van, a Singapore-based third-party logistics platform, laid off approximately 21 employees, about 10% of its tech team, as a cost-cutting measure. The affected employees, who represented 20% of the tech team, were offered a month's salary for every year of service. The layoffs were the result of cost optimisation efforts to ensure sustainable growth, with the company continuing to support the retrenched employees through a reasonable severance package and job placement support.

images.alt_text: As layoffs rip through Lazada, communication between the company the those that remain have been non-existent.
The takeover of Tokopedia by TikTok has renewed the e-commerce battle in Indonesia, widely seen as the crown jewel of the region.
ShopBack's Singapore headquarters in Pasir Panjang. The company is cutting 195 employees “to become more focused and self-sustainable as a company”.
Cold-chain ticked the boxes of higher margins and mass market opportunities said Lai Chang Wen, CEO and co-founder of Ninja Van

site_title: HSBC CEO to retire; bank reports 1.7% lower Q1 profit of US$10.8 billion
summary: HSBC's CEO Noel Quinn is retiring after nearly five years, with the bank's board beginning a formal search for his successor. Quinn will remain available until the end of his 12-month notice period in April 2025. The bank reported a Q1 profit of US$10.8 billion, down 1.7% from the same period last year, driven by higher revenue and a one-off gain on disposal. Operating expenses grew 6.9% year-over-year, and the bank announced a share buyback program of up to US$30 billion.

images.alt_text: The court ruled that while investors had suffered significant losses, they couldn’t assert that HSBC and its bankers had acted dishonestly.
FILE PHOTO: A logo of HSBC is seen on its headquarters at the financial Central district in Hong Kong, China August 4, 2020. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo
China’s economic growth remains strong relative to other nations, and its wealthy citizens are focused on overseas investments, Michael Roberts, HSBCs CEO for the USA and Americas says.
Banks in Hong Kong have been tightening their wallets, leaving a gap that private equity has been happy to fill.
Goldman’s first-quarter results included rising net income as traders scored a windfall, with its return on equity improving.

Dr Amy Khor, Senior Minister of State for Sustainability and the Environment; Mr Wong Kee Joo, Chief Executive Officer, HSBC; and Prof Jeff Obbard, NYAA Climate Change Advisor,
moderated by Asst Prof Goh Jing Rong, Singapore Management University.
Global financial firms have been cutting investment banking staff in Asia due to a deal drought amid deteriorating US-China relations.

site_title: Biden’s ‘worker-centred trade policy’ involves building ‘tripartism’: US trade chief
summary: US Trade Representative Katherine Tai says the Biden administration's "worker-centred trade policy" aims to address the needs of everyday people, regardless of their location or education level. This approach involves building "tripartism" within the US system, where the government, employers, and employees collaborate to make economic policy. Tai drew inspiration from Singapore's unique model of tripartism, where the government, employers, and workers work together to make decisions. The goal is to make trade work "without pitting parts of our economies against each other".

images.alt_text: The success of the US-Singapore FTA demonstrates how countries can benefit from an open, inclusive, rules-based multilateral trading order, said Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong.
Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong will make an official visit to the US and Canada from Apr 28 to May 3.

site_title: Blackstone in talks to buy Dulwich schools in Singapore, Seoul for US$600 million
summary: Blackstone is in talks to acquire Dulwich College International's Asian assets, including schools in Singapore and South Korea, for approximately US$600 million. The deal, pending final valuation and terms, would not include schools in China. If successful, Blackstone plans to expand Dulwich's presence in the Middle East and potentially other South-east Asian countries. This acquisition marks the latest move by a buyout firm in the education sector, following a trend of British schools expanding overseas.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A headset is seen in front of displayed Hipgnosis logo in this illustration taken, June 28, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the Blackstone Group headquarters in New York City, U.S., January 18, 2023. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon/File Photo
Last year, Crown Resorts agreed to pay a A$450 million (S$395.7 million) fine for breaking anti-money laundering laws.

Hipgnosis - co-founded in 2018 by legendary guitarist and producer Nile Rodgers and Merck Mercuriadis, the former manager of Beyonce and Elton John - manages the rights to more than 150 of the world’s biggest song catalogues.

site_title: Starbucks points to weaker consumer as profit falls
summary: Starbucks reported a 15% decline in profits to $772.4 million in the quarter ending March 31, citing weaker consumer sentiment and a deteriorating economic outlook in China. Comparable sales in North America fell 3%, while those in China plummeted 11%. The company attributes the decline to a "more cautious consumer," particularly those who initiate digital orders but do not follow through. Starbucks aims to improve communication systems to address this issue, with a plan to better inform consumers about the status of online orders.

images.alt_text: Members of the Starbucks Workers Union and other labour organisations hold a rally outside a company-owned Starbucks store in New York City, US, Nov 16, 2023.

site_title: Hong Kong team plants seeds to safeguard legacy grains
summary: Scientists and farmers in Hong Kong are reviving dormant rice varieties that once grew in the region, with the goal of improving food security in the face of climate change. Researchers have planted seeds from the International Rice Research Institute and the US Department of Agriculture, which were deposited in the Philippines decades ago. The project aims to preserve Hong Kong's agricultural heritage and potentially produce locally grown grains for the city's 7.5 million population.

images.alt_text: The level of demand for the funds will provide clues on whether Hong Kong’s push for a tightly regulated digital asset hub is gaining traction.

Hong Kong is set to be Asia’s first to accept cryptocurrency products as a mainstream investment tool, and the products have also received official regulatory approval from the Securities and Futures Commission.
Banks in Hong Kong have been tightening their wallets, leaving a gap that private equity has been happy to fill.
Soaring construction costs and falling valuations have upended developers’ appraisals of new projects, forcing some to reconsider.

site_title: China Vanke’s first public commercial Reit falls in early trade on debut
summary: China Vanke's first public commercial real estate investment trust (Reit) fell as much as 3% in early trade on its debut, reflecting caution towards the second-largest property developer amid a prolonged property market downturn. The CICC-SCPG Consumption Infrastructure Reit, backed by shopping centers owned by Vanke, raised around 3.3 billion yuan but still faces short-term liquidity pressures. Vanke's shares have slumped 28% since the start of the year, and its total cash position can only support 15 months of cash outflow.

images.alt_text: Vanke, the country’s second-largest developer by sales last year, has seen its stock and bonds slide over concerns about its financial condition.
China Vanke’s long-term corporate family rating was downgraded by Moody’s to Ba3, from Ba1, on Friday.

Signage for China Vanke Co. in Shenzhen, China, on Monday, April 15, 2024. Vanke shares rose the most in more than a month after the state-backed builder said it has made plans to resolve liquidity pressure. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Vanke has recently been hit by various market rumours and controversies involving a local partner.

site_title: Bangkok airports set for US$4.8 billion expansion as tourism booms
summary: Bangkok's two main airports, operated by Airports of Thailand, plan to spend $4.8 billion to expand capacity by the end of the decade, aiming to increase annual capacity to 135 million travelers. The expansion includes two new runways, a new terminal, and renovations at Don Mueang airport. The project will help Thailand cope with a surge in post-pandemic tourism, which is expected to reach 35-40 million foreign tourists this year. The expansion is expected to more than double net income to 21 billion baht by the end of the fiscal year.

images.alt_text: Thai finance ministry said the economy was still stable despite the downward revision, and said disbursement of the recently approved fiscal budget would help drive growth.

People were advised to stay in the shade and avoid working for long hours under the sun. Deaths related to heat have risen to about 30 nationwide this year, according to the Ministry of Public Health.

Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin speaks during a presser regarding the government’s proposed 10,000 baht digital wallet scheme at Government House in Bangkok on April 10, 2024. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

site_title: Huawei’s pivotal role in the US-China tech war, from 5G to chips
summary: The US-China tech war has shifted focus to semiconductors, with Huawei emerging as Beijing's key weapon. Despite US sanctions, Huawei has rebounded, becoming dominant in China's vast domestic market. The company is now developing its own chips, with a 7-nanometre chip in its Mate 60 Pro smartphone. Huawei's ambitions extend beyond hardware, with its homegrown operating system HarmonyOS connected to over 800 million devices. The US is deliberating ways to co-opt allies and explore additional sanctions on Huawei and its Chinese partners.

images.alt_text: Visitors look at screens that demonstrate Huawei's intelligent driving software Qiankun.
Huawei has enjoyed a resurgence since the Mate’s August debut.
On Tuesday, Huawei unveiled the S9 sedan, the first model under the premium Stelato brand it launched with Baic.
The Biden administration is considering blacklisting Chinese companies it suspects could make chips for Huawei.
The Pro and Ultra versions were out of stock at Huawei’s official online store just a minute after the sales started.

site_title: Dubai ruler’s firm refinances US$8.2 billion to tap property boom
summary: Dubai Holding's firm, Nakheel and Meydan, refinanced a $8.2 billion loan to replace older facilities, securing more favorable terms with Emirates NBD Bank and Mashreqbank. The refinancing positions the companies to capitalize on Dubai's booming real estate market, where home prices, rents, and sales have hit records. The move is part of Dubai Holding's efforts to cut costs and streamline operations under CEO Amit Kaushal, who may consider listing some units in the future.

images.alt_text: Nakheel, the group behind Dubai’s palm-shaped islands, was taken over by the government in 2011 as part of a US$16 billion rescue plan in the aftermath of a 2009-2010 real estate crash.

site_title: Navigating the ethical issues of impact reporting
summary: Investors in sustainable investing face challenges in ethically claiming credit for positive outcomes, such as greenhouse-gas reduction from a solar panel project. A study by Graham and Cooper proposes that credit is justified if it matches the contribution to the work activity and is worthy of civil society's approbation. To improve impact reporting, investors should be specific about their contribution, avoid exaggeration, acknowledge other contributors, and provide context and balance. Ultimately, the goal is to foster trust and credibility in sustainability efforts while adhering to ethical principles and taking responsibility for both positive and negative consequences.

images.alt_text: seedlings, soil, spring flowers

site_title: Computer parts maker Logitech Q4 sales rise; first positive quarter in over two years
summary: Logitech International reported its first positive quarter in over two years, with a 5% increase in US dollar sales to US$1 billion in the fourth quarter. The company's non-GAAP operating profit rose 93% to US$159 million. For the full year, sales fell 5% to US$4.3 billion, but were better than expected. Logitech now aims to increase sales by 0-2% to US$4.3-4.4 billion over the next 12 months, with non-GAAP operating income expected to be US$685-715 million.

images.alt_text: Logitech has been dealing with customers wrestling with high inflation, and uncertainty among businesses unsure about future economic development and how to equip their offices as they move to hybrid working models.

site_title: US: Wall Street stocks fall as markets weigh strong wage data, Fed meeting
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 574.08 points or 1.47% to 37,823.57, as markets weighed strong wage data and deteriorating consumer confidence ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. US labor costs rose 1.2% and consumer confidence dropped to its lowest level in over a year. Despite expectations of unchanged interest rates, investors were cautious, with most major stocks finishing lower, including Tesla and Alphabet.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the floor as screens display the logo for Chevron Corp. and Hess Corp. at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., October 23, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Trump social media firm's rising shares pressure short-sellers: S3
summary: Trump Media & Technology Group's shares jumped nearly 7% on Tuesday, with a 5-day rally, amid rising short-seller losses. The company, which operates former President Donald Trump's social media firm Truth Social, has seen its shares rise 75% in two weeks, forcing short-sellers to exit positions due to high borrowing costs. Short-sellers are now facing market-to-market losses of $94.8 million, with some considering new short positions at higher levels.

images.alt_text: Given the heightened tensions with Israel, a potential Trump return could make the Iranian leadership feel even more vulnerable.

site_title: Asia: Markets build on Wall Street rally, yen holds bounce
summary: Asian markets continued their rally on Tuesday, following advances on Wall Street, while the yen held its gains after the previous day's sharp swings. Hong Kong rose for a seventh consecutive day, with Shanghai, Sydney, and other Asian cities also on the rise. China's April factory activity growth exceeded expectations, providing support to the markets. The yen weakened slightly but held most of its previous day's surge, which was attributed to an intervention by authorities. The Federal Reserve's upcoming policy decision will be closely watched for clues about their plans for the rest of the year.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced 0.4 per cent to 38,386.09 on Monday.
Across the broader market, gainers

site_title: Ex-Binance chief set for sentencing in US court
summary: Former Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao is set for sentencing in a US court after pleading guilty to violating US anti-money laundering laws. Binance agreed to pay US$4.3 billion to settle charges in February. The US Federal prosecutors are seeking a prison sentence for Zhao, who resigned from his post at Binance as part of a deal with US authorities. Investigations found Binance failed to prevent transactions with terrorist groups such as the Islamic State and Hamas.
