images.alt_text: (FILES) Blockchain and cryptocurrency Binance founder and CEO Chinese-born Canadian Changpeng Zhao, also known as CZ, poses during an interview at the technology startups and innovation fair in Paris on May 16, 2022. Former boss of Binance, Changpeng Zhao, will be handed down his sentence over money laundering by a Seattle court on April 30, 2024. (Photo by Eric PIERMONT / AFP)

site_title: Deflation reaches UK stores as non-food prices fall 0.6%
summary: Deflation reaches UK stores as non-food prices fall 0.6% for the first time in over two years, according to the British Retail Consortium. This easing of price pressures provides relief to households, with prominent retailers such as Next and Primark expecting further sales growth. The Bank of England is expected to cut interest rates, with policymakers set to convene next Thursday to set rates. Shop price inflation remains high, driven by food inflation, but overall numbers show signs of normalizing.

images.alt_text: The monthly Lloyds Bank Business Barometer showed a net 63 per cent of companies expected to raise prices in the coming months, up from 60 per cent in March and marking the highest reading since November.
Hopes are fading that the Bank of England might cut interest rates as early as the summer after warnings by policymakers about the threat from persistent inflation.
The figures underscore the pressure on the public finances as Prime Minister Rishi Sunak prepares for a general election later this year, possibly as early as October.
The UK is eyeing exports as a way to pull its economy out of a period of lacklustre growth.

site_title: Goodbye Garage, hello Tech in Asia: How BT’s startup coverage is evolving
summary: BT's Garage vertical, a startup-focused section, is being phased out and replaced by a partnership with Tech in Asia, a Singapore-based tech news outlet. The partnership will give BT subscribers access to Tech in Asia's content, including deep dives into startup trends and deals, and will complement BT's business journalism. The move aims to boost BT's regional presence as a financial news publication. Past Garage articles will remain available on the website, and the Tech in Asia brand will be integrated into the BT website under the "Startups" tab.

images.alt_text: Tech in Asia staff paid a lunchtime visit to The Business Times following the announcement of the acquisition by SPH Media.  For new ideas to emerge from the acquisition, teams from both entities will need to come together and allow cultural diffusion to take place.
Willis Wee founded Tech in Asia in 2009 during the social media boom.
Willis Wee (left), CEO of Tech in Asia, with Wong Wei Kong, Editor-in-Chief of SPH Media’s English, Malay and Tamil Media Group.

site_title: The not-so-idyllic view on Sentosa
summary: Sentosa properties, located in Singapore's Core Central Region, have seen current prices lag behind those of homes in prime areas on the mainland, with prices 40% lower than initial sales in 2010. Landed homes on Sentosa also underperformed, with a seized villa auctioning for S$20 million below its reserve price. In contrast, luxury homes in Good Class Bungalow areas have seen significant sales, with a recent transaction selling for S$84 million. Private home prices eased further in the first quarter, while public housing prices moved in the opposite direction.

images.alt_text: An entire ecosystem feeds on developers building new homes, including contractors, professional service providers and property agents, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.

If participation continues to be weak and developers continue to sit out state land sales - and they are already stepping back from private collective sales - housing supply will diminish, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Recent reports have cast a positive light on Singapore’s office market, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
In the public housing sector, market forces appear to be regrouping, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
In today’s private housing market, the luxury condominium segment is struggling, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.

site_title: China developer Fantasia proposes new restructuring terms, shares up
summary: China property developer Fantasia has entered into a new restructuring agreement with its bondholders, offering revised terms for its US$4 billion debt. The revised terms include swapping US$1.3 billion of debt into company shares and issuing new notes with interest rates ranging from 4.5 to 6.5%. Shares jumped 11% on the news, outperforming the Hang Seng Mainland Properties Index. The agreement comes as the country's real estate sector faces a worsening outlook, with creditors expecting tighter terms.

images.alt_text: Blue Green Shuangcheng Technology Group will assist Fantasia with reorganisation plans for its onshore projects, negotiate with onshore creditors and accelerate asset sales.

site_title: Samsung says Q1 operating profits soar nearly tenfold on-year
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a nearly tenfold increase in Q1 operating profits, reaching 6.61 trillion won (S$6.6 billion), due to strong sales of flagship Galaxy S24 smartphones and higher prices for memory semiconductors. The company's Memory Business returned to profit, driven by demand for high-value-added products, and sales rose 12.8% year-on-year to 71.9 trillion won. The recovery in the semiconductor market is expected to continue, with demand for AI chips and other high-tech products driving growth.

images.alt_text: SK On has posted an operating profit of 625 billion won for the January to March period.
SK Hynix has been the sole supplier of HBM3 to Nvidia and began mass production of the latest version of HBM chips, called HBM3E.
The Biden administration is considering blacklisting Chinese companies it suspects could make chips for Huawei.
The momentum in exports has been felt in other parts of Asia, a region with factories that make advanced components in high-tech consumer products.
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing is one of three companies with leading-edge technologies and the scale required to turn a profit in the chipmaking industry.
AMD said the new chips are expected to be available in platforms from HP and Lenovo starting in the second quarter of 2024.
The world’s largest contract chipmaker has benefited from a surge towards AI that has helped it weather the tapering off of pandemic-led electronics demand.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Samsung Electronics is seen at its office building in Seoul, South Korea, March 23, 2018.   REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo

site_title: Prabowo must reignite Indonesia’s manufacturing sector, adopt green technologies
summary: Indonesian president-elect Prabowo Subianto has vowed to achieve annual growth of 7 to 8 per cent and push the country to developed status by 2045. To ignite economic growth, Prabowo plans to boost the domestic manufacturing sector, adopt green technologies, and attract significant foreign investments, particularly from Western economies. This will involve easing import restrictions, improving the quality of the workforce, and fostering a conducive environment for innovation and entrepreneurship. Prabowo's administration will also prioritize investments in key sectors such as energy, agriculture, finance, and education to create jobs and boost exports.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's President-elect Prabowo Subianto (L) and vice president-elect Gibran Rakabuming Raka (R) walk past a picture of Indonesia’s President Joko Widodo, also father of Gibran Rakabuming Raka, during the plenary meeting of general election commission (KPU) announcing the 2024 presidential election in Jakarta on April 24, 2024. (Photo by ADEK BERRY / AFP)

site_title: US-Singapore FTA marks 20 years: a bridge ‘at the right place, right time’
summary: The US-Singapore free trade agreement (FTA) marked its 20th anniversary, with bilateral trade tripling from US$40 billion in 2003 to US$120 billion in 2022. Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong praised the agreement's success, citing its role in fostering an "open, inclusive, and rules-based multilateral trading order." The milestone demonstrates how countries can benefit from a collaborative and structured trade environment, according to Gan Kim Yong.

images.alt_text: Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong will make an official visit to the US and Canada from Apr 28 to May 3.

site_title: Why spot Bitcoin ETFs took forever – and became instant hits
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission's approval of direct Bitcoin ETFs has drawn a large number of new investors to the cryptocurrency market. These ETFs, offered by Fidelity Investments and BlackRock, hold Bitcoin rather than investing in futures, making them a more accessible option for Americans. The approval has led to a surge in interest in Bitcoin, with prices reaching record highs. As a result, spot Bitcoin ETFs have become instant hits, providing a new way for investors to gain exposure to the cryptocurrency. This shift is expected to drive further growth in the market.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong already permits crypto-futures based ETFs and three have listed so far:
The level of demand for the funds will provide clues on whether Hong Kong’s push for a tightly regulated digital asset hub is gaining traction.

site_title: Tyson v Paul sanctioned as professional boxing fight
summary: Mike Tyson, 58, will face Jake Paul in a sanctioned, professional boxing match on July 20 at the 80,000-seat AT&T Stadium. The eight-round bout, streamed live on Netflix, will count towards both fighters' records. The exhibition was expected to be due to Tyson's age, but the bout has been upgraded to a professional fight. The event will feature 14-ounce gloves and take place two weeks after Paul's last fight.

images.alt_text: In a joint statement it was confirmed Aramco would become Fifa’s Major Worldwide Partner exclusive in the energy category.

site_title: Low-carbon transition is rewiring energy systems – and portfolios
summary: The low-carbon transition is expected to drive a significant shift in energy systems, with an average of $4 trillion in annual capital investment, and low-carbon sources like solar and wind making up 70% of the world's energy mix by 2050. Investors are increasingly adopting a whole-portfolio approach to transition investing, with 98% already incorporating transition investment objectives across their portfolios. The transition will intersect with private markets, infrastructure, and emerging markets, creating opportunities for targeted exposures and faster, more flexible financing.

images.alt_text: The late stage venture capital and early growth private equity fund had attracted over 30 institutional investors from 18 countries, said Decarbonizatioin Partners in a press release on Thursday (April 25).
One challenge is the need for new investment in infrastructure. For example, for electric vehicles to have a meaningful impact, it is essential to invest in a reliable network of charging stations.

site_title: China’s top leaders hint at property support, interest rate cuts
summary: China's top leaders hinted at providing support for the economy and cutting interest rates to alleviate the property crisis, according to a Politburo meeting statement. The decision aims to "make flexible use" of tools to lower borrowing costs. Monetary policy should be "prudent," while fiscal policy should be "proactive." The meeting also reaffirmed a pledge to expand domestic demand and support for strategic technology, with President Xi Jinping set to convene senior officials in July for a closed-door conclave.

images.alt_text: Asia is set to expand 4.5 per cent in 2024 from the prior year.

China's National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) manufacturing PMI dropped to 50.4 in April from 50.8 in March, above the 50-mark separating growth from contraction and just ahead of a median forecast of 50.3 in a Reuters poll.
Profits at China’s industrial firms rise 4.3 per cent in the first quarter from a year earlier.
Leading the push are firms in industries where China is racing ahead of rivals, such as electric vehicles and solar energy.
Beijing has announced plans to step up central government spending as an offset.
The average coupon in April on new debt fell to just 2.83 per cent – the lowest level in data going back to 1999.
China grew faster than expected in the first quarter,  offering some relief to officials, but March indicators showed domestic demand remains frail.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on labour costs data
summary: US stock markets opened lower on Tuesday, April 30, due to stronger-than-expected labour costs data, which signalled persistent inflationary pressures. The Dow Jones fell 48.7 points, or 0.13%, to 38,337.4, while the S&P 500 dropped 12.4 points, or 0.24%, to 5,103.78. Caution prevailed ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, with investors weighing market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

site_title: 3M to cut dividend on health-care spin, losing aristocrat status
summary: 3M will cut its dividend by slashing it to roughly 40% of adjusted free cash flow starting in May, marking the end of its 60-year payout streak. The decision follows the spinoff of its health-care division, Solventum Corp., which accounted for 30% of the company's free cash flow. The move breaks 3M's legacy as a "dividend aristocrat" and comes as the company reports strong first-quarter earnings, with adjusted earnings per share topping analyst estimates. CEO Mike Roman will step down, replaced by William "Bill" Brown.

images.alt_text: 3M's adjusted earnings are US$2.42 per share in the fourth quarter, better than the US$2.31 analysts predicted.

site_title: German economy skirts recession, helped by construction and exports
summary: Germany's economy narrowly avoided recession in the first quarter, growing 0.2% from the previous three-month period, exceeding analyst forecasts. The construction sector and exports drove growth, despite structural weaknesses limiting the pace of recovery. The German government raised its economic growth forecast to 0.3% for this year, while economists predict narrow-gauge growth.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Containers are loaded onto trucks at the seaport terminal DIT Duisburg Intermodal Terminal at the Duisburg harbour, on July 13, 2023. German exports fell sharply in December on weaker demand from eurozone countries, official data showed February 5, 2024, capping a disappointing year in foreign trade for Europe's largest economy. Exports totalled 125.3 billion euros (USD 135 billion) in December, a 4.6-percent plunge on the previous month, federal statistics agency Destatis said. (Photo by Ina FASSBENDER / AFP)

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 30)
summary: Singapore's employment levels expanded in Q1, but at a moderated pace, with a total of 4,900 new jobs added, lower than the 7,500 recorded in Q4. This is attributed to tighter foreign worker quotas for construction firms. The growth in employment is a slight improvement from the previous quarter, where employment declined. The data from the Ministry of Manpower suggests that the country's employment growth is easing, but still indicates a positive trend.

site_title: IMF boosts Asia growth forecast this year on China, India
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has boosted its growth forecast for Asia this year to 4.5%, citing a rosier outlook for China and India. China's real GDP is expected to expand by 4.6% and India by 6.8% in 2024, while officials left the 2025 outlook unchanged at 4.3%. However, risks remain, including a potential long-term property sector downturn in China and growing fiscal deficits. Officials also warned against relying too heavily on the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions when setting monetary policy.

images.alt_text: International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank spring meetings signage inside the IMF headquarters in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, April 17, 2024. The International Monetary Fund inched up its expectations for global economic growth this year, citing strength in the US and some emerging markets, while warning the outlook remains cautious amid persistent inflation and geopolitical risks. Photographer: Samuel Corum/Bloomberg
Tight labour markets and wage growth above 10 per cent across the central, eastern and south-eastern Europe region will add to price pressures, the IMF says.
The International Monetary Fund is working to reinforce its ability to support low-income countries hit hardest by recent shocks.

(From left) Krishna Srinivasan, director of the IMF’s Asia and Pacific department and Thomas Helbling, deputy director of the IMF's Asia Pacific Department at the press conference following the release of the IMF’s Regional Economic Outlook for Asia and Pacific on Tuesday. They recommend Asia central banks to focus on their domestic fundamentals in making monetary policies.
FILE PHOTO: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva speaks during an interview during a G20 Financial Summit, in Sao Paulo, Brazil, February 27, 2024. REUTERS/Carla Carniel/File Photo

site_title: Singapore stocks rise, tracking regional bourses; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% on Tuesday, tracking regional gains, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,292.69. Marine engineering group Seatrium was the biggest gainer, while Thai Beverage and Wilmar International also saw gains. The Kospi and ASX 200 were up, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.3% due to China's manufacturing data. Analysts say China's economy remains in weak growth, but market participants will look for signs that the worst is over.

images.alt_text: In early trade, Hong Kong rose for a seventh successive day, while Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington, Taipei and Jakarta were also on the rise on Tuesday.
XX
Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index advanced 0.77 per cent, while China’s blue-chip index edged 0.06 per cent higher on Monday morning.
Despite coming close to a technical correction, Japanese stocks remain a top bet for many thanks to the country’s growth revival and a push for corporate reform

site_title: Eurozone economy rebounds in first quarter, inflation stable in April
summary: The eurozone economy rebounded in the first quarter of 2024, growing 0.3% compared to the previous quarter, exceeding expectations. The growth follows the eurozone's technical recession in the second half of 2023. Inflation remained stable at 2.4% in April, close to the European Central Bank's 2% target. The data suggests the ECB may cut interest rates in June as expected, despite the growth figure. Key economies, including Germany and France, also recorded growth, while Southern Europe showed stronger performance.

images.alt_text: The flash services PMI soared to 52.9 from last month’s 51.5.
Interest-rate hikes to curb inflation have weighed particularly on the property market, where new investments have fallen.

While banks were slowly turning less cautious – at least about extending home loans – households and companies showed little appetite for taking on fresh debt, the ECB’s quarterly Bank Lending Survey showed.

epa11204097 An exterior view of the European Central Bank (ECB) building before a press conference following the meeting of the ECB Governing Council in Frankfurt am Mainn, Germany, 07 March 2024.  EPA-EFE/CHRISTOPHER NEUNDORF

site_title: Coca-Cola raises annual sales forecast on global demand, higher prices
summary: Coca-Cola raised its annual organic sales forecast after beating first-quarter revenue and profit expectations. The company's average selling prices rose 13% in the first quarter, while unit case volumes increased 1%. Strong demand in the US, driven by away-from-home sales, and international markets such as Europe and Latin America, contributed to the positive results. Coca-Cola's sales forecast was raised due to higher prices and increasing demand for its products globally.

images.alt_text: Subway announced the new 10-year pact to serve PepsiCo products such as Mountain Dew sodas, Tropicana juices and Gatorade sports drinks.
Coca-Cola has been making acquisitions to help it diversify away from sugary drinks.
Coca-Cola's average selling prices rose 9 per cent in the fourth quarter, while unit case volumes increased 2 per cent.

site_title: Hong Kong vies with US in Bitcoin ETF market after crypto’s revival
summary: Hong Kong is set to launch a series of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) investing directly in Bitcoin and Ether, competing with US Bitcoin products. The funds, listed by Harvest Global Investments and Bosera Asset Management, will debut on April 30, marking a push for Hong Kong to establish itself as a tightly regulated digital asset hub. The level of demand for the funds will be a key indicator of the city's efforts, with officials hoping to restore its reputation as a modern financial center.

images.alt_text: The applications come in the wake of the US$53 billion amassed by US Bitcoin ETFs this year, including offerings from BlackRock and Fidelity Investments.

Hong Kong is set to be Asia’s first to accept cryptocurrency products as a mainstream investment tool, and the products have also received official regulatory approval from the Securities and Futures Commission.
Hong Kong already permits crypto-futures based ETFs and three have listed so far:
The launch of the Bitcoin memecoins took place following another high-profile event.
For some crypto fans, the halving will underscore bitcoin’s value as an increasingly scarce commodity.

site_title: Distressed builder Taeyoung wins debt restructuring vote
summary: Korean builder Taeyoung Engineering & Construction Co has secured creditor backing to restructure its debt, with support from creditors holding at least 75% of its aggregate debt. The move aims to implement a debt-to-equity swap and defer repayment on project finance debt for three years. If successful, Taeyoung is expected to secure stable liquidity by the end of 2025, but analysts warn that the company may not be the last builder facing difficulties repaying debt, with 111 trillion won of Korea's project-finance debt classified as "troubled".

images.alt_text: Evergrande’s shares, which were suspended from trading on Jan 29 this year, will continue to remain suspended.

site_title: OCBC should be seen as ‘financial conglomerate’ unlike local banking peers, says chairman
summary: OCBC, Singapore's second-largest lender, should be viewed as a financial conglomerate comprising its banking licenses, insurance arm Great Eastern, and asset manager, according to Chairman Andrew Lee. The bank's high capital levels, 15.9% CET-1 ratio, are seen as "very high" compared to peers DBS and UOB. Lee acknowledged the impact of excess capital on return on equity but noted that the board is prudent in deploying capital to suit its strategy. OCBC has set a clear dividend policy and is open to suggestions on enhancing its share value, with its shares closing 0.3% higher at S$14.25.

images.alt_text: The local banking trio are due to report their first quarter results in early May – beginning with DBS on May 2, followed by UOB on May 8, and OCBC on May 10.
Great Eastern chairman Soon Tit Koon assured that its board has heard shareholders' concerns of falling returns, and will look into the suggestions they provided.
Analysts expect the banks to have enough liquidity to manage costs, especially given impending interest rate cuts.
Helen Wong, OCBC group CEO speaking at the OCBC Bank First Half 2023 Results Briefing on August 4, 2023.

site_title: Indonesia may offer dual citizenship to attract overseas workers, minister says
summary: Indonesia may offer dual citizenship to people of Indonesian descent living overseas to attract skilled workers. The move, proposed by Coordinating Minister Luhut Pandjaitan, aims to bring highly skilled Indonesians back to the country. This plan, which contradicts current Indonesian law, would allow individuals to hold dual citizenship without renouncing one passport at age 18. The decision comes as Indonesia seeks to boost its economy, with Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella announcing a $1.7 billion investment in the country.

images.alt_text: Indonesia Minister of Investment Bahlil Lahadalia (right)  announced that Indonesia's investment realization in first quarter of 2024 grew 15.5% from the same period last year.

site_title: Why China’s electric cars are piling up at European ports
summary: China's electric cars are piling up at European ports due to a lack of buyers, despite being cheaper and having similar range, quality, and technology to European brands. Chinese automakers face challenges such as buyer wariness, a lack of brand image, trade protectionism, and rapid outdatedness. High import tariffs, currently 10% in the EU and 27.5% in the US, also hinder sales. To succeed, Chinese makers need to focus on selling to fleets and rental companies, and invest in building brand loyalty and reliability.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen AG vehicles on display during the Beijing Auto Show in Beijing, China, on Thursday, April 25, 2024. Slowing demand for electric vehicles, heightened trade tensions and questions about whether Western legacy automakers can interest Chinese consumers will be the talk of Beijing as executives from top global car marques descend on the capital for the Auto China show. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Mitsubishi Motors at the Montreal Electric Vehicle Show. US protectionism against China is creating an opportunity for Japanese carmakers to bring EV production to North America.
BYD has been expanding its luxury lineup, including the Auto China show launch of the Denza Z9GT, a shooting-brake style design with a heavy emphasis on technology.

site_title: Barclays says it is winning Asia banking business from US firms
summary: Barclays is gaining market share in Asia from US rivals after hiring senior staff, including from Goldman Sachs and Citigroup, to accelerate business growth. The bank's Asia global markets business revenue increased 2.5% last year, driven by a 4% boost in its macro and equities units. Barclays sees itself as Europe's last-remaining global investment bank and aims to boost return on tangible equity to 10% this year and 12% by 2026. The bank is also benefiting from Japanese money flowing into the US and strong appetite from US clients in Asia.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A pedestrian walks past a row of ATMs outside a branch of British bank Barclays in central London on July 28, 2021. British bank Barclays said on February 20, 2024, that annual net profit slid 15 percent as it was hit by a large restructuring charge. Profit after tax decreased to £4.3 billion ($5.4 billion) last year after a £900-million charge in the fourth quarter, Barclays said in a results statement. It also outlined a three-year plan to improve performance and return more cash to shareholders. (Photo by Tolga Akmen / AFP)

site_title: Singapore shares open in the red on Tuesday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% at the opening bell on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 8.54 points to 3,273.51. Despite global markets gaining overnight, the local market saw a mixed day with Seatrium and Yoma Strategic being the top traded counters. Banking stocks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, declined, while stocks in the US and Europe also experienced losses, driven by inflation concerns and tariff threats.

site_title: Fifth money launderer gets longer jail term of 15 months
summary: Zhang Ruijin, a Chinese national, has been sentenced to 15 months in jail for laundering S$36 million. He pleaded guilty to three charges of money laundering and forgery, with five other charges taken into consideration. Zhang's assets, including S$131 million, have been seized or prohibited from disposal. He has agreed to forfeit 90% of his assets, valued at around S$118 million, including cryptocurrencies, properties, and vehicles.

site_title: China central bank wants to halt bond-buying spree, not join it
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has hinted that it will not join the global bond-buying spree to boost markets, despite the recent surge in yields. The PBOC has instead warned lenders to curtail ultra-long bond investments and stepped up verbal pushback against bond bulls. The central bank's concerns include the downward pressure on the yuan, pessimism about the economy, and potential financial stability risks. Analysts say the PBOC is not likely to use sovereign bond buying as a tool for managing liquidity anytime soon, as there is already sufficient liquidity in the financial system.

China’s central bank has not made a significant bond purchase since 2007.

site_title: China’s factory activity grows at slower pace in April
summary: China's manufacturing activity expanded at a slower pace in April, with the National Bureau of Statistics' manufacturing PMI dropping to 50.4 from 50.8 in March, just ahead of a median forecast of 50.3. This marks a slower pace than the previous month, suggesting some loss of momentum for the sector at the start of the second quarter, despite solid first-quarter GDP growth reducing the urgency to ramp up stimulus measures.

site_title: Europe: Stocks eke out gains after German inflation data; Deutsche Bank drops
summary: European stocks closed 0.1% higher on Monday, marking the first weekly gain in four weeks, after Germany reported slightly higher-than-expected inflation and Deutsche Bank's shares dropped 8.6% amid concerns over its Postbank acquisition. The Stoxx 600 is on track for its worst month in half a year if losses hold. Meanwhile, Philips surged 29% after announcing a smaller-than-expected claims figure for its recalled breathing devices.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced 0.4 per cent to 38,386.09 on Monday.

site_title: Record gold prices boost recycling: WGC
summary: Record gold prices have boosted recycling to its highest level in over three years, according to the World Gold Council (WGC). Total demand for gold dropped 5% in the first quarter due to high prices, but recycling increased 12% as consumers sold gold holdings to lock in higher prices. The price surge, driven by interest rate cuts and global conflicts, has made gold a sought-after safe-haven investment, with demand in Asia offsetting falls in Europe and North America. The WGC predicts a stronger return for gold in 2024.

images.alt_text: Analysts raised their 2024 gold price forecasts, expecting simmering geopolitical woes to coax investors to seek refuge in the safe-haven asset.

site_title: Japan’s top FX diplomat says ready to deal with yen around the clock
summary: Japan's vice-finance minister Masato Kanda stated the government is ready to deal with foreign exchange matters around the clock, amid a surge in the yen against the dollar. The currency surged as much as five yen against the dollar, with some reports suggesting intervention by Japanese authorities. Kanda declined to comment on intervention, but warned excessive foreign exchange moves could negatively impact people's daily lives. The government would need to respond to such moves, acting in accordance with international frameworks, and has agreed to consult on currency markets with the US and South Korea.

site_title: Singapore Airlines could post highest-ever earnings of about S$2.7 billion for FY2024, says analyst
summary: Singapore Airlines is expected to post its highest-ever net profit of approximately S$2.7 billion for FY2024, according to analyst Raymond Yap of CGS International. A final dividend of S$0.38 per share is anticipated, with a possible increase to S$0.42. The airline's core net profit could reach S$550 million or earnings before interest and tax of S$600 million for the fourth quarter of FY2024. However, earnings are expected to decline in FY2025 due to compressed yields, higher operating costs, and limited capacity increase.

site_title: Singapore’s employment growth eases in Q1, as tighter foreign worker quotas kick in for construction firms
summary: Singapore's employment growth eased in Q1 due to tightening foreign worker quotas for construction firms, resulting in the first decline in non-resident employment since Q3 2021. Total employment, excluding migrant domestic workers, rose by 4,900 in Q1, lower than the 7,500 recorded in Q4 2023. This moderation in growth is attributed to cooling labour demand, mainly in the construction sector. The decline marks a shift in the labour market, with a more cautious approach to hiring foreign workers.

images.alt_text: Retrenchments fell in Q4 from the previous quarter, MOM says.

site_title: South Korea’s March factory output falls most in 15 months
summary: South Korea's factory output fell 3.2% in March, the largest decline in 15 months, according to government data. This was driven by a drop in metal processing and electronic parts. The annual production rose 0.7%, slower than expected, with a 4.6% increase in February. The decline is attributed to economic slowdown and supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Australian retail sales unexpectedly decline, currency drops
summary: Australian retail sales unexpectedly declined 0.4% in March, contradicting expectations of a 0.2% gain, as households faced higher borrowing costs. The decline follows a downwardly revised 0.2% increase in February. The Australian dollar dropped 0.4% and the three-year government bond yield declined, while economists stick to forecasts for easing monetary policy, but with a more conservative timing. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep interest rates at a 12-year high of 4.35% at its next meeting on May 6-7.

site_title: Campaigning EU chief von der Leyen defends record during debate
summary: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen defended her record during a debate ahead of the European elections, focusing on the EU's "Green Deal" and her stance on the war in Ukraine. She faced criticism from candidates on issues such as climate change and cooperation with Russia. Von der Leyen also expressed openness to banning TikTok and emphasized the need for cooperation with certain European groups. The debate comes before the June 6-9 European Parliament elections, where von der Leyen is running for a second term as EU president.

site_title: India’s influencers still struggle years after TikTok ban
summary: India's influencers struggled to replicate their TikTok success on local platforms after the app's ban in 2020. Many, including choreographer Sahil Kumar, who had over 1.5 million followers, migrated to US-based platforms like YouTube and Instagram. However, their followings dwindled significantly, with Kumar's Instagram following dropping to 94,000. Established US platforms, such as Instagram and YouTube, benefited from the ban, with Instagram seeing a surge in short-form videos, and YouTube rolling out its own TikTok rival, Shorts.

site_title: Singapore’s burnout rate shows the price of success
summary: Singaporeans face a high burnout rate due to the country's competitive and overworked environment, with long hours and a stigma surrounding mental health issues. Despite having high living standards, citizens struggle to balance work, life, and personal aspirations, leading some to opt out of the traditional path. A 31-year-old retiree, Ashish Xiangyi Kumar, has taken a non-traditional route, sparking interest and conversations about the need for change in the country's expectations of success. The government is trying to address the issue with flexible work arrangements and mental health support, but a cultural shift is still needed to break the pressure-cooker environment.

images.alt_text: Besides workforce challenges, both labour leaders acknowledged other pressures faced by workers from inflation and high prices, to immediate cost concerns.

site_title: Indonesia’s Mount Ruang erupts again, closes international airport
summary: Mount Ruang volcano in Indonesia's North Sulawesi province erupted several times, forcing evacuations of over 6,000 people, closing the Sam Ratulangi international airport, and raising the alert level to its highest. The volcano sent ash 5 km into the sky and raised a 6-km exclusion zone, warning of potential tsunamis and ejections of incandescent rocks. Over 800 people live on the volcano, with some returning home after the emergency response status ended. The latest eruption prompted authorities to close the airport due to volcanic ash.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher, extending rally
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, extending a rally ahead of a Federal Reserve decision and key earnings reports. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.4% to 38,386.09, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.3% and 0.4% respectively. Notable gains included Tesla's 15% increase after receiving a Chinese security clearance, and Domino's Pizza's 5.6% jump on strong first-quarter sales. The week ahead will feature the Fed decision, April jobs data, and earnings reports from major companies like Apple and Pfizer.

site_title: China Vanke posts another quarterly loss on sales drought

The company's revenue fell 10% and cash and cash equivalents dropped 41% year-over-year. Vanke faces a maturity wall in 2025 with 36.2 billion yuan of bonds coming due, and its stock and bonds have slid due to concerns about its financial condition. The company is seeking to ease worries about default and has received support from financial institutions.

summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 0.9% decline in Q3 net property income to S$37.7 million, primarily due to weaker foreign currencies and a divestment loss. However, gross revenue rose 0.7% to S$47.6 million, driven by Singapore properties. The Reit maintained a 98% overall portfolio occupancy and a gearing ratio of 37.2%. site_title: Diamond giant De Beers is in the shop window, but the potential buyers are few
summary: De Beers, the world's largest diamond miner, is likely to be sold or listed in the near future due to declining sales and an uncertain future. British multinational mining company Anglo American, which owns an 85% stake in De Beers, is considering selling the company amid a US$39 billion takeover bid by BHP. A sale could lead to restructuring in the diamond trade, with potential buyers including luxury goods companies or large mining companies. De Beers' sales have fallen by 14.3% in the first quarter of 2024, amid a surge in lab-grown synthetic diamonds and Russia's Alrosa being banned from selling to the West due to sanctions.

site_title: More UK companies plan price rises but wage expectations cool: Lloyds
summary: British companies plan to raise prices in the coming months, with a net 63% of companies expecting price increases, the highest reading since November. This marks a slight increase from March, when 60% of companies planned price hikes. However, wage expectations cooled, with fewer companies expecting pay rises. The mixed news comes as the Bank of England monitors inflation pressure, despite the expected drop in the headline rate of inflation below the 2% target in the coming months.

site_title: Miami office tower goes up for sale for more than US$500 million
summary: Miami office tower 701 Brickell, located in the Brickell neighborhood, is up for sale for over $500 million. Nuveen Real Estate, the owner, has hired Jones Lang LaSalle to find a buyer. The building, renovated since 2021, has more than 90% occupancy and high rent growth. The Brickell neighborhood has seen a boom in demand, with tech and finance firms relocating or opening outposts in the area. This sale comes as office owners in the US struggle with rising vacancies and borrowing costs.

site_title: Why the potential for another Donald Trump presidency is making Iran very nervous
summary: Iran is concerned about a potential second Donald Trump presidency due to the heightened tensions with Israel and the looming threat of a wider Middle East war. A new Trump administration could pose significant risks, including a potential economic shock, bolder military action against the regime, and increased protest movements. Trump's previous campaign against Iran reduced oil exports to a historic low, further exacerbating the country's internal challenges. The Iranian leadership feels vulnerable under such conditions, making a Trump return a cause for concern.

summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. is leading a US$1.05 billion financing for metal and hardware producer ASC Engineered Solutions, offering a 4.25 percentage point spread over the Secured Overnight Financing Rate. This is at the lower end of recent private credit deals, which range between 5 percentage points to 5.5 percentage points over the benchmark. Apollo Global Management and Oaktree Capital Management are also in the mix, as competition for new financings has intensified with pricing reaching record lows in some recent direct lending deals.

site_title: Paramount replaces CEO with trio as it talks merger with Skydance
summary: Paramount Global replaced CEO Bob Bakish with a trio of executives, including CBS President George Cheeks, Paramount Pictures studio chief Brian Robbins, and Showtime head Chris McCarthy. The change comes as the company is in talks with Skydance Media about a possible merger. Despite analysts' concerns, the new arrangement appears to be well-received by the market, with Paramount's shares rising nearly 1% in after-hours trading. The company reported better-than-expected earnings for the quarter, with revenue and streaming unit gains. A long-term strategic plan is being finalized to position the company for future success.

site_title: Japan’s March factory output rises 3.8% vs month earlier
summary: Japan's factory output rose 3.8% in March from the previous month, exceeding market forecasts of a 3.5% increase. Manufacturers predict a 4.1% rise in April and 4.4% in May. Meanwhile, Japanese retail sales expanded 1.2% in March, marking the 25th consecutive month of growth, but below market forecasts of a 2.2% rise.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust Q1 net property income rises 6% to S$25.1 million
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust's net property income rose 6% to S$25.1 million in Q1, driven by a 7.5% increase in gross revenue. site_title: Oil falls more than US$1/barrel on Middle East peace talks, US rate cut doubts
summary: Oil prices fell over $1 a barrel on Monday, with Brent crude futures settling at $88.40 a barrel, down 1.2%. The decline was driven by tempered fears of a wider Middle East conflict following Israel ceasefire talks in Cairo, and dimmed expectations of imminent US interest rate cuts due to moderate March inflation. US West Texas Intermediate futures fell 1.5%, while investors await the US Federal Reserve's May 1 monetary policy review and the upcoming US nonfarm payrolls report.

site_title: US to require new cars to have emergency braking systems by 2029
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has announced a new rule requiring all new passenger cars and trucks sold in the US to have automatic emergency braking systems by September 2029. This rule aims to save at least 360 lives annually and prevent at least 24,000 injuries. Automatic emergency braking systems use sensors to detect potential collisions and apply brakes automatically if the driver has not. The rule also requires the systems to detect pedestrians in both daylight and night.

site_title: WeWork cuts new restructuring deal that spurns Adam Neumann
summary: WeWork has struck a new restructuring deal with senior lenders, agreeing to provide roughly $450 million in Chapter 11 and exit financing in exchange for equity. The deal, which has support from owners of most of WeWork's senior debt, leaves out co-founder Adam Neumann, who had floated an offer to buy back the company for over $500 million. The agreement, if approved, would allow WeWork to exit bankruptcy and exit court protection in the coming months with less debt and a leaner lease portfolio.

images.alt_text: An attorney for Adam Neumann’s real estate firm Flow told FT that the company and its financial partners were prepared to beat any other offer that WeWork has received by 10 per cent.
During its Chapter 11 bankruptcy case, Wework came under fire for withholding payments from property owners who wouldn’t agree to lower rent.
The receivership comes as WeWork retrenches following its US bankruptcy filing last year.
WeWork has racked up losses on its long-term lease obligations as more people began working from home during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Amazon Purr-rime: Cat accidentally shipped to online retailer
summary: A curious cat named Galena accidentally slipped into an Amazon box in Utah and was shipped to California, where it was discovered by a warehouse worker at an Amazon center. Galena's owner, Carrie Clark, had posted "missing" posters after the cat vanished on April 10. A week later, a vet in Los Angeles contacted Clark to inform her that Galena had been found in the box, which contained steel-toed work boots, and was rescued by Amazon employee Brandy Hunter. The cat was otherwise unharmed and reunited with its owner.

images.alt_text: Japanese shiba inu Kabosu, best known as the logo of cryptocurrency Dogecoin, taking a rest at the office of her owner Atsuko Sato in Narita, Tokyo, Japan, March 19, 2024.
According to the Brazilian Center for Road Ecology, some 475 million vertebrate animals die on the road every year.

Cows in an open field near Tavis Air Force Base in Solano County, Calif., on Aug. 24, 2023. A company called Flannery Associates has been purchasing large amounts of land in the area. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

site_title: Chevron CEO expects ExxonMobil arbitration resolved in coming months
summary: Chevron CEO Mike Wirth expects a resolution to the arbitration dispute with ExxonMobil over a Guyana oil contract in the coming months, allowing for the completion of the US$53 billion acquisition of Hess this year. Chevron argues Exxon's right of first refusal does not apply due to the corporate merger with Hess, rather than an asset sale. The dispute has delayed the acquisition and threatens to leave Chevron in strategic limbo for months or longer, but Wirth is confident in Chevron's interpretation of the contract.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Chevron logo is pictured after the U.S. government granted a six-month license allowing Chevron to boost oil output in U.S.-sanctioned Venezuela, in Caracas, Venezuela, December 2, 2022. REUTERS/Gaby Oraa/File Photo
Chevron says it has conducted its “exit from Myanmar in a responsible, orderly and safe manner, in accordance with international law and trade sanctions”.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts reports 6.8% higher Q1 net property income of S$34.9 million
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a 6.8% increase in Q1 net property income to S$34.9 million, driven by a 7.3% rise in gross revenue to S$65.3 million. The stapled group's properties in Singapore, Australia, the UK, and Germany saw varying performances, with Japan hotels experiencing the highest RevPAR growth of 32.6% due to robust inbound demand. The company's gearing stood at 37.8% and interest coverage ratio was 2.73 times.

images.alt_text: W Singapore at Sentosa Cove is one of the properties under CDL Hospitality Trusts.

site_title: MicroStrategy posts loss on impairment charge, revenue declines
summary: MicroStrategy posted a first-quarter net loss of $53 million, or $3.09 a share, despite its Bitcoin holdings surging during the period. The company took an impairment charge of $191.6 million against the value of its $13 billion Bitcoin holdings, as it cannot recognize increases in its holdings under current accounting rules. Revenue fell 5.5% to $115.2 million, missing analyst estimates. MicroStrategy's Bitcoin holdings increased by 25,250 since the end of the fourth quarter, with 214,400 Bitcoins held as of April 26.

images.alt_text: Michael Saylor started buying Bitcoin in 2020 as an inflation hedge and alternative to holding cash.
Michael Saylor has previously argued that the company will remain an attractive option to investors seeking exposure to Bitcoin even if the US approves spot Bitcoin ETFs.

site_title: Boeing gets a welcome respite with US$10 billion bond offering
summary: Boeing raised $10 billion from a bond sale, attracting $77 billion of orders and easing its financial strains by refinancing part of its massive debt load. The deal came after the company posted a first-quarter loss and Moody's cut its credit grade to the edge of junk. Boeing shares rose 3.6% on the news, providing a welcome respite for the struggling planemaker. The proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes.

images.alt_text: S&P changed its outlook on Boeing’s bottom of investment grade rating to “negative” from “stable” to reflect an increased potential for the planemaker to face further delays in expected recovery of its cash flow and credit ratios.
Boeing says its first-quarter cash burn, a metric closely watched by investors, was US$3.9 billion, compared with negative US$786 million a year ago.
The fuselage plug area of Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 Boeing 737-9 MAX which was forced to make an emergency landing with a gap in the fuselage, Jan 7, 2024.

The union said the two engineers were at odds with Boeing managers in 2022, when “they insisted on using a different set of assumptions in the analysis of the on-board computer networks on Boeing 777s and 787s, in order to comply with the new FAA guidance.”

site_title: China’s BYD shows effects of price war with weaker first-quarter earnings
summary: China's electric vehicle maker BYD reported its weakest quarterly profit growth since 2022, with a 10.6% increase in net profit to 4.57 billion yuan (S$858.5 million) and a 4% revenue growth to 124.94 billion yuan. The company's revenue growth slowed due to a price war in China's largest auto market, which has hit demand for electric vehicles. BYD still outperformed Tesla, which reported its first quarterly revenue fall since 2020. The company is under pressure to maintain sales growth as local EV upstarts compete for market share.

images.alt_text: BYD has been expanding its luxury lineup, including the Auto China show launch of the Denza Z9GT, a shooting-brake style design with a heavy emphasis on technology.
Visitors look at screens that demonstrate Huawei's intelligent driving software Qiankun.
FILE PHOTO: People walk past an ID. Store X showroom of SAIC Volkswagen in Chengdu, Sichuan province, China January 10, 2021. Picture taken January 10, 2021. REUTERS/Yilei Sun
More than 110 new energy vehicle models among a total of 150 new cars are expected to be launched this year, intensifying competition.
China’s biggest automaker unveiled the Super 3 and Bao 8 SUVS at its Shenzhen headquarters on Tuesday (Apr 16) night in a glitzy livestreamed event.

epa11247954 A visitor inspects Chinese automaker BYD's Seal electric car displayed at the 45th Bangkok International Motor Show 2024  in Nonthaburi province on the outskirts of Bangkok, Thailand, 28 March 2024. More than 49 leading brands of the world's major automakers attend to exhibit and unveil their automotive products and technology including the new electric vehicles, in the annual automobile showcase amid Thailand's sluggish domestic car sales continuing to decline to the lowest level in two years by 26 percent year-on-year in February 2024, according to the Federation of Thai Industries.  EPA-EFE/RUNGROJ YONGRIT
Chinese carmakers were in the spotlight amid the growing challenge to Japanese auto giants that have long dominated Thailand’s vehicle market.
While BYD vehicles are not available in the US, the automaker has been pushing into markets in Asia, Australia and South America, where pickups are popular.

site_title: Stablecoin issuer Tether invests US$200 million in brain-computer interface company
summary: Tether Holdings, the issuer of the largest stablecoin, has invested $200 million in Blackrock Neurotech, a brain-computer interface technology company. The investment was made through Tether's new venture capital arm, Tether Evo. This move is part of Tether's strategy to utilize its surplus earnings from holding a large hoard of Treasuries. The funds will be used to roll out Blackrock Neurotech's products, which have gained popularity with Elon Musk's Neuralink technology.

site_title: Any pivot on rates by Fed will mean more blood in stock markets
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's pivot on rates may lead to more bloodshed in the stock market if he cancels rate-cut plans or hints at returning to hiking rates to combat inflation. Recent GDP and inflation data show a sustained up-tick in prices, contradicting Powell's previous claims of a "soft landing." The Fed's decision may impact commercial property prices, bank failures, and the single-home residential market, potentially leading to a market correction.

images.alt_text: The latest outlook, coming after a series of disappointingly high inflation readings in the US along with better-than-anticipated economic activity, is revamping the investment landscape.

site_title: NTUC to help workers develop skills, adapt to new job opportunities
summary: NTUC plans to help workers develop skills and adapt to new job opportunities amid Singapore's rapidly changing employment landscape. The labour movement aims to address workforce challenges such as inflation, high prices, and retrenchments by fostering career advancement and building resilience among workers. NTUC will focus on upskilling workers for "new, high-value jobs" and encourage employers to form training committees. The organization will also advocate for better salaries and provide assistance to lower and middle-wage workers, as well as platform workers and the self-employed, to cope with rising costs.

images.alt_text: NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng at a pre-May Day media session. NTUC wants PMEs to understand that the workers' union represents all workers, including them, he said.

site_title: Ford’s BlueCruise probed by regulators after fatal crashes
summary: US safety regulators are investigating Ford's BlueCruise driver-assistance feature after two fatal crashes involving the technology. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is reviewing the incidents, which occurred in February and March, involving stationary vehicles. The probe covers approximately 130,050 Mustang Mach-E vehicles from 2021 to 2024 model years. Ford is cooperating with the investigation, which comes after the US National Transportation Safety Board previously investigated the Mach-E crashes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Ford CEO Jim Farley speaks during the official launch of the all-new Ford F-150 Lightning electric pickup truck at the Ford Rouge Electric Vehicle Center in Dearborn, Michigan, U.S. April 26, 2022. REUTERS/Rebecca Cook/File Photo

site_title: Israel concerned over possible ICC arrest warrants related to Gaza war
summary: Israeli officials are concerned that the International Criminal Court (ICC) may issue arrest warrants for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and other top officials for alleged violations of international humanitarian law during the Gaza war. The ICC is investigating the October 7 cross-border attack by Hamas and Israel's military assault on Gaza, now in its seventh month. The ICC can charge individuals with war crimes, crimes against humanity, and genocide. Foreign Minister Israel Katz has warned of a "wave of severe antisemitism" amid the potential warrants, prompting embassies to bolster security measures.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken (L) speaks at a panel with the World Economic Forum President Borge Brende (R) during the WEF in Riyadh on April 29, 2024. (Photo by EVELYN HOCKSTEIN / POOL / AFP)
Shares of shipping companies have risen in the wake of the recent hijacking of container carrier MSC Aries in the Strait of Hormuz.
A billboard in Tehran depicts Iranian missiles. Israel's strike on Iran last week was downplayed by both sides, but that does not rule out future direct clashes.

A pro-Israel counter-protester walks with an Israeli flag near protesters attending a demonstration in support of Palestinians in Gaza, at UCLA in Los Angeles, California, April 28, 2024. Israel’s government has come under intense pressure from global allies to reach a ceasefire in the war that humanitarians say has brought Gaza to the brink of famine.
“Heightened tensions in the Middle East have been exerting upward pressure on prices for key commodities, notably oil and gold,” the World Bank announced in its outlook for global commodity markets.

site_title: Binance and CZ’s fortunes are set to grow, jail or no jail
summary: Binance founder Zhao Changpeng "CZ" is set to serve a 3-year prison sentence for violating anti-money laundering laws. Despite his guilty plea, CZ's estimated $43 billion personal fortune remains intact, and his wealth is expected to grow as Binance's business accelerates during the crypto bull run. CZ has relinquished his role as public face of the company, but his partner, Yi He, remains a key figure. Binance has agreed to pay $4.3 billion in penalties and CZ has agreed to a $50 million personal fine. The company's dominance in the crypto market has remained, with over 40 million new users and $100 billion in customer holdings. Critics argue that the DOJ should have charged more people and punished them further, but CZ's cooperation with the government and low-key demeanor have contributed to the company's ability to thrive despite the allegations.

images.alt_text: The growth in wealth for Zhao is more than five times the size of the US$4.3 billion in fines that Binance agreed to pay to US authorities.
Over the past year, Binance saw its share of such Bitcoin trading drop to 55.3 per cent from 81.3 per cent.
The Safu fund is generally maintained at around US$1 billion, but has fluctuated in the past in tandem with market movements, Binance says.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on megacap strength, Fed verdict awaited
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by gains in megacap companies like Tesla and Apple. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 42.5 points, or 0.11%, to 38,282.16, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased. Investors are cautious ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision later in the week.

site_title: Yahoo to lay off staff in Singapore as it shifts to content curation
summary: Yahoo is laying off 17 staff in Singapore as it shifts its strategy to content curation, citing a thorough evaluation of partner content driving engagement. The affected staff will receive slightly more than two weeks' pay per year of service. In its new strategy, Yahoo is hiring three "curation editors" and a market lead for Yahoo News Singapore. The move follows a larger restructuring plan by Yahoo, which eliminated 1,000 jobs in the US last year.

images.alt_text: Yahoo’s restructuring will create a new division called Yahoo Advertising.

site_title: Yen surges against US dollar on suspected intervention
summary: The US dollar fell as far as 154.4 yen in Asia trade, with Japanese banks suspected of intervening to boost the currency, which had hit 34-year lows earlier. This move is seen as a response to heavy yen-buying by Japanese banks for the first time in 18 months. The dramatic shift begins a potentially busy week for currency traders ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting and key economic data releases, including US payrolls and European inflation data.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Japanese Yen and U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo
The greenback bought 160.17 yen in morning trade, fanning speculation that Japanese authorities would step in to support their currency.

site_title: German inflation creeps up to 2.4% in April
summary: German inflation rose to 2.4% in April, up from 2.3% in March, driven by higher food prices and a smaller drop in energy prices. Core inflation, excluding food and energy, eased to 3% from 3.3% in March. Economists expect the inflation rate to rise again in coming months, while the European Central Bank is set to lower borrowing costs in June. This marks a slight end to a year-and-a-half trend of declining inflation.

images.alt_text: Companies were more satisfied with their current business in April, and expectations also brightened.
The German economy shrank slightly last year, hit by soaring inflation, a manufacturing slowdown and weakness in trading partners, and has acted as a major drag on the 20-nation eurozone.
FILE PHOTO: Workers assemble campers at Knaus-Tabbert AG factory in Jandelsbrunn near Passau, Germany, March 16, 2021. REUTERS/Andreas Gebert/File Photo

site_title: China’s mega banks post rare profit drops on margin squeeze
summary: China's mega banks, including ICBC, Agricultural Bank of China, and Bank of China, reported rare profit drops in the first quarter due to a margin squeeze. Net income fell 2.78% to 87.7 billion yuan for ICBC, while domestic rivals Bank of China and China Construction Bank also reported declines. The decline is attributed to weak loan growth, margin contraction, and lower fee income, amid a prolonged squeeze that has narrowed margins to record lows.

images.alt_text: To plug a capital shortfall, the five Chinese largest lenders this year have announced plans to issue as much as 440 billion yuan of TLAC bonds in total, with issuance of the bonds could be as soon as the second quarter this year.

The rating action for financial institutions including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China is primarily driven by the change in outlook to negative from stable on the government’s credit ratings, according to Moody’s.

site_title: JTC to sell hospitality project being built in Punggol Digital District
summary: A 200-room hospitality project in Singapore's Punggol Digital District, expected to be completed in 2024, is being sold with a 60-year lease. The project will be integrated with a business park tower and is the first hospitality venture in the district. The site is part of a 50-hectare business campus and will be used as a hotel or serviced residence, offering investors a unique opportunity to capture demand in the region. The sale closes on April 30.

images.alt_text: Punggol Digital District: Singapore's first tech-driven enterprise district

site_title: Saudi Arabia says economic revamp momentum intact as plans shift
summary: Saudi Arabia's economic transformation plan, Vision 2030, remains on track despite some project delays, according to Minister Faisal Al-Ibrahim. The kingdom is focusing on accelerating diversification and prioritizing projects with investor interest. While some projects, like The Line, have been scaled back, the government is committed to delivering them. Non-oil growth is expected to accelerate between 4% and 5% this year, and the non-oil sector now accounts for 50% of the country's GDP.

images.alt_text: “If you look at the non-oil GDP, it is growing at very healthy numbers: 4 per cent and north of 4 per cent. We are expecting 5 per cent-plus in the medium term,” Jadaan told delegates at the Saudi Capital Markets Forum in Riyadh. “That is very strong growth.”

site_title: If the US economy is robust, why is the yield curve still inverted?
summary: The US Treasury yield curve has remained inverted for nearly two years, despite the economy avoiding a recession. Historically, an inverted yield curve is a warning signal for the economy, but experts attribute the inversion to the Federal Reserve's credit tightening measures to combat inflation, rather than a sign of an impending recession. The International Monetary Fund has raised its 2024 US growth forecast to 2.7%, describing the economy as possibly "overheated," which contradicts the notion that the inverted yield curve signals an economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., April 25, 2024. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid
Bond buying is a tricky calculus for individuals, in part because the tiiming and number of rate cuts keep getting pushed back. That favours active management.
FILE PHOTO: The Federal Reserve building stands in Washington April 3, 2012. REUTERS/Joshua Roberts/File Photo

site_title: Myanmar records hottest ever April temperature of 48.2 deg C
summary: Myanmar recorded its highest ever April temperature of 48.2°C, surpassing the previous record of 45.5°C set in 1968. The temperature was recorded in Chauk, central Myanmar's Magway region, and was 3-4°C higher than the April average. Similar high temperatures were also reported in Yangon and Mandalay. This heatwave is part of a larger trend of climate change causing heatwaves to be longer, more frequent, and more intense in the region.

images.alt_text: A woman shelters from the sun as she walks along a street on a hot day in Yangon on April 25, 2024. Extreme heat is scorching parts of South and Southeast Asia, prompting health warnings from authorities as high temperatures are recorded across the region. (Photo by Sai Aung MAIN / AFP)
The Bangkok’s environment department warned the heat index was at an “extremely dangerous” level.

site_title: G7 reaches deal to exit from coal by 2035
summary: G7 energy ministers agreed to shut down their coal-fired power plants by 2035, a significant step towards transitioning away from fossil fuels. The accord, to be included in the G7 energy ministers' final communiqué, follows last year's COP28 United Nations climate summit's direction. The agreement is seen as a major milestone in phasing out coal, with Italy planning to turn off its plants by 2025 and Germany and Japan aiming to reduce coal's share in electricity production.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A truck unloads tonnes of coal inside a warehouse in Tondo city, metro Manila January 11, 2016. REUTERS/Romeo Ranoco/File Photo

site_title: English Premier League clubs vote in favour of spending cap: BBC
summary: Premier League clubs have tentatively agreed to implement a spending cap, with the cap based on the lowest-earning club's television rights revenue. A final vote is expected in June, following majority support. The move aims to curb financial excess and promote competitiveness in the league.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Soccer Football - Premier League - Manchester City v Newcastle United - Etihad Stadium, Manchester, Britain - August 19, 2023 General view of the Premier League trophy as it is shown on display before the match REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo

site_title: Scotland’s Humza Yousaf quits in boost to Labour before UK vote
summary: Scotland's First Minister Humza Yousaf has resigned after a week of chaos triggered by scrapping a coalition agreement with the Green Party. His decision comes amid a funding scandal, infighting within the pro-independence Scottish National Party (SNP), and a decline in popular support. Yousaf's resignation creates an opportunity for the UK opposition Labour Party to regain ground in Scotland, where they have been gaining popularity. The Scottish parliament has 28 days to choose a new first minister before a possible election.

images.alt_text: The BBC has named Sturgeon as the suspect arrested in connection with the ongoing investigation into the funding and finances of the Scottish National Party.
Humza Yousaf is expected to be formally appointed as first minister in the Scottish Parliament in Edinburgh on Mar 28.

site_title: Abu Dhabi builder plans US$6.8 billion luxury housing project
summary: Aldar Properties, Abu Dhabi's largest developer, plans to build a $6.8 billion luxury housing project on Al Fahid Island, comprising 7,000 homes, schools, hotels, and entertainment facilities. The project, valued at 25 billion dirhams, is expected to take 5-7 years to complete. The development comes as Abu Dhabi emerges as a new wealth haven, attracting high-net-worth individuals, including crypto millionaires and billionaires.

images.alt_text: Roads lead to the headquarters of Aldar Properties PJSC, Abu Dhabi's biggest real estate company, in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, on Tuesday, March 27, 2012. Property values and rents slumped in the United Arab Emirates after banks curtailed lending and speculators left the market during the global recession. Photographer: Gabriela Maj/Bloomberg

Roads lead to the headquarters of Aldar Properties PJSC, Abu Dhabi's biggest real estate company, in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, on Tuesday, March 27, 2012. Property values and rents slumped in the United Arab Emirates after banks curtailed lending and speculators left the market during the global recession. Photographer: Gabriela Maj/Bloomberg

site_title: BHP tells investors Anglo bid is 'on strategy', stresses discipline
summary: BHP, the world's largest listed mining group, is weighing its next move after its $39 billion takeover proposal for Anglo was rejected. Investors privately told BHP that the bid is in line with its strategy and that they would be open to a revised offer. BHP is fine-tuning a new proposal and seeking feedback from investors through meetings with fund managers. The company is expected to remain disciplined in its approach, prioritizing value in Anglo's quality copper assets and long-term copper prices.

images.alt_text: The potential for Chinese involvement is among a swathe of challenges that BHP chief executive officer Mike Henry faces in pulling off an ambitious but complex deal.

site_title: IReit Global occupancy rate grows to 91.5% in Q1
summary: IReit Global's portfolio occupancy increased to 91.5% in Q1, driven by new leases and the divestment of a low-occupancy property. The European real estate market is expected to improve this year, despite challenges from lower financing costs and high inflation. The company's weighted average lease expiry remained unchanged at 4.9 years, and its aggregate leverage decreased to 37%. IReit Global's shares closed unchanged following the announcement.

images.alt_text: For the full year, the Reit reported  gross revenue of €65.0 million, up 5.4 per cent on year, while net property income rose 2.3 per cent to €49.9 million.
Reit manager IReit Global Group said that the lease extension in France will add over 22 million euros of cash flows.

site_title: China’s top airlines improve balance sheet in Q1; outlook positive for May Day
summary: China's top airlines, China Southern, China Eastern, and Air China, reported improved balance sheets in the first quarter, with China Southern swinging back to a profit of 756 million yuan after a loss of 1.9 billion yuan in the same period last year. Analysts expect the industry to continue recovering from the pandemic's after-effects, with travel demand expected to be strong during the upcoming Labour Day holiday. Industry recovery is seen as positive for May Day, with more international flights planned.

images.alt_text: A China Southern Airlines Airbus A321 plane is towed at Changi Airport in Singapore April 4, 2024. REUTERS/Edgar Su
Air China says the C919 planes will be delivered between 2024 and 2031.
Cathay Pacific Flight CX739 arriving at Changi Airport Terminal 4 on September 13, 2022.

FILE PHOTO: An Airbus A380-800 aircraft from China Southern Airlines lands at the Beijing Daxing International Airport that is under construction, during a test flight in Beijing, China May 13, 2019.   REUTERS/Stringe

site_title: Asset manager Value Partners cuts one-third of China staff in overhaul: sources
summary: Value Partners Group, a Hong Kong-listed asset manager, is cutting about one-third of its China staff as part of a planned overhaul to boost profit. The job cuts follow a 9.4% drop in assets under management to HK$5.6 billion in 2023, leading to operating losses in 2022. The move comes after the company reported a HK$23 million annual profit in 2023, a significant improvement from a HK$544 million loss in 2022.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of HSBC is seen on its headquarters at the financial Central district in Hong Kong, China August 4, 2020. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo
Mubadala and an affiliate of Apollo have contributed more than US$290 million into the fund, which has over US$790 million in assets.

site_title: Apple’s iPad hit by EU’s digital dominance crackdown
summary: The EU's Digital Markets Act has added Apple's iPad to its list of targeted products and services, requiring the company to adapt its operating system and ecosystem to ensure fairness and competition. Apple has six months to comply with new rules, including allowing users to download apps from beyond Apple's confines and uninstalling preloaded apps. The decision is part of a broader effort to prevent tech giants from abusing their dominance and ensure users' rights.

images.alt_text: The two companies have begun discussing terms of a possible agreement and how the OpenAI features would be integrated into Apple’s iOS 18, the next iPhone operating system, say sources.

Spotify submitted a new version of its app to Apple with basic pricing and website information, which is a minimum requirement under the European Commission’s ruling in its music streaming case, it said in a post on X on Wednesday.
Not just fun and games: How mobile games have become big business
Apple is betting that the new iPad models, with faster chips and revamped accessories, can help reinvigorate the category.

site_title: US, Britain urge Hamas to accept Israeli truce proposal
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and British Foreign Secretary David Cameron urged Hamas to swiftly accept an Israeli truce proposal, which includes a 40-day ceasefire and the release of Israeli hostages and thousands of Palestinian prisoners. The proposal is seen as "generous" by both countries, with Blinken calling it "extraordinarily generous" and Cameron saying it's a "deal that should be taken." The US and Britain are pushing for a diplomatic resolution to the Gaza war, which has killed around 34,500 Palestinians and displaced over a million.

images.alt_text: A pro-Israel counter-protester walks with an Israeli flag near protesters attending a demonstration in support of Palestinians in Gaza, at UCLA in Los Angeles, California, April 28, 2024. Israel’s government has come under intense pressure from global allies to reach a ceasefire in the war that humanitarians say has brought Gaza to the brink of famine.

site_title: Deutsche Bank merger ends Numis dealmakers’ boutique freedom
summary: Deutsche Bank's acquisition of Numis has led to tighter restrictions on how Numis bankers interact with the firm's stock analysts, a change that reflects the integration of the two firms. The new combined coverage of UK stocks will be around 340 companies, up from 270. This shift is part of a broader effort by Deutsche Bank to manage the integration of its newly acquired boutique firm, with some analysts and sales staff relocating to different offices. The move highlights the challenges global banks face when acquiring smaller firms, potentially risking the loss of talent and clients.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank didn’t beef up its investment banking units as much as many Wall Street peers did during the boom two years ago, partly because it was simply unable to keep up with the enormous pay packages offered at the time, sources said.

site_title: Pakistan central bank holds key policy rate at 22%
summary: Pakistan's central bank maintained its key interest rate at 22% for the seventh consecutive meeting, citing the need to bring inflation down to 5-7% by September 2025. The decision comes amid battling inflation and limited foreign exchange reserves, with the country seeking a longer-term IMF program to address its economic challenges. The bank noted that recent oil price volatility poses a risk to the outlook and that inflation expectations have edged up. The decision was seen as prudent to keep rates unchanged despite a positive real interest rate.

images.alt_text: This handout photograph taken and released by Pakistan Prime Minister's Office on April 22, 2024 shows Iran’s President Ebrahim Raisi (R) being greeted by Pakistan's Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif upon his arrival in Islamabad. The State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) has raised its key policy rate by 12.25 percentage points since April 2022, to curb soaring inflation.
