site_title: China State Shipbuilding to build 18 LNG ships for QatarEnergy
summary: China State Shipbuilding Corp (CSSC) has signed an agreement to build 18 ultra-large LNG ships for QatarEnergy, the world's largest with a capacity of 271,000 cubic meters each. The vessels will bolster QatarEnergy's shipping fleet ahead of a massive expansion in LNG output, which includes eight LNG trains that will raise Qatar's liquefaction capacity by 85% to 142 million tonnes per annum by 2030.

site_title: Swedish economy posts fourth straight quarter of contraction
summary: Sweden's economy contracted for the fourth consecutive quarter, with seasonally adjusted gross domestic product declining 0.1% in the three months through March compared to the fourth quarter of 2023. The contraction is attributed to rising borrowing costs and a plunge in housing construction. The central bank expects to cut its benchmark rate, which could boost household spending and optimism. However, a separate retail sales report showed a 0.4% decline in March, and economists warn that the growth outlook could darken if the rate cuts are delayed.

site_title: Relative measures can be absolutely wrong
summary: Financial comparisons can be misleading, nonsensical, or even dangerous. Relative measures, such as percentages and ratios, can distort facts and obscure unpalatable truths. The author argues that absolute numbers are often more meaningful, especially in areas like national defence and corporate sustainability. Comparing defence budgets to GDP, for instance, is misleading, as it doesn't account for actual military capabilities. The author advocates for a more nuanced approach, focusing on absolute numbers and avoiding arbitrary denominators.

images.alt_text: Nvidia has pulled away from the rest of the Magnificent Seven as it transforms hype into stratospheric sales and profits.
Consumer price inflation in China, after a brief uptick during the Chinese New Year holiday in February, was near zero in March.

site_title: Financial Times, OpenAI sign content licensing partnership
summary: The Financial Times has signed a content licensing partnership with OpenAI, allowing the AI model ChatGPT to access attributed FT content and collaborate on new AI products and features for FT readers. The agreement enhances ChatGPT's capabilities, enabling it to use select summaries, quotes, and links to FT's stories. This partnership follows a similar deal with the Associated Press last year, marking the latest media tie-up for OpenAI, which has also been used by other outlets such as BuzzFeed and the New York Times.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: OpenAI logo is seen in this illustration taken, March 11, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Red Cross finances ‘stabilised’, new chief says
summary: The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has stabilised its finances after drastic crisis cuts, its new director general Pierre Krahenbuhl said. The ICRC cut its 2024 budget by around US$770 million and laid off 4,000 people, but has now returned to its core mission of humanitarian action in situations of armed conflict. Krahenbuhl denied the ICRC has a mandate to replace the embattled UN agency for Palestinian refugees in Gaza, citing "completely different mandates".

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Pierre Krahenbuhl, Commissioner-General of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA), attends a news conference in Geneva, Switzerland January 29, 2019. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: Maersk unit worth more than US$1 billion set to trade in spinoff
summary: Maersk is demerging its tugboat unit, Svitzer Group, which is estimated to be worth around $1.6 billion in enterprise value. The move is part of Maersk's strategy to focus on container transport. Shareholders will receive two Svitzer shares for each Maersk share, with a nominal value of $144. Analysts predict the demerger could slash Maersk's market value by over 5%. Svitzer is the world's largest tugboat operator, with 450 ships and 4,000 employees, and aims to become a dividend stock.

site_title: Wilmar Q1 net profit falls 22.6% to US$302.9 million
summary: Wilmar International reported a 22.6% drop in net profit to US$302.9 million in Q1, driven by declining commodity prices. Revenue fell 7.3% to US$15.7 billion, despite increases in sales volume across core business segments. The company attributed weaker performance in its feed and industrial products segment, particularly its sugar merchandising division, to lower profits. Despite this, Wilmar's net gearing ratio improved to 0.81 times, and the company expects satisfactory results for the rest of the year.

images.alt_text: Wilmar’s board of directors says it approved Yeo’s appointment after considering his “qualifications, experience, suitability and independence”.

A local resident walk pasts the railway station destroyed by a Russian missile attack in Konstyantynivka, Donetsk region, on February 25, 2024, amid the Russian invasion of Ukraine. (Photo by Anatolii STEPANOV / AFP)
The destroyed oil tanks are part of a facility owned by Delta Wilmar Ukraine, a subsidiary of Wilmar.

site_title: Singapore stocks start week in the black ahead of Fed meeting; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks started the week in the black, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.1% to 3,282.05 points, driven by gains from marine engineering group Seatrium and several real estate investment trusts. The US Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates steady amid sticky inflation data, contributing to a broader regional market gain.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index advanced 0.77 per cent, while China’s blue-chip index edged 0.06 per cent higher on Monday morning.
The spread betwen US and Chinese 10-year yields of more than 200 basis points is nearly the widest in over 20 years.
Despite coming close to a technical correction, Japanese stocks remain a top bet for many thanks to the country’s growth revival and a push for corporate reform

The MSCI Emerging Markets Index finished the session 1.3% higher, with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., Tencent Holdings and Alibaba Group Holding accounting for the biggest chunk of its gains.

site_title: Abu Dhabi sovereign wealth fund plans debut dollar bond sale
summary: Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund ADQ is planning its debut dollar bond sale, following the emirate's government in the debt market. ADQ may issue US dollar-denominated, senior unsecured bonds with maturities of five and 10 years. This move comes after Abu Dhabi raised US$5 billion in eurobonds last week. The sale is part of ADQ's efforts to diversify its funding sources and explore new investment opportunities, including a potential US$500 million investment in Kenya.

site_title: Abu Dhabi developer Aldar posts 88% in Q1 leap
summary: Aldar Properties, Abu Dhabi's largest developer, reported a 88% leap in Q1 net profit to 1.57 billion UAE dirhams (S$581.3 million), surpassing analyst expectations of 1.03 billion dirhams. Revenue grew 83% year-over-year to 5.6 billion dirhams, driven by strong growth.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 29)
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed support for Indonesia's growth in the green economy, including sustainable development of Nusantara. A money launderer, Su Baolin, was sentenced to 14 months' jail. Great Eastern reported a 26% year-on-year increase in Q1 profit to S$306.7 million. Sembcorp Industries signed long-term power purchase agreements with Equinix. Health-tech startup Thrixen raised US$7 million. Singapore stocks started the week in the black ahead of the US Fed meeting, with the STI up 0.1%.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust posts 2.5% drop in Q4 DPU; manager warns of further headwinds
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust reported a 2.5% drop in Q4 distributions per unit (DPU) to 2.211 cents, citing high interest costs and weak regional currencies. The trust's full-year DPU rose 3.3% to S$447.1 million, while gross revenue increased 0.4% to S$733.9 million. Quarterly gross revenue rose 1.2% to S$181 million, but net property income (NPI) was weighed down by a 4.5% increase in property expenses to S$25.7 million.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Logistics Trust's divestment of the property at 73 Tuas South Avenue 1 is part of the manager's strategy to rejuvenate the portfolio through selective divestments.
Mapletree Logistics Hub – Jubli Shah Alam is located in Shah Alam, one of Malaysia’s major industrial regions with close proximity to Kuala Lumpur City Centre and Port Klang.

site_title: Shell earns US$1 billion a year from US crude trading, court filing shows
summary: Shell's US crude trading unit earns around $1 billion annually, accounting for 13-15% of its US pre-tax profits. The company does not disclose this financial performance, sparking investor concerns. Traders make money by buying and selling oil and gas, with bonuses often tied to performance. A recent court filing showed Shell's former employee, Eva-Maria Frohn, was awarded a $5 million bonus in 2020, while the company denied her breach of contract claim.

images.alt_text: Both companies intend to promote best practices in the design and construction of floating production systems.
Former Shell chief Ben van Beurden says there is a deeper pool of investors and capital in New York, and the attitude is more positive towards oil and gas companies.
Aramco believes the deal would position it as a global LNG player.

site_title: 😢 “I cry a lot, but I’m so productive”
summary: A recent article from Thrive Newsletter features an interview with Chloe Lim, who shares her productivity secrets despite experiencing frequent emotional breakdowns. Lim attributes her success to her ability to acknowledge and express her emotions, rather than suppressing them. She emphasizes the importance of self-care and emotional intelligence in achieving personal and professional goals. Lim's story serves as a reminder that mental health and emotional well-being are crucial for overall success and happiness.

images.alt_text: Employers need not fear hiring those who are neurodivergent. Viewing neurodivergence as a difference rather than a disability contributes to an inclusive workplace where people’s strengths are recognised and celebrated.

site_title: Thailand cuts growth outlook but pins hopes on Q4 stimulus boost
summary: Thailand revised its economic growth forecast to 2.4% for this year, down from 2.8% in January, citing weaker exports and manufacturing output. However, the finance ministry expects growth to reach 3.3% if the government's 500 billion baht stimulus plan is deployed in the fourth quarter. The plan, which includes a "digital wallet" handout scheme, aims to boost overall economic growth and is seen as a key factor in driving growth.

images.alt_text: People were advised to stay in the shade and avoid working for long hours under the sun. Deaths related to heat have risen to about 30 nationwide this year, according to the Ministry of Public Health.

Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin speaks during a presser regarding the government’s proposed 10,000 baht digital wallet scheme at Government House in Bangkok on April 10, 2024. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)
Pichai Chunhavajira, who was Srettha’s advisor, resigned as the chair of the board of Bangchak Corporation earlier on Thursday (Apr 25).

The policy received Cabinet approval on Tuesday, clearing another hurdle for the government to roll out the stimulus plan, which would give 10,000 baht to each of 50 million Thais to spend in their communities in a six month period.
The Bank of Thailand left its key interest rate unchanged for a third straight meeting on April 10.

site_title: Money launderer Su Baolin sentenced to 14 months’ jail
summary: Su Baolin, a money launderer, was sentenced to 14 months in jail for 3 charges related to forgery, fraud, and money laundering. He initially faced 13 charges but agreed to forfeit 90% of his seized assets, valued at around S$65 million. Su was found guilty of operating an unlawful remote gambling operation, earning around S$4 million in cryptocurrency, and abetting a director to cheat IRAS. His other charges were related to money laundering, forgery, and attempting to cheat the government.

images.alt_text: Su Baolin was arrested on Aug 15, 2023, along with nine other foreign nationals. Over S$130 million worth of assets in his and his wife’s names have been seized.
The 99-year leasehold site, which was being advertised at a guide price of S$27.1 million.

Vang's charges ranged from allegedly possessing S$2.4 million in criminal benefits generated from unlicensed moneylending operations in China, to submitting a forged bank statement to Citibank Singapore.

site_title: Philips pays US$1.1 billion in US settlement over ventilator recall
summary: Philips has agreed to pay $1.1 billion in a US settlement related to the global recall of ventilators used to treat sleep apnea. The devices were recalled in 2021 due to concerns over potential cancer risks. The company did not admit fault or liability but the settlement will end uncertainty over US litigation. Philips also reached an agreement with insurers for 540 million euros in product liability costs and booked a provision of 982 million euros for the settlement payments.

images.alt_text: The new issue identified by the FDA involves a humidifier used in the Philips “DreamStation 2” sleep therapy device.
New orders were down 9 per cent from last year, as demand from China continued to cool from a pre-pandemic boom and supply chain problems persisted.

site_title: Health-tech startup Thrixen bags US$7 million from 22Health Ventures, Aldevron co-founder
summary: Thrixen, a Singapore-based health-tech startup, has secured US$7 million in funding from 22Health Ventures and Aldevron co-founder John Ballantyne. The investment will support the development of its diagnostic technology platform, which aims to perform multiplex diagnostic tests at the point of care for the first time. The platform has shown 99.5% sensitivity in clinical trials and can distinguish between bacterial and viral infections using a finger-prick sample within 10 minutes. The funding will also provide accelerated access to the US market and management guidance.

images.alt_text: PremjiInvestis among the first large Indian asset managers to use AI tools in the private equity space.
TikTok fuels growth for more than seven million businesses in the US.
Confidence in the global economy has strengthened this year, backed mainly by US growth and recent signs of a rebound in China.
Microsoft chief executive officer Satya Nadella says: “Artificial intelligence is the most transformative technology of our time, and we must ensure it is deployed safely and responsibly.”

site_title: So long, farewell, and thanks for all the tips
summary: Garage, a Singapore-based startup newsletter, is concluding its five-year run. The team has highlighted some of its most notable stories, including the collapse of Flash Coffee, Biofourmis' layoffs, and the closure of Tessa Therapeutics. The newsletter also profiled startup founders and investors, and documented the changing landscape of the Singapore startup ecosystem. As Garage ends, readers are encouraged to sign up for Tech in Asia's daily newsletter for continued startup and tech news.

images.alt_text: The comic strip, produced by then-Garage editor-in-charge Kenneth Lim, that marked the vertical’s launch in May 2019.
Singapore companies have been building sleek robots that do everything from patrolling buildings to delivering food in restaurants, writes Garage correspondent Claudia Chong.
search for profitability is a common mantra that almost all late-stage startups have been chanting as they navigate a funding crunch.
With AI on the rise, investors are keeping a close eye on the deep-tech sector.
A key missing piece in the funding picture is large deals of over US$100 million, a sign that late-stage deals are not coming through.

site_title: Singapore, Indonesia to deepen cooperation on green economy
summary: Singapore and Indonesia have strengthened their cooperation on a green economy, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and President Joko Widodo discussing investments in Indonesia's new capital Nusantara, a green capital city. The two countries agreed to collaborate on clean energy power generation, carbon capture and storage, and carbon credits. They also signed a memorandum of understanding to work together on community empowerment activities related to mangrove ecosystems. Singapore has expressed interest in investing in Nusantara, with companies like Sembcorp Industries already involved in a joint venture to build a large-scale integrated solar project. The bilateral relationship remains a key one for both countries, with economic ties being a main pillar.

images.alt_text: The outgoing and incoming leaders of both Singapore and Indonesia met on Monday (Apr 29) at a leaders' retreat in Bogor, Indonesia.
Singapore’s Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan (right) meets President-elect and Minister of Defence Prabowo Subianto on the first day of his four-day working visit.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong with Indonesian President Joko Widodo at the Singapore-Indonesia Leaders' Retreat on Mar 16, 2023.

site_title: Blackstone beats Concord with US$1.6 billion bid for Hipgnosis Songs
summary: Blackstone has agreed to acquire Hipgnosis Songs Fund for approximately US$1.57 billion, surpassing Concord's US$1.4 billion offer. The deal, valued at US$1.30 per share, includes over 65,000 songs by artists such as Blondie and Neil Young. Hipgnosis shares rose 2.7% after the announcement, as the company's board withdrew its recommendation for Concord's offer.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A headset is seen in front of displayed Hipgnosis logo in this illustration taken, June 28, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

Hipgnosis - co-founded in 2018 by legendary guitarist and producer Nile Rodgers and Merck Mercuriadis, the former manager of Beyonce and Elton John - manages the rights to more than 150 of the world’s biggest song catalogues.
FILE PHOTO: A headset is seen in front of displayed Hipgnosis logo in this illustration taken, June 28, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Without a game changer, Sentosa Cove condos will continue underperforming
summary: Sentosa Cove condos in Singapore are struggling to appeal to local owner-occupiers, with recent sales at The Residences at W Singapore Sentosa Cove fetching an average price of S$1,780 per square foot, 36% below the initial launch price. The development's low price is attributed to the 81 years remaining on its 99-year leasehold land, which is worth around 4.8% less than a similar land parcel with 99 years of land lease outstanding. To improve Sentosa Cove's fortunes, some experts suggest increasing its appeal to locals buying for owner occupation, potentially by introducing a primary school or other educational institutions.

images.alt_text: CDL unit sells 65 units of The Residences at W Sentosa after slashing prices
The 99-year leasehold site, which was being advertised at a guide price of S$27.1 million.

site_title:
India tech tycoon’s family office bets 
on AI to prop US$10 billion fund
summary: Premji Invest, a US$10 billion Indian family office, is betting on AI to identify investment opportunities globally, using a proprietary AI investment tool that scours over 10,000 companies on 600 parameters. The asset manager plans to invest more in AI companies and develop an AI quant model for public market bets. With exponential returns, Premji Invest is scouting for investment targets in the US with the latest technologies that can be brought to India, and will allocate more assets to technology and financial services sectors.

images.alt_text: Systems based on AI have the potential to revolutionise industries from healthcare to logistics, but replacing human judgment with machine learning carries risks.
Across the US, utilities are preparing for historic increases in electricity demand led by data centres and AI.

site_title: Saudi National Bank posts marginal rise in Q1 profit
summary: Saudi National Bank (SNB) posted a 0.4% rise in Q1 net profit to 5.04 billion riyals (S$1.82 billion), beating analysts' estimate of 4.97 billion riyals. The bank's net result was partially offset by higher operating expenses, including a 52% increase in net impairment charges. Loans and advances rose 10.4% to 625.2 billion riyals, while customer deposits grew 7.4% to 656.3 billion riyals. The bank's new CEO, Tareq Abdulrahman Al Sadhan, will start his role on May 1.

images.alt_text: The logo of the Saudi National Bank (SNB) can be seen at the banks' headquarters in Riyadh on March 27, 2023, after the chairman of SNB, the main shareholder of troubled lender Credit Suisse which was bought out this month, resigned. (Photo by Fayez Nureldine / AFP)

site_title: PetroChina profit rises as economic recovery remains uneven
summary: PetroChina reported its highest first-quarter profit with net income of 45.7 billion yuan (S$8.58 billion), up 4.1% from the same period last year. The company's drilling and natural gas segments drove the increase, offsetting declines in refining and marketing. Global oil prices were slightly lower, and looser rules for domestic natural gas prices contributed to the profit. PetroChina's output increased 1.4% for oil and 3.9% for gas, as China's economy continues its uneven recovery from Covid-era restrictions.

images.alt_text: PetroChina’s net profit amounted to 161.1 billion yuan (S$30.1 billion) in 2023, versus 148.7 billion in 2022, while revenue fell 7.0 per cent to 3,239 billion yuan.

site_title: KFC shutters over 100 restaurants in Malaysia amid pro-Palestine boycott
summary: KFC Malaysia has shut down over 100 restaurants due to a pro-Palestine boycott sparked by the ongoing war in Gaza. The boycott, led by the Boycott, Divestment, Sanctions (BDS) Malaysia group, has led to a decline in customer traffic, prompting the company to temporarily close outlets nationwide. KFC has shifted its branding strategy to emphasize its ownership by the Johor state government to mitigate the boycott. The move affects more than 600 KFC restaurants in Malaysia, with the worst-affected being Northeast Kelantan state.

images.alt_text: Fast-food traffic worsened in the fourth quarter, with KFC and Pizza Hut seeing declines of 4.8 per cent and 2.6 per cent, respectively.

site_title: Agri-food’s transition from a liability for sustainability into an asset
summary: The agri-food industry, a significant contributor to greenhouse gas emissions and deforestation, can be transformed into a net-positive asset with the right investments. Current solutions, such as precision agriculture and alternative proteins, can reduce emissions and biodiversity impacts, but more investment is needed. A $200-500 billion investment can generate a $5 trillion economic windfall in net benefits. The financial sector can facilitate this transition by offering financing options, convening stakeholders, and engaging with large food companies and commodity traders. However, public authorities must lead the change by aligning agricultural subsidies with sustainability goals and driving industry and consumer practices.

images.alt_text: Pests are responsible for around 10 per cent – or 21 million tonnes – of crop losses every year, but controlling them has lead to the widespread use of chemical pesticides.

site_title: Indonesia’s Q1 FDI up 16% at 204.4 trillion rupiah despite political uncertainty
summary: Indonesia's foreign direct investment (FDI) in the first quarter of 2024 reached 204.4 trillion rupiah, a 16% increase from the previous year. The country's largest foreign investor, Singapore, committed 12,112 projects valued at US$4.24 billion, accounting for 31% of total FDI. Despite ongoing political uncertainty, the government expects investors to actualize a significant portion of their investments in the second quarter, with growth exceeding 15%. The ban on nickel exports has driven FDI into manufacturing, infrastructure, and mineral downstreaming.

images.alt_text: The outgoing and incoming leaders of both Singapore and Indonesia met on Monday (Apr 29) at a leaders' retreat in Bogor, Indonesia.

site_title: Sembcorp announces long-term power purchase agreements with Equinix
summary: Sembcorp Industries has signed two long-term power purchase agreements with Equinix, increasing its contracted capacity for gas-fired power generation in Singapore to 77% from 74%. The agreements, worth 75MWp and 30MW, will be accretive to earnings in the 2024 financial year. The renewable energy PPA will be sourced from solar panels installed across 1,290 HDB blocks and 99 government sites, contributing over 3 million megawatt hours of renewable energy annually.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Energy Storage System (ESS) at Banyan in Jurong Island, on Feb 2, 2023.

site_title: BYD shares face earnings test as China’s EV price war heats up
summary: BYD, China's largest EV maker, faces an earnings test as it battles to maintain profitability amid a price war in the country's EV market. Despite cutting prices on mass-market models, BYD is expected to post its lowest sales growth in four years and a declining gross profit margin. The company's growth in higher-end models and overseas sales are key points to watch, with targets of selling 500,000 vehicles outside China this year and doubling that in 2025.

images.alt_text: More than 110 new energy vehicle models among a total of 150 new cars are expected to be launched this year, intensifying competition.
China’s biggest automaker unveiled the Super 3 and Bao 8 SUVS at its Shenzhen headquarters on Tuesday (Apr 16) night in a glitzy livestreamed event.
While BYD vehicles are not available in the US, the automaker has been pushing into markets in Asia, Australia and South America, where pickups are popular.

site_title: China’s Xi to visit France, Serbia and Hungary, aims to boost EU ties
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping will visit France, Serbia, and Hungary from May 5-10, aiming to boost EU ties amid tensions. Xi seeks to push the China-France partnership to a new level, enhancing trust and cooperation. The visit comes as China-EU relations have soured due to trade disputes, with France backing an EU anti-subsidy probe into Chinese electric vehicles. Xi also aims to upgrade China's relations with Serbia and Hungary, particularly in promoting the Belt and Road initiative.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping (C) holds a meeting with US Secretary of State Antony Blinken (3rd L) at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on April 26, 2024. (Photo by Mark Schiefelbein / POOL / AFP)
China’s central bank has not made a significant bond purchase since 2007.

China's President Xi Jinping attends the closing session of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on March 10, 2024. (Photo by GREG BAKER / AFP)

“China’s export of electric vehicles, lithium batteries and solar products have enriched supplies to the global market and eased inflationary pressure, as well as made a great contribution for global efforts to tackle climate change and green transition,” President Xi told Chancellor Olaf Scholz.
Xi Jinping has pledged to bring Taiwan under China's control someday, by force if necessary.

US President Joe Biden (right) and China's President Xi Jinping (left) have managed to maintain a veneer of diplomatic stability despite deep mutual suspicion between their countries, and as their governments pursue export controls, sanctions and tariffs.

site_title: Tesla clears key regulatory hurdles for self-driving in China during Musk’s visit
summary: Tesla has cleared key regulatory hurdles to roll out its self-driving software in China, paving the way for a favorable outcome from Elon Musk's visit. The company has reached an agreement with Baidu to use the Chinese tech giant's mapping license for data collection, and its Model 3 and Y cars have been found to be compliant with China's data security requirements. This clears the way for Tesla to transfer driving data overseas, a key step for Full Self-Driving (FSD) software to be introduced in the country.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk’s target of a new car in a year was seen as optimistic at best by many investors and analysts.
Several companies have been betting on humanoid robots to meet potential labour shortages and perform repetitive tasks.
Tesla reported profits of US$1.1 billion, down 55 per cent from the year-ago quarter on revenues of US$21.3 billion, down nine per cent as the company described EV sales as “under pressure.”
The reductions include 2,688 workers in Austin, where the electric vehicle maker is headquartered and has a major factory.

site_title: Church to tackle US housing crisis
summary: The Inglewood First United Methodist Church in California is launching an affordable housing initiative by building 60 studio apartments, with 30 units reserved for older adults, on its property. The church aims to address the US housing crisis and provide below-market-rate rents. This project is part of a growing trend of faith organizations developing low-cost housing, following California's passage of SB 4, which allows non-profit institutions to build up to 30 units per acre in major cities with affordable housing requirements.

images.alt_text: The Central Park Tower residential skyscraper at 217 West 57th Street, center, along Billionaires' Row in the Midtown neighborhood of New York, U.S., on Sunday, Nov. 14, 2021. Midtown is the only section of the borough where new-development sales are lagging behind their pre-pandemic performance. Photographer: Amir Hamja/Bloomberg

site_title: US lawmakers strike deal to boost aviation safety, will not hike pilot retirement age
summary: US lawmakers have reached a deal to boost aviation safety by increasing air traffic controller staffing and funding to prevent runway close call incidents. The deal does not include a hike in the airline pilot retirement age to 67, contrary to a previous House vote. The bipartisan proposal, part of a new $105 billion, five-year deal for the Federal Aviation Administration, is set to be voted on by the Senate this week. The agreement aims to address safety concerns and support the aviation industry.

site_title: SK Innovation expects solid Q2 refining margins, battery unit widen losses
summary: SK Innovation expects solid Q2 refining margins due to firm demand, backed by Opec+ cuts and improved travel demand. The company posted an operating profit of 625 billion won for the January to March period, despite a 1.5% fall in revenue. SK On, its battery unit, widened its operating loss to 332 billion won in the first quarter due to weaker electric vehicle demand. Analysts suggest the company needs to broaden its product lineup to meet the needs of automakers diversifying EV battery types to lower costs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of SK Innovation is seen in front of its headquarters in Seoul, South Korea, February 3, 2017. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo
SK says it expects economic stimulus measures and firmer travel demand backed by the Chinese New Year holiday in China to push up refining margins.
The company is boosting its exposure to the EV battery market as it bets on a faster-than-expected electrification of cars.

site_title: Singapore’s Geniebook edutech startup seizes Vietnam opportunities
summary: Singapore-based edutech startup Geniebook is expanding its presence in Vietnam, a market that raised over $30 million in edutech investments in 2023. The company's platform provides personalized learning to students across Singapore, Vietnam, and Malaysia, leveraging AI and live classes. Geniebook's CEO Neo Zhizhong will share his experience at the upcoming Saigon Summit, highlighting the country's young and tech-savvy demographic and government investment in education. The company has seen a strong response from students and parents, with steady revenue growth, and aims to become a bridge to international opportunities for Vietnamese students.

images.alt_text: Students, who range from factory owners to fresh graduates, often take classes for multiple foreign shopping platforms including Amazon and South-east Asia’s Shopee.
Nearly 900 students from other South-east Asian countries are enrolled at Singapore Management University.
Since 2023, many tutoring firms that have gone international have strengthened their offline offerings to keep up with demand and cut costs.

site_title: Perpetual in talks with KKR for corporate trust and wealth management unit sale
summary: Perpetual, an Australian financial services firm, is in exclusive talks with KKR & Co for the potential sale of its corporate trust and wealth management business. A deal would allow KKR to expand its investment management footprint in Australia and Perpetual to become an asset management business. This comes after top shareholder Washington H Soul Pattinson made a rejected A$3.1 billion bid in December, which called for the separation of Perpetual's asset management business. The talks have exclusivity until May 7, with no certainty that an agreement will be reached.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the Blackstone Group headquarters in New York City, U.S., January 18, 2023. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon/File Photo
India has become a key market for HSBC as it looks to expand its operations in Asia.
Evergreen funds are gaining in popularity among private credit managers as a way to raise capital.

site_title: Chinese property developer Kaisa’s liquidation hearing adjourned to May 27
summary: A Hong Kong court adjourned a hearing to liquidate Kaisa Group to May 27, as the embattled Chinese property developer said it aims to iron out restructuring terms with bondholders within four weeks. Kaisa has been working on an offshore debt restructuring for two years after defaulting on $12 billion of offshore debt in 2021. The company's lawyer stated progress had been made in negotiations with the ad hoc group of bondholders.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of Chinese developer Country Garden is pictured in Tianjin, China August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
The accounting regulator will look into  alleged deficiencies in PwC’s systems of quality management and the quality of its audits of Evergrande.
A China Vanke development in Hefei, China. Source: Bloomberg
China’s property sector has been in crisis since 2021 after a regulatory crackdown on high leverage among developers triggered a liquidity crisis.
Contracted sales for March were 24.5 billion yuan (S$4.6 billion), Vanke says. That represents a 43 per cent decline from a year earlier.
At least 23 Chinese builders or related companies have so far received wind-up petitions in Hong Kong from creditors since the beginning of the real estate crisis.

The high number of projects already approved for possible support highlights the Chinese government’s efforts to free up funding for the debt-riddled industry, although it is unclear how many will secure loans.
Never in recent memory has a bankruptcy judge in Hong Kong, the de-facto home for such cases, earned a reputation for holding deadbeat companies to account quite like Linda Chan.
With US$12 billion of offshore debt, Kaisa is China’s largest issuer of offshore debt among developers after China Evergrande Group.
Shih Wing Ching, chairman of Centaline, says local governments should be banned from selling land.

site_title: Foodpanda doubles down on quick commerce with house-brand grocery products
summary: Foodpanda is launching a new house-brand grocery line called Bright, offering affordable products with delivery within an hour. The platform aims to meet the three principles of affordability, local relevance, and convenience. Bright has 250 products in Singapore and 1,200 across eight countries, with 50% of foodpanda's orders including at least one Bright product. The brand's success may put it in direct competition with its partner DFI Retail Group, but Zagolin sees it as targeting mid-week grocery top-ups. The focus on volume and operational efficiency may aid foodpanda's path to profitability.

images.alt_text: Delivery Hero, which owns foodpanda, has been trying to divest its loss-making South-east Asian business in a wider effort to reach profitability while maintaining growth.
Angele (left), who was with foodpanda for nine years, has been replaced by John Fang, who most recently served as chief international officer.
From left: Sng Ren Yeong, director of yuu Rewards Club's minden.ai, together with Lawrence Wen, CEO of Foodpanda Singapore and Yoep Man, managing director, food at DFI Retail Group.

site_title: Dubai begins construction of ‘world’s largest’ airport terminal
summary: Dubai has begun construction on a new terminal at Al Maktoum International Airport, which will become the world's largest at a cost of $35 billion. The terminal will have a capacity to handle 260 million passengers annually and is expected to be five times the size of the current Dubai International Airport. The project's first phase is expected to be completed within 10 years, with a capacity to accommodate 150 million passengers annually. The new terminal aims to replace Dubai International Airport, which is currently the busiest air hub in the city.

images.alt_text: Al Maktoum International Airport in Dubai. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg
Vehicles are stranded in flood waters along a highway in Dubai following heavy rains on April 18, 2024
Dubai is seeking to grow its economy through tourism, building a local financial centre and by attracting foreign capital, including into property.

site_title: Chinese bonds dodge global debt sell-off  as yield gap widens
summary: China's sovereign bonds have defied a global debt sell-off, with the nation's benchmark 10-year yield dropping 23 basis points this year, while US Treasury yields have jumped 78 basis points. The spread between US and Chinese 10-year yields is near the widest in over 20 years, driven by China's differing economic cycle and central bank's easing policy to support growth. Despite a recent slowdown in bond prices, analysts expect yields to remain low in the long term due to weak credit demand and ongoing efforts to address local government debt risks.

images.alt_text: A branch of the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) in eastern China has informally asked some institutions to reduce bond duration and focus on their core businesses
The Fed has yet to move, but just the expectation of far fewer rate cuts in 2024 than earlie anticipated is enough to cause bond prices to fall and yields to rise.

site_title: Asia: Shares rise as Fed looms large; yen crumbles below key level
summary: Asian stocks rose on Monday ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, with the Hang Seng Index advancing 0.77% and China's blue-chip index edging 0.06% higher. The dollar surged to a 34-year high of 160.245 yen, driven by expectations of higher US interest rates and thinned liquidity in Japan. Despite the yen's slide, Tokyo has resisted intervening in the currency market. The Fed's meeting is expected to keep rates on hold, with market pricing showing a first rate cut in September and a more dovish tone than expected.

images.alt_text: The greenback bought 160.17 yen in morning trade, fanning speculation that Japanese authorities would step in to support their currency.
The Australian dollar surged 1.1 per cent to 104.58 yen, the highest since 2013, after jumping 1.9 per cent on Friday.
Across the broader market,

site_title: Indonesia to drive the growth of Asean’s green economy: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed confidence that Indonesia will drive the growth of South-east Asia's green economy, with the two countries cooperating on carbon credits. During a leaders' retreat in Bogor, Indonesia, Lee and Indonesian President Joko Widodo signed a memorandum of understanding to promote sustainable mangrove ecosystems and a bilateral framework for cooperation on community empowerment activities. Investments from Singapore to Indonesia have exceeded $74 billion, and 29 Singaporean companies have expressed interest in investing in Indonesia's new capital, Nusantara.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong with Indonesian President Joko Widodo at the Singapore-Indonesia Leaders' Retreat on Mar 16, 2023.
Singapore’s Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan (right) meets President-elect and Minister of Defence Prabowo Subianto on the first day of his four-day working visit.
During his campaign, Prabowo managed to turn his image into one that appealed to the young as a likeable uncle.
Bambang Susantono, chairman of Indonesia Nusantara Capital Authority shows Indonesia's future capital Nusantara layout in a presentation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Keppel, Great Eastern, Seatrium, Best World
summary: Several Singaporean companies announced significant developments on Monday, April 29. Singtel expects to recognize around S$3.1 billion in exceptional non-cash impairment provisions for the second half year. Keppel will issue 70 million euros in floating-rate notes, while Great Eastern's insurance arm posted a 26% year-on-year increase in profit to S$306.7 million. Seatrium announced a S$100 million share buyback program, and Best World International's shareholders raised questions about dividend payouts and director compensation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman using a mobile phone walks behind a Singtel signage at their head office in Singapore February 11, 2016.  REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo

site_title: Norway sovereign wealth fund backs HSBC bonus policy reform
summary: HSBC's sovereign wealth fund, Norway's $1.6 trillion fund, will support the bank's proposed bonus policy change for material risk takers (MRTs), allowing for full discretion over bonuses. This comes after Britain scrapped EU rules capping MRT bonuses. The move is expected to increase HSBC's ability to recruit and retain employees, particularly those based outside the EU. The bank's annual shareholder meeting on May 3 will vote on the resolution.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars jump to decade-highs against weakened yen
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars reached decade-highs against the weakened Japanese yen, with the Aussie surging 1.1% to 104.58 yen and the kiwi dollar jumping 1% to 95.00 yen. The gains are attributed to the Bank of Japan's dovish stance and diverging interest rate outlooks between Australia and New Zealand. Traders await economic data releases to gauge policy direction, with analysts predicting potential interest rate hikes in Australia and rate cuts in New Zealand.

images.alt_text: As Golden Week gets underway this week, local travellers are opting for Kochi in the south, Atami near Tokyo and other popular spots such as Okinawa and Hokkaido.
The dollar hit 157.795 yen on Friday, the highest since June 1990.
A weak currency spells trouble for local consumers and businesses in the Philippines, especially since the country is a net importer.
The yen hovered around 156.12 in afternoon trade after weakening as much as 156.16 per dollar.
The core consumer price index in Tokyo, a leading indicator of nationwide figures, increased 1.6 per cent in April from a year earlier, slowing from a 2.4 per cent gain in March.
Early on Friday, one dollar bought 155.58 yen, compared with 155.74 the previous day - a level not seen since 1990.

site_title: Singtel falls 2.5% after announcing S$3.1 billion impairment hit
summary: Singtel fell 2.5% after announcing a S$3.1 billion impairment hit, mainly due to its Australian subsidiary Optus' expected non-cash impairment provisions. The group expects to record A$540 million in non-cash impairment provisions on its enterprise fixed assets and A$2 billion on goodwill. However, Singtel's dividend payment and underlying net profit for the full-year period remain unaffected. The impairment is attributed to weaker prospects in Optus' enterprise market, increased cost of capital, and a softer macroeconomic outlook in Australia.

images.alt_text: Singtel is trading as the top traded counter as at 9.31 am.
Singtel expects to receive Nvidia’s GB200 Grace Blackwell Superchips in early 2025.

site_title: Japan’s proposed export curbs will impact normal trade, China says
summary: Japan's proposed export curbs on advanced materials and equipment for military applications will significantly impact normal trade between China and Japan, according to China's commerce ministry. The move, aimed at preventing the diversion of sensitive technology, may undermine the global supply chain stability. China urged Japan to rectify the "erroneous practices" and will take necessary measures to protect its legitimate rights and interests.

site_title: Heat wave in South-east Asia closes schools, triggers health alerts
summary: A heat wave in South-east Asia has prompted health alerts and school closures across several countries, including Thailand, the Philippines, and Vietnam. Temperatures are expected to soar to record highs, with Thailand's northern and northeastern regions reaching 44°C and the Philippines forecast to reach 37°C. The heat wave has triggered heat stroke cases, with 30 deaths reported in Thailand this year. Power grids are also under pressure, with the Philippines warning of potential overloading.

images.alt_text: A woman shelters from the sun as she walks along a street on a hot day in Yangon on April 25, 2024. Extreme heat is scorching parts of South and Southeast Asia, prompting health warnings from authorities as high temperatures are recorded across the region. (Photo by Sai Aung MAIN / AFP)
Vietnam accounts for about a third of the world’s supply of robusta beans, which are typically used for instant drinks and espresso coffee.

A worker spreads burning straw on the ground in a vineyard to create a smoke screen to keep temperatures above 0 deg C and prevent vines from freezing due to a cold wave hitting the region near Saint-Emilion, France, April 23, 2024.
The Bangkok’s environment department warned the heat index was at an “extremely dangerous” level.

site_title: Vietnam’s inflation advances to 15-month high amid FX, gold pressures
summary: Vietnam's inflation rose to a 15-month high of 4.4% year-on-year in April, driven by rising food, transport, housing, and healthcare costs. This is faster than the 4% recorded in March and the highest April pace since 2014. Despite the economic recovery and inflation within target, analysts expect the State Bank of Vietnam to hold policy rates for the rest of the year. The country's trade turnover maintained double-digit growth in April, with exports up 10.6% and a trade surplus of around $8.4 billion.

images.alt_text: The price of gold in Vietnam has skyrocketed.

site_title: Japan’s yen jumps against the dollar on suspected intervention
summary: Japan's yen surged against the dollar on April 29, 2024, with the currency reaching 155.01 yen per dollar, a 3.5% increase. The sharp move is attributed to suspected intervention by Japanese authorities to prop up the currency, which has fallen 11% against the dollar this year to 34-year lows. The yen's plunge has come despite Japan exiting negative interest rates last month, with traders betting on low interest rates for the foreseeable future. The move comes ahead of the US Federal Reserve's May 1 policy review, which investors expect may be delayed due to market uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar surged 1.1 per cent to 104.58 yen, the highest since 2013, after jumping 1.9 per cent on Friday.

site_title: Gold eases as steady US dollar dampens appeal
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $2,328.20 per ounce as the US dollar strengthened, making bullion less affordable for overseas buyers. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate cut expectations remain unchanged, with policymakers awaiting further inflation data. China's gold consumption rose 6% in the first quarter, while physical gold dealers in India charged premiums for the first time in nearly two months. Spot silver, platinum, and palladium also declined.

images.alt_text: Top consumer China’s net gold imports via Hong Kong jumped 40 per cent in March from the previous month, data showed.

site_title: CICC cutting dealmakers’ base pay by 25%, sources say
summary: China International Capital Corp (CICC) is cutting the base pay of onshore investment bankers by as much as 25% amid volatile markets and Beijing's austerity drive. The move affects over 2,000 bankers, following a similar 40% reduction in bonuses last year. The cuts are part of a broader effort by Chinese financial firms to reduce costs, with some also considering job cuts at its offshore investment banking unit in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: CICC is slashing bonuses after a tough year that saw profit drop by 30 per cent.
The PBOC hasn’t yet released the figures for June, but said the overall amount of mortgages has decreased slightly.
Citic Securities Co. Ltd, China's financial company.
Brokerages have stepped up cost-cutting efforts after some scaled back travel perks last year.
“Snowballs” are derivatives in which investors receive a bond-like coupon if the underlying assets, such as the CSI500 and CSI1000 indexes, do not hit a pre-determined “knock-in” level.
Most of China’s 29 listed Reits are backed by infrastructure assets such as industrial parks, tollways and sewage treatment plants.
CICC estimated that loans to first-home buyers account for about 80 per cent - 90 per cent of total outstanding mortgages.

Chinese President Xi Jinping launched the "common prosperity" drive in 2021 to reduce income inequality, which could threaten long-term economic growth and even the legitimacy of Communist Party rule.
Property investment likely contracted further in July, taking the decline in the first seven months of the year to 8 per cent compared with the same period last year.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit divests two assets for 7.2 million euros
summary: Cromwell E-Reit has divested two assets, a 6,191.4 sqm property in Finland and a complex of three buildings in Italy, for 7.2 million euros. The sale proceeds will be used to repay the Reit's revolving credit facility or for working capital purposes. The divestments reduce Cromwell E-Reit's exposure to Poland and Finland by 1.7 percentage points, increasing its logistics and light industrial weighting to 53.2%.

images.alt_text: Cromwell E-Reit's distribution will be paid on Mar 28 after record date on Mar 5.

The results bring the Reit's year-to-date DPU to 11.795 euro cents.

site_title: A helping (robotic) hand
summary: Singapore companies are building sleek robots for various tasks, including patrolling buildings and delivering food, contributing to the global expansion of the service robot market. A national robotics programme launched eight years ago has helped put the country on the map. Meanwhile, the telemedicine industry has evolved, with startups expanding services beyond general consultations and investing in physical assets and wellness medicine. A new initiative, RoboCluster, aims to develop more commercialized technologies through collaboration between researchers, end-users, and robotics companies.

images.alt_text: search for profitability is a common mantra that almost all late-stage startups have been chanting as they navigate a funding crunch.

site_title: Inflation overshadows US economic resilience, hurting Biden
summary: The US economy showed resilience, with growth and jobs remaining strong, but inflation continues to overshadow President Biden's economic record. The latest GDP report revealed a weak headline number, but economists noted underlying momentum remained strong. Inflation, which had declined since June 2022, has now flattened, and core PCE rose by 3.7% in the first quarter, its first acceleration in a year. This has led the Federal Reserve to reconsider interest rate reductions and may delay rate cuts. The Biden campaign is shifting focus to issues like abortion rights and protecting democracy, as inflation has damaged his standing with voters.

images.alt_text: Consumers expect prices will climb at an annual rate of 3.2 per cent over the next year, the highest since November and up from the 2.9 per cent expected in March.

Growth was largely supported by consumer spending.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage increased 11 basis points in the week ended Apr 19 to 7.24 per cent, the highest since Nov 24.

site_title: Hot stock: Seatrium up 5.6% on S$100 million share buyback programme
summary: Seatrium, an offshore and marine giant, announced a S$100 million share buyback programme, allowing it to repurchase up to 2% of its total issued shares. The programme, which could take over a year to complete, aims to align the company's interest with shareholders and increase shareholder returns. Following the announcement, Seatrium's shares rose 5.6% on the Singapore Exchange.

images.alt_text: The S$500 million bonds due 2026 are expected to be redeemed in full on May 27, 2024 and will be cancelled thereafter, the group said in a bourse filing.

site_title: Singapore stocks decline at Monday’s open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares declined at the opening bell on Monday, with the Straits Times Index falling 0.3% to 3,271.7, due to investors awaiting macroeconomic data. Despite gains in global markets, gainers outnumbered losers 57 to 45. Seatrium led gains, while Singtel and UOB had mixed performances. On Wall Street, stocks ended higher on Friday, driven by strong tech results, with the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 2% and the S&P 500 gaining 1%.

site_title: RBNZ says insurance may become unaffordable for high-risk homes
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) warns that insurance may become unaffordable for high-risk homes, particularly in earthquake-prone areas like Wellington. Insurers are adopting risk-based pricing, leading to higher costs for homeowners. The RBNZ predicts that some properties may be uninsurable due to the increasing risks of under-insurance. To mitigate this, the central bank advises banks to scrutinize lending decisions and work with insurers to obtain better insurance information on mortgaged properties.

images.alt_text: Slowing demand for imports is a symptom of a sluggish economy, as both households and companies feel the weight of high interest rates.
Reserve Bank of New Zealand's Ian Woolford said it would be the first digital form of New Zealand currency backed by the government and available to the public.
Recent data has raised the risk of an extended recession.

site_title: Powering optimal deals with innovation
summary: Deal activity is expected to pick up in the second half of 2024 as markets recover from a muted period, driven by abundant dry powder and converging valuation expectations. KPMG's Stephen Bates notes that integrating AI and human capabilities is key to achieving optimal results, with AI offering potential in automating tasks, developing predictive models, and identifying synergy in mergers and acquisitions. However, human expertise is indispensable, particularly in establishing trust and fostering relationships, making a seamless implementation of AI technology crucial for success.

images.alt_text: Amid the more demanding climate, the savviest tax leaders have recognised the importance of transformation, said Ajay Kumar Sanganeria, partner and head of tax at KPMG in Singapore

site_title: Zendaya helps ‘Challengers’ net top spot in North America box office
summary: Zendaya's tennis-based romance film "Challengers" topped the North American box office with an estimated US$15 million, thanks to her star power and director Luca Guadagnino's talents. The film follows a tennis prodigy who helps her husband prepare for a key match against her former lover. It was followed by Lionsgate's faith-based drama "Unsung Hero" at US$7.8 million and Warner Bros' "Godzilla x Kong: The New Empire" at US$7.2 million.

images.alt_text: "Civil War" starring Kirsten Dunst held on to its no. 1 spot at North American theatres.

The US film, television and animation industry employs some 550,000 people.
Australian director George Miller sharing a few early details about 'Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga' at the CinemaCon movie theater convention in Las Vegas on Monday.

site_title: How to handle populists: a CEO’s survival guide
summary: Western business leaders are adapting to volatile electoral politics worldwide, with many CEOs drafting compliments for leaders like Narendra Modi and Claudia Sheinbaum. However, few are thrilled about the prospect of Donald Trump's victory in the US elections, despite his talk of slashing red tape. The long-term trend is clear: politicians are more likely to trash free enterprise ideas than celebrate them. To navigate these uncertainties, companies are turning to specialist consultancies, consulting giants, and investment banks for guidance. Some firms are even courting favor by opening factories in India or hitching themselves to national champions. Despite these efforts, companies are still vulnerable to the whims of politicians and the risks of power.

images.alt_text: During his campaign, Prabowo managed to turn his image into one that appealed to the young as a likeable uncle.

Green-energy and cannabis stocks briefly became market darlings as the odds of a victory for Joe Biden rose in 2020.

site_title: Philippine peso nears critical 58-per-dollar mark amid regional currencies sell-off
summary: The Philippine peso has reached a 17-month low, hovering near 57.8 against the US dollar, amid a regional sell-off in currencies. The currency's decline is attributed to interest rate expectations and escalating geopolitical tensions. If it falls below 58, it may trigger intervention from the central bank. The Philippines' net importer status exacerbates the issue, posing trouble for local consumers and businesses. The peso's weakness is closely watched, with analysts warning of potential pressure on the currency if it underperforms its peers.

images.alt_text: The Indonesian rupiah breached the key 16,000 level to the US dollar on April 11, falling further beyond 16,200 to the greenback on April 16.

Ralph Recto says the Philippine economy is still expected to grow between 6 to 7 per cent this year even if the nation holds off reducing interest rates.

Philippines Finance Secretary Ralph Recto speaks during a press conference by the Intergovernmental Group of Twenty-Four on International Monetary Affairs and Development (G-24) during the IMF-World Bank Group spring meetings at the IMF headquarters in Washington, DC, on April 16, 2024. site_title: Iran-Israel strife throws out a lifeline to shippers
summary: Escalating tensions between Israel and Iran have boosted global shipping rates, with war-risk premiums providing a floor under rates. The recent hijacking of MSC Aries in the Strait of Hormuz and ongoing disruptions in the Red Sea have led to rerouting of ships, adding weeks to journeys. Despite concerns, shipping companies have seen shares rise, with companies like Hapag-Lloyd and AP Moller-Maersk rebounding from March lows. The industry is optimistic, awaiting signs of strength in Chinese exports and alternative production hubs, but for now, even bad news is being used as an excuse to be optimistic.

Brent futures for June delivery fell 20 cents, or 0.2 per cent, to US$90.25 a barrel while West Texas Intermediate (WTI) futures for May delivery were down 33 cents, or 0.4 per cent, at US$85.33 a barrel by 0225 GMT.

site_title: Oil prices fall 1% on Israel-Hamas ceasefire talks, US inflation concerns
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Monday, erasing gains from Friday, as Israel-Hamas ceasefire talks eased fears of a wider conflict in the Middle East. US inflation data also dimmed the prospects of interest rate cuts, leading to a stronger US dollar and putting pressure on commodity prices. Brent crude futures fell to $88.50 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate futures fell to $83.01 a barrel. A potential invasion of Rafah by Israel has been put on hold in the event of a deal involving the release of Israeli hostages.

site_title: Mergers, closures, diversification: What is happening to Singapore’s cultivated meat sector?
summary: Singapore's cultivated meat sector has slowed down amid challenges in commercialization, cost pressures, and lack of clear consumer demand. Companies such as Eat Just and Avant Meats have scaled down or paused production, while others like Shiok Meats and Umami Bioworks have diversified their product offerings. The sector is expected to see more consolidation through mergers and acquisitions, with companies looking to pool resources and technical knowledge to bring about quicker technological breakthroughs and commercialization. Investors have become more conservative, and the sector faces challenges in scaling up technology quickly and bringing products to market.

images.alt_text: Meatiply's cultivated duck with skin, fat, and muscle layers - one of the company's three advanced cultivated meat technology prototypes.
Meatable is looking to sell its cultivated pork products in Singapore by Q2 2024, subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: Berlin kidnapping charge hangs over rise of Vietnam’s anti-graft enforcer
summary: Vietnam's Minister of Public Security, To Lam, is embroiled in a controversy surrounding the 2017 kidnapping of Trinh Xuan Thanh, former chairman of PetroVietnam Construction JSC. Thanh was allegedly kidnapped by Vietnamese authorities and later confessed to embezzlement. Lam's involvement in the kidnapping is unclear, but his anti-corruption campaign has ensnared hundreds of officials, including two deputy prime ministers. Lam is seen as a potential candidate for the presidency and is considered a powerful figure in the Communist Party, but his ascent is uncertain due to the fluid state of Vietnam's secretive politics.

images.alt_text: Truong My Lan, chair of major developer Van Thinh Phat, was found guilty this month of swindling cash from Saigon Commercial Bank (SCB) over a decade.
Vuong Dinh Hue, the head of Vietnam's National Assembly, has been asked to step down due to 'violations and shortcomings.
The new system will handle the settlement of transactions within a day, speeding up operations and facilitating trading, especially short selling.

site_title: China developer Cifi gets bondholder go-ahead on restructuring plan
summary: Cifi Holdings, a Chinese property developer, has reached an agreement with a key group of bondholders on a debt restructuring plan, worth around $3.3 billion to $4 billion. The proposal, which has received "in principle" approval from the bondholders holding 43% of Cifi's offshore debt, offers creditors a choice between a 85% haircut in cash or a mixture of new notes, loans, and shares with smaller or no haircuts. The move comes as many Chinese developers struggle with rising debt amid sluggish property sales.

site_title: Great Eastern reports 26% higher Q1 profit of S$306.7 million
summary: Great Eastern reported a 26% year-on-year increase in Q1 profit to S$306.7 million, driven by higher profit from its insurance business and favorable investment performance. Total weighted new sales rose 34% to S$524.2 million, while new embedded business value grew 21% to S$163.2 million. Group CEO Khor Hock Seng said the company will take "firm steps" to grow its business and create sustainable value for stakeholders.

images.alt_text: Great Eastern chairman Soon Tit Koon assured that its board has heard shareholders' concerns of falling returns, and will look into the suggestions they provided.

On GEH’s 21 per cent decline in the New Business Embedded Value for the Singapore market in 2023, the insurer attributed the dip mainly to the lower single premium sales as the inverted Singapore dollar yield curve has made shorter-term interest yielding investments more appealing than the insurer’s typical single premium products.
For the three quarters, the insurance group's net profit increased 65 per cent to S$617.4 million.

site_title: AIA’s first-quarter new business value rises 31%, announces US$2 billion buyback
summary: Hong Kong-based insurer AIA Group posted a 31% rise in its first-quarter value of new business (VONB) to US$1.33 billion, up from US$1.05 billion a year ago. The company also announced an additional US$2 billion share buyback. AIA's VONB is a key barometer for future growth, indicating strong expected profits from new premiums.

site_title: Bitcoin ETF bandwagon heads to Australia after US$53 billion haul in US
summary: Australia is poised for a wave of Bitcoin exchange-traded fund (ETF) launches, following the US and Hong Kong, amid a sharp crypto rebound that saw Bitcoin reach a record of almost US$74,000 last month. Issuers such as Van Eck Associates and BetaShares are seeking to capitalize on the trend, with the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) expected to approve the first spot-Bitcoin ETFs for the main board by the end of 2024. The US$53 billion amassed by US Bitcoin ETFs this year, including offerings from BlackRock and Fidelity Investments, is seen as evidence that digital assets are "here to stay."

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is set to be Asia’s first to accept cryptocurrency products as a mainstream investment tool, and the products have also received official regulatory approval from the Securities and Futures Commission.
Hong Kong already permits crypto-futures based ETFs and three have listed so far:
The launch of the Bitcoin memecoins took place following another high-profile event.
For some crypto fans, the halving will underscore bitcoin’s value as an increasingly scarce commodity.

site_title: Intel tumbles most in three months after tepid forecast
summary: Intel's stock tumbled 9.2% after the chipmaker reported lackluster earnings for the second quarter, with sales of $13 billion and a profit of 10 cents a share. The company's CEO, Pat Gelsinger, remains optimistic about the future, citing progress in its foundry business and the introduction of a new AI chip. However, the outlook suggests that Intel's efforts to revive the company will take more time and money. The company's manufacturing operations are expected to break even in the next couple of years, but its revenue and technological know-how remain lagging behind rivals.

images.alt_text: Beijing has introduced guidelines to phase out US chips from Intel and AMD from government personal computers and servers.
Intel has now switched over to using EUV tools, which will cover more and more production needs as older machines are phased out.
The package will support more than US$100 billion in US investments from Intel, including efforts to produce cutting-edge semiconductors at large-scale plants in Arizona and Ohio.

site_title: Hot stock: Don Agro surges after plans to sell 92.3% group assets for 4.5 billion roubles
summary: Don Agro International's shares surged 55.2% in early trading after the group announced plans to sell 92.3% of its assets, including four subsidiaries in Russia, for 4.5 billion roubles (S$66.4 million). The sale includes 65,000 hectares of land banks in Russia and is expected to unlock value in the four units, allowing the group to re-strategize its financial and capital resources.

images.alt_text: New Delhi has imposed a 20 per cent export duty on parboiled rice exports in August 2023 to control domestic rice prices.
The current Senate’s term ends next month and the reduction in the powers of the chamber by 2024 had been written into the constitution.
The estimated income loss from climate change will be driven mainly by rising temperatures, which will affect agriculture, public health, productivity and more.
Farmers are increasingly turning to artificial intelligence to boost yields and returns with applications like self-driving tractors.

site_title: Temasek Trust launches advisory and management services initiative
summary: Temasek Trust has launched the TT Foundation Advisors (TTFA) to provide advisory and management services to impact organizations across Asia. Leveraging Temasek Trust's resources and networks, TTFA aims to be a "one-stop independent provider" for such organizations, offering insights, management training, and collaboration opportunities. The initiative is seen as a positive development for the regional philanthropic ecosystem, addressing shifting trends in impact measurement and environmental sustainability.

images.alt_text: Over 4,500 of Standard Chartered employees based in Singapore volunteered at least once in 2023.

Dr Amy Khor, Senior Minister of State for Sustainability and the Environment; Mr Wong Kee Joo, Chief Executive Officer, HSBC; and Prof Jeff Obbard, NYAA Climate Change Advisor,
moderated by Asst Prof Goh Jing Rong, Singapore Management University.

site_title: China firms go ‘underground’ on Russia payments as banks pull back
summary: China's big banks are pulling back from financing Russia-related transactions due to concerns over US sanctions, forcing some companies to turn to small banks and underground financing channels, including banned cryptocurrency. The US has imposed sanctions on Russia since its invasion of Ukraine in 2022, and China's foreign ministry denies any involvement in the sanctions. As a result, Chinese exporters are struggling to settle payments with Russian clients, with some companies resorting to waiting months to open accounts at rural banks along the border. The shift to underground channels carries significant risks, and the impact on China's economy and trade with Russia remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping (C) holds a meeting with US Secretary of State Antony Blinken (3rd L) at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on April 26, 2024. (Photo by Mark Schiefelbein / POOL / AFP)

Chinese policymakers already battling a protracted property crisis and weak demand at home have scant incentive to escalate tensions.

site_title: AI boom’s secret winners? The companies expected to power it
summary: The AI boom is driving historic increases in electricity demand in the US, particularly in data centers, with utilities preparing for significant growth. Companies such as Meta, Alphabet, and Microsoft are investing heavily in AI, leading to increased power consumption. The utilities sector, which has struggled in recent years, is expected to benefit from the AI surge, with Goldman Sachs creating investment baskets to play the trend. Investors are flocking to companies that will benefit from the increased demand, including those involved in grid upgrades, renewable energy, and data center equipment.

images.alt_text: Vantage has facilities in three parts of Hong Kong – Fo Tan, Kwai Chung and On Lok – and an office in Kowloon that it opened in 2022.

Mapletree Industrial Trust’s aggregate leverage ratio rose to 38.7 per cent as at March 2024, up from 37.4 per cent a year earlier. Interest coverage ratio, meanwhile fell to 4.6 times from 5 times over the same period.

site_title: Wanted: More and better data on private markets
summary: A survey of nearly 500 investment institutions worldwide by State Street found growing demand for data platforms to analyze private markets holdings. The survey highlighted challenges such as the cost of gathering data and the disparate nature of private markets. A quarter of respondents believed a data platform would be "transformational" for their operations, citing better risk measurement and financial metrics. Experts predict improvements in data availability may take 4-6 years, with regulatory requirements and increased transparency fueling data needs.

Market data shows private equity and private credit have significantly outperformed traditional asset classes in recent years.

site_title: Fading bets of early RBA cuts frustrate Albanese reelection plan
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's reelection plan faces challenges as sticky inflation pushes back the timetable for interest-rate relief. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) will hold its cash rate at a 12-year high of 4.35% for most of 2024, with the odds of monetary easing now seen in November instead of September. This frustrates Albanese's plan to call an early election to ride the momentum of rate cuts, and raises concerns about further financial stress for households.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) building in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday, Feb. 6, 2024. Australia’s central bank kept interest rates unchanged at its first meeting of a revamped policy schedule and signaled further tightening remains possible, sending the currency and bond yields higher. site_title: Weaker yen keeps Japanese tourists at home while visitors throng
summary: Japan's tourism industry is experiencing a resurgence as the country's weaker yen and domestic travelers opt for local destinations during Golden Week. Only 1.22 million Japanese tourists ventured abroad in March, a 36.8% decrease from 2019. In contrast, a record number of tourists visited Japan last month. Airlines are allocating more seats to inbound travelers and popular regions, indicating a recovery in outbound travel may not occur until next year. The government forecasts a recovery in outbound travel will not happen until next year at the earliest.

images.alt_text: The yen hovered around 156.12 in afternoon trade after weakening as much as 156.16 per dollar.
The core consumer price index in Tokyo, a leading indicator of nationwide figures, increased 1.6 per cent in April from a year earlier, slowing from a 2.4 per cent gain in March.

Service price moves are closely watched by the Bank of Japan as a key indicator of whether wages and inflation are rising in tandem, which it set as one of the prerequisites for raising interest rates.

The au Jibun Bank flash Japan manufacturing purchasing managers’ index (PMI) rose to 49.9 in April from 48.2 in March, remaining below the 50.0 threshold separating growth from contraction for 11 straight months.

site_title: Bond funds suffer as rate-cut hopes fade, but there is a silver lining
summary: Bond funds have suffered losses as rate-cut expectations fade, but higher yields are expected to cushion losses and help bonds finish 2024 in positive territory. The US Federal Reserve has yet to move, but the expectation of possibly zero cuts or far fewer cuts in 2024 has caused bond prices to fall and yields to rise. Despite this, strategists remain optimistic about fixed income, citing higher starting yields and the potential for diversification with equities. Asian high-yield bonds have seen positive returns, while Asian bond funds are expected to remain relatively resilient.

Can be used for stories on Singapore economy, business.
