site_title: Indonesia’s hawkish monetary stance; Vietnam not liking a gold rush
summary: Indonesia's central bank raised its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 6.25% to support the battered rupiah, amid a surge in inflation to 3.05% in March, the highest in seven months. Vietnam held its first gold auction in 11 years to stabilize the market amid record-high prices, while Malaysia plans to build the region's largest chip design park. Meanwhile, Thailand welcomed another China EV player to set up a production plant. Despite these moves, concerns about an impending Asian financial crisis persist, with currency volatility expected to persist due to the US Federal Reserve's "higher for longer" monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The Vietnam central bank has an exclusive right to produce gold bars. PHOTO: BT FILE

site_title: AirAsia discloses new listing plans under RM6.8 billion units merger
summary: AirAsia Group, the parent of Malaysian airline operator AirAsia, has announced plans to merge various airline affiliates under a new listing entity worth RM6.8 billion. The deal will see AirAsia X take over Capital A's aviation business and create a new company, allowing the airline to streamline operations and eliminate significant liabilities. The new entity, AirAsia Group, will operate low-cost air transportation services across Southeast Asia, with plans to conduct a private placement to raise RM1 billion and manage debt. The deal will also see AirAsia Bhd acquire Capital A's debt without paying a purchase price.

images.alt_text: The listing will allow CAPI to access the world’s most extensive and liquid capital markets, and enhance Capital A’s international credibility and presence, Group chief executive Tony Fernandes says.
AirAsia's net loss attributable for the three months ended in December is RM159.6 million (S$45.2 million), compared to a profit of RM109.9 million a year ago.
The listing will allow CAPI to access the world’s most extensive and liquid capital markets, and enhance Capital A’s international credibility and presence, Group chief executive Tony Fernandes says.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust Q4 DPU rises 0.9% to S$0.0336
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) reported a 0.9% increase in its fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0336, from S$0.0333 in the same period last year. The trust's distributable income rose 4.4% to S$95.2 million due to higher net property income and a joint venture's increased distribution. On a full-year basis, MIT's DPU fell 1% to S$0.1343, despite a 2.7% increase in distributable income. The trust's CEO attributed the challenges to macroeconomic uncertainties and higher operating expenses.

site_title: Microsoft beats estimates as AI drives revenue
summary: Microsoft reported a 17% increase in sales to $61.9 billion and a 20% rise in net profit to $21.9 billion for the January to March period, driven by its aggressive push into artificial intelligence. The company's cloud services, particularly Azure, saw a 24% increase in revenue. Microsoft's AI efforts, including its partnership with OpenAI, have boosted sales and solidified its position as the world's largest company by market capitalization.

site_title: Weak yen pressures Bank of Japan’s interest rate decision
summary: The Bank of Japan is under pressure to tighten monetary policy due to the weak yen, which has fallen to three-decade lows. One dollar bought 155.58 yen on Friday, a level not seen since 1990. Despite speculation of a potential interest rate hike, analysts expect the BoJ to keep rates unchanged. The government may intervene in forex markets to prop up the currency for the first time since 2022.

A strong dollar tends to raise the price of American exports and lower the price of imports, which would widen the country’s persistent trade deficit – a bugbear of Donald Trump’s for many decades.
Governor Ueda has not ruled out responding to exchange rates with a policy move if the impact on prices is seen to be “non-negligible”.
Japanese authorities will work closely with overseas counterparts to deal with excessive volatility in the foreign exchange market, Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki said on Tuesday.

site_title: Toyota is investing US$1.4 billion to build another all-electric SUV in US
summary: Toyota is investing $1.4 billion to build an all-electric SUV at its Princeton, Indiana, facility, its second US investment in electric vehicles this year. The new SUV will join the company's existing electric models, including the bZ4X and Lexus RZ 450e, which are manufactured in Japan. The move aims to keep Toyota compliant with US emissions standards and stay competitive with rivals' EVs that benefit from US government subsidies. This investment follows Toyota's previous $1.3 billion commitment to a Kentucky factory for a separate three-row, fully electric SUV.

site_title: Laid-back vibe, stunning beaches, rich cuisine and low cost of living lure more expat retirees to Malaysia
summary: Malaysia's long-term residency scheme, Malaysia My Second Home (MM2H), continues to attract expat retirees with its low cost of living, rich cuisine, and stunning beaches. However, policy flip-flops and profiteering relocation agents have diluted its appeal. The program has seen over 56,000 foreigners choose Malaysia as a "second home" since its launch 22 years ago. Despite challenges, many expats, including Keith Judd, Shanta Mansukhani, and Gary Crestejo, praise the country's warm climate, friendly people, and good food. Recent changes to the program, including the introduction of new categories and lower financial thresholds, aim to target different segments of people but have been met with uncertainty and lengthy waiting periods.

images.alt_text: Good food is the key reason that attracts foreigners to Malaysia, and Char Kway Teow is one of the irresistible local specialties.
Gary Crestejo (with black T-shirt) celebrating the opening of one of his new outlets in Gohtong Jaya with the shareholders and staff.
Despite some unpleasant encounters in Malaysia, Taiwanese author Li Yu Xi said a change of perspective will turn the stay in Malaysia a rewarding experience.
"Food is another reason that attracts many to Malaysia," said Keith Judd, who moved to Malaysia in 2010 under Malaysia My Second Home programme.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly fall
summary: US initial jobless claims unexpectedly fell to 207,000 for the week ended Apr 20, dropping 5,000 from the previous week. Economists had forecast 215,000 claims. Tight labor market conditions, companies hoarding workers, and low layoffs have sustained wage growth and consumer spending, accounting for over two-thirds of economic activity. Continuing claims declined 15,000 to 1.781 million, contributing to a 0.1 percentage point drop in the unemployment rate from 3.9% in February to 3.8% in March.

site_title: Semiconductor unicorn Silicon Box vows to avoid geopolitical mire
summary: Silicon Box, a Singapore-based semiconductor unicorn, aims to avoid the geopolitical tensions in the global semiconductor industry by rejecting state-linked funds and manufacturing on neutral ground. The company's CEO, Han Byung Joon, has stated that he will not have any funds related to any political or government-related fund in his shareholder portfolio. Silicon Box has already set up manufacturing facilities in Singapore and Italy, and is targeting customers in the automotive, high-performance computing, and mobile industries. The company's founders, including industry veterans Sehat Sutardja and Dai Weili, have attracted significant investor interest, and Silicon Box remains majority founder-owned.

images.alt_text: Silicon Box said its chiplet approach addresses a key bottleneck in chip production.
Silicon Box's semiconductor manufacturing facility will be worth US$2 billion when it is fully fitted out.
A view of a cleanroom in Silicon Box's advanced semiconductor manufacturing foundry in Singapore July 20, 2023. Picture taken through tinted window. REUTERS/Edgar Su

site_title: Hertz reports US$392 million loss as it unwinds Tesla fleet burden
summary: Hertz Global Holdings reported a loss of $392 million, or $1.28 a share, due to accelerated sales of electric vehicles to reduce its Tesla fleet. The company took a $195 million charge for the depreciation of 10,000 EVs being held for sale. Despite meeting revenue expectations, Hertz is trying to quickly work past its failed bet on electric vehicles, which have led to lower rental rates and higher costs. New CEO Gil West aims to reduce the damage and generate sustainable earnings for shareholders.

images.alt_text: Hertz’s new owners were making a fully charged bet to swap Hertz’s petrol-powered rental-car fleet for EVs.
Hertz’s CEO to step down as car renter unwinds bet on EVs

site_title: Homebuyers shun new real estate in Vancouver, hurting builders
summary: Canada's housing market in Vancouver is struggling due to a lack of buyers, despite efforts by politicians to increase the supply of homes. Condo developers face a 12-month deadline to market and sell projects, but high mortgage rates and increasing complexity of projects are making it difficult to meet this deadline. New home sales in metro Vancouver dropped 20% last year, while inventories rose, leading to concerns that the 12-month timeline may be impeding the development of housing.

images.alt_text: Condominiums stand along the shore of Lake Ontario in this aerial photograph taken above Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Monday, Oct. 2, 2017. Toronto housing prices fell for a fourth month in September as sales remained sluggish, particularly in the detached-home segment that has borne the brunt of the correction in Canada's biggest city. Photographer: James MacDonald/Bloomberg
Rapid growth in Canada’s immigrant population has driven the housing shortage along with inflation and high interest rates.

site_title: As COP29 planning begins, reforms needed to fulfil Paris ambition
summary: The COP29 climate conference, set to take place in Azerbaijan, aims to deliver an effective global climate deal amid criticism of the COP28 text. Despite growing attendance, the summit's comparative failure to deliver on the Paris Agreement's ambition has led to calls for fundamental changes in the UN-led climate framework. The COP28 deal included historic language on transitioning from fossil fuels and a 2030 global deforestation goal, but critics argue that it fails to address climate finance, adaptation, and the Paris goal of limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius. Reforms are needed to turbocharge negotiations and push key countries to increase their ambitions.

images.alt_text: (From left) Nato Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg and Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev deliver press statements following their talks in Baku, Azerbaijan on March 17, 2024.

Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu and Papua New Guinea Minister of Environment, Conservation and Climate Change Simo Kilepa at the signing ceremony of the implementation agreement between Singapore and Papua New Guinea.

site_title: Pricey coffee is here to stay as hoarding, heat hit Vietnam supply
summary: Vietnam, the world's largest producer of robusta beans, is facing a severe coffee supply crunch due to hoarding and poor weather. Prices have surged to an all-time high, with some farmers holding onto beans to avoid missing out on better deals. Climate change is exacerbating the issue, with droughts and erratic weather conditions expected to compound the shortage. Vietnam accounts for about a third of the world's robusta supply, and the shortfall has driven benchmark futures in London up around 50% this year, with prices reaching their highest level in at least 16 years.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A visitor checks coffee beans at the 'International Coffee Festival 2007' in the southern Indian city of Bangalore February 24, 2007. REUTERS/Jagadeesh Nv (INDIA)/File Photo

site_title: New York court overturns Harvey Weinstein sex crime conviction
summary: The New York State Court of Appeals overturned Harvey Weinstein's 2020 conviction on sex crime charges, ruling that the trial judge erred in admitting testimony from additional women not named in the charges. A new trial is ordered, but the decision does not affect Weinstein's 16-year rape sentence in California, leaving him still behind bars.

images.alt_text: Johnny & Associates Inc. former president Julie Keiko Fujishima (second from right) at the press conference where she announced she would step down. The new president of the talent agency is Noriyuki Higashiyama (second from left).

Former film producer Harvey Weinstein now faces 11 more charges, including sexual battery by restraint, forcible rape and forcible oral copulation against women in Beverly Hills and Los Angeles hotels between 2004 and 2013.
Kevin Spacey has been ordered to pay US$31 million to the production company that fired him from House of Cards after allegations of sexual harassment emerged.
Harvey Weinstein extradition delayed, new challenge expected
Disgraced Harvey Weinstein loses top royal honour

site_title: Google parent announces first-ever dividend; beats on sales, profit; shares soar
summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, announced its first-ever dividend of 20 US cents per share and a US$70 billion stock buyback, leading to a nearly 16% surge in its stock price. The company beat expectations for the quarter in sales, profit, and advertising, driven by rising demand for its cloud services and steady advertising spending. Revenue reached US$80.54 billion, with advertising sales rising 13% to US$61.7 billion. The dividend payout and buyback are seen as a strategic move to return capital while investing in data centers to catch up with rivals on generative artificial intelligence.

images.alt_text: Google has been talking with publishers, marketers and regulators about its plan to replace cookies, the software marketers use to track people’s online activity and tailor ads accordingly, through an initiative known as the Privacy Sandbox.
Big tech is crucial to the S&P 500 since the companies carry the heaviest weightings in the benchmark.
A drone view shows the Google logo on a building after the launch of Google El Salvador in San Salvador, El Salvador, April 16, 2024. REUTERS/Jose Cabezas

site_title: US: Stocks hit by GDP data, Meta results
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday following disappointing economic data, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 1.0% to 38,085.73. The US economy grew 1.6% in the first quarter, slower than expected, and inflation data is expected to keep interest rates high. Meta parent company shares sank 10.6% after strong results were overshadowed by concerns about artificial intelligence spending. Other companies, including Southwest Airlines and Caterpillar, also reported declines. Analysts say the economy's slowdown is not as bad as it appears, but the data has weighed on stocks.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - FEBRUARY 29: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on February 29, 2024 in New York City. Stocks opened up on the rise as investors await the latest release of inflation data from the Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) index, the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation indicator.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Sri Lanka’s economy expected to grow 3% in 2024, central bank says
summary: Sri Lanka's economy is expected to grow 3% in 2024, according to the Central Bank of Sri Lanka. The country has reduced interest rates amid easing inflation, following a 2.3% contraction in 2023. Despite not fully exiting its financial crisis, the central bank emphasizes the need to stick to its International Monetary Fund agreement and complete debt restructuring. The government has rejected a debt restructuring proposal from international bondholders, delaying efforts, but plans to resume negotiations.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker carries a sack of vegetables at a market in Colombo, Sri Lanka June 1, 2023. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte/File Photo

We hope to continue discussions with the bondholders with a view to reaching common ground ahead of the IMF board consideration of the second review of Sri Lanka’s EFF (extended fund facility) programme,” says state finance minister Shehan Semasinghe in a statement.
After the announcement, Sri Lanka’s bonds were down between 2.3 and 2.8 cents, leaving them at just over half their original face value at between 53 and 55 cents on the US dollar.
Sri Lanka Photographer: Jonathan Wijayaratne/Bloomberg

site_title: US economic growth slows more than expected in Q1
summary: US economic growth slowed to a 1.6% annualized rate in Q1, lower than expected 2.4% forecast. Consumer spending drove growth, while inflation accelerated, suggesting the Federal Reserve won't cut interest rates before September. The economy expanded at a pace above the non-inflationary growth rate of 1.8%, outperforming other advanced economies. The International Monetary Fund upgraded its 2024 US growth forecast to 2.7% due to stronger-than-expected employment and consumer spending.

site_title: S-Reits falter as investors weigh possibility of zero rate cuts in 2024
summary: S-Reits have faltered in recent weeks due to shifting interest rate expectations and geopolitical tensions. Prices sank to 974.08 on April 19, before rebounding to 1,005.27 on April 25. Analysts attribute the underperformance to changing expectations over the high interest rate environment. In a scenario with no 2024 rate cuts, investors are expected to seek safety in S-Reits with healthier financial metrics, such as low gearing levels and higher interest coverage ratios.

images.alt_text: New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.  The Reit’s portfolio occupancy fell to 83 per cent in the first quarter ended Mar 31, 2024, from 91.2 per cent in Q4, 2023.

Office S-Reits with mainly local assets have also been laggards in terms of their trading valuations. Keppel Reit trades at around a 35 per cent discount to its book value, while others such as OUE Reit and Suntec Reit are currently trading around half their book value.
Analysts told The Business Times that operational performance for Reits are expected to stay resilient, but distributions per unit (DPU) would likely remain under pressure from financing costs.

site_title: Baltimore’s trapped ships start leaving as new channel opens
summary: Four ships trapped in Baltimore Harbor since the Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse have cleared the wreckage and are en route to their destinations. The Balsa 94, a general cargo ship, was the first to leave, followed by the Saimaagracht, Carmen, and Phatra Naree. A temporary 35-foot-deep channel was established to allow essential ships to pass the harbor, and salvage operations continue. The new channel is open until April 29, pending inclement weather, with prolonged delays expected due to the magnitude of the situation.

site_title: Saudi oil giant Aramco agrees major Fifa sponsorship deal
summary: Saudi Arabia's state oil giant Aramco has agreed to a major sponsorship deal with FIFA until the end of 2027. The deal, worth an undisclosed amount, makes Aramco the energy category's exclusive Major Worldwide Partner. The partnership includes sponsorship rights for the 2026 Men's World Cup and the 2027 Women's World Cup. This is the latest high-profile investment in global sports by Saudi Arabia, which has been accused of "sportswashing" to hide human rights abuses. Aramco CEO Amin H Nasser said the partnership aims to contribute to football development and promote growth.

images.alt_text: The 82,500-seat MetLife Stadium, across the Hudson river in East Rutherford, New Jersey, has held a number of international football games including the final of the 2016 Copa America tournament.
Aramco is in talks with parent Hengli Group and signed a memorandum of understanding over the proposed transaction, which is subject to due diligence and regulatory approvals
Jude Bellingham’s move to Real Madrid is one of the top transfers in 2023.
Aramco believes the deal would position it as a global LNG player.

site_title: India’s IndiGo gets into long haul game with Airbus A350 deal
summary: IndiGo, India's largest airline, has signed a deal for 30 Airbus A350-900 jets with options for 70 more, transforming the budget airline into one of the biggest A350 customers. The order is part of a larger effort by Indian carriers to handle increasing volumes in the world's fastest-growing aviation market. Deliveries will begin in 2027, and the deal is seen as a strategic move to expand long-haul services, competing with Middle-Eastern hub operators and a resurgent Air India.

images.alt_text: IndiGo plans to add 10 new destinations in fiscal 2025 and manage a fleet of more than 600 aircraft by 2030.

site_title: Austrian artist turns Hitler manifesto into cookbook
summary: Austrian artist Andreas Joska-Sutanto is reimagining Adolf Hitler's manifesto "Mein Kampf" into a cookbook by cutting up the book letter by letter and rearranging the text into recipes. Joska-Sutanto has spent 8 years and 900 hours working on the project, cutting up about a quarter of the 800-page book. The result is a cookbook with 22 recipes, including pizza and egg dumplings, which Joska-Sutanto believes can "deconstruct" the negativity of the original text. The project aims to show that something negative can be turned into something positive by rearranging its content.

images.alt_text: A man points at a screen showing the chosen plan for the architectural redesign of Adolf Hitler's birth house, during a press conference at the Austrian Interior ministry in Vienna in 2020.

site_title: Temasek-BlackRock joint venture closes inaugural decarbonisation-focused fund at US$1.4 billion
summary: Temasek and BlackRock's joint venture, Decarbonization Partners, has closed its inaugural fund at US$1.4 billion, surpassing its initial target of US$1 billion. The fund focuses on companies with proven decarbonization technologies, attracting over 30 institutional investors from 18 countries. The fund's geographic breakdown is 50% US, 25% Europe, and 25% Asia-Pacific, with investments in sustainable materials, clean hydrogen, and science-based carbon management services. The partnership aims to accelerate capital deployment into emerging climate tech and support innovative solutions for real-world decarbonization at scale.

images.alt_text: Panellists at Ecosperity highlighted corporate buy-in as important for securing funding.
Edwin Conway of BlackRock says:  “We think of decarbonisation as one of the best investment opportunity sets across private markets, because the world is in transition.”

Incorporating rain gardens helped naturalise this concrete canal at Tampines. Such nature-based solutions are increasingly used to create "green-grey" infrastructure to help cope with the impact of climate change, said Koh Lian Pin, director of NUS' Centre for Nature-Based Solutions.
Singapore should step up to help emerging countries with net-zero transition, says BlackRock CEO
Temasek defends green goals after backing Singapore polluters
Temasek and BlackRock form US$600m decarbonisation investment partnership

site_title: ‘Extreme’ climate blamed for world’s worst wine harvest in 62 years
summary: The International Organisation of Vine and Wine reported a 10% drop in world wine production last year, the largest fall in over six decades, due to "extreme" climate changes. The drop was most significant in Australia (26%), Italy (23%), and Spain, with harvests in Chile and South Africa also down by over 10%. France, the world's largest wine producer, bucked the trend with a 4% increase. Climate-related issues such as droughts, fires, and heavy rain contributed to the decline, while global wine consumption also fell by 3% to its lowest level since 1996.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - A worker spreads burning straw on the ground in a vineyard to create a smoke screen to keep temperatures above 0°Celsius and prevent vines from freezing due to a cold wave hitting the region, near Saint-Emilion, south-western France, on April 23, 2024. Temperatures are dropping and buds are already appearing: from Var to Burgundy, farmers are facing a week of danger, with the risk of frosts that could destroy future harvests. (Photo by Christophe ARCHAMBAULT / AFP)
A selection of Riesling wines.
Ryuichiro Masuda in his wine and sake cellar.
Retrospect, a variation of the classic Bamboo cocktail, uses rice vodka to bring out the nuttiness in sherry.
Former New Zealand All Black rugby player John Ashworth inspecting his grape vines at his home at Junction Wines vineyard in Takapau.

site_title: GlaxoSmithKline sues Pfizer and BioNTech over Covid-19 vaccine technology
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) has sued Pfizer and BioNTech over patent infringement related to their Covid-19 mRNA vaccines. GSK claims its patents developed mRNA-vaccine innovations "more than a decade before" the pandemic, which Pfizer and BioNTech allegedly used in their Comirnaty vaccine. GSK is seeking monetary damages, including an ongoing patent-licensing fee, and is willing to license its patents on commercially reasonable terms to ensure patient access.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows GlaxoSmithKline headquarters in London, Britain, January 17, 2022.REUTERS/Hannah McKay/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: A view shows GlaxoSmithKline headquarters in London, Britain, January 17, 2022.REUTERS/Hannah McKay/File Photo

site_title: iFast Q1 net profit surges on ePension unit performance
summary: iFast Corp posted a 387.4% spike in net profit to S$14.5 million for its Q1 2024, driven by ePension business unit and core wealth management platform improvements. Revenue rose 53.1% to S$78.8 million, and earnings per share increased to 4.89 cents. Assets under administration reached a record high of S$21.1 billion. The group expects "robust" growth in revenues and profitability in 2024, driven by ePension and iFast Global Bank.

images.alt_text: iFast is trading significantly higher on Thursday morning after reporting a surge in its fourth quarter net profit.

site_title: US pending home sales jump in March to hit highest in the year
summary: US pending home sales surged to their highest level in a year in March, reaching 78.2, driven by gains in the South and West. Despite high borrowing costs and low supply, the index surpassed economists' median estimate of 0.4% growth. The sales surge is attributed to builders offering lower interest rates and incentives to complete deals. However, industry experts, including NAR chief economist Lawrence Yun, emphasize that meaningful gains will only occur with declining mortgage rates and rising inventory, which remains below pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage increased 11 basis points in the week ended Apr 19 to 7.24 per cent, the highest since Nov 24.

site_title: Honda to spend US$11 billion on EV strategy in Canada
summary: Honda plans to invest C$15 billion (S$14.9 billion) in its electric vehicle supply chain in Canada, with US$11 billion coming from government aid. The investment includes building a battery plant in Ontario and a manufacturing facility producing 240,000 vehicles per year by 2028. The move aims to reduce reliance on external manufacturers for batteries and is part of Honda's goal to have 100% electrified sales by 2040. The investment will also create jobs and support Canada's bid to secure a share of the North American auto industry.

images.alt_text: Honda expects to produce as many  as 150,000 vehicles per year at its Itirapina plant by 2030.
Honda planned to roll out a total of 10 Honda-brand EV models in China by 2027 in the race to ensure EVs make up 100 per cent of its automobile sales in the country by 2035.

This photo taken on December 8, 2023 shows workers inspecting a car on the production line during a media tour of the "Nissan Intelligent Factory" at the Nissan Motor Tochigi plant, the company's largest in Japan, in Kaminokawa, Tochigi prefecture, some 105 kms (65 miles) north of Tokyo. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: Yellen says US can bring inflation down without hurting jobs
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that the labor market is not a necessary factor in reducing inflation, saying there's no evidence that wage pressures are a source of inflation. Yellen played down a slowdown in economic growth, attributing it to "peculiar" elements. Housing costs, the largest contributor to inflation, are expected to decrease over the coming year. Yellen declined to comment on interest-rate cuts, citing her successor Jerome Powell's need for more evidence on inflation before easing policy.

site_title: At Venice Biennale, Singapore artists probe history & nature
summary: Singapore artists are showcasing their works at the Venice Biennale 2024, with a record representation of the country's artists. The Singapore Pavilion features a mysterious forest-like structure, accompanied by films by Robert Zhao Renhui, which depict animals seemingly disconnected from their urban surroundings. The exhibition explores the relationship between nature and history, highlighting the contrast between the natural world and the human-made environment. This marks a significant milestone for Singapore's presence at the prestigious art event.

images.alt_text: Chua Mia Tee's iconic 1955 painting titled Road Construction Worker (second from left) is being exhibited in Venice Biennale 2024, which carries the provocative theme "Foreigners Everywhere".
Cheong Soo Pieng's Life In A Longhouse (1978) is one of 30 works selected for materials analysis.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as Meta Platforms, economic data weigh
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, April 25, due to dour quarterly results from Meta Platforms and signs of persistent inflation, which dampened hopes of the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 408.83 points, or 1.06%, to 38,052.09, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined.

site_title: Blackstone strikes US$1.6 billion student housing deal with KKR
summary: Blackstone agreed to sell a US$1.64 billion student housing portfolio to KKR, consisting of 19 properties with over 10,000 beds near 14 public universities. The deal is expected to be completed by the third quarter and represents a 7% premium to net asset value. This marks Blackstone's latest asset sale, following a US$20 billion sale of real estate assets at a premium since 2022, as the firm hunts for deals amid falling commercial property prices.

images.alt_text: Last year, Crown Resorts agreed to pay a A$450 million (S$395.7 million) fine for breaking anti-money laundering laws.

Hipgnosis - co-founded in 2018 by legendary guitarist and producer Nile Rodgers and Merck Mercuriadis, the former manager of Beyonce and Elton John - manages the rights to more than 150 of the world’s biggest song catalogues.

site_title: BOE reports record usage of short-term liquidity repo
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) has reported a record usage of short-term liquidity repo, allotting £7.587 billion in a one-week operation to offset the impact of quantitative tightening on market interest rates. This is the largest single usage of the facility since its launch in October 2022, surpassing the previous record of £5.384 billion set on April 11. The BOE uses the weekly repo to maintain money market rates close to its official Bank Rate while reducing its reserves through quantitative tightening.

site_title: US dollar briefly falls versus yen after GDP data
summary: The US dollar briefly fell to 155.31 yen against the Japanese currency after data showed the world's largest economy grew at a 1.6% annualized rate in the first quarter, lower than expected. The dollar recovered and rose 0.2% to 155.67 yen, prompting some market participants to expect Tokyo authorities to intervene to prop up the currency. Analysts expect the Bank of Japan to deliver a marginally hawkish outcome at its meeting, potentially leading to intervention and a further decline in the yen to 160.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index was last up 0.2 per cent at 105.85 after earlier touching the lowest since Apr 12 at 105.59.

site_title: Great Eastern chairman appeals for patience as shareholders fume over share price ‘disaster’
summary: Great Eastern Holdings (GEH) chairman Soon Tit Koon has appealed to shareholders to remain patient as the board works to boost returns, following concerns over falling share prices. GEH's board has taken steps to improve total shareholder returns, including changing its dividend policy and increasing investor relations activities. Despite proposed resolutions to address concerns, Soon emphasized that linking directors' fees to share price performance is not desirable and that the company is committed to improving performance. The board will review management compensation and deliberate on shareholder suggestions, with a focus on improving the company's sustainable profit level.

images.alt_text: On GEH’s 21 per cent decline in the New Business Embedded Value for the Singapore market in 2023, the insurer attributed the dip mainly to the lower single premium sales as the inverted Singapore dollar yield curve has made shorter-term interest yielding investments more appealing than the insurer’s typical single premium products.
The rationale for insurance groups Great Eastern Holdings and United Overseas Inusrance to remain listed on the local bourse is weak.
The Japanese stock market is rising in value, partly thanks to a new emphasis on corporate governance.
The Great Eastern logo on the facade of Great Eastern Centre located at Pickering Street on 4 Dec 2019.
GEH says its management is "aware that while GEH shares currently trade above its NAV, they trade below its estimated (embedded value) as at end-2023".
Minority shareholders of Great Eastern want to put forward three resolutions, including one to end the practice of Great Eastern paying its executives with OCBC shares.
A group of close to 80 shareholders have raised concerns over GEH’s depressed share price and continued valuation decline over the last decade, despite its “strong financial position”.

site_title: Heatstroke kills 30 in Thailand this year as South-east Asia bakes
summary: Heatstroke has claimed at least 30 lives in Thailand this year, with temperatures expected to soar above 52 degrees Celsius in Bangkok, according to the city's environment department. The region, including the Philippines, India, and Nepal, is experiencing unusually hot weather due to climate change, with severe heatwave conditions forecast in several countries. The United Nations has warned that Asia was the most affected by climate and weather hazards in 2023, with heatwaves expected to be longer, more frequent, and more intense.

images.alt_text: epa11297168 A woman protects herself from the sunlight during hot weather in Bangkok, Thailand, 24 April 2024. Thai authorities issued a high temperature warning for all regions in the country with the temperature reaching as high as 44 degrees Celsius (111 Fahrenheit), which is at a dangerous level with a risk of heat stroke, as the hot weather breaks record in five years, according to the Meteorological Department.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK

People buy coconut water to cool themselves along a road in Manila on April 24, 2024, as extreme heat affected the country. Extreme heat scorched the Philippines on April 24, forcing schools in some areas to suspend in-person classes and prompting warnings for people to limit the amount of time spent outdoors. (Photo by Ted ALJIBE / AFP)

Houses submerged in floodwaters following heavy rainfall, at a village in Qingyuan, Guangdong province, China April 22, 2024. Last year, 79 disasters associated with water-related weather hazards were reported in Asia.
The estimated income loss from climate change will be driven mainly by rising temperatures, which will affect agriculture, public health, productivity and more.
Workers, especially the world’s poorest, are more vulnerable than the general population to the dangers of climate extremes.

site_title: Far East Orchard acquires 49% stake in UK-based purpose-built student accommodation operator for £17.6 million
summary: Far East Orchard acquired a 49% stake in UK-based student accommodation operator Homes For Students for £17.6 million. The acquisition supplements Far East Orchard's PBSA operating management capabilities in the UK and is part of its objective to build a lodging platform. The company may acquire the remaining 51% in two stages by September 2025 and November 2030, subject to certain conditions. The acquisition is expected to propel Far East Orchard to surpass its target of 5,000 beds in the UK, with its PBSA portfolio set to grow to approximately 4,700 beds.

images.alt_text: Far East Orchard has a student accommodation portfolio in the UK.

site_title: Middle East tensions threaten global progress on inflation: World Bank
summary: Middle East tensions are threatening to reverse recent progress in tackling global inflation, according to the World Bank. The ongoing conflict in Gaza has pushed up oil prices, exerting upward pressure on key commodities, notably oil and gold. A worst-case scenario shock to oil prices could raise global inflation, potentially causing interest rates to remain higher than expected and increasing food insecurity. The World Bank estimates a moderate conflict-related supply disruption could raise oil prices to $92 per barrel, while a severe disruption could push it above $100.

images.alt_text: A panoramic view of Jerusalem's Old City is pictured at dawn of Apr 14, 2024, after Iran launched a drone and missile attack on Israel.

Foreign ministers from the G7, comprising the US, Italy, Canada, France, Germany, Japan and Britain, wrapped up three days of talks on the island of Capri that were dominated by wars in Ukraine and the Middle East.
Even if the tit-for-tat between Israel and Iran escalates, it is unlikely to change much. Any reduction in Iran’s exports might be balanced by more pumping from the rest of Opec.
Deep losses in Asia carried over into European trading, but Wall Street’s main indices wobbled as corporate earnings season continued.

Pieces of an Iranian missile in a pickup truck outside Arad, Israel, on Sunday, April 14, 2024. On Saturday, Iran launched a retaliatory missile and drone attack on Israel; most of the missiles and drones were intercepted.

site_title: Money laundering accused who faces 22 charges to plead guilty on May 14
summary: Vang Shuiming, a 22-charged money laundering suspect, is set to plead guilty on May 14 in Singapore's largest money laundering case, worth over S$3 billion. He faces charges of fraud, forgery, and money laundering, including possessing S$2.4 million in criminal benefits from unlicensed moneylending operations in China. Over S$200 million of his assets have been seized, and he has been in remand since his arrest in 2023. The guilty plea is the sixth from the 10 foreign nationals involved in the case, with the remaining four still in remand.

images.alt_text: Su Haijin was formerly a director of Catalist-listed food and beverage operator No Signboard.
Chinese passport holder Wang Baosen (left) was handed 8 charges related to money laundering, forgery and lying to the authorities.
Zhang Ruijin currently faces three charges related to forging bank documents used to cheat CIMB Bank.
Su Baolin
The 99-year leasehold site, which was being advertised at a guide price of S$27.1 million.

site_title: Changi Airport’s Q1 passenger movements surpass pre-pandemic levels
summary: Changi Airport reported 16.5 million passengers in Q1 2024, surpassing pre-pandemic levels by 0.5%. Passenger movements increased in January, February, and March, with February and March reaching 104.3% and 101.7% of 2019 levels, respectively. Airfreight throughput also rose 14% year-over-year, marking the first quarter of growth after seven consecutive declines. The airport's top markets were China, Indonesia, Malaysia, Australia, and Thailand, with North America showing a 25% increase in traffic.

images.alt_text: Lee Seow Hiang (left) and Yam Kum Weng.
This year the title has switched, with 12-time winner Singapore being edged out of the top spot by its Middle Eastern rival in the Skytrax World Airport Awards 2024.

site_title: Thai banks cut rate for some borrowers after push from PM
summary: Thailand's biggest commercial banks have agreed to temporarily lower borrowing costs for vulnerable groups and small businesses by 25 basis points for six months. The move follows an appeal by Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin, who aimed to ease the burden on individuals and small businesses struggling with high interest rates. The decision is in line with the government and central bank's policy to revive the economy, which has grown at a slower pace than regional peers.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Thailand left its key interest rate unchanged for a third straight meeting on April 10.

site_title: Nasdaq’s profit falls as shaky economy keeps IPO revival elusive
summary: Nasdaq's profit fell to 63 US cents a share, below expectations of 65 US cents, marking the first decline in a year. The decline was attributed to a shaky economy, with just 27 companies going public on the exchange in the first three months of the year, down from 40 in the same period last year. This marks a reversal from last year's surge, and the company's statement lacked any commentary on IPOs for the first time since the third quarter of 2022.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - FEBRUARY 29: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on February 29, 2024 in New York City. Stocks opened up on the rise as investors await the latest release of inflation data from the Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) index, the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation indicator.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: S&P Global first-quarter profit beats estimates on strong product demand
summary: S&P Global beat first-quarter profit estimates with a 29% jump in revenue from its Ratings segment, driven by strong demand for data and analytics products amid hopes of a "soft landing" for the US economy. The company raised its full-year revenue and profit forecast, citing growing optimism for a rebound in the economy and increased confidence in strong demand for its services. S&P Global now forecasts a full-year adjusted profit of $13.85 to $14.10 per share, up from its earlier expectations of $13.75 to $14.00 per share.

images.alt_text: Smoke rises during an Israeli military operation in Al Nuseirat refugee camp, central Gaza Strip, April 17, 2024. All three major rating firms have put out warnings on Israel’s credit score since the onset of the war with Hamas.
The bank has sold assets to shore up its balance sheet.

site_title: Philippines central bank not seeing rate hike despite peso weakness: finmin
summary: The Philippines' central bank, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, has no plans to hike interest rates despite the peso's weakness against the US dollar, according to Finance Secretary Ralph Recto. The policy rate will be adjusted based on inflation outlook, which is within the central bank's 2-4% target. BSP Governor Eli Remolona vowed to manage any unnecessary movement of the peso, which closed weaker at 57.78 per US dollar on Thursday. The benchmark rate remained steady at 6.5% for a fourth straight meeting.

site_title: ☔ What insurance do you actually need?
summary: Daryl Choo shares his personal experience with buying insurance policies, highlighting the importance of choosing the right coverage for one's needs. He owns hospitalisation, term life, disability, and critical illness insurance, and explains that each policy serves a specific purpose in providing financial protection against unexpected events. Choo emphasizes that insurance isn't about investing, but rather a hedge against losses, and encourages readers to assess their individual circumstances to determine the necessary coverage.

site_title: Sheng Siong Q1 net profit up 9.3% on higher revenue
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket chain, reported a 9.3% increase in net profit to S$36.3 million for its first quarter ended March 31. Revenue rose 5.5% to S$376.2 million, driven by higher same-store sales and a longer sales period before the Chinese New Year. The company plans to diversify its supply chain and refine its sales mix towards higher-margin products to manage risks effectively.

images.alt_text: The Sheng Siong Supermarket at Chin Swee Road, Feb 28, 2024.

site_title: India's Vedanta misses Q4 profit estimates on lower prices
summary: Vedanta, an Indian mining group, reported a 27% drop in fourth-quarter profit to 13.69 billion rupees (S$223.3 million), missing analysts' estimates of 21.10 billion rupees. The company attributed the decline to weaker metal prices, particularly for aluminium and zinc, which were subdued due to demand concerns from China. Finance costs also increased nearly 34% due to a jump in expenses. The drop in earnings comes as Vedanta is planning an overhaul of its operations to unlock higher value for shareholders.

images.alt_text: Deliberations are ongoing and no final decisions on the structure or timing of the de-merger have been made.
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past the logo of Vedanta outside its headquarters in Mumbai, India January 31, 2018. REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: European real estate deals slump to lowest level in 13 years
summary: European real estate deals plummeted to their lowest level in 13 years, with the first-quarter total of 34.5 billion euros down 26% compared to the previous year. Higher interest rates have caused a sharp correction, with office properties leading the declines, down 45% in Q1. Sellers are holding on, waiting for prices to recover, despite rates expected to come down soon, and a 20% gap remains between asking prices and completed deals.

images.alt_text: Sign showing "for rent" outside a residential apartment building in France; high-end, 100-square-metre primary residences are currently asking around 10,000 euros per week.

site_title: Nestle sales growth sputters on US slump, vitamin snags
summary: Nestle's sales growth sputtered in the first quarter due to cooler demand in North America and supply constraints at its vitamins unit, with organic sales rising 1.4% compared to expected 2.9%. The company expects real internal growth to rebound in the second quarter, particularly at its vitamins business. Despite this, Nestle's shares fell 4.8% in early trading, indicating investor skepticism about the company's outlook.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker arranges packets of Nestle's Maggi noodles next to Reliance's Snac tac noodles on a shelf inside a Reliance supermarket in Mumbai, India, March 16, 2021. Picture taken March 16, 2021. REUTERS/Niharika Kulkarni/File Photo
Pressure is growing on food companies to make their range of products healthier.
Nestle’s net profit rose sharply by about 20 per cent to US$12.76 billion.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 25)
summary: Singapore's industrial rents rose 1.7% in Q1, despite occupancy rates dipping and prices falling for the first time in three years. Condo resale volumes rebounded 17.4% in March, reaching a seven-month high. The cut-off yield on the latest six-month T-bill fell to 3.74%. Malaysia's inflation rate remained steady at 1.8% in March. Keppel reported a 6.3% fall in Q1 revenue to S$1.5 billion. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.2% lower.

site_title: Riesling – elegance in a glass
summary: German Riesling wine is renowned for its elegance and versatility, with various expressions ranging from dry to lusciously sweet. The Pradikatswein classification system categorizes Rieslings into five levels of sweetness, with Kabinett being the most delicate and light-bodied. German climate and late harvest contribute to high sugar levels and acidity. Popular winemakers include Egon Muller, Johann Josef Prum, and Weingut Donnhoff, offering a range of Kabinett Rieslings with unique characteristics. Kabinett Rieslings pair well with South-east Asian, Japanese, and European cuisine, with recommended serving temperatures between 13-15 degrees Celsius.

images.alt_text: Sauvignon Blanc displays regional differences that offer a wide choice in the style of wine.

site_title: Malaysia’s March inflation steady at 1.8%, beats economists’ forecast
summary: Malaysia's inflation rate remained steady at 1.8% in March, beating economists' forecast of 2% due to resilient consumer spending. Core inflation rose 1.7% year-on-year, slower than February's 1.8%. This steady inflation rate suggests that the Malaysian economy is stable, but economists expect inflation to rise in the coming months. The country's central bank may consider rate cuts to shield the economy from potential tariff threats.

images.alt_text: The government is on track to focus its handouts on helping the needy, Rafizi Ramli says.
Stocks have given up ground, and in futures markets, the price of oil has climbed as much as 18 per cent this year.

site_title: BNP Paribas beats estimates as lower costs offset trading slump
summary: BNP Paribas reported a 20% decline in fixed income trading revenue in Q1, but beat forecasts with a 2.2% drop in group net income to 3.1 billion euros, exceeding analyst estimates. The bank attributed lower costs to its growth plan, which includes its investment banking division. BNP Paribas reiterated its goal to generate full-year earnings of over 11.2 billion euros and announced a new target for group revenue to exceed 2023 levels by 2%.

images.alt_text: BNP Paribas is leveraging its European status to slowly expand in China even as some Wall Street firms scale back amid growing US-China tensions.

site_title: ‘To the Future’: Saudi Arabia spends big to become an AI superpower
summary: Saudi Arabia is redirecting its oil wealth into building a domestic tech industry, aiming to become an AI superpower by 2030. The kingdom has created a $100 billion fund for AI investments, with plans to add $40 billion. Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's "Vision 2030" aims to diversify the economy, and the government is requiring international firms to establish roots in the kingdom to access its money. The move has sparked concerns in the US, with worries that Saudi Arabia's authoritarian leanings and ties to China could undermine US interests.

images.alt_text: Even if the tit-for-tat between Israel and Iran escalates, it is unlikely to change much. Any reduction in Iran’s exports might be balanced by more pumping from the rest of Opec.

The logo of Saudi Telecommunication Company (STC) is seen at the Mobile World Congress (MWC), the telecom industry's biggest annual gathering, in Barcelona on March 2, 2023. (Photo by Josep LAGO / AFP)
While Zuckerberg's track record is good, there is a lingering problem with the “metaverse,” a bet that has shown only minimal signs of bringing good results.

site_title: Consumer gulf widens as demand for premium and budget foods grows
summary: The consumer market is experiencing a widening gap between premium and budget food options, with demand for both increasing. Food companies such as Nestle and Danone are reporting growth in higher-priced products, while cheaper alternatives like Maggi noodles are also gaining traction. This shift is attributed to consumers adapting to higher prices caused by global supply chain disruptions and rising costs, with fewer interested in middle-priced items. Executives are easing up on price hikes as costs slow to rise.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker arranges packets of Nestle's Maggi noodles next to Reliance's Snac tac noodles on a shelf inside a Reliance supermarket in Mumbai, India, March 16, 2021. Picture taken March 16, 2021. REUTERS/Niharika Kulkarni/File Photo

site_title: Latest Singapore 6-month T-bill offering cut-off yield of 3.74% as applications dip
summary: Singapore's latest 6-month Treasury bill auction saw a cut-off yield of 3.74%, down from 3.75% in the previous auction, with a total of S$14.4 billion in applications for the S$6.6 billion on offer. Demand was lower compared to the previous auction, which received S$16 billion in applications. The cut-off yield has stabilized around the mid 3.70s, according to DBS senior rates strategist Eugene Leow, who noted that market participants will be closely watching the upcoming Fed meeting for guidance on policy direction.

images.alt_text: A total of S$10.1 billion in applications were made for a total amount allotted of S$5.1 billion, which puts the bid-to-cover ratio at 1.97.
The previous auction, which closed on Mar 27, offered 3.8 per cent yield.

site_title: Malaysia ex-PM Mahathir facing anti-graft probe in a case involving his sons
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is being investigated in connection with a graft probe involving his sons, Mirzan and Mokhzani. The investigation, led by the Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC), comes amid a crackdown on high-level corruption targeting prominent politicians, including Mahathir, who has denied the allegations as politically motivated. The MACC has served Mahathir's sons with notices to declare their wealth as part of the investigation into offshore financial and business records.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's recent graft investigations involved prominent businessmen and political leaders.
Felda Global Ventures Holdings Berhad (FGV) chairman Mohd Isa Abdul Samad at a Ramadan event sponsored by FGV.
Daim served as finance minister from 1984 to 1991 and from 1999 to 2001.
The Malaysian Anti Corruption Commission (MACC) says it has recorded a statement from former prime minister Ismail Sabri in relation to the alleged spending.
US have allowed the 10-year prison sentence to be deferred so that Ng (above) could return to Malaysia and assist the investigation.

The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission had earlier confirmed it suspected Low was in gambling haven and Chinese special administrative region Macau.

site_title: Thailand to appoint former energy executive Pichai as finance minister: sources
summary: Thailand is set to appoint Pichai Chunhavajira, a 75-year-old former energy executive, as its new finance minister, replacing Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin. Pichai, who holds a master's degree in business administration, was Srettha's advisor and has experience as a board member of the Bank of Thailand and a director at PTT Exploration and Production. He faces the challenge of reviving Thailand's economy, which lags regional peers due to high household debt and borrowing costs, as well as China's slowdown.

images.alt_text: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin speaks alongside Cambodia's Prime Minister Hun Manet during a joint press conference at the Government House in Bangkok on February 7, 2024. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

site_title: TikTok ultimatum puts US firms in firing line for China response
summary: US President Joe Biden has signed a law that could expel TikTok from the US market, prompting China to consider a retaliatory response. The legislation gives Chinese parent company ByteDance nearly a year to divest TikTok before facing an outright ban. China may try to prevent TikTok from being sold to an American entity, potentially targeting US tech brands as collateral damage. Beijing has shown restraint in responding to US trade curbs, but may escalate measures to safeguard its legitimate rights and interests, potentially affecting US companies operating in China.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This photograph taken in Mulhouse, eastern France on October 19, 2023, shows the logo of the social media video sharing app Tik Tok reflected in mirrors. The US Senate on Tuesday approved legislation requiring the wildly popular social media app TikTok to be divested from its Chinese parent company ByteDance or be shut out of the American market. The measure was part of a $95 billion foreign aid package, including military assistance to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan, which has now cleared Congress and heads to President Joe Biden's desk. (Photo by SEBASTIEN BOZON / AFP)

site_title: Singapore stocks end lower after US market wobbles ahead of CPI data; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.2% lower at 3,287.75 on Thursday, following a steady close on Wall Street ahead of US inflation data on Friday that could impact interest rate policy. Shares of Genting Singapore dropped 2.1%, while UOB closed ex-dividend. Almost half of the STI's components declined, with six counters remaining unchanged.

images.alt_text: People waiting to enter the Casino at Resorts World Sentosa on Wednesday, July 1 2020.
Tokyo, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei and Jakarta all fell, though Hong Kong resumed its latest rally, while Shanghai and Manila were also up.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers

site_title: AstraZeneca leaps after smashing Q1 forecasts
summary: AstraZeneca surpassed market expectations with a 26% jump in first-quarter sales to $5.12 billion, driven by strong demand for its blockbuster drugs and steady sales from partnered medicines. The company reported a 19% year-on-year rise in total revenue to $12.68 billion, with core earnings per share of $2.06. The news sent shares up 5.7%, the highest since May last year, and boosted the company's pipeline of new drugs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Test tubes are seen in front of a displayed AstraZeneca logo in this illustration taken, May 21, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo
AstraZeneca has been working on cancer treatments that are more targeted than radiotherapy and chemotherapy, which have been mainstays.

The deal, which includes an US$800 million upfront payment and an additional contingent payment of US$250 million on achieving a specified regulatory milestone, is expected to close by the third quarter of 2024.

site_title: Toyota and Nissan pair up with Tencent and Baidu for China AI arms race
summary: Toyota and Nissan partner with Tencent and Baidu to enhance their China-made passenger vehicles with AI technology, leveraging Tencent's big data, AI, and cloud computing capabilities. The collaboration aims to counter the rise of domestic brands and shifting market trends. Nissan will use Baidu's generative AI on its platform to study future tech development, while Toyota will integrate Tencent's technology into its China-made vehicles. The move highlights the importance of AI in the Chinese automotive market, where Japanese manufacturers face increased competition from local manufacturers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Toyota logo is seen at the Tokyo Motor Show in Tokyo, Japan, Oct. 24, 2019. REUTERS/Soe Zeya Tun/File Photo

site_title: US births retreat after pandemic-era growth
summary: US birth rates declined by 2% in 2023, returning to pre-pandemic trends. The number of births fell to 3,591,328, a 2% decrease from the previous year. Birth rates among women aged 20-24 and 18-19 years declined by 4% and 3%, respectively, to record lows. The decline was more pronounced among Black and Native American women, who experienced 4% and 5% declines, respectively. The birth rate among Hispanic women rose by 1%.

images.alt_text: The supply of new homes for purchase rose to 477,000 in the month, the highest since 2008.
A growing number of Americans have seen their savings dwindle as rising prices squeeze budgets.
The Fed created so much money during the pandemic that, by some measures, the excess has still not been fully absorbed by the economy.
The Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC. The US central bank's next action is likely to be an interest rate hike instead of a cut, say some economists.

site_title: NTUC aims to do more to support PMEs, who now account for nearly half its membership
summary: NTUC aims to better support nearly half of its 1.4 million members, professionals, managers, and executives (PMEs). The union plans to focus on career protection, progression, and job placement. NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng emphasized the need for PMEs to join the labour movement to benefit from NTUC's support, shifting the perception that NTUC is only for blue-collar workers.

images.alt_text: Employers are not obliged to accede to all FWA requests “due to practical reasons and constraints,” said SNEF.
Employers’ increased flexibility and openness to a wider talent pool has made them better able to fill vacancies, resulting in the proportion of harder-to-fill spots trending down, says MOM.
The best way for Singapore to deal with inflation is for business and wages to grow in real terms, says Finance Minister Lawrence Wong.

site_title: Meta’s results are best viewed through rose-tinted AI glasses
summary: Meta Platforms' first-quarter results were met with disappointment, with shares sliding 19% in after-hours trading due to lower-than-expected revenue forecast and increased capital expenditure expectations. The company's focus on artificial intelligence and the "metaverse" project is still uncertain, with significant spending and risks involved. Despite this, CEO Mark Zuckerberg emphasized the potential of AI, citing 30% of Facebook's recommended content now driven by AI, and early sales of Ray-Ban smart glasses. Investors must decide whether to trust Zuckerberg and Meta's long-term vision.

images.alt_text: Meta’s latest technology is being rolled out in more than a dozen English-speaking countries, including Australia, Canada, Singapore and the United States.

Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg says the biggest version of Llama 3 is currently being trained with 400 billion parameters and already scoring 85 MMLU, citing metrics used to convey the strength and performance quality of AI models.
Catherine Wood's ARK Invest predicts that AI will "transform every sector, impact every business, and catalyse every innovation platform".

site_title: Barclays Q1 profit falls 12% as mortgage competition, deals drought hit
summary: Barclays reported a 12% fall in first-quarter profit to £2.277 billion, down from £2.6 billion a year ago, due to increased mortgage competition, lower trading income, and a lack of mergers and acquisitions fees. The bank aims to restore investor faith in its universal banking model through investments in domestic banking and cost-cutting measures. Analysts' forecasts were met, and rival Deutsche Bank posted a 10% increase in Q1 profit. Barclays plans to sell an Italian retail mortgage book, generating a pre-tax loss of £225 million, to simplify its exposures.

images.alt_text: The British companies have a market capitalisation of £200 billion, equivalent to 8 per cent of the stock market

site_title: Deutsche Bank Q1 profit jumps 10% as investment bank outperforms
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a 10% increase in Q1 profit, driven by a resurgence in fixed-income trading and deal-making at its investment banking division. This marks the 15th consecutive quarter of profit for the bank, which had suffered heavy losses in the past decade. Net profit attributable to shareholders rose to 1.275 billion euros, beating analyst expectations. The bank's investment banking division is expected to remain its biggest income generator through 2026, a shift from last year's forecast.

images.alt_text: As many as 60 roles were culled in Singapore and Hong Kong at Deutsche Bank over the past year.

site_title: LSEG reports in-line first quarter as Microsoft partnership progresses
summary: LSEG (London Stock Exchange Group) reported in-line first quarter results, with total income excluding recoveries at £2.089 billion and gross profit at £1.893 billion. The company's organic annual subscription value growth came in at 6% in the first quarter, short of expectations. Despite this, LSEG remains confident of continued growth and improving profitability, with CEO David Schwimmer citing the progress of its Microsoft partnership and the integration of Refinitiv as key drivers. The company also completed a £500 million directed buyback in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: LSEG's adjusted operating profit hit £2.86 billion, in line with expectations.
Britain is reforming its financial sector in a bid to remain globally competitive as UK tech companies like chip designer Arm Holdings choose to list in New York.

site_title: Born in Oasi Zegna: Take a colourful, quirky trip
summary: Zegna's new book, "Born in Oasi Zegna," chronicles the history of the Italian luxury brand and its founder's legacy. The 2.5 kg book features beautifully illustrated pages, quirky illustrations, and historic documents, tracing the brand's pursuit of superior wool fabric and commitment to sustainable practices. The book, divided into four chapters, showcases the founder's efforts to uplift his community and provide social welfare to his staff and their families. It is illustrated by acclaimed artists and includes interactive elements to engage readers, offering a unique and immersive experience.

images.alt_text: To mark the launch of its book, Born in Oasi Zegna, the Italian luxury menswear label carried out multiple activations during Milan Design Week.

site_title: Hermes Q1 sales jump 17% on strong China demand
summary: Hermes reported a 17% surge in first-quarter sales, driven by strong demand in China and Asia. The luxury goods group's sales rose to 3.81 billion euros, beating expectations and outpacing rival LVMH. Despite a slight slowdown in China following the Chinese New Year holiday, Hermes' sales in Asia excluding Japan grew 14%, while all other regions reported double-digit rises. The company's leather goods division grew 20% in the quarter, driven by new models and price increases.

images.alt_text: Kering warned of a sharp decline in first-half profits, attributing it to weak demand in Asia, especially China, and challenges with revitalizing Gucci.

File photo of a Hermes Silver Metallic Chevre Birkin 30 handbag up for auction at Sotheby's in New York City, June 1, 2023. Among the brands, flagship label Prada’s retail sales grew by 7 per cent in the January-to-March period, while Miu Miu, which accounts for around 15 per cent of total sales, posted an 89 per cent increase.
A healthy portion of the purchases by Chinese tourists occurred in Japan, where the well-heeled took advantage of the weak yen to buy Louis Vuitton bags and other costly items for less.

site_title: South Korea readies new system to detect illegal short-selling
summary: South Korea's financial market watchdog is checking the effectiveness of a new system to detect illegal short-selling of domestic stocks, which bans 'naked' short-selling. The new system will electronically process transactions and filter them through a central detection system. The ban on short selling is set to remain until adequate prevention measures are adopted. The regulator aims to resolve the "Korea discount", a phenomenon where domestic companies have lower valuations than global peers due to factors such as low dividend payouts and opaque governance structures.

images.alt_text: South Korea expects its economic growth to accelerate to more than 2 per cent this year, as exports continue to advance.
Policymakers can ill afford a steep drop in property prices that might exacerbate bad loans and hurt the economy, as happened in Japan in the 1990s.
The momentum in exports has been felt in other parts of Asia, a region with factories that make advanced components in high-tech consumer products.
South Korean doctors march to protest against the government medical policy in front of the Presidential office in Seoul, South Korea, February 25, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Soo-Hyeon

site_title: Hamilton: History told in hip-hop harmonies
summary: The Broadway musical sensation "Hamilton" has made its debut in Singapore at the Sands Theatre in Marina Bay Sands, with style and sizzle intact. The nearly three-hour-long musical narrates the life of American founding father Alexander Hamilton, told through hip-hop, R&B, and jazz melodies. The cast, comprising predominantly black, Latino, and Asian actors playing white historical characters, has drawn a broader audience, including teenagers who know its lyrics by heart. The show, which runs until May 26, is a thrilling story of an immigrant made good, resonating with creator Lin-Manuel Miranda, who drew inspiration from Ron Chernow's biography of the statesman.

images.alt_text: Artist Robert Zhao (left) and senior curator Haeju KIm against the forest-like structure in the Singapore Pavilion.

site_title: FTSE 100 hits record high on big mining M&A, earnings push
summary: The FTSE 100 index reached a record high of 8,098.14, driven by a surge in Anglo-American's shares after BHP Group made a £31.1 billion offer to buy the miner. The deal would create the world's largest copper miner. Other blue-chip firms like Unilever, AstraZeneca, and Barclays also saw significant gains, with AstraZeneca and Unilever rising 5.3% and 4.1%, respectively, due to strong quarterly earnings reports. The FTSE 350 industrial metal miners index rose 2.6% and the FTSE 100 ticked up 0.7%.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A pedestrian walks past the logo for the London Stock Exchange Group outside the stock exchange in London on December 29, 2020. The Metropolitan Police reported Sunday, January 14, that detectives had arrested six activists from the Palestine Action group who were intending to target the London Stock Exchange on Monday morning (15th), with the intention of preventing the building from opening for trading. (Photo by Tolga Akmen / AFP)

site_title: Japan brokerage Daiwa’s Q4 profit more than doubles as markets recover
summary: Daiwa Securities Group, Japan's second-largest brokerage and investment bank, reported a 131% year-on-year jump in quarterly net profit to 131 billion yen. The company's focus on wealth management services, rather than traditional commissions, contributed to the strong results. The retail division saw its highest profit in eight years, while the global investment banking segment generated record revenue. Daiwa aims to grow its M&A business by 50% over eight years and ranked fifth among Japanese firms in terms of M&A deals in 2024.

images.alt_text: Japan has missed out on that opportunity over the last three decades as Wall Street firms poured resources into rival hubs such as Hong Kong to tap into mainland China.
The M&A deal boom has echoes in other markets.

site_title: Sanofi Q1 profit slips on generic competition, forex effects
summary: Sanofi's Q1 operating income declined 14.7% due to unfavourable currency effects and generic competition. The French drugmaker reported 2.84 billion euros in adjusted operating income, slightly above analyst expectations. Sanofi expects 2024 adjusted earnings per share to slip by a "low single-digit" percentage, citing higher taxes and increased development expenditure. Quarterly sales of Dupixent, an eczema and asthma drug, jumped 25% currency-adjusted to 2.84 billion euros.

site_title: Cordlife’s independent auditor to retire after issuing disclaimer of opinion on FY2023 financials
summary: Cordlife's independent auditor, KPMG, has decided not to seek reappointment, citing insufficient audit evidence for several areas, including the company's compliance with laws and regulations amid ongoing investigations by the Ministry of Health and Commercial Affairs Department. KPMG also expressed uncertainty in providing an audit opinion on refunds and claims, citing unquantified damages from temperature excursions affecting cord-blood units. The company's financial statements for FY2023 have been flagged with material discrepancies between audited and unaudited accounts.

images.alt_text: The arrests of Cordlife's directors and group chief executive are related to alleged breaches-of-disclosure obligations regarding irregular temperatures in its storage tanks.

The cord-life bank had previously received two letters dated Apr 22 from SAC Capital, stating that Nanjing Xinjiekou was reviewing its shareholding in Cordlife and considering making an offer to increase its shareholding.
Customers of Cordlife are mulling legal action against the company after an additional 5,300 cord-blood units were found to be at high risk of being adversely affected by the temperature excursions.
