In letters seen by ST, parents who have been paying their storage fee annually have been offered refunds of $537.50.

site_title: Toyota hits record annual output, sales on robust demand
summary: Toyota achieved record annual sales and production, with global sales rising 7.3% to 10.31 million units and output increasing 9.2% to 9.97 million units. Despite this, the company plans to delay US EV production to 2026 to ensure product safety and quality, following scandals at group firms. Global battery EV sales jumped 300% to 116,654 units. Toyota's sales and production fell in March due to fierce competition in China, but the company remains the world's largest automaker by volume.

images.alt_text: The fresh US$300 million will be split evenly between the Toyota Ventures' second climate fund and its second deep technology fund.
Chinese carmakers were in the spotlight amid the growing challenge to Japanese auto giants that have long dominated Thailand’s vehicle market.
Toyota Motor North America, a unit of Japan’s Toyota Motor, sold 565,098 vehicles compared with 469,558 units a year earlier.
Koji Sato enters his second year as CEO, faced with the challenge of expanding corporate value in the rapidly changing automotive industry.

site_title: China's largest auto show displays all-electric future, local brands dominate
summary: China's largest auto show kicked off in Beijing, featuring 278 new energy vehicles (NEVs) from 117 new models, a 7% increase from last year. The show comes as NEV sales reached 50% of total car sales in China, marking a significant milestone. Local brands dominate the display, highlighting China's shift towards an all-electric future. The event runs through early next month, showcasing the country's commitment to electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Nissan has introduced two battery electric vehicle (EV) concept cars and two plug-in petrol-electric hybrids, all from a joint effort with local partner Dongfeng.

site_title: Venice residents protest as city begins tourist entry charge
summary: Residents of Venice protested the city's introduction of a 5-euro fee for day-trippers, citing concerns it would turn the city into a "theme park." The fee aims to reduce crowds and promote a new balance between residents and tourists. Despite the councillor's intention to find a balance, hundreds of protesters disagree, viewing the fee as an attempt to control the city.

images.alt_text: There will be no limit on the number of people entering the city, at least initially, as city authorities study the efficiency of the system.
Artist Robert Zhao (left) and senior curator Haeju KIm against the forest-like structure in the Singapore Pavilion.
Singaporean artists taking part in Venice Biennale.

site_title: Nissan, Mazda roll out new models for China as they aim for comeback
summary: Japanese automakers Nissan and Mazda unveiled new models for China's growing market, aiming to regain ground after losing market share to local manufacturers. Nissan introduced two battery EV concept cars and two plug-in hybrids, while Mazda introduced an EZ-6 sedan with two powertrain variants. The moves follow a decline in sales for Nissan, which slumped 16% to 794,000 vehicles last year, and Mazda, which lost 72% of its 2017 market share. The companies plan to export cars from China starting in 2025, targeting 100,000 to 200,000 vehicles annually.

images.alt_text: Carmakers have returned more money to shareholders in recent months after benefiting from pent-up demand after years of supply-chain disruptions.
Xiaomi targets more than 100,000 deliveries for the SU7 in 2024.
Mitsubishi Motors at the Montreal Electric Vehicle Show. US protectionism against China is creating an opportunity for Japanese carmakers to bring EV production to North America.

site_title: Cisco says hackers subverted its security devices to spy on governments
summary: Hackers, identified as a "sophisticated state-sponsored actor" group called UAT4356, subverted Cisco's security devices to spy on government networks globally, exploiting previously unknown vulnerabilities in the company's Adaptive Security Appliances. The breaches occurred earlier this year and have been patched. Cisco urges customers to update their software immediately. The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has released an alert on the vulnerabilities, but has not confirmed evidence of US government network involvement at this time.

images.alt_text: Cisco has announced the acquisition of data-crunching software maker Splunk in September 2023.
The deal announced last year is Cisco’s biggest-ever and aims to boost its software business amid a boom in artificial intelligence.
Cisco has agreed to buy Splunk in a deal valued at about US$28 billion in September.
Cisco will incur a charge of US$800 million on the layoffs before tax consisting of severance and other costs.

site_title: Blinken to meet businesses in Shanghai as he kicks off a tough China trip
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken is visiting China, meeting with business leaders in Shanghai, and holding talks with Foreign Minister Wang Yi and President Xi Jinping in Beijing. Blinken aims to resolve issues such as China's supply of chemicals used to make fentanyl, the South China Sea, and China's backing of Russia in Ukraine. Despite tensions, Blinken notes that "face-to-face diplomacy matters" in advancing US interests and avoiding miscommunications. The visit follows stabilizing ties between the US and China, but strains remain over various issues.

images.alt_text: Many buyers and sellers at China’s biggest trade event have shrugged off the risk of an escalating trade war.
While the US bars Nvidia and its partners from selling advanced chips to China, including via third parties, the sale and purchase of the chips are not illegal in China.
Chinese policymakers already battling a protracted property crisis and weak demand at home have scant incentive to escalate tensions.

site_title: XPeng CEO says its software, AI upgrades to enter ‘super fast cycle’
summary: XPeng, a Chinese electric vehicle maker backed by Volkswagen, plans to refresh its software and artificial intelligence (AI) upgrades every two months, entering a "super fast cycle" from May. The company aims to hire 4,000 people and invest 3.5 billion yuan in AI for intelligent driving technology. CEO He Xiaopeng predicts XPeng will surpass rivals in China's autonomous driving technology, while also expanding its platform to other Asian countries and Europe. The company plans to sell a smart EV under the brand "Mona" and pre-sell a flying car in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: BYD, which overtook Tesla to become the world’s largest EV producer in late 2023, saw sales jump 46 per cent year on year to 302,459 vehicles.
Cars produced through the partnership will carry the VW logo.

site_title: China's Sinopec charts global expansion with refinery in rival India's backyard
summary: Sinopec, the world's largest oil refiner, plans to build a refinery at Sri Lanka's Hambantota port, a move that puts it in direct competition with India's efforts to expand its energy supplier role in the country. The $4.5 billion project, set to be completed by June, is a shift in Sinopec's global strategy to compensate for slowing demand growth at home. This move is part of the company's efforts to access Sri Lanka's market and gain greater access to the country's energy needs.

images.alt_text: Signage at a China Petroleum & Chemical Corp. (Sinopec) gas station in Hong Kong, China, on Thursday, March 21, 2024. Sinopec is scheduled to release earnings on March 24. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore Q1 industrial rents rise further as occupancy dips and prices fall: JTC
summary: Singapore's industrial rents rose 1.7% in Q1, driven by higher rents for prime logistics spaces, but occupancy rates dipped 0.3% to 88.7% due to increased supply. Prices fell 0.2% for the first time in 13 quarters, with overall rental transaction volume down 9% from the previous year. Experts expect rents to continue moderating and prices to ease, with slowing global growth and higher supply.

images.alt_text: JTC buildings near the Ayer Rajah industrial estate on 29 October 2019.

site_title: American extradited to Singapore gets 39 months’ jail for ponzi forex scheme
summary: A US citizen, Michael Philip Atkins, was sentenced to 39 months in jail for running a Ponzi forex scheme in Singapore that scammed over 1,300 clients of $18 million. Atkins, 51, was director at Aureus Capital, a Singapore-based firm, and used only a fraction of client funds for forex trading. He pleaded guilty in April 2023 and was extradited from the US to Singapore, where he was re-arrested.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as global rally stalls, eyes on yen
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday as investors became cautious after three days of significant gains, driven by Meta's warning of increased spending. The yen hit a 34-year low, prompting concerns of intervention by Japan's authorities. Meanwhile, key US inflation data is set to be released on Friday, which could impact the Federal Reserve's interest rate plans. Despite this, Hong Kong resumed its latest rally, while Shanghai and Manila also rose, offsetting declines in Tokyo, Singapore, and Jakarta.

images.alt_text: Asia continued the week’s rally, with Tokyo and Taipei up more than two per cent, while Hong Kong, Seoul and Manila were more than one per cent higher.

site_title: Swedish manufacturer is latest to offer electric pleasure craft in Singapore
summary: Swedish manufacturer Candela has made its Asia-Pacific debut in Singapore, offering electric pleasure craft and ferries. The company's C-8 electric boat has a range of around 60 nautical miles per charge and uses battery technology from Polestar. Candela aims to sell ferries as well, with the P-12 model undergoing testing as a public ferry in Stockholm, Sweden. The company sees potential in Singapore's market for recreational vessels and harbour craft, with plans to appoint dealers in the region.

images.alt_text: A charging point for electric harbour craft by Pyxis Maritime and SP Mobility under a pilot project initiated by the Maritime Port Authority of Singapore.
Shipping contributes 3 per cent of current total emissions; that number could balloon to 10 per cent by 2050 unless alternative fuels are rapidly developed, commercialised and scaled.
Arsenio Dominguez, secretary-general of the International Maritime Organisation, says that two issues he has prioritised are decarbonisation and terrorist attacks in the Red Sea.
Photo illustration for cybersecurity stories

site_title: Axiata, Sinar Mas move closer to US$3.5 billion telco merger
summary: Indonesian wireless carrier Axiata Group and conglomerate Sinar Mas Group are moving forward with plans to merge their telecommunications operations, valued at approximately US$3.5 billion. The potential deal would create a 100 million customer base, combining XL Axiata and Smartfren Telecom. A non-binding agreement may be reached in the coming months, allowing for further negotiations and due diligence. The process is private, and there's no guarantee the companies will proceed with the merger.

images.alt_text: Axiata said Edotco Investments (Labuan), a wholly owned subsidiary of its telco tower arm Edotco Group, had agreed to sell its entire 87.5 per cent stake in Edotco Investments Singapore, the sole shareholder of Edotco Myanmar.
Axiata’s Link Net has a market value of about 3.5 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, FCT, Suntec Reit, OUE Reit, Clint, Digital Core Reit, OKP, Cordlife
summary: Stocks to watch on April 25, 2024: Keppel's Q1 revenue declined 6.3% to S$1.5 billion, while Frasers Centrepoint Trust's DPU dropped 1.8% to 6.022 cents. Suntec Reit's DPU declined 13% year-over-year, while OUE Reit's NPI and revenue increased 6.9% and 9.5%, respectively. Digital Core Reit's distributable income decreased 2.4% to US$10.6 million. OKP secured a S$92.9 million contract, and Cordlife Group's auditor declined re-appointment due to a disclaimer of opinion on the company's consolidated financial statements.

images.alt_text: Gainers outnumbered losers 405 to 205, after 1.9 billion securities worth S$1.5 billion changed hands.

site_title: Singapore shares retreat at Thursday’s open; STI down 1.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 1.1% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 37.1 points to 3,256.03. The broader market saw losers outnumber gainers 84 to 30, with notable declines in banking stocks like DBS (-1%), OCBC (-0.1%), and UOB (-2.8%). The declines were influenced by global market trends, with the Nasdaq Composite Index and S&P 500 experiencing little change.

images.alt_text: Keppel posts a 6.3 per cent drop in revenue to S$1.5 billion in the first quarter of 2024.

site_title: Mercedes says it will continue to invest in China tie-ups
summary: Mercedes-Benz announced plans to continue investing in China tie-ups, despite a 12% decline in first-quarter sales in the country. The company's China chief, Hubertus Troska, stated that China is crucial to Mercedes' global strategy, citing the country's dynamic new energy vehicle market. Mercedes also showcased electric models at the Beijing autoshow and plans to launch the electric G-class in China this year. The company has pushed back sales goals for electrified vehicles by five years and aims to spruce up its combustion-engine models.

site_title: Markets are embracing India’s Modi for what he won’t do
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is likely to win a third term, sparking optimism in the global financial industry. Unlike his predecessor, Modi has toned down his promises of major economic reforms, instead focusing on investment and growth through discretionary incentives and protective trade barriers. Investors are betting on what Modi won't do, such as taking an authoritarian turn or imposing harsh policies on the private sector. Modi's government is expected to invest heavily in key sectors, with tycoons like Gautam Adani and Mukesh Ambani poised to benefit from the prime minister's vision of Indian growth.

images.alt_text: A voter's finger is marked with indelible ink after casting a ballot at a polling station during the first phase of voting for national elections in Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India, on Friday, April 19, 2024. Almost 1 billion Indians begin voting today in elections lasting more than six weeks, weighing up whether to hand Prime Minister Narendra Modi a third five-year term to continue his mix of economic and Hindu nationalist policies. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg
Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is widely tipped to win a record-equalling third term in the general election, which begins on Friday.

site_title: Morgan Stanley Asia private equity unit to reorganise as CEO retires
summary: Morgan Stanley Asia's private equity unit is reorganizing as its CEO, Chou Chin, retires. A China-focused team will be carved out from the rest of the region, focusing on investments in onshore and offshore China. Xu Jun, head of yuan-denominated investment funds, will lead all private equity investing in China. The reorganization aims to capitalize on China's growing economic influence in the region.

images.alt_text: Global financial firms are seeking to reduce expenses amid a deal drought.
Morgan Stanley’s total revenue increased to US$15.14 billion in the first quarter.
Asian central banks are unlikely to lower rates ahead of the Fed to protect their currencies.

site_title: Malaysia mulls over plans for casino in Forest City as part of Johor-S’pore Special Economic Zone: sources
summary: Malaysia is considering allowing a casino in the RM450 billion Forest City project in Johor, part of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone. The proposed development aims to revitalize the troubled reclaimed islands and boost the local economy. However, opening a second casino in the country could prompt political backlash from the Malay-Muslim majority, who are already struggling to win over the Anwar government. Genting Group, which controls Malaysia's only casino, is reportedly involved in the discussions, and proponents see the casino as a boon for the Forest City township and the wider Johor economy.

images.alt_text: The RTS Link development has been seen as a game-changer to Malaysia and Singapore, the project is expected to complete in end-2026.
Shopping crowd at The Exchange TRX mall in Kuala Lumpur, economists expect Malaysia’s inflation to go higher in coming months underpinned by resilient consumer spending.
Forest City houses fewer than 10,000 people - about 1 per cent of its target.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 falls on banks drag; tech contains losses on ASMI boost
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell 0.5% on Wednesday, as financials declined 2% due to disappointing earnings from Handelsbanken and SEB. Tech stocks rose 1.3% after ASM International's strong forecast. Despite a long-term average of 54% exceeding earnings estimates, sentiment soured due to concerns about the European Central Bank's interest rate cut. The ECB may cut rates by 25 basis points in June, but not follow with further policy easing.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index jumped 1.1 per cent on Tuesday, boosted by technology shares that advanced 2.6 per cent.

site_title: South Korea’s economic growth beats forecast as exports rise
summary: South Korea's economy grew 1.3% in the first quarter, beating forecast, driven by a surge in exports and construction investment. Exports increased 8.3% year-on-year, with technology products such as semiconductors driving growth. The government expects economic growth to accelerate to over 2% this year. Despite this, risks remain, including inflation and geopolitical tensions, and the central bank may keep interest rates restrictive for longer. The economic growth is seen as a positive for President Yoon Suk-yeol, but his government may face pressure to accommodate opposition demands for more stimulus after recent parliamentary elections.

images.alt_text: Policymakers can ill afford a steep drop in property prices that might exacerbate bad loans and hurt the economy, as happened in Japan in the 1990s.
The momentum in exports has been felt in other parts of Asia, a region with factories that make advanced components in high-tech consumer products.
South Korean doctors march to protest against the government medical policy in front of the Presidential office in Seoul, South Korea, February 25, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Soo-Hyeon

site_title: VinFast chief plans to invest US$1 billion more from his fortune in EV maker
summary: Vietnamese billionaire Pham Nhat Vuong, chairman of Vingroup, plans to invest an additional US$1 billion from his fortune into VinFast, the electric vehicle maker, where he already has US$11.4 billion invested. Vuong expressed confidence in the electric vehicle market's growth, stating it will surpass combustion engine cars. The investment is seen as a commitment to VinFast despite its loss-making status, with Vuong saying he will not give up on the company.

images.alt_text: VinFast received US$11.4 billion of capital injections from Vingroup, its affiliates and the group’s billionaire founder Pham Nhat Vuong.
VinFast plans to expand to 50 countries.
VinFast's India CEO Pham Sanh Chau says the company is already closely working with some 55 Indian dealers to have a sales network.

site_title: Zilingo ex-CEO’s criminal complaint is retaliation against whistleblowers: source
summary: Former Zilingo CEO Ankiti Bose has filed a criminal complaint against co-founder Dhruv Kapoor and ex-COO Aadi Vaidya, alleging they misled investors and forced her to relinquish shares under false pretences. Bose claims they retaliated against her after she was fired in 2022 following allegations of financial irregularities. Kapoor and Vaidya deny the allegations, calling them "completely baseless and untrue". A source close to Zilingo supports Kapoor's statement, suggesting Bose's complaint is retaliation for their whistleblowing efforts that exposed the company's issues.

images.alt_text: Singapore-based Zilingo provides digital services for e-commerce merchants.
The Zilingo meltdown has rattled the tech industry in South-east Asia and beyond.

site_title: Oil settles lower as US business activity cools, concerns over Middle East ease
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday as US business activity cooled and concerns over the Middle East eased. Brent crude futures dropped 40 US cents, or 0.45%, to $88.02 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures slipped 55 US cents, or 0.66%, to $82.81. A decline in US crude inventories and a weaker US dollar also contributed to the decline. Analysts expect a US$90 per barrel ceiling on Brent due to perceived de-escalation between Iran and Israel.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose US$1.42, or 1.6 per cent, to settle at US$88.42 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures climbed US$1.46, or 1.8 per cent, to US$83.36 a barrel.

site_title: Lucrum Capital looks to sell Killiney hotel site for S$195 million
summary: Lucrum Capital is selling the freehold boutique hotel under construction in Killiney Road, Singapore, for S$195 million. The seven-storey Mama Shelter Singapore Orchard hotel, operated by Accor's Ennismore, is expected to open in 2025. The site was acquired by Lucrum Capital in 2017 for S$84.9 million and was initially planned for redevelopment into a serviced apartment. The current price tag works out to around S$1.7 million per room, with a rooftop pool and bar, and a 40-metre-wide main road frontage along Killiney Road.

images.alt_text: The former Singapore Restricted Passport Centre at the now-vacant 240 Outram Road.
Typically, investors look at wealth preservation and capital appreciation when buying shophouses, said Savills Singapore.
MBS' revenue from hotel rooms grew 29.9 per cent to US$126 million in Q1 from US$97 million a year ago.

site_title: SK Hynix expects full chip recovery after Q1 earnings surprise on AI boom
summary: SK Hynix, South Korea's second-largest memory chipmaker, reported a 2.9 trillion won (S$2.9 billion) operating profit in its first quarter, surpassing expectations and marking its second-highest profit in nearly two years. The company attributes the improvement to strong AI demand, with its HBM3 chips being the main supplier to Nvidia's AI systems. SK Hynix expects a full recovery in memory chips and plans to invest $3.87 billion in an advanced chip packaging plant and $5.3 trillion won in a new Dram chip factory, with AI products expected to account for double-digit sales in 2024.

images.alt_text: The total investment in the new production base is expected to be more than 20 trillion won (S$19.8 billion) in the long term.
SK hynix dominates the market for HBM chips - crucial components to power artificial intelligence - and is a top supplier to US-based chip titan Nvidia. TSMC also supplies Nvidia.
SK Hynix has evolved into a key player in the AI development boom as the leading designer and producer of so-called HBM chips.
HBM chips are advanced memory chips in high demand for use in the GPUs produced by Nvidia and others that process vast amounts of data in generative AI.

site_title: IBM falls on weak consulting sales, overshadowing HashiCorp deal
summary: IBM's stock fell 9% in extended trading after the company reported weak consulting unit sales, despite announcing a $6.4 billion acquisition of HashiCorp, a software firm that helps manage cloud-computing operations. First-quarter sales gained 1% to $14.5 billion, with the consulting division's revenue remaining unchanged from the previous year. The acquisition is IBM's largest since buying Red Hat in 2019 and aims to turn the legacy tech hardware company into a focus on high-growth software and services.

images.alt_text: IBM’s largest acquisition to date remains its US$34 billion acquisition of Red Hat in 2019.

IBM recently hit its highest since 2013, putting it about 6 per cent below an all-time high as investors bet that a turnaround is finally bearing fruit after years of tepid growth and share-price returns.
IBM said it was using Adobe’s tools, which can generate images from text-based prompts, to help with marketing campaigns.

site_title: Gold trades in tight range as market focuses on US economic data
summary: Gold prices remain flat at US$2,317.03 per ounce, stuck in a tight range as investors await US economic data for clarity on the Federal Reserve's interest rate path. The market is also watching for the first-quarter US GDP data and March personal consumption expenditures report. Recent remarks from Federal Reserve officials suggest no urgency to cut rates, with traders expecting the first rate cut in September. Higher interest rates reduce gold's appeal, contributing to the tight range.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: American gold bars stand on display during a preview of "Gold", a new exhibition dedicated to the highly prized mineral at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, November 15, 2006.   REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo

site_title: Condo resale volumes rebound in March; prices inch up 0.4%: SRX, 99.co
summary: Condo resale volumes rebounded 17.4% in March, reaching a seven-month high, with 883 units sold. However, this represents a 22.8% decline year-over-year. Possible reasons for the recovery include resumptions of condo launches and a spillover effect on the resale market. Resale prices inched up 0.4% but were 5% higher year-over-year. Foreign buyers accounted for 1.3% of total resale volume, up from 0.5% in February. Despite the uptick, analysts note that high interest rates and pricing expectations may weigh on transactions.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of private properties in Singapore.

site_title: Battery firm LG Energy Solution Q1 profit plunges on weak EV sales
summary: LG Energy Solution, a South Korean battery firm, reported a 75% drop in quarterly profit due to weakening demand from electric vehicle sales. The company's operating profit declined to 157 billion won, down from 633 billion won a year earlier. Revenue fell 30% to 6.1 trillion won. The decline is attributed to a decrease in sales from major customer Tesla, which reported a decline in quarterly sales and plans to accelerate the roll-out of more affordable EVs.

site_title: PropertyBT: Making sense of residential property taxes (Ep 30)
summary: Senior correspondent Leslie Yee discusses residential property taxes with CBRE's Tricia Song, exploring whether property taxes will rise further and their impact on owner-occupiers and non-occupiers. Key concerns include retirees' ability to afford their homes with rising annual values, potential concessions, and the risk of increased property tax.

images.alt_text: Owner-occupiers of pricier private homes may wish to factor in higher property taxes in their retirement planning.
Retirees who are owner-occupiers of private homes should be mindful that costs linked to home ownership such as property tax may rise over the long term.
Did you know you can invest in landed homes with just a fraction of the capital?
Is it better to own physical property or buy listed property equities?

site_title: TSMC says ‘A16’ chipmaking tech to arrive in 2026, setting up showdown with Intel
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) announced plans to introduce its A16 chipmaking technology in the second half of 2026, potentially outpacing Intel's 14A technology. The new technology is expected to be adopted by AI chip firms first, rather than smartphone manufacturers. TSMC's A16 chipmaking process was developed faster than expected due to high demand from AI chip companies, and the company may not need to use Intel's expensive High NA EUV lithography tool machines. Analysts question Intel's claims of overtaking TSMC in making the world's fastest computing chips.

images.alt_text: “We are progressing very well on all fronts. A lot of manufacturing is ongoing – some of it is completed even before schedule,” Orsted’s Asia-Pacific president Per Mejnert Kristensen says.
The most obvious hallmark of Mark Liu's term as TSMC chairman is the company's global expansion.
SK hynix dominates the market for HBM chips - crucial components to power artificial intelligence - and is a top supplier to US-based chip titan Nvidia. TSMC also supplies Nvidia.

Workers carry out rescue operation at the site where a building collapsed, following the earthquake, in Hualien, Taiwan, in this screengrab taken from a SET TV video shot April 3, 2024. SET TV/Handout via REUTERS  ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. MANDATORY CREDIT. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES. TAIWAN OUT. NO COMMERCIAL OR EDITORIAL SALES IN TAIWAN

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust posts 1.8% drop in H1 DPU to S$0.06022
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 1.8% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.06022 for the first half ended Mar 31, due to declines in gross revenue and net property income. The decline was attributed to lower contributions from Tampines 1, undergoing asset enhancement works, and Changi City Point, divested in October 2023. Excluding these factors, gross revenue would have grown 2.9% and NPI would have risen 2.1%.

images.alt_text: FCT said in January it would pay S$523.1 mil for an additional 24.5 per cent of Nex, a shopping mall close to the Serangoon MRT station
FCT’s portfolio has grown to nine suburban retail malls and an office building with a combined S$6.5 billion in assets under management as at Dec 31, 2023.
CapitaLand Ascott Trust, ComfortDelGro, Keppel DC Reit, Keppel Reit and Suntec Reit are in the STI reserve list.
Proceeds from the placement will be used to partially fund FCT’s acquisition of Frasers Property’s 24.5 per cent stake in retail mall Nex.
FCT manager notes that the agreed property of value of Nex is S$2.1 billion, an average between two independent valuations as at the end of last December.

site_title: Seatrium will have to wait longer to catch wind in sail
summary: Seatrium, a Singapore-listed offshore and marine giant, is expected to recover its profitability after grappleing with lawsuits and loss-making projects post-pandemic. Analysts see a light at the end of the tunnel, citing recent contract wins and the company's announcement of a third offshore wind project. However, Seatrium's share price has corrected due to write-down uncertainty and delayed contract awards, and its profitability targets seem less inspiring. The company expects to generate S$1 billion in Ebitda by 2028, but has already achieved S$600 million in Ebitda before provisions and write-downs in 2023.

images.alt_text: A lack of investment in the oil and gas sector after the oil price crash of 2016 has resulted in muted supply of vessels despite strong demand amid buoyant oil prices.
Seatrium unit ordered to pay US$108 million in arbitration over equipment supply contracts
Both companies intend to promote best practices in the design and construction of floating production systems.

site_title: WhirlPool is cutting 1,000 jobs as US appliance demand remains stagnant
summary: Whirlpool is cutting 1,000 salaried positions worldwide to reduce costs amid stagnant US home sales, which limit demand for large appliances. The company employed 59,000 workers worldwide as of 2023. Whirlpool aims to reduce expenses by $400 million this year, but higher labor and transportation costs are making it tougher. Sales of large appliances in North America fell 8.1% in the first quarter, and the company is shifting focus to smaller countertop appliances and remodelling services.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The administrative entrance at the Whirlpool plant in Clyde, Ohio, U.S. October 3, 2017. Picture taken October 3, 2017.  REUTERS/Aaron Josefczyk/File Photo
Supply disruptions have stabilised and that’s also helping the business, Jim Peters says.
The economy in the US — Whirlpool’s largest market — has been stalling as inflation and narrower access to credit weigh on consumer spending.

site_title: China 2024 growth outlook raised to 4.8%, deflation risk lingers
summary: China's growth outlook for 2024 has been upgraded to 4.8% due to a better-than-expected first quarter performance, but analysts still see deflationary pressures lingering. Consumer price inflation is forecast to average 0.6% in 2024, down from 0.8%, and industrial prices are expected to fall at an average 0.6% pace. The property downturn poses the biggest risk to China's growth, with low inflation and weak domestic consumption also being major concerns. The government is expected to implement fiscal measures to stabilize demand, with central government spending set to increase.

images.alt_text: Kering warned of a sharp decline in first-half profits, attributing it to weak demand in Asia, especially China, and challenges with revitalizing Gucci.
Destinations that have either waived the visa process for Chinese citizens or are offering electronic visas on arrival include Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, and the Middle East and North Africa.
Steel analysts have also said that China’s exports of hot-rolled coil are being fuelled by a tax scam that effectively allows Chinese traders to trim VAT payments and make even cheaper export offers.
The average coupon in April on new debt fell to just 2.83 per cent – the lowest level in data going back to 1999.
Beijing has revealed about its plan for incentives that will encourage Chinese businesses and households to adopt cleaner technologies.

site_title: OCBC should put its properties into a Reit and distribute the trust’s units to shareholders
summary: OCBC, Singapore's longest-established bank, is exploring the redevelopment of its 63, 65 Chulia Street and 18 Church Street properties to create a new CBD landmark. The redevelopment, which could exceed S$2.5 billion in gross development value, may be bundled into a Singapore-listed real estate investment trust (Reit) and distributed to shareholders as units. This move aims to optimize property value, reduce management costs, and provide shareholders with potential asset appreciation. OCBC's shareholders are expected to welcome the proposal, which could also lead to increased dividend payments.

images.alt_text: The bank's properties include OCBC Centre, OCBC Centre South and OCBC Centre East.
OCBC Centre South in the foreground. To the left behind it is the 50-storey OCBC Centre, where the bank's head office is located/

site_title: Meta profits soar but costs of AI cause worry
summary: Meta Platforms reported a 27% increase in quarterly revenue to $36.5 billion, with net profit rising to $12.4 billion, driven by growth in US ads. However, the company's share price took a hit due to concerns over the cost of artificial intelligence (AI). Meta's latest technology is being rolled out in over a dozen English-speaking countries. CEO Mark Zuckerberg attributed the growth to the estimated 3.2 billion daily users of its apps.

images.alt_text: The move will allow partner companies to build their headsets using Meta Horizon OS, a rebranded operating system.
Big tech is crucial to the S&P 500 since the companies carry the heaviest weightings in the benchmark.

Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg says the biggest version of Llama 3 is currently being trained with 400 billion parameters and already scoring 85 MMLU, citing metrics used to convey the strength and performance quality of AI models.

site_title: US core capital goods orders rise moderately in March
summary: US core capital goods orders increased 0.2% in March, rebounding from a 0.6% decline in February. Non-defence capital goods orders excluding aircraft rose 0.2%, in line with economist forecasts. Business spending on equipment, which accounts for 10.4% of the economy, is expected to have posted a mild gain after contracting for two straight quarters. The rebound in core capital goods shipments suggests business spending may have been sluggish in the first quarter, despite a resilient economy.

images.alt_text: General view of metal cutting machines inside Gent Machine Co.'s 55-employee factory in Cleveland, Ohio, U.S., May 26, 2021. REUTERS/Timothy Aeppel

site_title: BHP targets Anglo American in bid valuing miner at US$39 billion
summary: BHP has proposed an all-share deal to acquire Anglo American, valuing the smaller miner at US$38.8 billion. The deal would give BHP roughly 10% of global copper mine supply ahead of an expected shortage, sending prices soaring. Anglo would first spin off its controlling stakes in South African platinum and iron ore companies to shareholders before being acquired by BHP. The proposal is a 14% premium to Anglo's closing share price, sparking a 13% jump in Anglo shares and a 3.7% decline in BHP shares.

images.alt_text: The world’s largest listed miner continues to review plans for its Western Australian nickel operations while focussing on preserving cash.
BHP has suffered a sharp profit slump in its fiscal first half.
BHP declared an interim dividend of US$0.72 per share, compared with US$0.90 per share declared a year earlier.
Nickel is essential to the manufacture of stainless steel and of batteries that are fuelling the world’s transition to greener energy.

site_title: Top-tier maritime players to boost sales, margins on oil rebound and tight vessel supply
summary: Maritime companies in Singapore are seeing a surge in demand for vessels and equipment due to the rebound in oil prices, which have risen to around $80-90 per barrel. A lack of investment in the oil and gas sector after the 2016 price crash has led to a tight market, resulting in muted supply. Top-tier players are expected to leverage their market positions to secure better projects with higher margins. Analysts have raised their estimates and target prices for companies such as Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Marco Polo Marine, and Dyna-Mac, citing strong demand and revenue visibility.

images.alt_text: Aerial view of Dyna-Mac’s Holdings' main yard in Gul Road.
Analysts see light at the end of the tunnel as the company leaves the spectre of large write-downs and lawsuits behind.
Stocks have given up ground, and in futures markets, the price of oil has climbed as much as 18 per cent this year.
Investors are not ruling out the possibility that Middle Eastern tensions will disrupt oil supply.

site_title: Suntec Reit Q1 DPU down 13% to S$0.01511 in absence of capital distribution
summary: Suntec Reit's first quarter distribution per unit (DPU) declined 13% to S$0.01511 due to the absence of capital distribution from 2023. The distribution for the quarter stood at S$44 million, down 12.5% from the prior year. Despite this, operational DPU was 1.8% lower, primarily due to higher financing costs and vacancies at overseas assets. However, the Reit's Singapore office, retail, and convention portfolios showed improvement, with gross revenue and net property income increasing. The Reit's gearing was 42.2%, and it plans to divest mature assets to lower gearing and deliver long-term value to unitholders.

site_title: OKP unit gets S$92.9 million LTA contract
summary: OKP Holdings' wholly owned subsidiary Eng Lam Contractors has secured a S$92.9 million contract from the Land Transport Authority to build cycling path networks in western Singapore. The 18-month contract began on April 18 and is expected to be completed by 2025. This marks the third LTA contract awarded to Eng Lam Contractors since August 2023, totaling S$359.5 million. The contract boosts OKP's net construction order book to a record S$735.2 million, with contracts lasting till 2027.

site_title: US: Stocks end flat ahead of key inflation data
summary: US stocks ended flat on Wednesday ahead of key inflation data, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.1% at 38,460.92. The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.1% to 15,712.75, while the S&P 500 was essentially flat at 5,071.63. Investors await Friday's inflation reading and earnings reports from tech giants like Meta and Amazon, with some analysts citing "caution" ahead of the data. Individual stocks saw mixed results, with Tesla and Hasbro surging and Boeing dropping 2.9% due to a quarterly loss.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Commuters pass by the NASDAQ Marketsite in New York, May 21, 2012. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Hong Kong spot crypto ETFs to start trading next week
summary: Hong Kong will become Asia's first hub to accept cryptocurrency products as a mainstream investment tool, with spot Bitcoin and Ether exchange traded funds (ETFs) set to start trading on April 30. The products have received official regulatory approval from the Securities and Futures Commission. The move comes three months after the US launched its first ETFs to track spot Bitcoin, which have drawn $12 billion in net inflows. This development is part of Hong Kong's efforts to boost its attraction as a financial center and follows China's ban on cryptocurrency.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong already permits crypto-futures based ETFs and three have listed so far:
Representations of cryptocurrency Bitcoin are seen in this illustration picture taken in Paris, France, March 9, 2024. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/Illustration

site_title: Keppel’s Q1 revenue down 6.3% to S$1.5 billion; legacy O&M assets a drag on net profit
summary: Keppel's Q1 revenue fell 6.3% to S$1.5 billion, primarily due to lower revenue from its real estate segment. However, excluding legacy O&M assets, the company's net profit was up. Keppel continues to pursue opportunities in renewables, clean energy, and decarbonization solutions. The company has sold 60% of its Seatrium shares and plans to launch new funds for data centers, education assets, and private credit. Keppel's debt levels remain a concern, but the company is monitoring its gearing and will begin reporting net debt to Ebitda figures starting from H1.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Keppel signage is pictured in Singapore July 6, 2023. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo

site_title: JPMorgan talking with investors about two synthetic risk transfers
summary: JPMorgan Chase is in early discussions with investors for two synthetic risk transfer (SRT) deals totaling approximately $2 billion in bonds. The transactions, expected to hit the market in the fourth quarter of this year, aim to mitigate potential losses and comply with looming changes to capital rules. The deals follow a similar trend seen in 2019, where JPMorgan issued private credit risk transfer bonds to shift risk away from its mortgage portfolios. The use of SRTs is expected to increase among Wall Street banks ahead of the Basel III Endgame rules.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Chase’s profit was US$13.42 billion, or US$4.44 per share, for the three months ended Mar 31.

site_title: Ford profit beats on commercial sales; EVs still dragging
summary: Ford Motor posted first-quarter earnings that beat Wall Street's expectations, driven by strong commercial vehicle sales and hybrid vehicle sales. The company expects to achieve its annual earnings guidance of $10 billion to $12 billion. However, Ford is struggling with electric vehicle (EV) production, which recorded a $1.3 billion operating loss in the first quarter and is expected to sustain a pre-tax loss of $5 billion to $5.5 billion for the year. Despite this, Ford shares rose over 3% in after-market trading.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A logo on a 2024 Ford Escape at the Canadian International Auto Show in Toronto, Ontario, Canada February 15, 2024. REUTERS/Cole Burston/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Money laundering accused Su Baolin’s Sentosa property goes unsold at auction
summary: A 99-year leasehold plot in Sentosa Cove, acquired by money laundering suspect Su Baolin in 2021, failed to secure a buyer at an auction after only one bid was placed at S$20 million, below the reserve price of S$27.1 million. The site, valued at S$1,386 psf, was put up for sale by OCBC to recover an overdue loan of S$19.5 million. The property will be withdrawn from sale, and interested buyers can still make offers to the bank.

images.alt_text: Eight Sentosa Cove landed homes were amongst the 152 properties issued with prohibition of disposal orders

site_title: TikTok suspends new app’s reward programme amid EU concerns
summary: TikTok has voluntarily suspended its reward programme for its Lite app amid EU concerns over the potentially addictive nature of the feature, particularly for children. The European Commission had given the company until April 25 to address its concerns under the Digital Services Act rules. The company stated it will address the concerns constructively and suspend the rewards functions while doing so. The move comes as the EU executive has opened two investigations into TikTok over its impact on children.

images.alt_text: TikTok Lite app promises to pay users through a points system, which the European Commission said risks creating an addictive effect on users.

TikTok has rivalled larger companies such as Meta Platforms for user attention and ad budgets, and its cultural power is reflected in its ability to catapult emerging artists into viral hits, changing how young people discover music.
“Rest assured – we aren’t going anywhere. The facts and the Constitution are on our side and we expect to prevail again,” TikTok CEO Shou Zi Chew says.
“It gives vital support to America‘s partners so they can defend themselves from threats to their sovereignty,” US President Joe Biden says.

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, on his second trip in less than a year to China, has also accused Beijing of fueling the Ukraine war by supplying components to Russia which it uses for its military expansion - claims Beijing condemned Tuesday as “groundless”.

US and other Western officials have voiced alarm over the popularity of TikTok with young people, alleging it allows Beijing to collect data and spy on users. It has 170 million users in the United States alone.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on tech boost, upbeat earnings
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by gains in the tech sector, led by Tesla's quarterly results. The Nasdaq Composite rose 109 points, or 0.69%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also increased. The market received support from upbeat earnings reports across various sectors.

site_title: BT subscribers can now share 5 premium articles a month with unlimited number of non-subscribers
summary: BT subscribers can now share up to five premium articles per month with unlimited non-subscribers. A gift link created through the revamped feature on the BT website or mobile app will expire after 14 days, but can be reused multiple times. There is no limit to the number of recipients who can access the article. This new feature aims to make premium content more accessible to a wider audience.

images.alt_text: By following keywords, myBT users can personalise their BT reading experience.

site_title: HSBC says growing Chinese wealth fuels client investments in US
summary: HSBC's CEO Michael Roberts says growing Chinese wealth fuels client investments in the US, with Chinese investors becoming increasingly sophisticated and focused on US investments. The bank manages around $1.8 trillion from wealthy clients, with a large portion coming from Asia. Despite simmering US-China tensions, HSBC remains committed to serving its wealthy clients, including those in China and Hong Kong, with 400,000 individual clients in 22 dedicated wealth centers worldwide.

images.alt_text: Quinn is hosting the bank’s three-day inaugural Global Investment Summit that kicked off in Hong Kong earlier Monday.

site_title: Hong Kong Stock Exchange bids farewell to first woman chair
summary: Hong Kong Stock Exchange has bid farewell to its first female chair, Laura Cha, after six years of leadership. Cha, known as the "iron lady," has reached the two-term limit and will remain an independent director of Ant Group and a top trading policy advisor. Her successor, Carlson Tong, will lead a task force to enhance stock market liquidity. Despite her efforts, the exchange has experienced a decline in IPOs and trading, with a 22% year-on-year drop in average daily trading and a 28% drop in new listings revenue.

images.alt_text: HKEX said its revenue in the first quarter was down 6 per cent to HK$5.2 billion, mainly due to shrinking trading and listing fee income.

Signage for Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd. (HKEx) at the Exchange Square Complex in Hong Kong, China, on Thursday, Feb. 29, 2024. Hong Kong’s stock exchange posted a 13% decline in fourth quarter profit as trading declined and initial public offerings remained weak. Photographer: Chan Long Hei/Bloomberg
The investment link between mainland China and Hong Kong will be broadened to include real estate investment trusts (Reits) and yuan-denominated stocks listed in Hong Kong.
The 69-year-old Carlson Tong, who is HKEX’s non-executive director, has emerged as the frontrunner to take over from current Chair Laura Cha, two sources say.

site_title: ‘We aren’t going anywhere’: TikTok CEO expects to defeat US restrictions
summary: TikTok CEO Shou Zi Chew expressed confidence that the company will prevail in a legal challenge to block US restrictions, citing the Constitution on its side. The US Senate has passed a bill requiring ByteDance to divest TikTok's US assets within 270 days or face a ban. TikTok will continue to operate as it challenges the restrictions, which are part of a broader war over the internet and technology between Washington and Beijing. The company plans to challenge the bill on First Amendment grounds and users are expected to take legal action.

images.alt_text: TikTok has rivalled larger companies such as Meta Platforms for user attention and ad budgets, and its cultural power is reflected in its ability to catapult emerging artists into viral hits, changing how young people discover music.
“It gives vital support to America‘s partners so they can defend themselves from threats to their sovereignty,” US President Joe Biden says.

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, on his second trip in less than a year to China, has also accused Beijing of fueling the Ukraine war by supplying components to Russia which it uses for its military expansion - claims Beijing condemned Tuesday as “groundless”.

US and other Western officials have voiced alarm over the popularity of TikTok with young people, alleging it allows Beijing to collect data and spy on users. It has 170 million users in the United States alone.

site_title: France's Casino supermarket chain to axe up to 3,200 jobs
summary: France's Casino supermarket chain plans to axe between 1,300 and 3,200 jobs as part of a reorganisation following its recent takeover. The company, which lost 5.7 billion euros in 2023, will sell hundreds of super- and hypermarket stores to rivals Intermarche, Auchan, and Carrefour. Casino will consult with unions and social partners on May 6 to safeguard most of its nearly 30,000 employees in France. The company aims to emerge from its debt mountain and has announced a 10-year purchasing alliance with Intermarche and Auchan.

images.alt_text: Casino is in exclusive talks with Groupement Les Mousquetaires – which holds the Intermarche brand – and Auchan with a view to sell all of its hypermarkets and supermarkets.

site_title: Cordlife substantial shareholder Nanjing Xinjiekou still mulling over offer to buy over remaining shares
summary: Substantial shareholder Nanjing Xinjiekou is still reviewing its potential offer to buy over remaining shares of Cordlife, a Shanghai-listed cord-blood bank. As of March 20, 2023, Nanjing Xinjiekou owns 20.3% of Cordlife's shares. The company received a third letter from SAC Capital, on behalf of Nanjing Xinjiekou, updating its consideration of the potential offer. However, no firm decision has been reached, and there is no certainty that an offer will be made.

site_title: Unilever's India quarterly profit disappoints
summary: Hindustan Unilever's quarterly profit fell 6% to 24.06 billion rupees (S$392.9 million), missing estimates. The company attributed the decline to high inflation and increased competition from local brands in Indian villages. However, CEO Ritesh Tiwari expressed optimism about a rural sales recovery, citing a good monsoon outlook and improving macroeconomic conditions. Sales rose marginally to 146.93 billion rupees, with revenue in the beauty and personal care segment declining 2.7%.

images.alt_text: Plastic sachets of Unilever's Sunsilk and Clinic Plus shampoo hang outside a shop in Mumbai, India, May 7, 2022. India’s elite classes are becoming pickier consumers, fueling the success of organic personal-care brands backed by slick social media marketing campaigns.

site_title: Nvidia agrees to acquire Israeli AI software provider Run:ai
summary: Nvidia agreed to acquire Israeli AI software provider Run:ai, a close collaborator since 2020. The deal's value is pegged at $700 million. Run:ai develops AI computing resources, and Nvidia employs about 3,200 workers in Israel, making it its second-most important market. This acquisition aligns with Nvidia's efforts to expand its presence in Israel and enhance its AI capabilities.

site_title: TikTok artists and advertisers to stay with app until ‘door slams shut’
summary: The US Senate has passed a bill that gives Chinese tech firm ByteDance up to a year to divest TikTok, or the app will be banned. Despite this, seven industry leaders, including TikTok artists and advertisers, plan to stick with the app until it's no longer viable, citing its cultural power and ability to catapult emerging artists into viral hits. The move reflects the app's significant influence on user attention and ad budgets, making it a key platform for music discovery among young people.

images.alt_text: Broken ethernet cable is seen on front of U.S. flag and TikTok logo, April 23, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Luxury sector outlook clouded by China’s slow recovery
summary: Luxury sector outlook is clouded by China's slow recovery, with Kering warning of a sharp decline in first-half profits due to weak demand in Asia and challenges with revitalizing Gucci. Italian luxury group Ermenegildo Zegna also saw revenue fall in the first quarter, while Prada reported booming demand for its Miu Miu fashion brand. Despite predictions of a challenging first quarter, luxury brands like Hermes and LVMH are seen as positioned to maintain their footholds in China due to their base of older, wealthy clients. Executives are pinning their hopes on Chinese government stimulus to boost consumer confidence and spending.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People queue outside a Gucci store in Tsim Sha Tsui, a bustling shopping hotspot, in Hong Kong, China December 5, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Microsoft, Amazon AI deals get UK antitrust scrutiny
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) is scrutinizing Microsoft's partnerships with AI startups Mistral and Inflection AI, as well as Amazon's $4 billion collaboration with AI firm Anthropic. The CMA is concerned that large tech firms investing in AI startups could allow them to shape markets and cause competition concerns. The agency is gathering information to determine if these deals threaten competition in the UK, following findings that an "interconnected web" of partnerships and investments within AI could lead to antitrust issues.

images.alt_text: Sources said the European Union antitrust regulator had decided not to investigate the partnership under EU merger rules, but that Microsoft could still face an antitrust investigation.

Amazon is looking to Subspace omega's lawsuit dismissed for a number of reasons, including its failure to show AWS had any requirement to provide free network connections to it in locations around the globe.

site_title: Digital Core Reit Q1 distributable income slips 2.4% to US$10.6 million
summary: Digital Core Reit posted distributable income of US$10.6 million for Q1 2024, down 2.4% from the same period last year, and net property income fell 9.5%. Gross revenue decreased 8.2% and property expenses dropped 5.7%. The Reit has a weighted average lease expiry of 2.8 years and aggregate leverage of 35.1%. CEO John Stewart expressed confidence in acquiring more data centers and stated that the Reit could take down an additional stake in its Frankfurt facility.

site_title: Biden signs Ukraine aid, TikTok ban Bills after Republican battle
summary: US President Joe Biden signed a bipartisan bill into law providing billions of dollars in aid to Ukraine, Israel, and other US partners, including $61 billion for Ukraine. The legislation, which includes $1 billion in humanitarian assistance to Gaza and $8 billion to counter China's military might, marks a rare bipartisan victory for Biden as he seeks reelection. The bill was passed after months of wrangling with Republicans, who had initially blocked the aid package. Biden also signed a separate bill banning TikTok in the US if its owner fails to divest the app within nine months.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, on his second trip in less than a year to China, has also accused Beijing of fueling the Ukraine war by supplying components to Russia which it uses for its military expansion - claims Beijing condemned Tuesday as “groundless”.

US and other Western officials have voiced alarm over the popularity of TikTok with young people, alleging it allows Beijing to collect data and spy on users. It has 170 million users in the United States alone.
FBI Director Christopher Wray said that TikTok parent company ByteDance is “beholden to the Chinese government” which is “attempting to steal our AI and hack American technology every day.”
TikTok Lite app promises to pay users through a points system, which the European Commission said risks creating an addictive effect on users.

site_title: UAE announces US$544 million for rain repairs, says lessons 'learned'
summary: The UAE has announced a $544 million plan to repair homes damaged by record-breaking rainfall that caused widespread flooding and disruptions in the oil-rich Gulf state. The storm, which dumped up to two years' worth of rain, killed at least four people and brought the country to a standstill. Prime Minister Sheikh Mohammed said the country learned "great lessons" in dealing with severe rains and formed committees to log infrastructure damage and propose solutions. The rainfall was deemed "high likely" to be made heavier by human-caused climate change, according to a climatologist.

images.alt_text: Vehicles are stranded in flood waters along a highway in Dubai following heavy rains on April 18, 2024
Abandoned vehicles on a flooded highway after a rainstorm in Dubai.

site_title: Money laundering accused Su Baolin to plead guilty after being handed 3 more charges
summary: Su Baolin, a Cambodian passport holder, is expected to plead guilty to 13 charges related to money laundering, including possessing over S$1.1 million in benefits from criminal conduct and lying to the Ministry of Manpower. He was arrested in August 2023 along with nine other foreign nationals and has had over S$130 million worth of assets seized in his and his wife's names.

images.alt_text: The 99-year leasehold site, which was being advertised at a guide price of S$27.1 million.
A rear view of the parcel of land at 69 Ocean Drive in Sentosa Cove, covered by a sound barrier, on Apr 15.
The 10 accused in the case.
Zhang Ruijin currently faces three charges related to forging bank documents used to cheat CIMB Bank.
Various items seized or issued prohibition of disposal orders during the anti-money laundering raid., including cash, bottles of liquor and luxury items.
Property agents and observers The Business Times spoke to said that existing anti-money laundering measures may not be foolproof, even after property agents conduct checks.

site_title: Prada outshines rivals with 16% revenue lift boosted by Miu Miu
summary: Prada reports a 16% revenue lift to 1.19 billion euros, surpassing analyst expectations, driven by a 89% increase in Miu Miu sales and growth in Europe and Asia-Pacific, particularly in Japan. The luxury brand's flagship label retail sales grew 7% in the first quarter, contrasting with Gucci-owner Kering's forecast of a 40-45% plunge in first-half operating profit. Prada's CEO Andrea Guerra attributes the sales growth to strong creativity and brand desirability.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk past a Prada store in Brussels, Belgium September 5, 2023. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

site_title: GM CEO Barra compensation fell 4% in 2023 to US$27.8 million
summary: General Motors CEO Mary Barra's total compensation in 2023 fell 4% to US$27.8 million, despite the company's strong financial performance and industry leadership. The company did not increase Barra's or GM President Mark Reuss' target compensation for 2024. In contrast, GM President Reuss' compensation rose to US$18 million and CFO Paul Jacobson's compensation rose to US$11.1 million. The company's underperformance on EV production and AV technology impacted executive stock-based compensation.

images.alt_text: General Motors reported that net income in the first quarter rose 24.4 per cent over the year-ago period to US$3 billion, on a 7.6 per cent rise in revenue to US$43 billion.
Some drivers say their insurance rates have increased as a result of the captured data, which GM shares with two brokers, LexisNexis Risk Solutions and Verisk.

site_title: Greenback recovers from PMI slump, yen closes in on 155 per dollar
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.2% to 105.85, rebounding from its lowest point since April 12, after a 0.4% slump on Tuesday. The recovery was driven by a decline in euro and sterling against the dollar. Meanwhile, the yen remained near 34-year lows despite intervention warnings from Japanese officials. The dollar's gain came despite robust European activity data and cooling US business growth, which had driven a slump in the dollar index the previous day.

images.alt_text: The euro reached 165.62 yen, its highest since 2008, after data showed business activity in the eurozone expanded at its fastest pace in nearly a year.
Japanese authorities will work closely with overseas counterparts to deal with excessive volatility in the foreign exchange market, Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki said on Tuesday.

site_title: Discussion on EU-Asean FTA has shifted towards cooperation in specific areas: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for cooperation in specific areas between the EU and Asean, shifting the focus from a region-to-region free trade agreement (FTA) to domains such as digitalization, sustainability, and supply chain resilience. Heng invited the EU to use Singapore as a testbed for breakthroughs in Asean, citing the country's central position in bridging the two blocs. The EU and Asean share the belief that connectivity and integration are key to growth and development, despite global trade contraction.

images.alt_text: Chris Humphrey, executive director of EU-ABC, says that
DPM Wong at a reception for Singaporeans living in France on Thursday – one of many events he attended over the week.
Talks on the Thai-EU FTA should be completed within 1.5 years, says Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin.

Despite global uncertainties and China's challenging restructuring, Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat believes that a global recession is unlikely in 2024, and the ASEAN economy will continue to grow. PHOTO: JASON QUAH, ST

site_title: US 30-year mortgage rate rises to five-month high of 7.24%
summary: US mortgage rates surged to a five-month high of 7.24% in the week ended Apr 19, according to Mortgage Bankers Association data. This increase pushed down home-purchase applications for the fifth time in six weeks, with the index of mortgage applications for home purchases falling 1%. The rise in borrowing costs has created a gap between the resale and new-home markets, with sales of previously-owned houses struggling to gain momentum.

images.alt_text: The supply of new homes for purchase rose to 477,000 in the month, the highest since 2008.
Home sales dropped 4.3 per cent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.19 million units.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage rose 12 basis points to 7.13 per cent in the week ended Apr 12.
Elevated mortgage rates have been a persistent market challenge, holding back first-time homebuyers and repeat homebuyers alike.
The Commerce Department says that construction spending dropped 0.3 per cent after an unrevised 0.2 per cent decline in January.
New home sales slipped 0.3 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 662,000 units last month, the Commerce Department’s Census Bureau says.

site_title: German business sentiment rises more than expected in April: Ifo
summary: Germany's business sentiment improved more than expected in April, with the Ifo institute's business climate index rising to 89.4, beating forecasts of 88.8. Companies reported higher satisfaction with their current situation and brighter future expectations. This trend reversal suggests the economy may have reached its winter low, according to senior economist Jens-Oliver Niklasch. The German government is expected to revise its growth forecast to 0.3% for this year, up from 0.2%, as the economy stabilizes, particularly in the service sector.

images.alt_text: The German economy shrank slightly last year, hit by soaring inflation, a manufacturing slowdown and weakness in trading partners, and has acted as a major drag on the 20-nation eurozone.
FILE PHOTO: Workers assemble campers at Knaus-Tabbert AG factory in Jandelsbrunn near Passau, Germany, March 16, 2021. REUTERS/Andreas Gebert/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Construction sites are photographed in Frankfurt, Germany, July 19, 2023. REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach/File Photo

A worker stands beside a furnace at Technotherm Heat Treatment Group, which must meet new rules on energy requirements, in Goppingen, Baden-Wurttemberg, Germany, March 14, 2024. Companies in Germany complain that the demands of bureaucracy cost them time and money that would be better spent building their businesses.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 24)
summary: A class action suit against Cordlife Group for non-viable cord blood may be difficult due to logistical complexities in Singapore. Meanwhile, Su Baolin, a money laundering accused, is expected to plead guilty to three new charges. Indonesia's central bank raised interest rates to support the falling rupiah, while a daughter of a Chinese steel tycoon purchased a S$84 million bungalow. The COE quota for May-July increased by 2.7%, and Asia stocks rose 0.6% on Wednesday amid Wall Street gains.

site_title: Orsted says Taiwan wind project to power TSMC on track for 2025 finish
summary: Denmark's Orsted, the world's largest offshore wind farm developer, says a Taiwan wind project to power chipmaker TSMC is on track for completion in 2025. The 920 MW Greater Changhua 2b and four offshore wind farms will supply TSMC, a top supplier to companies like Apple and Nvidia, aiming to reach net zero emissions by 2050. Orsted's Asia-Pacific president Per Mejnert Kristensen expressed progress, stating "a lot of manufacturing is ongoing" and that full installation is expected by the end of 2025.

images.alt_text: The wind farms, to be completed by 2030, are crucial if Denmark is to meet its target to reduce CO2 emissions by 70 per cent from 1990 levels by the end of this decade.
The most obvious hallmark of Mark Liu's term as TSMC chairman is the company's global expansion.
SK hynix dominates the market for HBM chips - crucial components to power artificial intelligence - and is a top supplier to US-based chip titan Nvidia. TSMC also supplies Nvidia.

Workers carry out rescue operation at the site where a building collapsed, following the earthquake, in Hualien, Taiwan, in this screengrab taken from a SET TV video shot April 3, 2024.
