site_title: UBS flags 'serious' concern about new Swiss capital requirements
summary: UBS expresses "serious concern" about new Swiss capital requirements, which could necessitate an additional $15 billion to $25 billion in capital. Chairman Colm Kelleher stated that "additional capital is the wrong remedy," suggesting the bank may need to re-evaluate its business model or strategy. The Swiss government's plan aims to strengthen the country's largest lender, but UBS executives argue it may not be effective in addressing underlying issues. The bank's response highlights potential tensions between regulatory requirements and the needs of the financial sector.

images.alt_text: While Chinese equities have rebounded from their early 2024 lows, brokerages have been reluctant to boost their index targets or upgrade recommendations.
“In total, 50-60 per cent of ex-CS (Credit Suisse staff) will probably be laid off over the five rounds,” SonntagsZeitung quotes a source it described as an insider as saying
FILE PHOTO: The company's logo is seen at a branch of Swiss bank UBS in Zurich, Switzerland February 2, 2016. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann

site_title: France records growing number of supercentenarians
summary: France has seen a growing number of supercentenarians, with around 2,000 people aged 105 or older in 2023. Women dominate the supercentenarian contest, with 38 of 39 reported cases in 2022 being women. The phenomenon is attributed to a combination of factors, including healthy diets and manual occupations. On current trends, 200,000 people in France are expected to reach 100 or older by 2070. The statistics are consistent with higher life expectancy rates in France compared to other European countries.

images.alt_text: How to live to 100

site_title: Roche cuts pipeline after research setbacks and sales drop
summary: Roche Holding cut nearly a fifth of its experimental pipeline, halting three cancer projects and an experimental psychiatric compound, amid research setbacks and falling sales. The Swiss drugmaker aims to revive growth through acquisitions, focusing on areas like cardiovascular and metabolism disorders. Despite a 6% sales drop in the first quarter, Roche reiterated its forecast for mid-single-digit growth this year.

images.alt_text: Lonza plans to invest around 500 million Swiss francs to upgrade the facility and enhance capabilities at the site to accommodate the next generation of mammalian biologics therapies.
Around 440 jobs will go in Switzerland and up to 240 in the United States over the next two to three years, Novartis says.

site_title: CapitaLand India Trust Q1 net property income up 19%
summary: CapitaLand India Trust's net property income increased 19% to 3.1 billion rupees in Q1 2024, driven by higher rental income from existing properties and income from acquisitions and developments. Total property income rose 26% to 4.2 billion rupees, with a 63% leasing rate for a recent acquisition in Pune. Committed occupancy in the portfolio reached 94%, up from 88% in Q1 2023.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

CapitaMall Shuangjing, located in Guangqu Road in Beijing’s Chaoyang District. The manager attributes the lower net property income in Q1 to lower contributions from logistics parks and the absence of a one-off property tax refund from CCT’s business parks.

site_title: Toymaker Hasbro posts quarterly profit beat, slower sales decline
summary: Hasbro reported a smaller-than-expected 24.3% drop in first-quarter sales to $757.3 million, beating profit estimates. The company's operating margin expanded to 15.3% due to efforts to clean up inventory and cost efficiencies. Revenue for its Wizards of the Coast and Digital Gaming segment grew 7%, driven by popular games like Baldur's Gate III and Monopoly Go!. Hasbro's earnings per share of 61 cents exceeded analyst expectations, and the company remains on track to achieve its fiscal 2024 targets.

images.alt_text: Lego has expanded its position as the world’s No 1 toymaker, growing consumer sales 4 per cent in 2023 when the overall market contracted about 7 per cent.
The Aequs toy manufacturing facility in Belgaum, India..
Hasbro has struggled to shake off a post-pandemic hangover.
Hasbro now expects fiscal 2023 revenue to fall 13 per cent to 15 per cent.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS International upgrades Nanofilm to ‘hold’ despite lower target price
summary: CGS International has upgraded its rating on Nanofilm Technologies to "hold" from "reduce" due to the company's resumption of revenue growth in the first quarter of 2024, with a 19% year-on-year rise in revenue to S$39 million. The research house now expects Nanofilm to deliver better-than-expected earnings per share growth for FY2024 and FY2025. The target price has been lowered to S$0.70 from S$0.75 previously.

images.alt_text: As at 9.35 am on Tuesday, the counter continues its upward trajectory, up 13.1 per cent to S$0.69 with 8.3 million shares transacted, as the fourth most heavily traded counter on the exchange.
The group expects profitability to improve in FY2024 from the continuous optimisation of cost structures coupled with a lower capital expenditure year-on-year.

site_title: Chinese tourists are again embracing international travel
summary: Chinese tourists are increasingly embracing international travel, with 63% of residents saying they're ready to explore the world again, according to a survey. Destinations with relaxed entry requirements, such as Singapore, Malaysia, and the Middle East, are expected to reap economic rewards. Outbound trip bookings for China's May holiday lagged 2019 levels by only 13%, with popular destinations like Egypt and the UAE seeing increased interest. Global Chinese tourist numbers are predicted to reach 130 million in 2024, with the US and Europe being less favored due to poor perceptions of safety.

images.alt_text: Total air passenger traffic reached almost 180 million trips in the first three months of 2024.
FILE PHOTO: People walk along Nanjing Pedestrian Road, a main shopping area, in Shanghai, China May 5, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song
For international travels, China witnessed around 13.5 million inbound and outbound trips during the holiday, growing by 2.8 times year on year.
During the New Year holidays, more than 128 million passenger trips were made on China’s transport network, up 78.4 per cent from 2023 and 33.1 per cent from 2022.

site_title: OUE Reit Q1 NPI rises 6.9% to S$60.5 million
summary: OUE Reit posted a 6.9% increase in net property income (NPI) to S$60.5 million for its first quarter ended March 31, 2024, driven by higher contributions from Hilton Singapore Orchard and resilient performance of Singapore commercial properties. Gross revenue rose 9.5% to S$74.9 million, while the Reit's commercial segment saw a 3.3% jump in revenue and a 1.7% rise in NPI. The Reit's hospitality segment revenue rose 22.7% year-over-year, and it obtained an S$600 million unsecured sustainability-linked loan.

images.alt_text: OUE Reit obtains S$600 million unsecured sustainability-linked loan, marking its first SLL tied to its recalibrated sustainability performance targets announced on Feb 29.

site_title: Retirement savers in Singapore need to cast their nets wide for growth
summary: Singaporeans need to diversify their retirement savings to keep pace with the country's ageing population. Historically, the Singapore stock market has offered around 5.3% real returns since 1963, but recent data shows a dismal 1% annual average return. This has led to a vicious cycle of lower valuations, fewer initial public offerings, and a rising trend of delistings. However, the relative unattractiveness of Singapore stocks may be a blessing in disguise, allowing individual savers to take measured risk and invest in a more diversified portfolio, such as globally diversified funds.

images.alt_text: In addition to leveraging government schemes to grow one's nest egg, reaching out to professional wealth planning managers can help close gaps and boost financial resilience.
In retirement, staying invested and figuring out how much you can withdraw can be challenging.
Singapore boasts one of the highest lifespans and health spans in the world. This, however, raises the challenge of generating enough returns for a lengthy retirement.

site_title: Boeing reports first revenue drop in 7 quarters as deliveries decline
summary: Boeing reported its first quarterly revenue drop in seven quarters, with a revenue of $16.57 billion, beating expectations. The company's first-quarter cash burn was $3.93 billion, lower than anticipated. Boeing's 737 MAX deliveries fell 41% to 67 aircraft, and the company expects a slower increase in 787 production rate and deliveries due to supplier shortages. Despite the challenges, Boeing's operating margins in its defense business rebounded to 2.2%, and the company's adjusted loss per share narrowed to $1.13, beating expectations.

images.alt_text: The fuselage plug area of Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 Boeing 737-9 MAX which was forced to make an emergency landing with a gap in the fuselage, Jan 7, 2024.

The union said the two engineers were at odds with Boeing managers in 2022, when “they insisted on using a different set of assumptions in the analysis of the on-board computer networks on Boeing 777s and 787s, in order to comply with the new FAA guidance.”
FILE PHOTO: The Boeing logo is displayed on a screen, at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., August 7, 2019. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo
Boeing employees assemble 787s in North Charleston, South Carolina, US, May 30, 2023.  Boeing still plans to steadily increase its rate to meet “strong demand” ,according to the memo seen by Reuters.

Whistleblower Sam Salehpour, a quality engineer at Boeing, prior to a Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations hearing in Washington, DC, April 17, 2024. US lawmakers challenged Boeing to expend the necessary time and effort to reset its safety culture and criticised the planemaker's relationship with regulators as too cozy.
A Boeing 787 Dreamliner being built at the aviation company's North Charleston, South Carolina, assembly plant on May 30, 2023.

site_title: Hilton lifts 2024 profit forecast on international travel demand
summary: Hilton Worldwide has lifted its 2024 profit forecast, citing strong international travel demand as a key factor. The company expects annual adjusted profit of between $6.89 and $7.03 per share, up from its previous forecast of $6.80 to $6.94. International travel demand is expected to remain strong, driven by increased global air connectivity to Asian and Latin American countries, while domestic travel in North America plates out. Hilton reported quarterly revenue per available room of $104.16, up 2% from the same period last year.

site_title: US Judge approves US$418 million settlement that will change real estate commissions
summary: A US federal judge has approved a $418 million settlement between the National Association of Realtors (NAR) and home sellers, paving the way for sweeping rule changes in real estate commissions. The settlement aims to reduce inflated fees and protect consumer choice. NAR will implement the changes, which are expected to take effect by September 16, and pay damages to affected homeowners. The agreement comes after a jury verdict would have required NAR to pay $1.8 billion in damages. The changes are expected to lower commissions and potentially force down home prices.

images.alt_text: The house of Julie Park and Tom McDonald in San Francisco, on April 19, 2024. Park and McDonald want to raise the roof of their San Francisco home by 7 feet and 3 inches. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

site_title: Thailand’s 500 billion baht handout aims to boost overall economy, not geared to poor: official
summary: Thailand's government has approved a 500 billion baht ($18.4 billion) stimulus plan, aiming to boost the overall economy through handouts to 50 million citizens. The policy, set to be rolled out in six months, will provide 10,000 baht to each recipient. Finance officials claim the plan targets the broader population, not just the poor, and will not negatively affect finances. The central bank had recommended targeting the poor, but its concerns were addressed by the government. The rollout of the digital wallet, which has been delayed, is also expected to proceed at the end of the year.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Thailand left its key interest rate unchanged for a third straight meeting on April 10.

The Bank of Thailand complex that houses the learning center, museum and offices in Bangkok, Thailand, on Thursday, Feb. 22, 2024. Growing political pressure aside, Thailand’s weak economy adds to the case for the central bank to cut interest rates sooner rather than later, according to money managers. Photographer: Andre Malerba/Bloomberg
On Wednesday, the central bank has revised down 2024 GDP forecast to 2.6 per cent from 2.5 to 3.0 per cent
Buildings inside the Bank of Thailand complex. The Monetary Policy Committee voted five to two to maintain the one-day repurchase rate steady at a decade-high 2.5 per cent.
The central bank has so far resisted government pressure to ease policy.

site_title: One in three Singapore SMEs expect AI to replace or take over jobs: survey
summary: A survey by QBE Singapore found that nearly half of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore expect AI to have a positive impact on their productivity, while 30% see it as a threat. About 1 in 3 SMEs expect AI to replace or take over jobs. The survey also revealed that only 47% of respondents were "fully informed" about cyber risks, with 19% lacking any processes or protection against cyber threats. Experts warn SMEs to balance the benefits of AI with the risks, and to educate themselves on cyber risks.

images.alt_text: Almost eight in 10 businesses are positive about the current business environment, with one in four expecting business performance to vastly improve this year
The retail sector has also “shown signs of resilience and registered modest growth” over the past quarters, says OCBC.
The poll, conducted in December 2023 and January this year, surveyed 605 local SMEs.

site_title: Volkswagen to keep China market share stable as price war rages
summary: Volkswagen aims to maintain its market share in China at around 14.5% by 2030, despite a price war with local electric vehicle (EV) rivals. The company plans to invest heavily in the market, including a new research hub and partnerships with Chinese EV makers, to develop more affordable EVs. To achieve its target, Volkswagen is targeting sales of around 4 million cars in China annually by 2030 and operating profits of over $2.14 billion in 2027 and $3 billion by 2030.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk past an ID. Store X showroom of SAIC Volkswagen in Chengdu, Sichuan province, China January 10, 2021. Picture taken January 10, 2021. REUTERS/Yilei Sun

site_title: COE quota for May-July up 2.7%; passenger car categories rise despite less cut-and-fill
summary: The total Certificate of Entitlement (COE) quota for May to July 2024 has increased 2.7% or 397 to 15,104, with only motorcycle quotas remaining unchanged. Category A, for mainstream cars, saw a 3% increase to 5,775, while Category B rose 1.3% to 3,944. Category E, the open category, rose 12.9% to 1,048, and Category C, for commercial vehicles, increased 5.3% to 1,232. Total cut-and-fill additions fell 26.4% to 2,400 across the same period.

images.alt_text: Industry observers said healthy sales at The Car Expo on Apr 13 and 14 could be the reason for a larger rise in Category A premiums.
The price for Category A rose to S$83,000, eclipsing the previous high of S$81,589 in January’s first round of bidding.
Generic photo of vehicles for COE bidding, car pollution, carbon tax related stories.
Industry watchers expect Certificate of Entitlement (COE) supply to increase in 2024, which should lead to lower prices.

site_title: Brokerage Haitong removes long-term Hong Kong unit chief Lin, appoints new head
summary: Haitong International Securities has removed long-time CEO Lin Yong from its Hong Kong-based offshore unit, citing internal changes. Lin, who led the offshore unit since 2007, is one of the longest-serving CEOs at a Chinese investment bank in Hong Kong. The move comes after Haitong Securities removed Lin from the top post, with a new head appointed in his place. The exact reasons for Lin's removal are not specified.

site_title: Asia stocks rise on Wednesday amid Wall Street rally; STI up 0.6%
summary: Asia stocks rose on Wednesday, with Singapore's Straits Times Index gaining 0.6% as markets anticipated weaker-than-expected US purchasing managers index figures, potentially leading to earlier US rate cuts. The Nikkei 225, Hang Seng Index, and Kospi Composite Index also rose, driven by lower US Treasury yields, a weaker US dollar, and Tesla's earnings, despite the company missing expectations.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers

archive: mapletree
CMG20221130-Darwis02 陈渊庄/ archival shots [pasir panjang, bukit batok]

site_title: ‘So hot you can’t breathe’: Extreme heat hits the Philippines
summary: The Philippines is experiencing extreme heat due to the El Nino weather phenomenon, with temperatures reaching up to 47 degrees Celsius. Thousands of schools have suspended in-person classes, and warnings have been issued for people to limit outdoor time. The heat index is expected to reach 42 degrees Celsius or higher in at least 30 cities and municipalities, with drought-stricken areas particularly affected. Experts advise people to drink plenty of water, wear umbrellas and hats, and stay indoors during the hottest part of the day.

images.alt_text: Rosmarie Wydler-Walti and Anne Mahrer, of the Swiss elderly women group KlimaSeniorinnen, attend the hearing for the ruling in their case against the Swiss government.
The estimated income loss from climate change will be driven mainly by rising temperatures, which will affect agriculture, public health, productivity and more.

Houses submerged in floodwaters following heavy rainfall, at a village in Qingyuan, Guangdong province, China April 22, 2024. Last year, 79 disasters associated with water-related weather hazards were reported in Asia.

site_title: Volvo Cars see good demand this year after higher Q1 unit sales
summary: Volvo Cars reported a 15% increase in full-year sales volume guidance, citing robust demand for its vehicles in the first quarter. Adjusted operating income rose 8% to 6.8 billion Swedish kronor. However, operating income for the first quarter fell short of expectations due to lower revenues and losses at its Polestar business. CEO Jim Rowan expects demand to remain robust in the coming quarters, driven by a strong market outlook.

images.alt_text: A male worker cleans a Volvo logo as it sits on a sign at the Volvo Cars display stand, ahead of the 85th Geneva International Motor Show in Geneva, Switzerland, on Monday, March 2, 2015. The International Geneva Motor Show opens to the public on Mar. 5, and will showcase the latest models from the world's top automakers. Photographer: Matthew Lloyd/Bloomberg
Faster charging times are seen as key to persuading more customers to switch to EVs.

site_title: Singapore artists at Venice Biennale
summary: Singapore has made a record number of artists participate in the 60th Venice Biennale, with 87 countries represented. The Singaporean artists showcased works dealing with topical issues such as human migration and the environment. Notable participants include Robert Zhao Renhui, Priyageetha Dia, and Deepa Khanna Sobti, who shared their thoughts on their pieces. The biennale is expected to draw 800,000 visitors from around the world, solidifying its reputation as a premier art event.

site_title: Abu Dhabi raises US$5 billion with first eurobonds in three years
summary: Abu Dhabi has raised $5 billion through its first eurobonds in three years, with final yields significantly tighter than initial guidance. This is part of a busy year for emerging market governments, which have sold almost $100 billion of dollar- and euro-denominated bonds in 2024. The deal marks one of the biggest from emerging markets this year, indicating strong investor demand.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A trader works on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., October 27, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Vietnam’s tech giant VNG seeks to push gaming, AI cloud businesses globally
summary: Vietnam's tech giant VNG, the country's first tech unicorn, is seeking to expand its gaming and AI-focused cloud businesses globally. Despite shelving its US IPO plans last year, VNG aims to tap the world's prominent capital market for technology companies through a US listing. The company's gaming division, which contributes 75% to its revenue, has over 78 million active users, largely from South-east Asia and Taiwan. VNG has also invested in cloud and AI-driven services, acquiring thousands of Nvidia's H100 chips to power AI applications for business clients, with the goal of reaching 332 million users.

site_title: Capital A chief Fernandes defers retirement, renews contract for five years
summary: Capital A's CEO Tony Fernandes has signed a new five-year contract, deferring his retirement plans. He cited requests from the company's board to stay on amid the company's financial struggles, which led to its classification as a financially distressed PN17 company. Fernandes aims to lift the PN17 tag and restore the airline's aviation business to pre-pandemic levels by the end of 2024. He also plans to merge AirAsia X with other airline operations and expand the fleet amid an industry-wide supply crunch.

images.alt_text: AirAsia's net loss attributable for the three months ended in December is RM159.6 million (S$45.2 million), compared to a profit of RM109.9 million a year ago.
The listing will allow CAPI to access the world’s most extensive and liquid capital markets, and enhance Capital A’s international credibility and presence, Group chief executive Tony Fernandes says.
Fernandes notes that drivers for capacity growth included improving demand from migrating workforce, tourism, students and connecting travellers.

Tony Fernandes, chief executive officer of Capital A Bhd., at the company's headquarters in Sepang, Selangor, Malaysia, on Thursday, April 20, 2023. Fernandes, the larger-than-life character credited with revolutionizing budget air travel in Asia, plans to focus more on areas such as health, education and private equity. Photographer: Nadirah Zakariya/Bloomberg

site_title:
Indonesia’s central bank surprises with 
‘pre-emptive’ rate hike to cushion falling rupiah
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, raised its key interest rate by 25 basis points to 6.25% to support the battered rupiah, which has reached four-year lows due to a rallying US dollar. The move aims to bolster the stability of the rupiah exchange rate amid escalating global risks and inflation concerns. The central bank forecasts the rupiah will strengthen to 16,000 by Q2 and 15,800 by year-end, with a growth forecast of 4.7-5.5% for 2024.

images.alt_text: The Indonesian rupiah breached the key 16,000 level to the US dollar on April 11, falling further beyond 16,200 to the greenback on April 16.
FILE PHOTO: Bank Indonesia's logo is seen at its headquarters in Jakarta, Indonesia, January 17, 2019. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo
BI has kept its key interest rate unchanged at 6 per cent for the fifth consecutive time during its March 2024 meeting.
The rupiah weakened as much as 2.27 per cent to 16,200 per US dollar, its weakest level since early April 2020, leading the decline among emerging Asia currencies.
The decision was in line with efforts to maintain stability of the rupiah and control inflation, Indonesia's central bank governor Perry Warjiyo says.
FILE PHOTO: Bank Indonesia's logo is seen at its headquarters in Jakarta, Indonesia, January 17, 2019. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo
Indonesian Central Bank Governor Perry Warjiyo speaks during the 10th ASEAN finance ministers and central bank governors meeting in Jakarta, Indonesia, August 25, 2023. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan

site_title: SK Hynix to invest US$3.86 billion in Dram chip production in South Korea
summary: SK Hynix plans to invest US$3.86 billion in a new dynamic random access memory (Dram) chip production base in South Korea, with construction set to start in April and mass production expected by November 2025. The total investment is expected to exceed 20 trillion won (S$19.8 billion) in the long term. The move aims to increase Dram capacity, particularly for high-bandwidth memory (HBM) chips used in AI systems, with demand forecasted to grow over 60% annually.

images.alt_text: SK Hynix has evolved into a key player in the AI development boom as the leading designer and producer of so-called HBM chips.

site_title: London stocks hit new record at open
summary: London's FTSE 100 index reached an all-time high of 8,083.92 at the open on Wednesday, driven by easing geopolitical tensions and interest rate cut hopes. The index later stood at 8,071.51, up 0.3% from Tuesday. This follows Tuesday's record high of 8,083.92. In contrast, Frankfurt's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices had smaller gains and losses, respectively, due to a profit warning from French luxury group Kering.

site_title: US seeks 36 months’ jail for Binance founder Zhao
summary: US prosecutors seek 36 months in prison for Binance founder Zhao Changpeng, who pleaded guilty to violating money laundering laws. Zhao agreed to pay $50 million and cease involvement with Binance, which he founded in 2017. The exchange admitted to failing to report 100,000 suspicious transactions with designated terrorist groups and supporting child sexual abuse material sales. Binance agreed to a $4.32 billion penalty, including a $1.81 billion criminal fine and $2.51 billion restitution. Zhao will be sentenced on April 30 in Seattle.

images.alt_text: Over the past year, Binance saw its share of such Bitcoin trading drop to 55.3 per cent from 81.3 per cent.
The Safu fund is generally maintained at around US$1 billion, but has fluctuated in the past in tandem with market movements, Binance says.
Users can continue trading USDC on Binance, while deposits and withdrawals of USDC via other supported networks will not be impacted.
Binance’s prime brokerage partners can plug investors into the liquidity available on the exchange.
The world’s largest cryptocurrency has surged 56 per cent this year, reaching an all-time high of almost US$73,798 last week.

site_title: Country Garden extends bonds to avoid first local default
summary: Country Garden Holdings, a Chinese developer, has secured approval to extend payments on three yuan bonds until September, staving off its first local default. The move comes after the company missed initial deadlines and was on the verge of defaulting on its 30 trading day grace periods. This is the second extension for the bonds, which were issued by the company's main onshore unit, and follows its previous default on US dollar bonds last year.

images.alt_text: China’s property sector so far has shown little hint of a turnaround.
“At the request of the company, trading in the shares of the company on the stock exchange will be suspended... pending publication of the 2023 Annual Results,” Country Garden says.
FILE PHOTO: The company logo of Chinese developer Country Garden is pictured at the Shanghai Country Garden Center in Shanghai, China August 9, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
Country Garden's operations focus on smaller cities, which expand faster in good times but have been harder hit by the housing slump and economic slowdown.

site_title: Top price predicted for long-lost Klimt portrait at Vienna auction
summary: A long-lost painting by Austrian symbolist icon Gustav Klimt, "Portrait of Miss Lieser," is set to be sold at an auction in Vienna on April 24, 2024. The 1917 portrait, commissioned by a wealthy Jewish industrialist's family, is estimated to fetch between 30 million to 50 million euros. The painting's provenance has raised questions, with some experts calling for a more in-depth investigation into its ownership history, which includes a period during the Nazi era. Despite these concerns, the auction house, im Kinsky, claims to have found no evidence of the painting being stolen or unlawfully seized.

images.alt_text: Sotheby’s estimates it will fetch up to £800,000.
The exhibition at MCA Denver is the largest museum solo the 39-year-old artist has had in the United States.
Art Basel Hong Kong will serve as a test of the city’s ability to stage major events, in the wake of several big-name controversies and cancellations.

site_title: Daughter of Chinese steel-and-nickel tycoon picks up S$84 million Bin Tong Park bungalow
summary: Xiang Yangyang, daughter of Chinese steel tycoon Xiang Guangda, has purchased a S$84 million bungalow in Bin Tong Park Good Class Bungalow (GCB) Area in Singapore for S$2,988 per square foot. The 18,000 sq ft two-storey property features six bedrooms, a pool, and a gym, and is the second high-end GCB sale in the area this year. Xiang Yangyang's father, Xiang Guangda, is the chairman of Tsingshan Holding Group, one of the world's largest stainless steel and nickel producers.

images.alt_text: The house Liqian Ma, is buying has a long driveway.
The changing profile of the Good Class Bungalow market

One of the trio of bungalows in Nassim Road that changed hands for a total of S$206.7 million this year. The transaction is among at least S$700 million of deals in GCB Areas for which buyers did not lodge caveats.

site_title: German forecast to offer signs if ailing economy on the mend
summary: Germany's economy is showing tentative signs of recovery, with improvements in industrial output, business activity, and key indicators such as the Ifo index. The country's growth forecast for this year has been revised to 0.2%, down from initial hopes of a strong rebound. Despite these signs, analysts warn that a full recovery is not assured, citing ongoing challenges such as strikes, higher interest rates, and a shortage of skilled labor. The German government is set to present its latest growth forecasts on Wednesday, with economists expressing cautious optimism about the economy's prospects.

images.alt_text: epa11295939 Passers-by walk in front of the Reichstag building, the seat of the German parliament Bundestag, in Berlin, Germany, 23 April 2024. The German Federal Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe is hearing a complaint against a reform bill of the electoral law that would reduce the number of MPs in the Bundestag.  EPA-EFE/CLEMENS BILAN

site_title: Why a stronger US dollar is dangerous
summary: The US dollar is strengthening, with a 4% increase this year, due to strong American growth and reduced interest rate bets. This could lead to a widening trade deficit and exacerbate tensions with China, particularly if Donald Trump wins the presidential election. A strong dollar benefits American exporters but hurts domestic manufacturers and imported goods. Other countries, such as Japan and South Korea, are also struggling with weak currencies, and China's renminbi is weakening against the dollar. The situation has the potential to lead to further tariffs and trade tensions, particularly between the US and China.

images.alt_text: Capital outflows are putting pressure on the renminbi. The renminbi’s weakness against the dollar constrains monetary policy accommodation, and China's authorities are wary of deploying large fiscal stimulus due to high leverage.
Over the past four years, gold prices have been rising, despite the dollar remaining relatively stable.

site_title: In San Francisco, a home renovation can become a battle royale
summary: In San Francisco, a couple's home renovation plans have sparked a contentious battle with neighbors over the height of the proposed roof raise, despite the project meeting city codes. The Planning Commission had previously approved the project, but neighbors appealed, citing concerns about the impact on the neighborhood's views and historic character. The case has become a symbol of the city's notorious planning battles and delays, with some officials arguing that San Francisco's regulatory system is too burdensome, while others defend its need for community input.

images.alt_text: The supply of new homes for purchase rose to 477,000 in the month, the highest since 2008.

site_title: The great Singapore cookout: More F&B businesses expanding overseas
summary: Singapore's food and beverage (F&B) industry is expanding overseas, driven by the country's unique food culture and extensive free trade agreements. Food exports have grown at 11% annually since 2020, with products available in over 120 markets worldwide. The government aims to broaden trade agreements to facilitate seamless food trade. Companies are leveraging these opportunities, with some planning to expand into Britain, South America, and other international markets. Alternative protein sources, such as insects, are gaining traction, with start-ups like Altimate Nutrition and WhatIF Foods showcasing their products at the FHA-Food & Beverage trade show.

images.alt_text: Singapore has garnered the lion's share of deal volume and value in 2023 compared to the rest of South-east Asia.
Enterprise Singapore chairman Peter Ong will retire from his role at the end of March.

At Wednesday's launch were (from left) Lee Pak Sing, assistant chief executive officer (trade and connectivity), Enterprise Singapore; Alvin Tan, Minister of State for Trade and Industry; and Dave Ng, chairman, Singapore Logistics Association.
Khoo will relinquish her appointment at PMO to fully assume her role at Enterprise Singapore on Apr 1.

site_title: Heineken sells more beer in Q1, sticks to outlook
summary: Heineken reported its first quarterly year-on-year growth in volumes, with beer sales by volume rising 4.7% organically in the January-March period. CEO Dolf van den Brink attributed the growth to all regions posting higher volume and net revenue, with total net revenue before one-offs rising 9.4%. Despite this, the company stuck to its forecast for profit growth in 2024 and cautioned that the economic environment remains "challenging and uncertain".

images.alt_text: Heineken, Carlsberg and Budweiser maker Anheuser-Busch InBev are among the beer companies that will benefit if good weather coincides with the Euro 2024 football tournament in June and July.

site_title: Japan is poised to fill an EV gap left by China
summary: US protectionism against Chinese electric vehicle (EV) makers is creating an opportunity for Japanese carmakers to expand in North America. Honda Motor is set to build an EV plant in Ontario, Canada, with incentives from the federal government, as the US has halted Chinese EV makers from setting up manufacturing on North American soil. This move could push North America further down the road to an all-electric future, with Japanese automakers like Honda and Toyota poised to capitalize on the opportunity.

images.alt_text: Honda hopes to sell only zero-emission vehicles by 2040, with a goal of going carbon-neutral in its own operations by 2050.
Both Honda and Nissan are considering cutting production capacity in China as sales decline.

site_title: Prabowo’s aide says Indonesia doesn’t need another rate hike
summary: Indonesia's incoming government, led by President-elect Prabowo Subianto, does not need another interest rate hike to shield the rupiah, according to Prabowo's economic advisor Dradjad Wibowo. The team aims to achieve an 8% growth target during the five-year term and seeks a supportive monetary policy. Wibowo expressed concerns about the independence of the central bank when governments weigh in on interest rates, but assured that Prabowo will uphold the central bank's independence. Despite expectations of a rate hike, the rupiah strengthened against the dollar for a third day.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's exports dropped 4.19 per cent to US$22.43 billion year-on-year in March, while imports dropped 12.76 per cent to US$17.96 billion.

site_title: China’s SenseTime soars 36% after unveiling beefier AI model
summary: SenseTime, a Chinese AI company, saw its stock surge 36% after unveiling its latest generative AI model, SenseNova 5.0. The company aims to compete with OpenAI's ChatGPT and has improved its linguistic and creative capabilities. SenseTime's stock has been depressed due to a low valuation and recent setbacks, including a co-founder's death and US sanctions. The company's efforts to develop AI are part of Beijing's strategy to encourage local companies to compete with US counterparts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of artificial intelligence (AI) startup SenseTime is seen at its office in Hong Kong, China August 18, 2021. Picture taken August 18, 2021. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Hong Kong bourse operator’s Q1 profit down 13% on weaker listings, trading
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd (HKEX) reported a 13% drop in Q1 profit to HK$2.97 billion, beating analysts' forecasts. Revenue declined 6% to HK$5.2 billion due to sluggish trading and listing activities. Despite this, CEO Bonnie Chan noted a notable uptick in headline average daily trading in March and April, indicating growing investor confidence. HKEX is battling bleak profits amid geopolitical tensions and China's faltering economy.

site_title: PBOC steps up rhetoric against long-end government bond rally
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has stepped up its warnings against a rally in long-term government bonds, citing a potential reversal and a mismatch between market prices and economic outlook. Despite record lows in yields, the central bank is optimistic about China's long-run growth prospects and expects yields to return to a reasonable range. The PBOC has taken measures to cool the rally, but investors continue to buy bonds due to China's dovish monetary policy, haven demand, and a debt supply shortfall.

images.alt_text: China's treasury bond market, now the third-largest globally, boasts improved liquidity, facilitating the central bank's secondary market transactions.
China’s central bank has not made a significant bond purchase since 2007.
China’s role as a major creditor to developing nations has come under renewed scrutiny as billions of dollars in loans over the past decade have soured.
China is struggling to revive borrowing demand as the property market keeps slumping and consumer confidence remains anaemic.

site_title: China’s Huawei launches new software brand for intelligent driving
summary: Huawei unveiled its new software brand, Qiankun, for intelligent driving, aiming to provide self-driving systems for the automotive industry. The brand plans to equip 500,000 cars with its system by the end of 2024. This marks Huawei's push to become a major player in the electric vehicle (EV) industry. The Qiankun brand combines the concept of heaven and the Kunlun Mountains, symbolizing the fusion of technology and nature.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration is considering blacklisting Chinese companies it suspects could make chips for Huawei.
The Pro and Ultra versions were out of stock at Huawei’s official online store just a minute after the sales started.
FILE PHOTO: Smartphones are displayed in Huawei's first global flagship store in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, China October 30, 2019. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
huawei Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: China knockoff raid jolts a global throng of fake-fashion influencers
summary: Chinese authorities raided Pandabuy's offices in Hangzhou and seized goods amid allegations of distributing massive amounts of knockoff shoes, clothing, and watches. The site, a "shopping agent" that promotes Chinese-made products, has been shut down temporarily, but its impact on the global market of fake-fashion influencers is expected to be long-lasting. The raid marks a rare win for retailers who have been battling to shut down Pandabuy and stop online personalities from promoting the site. Authorities are now planning to take further action against the UK assets of Pandabuy as part of their ongoing investigation.

images.alt_text: Italy – home of the most luxury fashion brands – is the clear leader in counterfeit seizures within the European Union, accounting for 63 per cent of detained items in 2022, according to a November EU report.
Nintendo is looking to clamp down on the operations of a company called Tropic Haze, registered in the US state of Rhode Island, which owns and runs Yuzu, a popular video game emulator.
Luxury authenticators are like detectives gathering evidence to solve a mystery, says Carousell's Heloise Meyer.

site_title: Sun rising for Singapore businesses breaking into Japan market
summary: Singaporean businesses are expanding into Japan's market, leveraging the country's established business ecosystem and growing openness to foreign investment. Companies such as Swat Mobility, Less & Co, and iJooz are innovating in on-demand transport, upcycled beverages, and fresh juice vending machines. Despite cultural differences and market entry challenges, these firms are finding niches and partnerships to succeed. Enterprise Singapore's support has helped facilitate collaborations with Japanese players and government authorities, enabling companies to tap into Japan's vast market and technological advancements, particularly in the digital and green economy.

images.alt_text: Spending on hotels by overseas investors recorded its fastest pace in nearly a decade, making up the largest proportion of hotel deals in Japan since 2014.

site_title: China’s Noah to hire 50 to 100 wealth managers in Hong Kong, Singapore
summary: NOAH Holdings plans to hire 50 to 100 wealth managers in Hong Kong and Singapore to manage an influx of capital from mainland China. The Shanghai-based firm, which has $28.7 billion under management, aims to double its current staff of 100 relationship managers. This move comes as wealthy Chinese investors, who previously flocked to Hong Kong but are now seeking more stable environments, seek to diversify their assets. NOAH Holdings is optimistic about the growth in the sector, driven by Chinese private entrepreneurs. The firm plans to reach 150 to 200 relationship managers by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Dubai is emerging as a preferred wealth hub for many entrepreneurs and rich families in Asia, mainly China, as they look to take advantage of favourable policies and expand their businesses, wealth managers say.

site_title: Cordlife customers push for legal action
summary: At least two groups of Cordlife customers in Singapore are seeking legal action over the damage or risk of damage to over 7,000 cord-blood units due to lapses in tank temperature. The affected units were stored in two tanks and a dry shipper, with the Ministry of Health finding that around 7,500 units are damaged or at high risk. Customers are mulling class-action-type suits, with at least one group discussing next steps with law firms, including litigation funding and a town hall meeting. The case raises concerns about compensation and the viability of cord blood as a stem cell source.

site_title: Tesla profits tumble but shares rise on new vehicle plan
summary: Tesla reported a 55% drop in quarterly profits to $1.1 billion, citing "under pressure" electric vehicle sales. However, shares rose 11% in after-hours trading after CEO Elon Musk announced plans to accelerate production of more affordable electric vehicles, with production starting in early 2025 or late 2024. The company also plans to pursue a "revolutionary" manufacturing strategy for its robotaxi product, despite skepticism from analysts about its commercial viability.

site_title: Victims’ families to urge US prosecute Boeing over fatal crashes
summary: Families of 346 victims of fatal Boeing 737 MAX crashes in 2018 and 2019 are urging the US Justice Department to prosecute the company for violating a 2021 deal to overhaul its compliance program. A January in-flight blowout exposed ongoing safety and quality issues, prompting relatives to argue that Boeing should be held accountable. They claim that an independent monitor is needed to ensure compliance with the agreement, which has no such requirement. The Justice Department is weighing the incident as part of a broader probe into whether Boeing breached the deal.

site_title: MPACT posts 1.8% higher Q4 DPU of S$0.0229
summary: Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT) reported a 1.8% increase in Q4 DPU to S$0.0229, driven by strong Singapore performance and stable Hong Kong contributions. Full-year gross revenue grew 16% to S$958.1 million, while NPI rose 15.2% to S$727.9 million. The Reit's portfolio occupancy stood at 96.1% as of March 2024. MPACT's manager is open to share buybacks and plans to refine its portfolio mix to position the company for future opportunities amid headwinds in the market.

site_title: Gold edges down as Middle East worries ebb
summary: Gold prices edged lower, down 0.1% at US$2,320.19 per ounce, as Middle East conflict fears eased. Investors await US economic data on interest rate cuts, with the first potential cut expected in September. Higher interest rates reduce gold's appeal. US business activity cooled in April, and inflation eased, suggesting possible relief for the Fed. The European Central Bank must see inflation return to 2% target before cutting interest rates, according to Bundesbank president Joachim Nagel.

images.alt_text: Spot gold rose 0.3 per cent to US$2,333.29 per ounce.

site_title: Climate court ruling could set precedents in Europe and beyond
summary: A European Court of Human Rights ruling has set a precedent for climate change cases, upholding a Swiss government's failure to take stronger action against global warming. The ruling, which found the Swiss state had violated the right to a healthy environment, has significant implications for the 46 member states of the Council of Europe, potentially increasing pressure on governments to step up action against climate change. The decision may also encourage other bodies to bring similar cases to the ECHR, and could influence the law across diverse jurisdictions, including the US.

images.alt_text: Supporters and members of the association Senior Women for Climate Protection hold banners as they arrive for the ruling in the climate case Verein KlimaSeniorinnen Schweiz and Others v. Switzerland, at the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) in Strasbourg, France.
Judges at The Hague District Court ruled three years ago that Shell must reduce its carbon emissions by 45 per cent by 2030, as it was contributing to the “dire” effects of climate change.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise on earnings optimism as US data approaches
summary: Asian stocks rose on Wednesday, with Tokyo and Taipei up more than two percent, and Hong Kong, Seoul, and Manila up more than one percent, following a strong rally on Wall Street and a record in London. Analysts attributed the gains to upbeat earnings reports and a slowdown in US economic activity, while easing Middle East tensions also provided support. The rally was fueled by hopes for strong earnings from tech titans and a major US data release this week, including the personal consumption expenditures index, which could influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.7 per cent higher at 38,503.69 on Tuesday.

site_title: Texas Instruments gives solid forecast in sign of comeback
summary: Texas Instruments has given a bullish revenue forecast for the current quarter, predicting sales of up to $4 billion, exceeding analyst estimates. The forecast suggests a recovery in demand for industrial and automotive components, with customers resuming chip orders after working through stockpiles. Texas Instruments shares rose over 6% following the announcement, indicating a positive sign for the broader economy. However, the company's chief financial officer noted that the recovery is uneven, with some end markets still declining, and the company will continue to refrain from making broad predictions about future demand.

images.alt_text: Analysts believe Automotive – once one of TI’s fastest-growing end markets – is now starting to show signs of inventory corrections.
Texas Instruments has the broadest list of customers in the semiconductor industry, making its forecasts a bellwether for demand across the economy.
Texas Instruments has the longest list of customers and broadest range of products in the US$580 billion industry, making its projections an indicator of demand across the economy.

site_title: Thai central bank says holding key rate steady creates ‘policy optionality’
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) maintained its key interest rate at 2.5% for a third consecutive meeting, citing robust policy optionality. The central bank stated that cutting rates could help lower debt in the short run but pose risks in the long term. The economy remains challenged by structural pressures, with low inflation and stable overall conditions. Government measures, including a fiscal budget and a 500 billion baht stimulus project, are expected to support the economy. The BOT's decision was met with criticism from Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin, who urged a rate cut to boost businesses and investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: The current Senate’s term ends next month and the reduction in the powers of the chamber by 2024 had been written into the constitution.

site_title: Private credit is disrupting Hong Kong bankers’ cosy lives
summary: Private credit firms are disrupting the Hong Kong banking sector, posing an existential threat to some finance circles. Banks have reduced employment by 10% and are tightening loan wallets, particularly in commercial real estate. Private credit is stepping in to fill the gap, with Ares Management seeking a majority stake in a luxury property development. The shift is attributed to China's economic slowdown and banks' reluctance to take on risks, with high-paid bankers prioritizing job security over deal-making.

site_title: Singapore-based Amazon execs feel the brunt of job cuts
summary: Amazon's recent job cuts have affected executive staff in Asia Pacific, including Sunil Yadav, head of Amazon Ads for Europe, the Middle East, Africa, and South-east Asia, and Elliot Renton, sales leader for the Asia-Pacific media, entertainment, and sports industry team at AWS. Despite the layoffs, Amazon stated it will continue hiring for "targeted areas based on customer needs."

site_title: Goldman Sachs shares rise to notch first record high since 2021
summary: Goldman Sachs shares reached a record high of $423.91 on April 23, surpassing their previous closing high in November 2021. The investment bank's first-quarter results showed a massive profit beat, with traders scoring a windfall and the bank's return on equity improving. Analysts attribute the stock's rally to optimism for a dealmaking revival and the bank's efforts to reorient itself as a simpler firm. The stock climbed 1.6% from its previous close, marking a significant milestone for the 155-year-old company.

images.alt_text: The issuance spree has helped to generate US$699 million of debt-underwriting revenue for Goldman Sachs Group in the first quarter.

Goldman’s annual meeting is Apr 24.

site_title: Trade, TikTok, Taiwan: Blinken faces tough talks in China
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken is facing tough talks in China amid a tense atmosphere, with Washington pressing Beijing on trade, technology, and the Ukraine war. China has condemned US claims of fueling the conflict by supplying components to Russia, while the US has launched a probe into China's trade practices. The US Senate has also approved a bill requiring TikTok to be divested from its Chinese parent company or shut out of the American market. Blinken's trip aims to rebuild ties, but deep-seated issues remain, including Taiwan and China's growing steel exports.

images.alt_text: FBI Director Christopher Wray said that TikTok parent company ByteDance is “beholden to the Chinese government” which is “attempting to steal our AI and hack American technology every day.”

site_title: Europe: Tech, retail stocks boost Stoxx 600 to one-week high
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index reached a one-week high, driven by technology shares, which advanced 2.6% led by SAP's 24% jump in first-quarter cloud revenue. Retail stocks also rose, with Hennes & Mauritz and JD Sports Fashion gaining 4.2% and 3.8% respectively. The UK's FTSE 100 index hit its all-time peak for a second day, while Italian stocks were the best performers. The gains were attributed to upbeat corporate updates and a weaker pound, with shares of Nordnet and Associated British Foods also rising 9.0% each.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.7 per cent higher at 38,503.69 on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore stocks climb at Wednesday’s open; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.4% on Wednesday, mirroring global gains, as investors digested corporate earnings and Middle East tensions. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 11.38 points to 3,284.10. Thai Beverage was the most traded counter, while banking stocks were mixed. The rally on Wall Street was driven by upbeat corporate earnings, with the Nasdaq Composite and S&P 500 advancing 1.6% and 1.2%, respectively.

site_title: The American small-business tyrant has a favourite political party
summary: The Republican Party is increasingly identified as the party of the "small-business tyrant," favoring policies that weaken worker protections and favor low-wage labor. This agenda is driven by business owners who view workers as extensions of themselves, prioritizing their own interests over employee safety and well-being. The party's rhetoric often masks its true intentions, with some leaders and cheerleaders adopting blue-collar affectations to appeal to working-class voters. This shift reflects a broader economic agenda that benefits local land-owning elites at the expense of workers.

images.alt_text: AUSTIN, TEXAS - MARCH 19: Workers renovate a newly constructed home on March 19, 2024 in Austin, Texas. From peaking in 2022, home prices and apartment rents in Austin, Texas, have declined more than any other city in the country in 2024. While Austin remains ranked as the 10th-largest city in the U.S., the city is now leading a national property cool-down. From 2020 through 2022, Austin led at the forefront of rapid economic growth, with major companies such as Tesla and Oracle arriving. Austin’s recent downswing indicates that various migration patterns, once fueled by the COVID-19 pandemic, continue to fade as the country slowly returns to pre-pandemic levels. site_title: Starbucks set for talks with unionised US stores
summary: Starbucks is set to hold talks with labour representatives from 425 unionized US stores, aiming to establish a "foundational framework" on key issues like wages, scheduling, and health care. The talks, starting on Wednesday, are a major step towards reaching contracts for more than 10,000 unionized employees. Starbucks has nearly 18,000 stores in North America, with 60% company-owned and 40% licensed. The talks follow a successful union campaign in Buffalo, New York, and come after the company provided benefits to non-union stores in February.

site_title: CapitaLand China Trust posts 7.7% drop in Q1 NPI to 313.1 million yuan
summary: CapitaLand China Trust recorded a 7.7% drop in net property income (NPI) to 313.1 million yuan in Q1, primarily due to lower contributions from logistics parks and the absence of a one-off property tax refund. NPI from the retail portfolio rose 0.1% and new economy NPI fell 22%. Gross revenue was down 1.6% to 468.1 million yuan, with retail gross revenue up 0.6% and new economy gross revenue down 6.6%.

site_title: China’s prices are just too low for buyers to sweat about tariffs
summary: China's competitive prices are deterring buyers from worrying about tariffs, with many at the Canton Fair expressing confidence that the country can withstand escalating trade tensions. Despite US President Trump's threat of a 60% tariff, buyers are finding workarounds, such as switching to "Free On Board" pricing, and many expect China to remain their top source due to lower quality and cost alternatives from other countries. Chinese producers are also adapting to weak domestic demand by pivoting to exports, which may help meet this year's growth target of 5%.

images.alt_text: While the US bars Nvidia and its partners from selling advanced chips to China, including via third parties, the sale and purchase of the chips are not illegal in China.

Chinese policymakers already battling a protracted property crisis and weak demand at home have scant incentive to escalate tensions.

site_title: Tesla could start selling Optimus robots by the end of next year, Musk says
summary: Tesla's humanoid robot, Optimus, may be ready for sale by the end of next year, according to CEO Elon Musk. The robot, still in development, has already shown its capabilities in the factory, with Musk predicting it will be able to perform tasks by the end of this year. This comes as several companies, including Microsoft, Nvidia, and Hyundai, are also developing humanoid robots for industries such as logistics and manufacturing. Musk believes Tesla is best positioned to reach volume production with efficient inference on the robot itself.

site_title: Microsoft launches lightweight AI model
summary: Microsoft has launched Phi-3-mini, a lightweight artificial intelligence model designed for simpler tasks, aiming to attract a wider client base with cost-effective options. The model offers a 10x cost difference compared to similar capabilities, making it easier for companies with limited resources. Phi-3-mini is available immediately on Microsoft's cloud service platform Azure and other platforms. This move is part of Microsoft's strategy to stake its future on AI technology, following recent investments and partnerships in the field.

site_title: Australian inflation boosts case for higher-for-longer rates
summary: Australia's inflation rate surged 3.6% in the first quarter of 2024, exceeding economists' expectations, and reinforcing the case for the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) to hold interest rates at a 12-year high. The RBA targets inflation of 2-3%, and policymakers have expressed concern about sticky services prices and potential inflation expectations becoming unmoored. The RBA is likely to maintain rates at a high level, with a less than one-third chance of a rate cut in December, according to market pricing.

images.alt_text: Morning commuters in Sydney, Australia, on Monday, Feb. 26, 2024. Australia’s economy slowed in the final three months of last year as elevated interest rates and rising living costs dragged on household spending. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

In the nine months to March 31, 7,742 companies had entered administration, up 36.2 per cent from the previous corresponding period, the Australian Securities and Investments Commission said.
Figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Thursday showed net employment dropped 6,600 in March from February, when it rose a revised 117,600.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MPACT, CapitaLand Ascott Trust, Hotel Properties, OUE Reit, CLCT
summary: Stocks to watch include Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust, which posted a 1.8% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit, and CapitaLand Ascott Trust, whose gross profit rose 15% year-on-year due to new properties and stronger operating performance. Hotel Properties priced S$190 million in fixed-rate senior unsecured notes, while OUE Reit obtained a S$600 million unsecured sustainability-linked loan. CapitaLand China Trust's net property income dropped 7.7% year-on-year, and First Reit's distribution per unit fell 3.2% year-on-year.

site_title: US Senate passes TikTok ‘divestment-or-ban’ bill, Biden set to make it law
summary: The US Senate passed a bill to ban TikTok in the US if its Chinese owner ByteDance fails to divest the app within 9-12 months. The bill, which has already passed the House of Representatives, is expected to be signed into law by President Joe Biden. The move is driven by concerns over data collection and surveillance by the Chinese government, with 170 million US users on the platform. The bill aims to address concerns that Beijing can access Americans' data or surveil them through TikTok.

site_title: The income statement is changing for the better
summary: The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) has issued a new accounting standard, IFRS 18, which will introduce greater structure to the income statement and tighten the use of management-defined performance measures. The new standard, effective in 2027, will formalize the definition of operating profit and require companies to disclose more detailed information about their income and expenses. The changes aim to improve transparency and comparability of financial performance across companies, reducing the use of "phoney" measures that can obscure the real costs of doing business.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett, chair of conglomerate Berkshire Hathaway, has described Ebitda as a “misleading statistic” by failing to include the cost of depreciation.
Non-standard financial metrics are now widespread, but there is often too big a gulf between adjusted and bottomline earnings.

site_title: Tesla to cut more than 6,000 jobs across Texas, California
summary: Tesla plans to cut over 6,000 jobs across Texas and California as part of a 10% workforce reduction. The layoffs include 2,688 workers in Austin and 3,332 employees in California. The cuts are expected to start on June 14 and may exceed 20,000 employees, according to sources. The move comes as Tesla's shares have tumbled 42% this year, the worst performance in the S&P 500 Index. The company had over 140,000 employees globally before the job cuts.

site_title: UK firms told to ‘urgently review’ green claims amid crackdown
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has issued a warning to companies to "urgently review" their green claims by the end of May, as part of a crackdown on misleading environmental claims. All FCA-authorised firms must assess their products and services for sustainability claims, with industry associations warning of far-reaching implications for British businesses. The FCA's regulation aims to enforce broad consumer protections against greenwashing, leaving companies with limited time to comply, according to EY.

site_title: Apparel company Express seeks quick bankruptcy sale
summary: Apparel retailer Express filed for bankruptcy protection with a non-binding agreement to sell most of its retail stores and operations to a consortium led by WHP Global. The company aims to finalize the sale within 30 days to avoid a complete liquidation of its business. Express, which owns Bonobos and UpWest brands, has 9,300 employees and over 500 US retail locations. The company plans to close at least 100 unprofitable locations and maintain around 280 retail locations. Express has $189 million in funded debt, citing long-term decline in US shopping mall foot traffic as the main factor in its bankruptcy.

images.alt_text: Express, which sells mid-priced apparel, has been burning through cash as it attempts to fix its troubled operations.

site_title: Celine Dion gives health update in rare interview
summary: Celine Dion, 56, has given a rare health update, stating she is well but managing a rare neurological disorder, Stiff Person Syndrome, which causes stiff muscles and spasms. The condition requires daily therapy and has no cure, but treatment can help control symptoms. Dion, who has sold over 250 million albums, made a surprise appearance at the Grammy Awards in February and has announced a documentary about her condition to raise awareness. She is currently taking life "one day at a time" and has no immediate plans to return to touring.

site_title: Google postpones phasing out of ad cookies in Chrome browser
summary: Google has postponed its plan to phase out third-party cookies in its Chrome browser until 2025, pushing the move from this year. The company is working with publishers, marketers, and regulators, including the UK's Competition and Markets Authority, on the Privacy Sandbox initiative. Google aims to eliminate third-party cookies early next year if an agreement can be reached with regulators. The delay is due to ongoing challenges in reconciling feedback from the industry, regulators, and developers.

site_title: French air traffic controller strike threatens flight chaos
summary: French air traffic controllers are set to stage a one-day strike on Thursday, risking flight cancellations at Paris' main airports. The strike is over salary increases and other measures in a planned overhaul of France's air traffic control system. The strike could see 75% of flights cancelled at Paris Orly and 65% at Charles de Gaulle airport, with major delays also expected. The main air traffic union has warned of further strike action over the May holiday weekend if demands are not met, potentially affecting hundreds of thousands of extra visitors to Paris during the Olympic Games.

site_title: UK pay settlements edge lower in first quarter: industry survey
summary: Median basic pay settlements in the UK increased by 4.8% in the first quarter of 2024, the smallest rise since the third quarter of 2022. This is down from 5.0% in the previous quarter. Industry survey Brightmine reported that pay awards are expected to centre on 5% for at least the first half of 2024, following a tight labour market that boosted wages but did not keep up with inflation.

images.alt_text: The regulation affects all FCA-authorised firms, with a view to enforcing broad consumer protections against misleading green claims.

British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak speaks during Prime Minister's Questions, at the House of Commons in London, Britain, January 10, 2024. UK Parliament/Jessica Taylor/Handout via REUTERS THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. MANDATORY CREDIT. IMAGE MUST NOT BE ALTERED.
The UK is eyeing exports as a way to pull its economy out of a period of lacklustre growth.
A shopper pushes a trolley in a supermarket in London, Britain April 11, 2017. REUTERS/Neil Hall/Files

site_title: New Zealand first-quarter imports fall amid sluggish economy
summary: New Zealand's imports fell to NZ$17.9 billion in the first quarter, the lowest since mid-2021, due to a sluggish economy. The decline is attributed to high interest rates affecting households and businesses. Gross domestic product contracted in the second half of 2023, and the Reserve Bank of New Zealand has kept the Official Cash Rate at 5.5%. Consumer prices rose 4% in the year to March, and imports of vehicles, machinery, and fuel also declined. The annual trade deficit narrowed to NZ$9.87 billion.

images.alt_text: NEW Zealand container Photographer: Brendon O'Hagan/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan’s corporate service inflation perks up in March
summary: Japan's corporate service inflation accelerated to 2.3% in March, surpassing the previous month's 2.2% rise, as companies pass on rising labor costs. This data suggests sustained wage gains and supports the Bank of Japan's view that rising service prices will drive inflation. The service producer price index is closely watched by the Bank of Japan as a key indicator of wage and inflation trends, which may lead to interest rate hikes. This marks a shift away from the bank's eight years of negative interest rates and historic monetary stimulus.

site_title: FAA probes union claims Boeing retaliated against two engineers in 2022
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is investigating claims by the Society of Professional Engineering Employees in Aerospace (SPEEA) that Boeing retaliated against two unidentified engineers in 2022. The engineers allegedly insisted on using different assumptions in the analysis of on-board computer networks on Boeing 777s and 787s to comply with new FAA guidance, leading to identical negative evaluations. The FAA is looking into whether Boeing unfairly disciplined the engineers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Boeing logo is displayed on a screen, at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., August 7, 2019. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo
Boeing employees assemble 787s in North Charleston, South Carolina, US, May 30, 2023.  Boeing still plans to steadily increase its rate to meet “strong demand” ,according to the memo seen by Reuters.
Robin Hayes will lead Airbus‘ commercial aircraft business in North America, which is based in Herndon, Virginia.

Whistleblower Sam Salehpour, a quality engineer at Boeing, prior to a Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations hearing in Washington, DC, April 17, 2024. US lawmakers challenged Boeing to expend the necessary time and effort to reset its safety culture and criticised the planemaker's relationship with regulators as too cozy.
A Boeing 787 Dreamliner being built at the aviation company's North Charleston, South Carolina, assembly plant on May 30, 2023.
United Airlines was impacted more than rivals by the MAX 9 grounding, which followed a January emergency landing of an Alaska Airlines flight after a panel on the fuselage blew out midair.

A vigil in south London to mark the sixth anniversary of the exposing of the Windrush scandal on Apr 6. The UK government’s compensation scheme for the victims has been criticised for being too ponderous and Byzantine to navigate.
Several Chinese carriers including Air China operate direct flights to and from the US.
Airbus is targeting a roughly 50 per cent increase in production of its A320neo cash cow to 75 planes a month by 2026.
Boeing has slowed the pace of work on the 737 family to give workers and suppliers breathing room to catch up on damaged or missing parts and get its production lines back in order.

site_title: Disney, Ford, Microsoft and the age of the quasi-merger
summary: Major tech firms, including Disney, Microsoft, and Ford, are forming partnerships and joint ventures instead of traditional mergers and acquisitions as regulatory barriers rise and high interest rates continue to bite. This "age of the quasi-merger" is becoming a popular way for businesses to expand their empires without fully tying the knot. Examples include Disney's partnerships with Fox and Reliance in India, and Microsoft's deals with AI model-makers OpenAI and G42. Quasi-mergers offer flexibility and can be easier to navigate than traditional takeovers, but also come with risks and uncertainties, as seen in recent disputes over Disney's new sports venture and Microsoft's AI partnerships.

images.alt_text: TikTok Lite app promises to pay users through a points system, which the European Commission said risks creating an addictive effect on users.

site_title: Tesla to accelerate launch of cheaper cars after sales miss
summary: Tesla plans to accelerate the launch of more affordable models to boost sales and profit margins, which have been under pressure due to a sales slump. The company aims to start production on cheaper cars before the second half of 2025, contrary to its previous pledge. This move comes after Tesla reported a 9% decline in revenue and a 45 cents adjusted earnings per share in the first quarter, below Wall Street's expectations.

images.alt_text: A Tesla store in San Francisco, California, US, on Wednesday, April 17, 2024. Tesla Inc. is slashing headcount by more than 10%, part of a global retrenchment extending all the way into its executive ranks as the carmaker struggles with slowing demand for electric vehicles. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
The cuts mark a pullback from Tesla’s nascent advertising initiatives.
A Tesla showroom in Beijing. Source: Bloomberg
The EV maker has been slow to refresh its ageing models as high interest rates have sapped consumer appetite for big-ticket items.
Elon Musk has ordered Tesla’s biggest layoffs ever and staked its future on a next-generation, self-driving vehicle concept called the robotaxi.

site_title: Mattel posts narrower loss, thanks to Hot Wheels growth and lower costs
summary: Mattel reported a narrower-than-expected first-quarter loss of 5 cents per share, driven by growth in its Hot Wheels segment and lower costs. The company's shares rose 5.3% to $19.74 after the announcement. Despite sluggish revenue of $809.5 million, the Hot Wheels segment showed a 5% increase, nearly offsetting declines in other toy categories. Mattel maintains its forecast for improved profitability in 2024, with projected cost savings of $60 million and higher full-year earnings.

images.alt_text: Lego has expanded its position as the world’s No 1 toymaker, growing consumer sales 4 per cent in 2023 when the overall market contracted about 7 per cent.
Mattel missed market estimates for holiday-quarter sales and profit, and forecast tepid 2024 sales as soft demand for toys overshadowed gains from its blockbuster "Barbie" movie.
Mattel Films is also developing projects based on other popular toy lines, including American Girl, Hot Wheels, Magic Ball, Barney and more.

site_title: Visa results beat expectations on strong consumer spending trends
summary: Visa reported strong second-quarter results, beating expectations with 10% net revenue growth to $8.8 billion, driven by resilient US consumer spending trends. Payment volume climbed 8% and cross-border volume excluding intra-Europe rose 16%, with processed transactions increasing 11%. The company maintained its forecast for low double-digit revenue growth in 2024, as analysts expect payment firms to continue growth despite easing bets on an economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: The deal will finally allow US merchants to charge customers extra when they are paying with certain types of Visa and Mastercard credit cards.
FILE PHOTO: Mastercard and Visa credit cards are seen in front of displayed Wirecard logo in this illustration picture taken June 26, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: BRC Asia to buy 19.9% of steel reinforcement company for S$16 million
summary: BRC Asia has agreed to buy 19.9% of Angkasa Daehan Steel, a steel reinforcement company, for S$16.1 million. The acquisition, subject to adjustments, is seen as a strategic move to take a financial interest in a sector familiar to BRC. Daehan Steel will hold 80.1% of Angkasa Daehan Steel after the transaction. The deal is expected to provide growth potential for BRC, and shares closed flat at S$1.97 following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Steel mesh and reinforcement company BRC Asia has posted increased profits and revenue for its first quarter.

site_title: First Reit reports 3.2% lower Q1 DPU of S$0.006 amid interest rate, forex headwinds
summary: First Reit reported a 3.2% lower distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.006 for the first quarter, amid interest rate and forex headwinds. Distributable income declined 2.2% to S$12.4 million, mainly due to a stronger Singapore dollar and higher finance costs. The Reit's gearing ratio remained flat at 38.8% and it has no refinancing requirements until May 2026. Despite the challenges, the Reit's manager sees opportunities in the healthcare sector, particularly in Asia-Pacific's aged care markets.

images.alt_text: OUE Reit obtains S$600 million unsecured sustainability-linked loan, marking its first SLL tied to its recalibrated sustainability performance targets announced on Feb 29.
Higher net property income was mainly due to higher rentals as well as contributions from 2 Blue Street, said the Reit’s manager.
The results represent the first quarter of financial results after the real estate investment trust conducted its capital recycling strategy in 2023.

site_title: FBI chief warns on TikTok as Senate set to back ban
summary: FBI Director Christopher Wray has warned that TikTok's Chinese parent company ByteDance is "beholden to the Chinese government" and poses a threat to US national security. The US Senate is set to approve a ban on TikTok, with a bill that gives ByteDance a year to sell the app or face a ban. The ban is part of a larger aid package for Ukraine and has bipartisan support in the House of Representatives. TikTok has denied sharing user information with the Chinese government, but the company's ties to the Chinese government have raised concerns among lawmakers and security experts.

images.alt_text: TikTok Lite app promises to pay users through a points system, which the European Commission said risks creating an addictive effect on users.
encent executives have said they fast-tracked the game’s release after seeing positive test results
Chinese policymakers already battling a protracted property crisis and weak demand at home have scant incentive to escalate tensions.
TikTok insists it has never shared US data and never would.
The House-passed TikTok legislation has support from data privacy and national security hawks concerned about troves of data on American users.
The successful rollout of TikTok Shop in markets like the US and South-east Asia have unlocked new revenue sources for ByteDance.
The government reported more than 50,000 such cases to various social media platforms, including Meta’s Facebook and TikTok, in the first three months of this year alone.

site_title: IBM is in advanced talks to acquire software provider HashiCorp
summary: IBM is in advanced talks to acquire software provider HashiCorp, with a potential deal expected as soon as Wednesday. HashiCorp's software helps companies set up digital infrastructure in the cloud, and a deal would strengthen IBM's hybrid cloud focus. The acquisition would also complement IBM's open-source products sold by Red Hat. HashiCorp shares jumped 28% on Tuesday, valuing the company at $5.8 billion, after Bloomberg reported in March that the company was considering a sale.

images.alt_text: IBM recently hit its highest since 2013, putting it about 6 per cent below an all-time high as investors bet that a turnaround is finally bearing fruit after years of tepid growth and share-price returns.
IBM said it was using Adobe’s tools, which can generate images from text-based prompts, to help with marketing campaigns.
Singapore domestic tax law allows a company, including a local subsidiary of a foreign corporation, to deduct interest payments on debt from their taxable income in the nation state.
IBM has slimmed its operations to focus on software and services in recent years.

site_title: US: Stocks climb for second straight day
summary: US stocks rose for a second consecutive day, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.7% to 38,503.69, and the S&P 500 advancing 1.2% to 5,070.55. Gains were driven by strong corporate earnings reports from companies like General Electric, Spotify Technology, and Kimberly-Clark. Individual stocks also saw notable movements, including a 4.4% gain for General Motors and an 8.3% rise for GE Aerospace.
