However, JetBlue plummeted 18.9% after projecting lower revenues in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: The S&P 500 rose 18.3 points, or 0.36 per cent, at the open to 5,028.85​, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 74.2 points, or 0.48 per cent, to 15,525.552 at the opening bell.

site_title: Apac Realty enters the Philippines with franchise agreement
summary: Apac Realty, a Singapore-based real estate services provider, has entered the Philippines through a franchise agreement with Upper Room Realty for an initial 15-year term. The agreement allows Upper Room to operate ERA member broker offices in Metro Manila, with Apac Realty holding the option to buy up to 20% of Upper Room's shares within three years. This marks the 13th country in ERA Asia Pacific's portfolio and the 40th under the ERA global umbrella. ERA Manila will be established with an office in Makati, Manila, and plans to recruit up to 1,000 salespersons in the first three years.

images.alt_text: Apac Realty, which operates under the ERA brand, said the move is in recognition of Australia’s “well-established real estate market and its significant long-term growth potential”.

site_title: Oil rises as dollar slips, focus shifts to economic data
summary: Oil prices rose by over $1 a barrel on Tuesday as the US dollar index fell to its lowest level in over a week, shifting investor focus to global economic data. Brent crude futures rose 1.6% to $88.42 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures climbed 1.8% to $83.36 a barrel. Economic indicators, including US business activity and euro zone expansion, are driving the price increase, as investors look past geopolitical disruptions.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled at US$87.00 a barrel, down 29 cents, or 0.33 per cent.

site_title: OUE Reit obtains S$600 million unsecured sustainability-linked loan
summary: OUE Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) has secured a S$600 million unsecured sustainability-linked loan to refinance its existing S$540 million debt. The loan is tied to the Reit's recalibrated sustainability performance targets, announced on February 29. OCBC is the sole mandated lead arranger and bookrunner for the transaction. The proceeds will be used for early refinancing and general corporate purposes.

images.alt_text: Having a diversified portfolio with both office and hospitality assets gives OUE Reit stability and a pathway for growth, says Han Khim Siew, chief executive of the Reit's manager.

OUE's revenue for H2 rose 8.9 per cent to S$318.6 million from S$292.4 million due to higher contributions from the group’s investment properties and hospitality divisions within the real estate segment, as well as higher revenue from its healthcare segment.

site_title: Hong Kong crypto ETF launches will test ambition to be digital-asset hub
summary: Hong Kong is set to launch a batch of cryptocurrency exchange-traded funds (ETFs), following the US, potentially by the end of April. The launches will test the city's ambition to become a digital-asset hub, with some of China's top asset managers preparing to list spot Bitcoin and Ether ETFs. This comes as Hong Kong vies with Singapore and Dubai to develop a tightly regulated home for the virtual-asset industry, aiming to restore the city's reputation as a modern financial centre. The launches may draw comparisons with US Bitcoin funds that have garnered $56 billion in assets.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - A woman speaks with a worker at a cryptocurrency exchange in Hong Kong on April 15, 2024. y. In April miners of bitcoin will face a halving of the reward for operating the most popular cryptocurrency, in a pivotal event that is a test of survival, industry commentators say. (Photo by DALE DE LA REY / AFP)

site_title: CapitaLand Ascott Trust’s Q1 gross profit rises 15%
summary: CapitaLand Ascott Trust reported a 15% year-over-year increase in Q1 gross profit, driven by sustained demand for lodging and portfolio reconstitution efforts. The group's revenue per available unit (RevPAU) grew 6% to S$135, with all key markets registering higher RevPAU. The portfolio's average occupancy remained unchanged at 73%, reaching pre-Covid levels on a pro forma basis. Despite a 1% loss for the quarter, the stapled group's net asset value per security stood at S$1.13, and gearing is expected to remain under 40%.

images.alt_text: Citadines City Centre Frankfurt is one of CapitaLand Ascott Trust’s (CLAS) properties that procures 100 per cent of its energy from renewable sources. CLAS is the only hospitality trust in the ‘Asia Pacific Hotel – Listed’ category to receive a five-star GRESB rating.

site_title: Abu Dhabi returns to debt market with new US dollar bond
summary: Abu Dhabi, the capital of the UAE, has returned to the US debt market with a new $15 billion bond issue, its first since 2021. The emirate plans to sell benchmark-sized bonds in tranches of 5-, 10-, and 30-years, with demand expected to be strong for high investment-grade credits from the Gulf. Abu Dhabi's strong fiscal position and government debt as a percentage of nominal GDP are seen as factors supporting the debt sale, although analysts note that the emirate's sovereign wealth funds may also be using the debt markets for indirect financing.

images.alt_text: Bond buying is a tricky calculus for individuals, in part because the tiiming and number of rate cuts keep getting pushed back. That favours active management.

site_title: Trump jury told how publisher buried negative press
summary: A former publisher of the National Enquirer, David Pecker, testified at Donald Trump's "hush money" trial, describing a "catch and kill" scheme to suppress negative stories about Trump. Pecker said he agreed to run positive stories about Trump and negative stories about his opponents, and worked with Trump's lawyer Michael Cohen to kill negative stories. The testimony aimed to demonstrate that Trump engaged in "election fraud" by paying $130,000 to adult film actress Stormy Daniels on the eve of the 2016 election. Pecker's testimony is part of the trial, which seeks to hold Trump accountable for falsifying business records and violating a partial gag order.

images.alt_text: Former U.S. President Donald Trump leaves Manhattan Supreme Court on the 6th day of the hush money trial against him on April 23 2024. Curtis Means/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: New US home sales jump to highest level since September
summary: US new home sales jumped to the highest level since September, rising 8.8% in March to a 693,000 annual pace. The supply of new homes for purchase increased to 477,000, the highest since 2008. Despite high mortgage rates and prices, underlying demand remains strong, with sales stabilizing after recent volatility. The median sales price of a new house decreased 1.9% to $430,700 in March.

site_title: Apple to hold launch event on May 7, with new iPads expected
summary: Apple is set to hold a launch event on May 7, where it's expected to unveil new iPad models featuring faster chips, revamped accessories, and improved displays. The new iPads will include the iPad Pro with OLED displays and the iPad Air with a 12.9-inch screen option. This marks the first major update to the iPad lineup in 18 months, following a record-setting drought since its introduction in 2010. The move aims to reinvigorate the tablet category and boost sales.

images.alt_text: Apple iPhone 15 smartphones in Beijing. Photographer: Andrea Verdelli/Bloomberg
Big tech is crucial to the S&P 500 since the companies carry the heaviest weightings in the benchmark.
The Singapore plans are subject to change, and Apple has not made Tim Cook’s schedule in the region public.
A rendering of Apple's upcoming, expanded campus in Ang Mo Kio.

Apple CEO Tim Cook (centre) walks with Indonesian Minister of Communication and Information Budi Arie Setiadi (left) to meet journalists after his meeting with Indonesia's President Joko Widodo at the Merdeka Palace in Jakarta on April 17, 2024.
Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh (R) meeting Apple CEO Tim Cook (L) at the Government Office in Hanoi on Apr 16, 2024. Apple is increasing its commitments to Vietnam by an unspecified amount.

site_title: Hotel Properties prices 5-year notes at 5.1%
summary: Hotel Properties Ltd priced S$190 million in fixed-rate senior unsecured notes at 5.1% per annum, with semi-annual coupon payments. The notes were issued under the group's S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme. The net proceeds will be used to finance working capital and refinance existing borrowings, including redeeming S$160 million perpetual securities. DBS, OCBC, and UOB were the joint bookrunners for the issue.

site_title: Hong Kong developer weighs stake sale in London office skyscraper project
summary: Hong Kong developer Lai Sun Development is considering selling a stake in its planned 100 Leadenhall Street office tower project in London. The company has appointed Eastdil Secured and DBS Group Holdings to advise on finding a partner, amid soaring construction costs and falling valuations. There is no certainty that Lai Sun will pursue a sale, but the project is one of several new office skyscrapers approved in London's financial district.

images.alt_text: The bleak outlook for swanky postcodes like London’s Mayfair neighbourhood (top) is partly down to a UK budget proposal that seeks to scrap preferential tax treatment for wealthy foreign residents.

site_title: Euro at highest to yen since 2008, markets nervy over Tokyo stepping in
summary: The euro reached a 16-year high of 165.62 yen, surpassing its previous peak in 2008, due to a strong eurozone business activity report. The yen hit multi-year lows against the US dollar and euro, prompting concerns of potential intervention by the Bank of Japan. The dollar rose to 154.87 yen, its highest since 1990, and the pound dropped to a five-month low. Markets await the Bank of Japan's policy meeting this week and the US GDP data on Thursday, which may influence currency movements.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong financial markets gained more than one per cent by mid day on Tuesday.
Japanese authorities will work closely with overseas counterparts to deal with excessive volatility in the foreign exchange market, Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki said on Tuesday.
The dollar’s trade-weighted index was above 106, but off the five-month highs hit last week.

site_title: Sunak says UK to raise defence spending amid global threats
summary: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has announced that the UK will increase its defence spending to 2.5% of GDP by 2030, amid global threats from Russia and other nations. This move aims to make the UK one of the highest defence spenders in the 32-member NATO alliance, with an expected £87 billion expenditure in 2030-31. The increase is part of a broader push by Western nations to boost defence funding following Moscow's invasion of Ukraine and the threat of escalation in the Middle East.

images.alt_text: A sign for Lockheed Martin on the X-59 aircraft during a media preview at Lockheed Martin Skunk Works in Palmdale, California, US, on Friday, Jan. 12, 2024. Lockheed Martin Corp. and NASA unveiled the X-59, a supersonic jet designed to fly faster than the speed of sound (about 760 mph at sea level) with much less noise. Photographer: Eric Thayer/Bloomberg

WASHINGTON, DC - OCTOBER 11: A General Dynamics Land Systems display is seen at the Association of the U.S. Army (AUSA) Annual Meeting's exposition hall at the Walter E. Washington Convention Center on October 11, 2023 in Washington, DC. The Association of the U.S. Army’s Annual Meeting is designed to highlight the Army’s message by providing informative and relevant presentations on the State-of-the-Army, panel discussions and seminars on military and national security subjects and networking events.   Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Kevin Dietsch / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Gucci-owner Kering posts 10% drop in Q1 sales on sluggish Chinese demand
summary: Kering, the parent company of Gucci, reported a 10% drop in Q1 sales due to a slowdown at Gucci, primarily caused by weakness in Asia. Gucci's sales declined 18% in the first quarter, worse than the 4% decline in the prior quarter. The company attributed the decline to its ongoing design overhaul and a decline in Chinese demand. As a result, Kering's first half operating profit is expected to be "sharply lower" due to the revenue decline.

images.alt_text: A healthy portion of the purchases by Chinese tourists occurred in Japan, where the well-heeled took advantage of the weak yen to buy Louis Vuitton bags and other costly items for less.
Gucci says Stefano Cantino would join the company at the beginning of May with the job of aiding CEO Jean-François Palus “define and implement the brand strategy”.
Kering has struggled to keep up with rivals such as LVMH and Hermes International as luxury sales have come off the boil over the past year, especially in China.

Pedestrians pass a Gucci luxury clothing boutique, operated by Kering SA, in central Paris, France, on Monday Feb. 5, 2024. Kering report full year earnings on Feb. 8. Photographer: Benjamin Girette/Bloomberg

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as more earnings roll in
summary: US stock markets opened higher on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 rising 18.3 points, or 0.36%, to 5,028.85. The Nasdaq Composite also rose 74.2 points, or 0.48%, to 15,525.55. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 116.1 points, or 0.30%, to 38,356.07. The gains followed a raft of quarterly earnings updates, with investors awaiting reports from Big Tech later in the week.

site_title: PepsiCo beats quarterly revenue estimates on price hikes, steady demand
summary: PepsiCo reported a beat on quarterly revenue estimates, with net revenue rising to $18.25 billion, exceeding analyst expectations of $18.07 billion. The company's international business, accounting for 40% of its total fiscal 2023 revenue, drove the growth. Despite a slowdown in the US market due to price hikes and inflation, demand remained steady for PepsiCo's products in international markets, including Tropicana juices and Cheetos. The company maintained its annual organic sales and core profit forecasts.

images.alt_text: Pepsi products at a store in San Francisco, California, US, on Wednesday, March 20, 2024. PepsiCo Inc. has reached an agreement to become the exclusive provider of beverages at all Subway sandwich shops in the US, replacing rival Coca-Cola Co. as the drink supplier to one of the nation's largest chains. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

Pepsico says the two companies had reached an agreement that will see the food and drink conglomerate’s products, which include Pepsi, Doritos chips and Quaker oats, return to Carrefour’s shelves in France.

One beverage manufacturing factory will be in southern Long An province in Vietnam and cost over US$300 million, and another for food processing will be in northern Ha Nam province with an investment of US$90 million.
Subway announced the new 10-year pact to serve PepsiCo products such as Mountain Dew sodas, Tropicana juices and Gatorade sports drinks.

site_title: Heathrow faces further strike action in May from ground staff
summary: Heathrow Airport is set to face further strike action in May from ground staff, with almost 800 workers walking out for seven days starting May 7. The strike is in protest of plans to outsource jobs in passenger services, trolley operations, and campus security. The Unite union claims Heathrow has refused to negotiate alternatives to outsourcing, citing concerns over job security and safety. The planned strike follows previous walkouts by border control and refuelling staff, with Heathrow maintaining that no job losses are expected.

site_title: General Motors beats quarterly results targets, raises forecast
summary: General Motors reported a 24.4% increase in net income to $3 billion in the first quarter, beating Wall Street targets, and raised its annual forecast to $12.5 billion to $14.5 billion. Revenue rose 7.6% to $43 billion. The company cited stable pricing and demand for gas-engine vehicles. However, GM's business in China lost $106 million in the quarter, and the company faces challenges in turning around its sales in the region and salvaging its Cruise robotaxi unit.

images.alt_text: SAIC Motor hopes to cut 30 per cent of employees at SAIC-GM, 10 per cent at SAIC Volkswagen and more than half at its Rising Auto EV subsidiary, sources said.
Some drivers say their insurance rates have increased as a result of the captured data, which GM shares with two brokers, LexisNexis Risk Solutions and Verisk.
SDVerse, the joint venture of GM, Magna and Wipro, will link the buyers and sellers through a digital platform, where the software’s features and attributes can be listed.
The cost to build the entire operation is estimated at about US$1.2 billion, and Nouveau Monde Graphite plans to raise US$725 million in debt and US$475 million in equity.

A Chevrolet Bolt electric vehicle (EV) at a dealership in Colma, California, US, on Friday, Jan. 26, 2024. General Motors Co. is expected to release earnings figures on January 30. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: 8 in 10 firms in S-E Asia, Greater China positive about business environment: UOB survey
summary: A survey of 4,000 small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and larger companies in South-east Asia and Greater China found that 80% of companies are positive about the current business environment, with 25% expecting vast improvement in 2024. Many businesses are focusing on reducing costs, sourcing new customers, and adopting digital solutions to improve productivity. However, only 44% of companies have implemented sustainability practices, with the main barrier being concerns about costs and profits. The survey also found that 83% of businesses are interested in expanding overseas, with the top four markets being Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, and Indonesia.

images.alt_text: The retail sector has also “shown signs of resilience and registered modest growth” over the past quarters, says OCBC.
The green balancing act: How Singapore SMEs can navigate sustainability and costs
At the top of businesses’ wish list for Budget 2023 was the extension of the Job Support Scheme, the UOB survey notes.

site_title: Eurozone business in services-led bounce in April, PMI survey shows
summary: The eurozone's services sector experienced a significant expansion in April, with the flash services PMI rising to 52.9, its highest level in 11 months. This growth more than offset a decline in manufacturing, with the manufacturing PMI dropping to 45.6. The services new business index also reached an 11-month high, while manufacturing new orders fell to a four-month low. Despite this, firms increased headcount at the fastest pace since June last year, and overall business activity expanded at its fastest pace in nearly a year.

images.alt_text: Interest-rate hikes to curb inflation have weighed particularly on the property market, where new investments have fallen.

While banks were slowly turning less cautious – at least about extending home loans – households and companies showed little appetite for taking on fresh debt, the ECB’s quarterly Bank Lending Survey showed.

epa11204097 An exterior view of the European Central Bank (ECB) building before a press conference following the meeting of the ECB Governing Council in Frankfurt am Mainn, Germany, 07 March 2024.  EPA-EFE/CHRISTOPHER NEUNDORF
HCOB’s composite Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) for the currency union climbed to 50.3 in March from February’s 49.2, improving on a preliminary 49.9 estimate.

Consumer price growth in Eurozone slowed to 2.4 per cent in March from 2.6 per cent a month earlier, defying expectations for a steady rate as food, energy and industrial goods prices all pulled the headline figure lower.

site_title: Lockheed Martin reports higher sales on strong defence demand
summary: Lockheed Martin reported a 14% rise in first-quarter sales, driven by strong demand for its missiles and fire control unit, which jumped 25.3% to nearly US$3 billion. The company's aeronautics business saw a 9.2% increase in sales. Lockheed reaffirmed its full-year outlook, projecting US$68.5-70 billion in net sales and US$25.65-26.35 per share in profit. The company's quarterly net income fell to US$1.55 billion, due to higher costs.

images.alt_text: A sign for Lockheed Martin on the X-59 aircraft during a media preview at Lockheed Martin Skunk Works in Palmdale, California, US, on Friday, Jan. 12, 2024. Lockheed Martin Corp. and NASA unveiled the X-59, a supersonic jet designed to fly faster than the speed of sound (about 760 mph at sea level) with much less noise. Photographer: Eric Thayer/Bloomberg

site_title: US business activity cools in April; inflation measures mixed
summary: US business activity cooled in April to a four-month low due to weaker demand, with the manufacturing and services sectors experiencing slower growth. Inflation measures showed mixed results, with input prices rising sharply but selling prices easing slightly. The Federal Reserve is closely watching employment data, which fell for the first time since June 2020, and is expected to leave its policy rate unchanged at the next meeting.

images.alt_text: Industrial production was up 0.4 per cent in March, holding steady from February’s revised figure, says the Fed Reserve.

site_title: Boeing bid for Spirit AeroSystems hits snag over Airbus assets
summary: Boeing's bid to re-integrate Spirit AeroSystems Holdings has stalled due to disagreements over pricing for factories that produce components for Airbus. Since Boeing first announced its intention in March, talks have been slow and incomplete. The deal would allow Boeing to gain tighter control over manufacturing quality and stabilize its supply chain, but Spirit makes parts for both Boeing and Airbus, complicating the process. Analysts expect Boeing to provide more details on the deal during its earnings call on Wednesday, while Spirit has been exploring options to spin off manufacturing complexes to Airbus.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Boeing logo is displayed on a screen, at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., August 7, 2019. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Tesla to cut 400 jobs in Germany via voluntary programme
summary: Tesla plans to cut 400 jobs at its German gigafactory through a voluntary program due to the weakening sales market for electric cars. The move aims to achieve efficiency gains and adjust temporary labor use. The cuts are part of the company's global 10% reduction plan. Tesla employs over 12,000 staff at the Gruenheide site, and the company has already parted with around 300 temporary workers. The job cuts come ahead of the company's first-quarter results, which are expected to show its lowest gross profit margin in more than six years.

site_title: Far from thawing, the US-China economic war could see a new front opening up
summary: The US and China are at odds over competition in the automotive and renewable energy sectors, with the US concerned about Chinese subsidies and industrial overcapacity. Despite recent efforts to repair relations, US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned that China's ballooning industrial output poses a threat to US firms. US President Joe Biden has announced plans to treble tariffs on Chinese steel and launch anti-dumping investigations, citing the need to protect American jobs and industries. The escalating tensions could lead to a costly confrontation between the two economic superpowers.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden speaks to members of the United Steel Workers Union at its headquarters in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, April 17, 2024. Biden announced new actions to protect American steel and shipbuilding industries including hiking tariffs on Chinese steel.
Janet Yellen says companies that provide material support for Russia’s war, will be at risk for US sanctions.

site_title: Private credit for real estate boosting green building premium
summary: Private credit funds are offering premium rates to refinance commercial real estate, particularly green or climate-adapted buildings. Industry players are seeking out energy-efficient and low-emission buildings due to the risks associated with climate change. The CRE market has been struggling, particularly in the US and Europe, as offices have not filled up post-pandemic. This trend highlights the growing importance of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in commercial real estate investments.

images.alt_text: Visitors and tenants at CapitaSpring can immerse themselves in the Green Oasis which is spread over four levels from the 17th floor.

site_title: Aztech Global Q1 net profit up 18.7% to S$16 million on foreign exchange gains, write-backs
summary: Aztech Global reported a net profit of S$15.9 million for Q1, a 18.7% increase from the previous year. Revenue decreased 20.4% to S$128.6 million due to rescheduled customer orders and heavy snowstorms in China. Despite this, the company remains cautiously optimistic about its business prospects for the financial year, citing concerns over supply chain management, inflation, and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: Michael Mun (right), executive chairman and CEO for Aztech will manage the group's accounting and finance functions following the resignation of CFO Leslie Tan, until a replacement is found.
Michael Mun, executive chairman (right) and CEO, as well as Jeremy Mun, executive director and COO for Aztech Global.

site_title: China’s central bank hints it may add treasury bond trades to policy toolkit
summary: China's central bank may use its buying and selling of treasury bonds in the secondary market as a monetary policy tool for liquidity management, according to a senior official. The move comes as the country's economy grew faster than expected in the first quarter but still faces headwinds. China's treasury bond market, now the third-largest globally, has improved liquidity, allowing the central bank to carry out bond transactions. The official also stated that long-term treasury bond yields will move within a reasonable range, and the economy's recovery is consolidating.

images.alt_text: China’s central bank has not made a significant bond purchase since 2007.
China’s role as a major creditor to developing nations has come under renewed scrutiny as billions of dollars in loans over the past decade have soured.
China is struggling to revive borrowing demand as the property market keeps slumping and consumer confidence remains anaemic.

site_title: GE Aerospace raises earnings goal on strong engine sales
summary: GE Aerospace raised its full-year profit guidance to $6.2 billion to $6.6 billion, driven by increased revenue from commercial aircraft engines and services. The company also provided an outlook for adjusted earnings per share, ranging from $3.80 to $4.05. This is GE's first report since the April 2 spin off of GE Vernova, its energy business. In the first quarter, GE Aerospace saw a 24% rise in operating profit to $1.5 billion and a 15% increase in sales to $8.1 billion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the GE Aerospace booth during the Singapore Airshow at Changi Exhibition Centre in Singapore February 21, 2024. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo

site_title: Australia’s First Sentier shuts A$14b of funds after growth disappoints
summary: Australia-based asset manager First Sentier Investors will close four investment teams with A$14 billion in assets under management, citing disappointing growth. The move is part of the firm's strategy to focus on differentiated investment offerings and grow its business. The closure will result in the departure of around 30 staff, including head of Australian and New Zealand fixed income assets Stephen Cooper. The decision is attributed to shifting industry dynamics, including client consolidation and margin pressures.

images.alt_text: Australia’s pensions system is the fourth largest in the world.

site_title: Bankers lose hope of London IPO revival for another year
summary: London's IPO market has lost hope of recovery this year, with only 2% of European IPO volumes coming from the UK since January, according to Dealogic data. The city's sluggish economic recovery and perception of an undervalued stock market are major factors. However, bankers anticipate a recovery in 2025 when more private equity-owned companies mature into IPO candidates. This year's UK IPOs have raised $130 million, a slight increase from last year but an 81% drop from 2022.

images.alt_text: CAB Payments joins other high profile London IPOs, including Aston Martin and Deliveroo, that have plunged after going public.

site_title: Apple's Q1 smartphone shipments in China tumble 19%, data shows
summary: Apple's Q1 smartphone shipments in China plummeted 19% due to competition from local rivals, particularly Vivo, which surpassed Apple to become the largest smartphone seller. Huawei's sales jumped 70% as the company released high-end phones, including the Pura 70 series, which contained advanced China-made chips. Apple's market share in China fell to 15.7% from 19.7% in the same period last year, putting it almost level with Huawei.

site_title: Thailand to replace military-appointed Senate, reduce its powers
summary: Thailand's Cabinet approved a plan to replace the military-appointed Senate, reducing its powers and effectively removing the military's veto over the prime minister. The Senate's term ends next month, and the reduction in powers was written into the constitution. The move comes after the military-backed senators blocked the anti-establishment Move Forward party from forming a government in 2023. The new Senate will not be able to vote on the prime minister, marking a significant shift in the country's power dynamics.

images.alt_text: The government says it will draw funding from 2024 and 2025 fiscal budgets and capital from the state-owned Bank for Agriculture and Agricultural Cooperatives.
Thailand’s four largest lenders are Bangkok Bank, Kasikornbank, Krungthaibank and SCBX.
F1 executives were in Bangkok to survey and study the routes for the race at the invitation of the Thai government, Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin says.
Chery Automobile will be the eighth automaker from China to set up a manufacturing plant in Thailand.
Thai Foreign Minister Parnpree Bahiddha-Nukara at a border checkpoint on the Thai-Myanmar boder. He is working with Asean on a stalled peace plan for Myanmar, known as its five-point consensus.

site_title: How Hudson Yards went from ghost town to office success story
summary: Hudson Yards, a US$30 billion private real estate project in New York City, has transformed from a ghost town to a thriving office market, with a vacancy rate of less than 10% compared to 18% across Manhattan. Luxury housing and retail offerings have struggled, but the area's modern office buildings have attracted top companies like BlackRock and Pfizer, paying high rents. The project's success has also led to increased tax payments to the city, despite initial concerns about the impact of property tax breaks.

images.alt_text: Relatively low unemployment has boosted the market, and many house hunters are stuck renting as high mortgage rates make buying a property tougher.

site_title: Vietnam holds first gold auction in 11 years to stabilise market
summary: The State Bank of Vietnam (SBV) held its first gold bar auction in 11 years to stabilize the market amid record-high prices. The auction sold 3,400 taels of SJC-branded gold bars at a reserve price of 81.3 million dong per tael. The move aims to boost supply, reduce domestic prices, and narrow the gap with global levels. However, the auction's limited quantity and substantial minimum bid may deter participation, and the central bank's efforts may not address the underlying issues of "goldenisation" in the economy.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's gross domestic product grew 5.66 per cent year on year in the first quarter of 2024, with export and import growth returning to double-digit rates.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 23)
summary: Singapore's inflation eased to a 2.5-year low in March, with headline inflation at 2.7% and core CPI at 0.2% decline. The number of funding deals in emerging tech startups in Singapore remained constant, but funding was concentrated on a few companies. The Singapore National Employers Federation clarified that the new flexible work arrangement guidelines are not meant to prescribe blanket outcomes for employers. Meanwhile, a S$16.5 million deal at The Ritz-Carlton Residences was the most profitable resale deal in the first quarter, and Bank Indonesia's next move on monetary policy is uncertain due to a multi-year low in the rupiah.

site_title: Spotify profits up, but lower marketing hits user growth
summary: Spotify's quarterly gross profit surpassed $1 billion for the first time, driven by a 14% increase in premium subscribers to 239 million. However, the company missed its forecast for monthly active users, which rose 19% to 615 million, and analysts' median estimate. Spotify cut marketing spending to boost margins, but CEO Daniel Ek plans to add back marketing spend to maintain user growth. The company's revenue rose 20% to $3.64 billion, and gross margins increased to 27.6%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Small figurines are seen in front of displayed Spotify logo in this illustration taken February 11, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Ilustration/File Photo

site_title: UOI reports 67% surge in Q1 profit before tax to S$8 million, driven by favourable market conditions
summary: UOI, the general insurance arm of UOB, reported a 67% surge in Q1 profit before tax to S$8 million, driven by favourable market conditions and better insurance services. Insurance revenue rose 6% to S$23.7 million, while other income increased to S$4.2 million. The group's net insurance financial results surged 46% to S$3.8 million. Shareholders' equity grew 4.9% to S$444.9 million, and return on average shareholders' equity increased to 6.2%.

images.alt_text: UOB's general insurance arm declared a final dividend of 8.5 Singapore cents per share and a special dividend of 4 cents per share for FY2023.
Insurance revenue for UOI, the general insurance arm of UOB, grew 7.9 per cent to S$68.4 million for the nine months ended Sep 30, 2023.

site_title: Japan’s 7-Eleven convenience chain targets aggressive global growth
summary: Japan's 7-Eleven convenience chain aims to boost global store count by 18% to 100,000 by 2030, expanding into 30 countries and regions, including Europe, Latin America, and Africa. The plan is part of a large-scale restructuring that involves selling lower-performing supermarket assets. The company has already announced the closure of Ito-Yokado supermarkets, exited its apparel business, and acquired convenience stores in Australia and the US, with plans for further mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: India tells spice makers to give details of quality checks after Hong Kong allegations
summary: India's spice exports regulator has asked MDH and Everest spice companies to provide details on quality checks after Hong Kong suspended sales of their products for allegedly containing high levels of a cancer-causing pesticide. Hong Kong halted sales of three MDH spice blends and an Everest spice mix for fish curries, while Singapore ordered a recall of the Everest mix. Indian authorities have also ordered quality checks on MDH and Everest spices. The companies claim their products are safe and were exported after receiving necessary clearances from the Spice Board of India.

site_title: UPS profit beats estimates as cost cuts offset weak delivery demand
summary: UPS reported a 3.2% decline in domestic average daily volumes and a 5.8% drop in international volumes, but still beat estimates with an adjusted profit of $1.43 per share. Cost cuts, including a 12,000-job reduction, offset weak demand and labor expenses. The company's focus on high-margin businesses, such as small and medium enterprises, and its recent contract with the US Postal Service, helped drive revenue to $21.71 billion. Despite a 35% decline in profit from last year, UPS's shares rose 3.5% premarket.

images.alt_text: UPS said the postal service’s award was “significant.”

epa10904016 A UPS truck driver unloads boxes from a truck onto a dolly in Washington, DC, USA, 06 October 2023. The United States economy added 336,000 jobs in September 2023, according to a new jobs report - which far exceeded expectations. The Dow gained three hundred points after the jobs report was released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Unemployment in the US has now remained under four percent for the longest stretch since the 1960s.  EPA-EFE/MICHAEL REYNOLDS

site_title: Ping An profit falls as market declines hurt investment returns
summary: Ping An Insurance reported a 4.3% drop in net income to 36.7 billion yuan (S$6.9 billion) in the first quarter, due to a decline in the stock market and falling bond yields eroding investment returns. This marks a 4.9% decline from the same period last year. Operating profit fell 3% despite an increase in savings product sales. Co-CEO Michael Guo previously stated that profitability would recover after a 23% drop in net income last year.

site_title: China’s surging steel exports are inflaming global trade tension
summary: China's steel exports surged 28% in the first quarter, reaching 26 million tonnes, the highest rate since 2016. The exports are fueled by a tax scam allowing Chinese traders to trim VAT payments and make cheaper export offers. This has worsened global trade tensions, with the US calling for tariffs of up to 25% on certain Chinese steel products. Countries such as Brazil, Colombia, and Chile have also launched or prepared trade measures to tackle the surge, while China's domestic demand has been sapped by a property crisis.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden speaks to members of the United Steel Workers Union at its headquarters in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, April 17, 2024. Biden announced new actions to protect American steel and shipbuilding industries including hiking tariffs on Chinese steel.
Soon Lee Heng’s 80,000 sq ft headquarters in Tampines, which in 2017 marked its initial foray into property management.
Steelmaking accounts for roughly 8 per cent of global carbon dioxide emissions.
The global steel industry is responsible for around 8 per cent of the world’s carbon dioxide emissions, and more than half of all production takes place in China.

site_title: Investors in US stocks set to demand more dividends
summary: Investors in US stocks are shifting their focus from price growth to dividends, driven by the end of four decades of low interest rates and the decline of share buyback programs. Senior portfolio manager Daniel Peris argues that dividends should be a key part of any investor's strategy, citing the importance of cash flow and the potential for companies to pay dividends even in a free-cash-flow positive market. Peris' book, "The Ownership Dividend," makes a compelling case for the importance of dividends, challenging the notion that companies don't need to share their earnings with shareholders.

site_title: Soilbuild bags contracts worth S$81 million
summary: Soilbuild Construction's subsidiaries secured contracts worth approximately S$81 million, bringing the group's order book to S$685 million. SB Procurement was awarded a S$64 million contract to build a five-storey transportation hub in Ubi, Singapore, aiming for the Green Mark Gold Plus rating. Precast Concrete received a S$17 million contract for precast components in a Housing and Development Board public housing project. The contracts are expected to start in Q3 2024 and complete by Q2 2027, with shares rising 6.7% after the announcement.

site_title: India’s inflation at risk from extreme weather, geopolitical issues: central bank
summary: India's inflation is at risk due to extreme weather events and geopolitical tensions, despite the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) keeping policy rates unchanged for seven meetings. Retail inflation eased to a five-month low of 4.85% in March, but food price pressures and climate shocks could disrupt the disinflation process. The RBI aims to ensure inflation aligns with the 4% target, and growth is expected to continue with a trend upshift in real GDP growth.

images.alt_text: Customers shop at a Kalyan Jewellers India Ltd. store during the festival of Dhanteras in Mumbai, India, on Friday, Nov. 10, 2023. Dhanteras is traditionally seen as the most auspicious day in the Hindu calendar to buy gold, with many shops remaining open until midnight and jewelers offering discounts and gifts. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

Shaktikanta Das, governor of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), during a governor talk at the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank in Marrakesh, Morocco, on Thursday, Oct. 12, 2023. The IMF and World Bank’s first annual meetings in Africa since 1973 were expected to give a spending boost to Morocco’s fourth-largest city and one of its top tourist destinations. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

Reserve Bank of India says it had permitted users, for the ease of doing business, to take positions of up to US$100 million across exchanges without providing documentary evidence to establish the underlying exposure.
Central bank governor Shaktikanta Das has repeatedly said that it is premature to ease policy before inflation returns to the 4 per cent target.

site_title: Singapore stocks track Wall Street gains on Tuesday; STI up 1.5%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.5% on Tuesday, following Wall Street gains, as markets rallied on easing Middle East tensions. The STI index gained 47.55 points to 3,272.72, with most counters ending higher. Regional indices also tracked gains, with the Nikkei 225, Hang Seng Index, and FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI rising. US tech companies will report earnings this week, influencing market dynamics, and the Federal Reserve's rate cut stance remains a topic of debate.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 113 to 26.
CapitaLand Ascendas Reit's average rental rate for leases renewed in Q1 is up year on year.

site_title: Flexi-work request guidelines not meant to prescribe blanket outcomes for employers or influence hiring of workforce: SNEF
summary: The Singapore National Employers Federation (SNEF) clarified that the new flexible work arrangement (FWA) guidelines, launched on April 15, do not prescribe blanket outcomes for employers or influence hiring decisions. Employers are not obligated to accede to all FWA requests due to practical reasons and constraints. The guidelines aim to facilitate discussions on FWA requests and promote a harmonious workplace culture, supporting both employers and employees in balancing work aspirations and personal responsibilities.

images.alt_text: Co-chairs of the tripartite workgroup – (from left) SNEF honorary secretary, Edwin Ng; Minister of State for Manpower, Gan Siow Huang; and NTUC assistant secretary-general and director of U SME and U Women and Family, Yeo Wan Ling – at McDonald's Ridout Tea Garden, where they launched new guidelines for flexi-work arrangements.

site_title: Secure a comfortable retirement via a stock portfolio
summary: Singaporeans face the challenge of generating enough returns for a lengthy retirement due to its high lifespan and health span. With life expectancy increasing, individuals need to save more for retirement. Investing in shares is a good opportunity to grow wealth and beat inflation. A well-planned stock portfolio can help secure a comfortable retirement, making it essential for Singaporeans to consider investing as a key aspect of their retirement planning.

images.alt_text: The move to shift members' savings in the CPF Special Account to the Ordinary Account when they turn 55, and to close the SA has sparked unhappiness.

site_title: China’s LGFV borrowing costs drop to record low as investors bet on bailout
summary: China's local government financing vehicles (LGFVs) have seen borrowing costs drop to a record low, with the average coupon in April falling to 2.83%, the lowest level since 1999. Investors are betting on a government bailout, fueled by stronger-than-expected government support, including a large-scale refinancing program and increased lending from trust companies. Despite core issues persisting, the turnaround is attributed to the government's willingness to intervene and prevent systemic risks.

images.alt_text: Buildings under construction in Hangzhou.

The unusual decision for a state-owned enterprise to raise funds for an LGFV is a sign Guizhou province, one of the poorest and most indebted regions of China, is stepping up efforts to address the financing pressures brought on by maturing LGFV debt.

site_title: Decarbonisation schemes are generating hot air
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) is struggling to develop a net-zero strategy for the shipping industry, which is seen as complicated and difficult due to unknowns in alternative fuels and technologies. The EU's Emissions Trading Scheme (EU ETS) has been unilateral, excluding non-EU countries and creating trade barriers. Singapore-registered vessels will have to surrender 5.5 million EU Allowances (EUAs) in 2026, while the EU ETS has been criticized for its complexity and potential to create costs and barriers for the industry. The IMO must develop a straightforward and effective strategy to address the decarbonization of shipping.

images.alt_text: Yemen’s Houthi rebels began their attacks on merchant vessels in the Red Sea in mid-November, forcing major liners to make detour via South Africa instead.
Proceeds from the loan will be used to replace Metroline’s current internal combustion engine-powered buses with electric ones.

site_title: Belgian whose body brews alcohol beats drink-driving rap
summary: A Belgian man, 40, was acquitted of a drink-driving charge due to his rare metabolic condition, auto-brewery syndrome (ABS), which causes his body to produce alcohol. He was pulled over twice in 2022 with breathalyzer readings above the legal limit, but tests confirmed he had ABS. Only 20 people globally have been officially diagnosed with the condition, and scientists believe it may be under-estimated. The man, who remains anonymous, is following a carbohydrate-light diet to manage his symptoms.

images.alt_text: China’s alcohol market is the world’s biggest, estimated at US$336 billion, though a fiery domestic spirit, baijiu, dominates it.
Many winemakers go back generations and are steeped in tradition. But falling demand is leaving them with no option but to leave the industry altogether.

site_title: Renault Q1 sales rise 1.8%, helped by financing business
summary: Renault reported a 1.8% increase in first-quarter revenue to 11.7 billion euros, driven by a 27.9% growth in financing activities. The company sold 549,099 units and reiterated its operating margin target of at least 7.5% for this year. Despite a drop in core automotive sales, Renault's sales volumes returned to growth last year after four years of decline. The company faces challenges from a slowing global demand for electric vehicles and fierce competition from China.

images.alt_text: With CMA-CGM’s acquisition of a 10 per cent stake in the E-van business, Renault and Volvo’s share will be reduced to 45 per cent each.
The new Renault Twingo electric car. Engineers will trim the number of parts by 20 per cent, using more generic components and favouring parts available at suppliers.
“We want to further our growth in Europe, we want to further have the leverage from the alliance,” Nissan CEO Makoto Uchida says.

site_title: Adobe to bring full AI image generation to Photoshop this year
summary: Adobe plans to introduce a full AI image generation tool in its Photoshop software later this year, following a test "beta" version available to some users. The tool, called Firefly Image 3, will allow users to tap a reference image for composition and generate fully featured images in various styles. This move aims to compete with startups like OpenAI, Midjourney, and Stability AI, which offer similar services. Adobe's focus is on speeding up professional workflows, and the new tool will enable users to quickly generate images with minimal description.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of Adobe Inc. is pictured at the company's office in Citywest Business Campus, Saggart, Ireland October 19, 2021. REUTERS/ Tom Bergin/File Photo

site_title: Climate change is stunting our economic growth
summary: Climate change is projected to reduce global income by 19% by 2049, with rising temperatures affecting agriculture, public health, and productivity, resulting in an estimated $38 trillion in lost income annually by mid-century. If left unchecked, the economic damage could rise to 60% of global income by 2100. The study's findings highlight the urgent need for a transition to renewable energy sources to mitigate the economic consequences of climate change, with developing countries expected to bear the brunt of the damage.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cracked and dry earth is seen in the wide riverbed of the Loire River near the Anjou-Bretagne bridge as a heatwave hits Europe, in Ancenis-Saint-Gereon, France, June 13, 2022. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo

site_title: Singapore’s inflation eases more than expected in March, with headline inflation at 2.5-year low
summary: Singapore's inflation eased to a 2.5-year low of 2.7% in March, below economists' median forecast of 3.4%. Core inflation fell to 3.1%, driven by lower food and services inflation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) maintained their full-year inflation forecasts, with both headline and core inflation expected to average between 2.5 and 3.5%. The decline in headline inflation was attributed to a decline in private transport costs, and MAS left its monetary policy settings unchanged in April.

images.alt_text: The central bank last adjusted its monetary policy stance in 2022.
The value of more frequent scheduled meetings arguably has less to do with MAS’ own internal decision-making, and more to do with public signalling.
MAS and MTI said February's higher core prices was driven by higher services and food inflation, partly reflecting seasonal effects associated with Chinese New Year.

site_title: London stock market hits record high
summary: The London stock market, represented by the FTSE 100 index, hit a record high of 8,072.88 points, surpassing a previous record of 8,047.06 in February last year. The 0.6% rise was attributed to easing concerns over the Middle East situation and expectations of interest rate cuts due to slowing inflation. This follows record highs in major global peers, including the Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX, earlier this year. The FTSE 100's late start to reaching a new summit is attributed to ongoing UK economic concerns ahead of the general election.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker shelters from the rain under a Union Flag umbrella as he passes the London Stock Exchange in London, Britain, October 1, 2008.  REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: UK budget deficit overshoots in setback for Hunt’s tax cut plans
summary: The UK budget deficit exceeded forecasts, reaching £120.7 billion in the 12 months through March, surpassing the £114.1 billion predicted by the Office for Budget Responsibility. The national debt hit £2.69 trillion, or 98.3% of GDP, as Chancellor Jeremy Hunt faces pressure to deliver pre-election tax cuts amid weak growth prospects. The figures come ahead of a general election, potentially limiting Hunt's ability to cut taxes.

images.alt_text: Shoppers cross a road near a Marks & Spencer Group Plc store on Oxford Street in central London, UK, on Thursday, Oct. 19, 2023. Retail sales are set to be a drag on gross domestic product for the whole of the third quarter, following a steep decline in July and only a slight rise in August. Photographer: Jose Sarmento Matos/Bloomberg
Two tax cuts and a slightly improving economy have failed to boost Rishi Sunak's political fortunes.

British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak speaks during Prime Minister's Questions at the House of Commons in London, Britain, March 20, 2024. UK Parliament/Maria Unger/Handout via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. MANDATORY CREDIT. IMAGE MUST NOT BE ALTERED.

site_title: German business activity returns to growth in April, PMI survey shows
summary: Germany's private sector unexpectedly returned to growth in April, driven by a solid rise in the service sector. The HCOB German Flash Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to 50.5 from 47.7 in March, above forecasts. Despite manufacturing remaining in contraction, the rate of decline eased, and confidence amongst goods producers reached its highest for a year. The service sector index rose to 53.3, its highest in 10 months, and GDP growth is estimated to expand by 0.2% in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Car bodies are lifted at "Factory 56", one of the world's most modern electric and conventional car assembly halls of German carmaker Mercedes-Benz, in Sindelfingen near Stuttgart, Germany, March 4, 2024. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

Germany's economic problems are largely down to the cutoff of Russian energy supplies, weak Asian demand for exports, problems among the country’s car manufacturers in adapting to the green transition and high interest rates.

site_title: Asia hit hardest by climate, weather disasters in 2023: United Nations
summary: Asia was the world's most disaster-hit region from climate and weather hazards in 2023, according to the United Nations, with floods and storms causing the majority of casualties and economic losses. The region experienced record-high temperatures, with Asia warming at a faster pace than the global average. The World Meteorological Organization reported 79 disasters, with over 2,000 deaths and 9 million people affected, highlighting the urgent need for improved national weather services and climate action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to the evolving climate.

images.alt_text: A cyclist peddles past flood waters near a river in Qingyuan City, Guangdong, China on April 21, 2024.
Fallen rocks on the Suhua highway due to an earthquake in Hualien, Taiwan, April 22, 2024.

site_title: India’s economic activity continues to expand
summary: India's economy is set to grow over 7% in the current fiscal year, making it the fastest-expanding major economy in the world. The services purchasing managers' index rose to 61.7 in April, driven by strength in both services and manufacturing sectors. The composite index reached 62.2, the highest reading since June 2010. Strong growth has given the central bank space to focus on price stability, with the benchmark rate remaining unchanged for the seventh straight meeting.

images.alt_text: Cargo Ships are docked at the Mumbai Port in India, Sunday September 18, 2005. Indian ports need to double capacity within the next five years to cope with India's rising demand for raw materials while handling increased exports.

site_title: Binance’s rivals muscle in on Bitcoin trading around the world
summary: Binance's share of Bitcoin trading has dropped to 55.3% from 81.3% over the past year, as rival exchanges like Bybit and OKX expand their presence globally. The decline is attributed to Binance's decision to end a trading fee promotion and the company's ongoing struggles with US regulators. Bybit's share of non-US Bitcoin trading has increased to 9.3%, while OKX accounts for 7.3%. The digital-asset industry has benefited from a fourfold jump in Bitcoin's price since last year.

images.alt_text: The launch of the Bitcoin memecoins took place following another high-profile event.
For some crypto fans, the halving will underscore bitcoin’s value as an increasingly scarce commodity.
Bitcoin slid more than 5.5 per cent to US$59,961 in the Asia session as the US dollar rose broadly.

site_title: British retailer JD Sports to buy US rival Hibbett for US$1.08 billion
summary: JD Sports, Britain's largest sportswear retailer, agreed to buy US rival Hibbett for $1.08 billion. The deal, expected to be funded through JD Sports' existing US cash resources and bank facilities, would increase the combined revenues of the enlarged group to $5.80 billion in North America. Hibbett's debt will be refinanced, and the region's contribution to total sales is projected to rise to 40% from 32%. The acquisition is expected to strengthen JD Sports' presence in the southeastern US.

site_title: Why has gold’s inverse relationship with the US dollar reversed?
summary: Gold prices have risen despite a relatively stable US dollar over the past four years, driven by central banks' buying spree and de-dollarization. The long-term viability of rising gold prices hinges on the US fiscal deficit, which continues to be high. The author attributes the recent surge in gold prices to the increased probability of Donald Trump's re-election, which would lead to fewer constraints and more aggressive fiscal expansion. Trump's populist tendencies and the potential for stagflation could further weaken the dollar and increase gold prices. As long as the US fiscal deficit remains high, gold prices are likely to continue trending upward in the long term.

images.alt_text: The dollar’s trade-weighted index was above 106, but off the five-month highs hit last week.
Higher interest rates reduce the appeal of holding non-yielding gold.

site_title: Thailand’s 500 billion baht stimulus project gets Cabinet approval
summary: Thailand's Cabinet has approved a 500 billion baht (S$18.4 billion) digital wallet stimulus project, aiming to boost the country's sluggish economy. The plan, which will give 10,000 baht to 50 million Thais, is expected to add 1.2 to 1.6 percentage points to economic growth and help the economy grow at least 5% next year. The government will draw funding from 2024 and 2025 fiscal budgets and capital from the state-owned Bank for Agriculture and Agricultural Cooperatives, despite warnings from economists and experts about the potential risk of violating fiscal discipline.

images.alt_text: Thailand’s four largest lenders are Bangkok Bank, Kasikornbank, Krungthaibank and SCBX.
F1 executives were in Bangkok to survey and study the routes for the race at the invitation of the Thai government, Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin says.

site_title: China bubble-tea chain Chabaidao plunges on Hong Kong debut
summary: China's bubble-tea chain Chabaidao's shares plummeted nearly 40% on its first trading day in Hong Kong, marking the worst debut since 2015. The company raised about HK$2.59 billion during its IPO, but soon dropped to HK$10.80, before recovering to HK$12.80. The poor debut is a blow to Hong Kong's efforts to revive its markets, which have seen a four-year drop in fundraising through new listings. Despite this, Hong Kong's leader John Lee announced new measures to boost sentiment, including supporting Chinese companies to list in the city.

images.alt_text: Bubble tea was invented in Taiwan in the late 1980s, with small stalls selling it near schools and offices.

site_title: Thai PM asks banks to lower interest rates to help economy
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin has asked the country's four largest lenders to lower interest rates to support small businesses and the economy. The move aims to alleviate the financial burden on vulnerable groups such as SMEs. The request comes as Thailand's financial institutions are considered strong, according to the Prime Minister.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise with earnings, US data in view
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, driven by hopes for strong earnings from tech giants this week, despite concerns over the Federal Reserve's interest rate plans and the Middle East crisis. Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Sydney led gains, while Shanghai and Wellington struggled. Oil prices edged up, and the yen inched higher as Japan warned of intervention to support the currency. The focus shifts to US growth and inflation data, which will influence the Fed's stance on interest rates.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.7 per cent higher at 38,239.98 on Monday.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 113 to 26.

site_title: Keppel Reit Q1 net property income rises 7.2% to S$48.2 million
summary: Keppel Reit posted a 7.2% increase in net property income to S$48.2 million in Q1 2024, driven by higher rentals and contributions from 2 Blue Street in Sydney. The Reit's property income rose 6.3% to S$61.3 million, while NPI attributable to unitholders grew 7.1% to S$43.4 million. Strong demand for prime office space contributed to the Reit's higher NPI.

images.alt_text: Key tenants of the office building include the Australian Taxation Office and the Bank of Queensland.

New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.  The Reit’s portfolio occupancy fell to 83 per cent in the first quarter ended Mar 31, 2024, from 91.2 per cent in Q4, 2023.

site_title: China finance ministry echoes Xi’s call for bond trading at PBOC
summary: China's Ministry of Finance has reiterated support for the People's Bank of China (PBOC) to trade government bonds, echoing President Xi Jinping's comments that sparked market speculation. The move aims to increase fiscal and monetary policy coordination, improve base money injection and money supply adjustment mechanisms, and provide an additional tool to pump liquidity into markets. This comes as China plans to sell 1 trillion yuan of special sovereign bonds this year, with analysts differing on the implications of the PBOC's potential bond-buying strategy.

images.alt_text: China’s role as a major creditor to developing nations has come under renewed scrutiny as billions of dollars in loans over the past decade have soured.
China is struggling to revive borrowing demand as the property market keeps slumping and consumer confidence remains anaemic.

site_title: Funding concentration seen in emerging tech startups: SGInnovate report
summary: Singapore's emerging tech ecosystem saw a relatively constant number of funding deals between 2022 and 2023, with 49 deals in 2023, but funding was concentrated on a few companies, particularly in advanced manufacturing. Two large deals accounted for most of the $402 million raised, while seed rounds grew, but intermediate rounds remained scarce. Exits were few, with only two merger and acquisition deals in 2023. The number of startups being incorporated has declined, but SGInnovate expects the actual number to increase as more startups exit stealth mode or secure funding.

images.alt_text: Singapore has now seen four startup exits valued at over US$1 billion, the latest Global Startup Ecosystem Report shows.
It is mainly biotech companies in the clinical stage that are set to face shortages, across junior, manager and C-suite roles.
Singapore has garnered the lion's share of deal volume and value in 2023 compared to the rest of South-east Asia.

site_title: SG fintech firm Bambu shuts down after missing profit targets, says founder
summary: Bambu, a Singapore-based fintech firm, shut down on December 31, 2023, after missing profit targets. Founded in 2016, the company aimed to enable financial institutions to offer robo-advisory products, but ultimately fell short due to a cooling market and ballooning interest rates. Despite having large clients and a scalable business model, Bambu was unable to generate sufficient revenue, leading to its closure. The company's founder, Ned Phillips, attributes the shutdown to the macroeconomic landscape and notes that Bambu's technology has been sold to multiple buyers, with its clients unaffected.

images.alt_text: Singapore's role as a global financial nucleus will enable KPay to push the digital payments envelope further, says co-founder and CEO Davis Chan.
Fintech funding in South-east Asia falls 13% in Q1 amid economic slowdown: report
From local to global: How S'pore tech firms boost growth with strategic industry-player partnerships

site_title: Citi picks Amit Dhawan to head Singapore commercial bank operations
summary: Citi has appointed Amit Dhawan as head of its Commercial Bank for Singapore, effective April 22. Dhawan will oversee Citi Commercial Bank's business and operations in the market, driving business strategy and financial performance. He will also continue to be head of emerging corporates for Asia, a role he held since 2017. With over three decades of banking experience, Dhawan will report to Gunjan Kalra, Tibor Pandi, and Gaurang Hattangdi. The appointment is seen as part of Citi's global strategy and growth plans for its Singapore operations.

images.alt_text: The two deals have emerged at a time when many Canadian companies, including banks, are going overseas to sell debt, often for better pricing.
The British companies have a market capitalisation of £200 billion, equivalent to 8 per cent of the stock market

site_title: China acquired recently banned Nvidia chips in Super Micro, Dell servers, tenders show
summary: China has acquired recently banned Nvidia chips in servers from US companies Super Micro, Dell, and Gigabyte, despite a US ban on exporting advanced chips to China. The purchases were made through resellers and were valued at around $10,000 to $259,000. Chinese entities, including the Chinese Academy of Sciences and the Shandong Artificial Intelligence Institute, obtained the chips through tenders fulfilled between November and February. US officials could investigate these transactions for potential violations of export controls, which can result in fines and up to 20 years in prison.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration is considering blacklisting Chinese companies it suspects could make chips for Huawei.
Chinese policymakers already battling a protracted property crisis and weak demand at home have scant incentive to escalate tensions.

US President Joe Biden speaks to members of the United Steel Workers Union at its headquarters in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, April 17, 2024. Biden announced new actions to protect American steel and shipbuilding industries including hiking tariffs on Chinese steel.
President Joe Biden is also calling for higher tariffs on Chinese steel and aluminium.

site_title: S$16.5 million deal at The Ritz-Carlton Residences tops Q1 gainers; seller reaps S$4.9 million profit
summary: A 3,057 sq ft unit at The Ritz-Carlton Residences Singapore sold for S$16.5 million, or S$5,397 per square foot, in January, making it the top-gaining resale deal in Q1 2024. The seller received a S$4.9 million profit, or 42% return on investment. This marked the first time prices in the prime residential market crossed the S$5,000 per square foot threshold since June 2023.

images.alt_text: Zhan Guotuan has been fined S$45,000 for authorising the purchase by Singaporeans of landed properties to hold in trust for him.

The gap between asking and transacted rents has narrowed, as landlords adjust their expectations to align with market conditions and tenant affordability, said Lee Nai Jia, PropertyGuru head of real estate intelligence, data and software solutions.
Rental volumes for both condo and HDB flats recover in March after falling in February.

site_title: ESR-Logos Reit posts 10.8% drop in Q1 NPI after divesting non-core assets
summary: ESR-Logos Reit reported a 10.8% drop in net property income (NPI) to S$62.9 million in Q1 2024, due to divesting non-core assets. On a same-store basis, NPI would have increased 0.2% to S$63.1 million. The Reit posted a positive rental reversion of 10.8% and a 91.7% occupancy rate, despite a 1.3% decrease in gross revenue to S$89 million. Its gearing stood at 36.3% on a pro forma basis.

images.alt_text: Artist impression of ESR-Logos' redevelopment at 21B Senoko Loop NTS Redevelopment - v1.jpg.JPEG
ESR-Logos Reit will use its first sustainability-linked loan for general corporate funding purposes.
The Reit's gross revenue is down 3.1 per cent to S$189.5 million for the half-year period.
ESR-Reit owns general industrial property at 120 Pioneer Road (above).

site_title: UBS lifts Chinese stocks to overweight in rare upgrade call
summary: UBS upgraded its recommendation on the MSCI China Index to overweight, citing positive earnings and fundamentals, particularly in consumption. This rare call comes as Chinese equities have rebounded from early 2024 lows. Strategists attribute the optimism to green shoots in the economy and improving corporate performance. However, lingering risks from geopolitical tensions and regulatory whiplash remain, making investors cautious. The upgrade suggests a tentative optimism that the market is on the mend.

images.alt_text: Chinese quant hedge funds have been venturing into overseas markets for years, but their expansion has accelerated as the sector has become increasingly crowded at home and regulators tighten their supervision.
The purchases helped China’s CSI300 blue-chip index bounced back roughly 14 per cent from five-year lows hit in February.
Brokerages are also offering revised product structures to meet investors’ changing risk appetite.

site_title: In Brazil, hopes to use AI to save wildlife from roadkill fate
summary: Brazil aims to use artificial intelligence to reduce roadkill fatalities, with approximately 475 million vertebrate animals dying on the country's roads annually. A computer scientist has proposed using AI to alert drivers to the presence of wildlife, particularly in areas with high road density. Direct strikes are the leading cause of death for many species, including capybaras, armadillos, and possums, which are forced to live near humans due to habitat loss. Implementing AI-powered warning systems could help mitigate this issue and protect Brazil's diverse wildlife.

images.alt_text: Farmers are increasingly turning to artificial intelligence to boost yields and returns with applications like self-driving tractors.
The artificial intelligence tool was developed by Japanese researchers to try and help managers provide targeted support to staff to stop them from quitting.

site_title: Taylor Swift fans descend on London pub name-checked on album
summary: Taylor Swift fans are flocking to a London pub called The Black Dog, which was name-checked on her new album "The Tortured Poet's Department". Fans believe the pub is about her former British boyfriend Joe Alwyn, whom she split with in April 2023. The pub's events and social media manager said she had to call in staff to cope with demand, and the pub has capitalized on its new-found fame with themed food and drinks. The album broke a record on Spotify for most-streamed album in a single day, achieving this feat in under 12 hours.

images.alt_text: Customers sit outside The Black Dog pub, believed by its owners to have been referenced in lyrics in the song The Black Dog by Taylor Swift, in London, Britain, April 22, 2024. REUTERS/Toby Melville

site_title: BOJ will hike rates if trend inflation accelerates, says Ueda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda stated that the central bank will hike interest rates if trend inflation accelerates towards its 2% target. The BOJ is likely to project inflation will stay around its target for the next three years, sparking market expectations of further rate hikes this year. Ueda emphasized that the BOJ will maintain an ultra-loose monetary policy until trend inflation reaches the target, but hinted at potential rate hikes if inflation accelerates.

images.alt_text: Kazuo Ueda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), says the central bank must maintain loose monetary policy for the time being as underlying inflation remains “somewhat below” its 2 per cent target,

The Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, March 19, 2024. The BOJ ended the most aggressive monetary stimulus program in modern history, scrapping the world's last negative interest rate and a raft of unconventional tools, while leaving the course of additional hikes unclear. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

This general view shows 10,000 yen notes (65 USD) on display in the window of a currency exchange shop in central Tokyo on April 17, 2024, as the yen continues its downward spiral against the US dollar. The prospect of US interest rates remaining high has sent the dollar surging this year, and this week hit a 34-year high against the yen as Japan's central bank keeps monetary policy loose. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: Gold edges higher; hovers near one-week low on tempered Middle East fears
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $2,333.29 per ounce on Tuesday, hovering near a one-week low, as Middle East conflict worries subsided. Investors' risk appetite increased, reducing safe-haven demand for gold. The US Federal Reserve's reluctance to cut interest rates also contributed to the increase. Meanwhile, spot silver rose 0.4% and palladium output increased by 3% in the first quarter, despite a 0.1% decline in palladium prices.

images.alt_text: Over the past four years, gold prices have been rising, despite the dollar remaining relatively stable.
Higher interest rates reduce the appeal of holding non-yielding gold.

site_title: Pundits divided on Bank Indonesia’s next move as rupiah hovers at multi-year low
summary: Bank Indonesia's key interest rate remains unchanged at 6% for the fifth consecutive meeting as the rupiah hovers at a multi-year low. Analysts expect the central bank to maintain the benchmark rate, citing rupiah stability and inflation management as priorities. Despite Indonesia's steady economic growth and manageable inflation, a small group of analysts predicts the central bank may hike rates to support the currency. The rupiah has lost over 5% of its value against the US dollar year-to-date, with some experts estimating the central bank may need to intervene with up to $7 billion in foreign exchange reserves to stabilize the currency.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's exports dropped 4.19 per cent to US$22.43 billion year-on-year in March, while imports dropped 12.76 per cent to US$17.96 billion.
The Indonesian rupiah breached the key 16,000 level to the US dollar on April 11, falling further beyond 16,200 to the greenback on April 16.

site_title: Hot stock: Nanofilm jumps 13.1% amid heavy trading on improved Q1 results
summary: Nanofilm Technologies' shares rose 13.1% on the Singapore Exchange on Tuesday after posting a 19% increase in first-quarter revenue. The company attributed the improvement to expanding revenue base and streamlining costs. It expects profitability to improve in FY2024 due to cost optimization and lower capital expenditure. As of 9:35 am, shares were trading at S$0.69, making it the fourth most heavily traded counter on the exchange.

site_title: The billionaire Kweks are busy housekeeping
summary: Singapore property giant City Developments Ltd is busy selling assets, including a 65-unit development at The Residences at W Singapore Sentosa Cove and a 40-year-old freehold building Delfi Orchard. The company's efforts may be influenced by recent failed sales of Far East Shopping Centre and Scotts Square mall. Meanwhile, CDL partnered with other developers to secure sites for new projects, including the Jurong Lake District and Zion Road. The market is also seeing a moderate take-up rate at recent private housing launches, with some arguing that too many property agents are contributing to the oversupply of agents.

images.alt_text: If participation continues to be weak and developers continue to sit out state land sales - and they are already stepping back from private collective sales - housing supply will diminish, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Recent reports have cast a positive light on Singapore’s office market, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
In the public housing sector, market forces appear to be regrouping, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
In today’s private housing market, the luxury condominium segment is struggling, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.
Senior correspondent Leslie Yee has been following developments surrounding the push to internalise the management of Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust.

site_title: US: Stocks rebound to open big earnings week
summary: US stocks rebounded on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average finishing 0.7% higher at 38,239.98, and the S&P 500 gaining 0.9% to 5,010.60. The Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.1% to 15,451.31, as markets breathed a sigh of relief after tensions in the Middle East subsided. This week's earnings calendar includes major tech companies like Amazon and Microsoft, which may influence market performance.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Commuters pass by the NASDAQ Marketsite in New York, May 21, 2012. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Honda to build major EV plant in Canada
summary: Honda plans to build a major electric vehicle (EV) plant in eastern Canada, with the federal government and province of Ontario providing financial incentives. The plant, to be built an hour outside Toronto, will also produce EV batteries and is expected to be worth C$14 billion. The move follows Canada's strategy to attract EV investment, with tax incentives, renewable energy access, and rare mineral deposits. Honda aims to sell only zero-emission vehicles by 2040 and go carbon-neutral in its operations by 2050.

images.alt_text: Honda expects to produce as many  as 150,000 vehicles per year at its Itirapina plant by 2030.
Honda planned to roll out a total of 10 Honda-brand EV models in China by 2027 in the race to ensure EVs make up 100 per cent of its automobile sales in the country by 2035.

This photo taken on December 8, 2023 shows workers inspecting a car on the production line during a media tour of the "Nissan Intelligent Factory" at the Nissan Motor Tochigi plant, the company's largest in Japan, in Kaminokawa, Tochigi prefecture, some 105 kms (65 miles) north of Tokyo. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)
Both Honda and Nissan are considering cutting production capacity in China as sales decline.

site_title: SAP cloud revenue meets estimate as AI adoption fuels demand
summary: SAP reported first-quarter cloud revenue in line with estimates, driven by a 25% rise in demand for artificial intelligence (AI) services. The German software company's adjusted cloud revenue reached 3.9 billion euros, with a 28% growth in cloud backlog. SAP aims to migrate customers from legacy on-premise software to the cloud, offering business AI services to sweeten the deal. The company is confident of achieving its 2024 goals, citing powerful growth drivers, including Business AI, cross-selling, and winning new customers.

images.alt_text: SAP have more than 106,000 employees as at Sep 30.
