The private sector also has a role to play to realise the potential of artificial intelligence for public good, said Minister Josephine Teo.
SAP, Europe’s biggest software company, also plans to move away from providing long-term guidance after 2025.

site_title: Rapid globalisation of Asia corporates drives demand for innovative solutions: Citi’s Gunjan Kalra
summary: Gunjan Kalra, Asia head of Citi Commercial Bank, notes that Asia's rapid globalization of corporates is driving demand for innovative solutions. The region is home to a growing number of emerging and mid-sized companies aggressively pursuing global growth, with clients seeking tailored banking solutions. Kalra's role involves building relationships with clients, providing advisory and capabilities, and ensuring their needs are met. She emphasizes the importance of innovation, entrepreneurship, and being curious, stating that hard work is also crucial for success.

site_title: Japan’s factory activity declines slow, PMI shows
summary: Japan's factory activity contracted in April, but approached the break-even point, with the au Jibun Bank flash Japan manufacturing PMI rising to 49.9 from 48.2 in March. The service sector continued to drive growth, with the services PMI edging up to 54.6 in April, its highest since May last year. Both manufacturers' confidence and employment growth improved, while input cost inflation rose, leading to average output prices increasing at the fastest pace in nine months.

site_title: Japan to work with counterparts on excessive FX moves, says finance minister
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki said authorities will work closely with overseas counterparts to deal with excessive volatility in the foreign exchange market. Suzuki stated that Tokyo is ready to take action "without ruling out any options" against excessive currency moves. This comes after a trilateral finance dialogue between the US, Japan, and South Korea, where finance leaders agreed to "consult closely" on foreign exchange markets.

site_title: California to wrap up ExxonMobil plastics probe ‘in weeks’, AG says
summary: California's two-year investigation into ExxonMobil's role in global plastic pollution is nearing completion, with a decision on whether to file a lawsuit expected by summer. The investigation, launched in 2022, found a "half-century campaign of deception" by fossil fuel companies, including ExxonMobil, about recycling and plastic waste. Attorney General Rob Bonta said ExxonMobil's "lies and deceit" have been well-documented, despite the company's claims that its solutions to improve waste management are focused.

site_title: Expect up to 12x returns for every dollar spent on climate adaptation: StanChart
summary: Standard Chartered's chief sustainability officer, Marisa Drew, says that every dollar invested in climate adaptation and resilience could generate 12 times as much in economic benefits, citing a guide developed by the bank, KPMG, and the United Nations. Climate adaptation has historically been underfunded and receives less private sector financing, but the increasing necessity of such goods and services due to climate change presents opportunities for growth. Experts emphasize the importance of taking adaptation and resiliency actions early to mitigate physical impacts from climate events and prevent affordability issues in the insurance industry.

site_title: Singapore banks lead market surge again on easing Middle East tensions; STI up 1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1% to 3,258.07, driven by easing Middle East tensions boosting investor confidence. Banking stocks led the market surge, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC up 1.2%, 0.7%, and 0.8% respectively. Across the broader market, gainers outnumbered losers 113 to 26. The gains followed overnight gains on global markets, with US indices closing higher on Monday.

site_title: China’s bubble tea boom creates a half-dozen billionaires
summary: China's bubble tea industry has created at least six billionaires, with Sichuan Baicha Baidao Industrial's IPO expected to raise over $300 million. The company's founders, Wang Xiaokun and Liu Weihong, would become billionaires with a combined net worth of $2.7 billion. However, growing competition and China's economic downturn have led to a decline in valuations, with some analysts warning that the profitability of consumer businesses remains uncertain. The industry's uneven revival has also led to a surge in new players, threatening some weaker competitors.

images.alt_text: Asung Daiso has grown into one of the country’s top sellers of cheap stuff, with more than 1,500 stores.
The noodle maker is not rushing to list and plans to bolster its market share and product portfolio first.

site_title: Memecoin mania sent Bitcoin fees soaring during the ‘halving’
summary: Transaction fees for Bitcoin surged to $82 million on April 20 as users rushed to mint speculative memecoins, despite the Bitcoin halving reducing the supply of new tokens. The halving, which halves the mining subsidy every four years, led to a 75% increase in mining revenue, with miners relying on transaction fees to stay afloat. The event briefly tempered the potential blow of the software update, which could lead to a 75% drop in daily Bitcoin production, resulting in over $10 billion in lost revenue annually.

images.alt_text: A bitcoin logo is displayed outside a cryptocurrency exchange in Hong Kong on April 15, 2024. In April miners of bitcoin will face a halving of the reward for operating the most popular cryptocurrency, in a pivotal event that is a test of survival, industry commentators say. (Photo by DALE DE LA REY / AFP)

site_title: Boeing expects slower increase in 787 production rate and deliveries: memo
summary: Boeing expects a slower increase in 787 production rate and deliveries due to supplier shortages on "a few key parts." Despite this, the company plans to steadily increase production to meet "strong demand." The FAA is aware of the issue and is working closely with Boeing to ensure safe and compliant deliveries. The move comes amid scrutiny over Boeing's manufacturing practices, including a recent US Senate hearing where an engineer claimed the company failed to adequately shim parts, potentially causing premature fatigue failure.

images.alt_text: Robin Hayes will lead Airbus‘ commercial aircraft business in North America, which is based in Herndon, Virginia.

Whistleblower Sam Salehpour, a quality engineer at Boeing, prior to a Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations hearing in Washington, DC, April 17, 2024. US lawmakers challenged Boeing to expend the necessary time and effort to reset its safety culture and criticised the planemaker's relationship with regulators as too cozy.
A Boeing 787 Dreamliner being built at the aviation company's North Charleston, South Carolina, assembly plant on May 30, 2023.
United Airlines was impacted more than rivals by the MAX 9 grounding, which followed a January emergency landing of an Alaska Airlines flight after a panel on the fuselage blew out midair.
Boeing has slowed the pace of work on the 737 family to give workers and suppliers breathing room to catch up on damaged or missing parts and get its production lines back in order.
Airbus says it won 170 new orders in the first quarter, with no cancellations.
The planemaker has been grappling with a full-blown safety crisis that has undermined its reputation following a Jan 5 mid-air panel blowout on a 737 MAX plane.

site_title: Blackstone-owned Crown Resorts can keep Sydney casino licence, regulator says
summary: Blackstone-owned Crown Resorts has been found suitable to retain its Sydney casino licence after nearly three years of remediation, according to the New South Wales state regulator. The company agreed to pay a A$450 million fine for breaking anti-money laundering laws last year. The regulator stated that Crown Sydney has fundamentally reformed its business and built a culture of transparency and accountability. The decision allows Crown to continue operating its Sydney casino, following similar approval for its Melbourne casino last month.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Clar, Keppel Reit, ESR-Logos Reit, Nanofilm, LHN
summary: Key stocks to watch include CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, which reported a higher average rental rate of 16.9% for Q1, and Keppel Reit, which saw a 7.2% increase in net property income. In contrast, ESR-Logos Reit's NPI fell 10.8% year on year, and Nanofilm Technologies' revenue rose 19% to S$39 million. Meanwhile, LHN disposed of its 20% interest in Coliwoo for S$20,000, with shares remaining flat.

site_title: Chinese restaurants spur Hong Kong’s retail property recovery
summary: Hong Kong's retail property market is experiencing a recovery, driven in part by the return of tourists and the growth of the Chinese food industry. Chinese restaurants are seeing the largest increase, with 36 new eateries in the first quarter, while non-Chinese restaurants declined by 18. The vacancy rate in key shopping areas dropped to 9.6% in the first quarter, the lowest in over three years, as tourists and locals alike return to the city. This trend is attributed to a growing trend of Hong Kong residents traveling to mainland China, fueling demand for Chinese cuisine.

site_title: Decarbonisation startup Accacia raises US$6.5 million
summary: Decarbonisation startup Accacia has raised US$6.5 million in pre-Series A funding led by Illuminate Financial. The platform, which tracks and benchmarks emissions in real estate portfolios, has been deployed to over 25 million square feet of real estate. Accacia aims to leverage this opportunity and scale globally, addressing the sector's lack of robust climate risk measurement tools.

site_title: Shadow banking stress in South Korea sends warning to global investors
summary: South Korea's shadow banking sector is experiencing stress due to rising interest rates, prompting concerns among global investors. Delinquency rates at Korean lenders nearly doubled to 6.55% last year, while economists estimate $111 trillion of project-finance debt is "troubled." Policymakers have expanded loan guarantees to stem contagion risks, but a recent restructuring announcement by builder Taeyoung Engineering & Construction highlights the threat of flare-ups. The sector's challenges are seen as a microcosm of global concerns, with Citigroup estimating a 0.2% slowdown in economic growth in the second half of the year.

The won extended declines against the dollar to hit the lowest in a year and a half.

site_title: Oil futures fall as fears of a wider Middle East war fade
summary: Oil futures fell on Monday, with Brent crude settling at $87.00 a barrel, down 29 cents or 0.33%, and US West Texas Intermediate crude finishing at $82.85 a barrel, down 29 cents or 0.35%. Traders cited a tightening supply-demand balance and strong market fundamentals, with few expecting the Middle East conflict to impact supply. The high spare capacity of oil-producing countries is seen as a buffer against potential disruptions, and a protracted oil rally is unlikely unless the Strait of Hormuz is disrupted or Saudi Arabia is drawn into the conflict.

images.alt_text: Brent futures fell 67 cents, or 0.77 per cent, to US$86.62 a barrel by 0402 GMT on Monday.

site_title: Nanofilm Q1 revenue up 19% on recovery of consumer business
summary: Nanofilm Technologies reported a 19% increase in revenue to S$39 million for its first quarter ended March 31, 2024, driven by the recovery of its consumer business segment. Its advanced materials business unit grew 41% year on year, with the 3C sector contributing 44% of revenue. The company expects profitability to improve in FY2024 from cost structure optimization and lower capital expenditure.

images.alt_text: Despite the first half’s losses, the group still managed to pull a full-year profit of S$3.1 million, although this is still down 92.8 per cent from S$43.8 million in profits posted in the previous financial year.

site_title: EU’s 2050 net zero goals at risk as EV rollout faces setbacks
summary: The EU's 2050 net zero goals are at risk due to high electric vehicle (EV) production costs in Europe, which may lead to relying on cheap imports from China. The European Court of Auditors warns that the bloc may create new economic dependencies and harm its own industry. Despite increasing EV purchases, charging infrastructure is lacking, and prices remain unaffordable, with batteries costing 15,000 euros per unit. The EU needs to rethink its policies to meet its 2035 ban on new petrol car sales and achieve its 2050 climate goals.

site_title: Citigroup sells maple bonds in first sizable deal since 2015
summary: Citigroup sold C$1 billion of fixed-to-floating rate notes in the Canadian-dollar bond market, marking its first sizable deal since 2015. The offering drew orders over twice the size of the deal and yielded 1.07 percentage points above Canadian benchmarks. The move comes as US banks seek to diversify funding after reporting earnings, with Citigroup's deal following a similar offering from Bank of America last week.

site_title: China wants everyone to trade in their old cars, fridges to help save its economy
summary: China's government has announced a plan to encourage businesses and households to trade in old cars and appliances to upgrade to cleaner technologies, boosting the country's electric vehicle industry and supporting economic growth. The program aims to upgrade industrial and household equipment, with incentives for consumers to scrap old machines and purchase new energy-efficient ones. Local governments will handle the practicalities, with subsidies ranging from 100 million yuan for cars to 20 million yuan for appliances. The plan is expected to help China's economy, which is forecast to fall short of its 5% growth target, by increasing consumer spending and business investment, and reducing overcapacity in China's factories.

site_title: Taiwan hit by numerous quakes, strongest reaching 6.3 magnitude
summary: Taiwan experienced a series of earthquakes overnight into Tuesday, with the strongest quake reaching a magnitude-6.3 in eastern Hualien. The first quake, a 5.5 magnitude, hit Monday, followed by aftershocks and intense tremors. Dozens of smaller quakes were recorded, causing fallen rocks on highways and swaying buildings. The region has experienced frequent earthquakes due to its location at the junction of two tectonic plates. The area was severely affected by a 7.4 magnitude quake on April 3, resulting in 17 deaths and widespread damage.

site_title: UK exports fewer goods after Brexit, tilting economy to services
summary: The UK's economy has become more reliant on services exports, with goods exports 15% below records in 2018, according to the Office for National Statistics. Despite this, services exports have continued to grow, increasing by 63% since 2010. The UK's trade balance has worsened since 2010, with falling EU trade weighing on progress made to boost business with the rest of the world. Experts say the shift to services is a global trend and could bring benefits at home, but it may be difficult to offset lost trade with the EU.

site_title: Meta opens Quest operating system to third-party device makers
summary: Meta Platforms is sharing its Quest headset operating system, Meta Horizon OS, with rival device makers, including Microsoft, to expand its influence in the virtual and mixed reality industry. Partner companies like Asus and Lenovo will use the operating system to create specialized headsets for activities like gaming, exercise, and entertainment. The move is seen as an effort to own the computational platform powering VR and MR devices, similar to Google's strategy with Android. Meta's CEO Mark Zuckerberg has previewed examples of specialized headsets, including ones inspired by Microsoft's Xbox gaming console.

The US "growth content" team, which consisted of about 40 employees, was eliminated, along with senior managers Alex Ingram and Jorge Milburn. This move marks a pullback from Tesla's nascent advertising initiatives, which were seen as a response to slowing global EV sales growth and increasing competition.

summary: China's central bank chief, Pan Gongsheng, urged creditors in debt restructurings for emerging market countries to agree on a fair burden-sharing approach, citing the need for "comparable treatment" in debt negotiations. This comes as billions of US dollars in loans over the past decade have soured, raising questions about China's role as a major creditor to developing nations. Pan called on private creditors to participate "on a comparable basis" and emphasized the importance of measuring concessionality in lending.

site_title: TikTok risks fines as EU issues ultimatum over app launch
summary: The European Union has issued an ultimatum to TikTok, warning it may face fines of up to 1% of its annual income if it fails to deliver a risk assessment for its new TikTok Lite app. The app's points system, which rewards users for tasks, has raised concerns over addictive behavior. TikTok has 24 hours to comply, or face penalties. This comes after the EU previously announced a formal investigation into TikTok's addictive design, screen time limits, and age verification procedures under the Digital Services Act.

summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has sued to block Tapestry's $8.5 billion acquisition of Capri, the parent company of luxury brands Michael Kors and Versace. The FTC claims the deal would eliminate direct competition between Tapestry's and Capri's brands, giving Tapestry a dominant share of the "accessible luxury" handbag market. The proposed merger would also combine customer data streams and achieve annual cost savings of $200 million. The FTC argues this would deprive millions of American consumers of head-to-head competition, affecting price, innovation, design, and advertising.

site_title: ASML takes step toward major expansion in Eindhoven, Netherlands
summary: ASML, the largest supplier of equipment to computer chip makers, has signed a letter of intent with the city of Eindhoven, Netherlands, to explore a major expansion that could house 20,000 new employees. The move follows a $2.7 billion investment by the Dutch government to improve infrastructure in the Eindhoven region. ASML prefers to keep its core activities in the Netherlands, citing factors such as talent availability, infrastructure, and investment climate as key preconditions for investment. The expansion is seen as a significant step towards resolving doubts about ASML's future operations.

site_title: Tesla’s latest price cuts risk wiping out China earnings
summary: Tesla's latest price cuts in China risk wiping out the company's earnings in the country, with its business potentially breakeven or even negative. The price cuts, which include discounts of up to 7%, may cost Tesla its operating profit in China, where its market share has shrunk to 6.7% in the fourth quarter. This comes as the company faces intense competition in the EV market, with rival Li Auto also cutting prices and offering cash rebates. Tesla is expected to report a 40% plunge in operating profit and its first revenue decline in four years when it releases first-quarter earnings on Tuesday.

site_title: Silent and brooding, Trump endures courtroom ordeal
summary: Donald Trump sat in a Manhattan courtroom on April 22, 2024, watching his criminal trial unfold as the first US president to face prosecution. Prosecutors detailed how Trump allegedly falsified business records to pay off adult film actress Stormy Daniels in 2016. Trump's defense lawyer downplayed the charges, saying they were "pieces of paper." The trial's first witness, David Pecker, a former executive of the tabloid group American Media, testified about the company's "checkbook journalism" tactics used to squash salacious stories about Trump. The trial will continue for the next month or two.

site_title: Former JetBlue CEO Hayes to lead Airbus in North America
summary: Former JetBlue CEO Robin Hayes has been named as the new head of Airbus' commercial aircraft business in North America, replacing C. Jeffrey Knittel, who is retiring as chairman and CEO of Airbus Americas on June 3. Hayes, who stepped down as JetBlue CEO in February after nine years, will lead the business based in Herndon, Virginia, and oversee coordination among Airbus' North American helicopter, space, and defense operations. Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury said Hayes will help deliver on the company's strategic objectives in the region.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after Friday sell-off, Middle East tensions subside
summary: US stock markets opened higher on Monday, April 22, 2024, after a sell-off on Friday, driven by easing Middle East tensions. The Dow Jones rose 130.5 points, the S&P 500 gained 20.1 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 114.1 points, as investors looked ahead to a week of major tech earnings and inflation data.

site_title: Thai central bank could adjust rates if economic outlook shifts, says deputy governor
summary: The Bank of Thailand has maintained its key interest rate at 2.50%, its highest in over a decade, despite government pressure to cut rates. Deputy Governor Alisara Mahasandana stated that the central bank may adjust monetary policy if the economic outlook changes and structural challenges impact long-term growth. The Bank forecasts a 2.6% economic growth this year and 3.0% in 2025, with inflation expected to return to the target range of 1-3% by the end of the year.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound after last week’s selloff, eyes on earnings and data
summary: European stocks rebounded 0.6% on Monday, recouping losses from last week's selloff due to geopolitical concerns and interest rate cut worries. The Stoxx 600 index rose, with Britain's FTSE 100 near record highs, driven by easing tensions in the Middle East and rising metal prices. This week, investors will focus on European bank earnings and US tech giants' reports, as well as economic data. Despite concerns about a year-long share price rally running out of steam, French central bank chief Francois Villeroy de Galhau said interest rate cuts are still on track for June.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit posts 17% rental reversion in Q1
summary: CAPITALand Ascendas Reit reported a 17% rental reversion in Q1, driven by a 16.9% increase in average rental rates for leases renewed. site_title: Sanofi to pay US$100 million to settle Zantac cancer lawsuits
summary: Sanofi will pay over $100 million to settle approximately 4,000 lawsuits accusing the company of failing to warn users of its Zantac heartburn medicine about its potential cancer risk. The average payout per claim is over $25,000, providing relief to former users. The settlement mainly applies to state court cases outside of Delaware, where a federal judge is considering the scientific evidence in over 70,000 suits.

images.alt_text: Sanofi still faces about 20,000 lawsuits over Zantac in Delaware state court.

site_title: US consumers on lower incomes face loan stress while banks pull back
summary: US consumers on lower incomes are experiencing loan stress as rising prices squeeze budgets, prompting banks to become more cautious about credit card and car loan approvals. Household debt has surged to an all-time high, with Americans borrowing more on credit cards, and default rates on these loans are higher than for those on higher incomes. Experts warn that if delinquency rates rise, it could be a leading indicator of worsening economic conditions.

site_title: At 5% yields, investors find it’s worth paying for actively managed bond funds again
summary: Investors are shifting assets into actively managed bond funds, with $90 billion flowing into active bond funds in Q1, the most since mid-2021. Yields are at their highest in nearly two decades, making it an attractive time for investors to lock in outsized returns. Active managers, including BlackRock and Capital Group, are capitalizing on this trend, with many seeing a "longer multi-quarter and potentially multi-year trend out of cash." Passive funds also saw inflows, but at a slower pace, as investors increasingly favor actively managed strategies.

site_title: Iranian president vows to boost trade with Pakistan to US$10 billion a year
summary: Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi vowed to boost trade with Pakistan to $10 billion annually during a three-day visit, amid efforts to mend ties after military strikes. The visit comes after local media reported bilateral trade worth over $2 billion in 2023. Raisi agreed to cooperate on counter-terrorism and joint approaches to address common challenges. The visit is seen as a key step towards normalizing relations, but Iran's Supreme Leader has the final say on state matters.

site_title: Vietnamese firms face Q1 debt crunch amid sluggish recovery
summary: Vietnamese firms face a debt crunch in Q1 2024 due to a sluggish economic recovery and tightened lending rules. Bank credit and corporate bond issuance remain limited, with a 0.26% growth in bank credit and a 36% decline in new corporate bond issuance. The State Bank of Vietnam attributes the slowdown to seasonal factors and weak capital absorption. However, analysts predict a recovery in the second half of the year, with bad loans expected to decrease and corporate bond market activity to increase. The government aims to increase corporate bond issuance to 20% of GDP by 2025.

site_title: Despite de-escalation, tensions between Iran and Israel remain high
summary: Tensions between Iran and Israel remain high despite a de-escalation last week, when Israel launched a limited military strike against Iran in retaliation for its missile and drone assault. The US is caught in a delicate balancing act, seeking to support Israel while avoiding a direct military confrontation with Iran. The situation has changed, with both countries willing to directly attack each other's territory, increasing the risk of a regional war. The US is considering new weapons deals for Israel and has vetoed a UN Security Council resolution calling for a Palestinian state, amid concerns of Iran's growing influence and the threat to global stability.

site_title: Upcoming plastic pollution rules will affect everyone
summary: Global rules on plastic pollution will affect everyone, as 160 governments meet in Ottawa, Canada, to finalize a revised draft. The new rules will govern the management of all kinds of plastic waste, with cost implications across the economy and opportunities for investment. The issue is complex, with over 19 million tonnes of plastic waste ending up in lakes, rivers, and seas each year. Existing international agreements address only some aspects of the problem, and momentum has been growing, with the UN Environment Assembly passing a resolution in 2022. Companies must adjust to extended producer responsibility, and innovative approaches are needed to bring all on board and ensure recycling can be done at scale.

images.alt_text: “The ocean is part of who we are, and it is our shared responsibility,” says EU Commissioner for Environment, Oceans and Fisheries Virginijus Sinkevicius.
Experts estimate that 44 per cent of ocean plastic consists of plastic bags, bottles, food containers, cutlery and wrappers.

site_title: An overstimulated US economy is asking for trouble
summary: The US economy is showing resilience despite expectations of a recession, with GDP growth forecasted to reach at least 2% for the seventh quarter in a row. This is attributed to the lingering effects of pandemic-era stimulus, including $10 trillion in new spending by the US government and the continued expansion of the money supply. This stimulus has kept growth artificially high and inflated asset prices, making the economy overheated and potentially setting it up for trouble if interest rates remain high for an extended period.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates in the US make life difficult for many countries by strengthening the value of the US dollar against other currencies.

site_title: Time to study broadening of private market access
summary: Wealth gap widens as billionaires' net worth surges to a record-breaking $14.2 trillion, despite a rising cost of living. Access to private markets may be contributing to this growth, as ultra-high-net-worth individuals can invest in diverse, uncorrelated asset classes. Public markets are shrinking, with the number of publicly traded companies declining globally. This trend is coinciding with a concentration of outperformance at the top end of the market, making it difficult for retail investors to participate. Experts suggest studying the pros and cons of democratizing private markets to address this issue.

This decline is attributed to increased concerns about job stability, reflecting Canadians' growing anxiety about their employment prospects.

The watch, which measures 44mm in diameter, features a split-second complication and came from the collection of prominent collector Auro Montanari. Despite a pullback in second-hand prices for luxury watches, collectors are still willing to break records for rare items.

Water blue is a new sapphire colour that Hublot has created.
Swiss watch exports to India could exceed 400 million francs by 2028, according to the audit firm Deloitte estimation.
The Watches and Wonders salon, which runs until Apr 15, will see 54 major watch brands show off their latest creations, including Rolex, Patek Philippe, Cartier, Chopard, Hermes and Chanel.
Watches of the Bioceramic Moonswatch Collection. Swatch makes high-end Omega, Tissot and Longines watches, as well the eponymous mass-market plastic models.
The timepieces include a unique FP Journe Vagabondage one Model from 2004 that commemorates each of Schumacher’s F1 championship wins.

site_title: Malaysia’s Sapura Energy to sell stake in SapuraOMV to TotalEnergies for US$705 million
summary: Malaysia's Sapura Energy is selling its 50% stake in SapuraOMV to TotalEnergies for $705.3 million. The deal includes a cash payment and the release of a $175 million obligation. TotalEnergies will become the sole owner of SapuraOMV, which holds operating interests in blocks SK408 and SK310 in Malaysia and exploration interests in other countries. Sapura Energy plans to use the proceeds to repay outstanding liabilities. The portfolio rationalization marks a strategic shift away from exploration and production.

site_title: ‘Tomb Raider’ games owner Embracer splits into three companies
summary: Embracer, the Swedish video game group owner of franchises like Tomb Raider and The Lord of the Rings, has announced a major restructuring by splitting into three separate companies. The move aims to cut costs, lower net debt, and streamline operations. Middle-Earth Enterprises & Friends will manage Embracer's big-budget game studios, while Asmodee Group will handle the tabletop business, and Coffee Stain & Friends will focus on smaller studios and free-to-play games. The decision is seen as a necessary adaptation to the changing gaming industry, with shares rising nearly eight percent in afternoon trading.

images.alt_text: Game companies have been coping with layoffs, mergers and product cancellations.

Embracer bought several development studios and the intellectual property rights to a number of games including a new Tomb Raider game, announced plans for the share issue late on Wednesday. e Tomb Raider, an action adventure game.

site_title: Reliance misses profit estimate on petrochemicals drag
summary: Reliance Industries, India's largest company by market value, missed its profit estimate for the quarter ended March 31, with net income falling 1.8% to 189.5 billion rupees. This marks the fourth straight quarter of missed profit estimates. Revenue rose 9.5% to 2.41 trillion rupees, but total costs increased 12% and other income jumped 57%. Despite a strong performance in consumer businesses, the petrochemicals business continued to be a drag on the company's results.

site_title: China’s Q1 fiscal revenue falls as tax cut policies weigh
summary: China's fiscal revenue dropped 2.3% in Q1 to 4.9 trillion yuan due to tax cut policies, despite the world's second-biggest economy growing faster than expected. Tax revenue declined 4.9% year-over-year, but revenue from cultural and advanced manufacturing industries grew rapidly. Fiscal expenditures rose 2.9% to nearly seven trillion yuan, with spending on disaster prevention and emergency management increasing by 53.4% in Q1. The government aims to strengthen macro control, expand domestic demand, and prevent risks to improve economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Chinese policymakers already battling a protracted property crisis and weak demand at home have scant incentive to escalate tensions.
China will facilitate foreign investment in domestic tech firms via an inbound investment scheme, QFLP.
Foreign direct investment (FDI) totalled 301.7 billion yuan (S$56.8 billion) in January-to-March quarter.
China’s nominal GDP growth rate of 4.2 per cent in the first quarter was considerably below the real growth rate, mainly dragged down by weak prices.
China’s manufacturing drive has exacerbated tensions with trading partners.

site_title: Memory of ‘Chariots of Fire’ hero Liddell burns bright for daughter
summary: Eric Liddell, a Scottish missionary and Olympic gold medalist, famously refused to run his favored 100m heat on a Sunday at the 1924 Paris Olympics. His daughter Patricia Russell, now 88, recalls fond memories of her father, who was a liberal Christian, and shares stories of their family's idyllic summer holidays together. Liddell was later interned by the Japanese during World War II and died of a brain tumor in 1945, at the age of 40. His legacy continues to inspire those who met him in the internment camp, providing some comfort to his daughter in her grief.

images.alt_text: Each individual Olympic champion will receive US$50,000 and relay teams will receive the same amount, to be shared among the team members.

site_title: HSBC contributes more than S$500,000 to sustainability initiatives since 2020
summary: HSBC Singapore has launched its third phase of a sustainability initiative with the National Youth Achievement Award Council, partnering with Institute of Technical Education (ITE) students and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to develop sustainable solutions for businesses and reduce carbon emissions. Since 2020, HSBC has contributed over S$500,000 to the initiative, with close to 140 ITE students and 35 SMEs participating in the third phase. The initiative aims to create a more resilient future by supporting local businesses and helping youth develop green skills.

images.alt_text: The artwork, Whispers of the Deep, was made from scraps found in the ocean and later restored by

site_title: LHN’s Coliwoo unit sells 20% of stake in subsidiary for S$20,000
summary: LHN Limited's indirect wholly-owned subsidiary, Coliwoo Holdings, has sold 20% of its stake in Coliwoo (TK) to Macritchie Developments for S$20,000. Coliwoo (TK) will remain a subsidiary of LHN and is expected to acquire a property through public tender on May 9, 2024. The sale represents 20% of Coliwoo (TK)'s total issued share capital, with Coliwoo Holdings retaining 80% ownership and Macritchie Developments holding 20%.

images.alt_text: GSM Building at 141 Middle Road.

site_title: A more reliable way to get enough investment returns
summary: Investors who can withstand short-term market volatility are more likely to achieve long-term returns. To achieve this, investors and their advisers should examine empirical evidence to determine reliable asset classes, such as global equities and bonds, and work out expected returns based on non-negotiable life goals. A mix of asset classes with estimated expected returns can be used to create a curated portfolio with a manageable level of volatility. Indexed funds or ETFs can also help reduce the returns gap by making it easier to hold onto investments and resisting short-term outperformance or underperformance.

images.alt_text: Theme funds: tread with care
The Morningstar report found that diversifying into areas including emerging markets stocks, high-yield bonds and global bonds generally hurt returns last year, when the S&P 500 gained 24 per cent.

site_title: US dollar forges higher after volatile week, yen in spotlight
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro and yen on Monday after a volatile week, with investors assessing policy and geopolitical developments ahead of the Bank of Japan's policy review. The dollar's trade-weighted index was above 106, but off five-month highs, while the yen traded at 154.76 per dollar, near a 34-year low. Analysts expect the BOJ to maintain its policy, and the market does not see a change in rates. The strong dollar has led to a repricing of global rate cut timelines, but expectations for the European Central Bank and Bank of England to start cutting by mid-year remain intact.

images.alt_text: Swiss franc, yen modestly up, but off highs

site_title: Denmark launches its biggest offshore wind tender
summary: Denmark has launched its largest offshore wind tender, offering six sites with a combined capacity of up to 10 gigawatts to be completed by 2030. The tender, which does not offer subsidies, requires bidders to pay the state 20% of the project's cost over 30 years. The goal is to reduce CO2 emissions by 70% from 1990 levels by the end of the decade. The winning projects can install up to 10 GW of turbines, enough to cover Denmark's consumption and potentially export green power to neighboring countries.

images.alt_text: Selling credits from wind farms and other activities to a company so it can offset pollution is seen as a way to help move money to climate-friendly projects.

site_title: Vodafone Idea fetches bids worth US$10.6 billion in India's largest-ever follow-on share sale
summary: Vodafone Idea raised US$10.57 billion in India's largest-ever follow-on share sale, garnering bids for 80.12 billion shares at a price band of 10-11 rupees per share. The company aims to raise US$2.16 billion to expand its network services and cover 40% of its revenue base with 5G service within two to two-and-a-half years. This is part of its plan to raise 200 billion rupees through equity and 250 billion rupees via debt to roll out 5G network service.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks across the LED display board showing the logo of Vodafone-Idea at the India Mobile Congress 2022, at Pragati Maidan, in New Delhi, India, October 3, 2022. REUTERS/Anushree Fadnavis/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Chinese quant funds expand abroad as rules tighten at home
summary: Chinese quant hedge funds are expanding abroad as the sector becomes increasingly crowded at home and regulators tighten supervision. Funds such as Meridian & Saturn Capital, DH Fund Management, and Ubiquant are establishing offshore offices and investing globally, seeking exposure to European and US investors. The expansion is driven by the need to build offshore structures and profit from market volatility, with many funds aiming to capture "alpha" or market outperformance. This trend is expected to intensify head-to-head competition with global giants, as Chinese fund managers launch the Chinese Overseas Private Funds Association to collectively voice their concerns to policymakers.

site_title: Saudi Aramco in talks to buy 10% of China’s Hengli Petrochemical
summary: Saudi Aramco is in talks to acquire a 10% stake in China's Hengli Petrochemical, a deal subject to due diligence and regulatory approvals. The proposed transaction aligns with Aramco's strategy to expand its downstream presence in China and secure long-term crude oil supply agreements. This would be the latest in a series of Aramco deals with Chinese refiners, following recent agreements with Rongsheng Petrochemical and Zhejiang Petrochemical.

images.alt_text: Aramco believes the deal would position it as a global LNG player.

Signage above the Saudi Aramco booth on day two of the Abu Dhabi International Petroleum Exhibition and Conference (ADIPEC) in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, on Tuesday, Oct. 3, 2023. The annual strategic energy conference runs from Oct 2-5. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

Fossil fuels accounted for 82 per cent of global consumption last year, according to a report from consultancy KPMG cited by Saudi Aramco chief executive Amin Nasser, who noted that the International Energy Agency has said oil demand could hit a record high this year.
The kingdom plans to hire JPMorgan as one of the main underwriters to the offering.

site_title: Taiwan hit by strong 5.5-magnitude quake
summary: A 5.5-magnitude earthquake struck Taiwan on April 22, causing widespread damage and killing at least 17 people, with the latest body discovered on April 13. The quake originated in eastern Hualien, where a magnitude-7.4 quake hit on April 3, causing landslides and building damage. The region is prone to frequent quakes due to its location at the junction of two tectonic plates. The latest quake was felt in the capital Taipei and was described as one of the strongest since a major quake in 1999.

images.alt_text: Workers carry out rescue operation at the site where a building collapsed, following the earthquake, in Hualien, Taiwan, in this screengrab taken from a SET TV video shot April 3, 2024. SET TV/Handout via REUTERS  ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. MANDATORY CREDIT. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES. TAIWAN OUT. NO COMMERCIAL OR EDITORIAL SALES IN TAIWAN
Technological advancements in Taiwan appear to have kept damage and casualties relatively low after the 7.4-magnitude quake on early Wednesday.

site_title: China state fund pours US$41 billion into stock market in Q1: reports
summary: China's state fund Central Huijin Investment purchased at least $41 billion in blue-chip stocks in the first quarter, helping China's CSI300 blue-chip index bounce back 14% from five-year lows in February. The purchases included various exchanged-traded funds (ETFs) and were part of a bid to shore up the sliding stock market. The rebound was also aided by market-friendly policies and the replacement of China's top securities regulator.

images.alt_text: Brokerages are also offering revised product structures to meet investors’ changing risk appetite.

The unpredictable nature of geopolitical tensions increases the risk of investing in Chinese stocks, an asset class that many were already avoiding due to regulatory uncertainties and a slowing economy.
The investment link between mainland China and Hong Kong will be broadened to include real estate investment trusts (Reits) and yuan-denominated stocks listed in Hong Kong.
Only about 30 companies may be delisted next year due to their financial metrics, according to CSRC calculations.

site_title: Thailand pitches to host Formula One race to bolster tourism
summary: Thailand has proposed hosting a Formula One (F1) street race in Bangkok, aiming to boost tourism and stimulate the economy. The Thai government, led by Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin, has invited F1 executives to survey potential routes for the event. If successful, the race could generate approximately 4 billion baht (S$147 million) in economic value and create over 1,000 jobs. Thailand's tourism industry, accounting for 20% of total jobs and 12% of the economy, is a key focus for the government, which aims to attract 80 million tourists by 2027.

images.alt_text: With most leaders positively responding to the single-visa concept, tourism-reliant Thailand aims to generate more revenue per traveller and cushion its economy from headwinds such as sluggish exports and weak global demand that’s hurt its manufacturing industry.

site_title: Asia stocks rise on cooling geopolitical tensions; STI up 1.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.5% on Monday, tracking regional gains amid expectations of lower geopolitical tensions between Israel and Iran. Other Asian markets also gained, with the Nikkei 225, Hang Seng Index, Kospi Composite Index, and FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI rising 1%, 1.8%, 1.5%, and 0.8% respectively. Local banks DBS and OCBC ended mixed, with DBS falling 6.4% after issuing a share bonus and OCBC gaining 1%.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market,
DBS is selling a portfolio of 46 HDB shop and shophouse units and private strata retail units.

site_title: Mongolia signs landmark climate finance deal for its grasslands
summary: Mongolia has signed a landmark climate finance deal, dubbed "Eternal Mongolia," worth $71 million to protect 144,000 square km of its grasslands, including the world's last great temperate grassland. The 15-year agreement aims to conserve the area, which stores 14-15 million tonnes of carbon, and is home to endangered wildlife. The deal, combined with a government commitment of $127 million, is expected to be one of the largest climate finance agreements in Asia and sets a blueprint for other countries.

images.alt_text: An aerial view of residential buildings in Mongolia's capital Ulaanbaatar. Locals say the construction boom – fuelled by a decade-long mining windfall – is squeezing out room for much-needed public services, from new hospitals to children’s playgrounds.

site_title: Forrest Li’s wife buys Gallop Road bungalow next to the one he has redeveloped
summary: Forrest Li's wife, Ma Liqian, is buying a S$42.5 million old bungalow in Gallop Road, next to the nearly completed redevelopment by Li, for S$2,544 per square foot. The couple is Singapore citizens and will expand their presence in the Good Class Bungalow market. The property, on freehold land, features a long driveway and is part of a sought-after area near the Singapore Botanic Gardens.

images.alt_text: One of the trio of bungalows in Nassim Road that changed hands for a total of S$206.7 million this year. The transaction is among at least S$700 million of deals in GCB Areas for which buyers did not lodge caveats.

site_title: Is the global economy stumbling into ‘the tepid Twenties’?
summary: The global economy is facing a potential "tepid Twenties" of stagnant growth, according to IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva. Weak productivity, retrenchment in globalization, and geopolitical turmoil will drag growth down to paltry levels, sowing seeds of "popular discontent" with mainstream politics. The IMF forecasts 3.2% global growth this year, but warns of a lower 2.9% average over the next decade. Policymakers must address a toxic mix of factors, including a fragmentation of the global trading system, industrial policies, and a lack of investment in key skills.

images.alt_text: The ECB has flagged a rate cut for June 6, but policymakers have largely avoided discussing what happens later on, partly on uncertainty over prices and partly due to risks that the US Federal Reserve, which sets the tone for the world economy, could delay its own rate cuts.
The IMF forecasts global real GDP growth of 3.2 per cent for 2024 and 2025 – the same rate as in 2023

SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA - NOVEMBER 10: U.S. Secretary of the Treasury Janet Yellen speaks during a news conference following a bilateral meeting with People’s Republic of China (PRC) Vice Premier He Lifeng at the Ritz Carlton Hotel on November 10, 2023 in San Francisco, California. Secretary Yellen and Vice Premier Lifeng will hold meetings ahead of the APEC summit being held in San Francisco.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Eurozone consumers increasingly struggle to pay for housing
summary: Eurozone consumers are struggling to pay for housing due to years of above-target inflation and surging borrowing costs. Lower-income households expect to make late payments for utilities or rent, rising to 20% in the first quarter from 15% in 2023, and mortgage payments nearly doubled to 30%. Interest-rate hikes have weighed on the property market, increasing pressure on rentals. The European Central Bank is expected to start lowering rates in June, amid concerns that tight monetary policy is holding back the 20-nation economy excessively.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 22)
summary: Forrest Li's wife, Ma Liqian, buys a bungalow in Gallop Road near the Singapore Botanic Gardens. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) releases a Zion Road site for sale after a developer commits to a bid of S$604.6 million. In other news, Intraco scraps its acquisition of a digital asset platform, the Monetary Authority of Singapore issues a 12-year prohibition order against a former Manulife representative for cheating, and feeder operators in South-east Asia impose an emergency surcharge due to "heavy congestion" at transhipment ports.

site_title: ‘Heavy congestion’ in South-east Asia transhipment ports prompts feeder operators to levy surcharge
summary: A group of Asian feeder operators is imposing an emergency cost recovery surcharge due to "heavy congestion" at major transhipment ports in South-east Asia, caused by disruptions in the Red Sea. Vessels may face delays of up to three days at Singapore ports until April 15. The congestion, resulting from Yemen's Houthi rebel attacks, has led to extensive berth delays and extended port stays, affecting shipping schedules. The surcharge, ranging from $40 to $100 per laden 20-foot-equivalent-unit container, will be implemented until further notice.

images.alt_text: epa11282619 People enjoy the beach as a cargo ship sails in the background, near the Red Sea port of Eilat, southern Israel, 16 April 2024. The port of Eilat, which serves as a gateway for Israel to trade with the countries of the East and Asia, has halted trade activities since Yemen's Houthis rebels attacks on cargo ships in Yemen Bab al-Mandab Strait. The port operator in March announced its intention to layoff half of the port's 120 employees after the seaport suffered financial issues due to the crisis in the Red Sea shipping lanes.  EPA-EFE/ABIR SULTAN
PSA ramps up capacity, resources amid global logistics convulsion
China's Yantian port hit by delays worse than those in Suez Canal incident; MTI says disruptions to Singapore 'manageable'

site_title: China’s state planner warns intensified EV price war on oversupply
summary: China's state planner warns of an intensified EV price war due to oversupply, with over 110 new energy vehicle models expected to be launched this year. The National Development and Reform Commission estimates a 2.1 million unit growth in market demand, but top brands BYD, Aito, and Li Auto plan to increase deliveries by 2.3 million units, signaling an oversupply. Price cuts of 5-10% are expected, with BYD and Tesla already leading the way with reductions of 7.15-9.7%.

site_title: Indonesia expects palm oil exports to recover in April
summary: Indonesia's palm oil exports are expected to recover in April after falling below the monthly average in March and February. The country's trade ministry predicts improved global demand for edible oil in May and June, which could lead to higher domestic market obligation realization. This comes after shipments in March and February fell short of the past year's average, with February exports at 1.3 million tonnes and March shipments at 885,000 tonnes.

images.alt_text: A worker stands as fresh fruit bunches are unloaded to be distributed from the collector site to CPO factories, as Indonesia announced a ban on palm oil exports effective this week in Kampar regency, Riau province, Indonesia, April 26, 2022. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan

site_title: BNP Paribas hires 30 to build up new China securities unit
summary: BNP Paribas has hired 30 people to launch its new China securities unit, re-entering the market 17 years after exiting a local joint venture. The French bank will focus on brokerage, research, and asset management units, but not onshore investment banking due to high costs. This move contrasts with other major banks scaling back in China amid US-China tensions. BNP Paribas aims to build on its existing corporate banking business and expand its presence in the market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man is silhouetted as he walks behind the logo of BNP Paribas at the bank's building in Issy-les-Moulineaux, near Paris, France, February 3, 2022. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: A logo on a BNP Paribas bank branch in Paris, France, February 9, 2022. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo
Major banks in Singapore have long preferred to locate their back-end staff outside the city centre where rents are cheaper.
FILE PHOTO: A logo on a BNP Paribas bank branch in Paris, France, February 9, 2022. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo

site_title: Sri Lanka's inflation drops to 2.5% in March
summary: Sri Lanka's inflation dropped to 2.5% in March, largely driven by a 22% cut in power tariffs for households. Food prices remained unchanged at 5% from February. The decrease was attributed to the receding impact of a higher sales tax under a US$2.9-billion IMF programme. The National Consumer Price Index (NCPI) showed a 0.7% rise in non-food prices in March compared to 5.1% in February.

images.alt_text: We hope to continue discussions with the bondholders with a view to reaching common ground ahead of the IMF board consideration of the second review of Sri Lanka’s EFF (extended fund facility) programme,” says state finance minister Shehan Semasinghe in a statement.
After the announcement, Sri Lanka’s bonds were down between 2.3 and 2.8 cents, leaving them at just over half their original face value at between 53 and 55 cents on the US dollar.

site_title: Indonesia court rejects election disputes, upholding president-elect Prabowo’s win
summary: An Indonesian Constitutional Court has rejected election disputes from two losing presidential candidates, upholding Prabowo Subianto's win in February's election. The court found no evidence of systematic fraud or state interference, and both candidates have agreed to respect the ruling. Prabowo is set to take office in October, replacing President Joko Widodo, who was the hugely popular incumbent. The court's decision brings an end to all election disputes, allowing Prabowo to assume the presidency.

images.alt_text: The two rivals of Defence Minister and former special forces commander Prabowo Subianto (pictured) have both asked the Constitutional Court to disqualify him from a contest he won by a huge margin, arguing widespread distribution of social aid in key areas had swayed the vote in his favour.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS raises StarHub target price on potential Ensign spin-off
summary: DBS Group Research has raised its price target for StarHub to S$1.54, citing the company's cybersecurity business, Ensign InfoSecurity, as a "stepping stone" for its potential spin-off and public listing. Analyst Sachin Mittal expects Ensign to break even by October 2025 and grow at a 20% compound annual rate. The new price target implies a 17 times FY2024 price-to-earnings ratio, with DBS expecting StarHub to re-rate and reach its historical average of 18 times.

images.alt_text: Starhub's total revenue has grown 5.3 per cent to S$622.1 million, from S$590.8 million a year ago.
StarHub chief executive Nikhil Eapen said that the move has allowed the company to pay a good dividend and reduce its net debt slightly to 1.36 times the company’s Ebitda.
In the age of cyberwarfare, passive defence is a losing game. Preparedness, fuelled by self-knowledge and a keen understanding of adversaries, is a better strategy.
Small companies are particularly attractive to hackers as they often have inadequate cybersecurity, making them easier targets.

site_title: Taiwan March export orders trails forecasts, but government pins hopes on AI
summary: Taiwan's export orders rose 1.2% in March to $47.16 billion, missing forecasts of a 3.55% gain. Despite the underperformance, the government expects surging demand for artificial intelligence applications to drive future demand for high-tech products. Orders for telecommunication products and electronic products increased 4.3% and 12.0% respectively, while orders from China rose 7.7% and from the US fell 2.2%. The government cites risks including high interest rates and geopolitical uncertainty, but notes rising demand for AI and high-performance computing.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cargo trucks work inside a container yard in Keelung, Taiwan, January 7, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Wang

site_title: Norway’s US$1.6 trillion fund turns developer on trophy UK properties
summary: Norway's $1.6 trillion sovereign wealth fund, Norges Bank Investment Management, is exploring development projects in London to revamp its aging trophy properties. The fund has already taken back a part of Bank of America's London office campus for a comprehensive overhaul, with a similar project underway at 20 Giltspur Street. As lease expiries approach for key tenants, including Amazon, the fund is seeking to reduce the carbon footprint of its projects and adapt to changing market demands. This marks a shift from passive ownership to active management, as the fund looks to maintain its presence in the UK property market.

images.alt_text: The highest interest rates in 16 years and a surge in inflation over the past two years has drained consumer finances.

site_title: World’s workers increasingly at risk as climate changes: ILO
summary: The International Labour Organization (ILO) reports that over 70% of the global workforce, or 3.4 billion workers, are at risk of climate-related hazards, resulting in hundreds of thousands of deaths annually. Workers, particularly the poor and those in the informal economy, are more vulnerable to heatwaves, droughts, wildfires, and hurricanes. Governments and employers are struggling to protect employees as climate change accelerates, and the ILO plans a 2025 meeting to provide policy guidance on climate hazards.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Malawian subsistence farmer carries a bag of fertilizer near the capital Lilongwe, Malawi February 1, 2016. REUTERS/Mike Hutchings/File Photo
An Australian gold mine collapsed, killing one miner and resulting in a major rescue operation which freed 29 workers who were trapped underground, March 13, 2024.
A Chinese worker who was injured in the explosion at a nickel smelter furnace is brought to the Morowali Regional General Hospital in Central Sulawesi, Indonesia, Dec 24, 2023.
The workplace is a new battlefront against domestic violence, argues SCWO CEO Koh Yan Ping.
Industries such as construction bear the brunt of workplace injuries, with accidents in this sector accounting for a significant portion of work-related fatalities and injuries.

site_title: Saudi PIF merges mobile tower firms to create regional giant
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) will create a regional mobile tower giant by merging its majority-owned Saudi Telecom's tower unit, Tawal, with Golden Lattice Investment. The new entity, valued at approximately $3.15 billion, will own 54% of the venture, with Saudi Telecom holding 43%. The PIF will invest 533 million riyals in the new entity's capital to maintain ownership. The merged company will manage a portfolio of 30,000 towers across five countries, aiming to potentially list on the local stock exchange and raise new sources of cash for Crown Prince Mohammed Salman's economic transformation.

images.alt_text: The state-backed firm’s Tawal infrastructure arm will pay cash for a portfolio of more than 4,800 towers in Bulgaria, Croatia and Slovenia.

site_title: Tencent shares climb most in months as blockbuster debuts early
summary: Tencent Holdings shares rose 5.3% after the company fast-tracked the release of Nexon's mobile game "Dungeon & Fighter (DnF) Mobile" in China, setting a May 21 debut date. The game is expected to refresh Tencent's gaming pipeline and draw in new users. Analysts predict the game could generate six billion yuan in revenue annually, helping to turn around Tencent's gaming revenue in the second quarter of 2024. The move is seen as a positive development for Tencent's games revenue in the second and third quarters of 2024.

images.alt_text: The Palworld mania has not gone unnoticed by other games makers.
Tencent says revenue reached 155.19 billion yuan (S$29 billion) for the three months ended Dec 31.
Tencent Music Entertainment reports revenue of 6.89 billion yuan (S$1.3 billion) for the quarter.
The company has made strides with so-called mini-games  and a livestreaming video platform that competes with TikTok’s local language service in China.

site_title: South Korea’s early exports rise as momentum remains strong
summary: South Korea's exports showed a 11.1% increase in the first 20 days of April, with semiconductor shipments rising 43% from a year earlier. This growth is attributed to the nation's strong high-tech product industry, particularly AI-driven developments. The momentum in exports has also been felt in other parts of Asia. A trade shortfall of $2.6 billion resulted from increased imports, which rose 6.1%. The Bank of Korea is set to release first-quarter GDP statistics, with economists estimating a 2.5% year-on-year expansion.

images.alt_text: Bank of Korea governor Rhee Chang-yong says that the exchange rate deviated a little bit from what could be justified by market fundamentals.
The won extended declines against the dollar to hit the lowest in a year and a half.

site_title: Intraco scraps acquisition of 51% stake in digital asset platform
summary: Intraco is terminating its proposed acquisition of a 51% stake in digital asset platform MHC Digital due to a clause not being fulfilled. The condition was for MHC to achieve a 12-month consolidated group net profit after tax of at least S$18.5 million within 24 months of the acquisition agreement. The transaction, valued at S$47.2 million, was contingent on this condition being met. All parties have agreed to terminate the acquisition and not pursue any claims against each other.

images.alt_text: Institutions are net buyers of Singapore stocks over the four trading sessions through to Jan 4, with S$90 million of net institutional inflow, as 15 primary-listed companies conducted buybacks with a total consideration of S$1.3 million.
Jadason Enterprises will have to meet requirements under Rule 1314(1) of the Listing Manual to be removed from the watch-list within 36 months from Jun 6.
Intraco to raise S$4.5m from share placement for expansion and MHC Digital Group investment
Intraco disposes 41.27% stake in Dynamic Colours for S$19.5m

site_title: Raimondo says Huawei’s chip breakthrough is years behind US tech
summary: US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo stated that Huawei's latest phone, powered by a homegrown 7-nanometre chip, shows China remains behind in cutting-edge chip technology, contrary to the company's claims of a breakthrough. Raimondo attributed this to the Biden administration's success in imposing export controls on China, indicating the US has successfully halted China's advances in chip technology.

images.alt_text: The Pro and Ultra versions were out of stock at Huawei’s official online store just a minute after the sales started.
FILE PHOTO: Smartphones are displayed in Huawei's first global flagship store in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, China October 30, 2019. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: MAS issues 12-year prohibition order against former Manulife representative for cheating
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) issued a 12-year prohibition order against former Manulife representative Ong Ka Yong for cheating 25 victims out of more than S$1.2 million between 2020 and 2021. Ong was convicted of 11 counts of cheating and sentenced to 47 months imprisonment. The MAS deemed Ong unfit to provide financial advisory services due to his dishonest actions. The prohibition order prohibits Ong from participating in management or providing advisory services at any financial advisory firm.

site_title: Volkswagen to face investors sceptical of China turnaround plan
summary: Volkswagen faces skepticism from investors regarding its plan to turn around its business in China, after being leapfrogged by BYD as the nation's top carmaker. The company expects to regain market share by 2026, but its stock has fallen 13% since CEO Oliver Blume took over in 2022. Analysts question whether Volkswagen can convince investors that the negative trend can be halted, citing a lack of affordable EV models and declining profitability at its joint ventures in China. Despite some brokers recommending a "buy" rating, the outlook remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: The vote marks the latest big win for Shawn Fain, who was sworn in as the United Auto Workers' president in March 2023.
FILE PHOTO: People walk past an ID. Store X showroom of SAIC Volkswagen in Chengdu, Sichuan province, China January 10, 2021. Picture taken January 10, 2021. REUTERS/Yilei Sun
Volkswagen says the Hefei site would help bring technologies to market around 30 per cent faster as the carmaker boosts electric vehicle production there.

site_title: Vietnam set to launch new stocks trading system in bid for market upgrade
summary: Vietnam is set to launch a new stocks trading system on May 2, which will speed up transaction settlement and facilitate trading, particularly short selling. The move is part of reforms aimed at upgrading the country's stock market and attracting foreign investors. The new system, provided by the Korea Exchange, will handle transactions within a day, boosting the chances of Vietnam being reclassified as an emerging market. Successful completion of the reforms could lead to upgrades by the MSCI and FTSE indices, potentially triggering $5-25 billion in net inflows to the market by the end of the decade.

site_title: EU aims to increase food exports to China despite trade tensions
summary: The European Union aims to increase its food exports to China despite ongoing trade tensions between the two countries. EU Agriculture Commissioner Janusz Wojciechowski stated his intention to avoid agricultural products paying the costs of trade disputes in other sectors. China is the EU's only major trading partner where the EU runs an export surplus, with the EU exporting more food than it imports from China. Wojciechowski's visit to China aims to strengthen trade relations and promote EU agricultural exports.

images.alt_text: Shipping containers at a port in eastern China's Jiangsu province. While Germany's overall imports from China dropped by nearly 20 per cent between 2022 and 2023, Germany’s dependence in areas such as pharmaceuticals and rare earths has increased.
The EU’s approach aligns with some Western allies, who are taking a firmer stance with Beijing.
Beijing’s focus on local and state-oriented procurement in medical technologies has increased in recent years.

site_title: Global military spending climbed 7% in 2023 amid conflicts
summary: Global military spending increased 7% in 2023 to $2.43 trillion, the largest annual rise since 2009, as international conflicts worsened. The top 10 spenders, including the US, China, and Russia, all increased their military spending. This rise in military spending is attributed to a deteriorating security landscape, with experts warning of an "action-reaction spiral." The Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI) attributed the increase to states prioritizing military strength in a volatile geopolitical environment.

images.alt_text: While there are more than plausible pathways to escalation in the Russia-Ukraine and Israel-Hamas conflicts, investors and many businesses presently show little to no reaction.

site_title: Vietnam central bank delays gold auction due to lack of interest
summary: Vietnam's central bank, the State Bank of Vietnam, has delayed its first gold auction in 11 years due to lack of interest from buyers. The auction, initially set for Monday, was rescheduled for Tuesday. The central bank aims to increase gold supplies amid a 15% surge in gold prices this year. Local businesses have urged the SBV to amend regulations to stabilize prices. The government has also been investigating gold trading firms for possible market manipulation amid soaring domestic prices.

site_title: Cordlife directors file court application against company to cancel private placement
summary: Cordlife directors, including a controlling shareholder and two non-independent non-executive directors, have filed a court application to cancel the company's private placement of S$8.2 million in new shares. The directors claim the placement contravenes Section 157 of the Companies Act 1967 and request an interim injunction to restrain the company from issuing new shares. This comes amid ongoing investigations by the Commercial Affairs Department, following the arrest of several directors and the former CEO.

site_title: Chinese banks hold lending rates with yuan under pressure
summary: China's benchmark lending rates remained unchanged at 3.45% and 3.95% for one-year and five-year loans, respectively. The decision follows the central bank's recent decision to maintain monetary policy, amid a struggling economy and weak consumer confidence. The yuan faces renewed depreciation pressure due to sticky US inflation and capital flight. China's cash withdrawal from the banking system for a second consecutive month signals caution towards monetary easing, and economists expect more stimulus to be needed to reach the 5% annual growth target.

images.alt_text: Chinese policymakers already battling a protracted property crisis and weak demand at home have scant incentive to escalate tensions.

site_title: URA releases reserve list site in Zion Road after developer commits to bid at least S$604.6 million
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has released a Zion Road site for sale after receiving a bid of at least S$604.6 million from a developer. The site, which can yield around 610 new private homes, is about 10% under the S$1,080 psf ppr minimum offer of a recently sold neighboring site. This launch follows URA's sale of a larger neighboring site last week, awarded to a joint venture at S$1.1 billion or S$1,202 psf ppr.

images.alt_text: Together, the sites potentially yield 730 residential units.
The former Singapore Restricted Passport Centre at the now-vacant 240 Outram Road.

site_title: Indonesia’s March trade surplus beats estimates, posting its largest in over a year
summary: Indonesia posted its largest trade surplus in over a year in March, exceeding expectations with a surplus of US$4.47 billion, driven by a 12.76% decline in imports and a 4.19% decline in exports. The decline in imports was attributed to reduced activity during Ramadan and uncertainty over the presidential election outcome. The country's exports saw an uptick, fueled by rising demand from China, while imports declined across several categories, including capital goods. The trade surplus is expected to spur foreign currency inflows, strengthening the rupiah, but analysts predict it may narrow again in the coming months.

images.alt_text: The two rivals of Defence Minister and former special forces commander Prabowo Subianto (pictured) have both asked the Constitutional Court to disqualify him from a contest he won by a huge margin, arguing widespread distribution of social aid in key areas had swayed the vote in his favour.
The expansion line from Bundaran Hotel Indonesia to Kota station is slated to open in 2029, and will cut travelling time.

The Indonesian rupiah breached the key 16,000 level to the US dollar on April 11, falling further beyond 16,200 to the greenback on April 16.

site_title: Oil prices ease as Iran-Israel tensions ease
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday, with Brent futures dropping 67 cents to $86.62 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude falling 64 cents to $82.50 a barrel. The decline was attributed to eased tensions between Israel and Iran, as well as a focus on market fundamentals. The US Federal Reserve's hawkish stance and a large build-up in US crude inventories also contributed to the price drop.

site_title: Russian bought S$88m of gold from dealer in Changi to launder funds for Ukraine invasion
summary: A Russian national, Feliks Medvedev, has been charged with money laundering and operating an unlicensed money transmitting business in the US, involving over US$150 million in illicit funds. He used this money to buy over US$65 million worth of gold from a Singaporean precious metals dealer, Singapore Precious Metals Exchange (SGPMX), at Le Freeport in Changi. The funds were allegedly laundered to fund Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Medvedev pleaded guilty to the charges in February and is expected to be sentenced on May 7.

site_title: Chinese property tycoon faces payment demands on overdue loans
summary: Chinese property tycoon Chen Hongtian and his wife face demands from banks to repay over $200 million in overdue loans, with each providing personal guarantees. The loans, totaling $138.8 million, are for term-loan facilities at Cheung Kei Group, which has lost $1.4 billion worth of properties to creditors. The company's liquidity issues have been exacerbated by an ongoing downturn in office markets worldwide, with sales plans for a London office tower shelved. The defendants have 14 days to respond to the demands or contest the proceedings.

images.alt_text: Two stalled sales in London’s office market are a sign of its stultified nature, amid higher interest rates and concerns around a trend towards hybrid working.

site_title: Gold edges down as rising bond yields dent appeal
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $2,381.36 per ounce, weighed down by rising US Treasury yields, which made non-yielding bullion less attractive for investors. Higher interest rates were cited as a key risk to financial stability, with the Federal Reserve's latest survey citing stalled progress on bringing down inflation. Despite this, copper, gold, and other metals are expected to rise further due to robust Chinese demand and macro uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Last year, China’s gold jewellery demand rose 10 per cent while bar and coin investments surged 28 per cent.

site_title: 11 missing, tens of thousands evacuated as storms strike south China
summary: Storms in southern China have left 11 people missing and over 53,000 evacuated due to heavy rain and flooding, with fears of "once a century" floods. The province of Guangdong, home to 127 million people, has been severely affected, with over 45,000 people relocated from the city of Qingyuan. Heavy rain is expected to continue, with thunderstorms and strong winds forecast for the region. The floods are part of a larger pattern of extreme weather events in China, exacerbated by climate change.

site_title: Asia: Markets bounce as Middle East fears ease, US inflation in view
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, recovering from last week's losses, as Middle East tensions eased and traders awaited US inflation data. Despite a negative lead from Wall Street, where the Nasdaq shed over 2% due to tech giant selling, Asian stocks rebounded. The easing of tensions between Iran and Israel, and a decline in oil prices, contributed to the gains. Traders are now focused on US inflation data and corporate earnings, which could impact market sentiment.

site_title: Thailand says China’s Chery Automobile to set up manufacturing plant
summary: Thailand's Board of Investment announced that Chery Automobile, a Chinese automaker, will set up a manufacturing plant in the country. Production is expected to begin in 2025, with the facility initially producing 50,000 electric and hybrid vehicles per year, increasing to 80,000 by 2028. This marks the eighth Chinese automaker to establish a plant in Thailand, as the country aims to convert about a third of its annual vehicle production into electric vehicles by 2030.

site_title: AEM’s thermal engine selected for fabless provider’s system-level test insertions
summary: AEM's thermal engine has been selected by a major fabless provider for system-level test insertions, with initial deliveries scheduled for FY2024. The thermal engine is designed for high-volume manufacturing and excludes traditional cooling fluids, catering to evolving test needs. This marks a significant milestone for AEM's active thermal control solutions, which are expected to support AI devices with high-power thermal demands. AEM's CEO notes that this recognition underscores the company's commitment to innovation and customer-centricity.

images.alt_text: Semiconductor companies in Singapore supply equipment makers instead of foundries, which could limit any impact from disruptions caused by the Taiwan earthquake.

site_title: Egypt reclaims 3,400-year-old stolen statue of King Ramses II
summary: Egypt has reclaimed a 3,400-year-old statue of King Ramses II, stolen over three decades ago from the Ramses II temple in Abydos, Egypt. The statue, depicting the head of the pharaoh, was discovered being sold in London in 2013 and later moved to Switzerland. Egyptian authorities collaborated with Swiss authorities to establish rightful ownership, and the statue was handed over to Egypt last year, where it is currently stored in the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, awaiting restoration.
