site_title: BT Podcasts: Future-proof your life with disability insurance
summary: Financial experts Edwin Wee from Great Eastern and Cynthia Chng from the Agency for Integrated Care discuss the importance of disability insurance, highlighting the significant financial costs associated with disability in Singapore, including caregiving and medical expenses. They also emphasize the need for advance care planning and creating an advance care plan to prepare for future healthcare needs.

images.alt_text: David Yip (right), head of accident and health business at Great Eastern and Willis Lau (left), Great Eastern financial representative and financial influencer speak to us about the importance of having disability insurance.

site_title: ComfortDelGro takes out S$100 million green loan to decarbonise UK bus fleet
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore-based transport operator, has secured a S$100 million green loan to replace its UK bus fleet with electric buses. The move aims to reduce carbon dioxide equivalent tailpipe emissions by 9,900 tonnes annually. The loan will be used to purchase 135 electric buses for Metroline, its UK subsidiary, consisting of 77 double-deck and 58 single-deck vehicles. The transition is expected to significantly reduce emissions and align with the company's sustainability goals.

images.alt_text: The contracts, awarded by the Greater Manchester Combined Authority, come with options to be extended for two one-year terms.
ComfortDelGro head office located along Braddell Road on Nov 25, 2021.
ComfortDelGro's profit after taxation and minority interests increased 30.4 per cent for the first quarter of 2022. Taxi revenue fell 11.2 per cent year on year to S$106.3 million.

site_title: Magnificent Seven earnings arrive with stocks at critical moment
summary: The Magnificent Seven tech giants, including Microsoft, Meta Platforms, Alphabet, and Tesla, are set to report earnings next week, with profits forecast to rise 38% in the first quarter from a year ago. This could provide an artificial intelligence (AI) powered rebound for the S&P 500 Index, which has suffered its worst week in over a year. However, some investors are skeptical about the group's ability to deliver growth, citing concerns about AI plans and valuations. Despite this, analysts expect the group's earnings growth to outpace the rest of the S&P 500, with the Magnificent Seven firms expected to post earnings growth of 17.5% in 2025, compared to 18% for the rest of the index.

images.alt_text: Nvidia has pulled away from the rest of the Magnificent Seven as it transforms hype into stratospheric sales and profits.
Generative AI is likely to touch all areas of the economy, and productivity is likely to be enhanced across many industries.

site_title: Europe suffered record number of ‘extreme heat stress’ days in 2023: monitors
summary: Europe experienced a record number of "extreme heat stress" days in 2023, according to climate monitors Copernicus and the UN's World Meteorological Organization. The extreme heat stress index, which measures the effect of heat on the human body, reached 46°C, prompting health risks such as heat stroke. The consequences of heat stress were particularly severe, with billions of dollars in damages and over 2 million people impacted. Europe saw scorching heatwaves, catastrophic flooding, and violent storms, with the warmest September on record, and a significant increase in heat-related deaths, estimated to be tens of thousands.

site_title: Telemedicine platforms evolve beyond virtual consultations
summary: Telemedicine startups in South-east Asia are expanding beyond virtual consultations, with some investing in physical assets or partnering with healthcare players. Following the COVID-19 pandemic, the industry gained traction as consumers adopted digital healthcare access. Companies like Doctor Anywhere are investing in health screening facilities with private pods, differentiating themselves from competitors. This shift aims to capture more value in the healthcare ecosystem, driven by the growing demand for convenient and personalized care.

images.alt_text: Bryan Koh, chief executive of WhiteCoat, says the firm aims to grow organically, rather than via mergers and acquisitions of other telehealth firms.

site_title: Malaysia to build region’s largest chip design park in bid for top startup-hub status
summary: Malaysia aims to establish itself as a regional digital hub by building the country's largest integrated circuit (IC) design park in Kuala Lumpur. The initiative, valued at RM3 billion (S$855 million), is part of the country's strategy to shift from back-end chip assembly to high-value front-end design work. The move is aimed at attracting global tech companies and propelling Malaysia into the top 20 global startup hubs by 2030. The country will also offer tax breaks, subsidies, and visa exemption fees to draw in investors and talent.

site_title: Sabana Reit sponsor will not need to abstain from voting on trust deed amendments: SGX RegCo
summary: SGX RegCo rules that Sabana Reit's sponsor, ESR Group, and its related parties do not need to abstain from voting on proposed trust deed amendments. The amendments, aimed at internalizing management, will affect all unitholders, including the sponsor and its related parties. The regulator notes that the amendments are not proposed to benefit any specific unitholder but rather to effect internalization, allowing all unitholders, including ESR Group and its related parties, to vote.

site_title: Destroyed oil tanks at Ukraine facility will take 6 months to rebuild: Wilmar
summary: Wilmar International estimates it will take six months to rebuild its damaged oil tanks in Ukraine, following a Russian missile attack on its Pivdennyi facility. Operations are expected to resume once local authorities clearances are obtained. The incident is not expected to have a material impact on Wilmar's financial results for FY2024.

site_title: World’s largest private firms fail to set climate targets: report
summary: Only 40 of the world's 100 largest private firms have set net-zero carbon emissions targets, lagging behind 70 of 100 publicly-listed companies, according to a report by Net Zero Tracker. The lack of market and reputational pressures on private firms, along with an absence of regulation, is to blame for their slow uptake of climate commitments. The report's findings come as the European Union introduces climate regulations that will require thousands of large companies to report their climate impacts and emissions.

site_title: Brokers woo ‘snowball’ buyers with 40% returns after China stock market rout
summary: Chinese brokerages are offering near-record-high returns of up to 40% on derivatives, known as "snowball" products, to lure investors back into the market after a stock market rout earlier this year. The products, which pay investors bond-like coupons, were previously available at 10-20% returns. Brokerages are also revising product structures to meet changing risk appetite, including issuing products with lower knock-in thresholds and monthly dividend-paying "phoenix" products. The move comes as brokerages face huge profitability pressures due to hedging losses and intensifying price competition.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Monday’s open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% at the opening bell on Monday, driven by a gain in the Straits Times Index (STI) to 3,180.07. The broader market saw 79 advancers and 36 decliners, with Seatrium and Genting Singapore being the most traded counters. Banking stocks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also showed gains, despite DBS opening 9.5% lower due to a bonus share restructuring. Global markets were subdued, with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 closing in the red on Friday.

images.alt_text: DBS is selling a portfolio of 46 HDB shop and shophouse units and private strata retail units.

site_title: Negotiations on global plastic treaty to resume in Canada
summary: Negotiations for a global plastic treaty, aimed at ending plastic pollution, will resume in Ottawa, Canada, from Tuesday with 175 countries involved. The talks, which began in 2022, have made progress but face challenges, including disagreements over the treaty's scope and environmental non-governmental organizations' concerns about a lack of firm progress. The goal is to achieve a text with 60-70% of the elements endorsed by delegates, with a deadline of April 29. The treaty's success hinges on resolving issues such as plastic production reduction, recycling, and banning problematic products, with the US, China, and Saudi Arabia among countries reluctant to consider production cuts.

site_title: Hong Kong bankers face more job cuts on China slowdown, high pay
summary: Hong Kong investment bankers face potential job cuts due to a slowdown in China deals and high pay, according to a Bloomberg Intelligence report. An estimated 200 Hong Kong bankers lost their jobs in the past year, with global financial firms cutting staff in Asia amid a deal drought. The city's initial public offerings (IPOs) have been depressed, with proceeds slumping to the lowest in over two decades, and US-China relations deteriorating. More job cuts are expected, especially in the investment banking sector, as employers look to trim highly compensated staff.

site_title: Parental fury after stem cell bank ruins thousands of samples in Singapore
summary: A Singapore-based cord blood bank, Cordlife, has damaged thousands of samples of cord blood, rendering them unusable for potential future medical treatments. The incident has sparked outrage among parents who paid thousands of dollars to store their children's stem cells, with some considering legal action. The company has offered a small refund, but many parents feel it's inadequate. The incident has raised concerns about the industry's oversight and the high cost of investigations. The Singapore Ministry of Health is conducting further tests to determine the extent of the damage, with many medical organizations questioning the use of private cord blood banking.

site_title: China braces for worst as it becomes punching bag in US election
summary: China is bracing for a potential economic backlash from the US election, with President Xi Jinping's government showing restraint despite being targeted by President Joe Biden's campaign. Beijing resisted escalating tensions, including after Biden vowed to triple tariffs on Chinese steel and aluminum exports and Washington launched a probe into China's shipbuilding sector. Chinese stocks in the industry plummeted, and Congress fast-tracked efforts to force TikTok to divest from its Chinese parent ByteDance. China's policymakers are unlikely to escalate tensions, given their own economic struggles, including a protracted property crisis and weak demand.

China’s nominal GDP growth rate of 4.2 per cent in the first quarter was considerably below the real growth rate, mainly dragged down by weak prices.
Total air passenger traffic reached almost 180 million trips in the first three months of 2024.

site_title: Ecosperity at year 10: It’s time to get serious
summary: Global players at the 10th Ecosperity sustainability conference emphasized the urgent need for action and implementation on climate action, despite available technologies and financing structures. However, progress is slow, with the world not on track to meet the Paris Agreement's 1.5°C target. Key challenges include the need for governments to set the right policy framework, and the private sector's reluctance to take on risk due to high interest rates and perceived risks in emerging markets. The public sector faces mounting challenges, including rising populism and nationalism, making it difficult to implement ambitious climate plans, and philanthropists and private investors are not yet ready to step up with risk capital.

images.alt_text: Temasek CEO said lawyers will be integral in shaping governance standards and legal frameworks for ESG.

site_title: Air New Zealand trims annual earnings outlook on ‘challenging’ economic conditions
summary: Air New Zealand has trimmed its annual earnings outlook for 2024 due to challenging economic conditions and cost-of-living pressures. The airline now expects earnings before taxation between NZ$190 million and NZ$230 million, down from a previous estimate of NZ$200 million to NZ$240 million. The decrease is attributed to softer revenue in domestic and North American markets, impacted by increased competition from US carriers and pricing pressures.

images.alt_text: The expansion to Singapore and New Zealand's Enhanced Partnership, announced by (from left) Luxon and PM Lee, will focus on supply chains and connectivity.
The greener fuel is essential to reduce emissions from long-haul flights, the source of most air-travel pollution, because electric planes do not have sufficient range.
Australia’s biggest businesses are increasingly asking when Qantas will obtain larger quantities of the cleaner-burning fuel.
An LATAM Airlines 787 plane, which was heading from Sydney to Auckland on Monday, dropped abruptly before stabilising, causing those on board to be thrown about the cabin.
Data from airline tracker FlightAware showed the Latam plane lost altitude about two hours into the three-hour flight from Sydney to Auckland.

site_title: High Court allows S$80 million sale of GSM Building to LHN’s Coliwoo
summary: The High Court has approved the sale of the GSM Building to LHN's unit Coliwoo for S$80 million, dismissing objections from minority owners who claimed the price was too low. The court found no evidence of a lack of good faith in the transaction, despite concerns over the committee's dealings with potential buyers and the tender period. The sale will see unit owners receive between S$774,378 and S$12,948,410 for each unit, with Coliwoo planning to convert the building into serviced apartments.

images.alt_text: The GSM Building has a total land area of 1,115.1 square metres, with a tenure of 99 years starting from May 2, 1978.

site_title: Singapore dollar outshines peers with 40% advance under PM Lee
summary: Singapore's stock market and local currency have outperformed peers under Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's 20-year rule, with the Singapore dollar rising 40% against major trading partners and government bonds outpacing global peers by 16 percentage points. The city-state's economy has more than doubled in size to S$532.3 billion, and its stock market has outperformed regional peers by nearly 32 percentage points. As PM Lee steps down, his successor Lawrence Wong will inherit a robust economy and assets, including a strong currency and sovereign debt, with scope for further support of local equities.

site_title: Australia to cut key global economy growth forecasts in budget
summary: Australia's Treasury Department will cut growth forecasts for major economies, including China, in its upcoming budget. Treasurer Jim Chalmers attributed the move to global uncertainty and lingering inflation concerns. China's economic expansion is expected to be around 4% this year and in 2025-2026, the weakest period since the late 1970s. Japan's 2024 growth forecast was lowered to 0.75% following weaker-than-expected consumption figures. Australia is on track for a second consecutive surplus in its budget, set to be released in less than four weeks.

site_title: Elon Musk’s robotaxi dreams plunge Tesla into chaos
summary: Elon Musk has ordered Tesla's largest layoffs ever, staking the company's future on a next-generation, self-driving vehicle concept called the robotaxi. The move comes amid slumping sales, confusing product decisions, and price cuts, resulting in a 40% plunge in operating profit and the company's first revenue decline in four years. Key managers, including Drew Baglino, have left the company, and Musk is prioritizing the robotaxi over a cheaper car project. The company's stock has slid 40% amid concerns about its strategy and Musk's leadership style.

images.alt_text: The EV maker has been slow to refresh its ageing models as high interest rates have sapped consumer appetite for big-ticket items.
Musk says: “If you’re trying to make a perfect product, then attention to detail is essential.”

South African businessman Elon Musk arrives at the Tenth Breakthrough Prize Ceremony at the Academy Museum of Motion Pictures in Los Angeles, California, on April 13, 2024. (Photo by ETIENNE LAURENT / AFP)
Musk, who runs six companies, said early this year he preferred to work on artificial intelligence and robotics products elsewhere unless he owns a 25 per cent stake in Tesla.
Tesla shares are the second-biggest decliner on the S&P 500 Index in 2024, erasing about US$290 billion in shareholder wealth.

Few Chinese-made EVs are sold in the US market, where they already face steep tariffs.

site_title: Dimon meets with development bank leaders seeking private money
summary: Jamie Dimon, CEO of JPMorgan Chase, met with executives from the World Bank Group and other multilateral development lenders to discuss redirecting private capital towards emerging markets and supporting development-focused projects. The meeting aimed to increase private investment in climate-related projects and was seen as an effort by the US to counter China's growing influence in development funding. Dimon and the lenders discussed risk-sharing and increasing access to private debt markets, with a focus on supporting emerging economies.

images.alt_text: Jamie Dimon likened the emerging technology to the “printing press, the steam engine, electricity, computing and the Internet.”
The issuance spree has helped to generate US$699 million of debt-underwriting revenue for Goldman Sachs Group in the first quarter.
A sign for JPMorgan Chase & Co. is displayed near the sidewalk outside their Park Avenue office building in New York, U.S., on Friday, October 7, 2016. Mark Kauzlarich/Bloomberg

site_title: South-east Asia’s sinking currencies raise spectre of ’97/98 financial crisis
summary: Southeast Asian currencies have plummeted, with the Indonesian rupiah hitting a four-year low and the Thai baht experiencing its largest year-to-date loss, amid a strong US dollar fueled by inflation and geopolitical tensions. However, experts believe the situation is not comparable to the 1997-1998 Asian financial crisis, citing improved regional economic fundamentals, stronger central banks, and more flexible exchange rates. While a crisis is unlikely, currency fluctuations may continue until the US dollar weakens, driven by factors such as US interest rate cuts, moderate oil prices, and softening global risk premiums.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue
The Thai baht has fallen some 5 per cent against the US dollar to a range of 36 per greenback.
The Vietnamese dong registered a year-to-date drop of about 3 per cent.
Ringgit, despite depreciating 0.55 per cent for the past 5 days, is not the worst performing currency in the Asia region.

site_title: Tesla cuts prices in China, Germany, and around globe after US cuts
summary: Tesla cuts prices in China, Germany, and globally after US price cuts, following its first quarterly decline in vehicle deliveries. The carmaker lowered US prices of Model Y, Model X, and Model S by $2,000, and China prices of the revamped Model 3 by 14,000 yuan. This move comes amid a price war for electric vehicles, particularly against cheaper Chinese EVs, and as Tesla grapples with falling sales and inventory. The company has also announced plans to lay off over 10% of its workforce and has postponed its India trip, citing obligations at Tesla.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk has ordered Tesla’s biggest layoffs ever and staked its future on a next-generation, self-driving vehicle concept called the robotaxi.
The price of the Model 3 appears to be unchanged.
Musk, who runs six companies, said early this year he preferred to work on artificial intelligence and robotics products elsewhere unless he owns a 25 per cent stake in Tesla.
Tesla shares are the second-biggest decliner on the S&P 500 Index in 2024, erasing about US$290 billion in shareholder wealth.

site_title: TikTok says US House bill that could ban app would ‘trample’ free speech
summary: The US House of Representatives has passed a bill that could ban the popular social media app TikTok in the US if its Chinese owner ByteDance sells its stake within a year. The bill, which has been approved by a margin of 360 to 58, now moves to the Senate for a potential vote. TikTok has expressed concerns that the bill would "trample" free speech rights, stating it has never shared US data and never would. The American Civil Liberties Union also opposes the bill on free speech grounds, citing the potential for national security risks and a violation of the First Amendment.

images.alt_text: The House-passed TikTok legislation has support from data privacy and national security hawks concerned about troves of data on American users.
The successful rollout of TikTok Shop in markets like the US and South-east Asia have unlocked new revenue sources for ByteDance.
With European elections approaching in June, mainstream politicians are wary of ceding ground to fringe parties who have successfully exploited its short video format.

site_title: Indonesia court to rule on petitions seeking presidential election re-run
summary: An Indonesian Constitutional Court is set to rule on two petitions challenging the outcome of February's presidential election, in which Prabowo Subianto won by a significant margin. The losing candidates, Anies Baswedan and Ganjar Pranowo, claim widespread distribution of social aid influenced the vote in Prabowo's favor and alleged tacit support from President Joko Widodo gave him an unfair advantage. The court's decision could result in a re-run of the election or disqualification of Prabowo and his running mate, Gibran Rakabuming Raka.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s track record of fiscal discipline will continue, thus supporting a stabilisation in the debt burden around current levels., according to Moody's report.

During their meeting on Wednesday, Kishida (R) “stated that Japan attached great importance to cooperation with Indonesia in maintaining and strengthening the free and open international order based on the rule of law”.
Chinese President Xi Jinping and Indonesia's President-elect Prabowo Subianto shake hands at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China April 1, 2024.

Defence Minister Prabowo and his vice-presidential running mate Gibran Rakabuming Raka received more than 96 million votes, roughly 58.6 per cent of the total count and enough to secure a first-round majority.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for March 28, 2025, highlights market trends in the tanker and dry bulk sectors. Key points include:

- The Capesize market softened, with the BCI 5TC declining from $22,311 to $20,503.
- The Panamax market saw sizeable gains, with NC South America driving demand for transatlantic cargo.
- Ultramax and Supramax markets remained steady, with limited period activity and cautious approach due to political uncertainty.
- Handysize markets showed mixed performance, with stability in the Continent and Mediterranean, but slow fundamentals in the South Atlantic and US Gulf.
- Clean market rates declined, with MEG LR2 freight dropping modestly.
- MR freight saw an upturn in the US Gulf, while MR Atlantic Triangulation Basket TCE increased.
- Suezmax rates recovered in the Atlantic, with the TD27 route increasing by 6 points.
- Aframax markets saw significant gains, particularly in the Mediterranean.
- LNG market declined, with most routes seeing a drop in rates.
- LPG market also declined, with rates falling across all routes.

images.alt_text: The Capesize market experienced a week of gradual strengthening, with positive momentum building (Mar 21, 2025).

site_title: Japan’s historic stock market rally expected to continue despite current pullback
summary: Japan's stock market is expected to continue its historic rally despite a recent pullback, with the Nikkei 225 Index Futures contract projected to conclude 2024 between 42,500 and 43,600. The index's tech-heavy composition, accounting for 50.27% of its weight, is expected to benefit from the growing AI and semiconductor industries. Structural drivers, including improved corporate profits and wage growth, remain unchanged, making Japanese equities attractive despite near-term weakness due to geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: People check their phones next to an electronic board showing a share price of the Nikkei index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on March 19, 2024. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)

site_title: UK’s wealthy boost property asking prices by most in 12 months
summary: UK property asking prices rose 1.7% in the past year, the highest annual pace in 12 months, driven by more large homes coming to market. The average asking price reached £372,324, just £570 shy of record levels in May 2023. The top-of-the-ladder sector, including large homes, is driving price growth, while lower segments remain less buoyant due to high borrowing costs and affordability concerns. The UK property market is showing signs of renewed activity, but buyers may pause their search in summer due to vacation plans and potential election uncertainty.

According to the latest ONS figures, the UK economy shrank by 0.3% percent for the final three months of last year.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

Crowds of shoppers on Oxford Street in London, UK, on Monday, Dec. 18, 2023. The Office for National Statistics are due to release the latest UK retail sales figures on Friday. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Former Pearl’s Hill School, Restricted Passport Centre in Outram set to make way for new homes
summary: Historic buildings in Singapore's Pearl's Hill area are set to be demolished to make way for new housing developments. The former Singapore Restricted Passport Centre and Pearl's Hill School will be cleared to build 6,000 new homes over the next decade. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has proposed amendments to its master plan, which includes three housing sites and a white site for mixed-use development. The developments aim to support housing demand and provide proximity to amenities and transport nodes. Residents and alumni have expressed concerns about the loss of historical buildings, with some suggesting they be retained and repurposed.

images.alt_text: GSM Building at 141 Middle Road.

site_title: Blackstone makes rival US$1.5 billion bid for troubled Hipgnosis
summary: US asset manager Blackstone has made a US$1.5 billion takeover bid for UK music rights owner Hipgnosis Songs Fund, surpassing rival Concord's offer of US$1.4 billion. The bid, valued at US$1.24 per share, proposes to acquire Hipgnosis' entire song catalogue, including works by Justin Bieber, Shakira, and Neil Young. The London-listed fund has been plagued by concerns over asset valuations and recently slashed the value of its songs catalogue by over a quarter. Hipgnosis has accepted the rival bid, and shares surged 30% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the Blackstone Group headquarters in New York City, U.S., January 18, 2023. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon/File Photo

site_title: 'Harvesting data': Latin American AI startups transform farming
summary: Latin American AI startups are transforming the farming industry by using data analysis and machine learning to boost yields and returns. Companies like Traive, which collects and analyzes agriculture-related data, and TerraFirma, which uses AI to forecast environmental risks, are working with farmers and agro-industry giants to provide easier access to credit and more efficient farming practices. The use of AI in agriculture has the potential to reshape the industry and help meet the world's growing food demand while reducing environmental destruction.

images.alt_text: Peptobiotics intends to use its fresh funds to produce larger commercial volumes.

Muhammad Yoga Anindito, co-founder and chief executive officer of Semaai says collaborations with fintech companies serve to address disruptions in the supply chain and narrow information gaps for Indonesia’s agri-retailers and smallholder farmers.

site_title: WealthBT: This can make or break your retirement (Ep 37)
summary: Christopher Tan, founder of advisory firm Providend, shares that contentment is key to a successful retirement, not just good investing and financial planning. He emphasizes the importance of sufficiency and contentment in achieving a fulfilling life. Tan also highlights the need to avoid common mistakes, such as not having a personal relationship with money, and to plan for retirement regardless of market factors. His retirement roadmap includes a focus on contentment and sufficiency.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Wilmar, Sheng Siong, Sabana Reit, Cordlife, Soup Holdings
summary: DBS is selling a portfolio of 46 HDB shop and shophouse units and private strata retail units with a total guide price of about S$210 million. Wilmar International confirmed its 80%-owned subsidiary's tank terminal facility was hit by a missile last Friday, with an estimated 6-month rebuild period. Sheng Siong's shareholders are seeking more details on mergers and acquisitions and capital allocation priorities. Sabana Reit's proposed trust deed amendments will not affect its sponsor and related parties. Cordlife Group has obtained an interim injunction to restrain the issuance of new shares.

images.alt_text: A man walks past a huge anti-Israeli banner, in Teheran on Apr 19. Early indications after reports of explosions in the Iranian city of Isfahan were that Iran was downplaying Israel's retaliation.

site_title: ‘Civil War’ stays on top at North American box office
summary: "Civil War," starring Kirsten Dunst, held the top spot at the North American box office for the second week, earning an estimated $11.1 million. The film, a dystopian story of a divided America, narrowly surpassed Universal's "Abigail" ($10.2 million) and Warner Bros.' "Godzilla x Kong: The New Empire" ($9.5 million). With a two-week domestic take of $44.9 million, "Civil War" is one of A24's top all-time grossers, uniting both blue and red states.

images.alt_text: 'Civil War' has raked in US$25.7 million in the US and Canada.

Lionsgate had last year agreed to spinoff its studio in a deal valued at about US$4.6 billion, including debt, to create a new public firm for its film and television assets, which include about 18,000 titles.
The US film, television and animation industry employs some 550,000 people.
Australian director George Miller sharing a few early details about 'Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga' at the CinemaCon movie theater convention in Las Vegas on Monday.
“I think Mamma Mia! did change a dynamic. I think it’s earned it’s place in the cultural history of musical theatre,” producer Judy Craymer says.

site_title: Five waves of UBS layoffs to start in June: report
summary: UBS plans to lay off 50-60% of former Credit Suisse staff, totaling 30,000-35,000 jobs globally, in five rounds starting in June. The cost-cutting program aims to save 12 billion Swiss francs ($17.9 billion) and is part of UBS's plan to eliminate around one in 12 of its Swiss jobs. The first round in June will see 25-30% of former Credit Suisse staff made redundant, followed by subsequent rounds in August, September, October, and November.

site_title: Landslides as southern China braces for 'once a century' floods
summary: Severe floods are expected in southern China's Guangdong province, with torrential downpours triggering landslides and flooding in mountainous areas. At least six people were injured and trapped in landslides in the northern town of Jiangwan, and emergency workers are racing to restore communications and assist those in need. Authorities have launched a level-two emergency response, citing the potential for floods seen around once a century, with waters expected to rise up to 5.8 meters above the warning limit starting Monday morning.

images.alt_text: Wind is likely to overtake nuclear as the world’s biggest source of clean energy some time in the next 12 months, says the writer.

site_title: Earnings season kicks off as 27 S-Reits confirm schedule
summary: 27 Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) have confirmed their financial results or business updates for the first quarter ended March 31, 2024. Sabana Industrial Reit reported a 23.7% increase in rental reversion, while Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit saw a 0.8% decline in net property income due to higher financing costs. Institutional investors net sold S$548 million worth of S-Reits, while retail investors continued to net buy the sector. The sector's performance is influenced by the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange (SGX).

site_title: To award or not to award, what is the question?
summary: Singapore's government land tenders have seen lower-than-expected bids and poor participation, potentially leading to a decrease in housing supply. The Marina Gardens Crescent parcel, for instance, would have yielded 775 residential units. If this pattern continues, it could put upward pressure on home prices and rents, contradicting the government's intention to temper rising home prices by increasing supply. Weak participation in state land tenders needs to be addressed to avoid a housing supply squeeze.

images.alt_text: Recent reports have cast a positive light on Singapore’s office market, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
In the public housing sector, market forces appear to be regrouping, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
In today’s private housing market, the luxury condominium segment is struggling, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.
Senior correspondent Leslie Yee has been following developments surrounding the push to internalise the management of Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust.

site_title: Soup Holdings reports food safety lapses, intended summons from regulator
summary: Soup Holdings reported five non-compliance cases of food safety regulations and one incident of cockroaches at its Cafe O outlet in 2023, resulting in a letter of intended summons. The company responded to shareholder concerns, stating the disclosure indicates a breach of food safety regulations. However, Soup Holdings said the outlet was not suspended from operating due to being within the 12-demerit-point allowance. The issue was resolved with corrective measures, and the company has not experienced the issue since.

images.alt_text: Soup Restaurant, Jumbo, ABR show financial strength in weathering pandemic

site_title: The Hill @ One-North and The Hillshore sell 43 and 3 units respectively at launch
summary: The Hill @ One-North, a 142-unit 99-year leasehold project, sold 43 units on its first booking day, with an average price of S$2,595 per square foot. The sales rate was described as one of the lowest for the first weekend of launch this year. Analysts attribute the muted sales to cautious market sentiment, easing home sales, and buyers' fatigue, with prices potentially higher than nearby projects. The Hillshore, a freehold development, sold 3 units on its launch day.

images.alt_text: The former Singapore Restricted Passport Centre at the now-vacant 240 Outram Road.

site_title: Chinese developer Landsea misses offshore notes redemption
summary: Chinese property developer Landsea Green Management missed a deadline to redeem US dollar notes due to liquidity issues, citing slow sales and a significant decline in pre-sales volume and collection of pre-sale proceeds in 2022 and 2023. The company has joined a growing list of developers facing liquidity problems due to the sustained fall in China's property market. Landsea is in discussions with note holders and will consider all possible actions to address the situation, which may involve accelerating debt repayments.

images.alt_text: Instead of buying land and owning projects from scratch, a growing number of Chinese property developers has begun providing construction services as contractors.

site_title: Wilmar unit’s Ukraine facility hit by Russian missile, damage to be assessed
summary: Wilmar International's 80% owned subsidiary, Delta Wilmar Ukraine, had its facility in Ukraine's Pivdennyi port hit by a Russian missile attack on Friday. No casualties were reported, and an assessment of the damage is underway after the fire at the facility was put out. Wilmar will provide details of the incident in due course. The company's stock rose 0.6% on Friday following the news.

site_title: UOB eyes concert partnerships with more K-pop, Asian acts
summary: UOB, Singapore's third-largest bank, plans to increase its entertainment sponsorships, focusing on Asia-focused acts to build client relationships and boost tourism. The bank has seen a surge in card spending and customer acquisition through its partnerships with global artists, including Taylor Swift and Ed Sheeran. UOB aims to announce two more partnerships with Asian artistes in the coming weeks, with a focus on offering a diverse range of acts to cater to its wide customer base. The bank expects the trend to remain strong, driven by consumers' willingness to indulge in unique experiences.

site_title: Asking rents down as demand slows and rental listings surge
summary: Singapore's asking rents for private residential properties have declined by 4-6% since the last quarter of 2023, as rental demand eased and supply surged, according to a report by PropertyGuru. The median asking rent rose 27.3% between January 2022 and December 2023, while the median transacted rent rose 35.3% during the same period. However, certain areas like Orchard and River Valley continue to buck the trend, with median rents at S$6,000 per month. Experts predict continued downward pressure on rents, with a possible price correction, as the rental market approaches an inflection point.

site_title: Sustainable financing in South-east Asia must consider SMEs, just transition
summary: Sustainable financing in South-east Asia is crucial for meeting ambitious net-zero targets, but substantial gaps remain. Eight out of 10 Asean member states have pledged to achieve net-zero targets by 2050. To address these gaps, sustainable financing must consider small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and support a just transition. The region's growing focus on energy transition has led to increased investment in sustainable financing, but more needs to be done to ensure a low-carbon and climate-resilient economy.

site_title: F&N looks to increase market reach, build on growth in dairy products
summary: Singapore-listed beverage giant Fraser and Neave (F&N) is shifting its focus towards the regional dairy industry, driven by growth potential and profit margins. The company aims to increase its market share in dairy products, such as juice, yogurt drinks, and milk, through partnerships with farmers' unions and other companies. F&N has a significant presence in countries like Thailand and Malaysia, where it is a major player in the canned milk market. The company's net profit for Q1 jumped 52.9% to S$43.8 million, and its board proposed a final dividend of S$0.04 per share to commemorate its 140th anniversary.

images.alt_text: The company said the manufacturing facility will strengthen its presence in Cambodia and produce sweetened beverage creamer in can and pouch.

site_title: Time to retire the ‘ESG’ label on funds
summary: ESG investing, which combines environmental, social, and governance factors, is losing appeal as investors question its effectiveness and marketing hype. According to Morningstar, US sustainable funds experienced outflows totaling $13 billion in 2023, while global sustainable funds saw their first quarterly outflows in the fourth quarter. Regulators are setting minimum thresholds for fund assets to be managed according to stated ESG/sustainability strategies, and ESG rating agencies are being regulated to enhance transparency and reliability. Research suggests that sustainable funds may not outperform non-sustainable funds, with one study finding that sustainable ETFs underperformed the US market by 0.2% over 10 years.

images.alt_text: Tan Jenn-hui says the just transition is a helpful part of Fidelity’s analytical toolkit, as it helps the manager understand the challenges investee companies face when they undertake their decarbonisation journeys.

site_title: Rewarding CEO, senior executives with OCBC shares helps to foster group spirit: Great Eastern
summary: Great Eastern Holdings (GEH), the insurer, has long rewarded its CEO and senior executives with shares of holding company OCBC Bank, fostering a "One OCBC Group spirit." However, the low liquidity of GEH shares makes this practice "difficult to execute" and affects liquidity further. In 2023, the CEO received nearly 30% of his pay package in OCBC shares. GEH attributed its 21% decline in New Business Embedded Value in 2023 to lower single premium sales, citing the inverted Singapore dollar yield curve.

images.alt_text: The rationale for insurance groups Great Eastern Holdings and United Overseas Inusrance to remain listed on the local bourse is weak.
The Great Eastern logo on the facade of Great Eastern Centre located at Pickering Street on 4 Dec 2019.

Minority shareholders of Great Eastern want to put forward three resolutions, including one to end the practice of Great Eastern paying its executives with OCBC shares.

site_title: Lens on Singapore: Is anyone too young for cancer? (Ep 8)
summary: Singaporeans, particularly younger individuals, are increasingly being diagnosed with cancer. Cancer treatment costs an average $100,000 to $200,000 per year. Experts, including oncologist Dr. Eileen Poon and cancer survivor Pratibha Rai, discuss the rising trend and the challenges of fighting cancer. A discussion on financial preparation for cancer is also highlighted, with DBS' Lorna Tan providing insights on how to prepare for a major illness like cancer. The rising incidence of cancer among younger people in Singapore and globally is a growing concern.

site_title: Digital trade co-operation may be building block for elusive EU-Asean free-trade pact
summary: The European Union (EU) and Asean may announce significant developments in digital trade cooperation by the end of the third quarter, according to Chris Humphrey, executive director of the EU-Asean Business Council. This could lead to a flourishing of EU-Asean trade and investment relations beyond bilateral free-trade agreements. The EU-Asean joint working group on trade and investment has made progress in talks on sectoral cooperation, covering the digital economy, sustainable trade, and supply chain resilience. Humphrey expects a major announcement on region-to-region cooperation at the EU-Asean Economic ministers meeting in September, which could pave the way for an EU-Asean digital trade agreement.

images.alt_text: DPM Wong at a reception for Singaporeans living in France on Thursday – one of many events he attended over the week.
Defa has the potential to boost Asean’s digital economy to US$2 trillion by 2030, doubling the current trajectory.

The European Union currently holds bilateral free trade agreements with Singapore and Vietnam.

Asean flags are seen alongside a flag of Europe at the Asean-EU summit in Brussels on December 14, 2022.

site_title: It will take a village to lift our stock market
summary: The Singapore stock market has been lagging behind the US and Japanese markets, prompting discussions on how to improve its performance. Listed companies, investors, and associations are exploring solutions, including improving investor relations, strengthening corporate governance, and attracting more foreign investors. The Singapore Exchange-listed Companies Association (SGListCos) has been working to enhance investor relations capabilities, offering accredited courses and masterclasses for professionals, and forming an Asian Alliance for IR to share best practices. The goal is to boost liquidity and attract new segments of shareholders, ultimately creating a vibrant stock market that supports local growth and entrepreneurship.

images.alt_text: CMG20240327-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.受限股票（restricted stock unit）

site_title: Sony deal for Paramount would draw added regulatory scrutiny
summary: US regulators and competition authorities are expected to scrutinize a potential deal between Tokyo-based Sony and Apollo Global Management to buy Paramount Global, citing national-security implications and studio consolidation concerns. The deal would trigger review by the Federal Communications Commission and agencies checking telecom transactions for national-security implications. Regulators have closely scrutinized deals under the Biden Administration, including the unsuccessful attempt to block Microsoft's acquisition of Activision Blizzard. The review process can take six months or more, raising concerns about the impact on theater owners and pay-TV subscribers.

images.alt_text: Paramount, the parent of CBS, MTV and other networks, has been selling assets, such as its Simon & Schuster book publishing arm, to reduce debt.

site_title: Fancy apartment rentals for Paris Olympics see poor demand and price cuts
summary: Parisians who listed their luxury apartments for rent at premium prices during the Olympics are now facing poor demand and price cuts. Real estate agencies report a tepid demand for high-end rentals, with some owners slashing prices to half of what they initially sought. Luxury apartments, once asking around 10,000 euros per week, are now available at significantly lower rates, with some owners abandoning the prospect of renting altogether. Experts attribute the slowdown to overhyped expectations and a lack of bookings, with many visitors having already secured lodgings for the Olympics.

images.alt_text: Greek actress Mary Mina, playing the role of the High Priestess, holds the torch after lighting it during the Olympic torch lighting ceremony for the Paris 2024 Olympics Games at the Ancient Olympia archeological site.

site_title: IMF urges higher for longer rates in eastern Europe on sticky inflation
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) advises central banks in central, eastern, and south-eastern Europe to keep interest rates higher for longer due to sticky inflation and high wage growth. Tight labour markets and wage growth above 10% will add to price pressures, making it challenging to cut rates. The IMF warns that growth in these economies will rely on consumption and may take longer to recover, as investment is expected to be impacted by tight monetary stances. Policymakers in countries such as Hungary and Poland should maintain a tight stance to fully rein in inflation.

site_title: Inflation, interest rates and oil prices have jolted the markets
summary: Markets are experiencing heightened uncertainty and measured self-restraint due to inflation, interest rates, and geopolitical risks. The US dollar has strengthened, and oil prices have climbed 18% this year, with Brent crude near $90 a barrel. Despite this, long-term investors can handle short-term turmoil, and shifts in interest rates and inflation readings are expected to guide market direction. The Fed's chair Jerome Powell has stated that short-term interest rates will remain elevated for months, and bonds are becoming increasingly attractive due to higher yields.

images.alt_text: On Wall Street, which is closely monitoring both the tech economy and the Fed, excitement over the possibilities of AI riches outweighs concerns about interest rates and inflation.

site_title: Asean’s baby bust; Vietnam’s fraud aftermath
summary: ASEAN economies face challenges as the region's currencies decline against the US dollar. Vietnam's largest-ever fraud case has resulted in a massive $24 billion rescue for Saigon Joint Stock Commercial Bank, while Indonesia's rupiah plummets to a four-year low, prompting concerns of a looming currency crisis. Meanwhile, Malaysia's birth rates have reached a historic low, and the country's economy is at risk of strain due to demographic challenges. Apple CEO Tim Cook met Indonesian President Joko Widodo to discuss investment opportunities, while Singapore and the Philippines celebrate 55 years of diplomatic ties.

images.alt_text:
Jakarta-Bandung HSR
The 142-km-long Jakarta-Bandung HSR was launched in October 2023. The plan to extend the project to Surabaya is still under consideration.
Indonesia’s outgoing leader Joko Widodo (left) will hand over the baton to incoming President Prabowo Subianto while Vietnam's President Vo Van Thuong (right) has resigned.
The Langkawi archipelago, one of Malaysia’s best-known holiday destinations, is also a popular choice among retired expatriates.

site_title: Office gossip is not just idle chatter. It is a valuable – but risky – way to build relationships
summary: Research suggests that workplace gossip can be a valuable way to build relationships, but its impact depends on how the recipient perceives the intentions of the gossiper. Studies indicate that genuine and authentic gossip can spark new friendships or rekindle old ones, while self-serving gossip can damage relationships. The study's findings highlight the importance of considering the recipient's interpretation of the gossiper's intentions, as it can significantly affect interpersonal relationships.

images.alt_text: Many employees complain of a decline in mental health due to work, and believe their organisations overlook the issue.

site_title: Giving a new definition to social enterprise
summary: Poultry East Africa (PEAL), founded by Lam Shumei, is a purpose-driven social enterprise that partners with 335 small-scale farmers in Rwanda to make chicken meat more accessible to locals. The company, established in 2012, has grown to become Rwanda's largest poultry company, with a weekly production of 9,000 chickens. PEAL aims to create a micro-economy and be self-sustaining, while also providing affordable chicken meat to the local population. The company's focus on biosecurity and minimizing human-chicken contact has been crucial in its success, with Lam emphasizing that profit and sustainability are essential for long-term impact.

images.alt_text: The artwork, Whispers of the Deep, was made from scraps found in the ocean and later restored by

site_title: How Israel and Iran came to brink of full-fledged war
summary: Israel and Iran are on the brink of full-fledged war, following a series of escalating attacks. Iran launched a drone and missile attack on Israel on April 14, 2024, which Israel responded to with airstrikes targeting Iranian diplomatic buildings in Syria. The attacks killed a top commander of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, Iran's premier security force. This marks a significant escalation in the shadow war between the two countries, which has been ongoing for decades. The situation remains volatile, with other militant groups supported by Iran joining the fray, raising concerns of a wider conflict.

images.alt_text: Foreign ministers from the G7, comprising the US, Italy, Canada, France, Germany, Japan and Britain, wrapped up three days of talks on the island of Capri that were dominated by wars in Ukraine and the Middle East.

The limited scale of Israel's attack and Iran’s muted response appeared to signal a successful effort by diplomats who have been working to avert all-out war since an Iranian drone and missile attack on Israel (top) last Saturday.
A man walks past a huge anti-Israeli banner, in Teheran on Apr 19. Early indications after reports of explosions in the Iranian city of Isfahan were that Iran was downplaying Israel's retaliation.

site_title: Fed survey cites inflation, US election as key financial stability risks
summary: The US Federal Reserve's latest survey of financial contacts highlights persistent inflation and higher interest rates as key risks to financial stability, with geopolitical tensions and the 2024 US presidential election also posing concerns. Despite high policy interest rates and inflation, the financial system is characterized as largely stable, with strong household and business balance sheets, stable banks, and low imminent threats. However, some areas of concern include declining commercial real estate values and rising leverage among hedge funds, and a rise in consumer debt delinquencies.

images.alt_text: US mortgage rates have risen in recent months, making homeownership costlier for buyers.
The Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC. The US central bank's next action is likely to be an interest rate hike instead of a cut, say some economists.

Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic said he still believes inflation is on the path to the central bank’s 2 per cent goal, but he noted that path is likely to be slower than people expect.

site_title: DBS, OCBC, UOB have enough liquidity to mitigate funding costs: analysts
summary: Singapore's major banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, have sufficient liquidity to mitigate funding costs, analysts say. This is due to the impending interest rate cuts and the rise in fixed deposits driven by overseas demand. Total deposits from residents outside of Singapore rose 9.1% to S$593.6 billion, with fixed deposits increasing 28.1% to S$356.9 million. Analysts expect the banks' earnings to remain strong in 2024, driven by moderating net interest margins and a recovery in fee income. This could help keep funding costs in check despite moderating net interest income growth.

site_title: China is front and centre of gold’s record-breaking rally
summary: China's gold demand surged 10% for jewellery and 28% for bars and coins last year, contributing to the record-breaking rally in gold prices above $2,400 an ounce. The country's central bank has also been a significant buyer, snapping up near-record levels of gold for 17 consecutive months. Chinese consumers' appetite for gold remains strong despite record prices and a weaker yuan, driven by uncertainty and limited investment options. The rally is expected to be sustainable, with China's booming demand helping to prop up prices.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.4 per cent at US$2,388.49 per ounce, as of 0111 GMT. US gold futures edged 0.2 per cent higher to US$2,403.30 per ounce.

site_title: Swiss franc, yen modestly up, but off highs
summary: The Swiss franc and Japanese yen modestly rose on Friday after news of a limited-scale Israeli attack on Iran, but their gains have slowed. The US dollar fell against the franc and yen, with the dollar index rising but giving up gains. The dollar's surge is attributed to a strong US economy, but currencies have bounced around in European and North American sessions. Asian currencies, particularly the yen, have been under pressure, with the Bank of Japan warning of potential interest rate hikes if the yen declines significantly.

images.alt_text: The dollar index, which measures the US currency against six others, was last down 0.11 per cent at 105.84.

site_title: US House passes US$95 billion in aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a foreign assistance package totaling $95 billion, combining $61 billion in aid for Ukraine with $34 billion for Israel and $32 billion for Taiwan. The package, which was approved on a 311-112 bipartisan vote, marks the end of a six-month impasse in funding for Ukraine, allowing Kyiv to replenish its stockpiles in its war against Russia. Speaker Mike Johnson worked with Democrats to overcome opposition from within his own party.

images.alt_text: The House-passed TikTok legislation has support from data privacy and national security hawks concerned about troves of data on American users.

site_title: Honda to invest US$808 million in Brazil by 2030
summary: Honda plans to invest US$808 million in Brazil by 2030, with a focus on new technologies and hybrid models. The company aims to produce 150,000 vehicles per year at its Itirapina plant, up from 100,000 this year. Honda also plans to launch a new entry-level SUV in 2025 and develop a hybrid-flex vehicle that can run 100% on ethanol. The investment is part of a series of fresh investments by automakers in Brazil, totaling nearly 130 billion reais.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Honda logo is seen during the New York International Auto Show, in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., April 5, 2023. REUTERS/David 'Dee' Delgado/File Photo

site_title: Colombian fund managers eye US$750 million fee bonanza after senators tweak pension bill
summary: Colombian lawmakers approved a proposal allowing private pension funds to charge an additional 0.7% annual management fee, estimated to generate US$750 million in management fees. The fee will be levied on assets under management, with the funds aiming to remain financially viable despite government cuts to private pension savings. The change aims to address President Gustavo Petro's criticisms of private pension funds, which he claims have low returns and should repatriate money invested overseas. The pension reform bill is expected to be discussed in the lower house after the senate's approval.

images.alt_text: Traders in Chile, Brazil and Colombia now price in odds of rate cuts starting in the second half of 2023.

site_title: US expects to finalise new Aukus trade exemptions in next 120 days
summary: The US State Department expects to finalize new trade exemptions for the Aukus defence project with Australia and Britain within the next 120 days, despite initial delays. The exemptions are needed for the US to share technology with its allies, particularly to counter China's growing power. The exemptions will allow Australia and Britain to acquire US defence technology without the strict US International Trafficking in Arms Regulations (ITAR) restrictions, enabling the countries to develop advanced capabilities quickly.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden (C) participates in a trilateral meeting with British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak (R) and Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese (L) during the AUKUS summit on March 13, 2023, at Naval Base Point Loma in San Diego California. - AUKUS is a trilateral security pact announced on September 15, 2021, for the Indo-Pacific region. (Photo by Jim WATSON / AFP)
For the Biden administration, Aukus is a centrepiece of efforts to contain Chinese power.

site_title: How utopian thinking can inspire business leaders
summary: Business leaders can break free from conventional problem-solving methods by embracing utopian thinking and inviting diverse stakeholders to envision the most desirable solution, even if seemingly impossible. This approach can help executives overcome guilt and denial, and instead, create a better future. By engaging in thought experiments and considering the needs of various stakeholders, leaders can build walls against discomfort and develop innovative solutions. This mindset shift can lead to a more desirable outcome, rather than just reacting to problems.

images.alt_text: To avoid slipping into hubristic behaviour, individuals should embrace a consultative approach. In other words, they need to be willing to listen to those in a position to provide advice or criticise their actions.

site_title: Why making computer chips has become a new global arms race
summary: The global chip industry has become a high-stakes battle among corporations and governments, driven by the US's efforts to limit China's rise as a rival economic power. Taiwan's chipmakers, particularly Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC), control a significant portion of the market due to their advanced technology and scale. The US has imposed export controls on China, and other countries, including Europe and Japan, are investing heavily to reduce their reliance on East Asian chip production. The global chip battle is playing out with China's chipmakers still relying on US technology and struggling to access overseas production technology.

images.alt_text: TSMC has gained about US$340 billion of market value since an October 2022 trough.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Samsung Electronics is seen at its office building in Seoul, South Korea, March 23, 2018.   REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) logo is seen near computer motherboard in this illustration taken January 8, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The news came out a day before Brite’s shares were set to begin trading on the Shanghai Stock Exchange.

site_title: Bitcoin 'halving' has taken place: CoinGecko
summary: Bitcoin completed its "halving," a process that halves the rewards for creating new tokens, reducing the supply of new bitcoins. The event, which occurs every four years, has been met with mixed reactions, with some seeing it as a sign of bitcoin's value as a scarce commodity and others viewing it as a technical change to inflate the virtual currency's price. The price of bitcoin fell 0.5% to US$63,747 following the event, with some analysts predicting a potential price drop due to the cryptocurrency being "overbought."

images.alt_text: Bitcoin slid more than 5.5 per cent to US$59,961 in the Asia session as the US dollar rose broadly.
Past Bitcoin halvings showed a pattern of heightened market activity and price rallies, but were followed by a correction phase.
The halving will cut the amount of Bitcoin that so-called miners can earn each day for validating transactions to 450 from 900.
The Bitcoin halving, set to happen later this month, is coming after the digital currency has more than quadrupled since November 2022.

site_title: Trade tensions threaten the rise of China’s stock champions
summary: Trade tensions between the US and Europe are threatening the rise of China's stock champions, particularly those in the green and high-tech industries. The sectors under scrutiny include electric vehicles, wind and solar projects, medical devices, and chips, which are of strategic importance to China's bid for leadership in the global green transition and high-tech development. This could hinder China's global expansion and lead to a full-blown trade war, dampening export growth drivers and investment in the Chinese economy.

images.alt_text: Last year, China’s gold jewellery demand rose 10 per cent while bar and coin investments surged 28 per cent.

site_title: Philippines’ Recto sees rate-cut delay risk if peso sinks to 59
summary: Philippine Finance Secretary Ralph Recto warned that interest-rate cuts may be delayed if the peso falls below 59 per US dollar, but he still expects the economy to grow between 6-7% this year. The peso has weakened past the 57-per-dollar level, partly due to Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's signal of delays in US rate reductions. Despite this, Recto stated that the government plans to tap international debt markets for about $9 billion this year to fund a budget deficit and support economic growth.

images.alt_text: peso, money, currency
Price risks in the Philippines have lingered even after the BSP’s most aggressive tightening campaign in two decades that has taken the key rate to a 17-year high.

Eli Remolona, Governor of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, speaks at an event at the Central Bank in Manila, Philippines, on Friday, July 28, 2023. Remolona said upside risks to inflation persist, in comments that indicate the monetary authority is open to further tightening. Photographer: Lisa Marie David/Bloomberg
The Philippines last week trimmed the economic growth forecasts for this year and next while widening fiscal deficit estimates to support higher spending.

site_title: Tesla cuts US prices by US$2,000 as sales slow, inventories swell
summary: Tesla has cut prices of its Model Y, Model X, and Model S in the US by $2,000, following disappointing first-quarter sales and swelling inventory. The price cuts, effective immediately, bring the lowest-cost Model Y to $42,990, down from $44,990 before federal tax credits. This move comes amid a tumultuous week for the company, marked by job cuts, executive departures, and a recall of nearly 3,900 Cybertruck pickups. The price cuts aim to boost sales and alleviate inventory pressure.

images.alt_text: In 2008, BMW engineers set out to develop an electric city car from scratch.
FILE PHOTO: Visitors check a Tesla Model 3 car next to a Model Y displayed at a showroom of the U.S. electric vehicle (EV) maker in Beijing, China February 4, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo
Elon Musk says a lack of advanced chips was hampering the training of Grok’s version 2 model.
Musk has long boasted of work Tesla is doing on its systems for electric cars to drive themselves.

site_title: ECB rate-setters agree on June cut but not much else beyond
summary: European Central Bank officials agree that interest rates will likely be cut in June, but there's disagreement on the number and speed of future cuts. ECB President Christine Lagarde said borrowing costs will be lowered in "reasonably short order" and economic data will guide policy decisions. Some officials, like Austria's Robert Holzmann, are less convinced, while others, like Finland's Olli Rehn, think it's time for the ECB to act. The ECB is also considering the impact of potential US Federal Reserve rate cuts and the risks of another oil-price shock on its policy decisions.

images.alt_text: The ECB has flagged a rate cut for June 6, but policymakers have largely avoided discussing what happens later on, partly on uncertainty over prices and partly due to risks that the US Federal Reserve, which sets the tone for the world economy, could delay its own rate cuts.

site_title: Bank of Japan’s Ueda says ‘very likely’ to hike rates if inflation keeps rising
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said the central bank is "very likely" to raise interest rates if underlying inflation continues to rise, and may begin reducing its bond buying. The BOJ aims to maintain loose monetary policy as underlying inflation remains below its 2% target, with long-term inflation expectations near 1.5%. The central bank will assess the impact of recent policy changes on the economy and inflation before considering further adjustments, with a potential cut in Japanese government bond purchases also on the horizon.

images.alt_text: Japan's core CPI, which excludes fresh food items, rose 2.6 per cent in March from a year earlier after rising 2.8 per cent in February.
BOJ officials, including governor Kazuo Ueda, have said the focus would be on whether wage increases will broaden, and prod firms to hike prices not just for goods but services.
Of the households surveyed by the Bank of Japan, 83.3 per cent said they expected prices to rise a year from now, up from 79.3 per cent in the previous survey conducted three months ago.

site_title: Wall Street bonus rules return to regulatory agenda in third try
summary: US financial watchdogs plan to vote on a measure to regulate Wall Street executives' pay, a requirement of the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act. The incentive-compensation rules aim to curb risky behavior by forcing executives to wait longer to cash out bonuses. A proposal would give companies up to seven years to claw back pay tied to misconduct and require financial firms to provide additional details on pay packages. The rules must clear six regulators before taking effect, a challenging process due to differing agency priorities and the November elections.

images.alt_text: Brokerages have stepped up cost-cutting efforts after some scaled back travel perks last year.
AI tools can replace much of Wall Street's entry-level white-collar work, raising tough questions about the future of finance.
Japan has missed out on that opportunity over the last three decades as Wall Street firms poured resources into rival hubs such as Hong Kong to tap into mainland China.
The industry’s bonus pool stood at US$33.8 billion for 2023, broadly in line with 2022.

site_title: Lululemon to shutter Washington distribution center, lay off 128 employees
summary: Lululemon Athletica will close its distribution center in Sumner, Washington, and lay off 128 employees, starting June 21, as part of its business optimization effort. The move comes amid slowing demand for premium athleisure in North America. The 150,000-square-foot center will close at the end of the year, with some employees to be retained and relocated to other facilities. The decision is part of Lululemon's efforts to adapt to a changing market.

images.alt_text: Lululemon’s performance has slowed in recent quarters following a stellar post-pandemic run.
The pandemic-era appetite for comfortable clothing and activewear has turned into a habit for most Americans

site_title: What Trump’s 34 felony charges are all about in the hush money trial
summary: Former US President Donald Trump faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records in a New York trial, related to payments made on the eve of the 2016 election to Stormy Daniels. Trump is accused of concealing his connection to the payments and falsifying records as part of a scheme to violate election laws. He has pleaded not guilty and denied the affair. The trial follows similar charges in Georgia over Trump's attempts to overturn his 2020 election loss to President Joe Biden, and allegations of election interference and handling of classified documents in two federal cases.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump, 77, who is seeking to recapture the White House in November, is accused of falsifying business records on the eve of his 2016 election victory to cover up a sexual encounter with a porn star.

Former President Donald Trump appears in the courtroom for the first day of his criminal trial at Manhattan Criminal Court in New York, April 15, 2024. Trump faces charges he falsified business records to cover up a sex scandal while serving as president. More than half of the first group of prospective jurors was dismissed almost immediately. (Jefferson Siegel/The New York Times)

site_title: Volkswagen workers vote decisively to unionise in Tennessee
summary: Volkswagen workers in Tennessee voted 73% in favor of unionizing, marking the first major victory for organized labor in the American South. The win comes after UAW President Shawn Fain's organizing campaign, which aimed to unionize 13 companies with nearly 150,000 workers in southern US states. The vote is a significant triumph for the union, following last fall's "Stand Up Strike" at Ford, General Motors, and Stellantis, where Fain secured salary hikes for members. A vote at a Mercedes-Benz factory in Alabama is set to take place from May 13-17.

site_title: IMF concerned about debt, fiscal challenges facing low-income countries
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is concerned about debt and fiscal challenges facing low-income countries, with many struggling to pay debt burdens and invest in essential services. The IMF lowered its 2024 growth forecast for low-income countries to 4.7% due to unsustainable debt levels, and reported that half of the world's 75 poorest countries are experiencing a widening income gap with wealthier economies. The IMF is working to support these countries, including through debt restructuring and increasing its resources, to help them address these challenges.

images.alt_text: (From left) Krishna Srinivasan, director of the IMF’s Asia and Pacific department and Thomas Helbling, deputy director of the IMF's Asia Pacific Department at the press conference following the release of the IMF’s Regional Economic Outlook for Asia and Pacific on Tuesday. They recommend Asia central banks to focus on their domestic fundamentals in making monetary policies.
FILE PHOTO: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva speaks during an interview during a G20 Financial Summit, in Sao Paulo, Brazil, February 27, 2024. REUTERS/Carla Carniel/File Photo
Higher interest rates in the US make life difficult for many countries by strengthening the value of the US dollar against other currencies.

(FILES) The International Monetary Fund (IMF) logo is displayed outside its headquarters in Washington, DC, on October 8, 2022. The International Monetary Fund officially launched the selection process to find the organization next leader on March 13, 2024, with current managing director Kristalina Georgieva widely tipped for a second five-year term. (Photo by Stefani Reynolds / AFP)

site_title: The wind is picking up, but only in China
summary: China is driving the recovery of the global wind industry, with wind power likely to overtake nuclear as the world's biggest source of clean energy within the next 12 months. After facing challenges such as rising interest rates and materials costs, the wind industry is experiencing a resurgence, with China's investments in renewable energy contributing significantly to this growth. The sector's recovery is attributed to China's aggressive push for renewable energy, which has led to an increase in installations of new turbines and a decrease in project cancellations and failed auctions.

images.alt_text: The Singapore city skyline in the evening on April 4, 2023.
China has by far the world's largest wind turbine production capacity, accounting for 60 per cent of the 163 gigawatts globally in 2023.

The China Electricity Council (CEC) forecast that grid-connected wind and solar would make up around 40 per cent of installed power generation capacity by the end of 2024, compared with coal’s expected 37 per cent.

site_title: Teheran signals no retaliation against Israel after drones attack Iran
summary: Iran has signaled no plans for retaliation against Israel after a limited drone attack on the city of Isfahan, indicating a successful effort by diplomats to avert all-out war. The attack, described as an infiltration, resulted in a muted response from Iranian media and officials, who referred to the incident as an internal security issue. Diplomats and world powers, including the US, have urged restraint, calling for a ceasefire in Gaza and an end to further escalation. The incident comes amid heightened tensions between Israel and Iranian proxies in the Middle East.

images.alt_text: Jerusalem's Old City, after Iran launched more than 200 drones and missiles on Israel.

site_title: US Senate has agreement on Fisa reauthorisation, will vote on Friday night, Schumer says
summary: The US Senate has reached an agreement to approve the reauthorisation of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (Fisa), a surveillance program that gathers foreign nationals' data, including communications with Americans, without a warrant. The bill will be voted on Friday night, with Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer stating it's crucial for national security. Critics argue the program violates Americans' constitutional right to privacy, citing recent instances where the FBI used the power to hunt for information on protesters and lawmakers.

images.alt_text: Apple sees sharp increase in US national security requests
Trump signs bill renewing NSA's internet surveillance program

site_title: Climate targets group's CEO seeks to ease concerns over carbon offset plan
summary: The CEO of the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi), Luiz Amaral, sought to ease concerns over the group's plan to allow companies to use carbon credits to offset greenhouse gas emissions. Critics worried that the policy could let companies off the hook for reducing emissions. Amaral emphasized the group's dedication to science-based decarbonization, public consultation, and standard-setting governance, and stated that the group is still gathering feedback and working with stakeholders to achieve the best possible outcome. The move aims to calm concerns and maintain the group's influence over the corporate world.

images.alt_text: The use of offsets should be limited and not substitute for cutting a company’s operating emissions, says global environmental group WWF, a founder of the initiative.
The United Nations-backed Science Based Targets initiative says it will allow the use of credits to cut emissions from value chains, otherwise known as Scope 3 emissions.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P tumble as Netflix, chip stocks drag
summary: US stocks declined on Friday as Netflix shares weighed on the benchmark S&P index and Nasdaq, despite American Express's quarterly earnings beating expectations. The Dow rose due to American Express's strong performance, but the Nasdaq fell 2.05% and the S&P 500 fell 0.88%. The decline marks the sixth straight session of losses for the S&P and Nasdaq, with the S&P down 5.46% from its record close in March.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JANUARY 19: Traders and media work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on January 19, 2024 in New York City. Stocks closed up over 350 points while the S&P 500 closed at an all-time high on Friday.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Hybrid work, career mobility, pay and wellness: Meeting changing employee needs
summary: Many employees in the Asia-Pacific region, particularly in the accountancy and finance sector, are seeking better career opportunities, enhanced salaries, and improved work-life balance due to declining mental health. A survey of 9,889 finance professionals in 157 countries found that nearly half expect their next career move to be external to their current organization. This highlights the need for organizations to prioritize employee well-being and address mental health concerns.

images.alt_text: blogger, screenwriter, desperate

site_title: Warner Bros CEO earned US$49.7 million in strike-impacted year
summary: Warner Bros CEO David Zaslav earned US$49.7 million in 2023, a year marked by a film and TV writers strike and significant job cuts. His pay is lower than his 2021 compensation of US$246.6 million at Discovery Inc. The company generated US$1 billion more in cash than expected, but this amount was excluded from Zaslav's pay calculations. Zaslav's 2023 pay is comparable to other media moguls, such as Netflix's co-CEOs.

images.alt_text: Warner Bros Discovery reports overall fourth-quarter revenue of US$10.28 billion, missing analysts’ average estimate of US$10.35 billion.

site_title: Plato Capital chairman Lim Kian Onn boosts his stake
summary:
Singaporean institutions sold S$73 million worth of stocks over the five trading sessions till Apr 18, while companies conducted buybacks totaling S$23.7 million. Key changes include:

- Plato Capital chairman Lim Kian Onn acquired 283,000 shares, increasing his stake from 79.81% to 82.14%.
- JEP Holdings' chairman and CEO Andy Luong sold 7.3 million shares, reducing his interest from 78.84% to 1.77%.
- Hai Leck Holdings' executive chairman and CEO Cheng Buck Poh acquired 302,900 shares, increasing his stake from 88.8% to 88.94%.
- GSH Corporation's executive chairman Sam Goi Seng Hui acquired 1,233,700 shares, increasing his stake from 63.70% to 63.76%.
- LHT Holdings' managing director Yap Mui Kee acquired 103,800 shares, increasing her stake from 16.72% to 16.92%.

These transactions reflect the ongoing market dynamics and strategic moves by key players in the Singaporean stock market.
