images.alt_text: The four trading sessions saw close to 70 changes to director interests and substantial shareholdings filed for more than 30 primary-listed stocks.

site_title: G7 pledges swift aid for Ukraine, seeks to calm Middle East
summary: The G7, consisting of the US, Italy, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, and Britain, pledged swift aid to Ukraine, aiming to bolster its air defenses against deadly Russian attacks. The group also urged de-escalation in the Middle East, where tensions between Israel and Iran risk sparking a wider regional conflict. China was told to stop supporting Russia's military industry to maintain good relations with the West, and the G7 will increase security assistance for Kyiv, including bolstering air defense capabilities. A decision on using profits from seized Russian assets to help Ukraine is expected at a G7 summit in June.

images.alt_text: People walk past screens displaying the Hang Seng stock index and stock prices outside the Exchange Square in Hong Kong, China January 23, 2024. REUTERS/Joyce Zhou

The limited scale of Israel's attack and Iran’s muted response appeared to signal a successful effort by diplomats who have been working to avert all-out war since an Iranian drone and missile attack on Israel (top) last Saturday.
Before the airports reopened, Flydubai said it had cancelled its Friday flights to Iran. One of its earlier flights turned back to Dubai, it said.

Iran’s Fars news agency reported “three explosions” were heard near the Shekari army airbase in the north-west of Isfahan province, while Iran’s space agency spokesman Hossein Dalirian said “several” drones had been “successfully shot down”.
US Deputy Ambassador to the UN Robert Wood votes against a resolution allowing Palestinian UN membership at United Nations headquarters in New York, April 18, 2024.
Reuters photographer Mohammed Salem’s winning image portrays Inas Abu Maamar, 36, sobbing while holding Saly’s sheet-clad body in the hospital morgue.

Iranian demonstrators show support during an anti-Israeli gathering at Palestine Square in Tehran, April 14, 2024, after Iran retaliated directly against Israel for the killings of its senior generals in Damascus, Syria, with an onslaught of more than 300 drones and missiles.

site_title: Ecuador president declares state of emergency over energy crisis
summary: Ecuador President Daniel Noboa has declared a second state of emergency due to an energy crisis, which has led to rationing in the country. The emergency, set to last 60 days, aims to ensure the continuity of electricity services. The crisis was caused by a drought at hydroelectric dams, partly due to the climate phenomenon El Nino. The previous emergency declaration in January focused on combating crime, and the latest measure involves deploying the military and police to guard energy infrastructure. The state of emergency will be suspended on Sunday for a referendum on security measures.

images.alt_text: An Ecuadorean police squad enters the premises of Ecuador's TC television channel after unidentified gunmen burst into the state-owned television studio live on air on January 9, 2024, in Guayaquil, Ecuador, a day after Ecuadorean President Daniel Noboa declared a state of emergency following the escape from prison of a dangerous narco boss. Gunshots rang out on live TV in violence-torn Ecuador as armed men carrying rifles and grenades stormed the studio shortly after gangsters vowed a "war" against the president's plans to reclaim control from "narcoterrorists". (Photo by STRINGER / AFP)

site_title: At Bar Spectre, a drink may be stronger than you think – and you can be, too
summary: Bar Spectre, a mental-wellness-focused bar, offers cocktail-based therapy through a cleansing ritual with fire. Customers write down their concerns, set them ablaze, and watch them disappear, symbolizing a mental reset. Founder Andrew Pang aims to "restart" patrons, encouraging them to arrive mentally refreshed. The bar's unique approach combines therapy with socializing, providing a space for patrons to confront and release their emotions.

images.alt_text: The living room whisky bar at Maduro offers a curated range of independent bottling whiskies, including some of the rarest bottles like Isabella’s Islay Aged 30 years.
I Like Big Bahts makes a statement not just with its unique glassware, but its bold tom yum-inspired savours.
Imagine Dragon, a highball inspired by the pop-rock band and crafted around the vivid red tones of dragon fruit, achieves a delicate balance with its diverse blend of ingredients. PHOTO: STUDIO 1939

site_title: Global wave of consultancy layoffs has not hit Singapore
summary: Singapore's consultancy and professional services sector remains resilient despite a global wave of job cuts in the industry. Big Four firms such as PwC, Deloitte, and Ernst & Young have cut jobs globally, citing economic headwinds and a slowdown in client demand. However, firms in Singapore, including KPMG and Deloitte, do not plan to cut jobs and are instead investing in talent development. Industry watchers note that some layoffs may eventually occur, particularly in areas with reduced demand, but Singapore's diverse economy and lean staffing levels are expected to mitigate the impact.

images.alt_text: Not long ago, the consulting industry looked indestructible. Now, however, growth has been soggy for this “Great Eight”, slowing to around 5 per cent in 2023.
Large accounting firms have made multiple rounds of layoffs in the past year amid subdued corporate advisory work and consulting activity.
McKinsey has more than 45,000 staffers in 130 cities around the world, according to its website.
Market watchers said weak global growth has been dampening demand for consultancy, both worldwide and in Singapore.

site_title: Europe: L’Oreal gains cap third week of declines
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell 1% for the week due to geopolitical tensions and concerns over higher interest rates. Despite this, individual stocks like L'Oreal, Royal Unibrew, and some tech companies declined, while European food and beverage and telecom stocks outperformed. A retaliatory strike by Israel on Iran earlier in the week dampened risk demand, but oil prices remained stable. The market's reaction to the incident was described as "calm and objective" by analysts, with some attributing the lack of a significant impact to the strength of demand.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 0.3 per cent higher on Thursday, as the earnings season picked up steam.

site_title: Oil prices steady after Iran plays down reported Israeli attack
summary: Oil prices steadied on Friday after Iran played down a reported Israeli attack, with Brent futures up 10 cents at $87.21 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude up 27 cents to $83 a barrel. The incident, which included explosions in the Iranian city of Isfahan, was downplayed by Tehran, leading investors to believe an escalation of hostilities might be avoided. Analysts say Middle Eastern tensions may still disrupt oil supply, but a recent increase in oil output by Opec+ is expected to start in July, potentially easing concerns.

images.alt_text: Foreign ministers from the G7, comprising the US, Italy, Canada, France, Germany, Japan and Britain, wrapped up three days of talks on the island of Capri that were dominated by wars in Ukraine and the Middle East.

The limited scale of Israel's attack and Iran’s muted response appeared to signal a successful effort by diplomats who have been working to avert all-out war since an Iranian drone and missile attack on Israel (top) last Saturday.
People walk past screens displaying the Hang Seng stock index and stock prices outside the Exchange Square in Hong Kong, China January 23, 2024. REUTERS/Joyce Zhou
Before the airports reopened, Flydubai said it had cancelled its Friday flights to Iran. One of its earlier flights turned back to Dubai, it said.

Iran’s Fars news agency reported “three explosions” were heard near the Shekari army airbase in the north-west of Isfahan province, while Iran’s space agency spokesman Hossein Dalirian said “several” drones had been “successfully shot down”.

site_title: South Korea government offers first compromise to end doctors' strike
summary: South Korea's government has offered its first concession to striking doctors, proposing to reduce medical school enrollment by up to 50% for the 2025 academic year. The move aims to ease doctor shortages, but medical professionals and trainees have expressed concerns that the changes will erode the quality of education and health services. The offer comes as the country's medical community advocates for a reevaluation of the reform plan, and it remains unclear whether trainee doctors will return to work.

images.alt_text: South Korean medical professors holding up signs protesting the government's plan to augment medical student admissions at Jeonbuk National University.  The health ministry this week reiterated that negotiations over the reform plans were out of the question.
President Yoon Suk Yeol (R) has spearheaded a package of medical reform plans and taken a hard line against the protesters, moving to suspend their medical licences for defying return-to-work orders.

site_title: China moves to boost foreign investment in domestic tech companies
summary: China has introduced measures to boost foreign investment in domestic tech companies, including supporting yuan bond issuance and facilitating foreign investment through an inbound investment scheme. The government will also relax restrictions on foreign strategic investments in Chinese listed firms. The move aims to attract foreign investors amid signs of a slowing economy and geopolitical tensions, with Chinese President Xi Jinping calling for "quality" growth through technological breakthroughs and innovation.

images.alt_text: Foreign direct investment (FDI) totalled 301.7 billion yuan (S$56.8 billion) in January-to-March quarter.
China’s nominal GDP growth rate of 4.2 per cent in the first quarter was considerably below the real growth rate, mainly dragged down by weak prices.
China’s manufacturing drive has exacerbated tensions with trading partners.
IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva says China’s investment-led economic growth model might have worked in the past but could not be sustained in future.

site_title: Rethink assumptions about next-generation wealth
summary: Wealthy families in Asia are expected to transfer an estimated $100 trillion to the next generation over the next 20-30 years, dubbed the "great wealth transfer". Contrary to popular stereotypes, many next-generation heirs are conscientious, disciplined investors with a strong understanding of their contribution to society. To mitigate risks, early family legacy planning and consistent review are crucial. Empowering the younger generation with real responsibilities and opportunities, such as managing capital and making investment decisions, is key to ensuring a smooth transition. Effective succession planning can help avoid public dramas and ensure the wealth transfer is a success.

images.alt_text: For The Bear, star Jeremy Allen White was named best comedy actor.
From left: Panellists Chan Mun Hoe, Regina Tan, Natalie Lau, Renita Chua, Ho Weijin and moderator, Vanessa Ho.

site_title: The art of high watchmaking
summary: High-end watchmakers showcased their latest creations at Watches and Wonders Geneva 2024, with notable debuts including Hublot's translucent water blue MP-11, Chanel's J12 Atelier Couture Automate Calibre 6, and Jaeger-LeCoultre's Duometre Heliotourbillon Perpetual. Ulysse Nardin's Freak S Nomad featured a sand-coloured hour disc with guilloché pattern, while Grand Seiko's Spring Drive Chronograph GMT recreated summer morning hues. These timepieces exemplify the art of high watchmaking, blending innovative technology and craftsmanship.

site_title: Telegram messaging service to allow Tether stablecoin payments
summary: Tether, the issuer of the world's most used stablecoin, has teamed up with the TON Foundation to allow customers to send crypto payments using Telegram's encrypted instant messaging service. The move aims to bring more users to the TON blockchain and crypto wallet, particularly in emerging markets where there is a demand for easy and efficient ways to send money. Tether's USDT stablecoin is backed by US dollar-denominated assets and has a market value of over $109 billion. The partnership may pose challenges for Telegram, which is considering going public and has faced scrutiny over its potential use in sanctions evasion.

images.alt_text: Tether’s USDT token is on the verge of surpassing US$100 billion in circulation for the first time.
Almost all major media, government entities and public figures in both Russia and Ukraine operate content channels on Telegram.

site_title: H5N1 strain of bird flu found in milk: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) announced that the H5N1 bird flu strain has been detected in high concentrations in raw milk from infected animals, although the virus's survival time in milk is unknown. The Texas health department stated that cattle infections do not pose a concern for commercial milk supply, as dairies destroy milk from sick cows and pasteurization kills the virus. This detection comes amid a growing number of outbreaks in birds and mammals, resulting in tens of millions of poultry deaths and infections in wild birds, land, and marine mammals.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The World Health Organisation (WHO) logo is seen near its headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland, February 2, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: Singapore-licensed Triple-A to offer PayPal stablecoin support
summary: Singapore-based payments firm Triple-A will add support for PayPal's stablecoin, PYUSD, by the end of June, allowing customers to use it to pay merchants. This is another step forward for PayPal's experimental stablecoin, which aims to challenge crypto rivals. PYUSD, issued by Paxos Trust, has a market value of around $200 million, significantly lower than Tether's USDT, the dominant stablecoin. Triple-A, backed by Peak XV Partners, aims to double its payment volumes by the end of 2024.

images.alt_text: PayPal has faced setbacks of its own with PYUSD.

site_title: P&G raises annual core profit forecast on resilient demand, price hikes
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) raised its annual core profit forecast due to lower commodity costs and steady demand for its products, despite a missed quarterly sales target. The company expects core earnings per share to rise 10-11% this fiscal year, driven by favorable commodity costs. P&G's strong sales in the US and Europe were partially offset by weaker sales of its SK-II skin care line in China. The company now expects a US$900 million after-tax benefit from commodity costs, up from its earlier forecast of US$800 million.

images.alt_text: P&G estimates it would record up to US$2.5 billion in charges over two fiscal years due to the Gillette business write down and restructuring of certain markets.
P&G says it would take a US$1.3 billion non-cash impairment charge before tax in the current quarter ending Dec 31 on its Gillette business.
On Wednesday, P&G said the company’s first-quarter global shipment volumes were weighed down by weakness and volatility in China.
P&G’s results underscore shoppers’ willingness to continue spending in the face of persistent inflation and economic uncertainty.

site_title: DBS puts 46 retail units, HDB shops on market for S$210 million
summary: DBS Bank has put 46 retail units, including 29 HDB shops and shophouses, and 17 private strata retail units, up for sale with a total guide price of S$210 million. The units, previously occupied by full-service bank branches, will be sold individually. DBS plans to lease back the space it currently occupies, with 16 locations being used for 24/7 self-service branches and ATMs. The sale is due to the bank's decision to streamline its branch network and focus on digital banking.

images.alt_text: DFI will enter into a long leaseback arrangement for the 10,624 sq ft space at Siglap V, allowing CS Fresh and Guardian to continue operating there.

krshop - Block 510 Bishan Street 13


Source: GOOGLE MAPS
The tender for Far East Shopping Centre closes at 3pm on May 2.
The FairPrice supermarket space at Block 166 Bukit Merah Central is part of the bundle of nine assets that JBE is buying from Mercatus.

site_title: Picking stocks is a losers’ game
summary: A study by Dimensional Fund Advisors found that few investment funds manage to both survive over time and outperform the market. In equity funds, only 25% of funds that were open 10 years later had outperformed their benchmark. High fees and costs, including trading costs, are associated with underperformance. The study suggests that investors may be better off with a passive-aggressive approach, using index funds with low fees and transparency, rather than trying to beat the market through active management.

images.alt_text: It can be tempting to do dollar-cost averaging for a portfolio that is a tad under the weather.  But we may only be throwing good money after bad in the hope that our average losses will look better.
Compared with the Russell 1000 index, 73 per cent of actively managed large-cap stock mutual funds had better returns.

site_title: UOB Kay Hian says ‘disadvantageous’ to reveal details of key management’s remuneration
summary: UOB Kay Hian, a brokerage firm, has stated that disclosing the remuneration of its key management personnel is "disadvantageous to the business and shareholders' interests" due to the "highly competitive human resource environment." The company cited this as a reason for not disclosing the details of its top five key management personnel's remuneration, which stood at S$6.2 million. UOB Kay Hian also addressed other queries from the Singapore Exchange, including its approach to board diversity and the implications of recent events, such as the death of Wee Cho Yaw and the appointment of Wee Ee Chao as chairman of Haw Par Corporation.

images.alt_text: The brokerage’s commission and trading income for the half hit S$152.9 million, up 9.6 per cent from S$139.6 million in the preceding half, while interest income grew 28.7 per cent from S$101.2 million to S$130.2 million.
Wee Ee Cheong, 71, has led United Overseas Bank (UOB) since 2007.

site_title: Photography is ‘mirror on society’: Sebastiao Salgado
summary: Brazilian photographer Sebastiao Salgado, known for his Amazon work, emphasizes the need to raise awareness about deforestation and climate change. In a 50-year career, he has chronicled society and its impact on the environment. Salgado, 80, continues to work and photograph, saying "photography is the mirror on society" and that together, people can make a difference. He created the Instituto Terra for reforestation and highlights consumerism and water scarcity as major concerns, alongside deforestation.

images.alt_text: According to preliminary satellite data from space research agency INPE, 5,153 square km of the Amazon are cleared in 2023, a 49.9 per cent drop from 2022.

site_title: Xi orders China’s biggest military reorganisation since 2015
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has ordered the biggest military reorganization since 2015, merging the Strategic Support Force with the Information Support Force. The Strategic Support Force, responsible for cyber warfare, will be terminated and its units will be reorganized under the new Information Support Force. The move aims to enhance China's cyber capabilities and provide key support in coordinating the nation's cyber information system. The restructuring follows a sweeping purge by Xi of the military establishment last year and comes as China faces off with the US in a fight for global sway.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping attends the closing session of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on March 10, 2024. (Photo by GREG BAKER / AFP)

site_title: American Express’ premium customers help it surpass profit expectations
summary: American Express surpassed profit expectations in the first quarter driven by an affluent customer base, increasing spending as recession fears ebbed. The company reported a profit of $3.33 per share, beating analysts' average expectation of $2.96. Net Interest Income grew 26% and billed business rose 6% in the quarter. Gen Z and millennial customers accounted for over 60% of new account acquisitions globally, shielding the company from significant economic impact.

images.alt_text: American Express raises its loan loss provisions for the fourth quarter to US$1.44 billion, compared with US$1.03 billion a year earlier.
These watches from the collection will be on offer at Centurion New York.
Gross card fraud per US$100 has fallen to US$0.066 in 2021, from US$0.072 in 2016, according to the Nilson Report, which publishes data on the global card and mobile payment industry.
FILE PHOTO: Credit card is seen in front of displayed American Express logo in this illustration taken, July 15, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Global equity funds see surge in outflows as rate cut hopes fade
summary: Global equity funds experienced their largest weekly net withdrawal since mid-December 2022, with $23.48 billion pulled out in the week ending April 17. The outflows were driven by fading hopes of interest rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve and escalating Middle East tensions. This led to a decline in mega-cap growth stocks and associated mutual funds. In contrast, bond funds and financial sector funds saw inflows, while consumer discretionary and healthcare sectors saw significant outflows.

images.alt_text: The second quarter could see more deals get going, but it still looks like 2024 will be a very bumpy year for private equity firms and the investment banks that rely on them.
Mubadala and an affiliate of Apollo have contributed more than US$290 million into the fund, which has over US$790 million in assets.

Roll-ups of dental clinics can benefit from a lower cost of consumables, more efficient backend administration, greater ability to attract the right manpower and the creation of higher barriers to entry for competitors.

site_title: Smart #1 Pro+ review: How smart is it, really?
summary: The Smart #1 Pro+ is a stylish and fast electric crossover with a unique German-Chinese design and engineering. Powered by a single motor, it delivers 272 hp and 343 Nm of torque, reaching 0-100 kmh in 6.7 seconds. With a 62 kWh battery, it has a range of 420 km and an efficiency of 17.4 kWh/100 km. The car features a spacious interior, with a flat floor and ample head- and legroom, but limited rear cargo space. A 12.8-inch touchscreen and foxy virtual assistant are also notable features, despite some layout issues.

images.alt_text: The Lexus LBX is compact and agile, has a lovely interior, and comes with a hybrid drivetrain made by a company famed for reliability.
The BMW iX1’s electric motor pulls it along with zero vibration, displaying the sort of manners that would please a Rolls-Royce owner.

site_title: US: S&P, Dow open flat as Middle East jitters ease, Netflix weighs on Nasdaq
summary: The US stock market opened flat on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 26.60 points, or 0.07%, to 37,801.98. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened lower, with the S&P 500 down 5.68 points, or 0.11%, and the Nasdaq down 54.40 points, or 0.35%. The decline was partly due to Netflix's disappointing forecast, which weighed on the Nasdaq. Middle East jitters eased, contributing to the flat opening.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JANUARY 19: Traders and media work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on January 19, 2024 in New York City. Stocks closed up over 350 points while the S&P 500 closed at an all-time high on Friday.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: China to facilitate Hong Kong IPOs and expand Stock Connect
summary: China's securities regulator has announced plans to facilitate Hong Kong listings by Chinese companies and expand the Stock Connect cross-border investment scheme. The moves aim to promote Hong Kong as a global financial center and include real estate investment trusts (Reits) and yuan-denominated stocks in the scheme. The expansion will also lower the bar for exchange-traded funds (ETFs) under Stock Connect, bolstering Hong Kong's financial center status and promoting coordinated capital market developments between China and Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Signage for Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd. (HKEx) at the Exchange Square Complex in Hong Kong, China, on Thursday, Feb. 29, 2024. Hong Kong’s stock exchange posted a 13% decline in fourth quarter profit as trading declined and initial public offerings remained weak. Photographer: Chan Long Hei/Bloomberg

“What we’re trying to do is really to deepen some of these connect schemes ... It’s just the beginning of a long journey, especially the southbound flows, the capital or the investments coming out from China into the world,” HKMA CEO Eddie Yue says.
Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index has tumbled nearly 14 per cent in 2023, its fourth consecutive year of decline.

site_title: India central bank cannot let its inflation guard down just yet, MPC minutes show
summary: India's central bank maintained its monetary policy stance, keeping the main lending rate at 6.5% due to inflation concerns, despite a slowdown in economic growth projections. The bank cited the recent Middle East tensions as a potential risk to global oil and commodity prices, which could boost imported inflation in India. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) also warned of potential spillovers to core inflation from overlapping food price shocks.

images.alt_text: Shaktikanta Das, governor of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), during a governor talk at the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank in Marrakesh, Morocco, on Thursday, Oct. 12, 2023. The IMF and World Bank’s first annual meetings in Africa since 1973 were expected to give a spending boost to Morocco’s fourth-largest city and one of its top tourist destinations. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

Reserve Bank of India says it had permitted users, for the ease of doing business, to take positions of up to US$100 million across exchanges without providing documentary evidence to establish the underlying exposure.

site_title: Deutsche Bank has cut dozens in Asia private banking overhaul
summary: Deutsche Bank has cut up to 60 roles in its private banking division in Singapore and Hong Kong over the past year, as the bank focuses on more profitable markets and eliminates underperformers. The cuts include relationship managers and supporting staff, amid a downturn in China's economy and a shift in investor interest to other regions. This move follows similar job cuts by rival UBS Group in Hong Kong and Singapore, and is part of a broader trend among global banks to scale back their presence in China's wealthy market.

images.alt_text: The current strike will affect Postbank's hundreds of branches across Germany and is the last one planned before negotiations resume on Apr 16.
The subindex, made up of eurozone lenders including Deutsche Bank, has risen more than 20 per cent in 2024, far outstripping the 7 per cent gain of the broader Stoxx 600 Index.
Deutsche Bank has been on a hiring spree in Apac since last year to boost its ranks and take market share from Wall Street rivals.

Christian Sewing, chief executive officer of Deutsche Bank, says the German lender will hit a goal of keeping expenses at 5 billion euros (S$7.27 billion) in the first quarter and the full-year figures will be around 20 billion euros.

site_title: Sheng Siong shareholders press for details on capital allocation, M&A opportunities
summary: Sheng Siong shareholders have expressed concerns about the company's capital allocation and mergers and acquisitions (M&A) opportunities, given its S$324 million cash reserve. The company has stated that it will carefully analyze benefits and risks before pursuing M&A opportunities, prioritizing organic growth and focusing on improving customer service and supply chain efficiency. Despite a 3.6% profit increase in the H2 period, shareholders also inquired about the sustainability of the company's growing profit margin and its core strategy targeting heartland malls.

images.alt_text: As at Dec 31, 2023, Sheng Siong owns 69 stores in Singapore, and 5 stores in China, up a total of three stores from a year ago.
Sheng Siong says it is actively working to reduce both its own environmental footprint and that of its supply chain by encouraging SMEs within its network to embrace sustainable business practices.
Sheng Siong supermarket outlet in Yishun St 81 at 2.15pm on 13 May 2020, Day 2 of easing circuit breaker measures.

site_title: Nissan cuts annual operating profit estimate by 14.5% on lower sales
summary: Nissan has cut its annual operating profit estimate by 14.5% to 530 billion yen (S$4.67 billion) due to lower-than-expected vehicle sales and other factors. The company now estimates 3.44 million vehicles will be sold for the year, down from a previous estimate of 3.55 million. Weaker sales in China and the impact of the New Year's Day earthquake on the Noto peninsula were cited as reasons for the lowered estimate.

site_title: Lufthansa evaluates new China routes amid slow recovery in capacity
summary: Lufthansa is evaluating new routes to China as capacity on existing routes has returned to 70% of pre-pandemic levels. The airline sees Chinese travelers making more individual trips, willing to pay for premium services, and is considering adding routes to cities like Shenyang and Qingdao. CEO Jens Ritter expressed confidence in China's economy and plans to increase capacity, but noted the need to resolve delays in aircraft deliveries and overcome visa and airfare challenges that have limited international travel to China.

images.alt_text: Lufthansa expects adjusted earnings before interest and taxes (Ebit) of 2.2 billion euros this year.
FILE PHOTO: Lufthansa planes are seen parked at Frankfurt Airport, Germany,  June 25, 2020. REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach/File Photo

site_title: Repeat of Manchester derby in FA Cup final remains on the cards
summary: The FA Cup semi-finals are set to take place this weekend, with Manchester United facing Coventry City and Manchester City taking on Chelsea. The FA Cup has scrapped replays from the first round onwards, a move aimed at reducing congestion in the fixture calendar. Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag will look to restore confidence after a difficult season, while Manchester City manager Mauricio Pochettino will rely on in-form player Cole Palmer to lead his team to victory. The winners will face each other in the FA Cup final, potentially setting up a repeat of the Manchester derby.

images.alt_text: Nike has stumbled badly over the past several quarters, with a sales slowdown and inventory issues rattling its operations.
England midfielder Kobbie Mainoo made his international debut against Brazil at Wembley in March 2024.
Premier League clubs will likely be limited to spending 85 per cent of their revenue on transfers, wages and agents fees.
Heineken, Carlsberg and Budweiser maker Anheuser-Busch InBev are among the beer companies that will benefit if good weather coincides with the Euro 2024 football tournament in June and July.

site_title: US mortgage rates jump above 7% for the first time this year
summary: US mortgage rates have risen above 7% for the first time this year, with the average 30-year mortgage rate reaching 7.1%, according to Freddie Mac. This increase is attributed to rising 10-year Treasury yields and the Federal Reserve's efforts to combat inflation. As a result, potential homebuyers and sellers are being affected, with some choosing to hold off on buying or selling due to higher rates, and others pushing prices higher due to existing loan rates.

images.alt_text: Home sales dropped 4.3 per cent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.19 million units.

site_title: Israel hits back, markets react; STI down 0.4%
summary: Israel retaliated against Iran's aggression, leading to a 0.4% decline in Singapore's Straits Times Index. Asian indices were mostly down, with Taiwan's TSEC Weighted Index and Japan's Nikkei 225 falling 3.8% and 2.7% respectively. Investors fear further escalation of Middle East tensions, which could lead to market volatility and potential downside. The US Federal funds rate delay and escalation of tensions had been priced in, but the latest developments reignite war worries, prompting market sell-off.

images.alt_text: Before the airports reopened, Flydubai said it had cancelled its Friday flights to Iran. One of its earlier flights turned back to Dubai, it said.
People walk past screens displaying the Hang Seng stock index and stock prices outside the Exchange Square in Hong Kong, China January 23, 2024. REUTERS/Joyce Zhou

Iran’s Fars news agency reported “three explosions” were heard near the Shekari army airbase in the north-west of Isfahan province, while Iran’s space agency spokesman Hossein Dalirian said “several” drones had been “successfully shot down”.

site_title: Hong Kong regulator to probe PwC auditing role over Evergrande
summary: Hong Kong's Accounting and Financial Reporting Council (AFRC) will investigate allegations of deficiencies in PricewaterhouseCoopers' (PwC) auditing systems and quality of audits for China Evergrande Group. The probe follows a whistleblower report expressing concerns over PwC's role in auditing Evergrande, which has been under scrutiny for alleged financial fraud. PwC has denied the allegations and initiated its own investigation. The AFRC may take stringent enforcement actions if misconduct is found, adding to PwC's recent troubles in other regions.

images.alt_text: PwC has been under the spotlight after China launched one of the biggest investigations of financial fraud in history.

site_title: Explosions in Iran, US media reports Israeli strikes
summary: Explosions occurred near Iran's Shekari army airbase in Isfahan province, prompting air defense systems to be activated across several cities. US media reported that Israel carried out retaliatory strikes, following Iran's missile and drone attacks on Israel over the weekend. Iran's space agency confirmed several drones were shot down, but no reports of a missile attack. The incident has raised concerns of a "full-scale regional conflict" in the Middle East, with UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres warning of the devastating consequences.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin slid more than 5.5 per cent to US$59,961 in the Asia session as the US dollar rose broadly.

Smoke rises during an Israeli military operation in Al Nuseirat refugee camp, central Gaza Strip, April 17, 2024. All three major rating firms have put out warnings on Israel’s credit score since the onset of the war with Hamas.

epa11084664 United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres speaks during a plenary session in the Congress Hall as part of the 54th annual meeting of the World Economic Forum (WEF), in Davos, Switzerland, 17 January 2024. The meeting brings together entrepreneurs, scientists, corporate and political leaders in Davos under the topic 'Rebuilding Trust' from 15 to 19 January.  EPA-EFE/GIAN EHRENZELLER
“A lot of guys will pile into the market, trying to make a quick buck. Brokers need to be aware of which are the right ones, which aren’t,” Marine insurance underwriter Chris Lambe advises.
Spot gold was up 0.4 per cent at US$2,369.93 per ounce.
Even if the tit-for-tat between Israel and Iran escalates, it is unlikely to change much. Any reduction in Iran’s exports might be balanced by more pumping from the rest of Opec.

Objects seen in the sky above Jerusalem on April 14 after Iran launched drones and missiles towards Israel hours earlier. The prospect of war in the Middle East has hurt investor sentiment, but is unlikely to affect stocks in the long run.

site_title: Robot at your service: Singapore companies ride global wave to build next-gen robots
summary: Singapore companies are embracing the global trend of building next-generation robots, which are increasingly being used for cleaning, food delivery, and security purposes. The country's National Robotics Programme (NRP) has provided over $450 million in funding to support robotics development, with companies like LionsBot and Kabam Robotics making a name for themselves in the industry. Despite challenges in securing funding and achieving financial sustainability, robotics startups remain optimistic about the future, with some companies experiencing significant growth in sales and market share.

images.alt_text: Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan (left) and chief executive officer of LionsBot, Dylan Ng (right) at the launch of LionsBot's new S$12 million facility in Kranji.

site_title: Issue 96: South-east Asia’s outsized green gap; Singapore banks on sustainability wave in finance
summary: South-east Asia's US$1.5 trillion green investment gap is approximately 40% of the region's combined GDP in 2022, and it is unlikely to be closed by 2030. The gap is estimated to require an immediate annual investment of US$208 billion per year or a 70% annual growth rate for seven years. The Singapore government has been spending 15-18% of its GDP on green initiatives, and increasing private and foreign direct investments could help close the gap. However, the region's climate goals are not ambitious enough, and South-east Asia has a high chance of missing its targets, emphasizing the need for adaptation investments.

images.alt_text: Minister Grace Fu said the election year will throw up challenges for implementing climate policies.
Projects include the early decommissioning of coal power plants.
Capital is not flowing to where it needs to be, said MAS' chief sustainability officer Gillian Tan.
Palm oil producer First Resources was responding to allegations made by The Gecko Project.
Temasek CEO said lawyers will be integral in shaping governance standards and legal frameworks for ESG.

site_title: Fourth money laundering accused Zhang Ruijin to plead guilty on Apr 30
summary: A fourth suspect, Zhang Ruijin, is set to plead guilty on April 30 for his role in a S$3 billion money laundering case. Zhang faces three charges related to forging bank documents to cheat CIMB Bank. His assets, totaling S$109.8 million, have been seized or prohibited from disposal. Zhang and his girlfriend, Lin Baoying, are among 10 foreign nationals accused in the case, with Lin also facing charges for her involvement.

images.alt_text: Suspects in the money laundering case have ties to dozens of companies, including two with a registered office address at Telok Ayer (above).
A rear view of the parcel of land at 69 Ocean Drive in Sentosa Cove, covered by a sound barrier, on Apr 15.
Su Wenqiang is the first of the 10 foreign nationals arrested in the anti-money laundering bust to plead guilty.
Su, originally from China, holds a Cambodian passport.
Su Haijin was formerly a director of Catalist-listed food and beverage operator No Signboard.
Chinese passport holder Wang Baosen (left) was handed 8 charges related to money laundering, forgery and lying to the authorities.

site_title: China’s Jan-March foreign investment inflows down 26%
summary: China's foreign investment inflows decreased 26% in the first quarter of 2024 compared to the same period last year, following a 26.1% contraction in 2023. Total foreign direct investment (FDI) reached 301.7 billion yuan (S$56.8 billion) in January to March, with investments in the manufacturing, accommodation, and construction industries rising. However, concerns over a new anti-espionage law, exit bans, and raids on consultancies have deterred foreign investors, with no specific sectors mentioned as seeing year-on-year declines. Chinese officials continue to step up efforts to attract investors.

images.alt_text: China’s nominal GDP growth rate of 4.2 per cent in the first quarter was considerably below the real growth rate, mainly dragged down by weak prices.
Total air passenger traffic reached almost 180 million trips in the first three months of 2024.
China’s manufacturing drive has exacerbated tensions with trading partners.
Consumer prices fell for several months from August, before rising 0.7 per cent in February.

The yuan has lost about 1.9 per cent in value against the US dollar so far this year, pressured by its relative low yields versus other currencies and outflows of foreign investment from an anaemic stock market.

site_title: Wilmar appoints former minister George Yeo as independent non-executive director
summary: Wilmar International has appointed former Singapore Minister George Yeo as an independent non-executive director, effective immediately. Yeo, 69, holds 400,000 shares in the agribusiness giant and has no current affiliations with substantial shareholders Kuok and Kerry groups. The board approved his appointment after reviewing his qualifications, experience, and independence, citing his ability to provide valuable insights on global business and political issues.

images.alt_text: Bursa Malaysia-listed crude palm oil futures are up about 20.8 per cent this year as at Mar 4 at RM4,345 per tonne. This is the highest price CPO futures have reached in a one-year period.
Wilmar International's chairman and chief executive, Kuok Khoon Hong, expects tough operating conditions to continue into FY2024.
Robert Kuok is the 112th richest person globally is turning 100 years old in October this year, with a net worth of US$11.8 billion

site_title: Chinese carmaker Chery to employ 1,250 people at Spanish plant
summary: Chinese carmaker Chery plans to create 1,250 jobs and produce 150,000 electric vehicles per year at its new plant in Barcelona, Spain, starting in 2027. The joint venture, majority owned by Ebro-EV Motors, will revive a factory previously shut down by Nissan in 2021. The project aims to boost Spain's reindustrialization efforts, with Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez attending the signing ceremony. Chery will initially recruit 150 employees and plans to increase production to 50,000 vehicles per year by 2027, rising to 150,000 by 2029.

images.alt_text: Chery joins a growing number of Chinese automakers, with European expansion plans as competition intensifies at home and domestic growth eases.

site_title: Middle East violence heightens market fears of rate hikes, inflation
summary: The Federal Reserve is considering a rate hike instead of a cut due to rising inflation and global market fears. The US central bank's next action could be influenced by ongoing Middle East violence, which may lead to higher oil prices and inflation. Some economists, like Joe Rinaldi, predict a 10% chance of a full-blown Middle Eastern war, which could trigger a 10% increase in oil prices and inflation to 4%. The Fed's pivot from rate cuts to a potential hike is seen as a response to its previous misapprehension of inflation as a "transitory" phenomenon.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic said he still believes inflation is on the path to the central bank’s 2 per cent goal, but he noted that path is likely to be slower than people expect.

BOE policymaker Megan Greene remarks that the numbers they are observing regarding wage growth and services inflation are not consistent with a sustainable 2 per cent (consumer price) inflation target.

(From left) Krishna Srinivasan, director of the IMF’s Asia and Pacific department and Thomas Helbling, deputy director of the IMF's Asia Pacific Department at the press conference following the release of the IMF’s Regional Economic Outlook for Asia and Pacific on Tuesday. They recommend Asia central banks to focus on their domestic fundamentals in making monetary policies.
Home sales dropped 4.3 per cent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.19 million units.

site_title: Far East Shopping Centre back on market at unchanged S$928 million asking price
summary: Far East Shopping Centre, a 999-year leasehold property in Singapore, has been put back on the market with an unchanged asking price of S$928 million. The tender, which closes on May 2, follows a deal that was pulled out by Glory Property Developments in September 2023 due to URA rejection of its redevelopment proposal under the Strategic Development Incentive (SDI) scheme. The property, built in 1974, is suitable for an integrated mixed-use redevelopment, subject to URA approval.

images.alt_text: The S$910 million collective sale of Far East Shopping Centre is said to have fallen through.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 19)
summary: Far East Shopping Centre has been put back on the market with an unchanged asking price of S$928 million. The US Federal Reserve faces concerns about inflation and rate hikes due to ongoing violence in the Middle East. Patec Precision Industry posted a lower Q1 DPU of S$0.02192 amid loss allowances. CSE Global secured a US$36.5 million contract extension for data centre solutions in the Americas. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,176.51 points, down 0.4% following Israel's retaliation against Iran's aggression.

images.alt_text: The Far East Shopping Center on Orchard Road in Singapore, on Thursday, April 11, 2024. A blockbuster deal backed by a Chinese commodities billionaire to purchase a mall in Singapore's prime shopping district for about S$908 million ($671 million) fell apart after plans for its redevelopment were rejected by authorities, according to people with knowledge of the matter. Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

site_title: Japanese AI tool predicts when recruits will quit jobs
summary: A Japanese AI tool developed by Tokyo City University professor Naruhiko Shiratori helps managers predict when new recruits are likely to quit their jobs. The tool analyzes data on employees, including attendance records and personal information, to create a turnover model for each firm. It then predicts which new hires are at risk of quitting in percentage points. The AI tool is being tested with several companies and may soon suggest suitable assignments for new employees based on job interviews and personal histories.

images.alt_text: Initial claims for state unemployment benefits were unchanged at a seasonally adjusted 212,000 for the week ended Apr 13.
Figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Thursday showed net employment dropped 6,600 in March from February, when it rose a revised 117,600.
Cho Na Young, 22, a university student seeking job opportunities, Seoul, South Korea, April 10, 2024.

site_title: CSE Global bags US$36.5 million data centre contract extension
summary: CSE Global has secured a US$36.5 million contract extension to design and integrate power-management systems in the Americas region from Q1 2024 to Q4 2025. The contract is part of the initial US$36.5 million contract bagged in 2022. Group managing director Lim Boon Kheng expects the project to positively impact CSE's financial performance for 2024-2025. The company aims to double its manufacturing and integration capacity to support the contract, driven by the growing demand for cloud services in the data-centre market.

images.alt_text: CSE Global, a mainboard-listed automation solutions provider, plans to evaluate investment opportunities in the US, Australia and New Zealand.
Each new share will be priced at S$0.40 a piece. Above: CSE Global group managing director and CEO Lim Boon Kheng.

CSE Global group managing director Lim Boon Kheng said: “These new contracts will strengthen our pursuit in the infrastructure sector, which is currently driven by the growing megatrends of urbanisation and electrification.”
Lim Boon Kheng, group managing director and chief executive officer of CSE Global.
CSE Global chief executive Lim Boon Kheng says that the group is actively expanding its electrification and critical communications businesses.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei drops more than 1,000 points, most in 3 years
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index plummeted 2.66% or 1,011.35 points to 37,068.35, its largest fall in over three years, amid reports of Israel's strikes on Iran and chip giant TSMC's warning of weakening macroeconomic conditions. The semiconductor sector led the decline, with major shares such as Tokyo Electron and Advantest plummeting 8.74% and 4.38%, respectively. Tensions in the Middle East and uncertainty surrounding the market contributed to the sharp decline, with the dollar rising to 154.37 yen.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei 225 index was down 3.08 per cent, or 1,170.97 points, to 36,908.73 at around 0145 GMT on Friday.

site_title: Higher gross rental income, lower expenses boost CICT’s Q1 NPI by 6.3%
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) reported a 6.3% increase in net property income (NPI) to S$293.7 million for Q1, driven by higher gross rental income and lower expenses. Gross revenue rose 2.6% to S$398.6 million. CICT also commenced asset enhancement initiatives for IMM Building in Singapore and Gallileo in Frankfurt. The trust's portfolio committed occupancy remained at 97%, while its aggregate leverage stood at 40%.

images.alt_text: CLI holds a 5.1 per cent interest in Gallileo while the CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) owns the remaining majority stake
CICT's improving operational performance has been keeping analysts positive on its units
The manager attributes the improvement in performance to higher contributions from Raffles City Singapore and full-year contributions from the Reit’s 2022 acquisitions.

site_title: Cordlife calls for trading halt after shares sink to all-time low, pending announcement
summary: Cordlife Group's shares plummeted 15.2% to an all-time low, trading at S$0.123, before a trading halt was requested pending an announcement. The company proposed a S$8.2 million raise by issuing 51.2 million new shares at S$0.16 apiece. Cordlife also filed a police report against former employees following an internal investigation into potential damage to stored cord-blood units. The company's stock has been affected by concerns over the safety of its cord-blood storage facilities.

site_title: Tensions mount in foreign exchange markets as US dollar surges
summary: The US dollar is surging in foreign exchange markets due to changing monetary policy expectations and geopolitical turmoil. The dollar's strength is fueled by robust US economic activity, inflation concerns, and protectionist pressures. The European Central Bank is expected to cut rates in June, further exacerbating the dollar's dominance. China's renminbi is under pressure due to massive capital outflows and the country's economic challenges, while Japan's yen is weak due to its sharp depreciation against the dollar. The dollar's breakout is seen as a reflection of a risk-on economy and risk-off geopolitics, with fears of fragmentation and protectionism further fueling the market's sentiment.

images.alt_text: (From left) Krishna Srinivasan, director of the IMF’s Asia and Pacific department and Thomas Helbling, deputy director of the IMF's Asia Pacific Department at the press conference following the release of the IMF’s Regional Economic Outlook for Asia and Pacific on Tuesday. They recommend Asia central banks to focus on their domestic fundamentals in making monetary policies.
The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index, which tracks the US currency against 12 of its major peers, has risen by more than 4 per cent this year.

site_title: London mansions sold at 30% discount spell gloom for luxury market
summary: London's luxury real estate market is experiencing a slump due to a proposed UK budget that aims to scrap preferential tax treatment for wealthy foreign residents. The move is expected to scare away investors, leading to price cuts and a buyers' market. A recent sale of a £27 million London mansion, discounted by 33% from its original price, highlights the trend. The high-end market, including the country home market, is also feeling the effects, with price reductions and a lack of deals reported in various locations.

images.alt_text: The number of homes sold for more than £5 million (S$8.5 million) in January is down 17 per cent from last year.

Luxury properties in the Kensington and Chelsea district of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 21, 2023. Britain's intensifying mortgage crunch is now forcing London’s wealthiest home sellers to agree to discounts or risk deals falling through. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: India votes in gigantic election dominated by jobs, Hindu pride and Modi
summary: India began voting in its historic election, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) facing off against a two-decade opposition alliance. The seven-phase election, set to conclude on June 1, is the world's largest, with nearly a billion eligible voters. Modi's BJP promises growth, welfare, and Hindu nationalism, while the opposition coalition vows greater affirmative action and protection of democratic institutions. Surveys suggest the BJP will easily win a majority, despite voter concerns over unemployment and rural distress.

images.alt_text: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is widely tipped to win a record-equalling third term in the general election, which begins on Friday.

Job applicants give a mock test for railway entrance exams at Platform coaching centre at Musallahpur Haat in Patna, the capital city of the eastern state of Bihar in India in 2022. Over half of India’s 1.4 billion people are aged under 30, according to government health figures.
Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is confident of victory in the upcoming parliamentary elections; many Indians are buying into the hope his party has raised.

site_title: Britain’s retail sales disappoint in sign of lacklustre recovery
summary: UK retail sales stalled in March, with a 0.1% gain after a revised 0.1% increase the previous month, missing economists' expectations of a 0.3% increase. The sector contributed 0.09 percentage point to GDP in the first quarter, with fuel sales providing a lift despite overall sales falling 0.3% excluding auto fuel. Consumer spending remains fragile due to the cost-of-living crisis, and retailers are resorting to price cuts to attract shoppers.

images.alt_text: Crowds of shoppers on Oxford Street in London, UK, on Monday, Dec. 18, 2023. The Office for National Statistics are due to release the latest UK retail sales figures on Friday. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg
Higher food prices have prompted even affluent shoppers to switch to cheaper grocers such as Aldi and Lidl.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) increasing 4.64 points to 3,192.3, driven by gains in Thai Beverage and Genting Singapore. Despite overnight losses on Wall Street, analysts expect reduced Federal Reserve action. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS and OCBC advancing, while UOB slipped. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.5% on Wall Street amid rising US Treasury bond yields.

images.alt_text: CICT posts a 6.3 per cent rise in net property income for the first quarter of 2024 to S$293.7 million.

site_title: Gold set for fifth weekly gain as geopolitical risks buoy demand
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $2,388.49 per ounce, on track for its fifth weekly gain, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid Middle East tensions and US interest rate uncertainty. The US announced new sanctions on Iran, while Federal Reserve policymakers considered holding interest rates steady. Labor market strength, as measured by unemployment claims, also supported gold prices.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin slid more than 5.5 per cent to US$59,961 in the Asia session as the US dollar rose broadly.
Spot gold was up 0.4 per cent at US$2,369.93 per ounce.

site_title: A cheat sheet of startup and tech M&As in South-east Asia
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Tech In Asia, a leading publication, has compiled a cheat sheet of recent startup and tech mergers and acquisitions (M&As) in South-east Asia. The region's M&A landscape has seen significant milestones, presenting opportunities and risks for economies. Notable deals include GoTo's rebound after a $2.2 billion sell-off and SMCCI and Maybank's collaboration to support Malay or Muslim-owned enterprises in Singapore and Malaysia. The article also highlights the impact of supply-chain reconfiguration on economies in South-east Asia, with some countries experiencing growth jitters and others benefiting from foreign investment. Key deals are tracked and analyzed.

TerraPay joins the growing list of MPI license holders in Singapore, which includes fintech firm Payoneer, USDC issuer Circle, and a unit of payments major PayerMax.
RedDoorz, which plans to expand into Malaysia, follows a multibranding strategy.

site_title: Taiwan says new Chinese air routes threaten islands' flight safety
summary: Taiwan has expressed concerns over China's decision to operate new air routes that pass perilously close to two Taiwanese-controlled islands, citing a flight safety risk. The routes, which connect to existing flights to the islands, were announced days before Taiwan's President-elect Lai Ching-te's inauguration. Taiwan's government has demanded that aircraft using the new routes be asked to turn around, amid concerns that the routes could compromise the safety of flights to and from the islands. China claims Taiwan as its own territory, but Taiwan considers the islands to be part of its own territory.

images.alt_text: (FILES) People walk past a Taiwanese flag in New Taipei City on January 13, 2024. Taiwan's freshly elected lawmakers will meet from February 1, 2024 with a new party emerging with an outsized influence over legislation after breaking through the self-ruled island's long-entrenched two-party system. (Photo by Sam Yeh / AFP)

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index tumbles 3% in morning trade
summary: The Nikkei 225 index in Tokyo plummeted 3.08% in morning trade, falling 1,170.97 points to 36,908.73, following a decline in tech shares on Wall Street and heightened Middle East tensions. The broader Topix index also fell 2.53% to 2,609.80. The drop was attributed to market volatility and uncertainty, with investors reacting to recent tensions in the Middle East and ongoing US-EU trade talks.

images.alt_text: A man walks past an electronic board displaying stock prices of Nikkei 225 listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange along a street in Tokyo on April 12, 2024. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers
The Dow Jones Industrial Average eked out a 0.1 per cent gain at 37,775.38 on Thursday..

site_title: Airlines scramble to change routes after Israeli attack on Iran
summary: Airlines quickly altered flight paths over Iran after an Israeli attack, diverting planes to alternate airports or returning them to departure points. Iran closed its airports in Teheran, Shiraz, and Isfahan, but later reopened them and cleared flights from the western portion of its airspace. Airlines such as Flydubai, Emirates, and Turkish Air continued to fly over the open airspace, while others like Lufthansa suspended flights to Teheran until the end of the month. The airspace and airport closures compounded a difficult week for Dubai-based carriers, with 1,478 flights cancelled to and from Dubai.

images.alt_text: People walk past screens displaying the Hang Seng stock index and stock prices outside the Exchange Square in Hong Kong, China January 23, 2024. REUTERS/Joyce Zhou

Capital outflows are putting pressure on the renminbi. The renminbi’s weakness against the dollar constrains monetary policy accommodation, and China's authorities are wary of deploying large fiscal stimulus due to high leverage.

Iran’s Fars news agency reported “three explosions” were heard near the Shekari army airbase in the north-west of Isfahan province, while Iran’s space agency spokesman Hossein Dalirian said “several” drones had been “successfully shot down”.
US Deputy Ambassador to the UN Robert Wood votes against a resolution allowing Palestinian UN membership at United Nations headquarters in New York, April 18, 2024.

site_title: Australia fines Macquarie Bank US$6.4 million for not preventing unlawful third-party transactions
summary: Macquarie Bank has been fined US$6.4 million by the Federal Court of Australia for failing to prevent unauthorized third-party transactions on customer accounts. The bank allowed customers to grant third parties, such as financial advisers, different levels of transaction authority, including fee withdrawals. Between 2016 and 2020, a financial adviser made fraudulent withdrawals of around A$2.9 million without being detected. Macquarie has since reimbursed affected clients and agreed to pay the fine, acknowledging its earlier failures in implementing controls to detect and prevent unauthorized transactions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Australia's biggest investment bank Macquarie Group Ltd adorns the main entrance to their Sydney office headquarters in Australia, October 28, 2016. REUTERS/David Gray
Nick O'Kane's renumeration for the year to March 2023 was A$57.6 million (S$50.5 million), up 59% from a year ago.
The bank says that net other operating income for the second half of 2024 is expected to be substantially down on last year.

site_title: Inside TSMC chairman Mark Liu's short but impactful reign
summary: TSMC Chairman Mark Liu's brief but impactful reign has led to significant growth, with a 252% stock rise and a market value exceeding $720 billion. His tenure has also prioritized environmental, social, and governance (ESG) initiatives, including large renewable energy purchases. Global expansion has been a hallmark, with investments in the US, Japan, and Germany, and the development of a crucial chip technology, Cowos, enabling powerful AI chips. Liu's legacy will be remembered for its sustainability, global expansion, and technological advancements.

images.alt_text: TSMC has gained about US$340 billion of market value since an October 2022 trough.
SK hynix dominates the market for HBM chips - crucial components to power artificial intelligence - and is a top supplier to US-based chip titan Nvidia. TSMC also supplies Nvidia.

site_title: Malaysia’s economy likely grew 3.9% yoy in Q1: advance estimate
summary: Malaysia's economy is estimated to have grown 3.9% in the first quarter of 2024, driven by a 4.4% year-on-year increase in the services sector. This growth outpaced the annual growth of 3.0% in the final quarter of 2023, when subdued exports weighed on growth. The positive growth was attributed to the wholesale and retail trade, transport and storage, and business services sub-sectors.

images.alt_text: RHB Bank had mobilised RM23.8 billion in green financing as of end 2023, exceeding its initial target of RM20 billion by 2026 under their sustainability strategy launched in 2022.
The Malaysian flag carrier will reroute flights to avoid airspace over parts of the Middle East, requiring more fuel and spurring the need to lighten its load.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CICT, Seatrium, Keppel DC Reit, UOB
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) posted a 6.3% rise in net property income to S$293.7 million for the first quarter of 2024, driven by higher gross rental income and lower operating expenses. Seatrium's unit was ordered to pay US$108 million to MHWirth, resulting in a 1.3% drop in its counter price. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: ‘Smart people’ don’t need oversight: Elon Musk
summary: Elon Musk is pushing back on his reputation as a micromanager, stating that "smart people" don't need oversight. In an interview, Musk emphasized the importance of attention to detail in product creation, but argued that he doesn't micromanage, rather, he "insists on attention to detail." He advised setting clear goals and allowing employees to manage themselves, suggesting that intelligent and talented individuals can self-regulate and achieve results. Musk cited examples of other demanding bosses, including Steve Jobs and Bill Gates, in support of his approach.

images.alt_text: South African businessman Elon Musk arrives at the Tenth Breakthrough Prize Ceremony at the Academy Museum of Motion Pictures in Los Angeles, California, on April 13, 2024. (Photo by ETIENNE LAURENT / AFP)

site_title: Bitcoin slides below US$60,000 on reports Israel strikes Iran
summary: Bitcoin plummeted below US$60,000 after reports of an Israeli missile strike on Iran, with prices sliding over 5.5% to US$59,961 in the Asia session. The US dollar's rise also contributed to the decline. Ether fell by a similar margin to US$2,895. The news led to a rush out of risky assets, causing oil, gold, and bonds to rally.

site_title: Asean says ‘deeply concerned’ over escalating Myanmar violence
summary: Regional bloc Asean expressed "deep concern" over escalating violence in Myanmar, following clashes over a key trading hub near the Thai border. The foreign ministers urged an immediate cessation of violence, amid a string of battlefield losses suffered by Myanmar's junta in recent months. This is the latest move from Asean to address the ongoing conflict since the military seized power in a February 2021 coup.

images.alt_text: Aung San Suu Kyi is serving a 27-year sentence for a host of criminal convictions ranging from corruption to breaching Covid-19 rules.
Thai Foreign Minister Parnpree Bahiddha-Nukara at a border checkpoint on the Thai-Myanmar boder. He is working with Asean on a stalled peace plan for Myanmar, known as its five-point consensus.
Myanmar is in the throes of an insurgency on multiple fronts, with allied anti-junta groups backed by a pro-democracy parallel government seizing control of several military posts and towns.
The United Nations has said at least 2.6 million people have been displaced by the fighting in Myanmar, and more than 18 million people are in need of assistance.

site_title: Apple removes WhatsApp, Threads from China app store on government order
summary: Apple has removed WhatsApp, Threads, Telegram, and Signal from its China App Store at the government's request, citing national security concerns. The move indicates growing intolerance towards foreign messaging services in China. Other Meta apps, including Facebook and Instagram, remain available, while the apps were previously accessible through virtual private networks. The removal follows China's new registration rule for apps, which came into effect on April 1.

images.alt_text: The Singapore plans are subject to change, and Apple has not made Tim Cook’s schedule in the region public.
A rendering of Apple's upcoming, expanded campus in Ang Mo Kio.
Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh (R) meeting Apple CEO Tim Cook (L) at the Government Office in Hanoi on Apr 16, 2024. Apple is increasing its commitments to Vietnam by an unspecified amount.

site_title: Gazelle Ventures makes cash offer for No Signboard shares at S$0.0021 apiece
summary: Gazelle Ventures has made a mandatory unconditional cash offer to acquire all issued and paid-up ordinary shares of No Signboard, a Singapore-listed restaurant operator, at S$0.0021 per share, a 97.5% discount from the last transacted price. The offeror aims to provide sufficient funds for the company's working capital and maintain its listing status. The offer will close on May 16.

No Signboard has shuttered a few restaurants.

site_title: Hedge funds cry foul over China education firm’s default
summary: Hedge funds and international investors are sounding the alarm after a Chinese education company, XJ International Holdings, defaulted on its $315 million convertible bonds in March. The company, which operates 24 schools in China, claims it's having difficulty redeeming the bonds due to external factors. A group of bondholders, including prominent hedge funds, has accused the company of avoiding its debt obligations and not engaging with them. The default could set a precedent for the broader market, with some experts warning of a sector-wide reassessment of credit risk.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) building in Beijing, China, on Monday, June 26, 2023. China's consumer-driven recovery is showing more signs of losing momentum as spending slows on everything from holiday travel to cars and homes, adding to expectations for more stimulus to support the economy. Source: Bloomberg
Fan Yifei is now accused of illegally receiving “property worth more than 386 million yuan (S$72.5 million).

To plug a capital shortfall, the five Chinese largest lenders this year have announced plans to issue as much as 440 billion yuan of TLAC bonds in total, with issuance of the bonds could be as soon as the second quarter this year.
UBS will shut up to 17 of its equity and bond private funds and return the money to the investors, out of 19 funds launched since the private fund management unit started in 2016.
Salesforce chief executive officer Benioff has been grappling with activist hedge funds pressing the company to run a tighter ship.
New York has long counted on the highest earners – many of whom are in finance – to balance its US$100 billion-plus budget.

Pedestrians cross a street in the Central district in Hong Kong, China, on Monday, Nov. 20, 2023. site_title: US veto sinks Palestinian UN membership bid in Security Council
summary: The US vetoed a UN Security Council resolution allowing Palestinian UN membership, despite 12 countries voting in favor. The US, Israel's key ally, has not supported Palestinian statehood, citing a need for a peace deal with Israel. The veto was seen as a setback for the Palestinian bid, with Palestinian leaders vowing to continue their efforts for statehood. The US position is unchanged, stating that the UN is not the venue for recognition of a Palestinian state, and that a two-state solution requires direct negotiations between the parties.

images.alt_text: epa11084664 United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres speaks during a plenary session in the Congress Hall as part of the 54th annual meeting of the World Economic Forum (WEF), in Davos, Switzerland, 17 January 2024. “A lot of guys will pile into the market, trying to make a quick buck. Brokers need to be aware of which are the right ones, which aren’t,” Marine insurance underwriter Chris Lambe advises.

Objects seen in the sky above Jerusalem on April 14 after Iran launched drones and missiles towards Israel hours earlier. The prospect of war in the Middle East has hurt investor sentiment, but is unlikely to affect stocks in the long run.

Iranian demonstrators show support during an anti-Israeli gathering at Palestine Square in Tehran, April 14, 2024, after Iran retaliated directly against Israel for the killings of its senior generals in Damascus, Syria, with an onslaught of more than 300 drones and missiles.

Gigi Coffee’s group CEO Marcus Low told ST that the chain has seen an uptick in sales.
Displaced Palestinians flee the war between Israel and Hamas in the northern Gaza Strip, walking to its southern section, Nov 26, 2023.

site_title: Pro-China local leader ousted in Solomon Islands election
summary: China's bid to expand influence in the Solomon Islands took a setback with the ousting of pro-China Premier Martin Fini in the country's recent election. Fini, who signed a memorandum of understanding with China's Jiangsu province, lost his re-election bid, casting doubt on Beijing's plans for the province of Malaita. Fini's predecessor, Daniel Suidani, had previously refused to accept Chinese aid and investment, and Suidani attributed Fini's downfall to China's growing influence in the country. The outcome highlights concerns about China's expanding presence in the Pacific region.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping attends the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Summit in San Francisco, California, U.S. November 17, 2023. REUTERS/Carlos Barria

Australia’s Prime Minister Anthony Albanese (right) reacts as he speaks during a press conference with Papua New Guinea’s Prime Minister James Marape at Parliament House in Canberra, Australia. Dec 7, 2023.

China's ambassador to Solomon Islands Li Ming (left) sits with officials aboard a Chinese naval hospital ship after it arrived into Honiara, Solomon Islands on Aug 19, 2023. Solomon Islands and Kiribati both severed diplomatic links with Taiwan in September 2019, switching to Beijing in the wake of a sustained charm offensive.

“The United States is committed to ensuring an Indo-Pacific region that is free, open, prosperous, and secure. We’re committed to working with all the nations around this table to achieve that goal,” Joe Biden says.
US President Joe Biden  will host a second summit with Pacific island leaders this week.

site_title: Layoff whiplash scars US workers who find new jobs only to lose them
summary: US workers who experience multiple layoffs in a short span are facing significant challenges, questioning their career choices and self-worth. The ongoing job cuts, particularly in sectors like recruitment and marketing, have left many on edge, with a growing number of jobseekers expecting to be laid off within the next six months. To cope, workers are adopting strategies such as self-examination, networking, and skill-building, and some are even considering alternative career paths, like entrepreneurship or contract work. Despite the uncertainty, jobseekers' confidence in landing a new role is slowly increasing, with evidence suggesting the job market is starting to improve.

images.alt_text: Google let go of hundreds of workers across multiple teams in January as the company ramps up investment and builds its artificial intelligence offerings.

site_title: SK hynix, Taiwan’s TSMC to collaborate on next-gen chips
summary: SK hynix, the world's second-largest memory chipmaker, will collaborate with TSMC to produce next-generation high-bandwidth memory (HBM) chips for artificial intelligence technology. The collaboration aims to develop HBM4, the sixth generation of HBM, which will be mass produced from 2026. TSMC's advanced logic process will be used to produce customized HBM that meets customer demand for performance and power efficiency. The two companies will also work together to optimize the integration of their HBM and CoWoS packaging processes.

images.alt_text: AMD said the new chips are expected to be available in platforms from HP and Lenovo starting in the second quarter of 2024.

Commerce Department says the companies are “involved with providing AI chips to China’s military modernisation programmes” and military intelligence users.
Meta’s pivot to AI services has brought increased demand for computing power.

site_title: IMF boss says ‘all eyes’ on US amid risks to global economy
summary: IMF head Kristalina Georgieva warns that the global economy is closely watching the US due to potential spillovers from its interest rates and industrial policies. The two biggest issues are inflation and interest rates, and how the US will navigate a world of more intrusive government policies. Georgieva stated, "All eyes are on the US," emphasizing the global community's focus on the US economy.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates in the US make life difficult for many countries by strengthening the value of the US dollar against other currencies.

(FILES) The International Monetary Fund (IMF) logo is displayed outside its headquarters in Washington, DC, on October 8, 2022. site_title: Caught up in crypto fever? Heed lessons from 2022
summary: The Bitcoin halving, set to occur this weekend, may prompt a bull market, but it's essential to consider past lessons. The previous three halvings showed heightened market activity and price rallies followed by correction phases. While demand for Bitcoin may increase, investors should be cautious and selective about platforms. The industry has undergone a transformation since the 2022 crisis, with improved regulation and professional management. Investors should conduct due diligence on platforms, check for licenses, audited certifications, and experienced management, and consider decentralized exchanges for added security.

images.alt_text: The halving will cut the amount of Bitcoin that so-called miners can earn each day for validating transactions to 450 from 900.

Branding for Bitcoin cryptocurrency on the window of a crypto exchange kiosk in Warsaw, Poland, on Thursday, March 14, 2024.
