Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

site_title: Valuations for office Reits lag counterparts, but re-rating may face uncertainty
summary: Singapore office real estate investment trusts (Reits) are trading at a significant discount to their book value, with average prices-to-book (P/B) ratios ranging from 35% to 50% lower than their peers. Despite stable fundamentals, including a 15-year high in office rents, analysts attribute the discounts to high interest costs and a weaker outlook. Re-rating is seen as dependent on faster interest rate cuts, improved business outlook, and more active capital recycling by managers. Analysts suggest that internalizing management models and reducing acquisitions that disadvantage minority shareholders could also help narrow the discount.

images.alt_text: Analysts told The Business Times that operational performance for Reits are expected to stay resilient, but distributions per unit (DPU) would likely remain under pressure from financing costs.
Valuations of Singapore's prime office towers may be too rich considering looming threats to the office property sector.

site_title: Indonesia awards 45 billion yen contract to Japan’s Sojitz for Jakarta MRT extension
summary: Indonesia has awarded a 45 billion yen (S$399.6 million) contract to Japan's Sojitz Corporation to extend the Jakarta Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system, with the line set to open in 2029. The 5.8 km underground extension will reduce traveling time and connect Bundaran Hotel Indonesia to Kota station. The project is part of the North-South Line, a 23.3 km development that will connect North and South Jakarta. The contract will run for up to 75 months and is backed by a Japanese government loan.

images.alt_text: Indonesian giant property developer Agung Sedayu Group is building a 1,775 hectares tourism estate on the northen coast Jakarta called Pantai Indah Kapuk 2.

site_title: UK financial sector seeks stronger accountability of regulators
summary: The UK financial sector is pushing for stronger accountability of regulators, citing increased competition from the EU and New York. The government has announced reforms to boost capital markets, including objectives for the Financial Conduct Authority and Prudential Regulation Authority to aid international competitiveness and economic growth. A new sector-wide body may help ensure regulators comply with their new remit, addressing concerns over inconsistent rule-making.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA), the Britain's financial regulatory body, and the Payment Systems Regulator (PSR) is seen at their head offices in London, Britain March 10, 2022. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: Japan’s core inflation slows in March, weak yen complicates BOJ move
summary: Japan's core inflation slowed to 2.6% in March, down from 2.8% in February, as food price increases decelerated. The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) closely watched price index fell below 3% for the first time in over a year. Analysts attribute the slowdown to yen weakness, which could complicate the BOJ's policy deliberations. The BOJ is expected to keep short-term interest rates unchanged at its next meeting on April 26, amid concerns over service price increases and wage growth.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, March 19, 2024. The BOJ ended the most aggressive monetary stimulus program in modern history, scrapping the world's last negative interest rate and a raft of unconventional tools, while leaving the course of additional hikes unclear. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg
Results of the closely watched pay talks are announced in several stages, led by blue-chip firms in March and followed by small firms concluding talks around the middle of the year.

(Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)
With over 1,300 square metres over three floors, the shop is expected to cater to local shoppers and tourists alike.
The total of 3.08 million represented an increase of 69.5 per cent from March 2023 and a 11.6-per cent gain compared to March 2019 before the pandemic battered global tourism.

site_title: Oil jumps, equities fall as Iran blasts fan Middle East tensions
summary: Oil prices surged as much as 4% on concerns about Middle East tensions, while equities fell across Asia, with Tokyo and Taipei plummeting over 2% and 3% respectively. Reports of explosions in Iran and Syria fueled fears of an escalation of the conflict, with US officials citing Israeli strikes. The US economy data showed jobless claims below expectations, but the Federal Reserve is expected to hold off cutting interest rates this year, with some analysts predicting a higher-for-longer regime of inflation and interest rates.

images.alt_text: People walk past screens displaying the Hang Seng stock index and stock prices outside the Exchange Square in Hong Kong, China January 23, 2024. REUTERS/Joyce Zhou
The Dow Jones Industrial Average eked out a 0.1 per cent gain at 37,775.38 on Thursday..

Iran’s Fars news agency reported “three explosions” were heard near the Shekari army airbase in the north-west of Isfahan province, while Iran’s space agency spokesman Hossein Dalirian said “several” drones had been “successfully shot down”.
Bitcoin slid more than 5.5 per cent to US$59,961 in the Asia session as the US dollar rose broadly.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands Q1 profit surges 51.5% to US$597 million on tourism boom
summary: Marina Bay Sands reported a 51.5% surge in Q1 profit to US$597 million, driven by a 36.8% rise in revenue to US$1.2 billion. The hotel's revenue from rooms increased 29.9% to US$126 million, while casino revenue jumped 44.9% to US$859 million. The company's parent, Las Vegas Sands, also reported a 51.6% increase in MBS' share of net revenue, contributing to a US$3 billion net revenue for the quarter. The company expects further growth with ongoing capital investment programs.

images.alt_text: Genting is pledging to continue paying the state about 67 per cent of its slot machine revenue in taxes, an amount that includes administrative fees and other expenses.

site_title: S&P downgrades Israel rating on heightened geopolitical risk
summary: S&P Global Ratings downgraded Israel's credit rating to A+ from AA- due to heightened geopolitical risks in the region, particularly increased confrontation with Iran. This is the first-ever sovereign downgrade for Israel, with the outlook remaining negative. The downgrade follows warnings from all three major rating firms since the start of the war with Hamas, and is reflected in a decline of the shekel since the attacks in October.

site_title: Slow recovery as Dubai airport, roads still deluged
summary: Dubai's airport, one of the world's busiest, has experienced a third consecutive day of major disruption due to heavy rains that flooded the airport and surrounding roads. Over 1,244 flights were canceled and 41 diverted on Tuesday and Wednesday, with Emirates and flydubai resuming check-ins on Thursday. The airport hopes to resume normal operations within 24 hours. Traffic congestion remains severe, with roads blocked by water and flooding, and thousands of passengers stranded. Climate experts link the extreme weather to global warming, warning of increased variability in rainfall and extreme events.

images.alt_text: This year the title has switched, with 12-time winner Singapore being edged out of the top spot by its Middle Eastern rival in the Skytrax World Airport Awards 2024.
Abandoned vehicles on a flooded highway after a rainstorm in Dubai.
Dubai is seeking to grow its economy through tourism, building a local financial centre and by attracting foreign capital, including into property.

site_title: ‘We have our jury’: panel selected for Trump criminal trial
summary: A panel of 12 jurors was sworn in to judge Donald Trump in his unprecedented criminal trial, accused of falsifying business records to cover up a sexual encounter with a porn star on the eve of his 2016 election victory. Trump, 77, has pleaded not guilty and is seeking to recapture the White House in November. The trial, expected to last six to eight weeks, comes as Trump faces three other criminal cases, including attempting to overturn his 2020 election loss.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden speaks to members of the United Steel Workers Union at its headquarters in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, April 17, 2024. Biden announced new actions to protect American steel and shipbuilding industries including hiking tariffs on Chinese steel.
Smartmatic accused One America News of causing irreparable harm by “spreading disinformation” about the election and its technology.

Former President Donald Trump appears in the courtroom for the first day of his criminal trial at Manhattan Criminal Court in New York, April 15, 2024. US President Joe Biden is working to shore up support among Black voters ahead of his November rematch with former President Donald Trump.

site_title: Europe: Industrials boost Stoxx 600 as earnings season rolls in
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 closed 0.3% higher on Thursday, boosted by industrials, as earnings season gained momentum. ABB reached a record high after reporting better-than-expected first-quarter profit, while telecommunications and banks also rose. In contrast, Sartorius slumped 15.9% after missing earnings expectations. The European Central Bank signaled a June interest rate cut, which could support European equities, as markets await a flurry of corporate reports in the coming weeks.

site_title: Fintech KPay aims to triple Singapore merchant base, double local workforce
summary: KPay, a fintech point-of-sale terminal provider, aims to triple its Singapore merchant base to over 10,000 businesses within the next year. The company also plans to double its Singapore workforce to over 100 staff. Established in 2020, KPay currently serves 3,000 SMEs. The company's growth is expected to be fueled by Singapore's role as a global financial nucleus.

images.alt_text: Ruoyun Yang (left), Steven Li, Trasy Lou Walsh are co-founders of Fluid.

site_title: Oil holds near 3-week low as US sanctions interrupt easing tensions
summary: Oil prices held near a three-week low on Thursday, influenced by mixed US economic data, US sanctions on Venezuela and Iran, and easing tensions in the Middle East. Brent futures fell 18 cents to settle at US$87.11 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 4 cents to settle at US$82.73. Analysts expect the US Federal Reserve to delay cutting interest rates until September, driven by the economy's labor market resilience and elevated inflation.

Brent futures for June were down US$1.01, or 1.32, to US$89.01 a barrel at 11.19 am EST (1619 GMT), while US crude futures for May were down 88 cents, or 1 per cent, at US$84.48 a barrel.

site_title: Microsoft’s OpenAI partnership could face EU antitrust probe: sources
summary: Microsoft's $13 billion investment in OpenAI could face an EU antitrust investigation, despite initial plans to avoid a probe under EU merger rules. The European Union's antitrust regulator is building the case, focusing on whether Microsoft's market power distorts the market through certain practices. The Commission is leaning towards this angle, and no decision has been taken yet. Microsoft maintains it does not own any portion of OpenAI and has a non-voting position on the board.

images.alt_text: Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg says the biggest version of Llama 3 is currently being trained with 400 billion parameters and already scoring 85 MMLU, citing metrics used to convey the strength and performance quality of AI models.
The Microsoft-OpenAI partnership is also under informal scrutiny in other regions.

Microsoft president Brad Smith will join G42’s board, and G42 will use the US software maker’s Azure cloud for its AI applications.
Demis Hassabis says that Alphabet has superior computing power to rivals including Microsoft.
Adobe’s Premiere Pro app is widely used in the television and film industries.
The Japan office is the latest part of OpenAI’s international push, having already set up bases in London and Dublin.

site_title: Netflix handily beats subscriber targets, misses on revenue forecast
summary: Netflix reported strong subscriber growth, adding 9.3 million new customers in the quarter, exceeding analyst expectations. Revenue rose 14.8% to nearly $9.4 billion, driven by its ad-supported plans, which now account for 40% of new sign-ups. However, the company missed revenue forecasts and signaled that the positive subscriber growth might be over, forecasting slightly below analyst targets. Netflix will stop reporting subscriber additions quarterly, starting in 2025, and will focus on revenue and operating margins instead.

images.alt_text: Netflix begun its push into gaming by launching Netflix games on mobile phones in November 2021.
Netflix chief executive Reed Hastings is among one of two billionaires who have invested US$27 million in Nairobi, Kenya-based SunCulture alongside others such as InfraCo Africa and Acumen Fund.
Paramount’s studio division has long been eyed for purchase, with streaming television titan Netflix among the companies that have expressed interest in the operation.

Roku has raised its quarterly revenue forecast, a sign that ad spending was continuing to improve thanks to cooling inflation and hopes of a pause in interest rate hikes.
Attendance at cinemas has not recovered to pre-pandemic levels, putting pressure on Paramount's film studio as well.
Candace Bushnell, the creative force behind Sex and the City, says the show’s appeal comes from still being relatable while serving up nostalgia.

site_title: US existing home sales drop in March; median price increases
summary: US existing home sales dropped 4.3% in March to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.19 million units, the National Association of Realtors reported. The median existing home price increased 4.8% to $393,500, a record high for the month. Higher interest rates, which have drifted up towards 7%, and house prices have sidelined buyers, according to NAR's chief economist. The housing inventory jumped 4.7% to 1.11 million units, but remains below pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Permits for future construction of single-family homes fell 5.7% to a rate of 973,000 units in March, the lowest level since last October.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage rose 12 basis points to 7.13 per cent in the week ended Apr 12.
The Commerce Department says that construction spending dropped 0.3 per cent after an unrevised 0.2 per cent decline in January.
New home sales slipped 0.3 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 662,000 units last month, the Commerce Department’s Census Bureau says.

The figures indicate the resale market is breaking out of a protracted slump due to high mortgage rates that discouraged homeowners from moving and giving up a lower rate that they had locked in in the past few years.
Despite the hurdle created for many first-time buyers by higher mortgage rates, builders are cutting prices and offering other incentives to increase sales.

site_title: IMF cautions Asian central banks against excessive reliance on Fed’s rate trajectory
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has cautioned Asian central banks against relying too heavily on the US Federal Reserve's interest rate trajectory, advising them to prioritize domestic price stability. The IMF maintains its forecast for China's growth to slow to 4.6% in 2024 and 4.1% in 2025, despite a stronger-than-expected first-quarter growth. The organization notes that Asian countries are better equipped to manage exchange rate fluctuations and recommends focusing on domestic inflation rather than following the Fed's interest rate changes.

(Photo by Stefani Reynolds / AFP)
Fund officials estimate that the changes will reduce the time between staff agreement and board signoff on an IMF programme to as little as two months.
The IMF forecasts global real GDP growth of 3.2 per cent for 2024 and 2025 – the same rate as in 2023

site_title: US to reduce licensing by 80% for UK, Australia to boost Aukus
summary: The US Commerce Department plans to reduce licensing requirements for exports to Australia and the UK by 80% under the Aukus security pact, valued at over $7.5 billion annually. This change aims to foster defence trade among the three countries and push back against China's growing influence. The streamlined rules will make US export licensing requirements for the UK and Australia nearly the same as Canada's.

(Photo by Jim WATSON / AFP)

site_title: Keppel DC Reit reports 13.7% lower Q1 DPU of S$0.02192 amid loss allowances
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 13.7% lower first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.02192 due to higher finance costs and less favorable foreign exchange hedges in 2024. Despite this, gross revenue increased 18.4% to S$83.4 million, primarily driven by a settlement sum received from a dispute with DXC Technology Services and positive reversions and escalations.

site_title: Federal Reserve’s Bostic reiterates rate cut is not likely until end of year
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic reiterated that interest rates are unlikely to be cut until the end of the year, citing a slower-than-expected inflation path. He believes inflation is on track to reach the central bank's 2% goal but needs to be "high enough" to slow the economy. Bostic is comfortable keeping rates steady, monitoring job growth and inflation-adjusted wage gains, and is open to increasing rates if inflation starts moving away from the target. This stance differs from previous expectations of multiple rate cuts this year.

images.alt_text: Initial claims for state unemployment benefits were unchanged at a seasonally adjusted 212,000 for the week ended Apr 13.
The dollar index, which measures the US currency against six others, was last down 0.11 per cent at 105.84.
Cleveland Federal Reserve Bank President Loretta Mester said that she expects price pressures to ease further this year, allowing the Fed to reduce borrowing costs.
BOE officials have cautioned that they have lingering concerns about price pressures in the economy.
The US economy continues to surprise Fed officials with its resilience.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly lower after volatile session
summary: US stocks ended mostly lower on Thursday after a volatile session, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.1% to 37,775.38. The S&P 500 dipped 0.2% to 5,011.12, and the Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.5% to 15,601.50. Rising US Treasury bond yields and dimmed hopes for an imminent Fed pivot contributed to the decline. Analysts attribute the shift in market posture to reduced expectations for interest rate cuts in 2024, with the first major tech company, Netflix, reporting better-than-expected profits despite a 0.4% fall.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - FEBRUARY 29: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on February 29, 2024 in New York City. site_title: In Olympics launch, Adidas seeks to broaden sport appeal
summary: Adidas has expanded its Olympic product line to include shoes and apparel for 41 disciplines, a departure from its previous focus on fewer sports. The brand aims to capitalize on the Olympics' broad appeal to engage a wider audience, particularly Gen Z and teenage consumers. Adidas CEO Bjorn Gulden emphasized the importance of building products for each sport and country, as the company seeks to increase sales in the performance footwear category, which grew 8.2% in 2023.

Adidas CEO Bjorn Gulden during the launch REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier
Adidas sales growth is being driven by strong demand momentum in “terrace” retro styles, such as Samba, Gazelle and Campus, as well as strength in performance categories.

The bet is that athletes breaking records in Puma gear will nudge spectators towards its whole range of products, creating a potential “halo effect” for everything from marathon shoes to everyday sneakers.
Adidas says its board would propose a dividend of 0.7 euros (S$1.1) per share, unchanged from last year, despite a difficult 2023.

site_title: Gold rally unlikely to fizzle out; observers expect record highs ahead
summary: Gold prices continue to rally, reaching record highs of US$2,398.16 on April 12 and US$2,407.80 on April 16. The commodity has advanced 15.1% in the year to date, with spot and futures prices expected to hover closer to the US$3,000-per-ounce mark. The rally is driven by escalating tensions in the Middle East and is seen as unlikely to fizzle out, despite interest rates and a stronger US dollar.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.4 per cent at US$2,369.93 per ounce.
Gold is historically an inflation hedge, but it’s also something investors turn to when they are worried about the stability of the status quo.
FILE PHOTO: Gold bars from the vault of a bank are seen in this illustration picture taken in Zurich November 20, 2014. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
Gold is one of market watchers' top picks, as they expect central bank demand to remain strong while the downside risks for the previous yellow metal are limited.
FILE PHOTO: Gold bars at the Austrian Gold and Silver Separating Plant 'Oegussa' in Vienna, Austria, March 18, 2016.   REUTERS/Leonhard Foeger/File Photo

site_title: SPH Sultans of Swing team in pole position in BT Corporate Golf League
summary: The SPH Sultans of Swing team has taken the lead in the BT Corporate Golf League after a strong performance in the third leg, with a total of 248 points. They are now four points ahead of defending champions Team Boss and five points ahead of third-placed Singapore Pools. The team's transformation is attributed to the inclusion of seasoned golfers Gerald Ng and Samir Bedi, who combined for 72 points in the third leg.

images.alt_text: Teenage golfer Chen Xing Tong, part of the Singapore Global Trust team, took home the Longest Drive award at the second leg on Mar 22.
Team Hugo Boss players (from left) Becca Foe, Denise Ng, Marilyn Lum and Angelina Xiong.
Team Boss is fielding an all-female team at this year's BT Corporate Golf League. The event tees off on Thursday.

site_title: Seatrium unit ordered to pay US$108 million in arbitration over equipment supply contracts
summary: A tribunal under the Singapore International Arbitration Centre has ordered Seatrium's unit to pay US$108 million to MHWirth, a subsidiary of HMH, in vendor termination fees and ancillary costs. The ruling includes US$101 million in vendor termination fees and US$7 million for legal and arbitration proceeding fees. Seatrium claims the award is within the provision made in prior years.

images.alt_text: Sembmarine unit faces arbitration over equipment supply contracts

site_title: UN chief warns Mideast on brink of 'full-scale regional conflict'
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres warned that the Middle East is on the brink of a "full-scale regional conflict" due to escalating tensions over the war in Gaza and Iran's attack on Israel. He described the situation as a "humanitarian hellscape" for civilians in Gaza and urged all parties to exercise "maximum restraint." A miscalculation or miscommunication could lead to a devastating conflict, Guterres said, emphasizing the need for international cooperation to prevent further escalation.

images.alt_text: Explosions lighting up Jerusalem sky during an Iranian attack on Israel. Teheran has insisted the attack was an act of “self-defence”.

Iranian demonstrators show support during an anti-Israeli gathering at Palestine Square in Tehran, April 14, 2024, after Iran retaliated directly against Israel for the killings of its senior generals in Damascus, Syria, with an onslaught of more than 300 drones and missiles.

site_title: Kazakhstan: A tale of three cities
summary: Kazakhstan, the world's 11th-largest country, boasts a 1,600-year-old history shaped by nomadic cultures, historical empires, and significant transformations. The country's capital, Astana, showcases its transformation from a Soviet republic to an economic leader, featuring futuristic architecture and traditional Kazakh motifs. Other cities, such as Shymkent and Turkistan, offer distinct experiences, from the ancient Silk Road to modern cultural hubs. The country's rich heritage and evolving aspirations are reflected in its architecture, cuisine, and traditions, making it a fascinating destination for travelers.

hykazakh18 - Sights in Kazakhstan.

Conditions for usage: Free with mandatory credit

site_title: Charmain Kwee: Steering a car empire at 27
summary: At 27, Charmain Kwee is leading Eurokars, the largest privately owned auto dealership in Singapore, into a new era of automotive excellence. After initially pursuing a career in law, she took on a leadership role at Eurokars in 2022, leveraging her strategic acumen and innovative approach to drive growth and cater to the changing preferences of Gen Z. Under her direction, Eurokars is expanding its car leasing services and adopting digital marketing strategies to reach younger audiences. Kwee's vision is to create a seamless experience for customers, while navigating the complexities of her father's legacy management style.

images.alt_text: Lee Hui Li of Microsoft uses her unique perspective to ascend the leadership ladder in the tech world – which, as it stands, is still dominated by men.
Tan Min Lan heads the chief investment office, Asia-Pacific, at UBS Global Wealth Management.

site_title: Google fires 28 workers protesting against US$1.2 billion Israeli contract
summary: Google has fired 28 employees after they protested against a $1.2 billion contract with Amazon to provide AI and cloud services to the Israeli government and military. The protests, led by the No Tech for Apartheid organization, took place across Google offices in New York City, Seattle, and California on April 16. Google cited "physically impeding other employees' work" as the reason for termination, despite the protesters leaving the premises and not obstructing others. The move has sparked debate on labor rights and employee activism, with some arguing that tech workers have the right to object to how their work is used.

images.alt_text: Google let go of hundreds of workers across multiple teams in January as the company ramps up investment and builds its artificial intelligence offerings.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims unchanged at low levels
summary: US weekly jobless claims remained unchanged at a seasonally adjusted 212,000 for the week ended Apr 13, indicating continued labor market strength. This marks the third consecutive week of unchanged claims, which have been within a 194,000-to-225,000 range this year. Economists had forecast 215,000 claims.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign for hire is posted on the window of a Chipolte Restaurant in New York City, U.S., April 29, 2022.  REUTERS/Shannon Stapleton/File Photo

site_title: UK wage growth and services inflation too high for rate cut, BOE’s Greene says
summary: UK Bank of England policymaker Megan Greene says the latest wage growth and services inflation data is too high for a rate cut, contradicting the 2% consumer price inflation target. This is due to persistent inflation pressure, with Greene previously stating interest rate cuts in Britain remain "a way off" this year. The BOE is unlikely to cut interest rates, with Greene expecting a cut less than the US Federal Reserve this year. This decision reflects concerns about maintaining economic stability amidst high inflation rates.

images.alt_text: epa11248029 people walk in the City of London In London, Britain, 28 March 2024. Revised UK GDP figures have confirmed Britain has fallen into recession. According to the latest ONS figures, the UK economy shrank by 0.3% percent for the final three months of last year.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN
Fintech companies in the UK say there is not enough investment coming from UK-based investors in particular.

Crowds of shoppers on Oxford Street in London, UK, on Monday, Dec. 18, 2023. The Office for National Statistics are due to release the latest UK retail sales figures on Friday. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg
“These figures are a welcome sign that the economy is turning a corner,” finance minister Jeremy Hunt said in response to Friday’s data.
BOE officials have cautioned that they have lingering concerns about price pressures in the economy.

A bigger question is whether Ben Bernanke, who was head of the Fed from 2006 to 2014, will recommend that the BoE move closer to the US central bank’s ‘dot plot’ where each rate-setter anonymously publishes their own forecasts for interest rates, growth and inflation.

The BOE’s Financial Policy Committee (FPC) says finance for riskier corporates could be particularly vulnerable to a deterioration in investor risk sentiment as the possibility of a sharp correction in a broad range of asset prices has increased.

site_title: TSMC estimates losses of US$92.4 million due to Taiwan earthquake
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) reported estimated losses of US$92.44 million in the second quarter due to the April 3 earthquake, which also expected to lower its gross margin by 50 basis points. The quake did not cause power outages or structural damage to TSMC's fabrication facilities, and critical equipment remained unaffected.

site_title: Meta releases early versions of its Llama 3 AI model
summary: Meta has released early versions of its Llama 3 AI model and an image generator, aiming to compete with OpenAI's ChatGPT. The models will be integrated into virtual assistant Meta AI, with a new standalone website and prominent billing in Meta's apps. CEO Mark Zuckerberg cited the 400 billion parameters and 85 MMLU score of the largest Llama 3 version, indicating significant performance. The move is part of Meta's efforts to push generative AI products to its billions of users, following an overhaul of computing infrastructure and team consolidation.

images.alt_text: Lawsuits filed on behalf of young people have alleged that Mark Zuckerberg was repeatedly warned that Instagram and Facebook weren’t safe for children but ignored the findings and chose not to share them publicly.
Forrest has accused Meta of breaking Australia’s anti-money laundering laws by allowing third-party scammers to use its software and platform to advertise fake cryptocurrency schemes
Meta’s pivot to AI services has brought increased demand for computing power.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as some chip stocks bounce back after selloff
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday as some chip stocks rebounded from a recent selloff. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.25% to 37,847.21, while the S&P 500 gained 0.19% to 5,031.52 and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.14% to 15,705.70. The rebound is seen as a response to Federal Reserve officials' commentary on interest-rate cuts, which investors are digesting.

site_title: US dollar rally stalls after rare FX warning from finance chiefs
summary: The US dollar experienced a brief decline, falling 0.11% to 105.84 against a basket of six other currencies, after a rare warning from US, Japanese, and Korean finance chiefs about excessive currency volatility. The yen received a boost, strengthening to 153.96 against the dollar, as investors reconsider the likelihood of the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates. The dollar's safe-haven appeal was also attributed to tensions in the Middle East, with markets pricing in half a percentage point in cuts from the Fed this year.

images.alt_text: In early Thursday trade, Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta stocks all rose.
FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The yen last hovered around 154.64 per US dollar, its weakest level in 34 years, and close to what analysts say is the new resistance level of 155.

site_title: ROE target of 14% is ‘decent’ for UOB: CEO Wee Ee Cheong
summary: UOB, Singapore's third-largest bank, achieved a core return on equity (ROE) of 14.2% for its financial year ended 2023, up 2.3 percentage points from the previous year. The bank's target to achieve an ROE of 13-14% is considered "decent" by CEO Wee Ee Cheong, who expects the bank to perform well, especially with improved fees from its wealth business. The bank aims to maintain its target in the longer term and is willing to take calculated risks to achieve higher ROEs.

images.alt_text: UOB says credit card applications among 25- to 29-year-olds are up four percentage points from Jun 21 to Jul 7
UOB chief Wee Ee Cheong’s 2023 pay up 11.9% to S$15.9 million
UOB’s net profit for the fourth quarter rose 21.8 per cent to S$1.4 billion, compared with S$1.2 billion a year earlier, due to higher net fee income and other non-interest income.
“Yes, if the family members are interested, they’re more than welcome. But I think they need passion, they need love, and they need the desire to be part of the team,” said UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong.
UOB Q4 profit rises 21.8% to S$1.4 billion; proposes S$0.85 per share final dividend

site_title: Malaysia’s RHB Bank doubles green loans target to RM50 billion
summary: RHB Bank in Malaysia has doubled its green loans target to RM50 billion by 2026, exceeding its initial target of RM20 billion by 2026. As of end 2023, the bank had mobilized RM23.8 billion in green financing, surpassing its initial target. This move follows other Malaysian banks in raising their green loan targets, with Malayan Banking reaching half of its RM80 billion target for 2025.

site_title: How sustainable procurement can drive growth
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 introduced initiatives to support companies in their sustainability journeys, with a focus on sustainable procurement. This approach incorporates environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors into purchasing decisions, going beyond cost considerations. By adopting sustainable procurement, companies can mitigate risks of supply chain disruptions caused by climate change, resource scarcity, and social unrest, ultimately driving long-term value creation and growth.

images.alt_text: Restructuring the supply chains of SME globally will need a vast amount of long-term capital infusion.
Given the intersection of trade flows here, Singapore is in a strong position to help drive and promote leading practices in supply chains.

site_title: China's central bank signals caution over credit boost as demand weakens
summary: China's central bank signals caution over credit boost as demand weakens, despite the country's economy growing faster than expected in the first quarter. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) cautions against a "one-sided" pursuit of credit expansion, prioritizing the quality of credit over size and focusing on revitalizing existing loans. The central bank aims to prevent the accumulation of "idle funds" and maintain economic growth, with a target of 5% for 2024, amid fragile confidence and a slowdown in bank lending.

images.alt_text: The yuan has lost about 1.9 per cent in value against the US dollar so far this year, pressured by its relative low yields versus other currencies and outflows of foreign investment from an anaemic stock market.
The Chinese currency slid to the weakest since November earlier this week.

site_title: India’s Infosys misses fourth-quarter revenue estimates
summary: India's Infosys reported lower-than-expected fourth-quarter revenue, rising 1.3% to 379.23 billion rupees, due to cautious clients cutting spending amid macroeconomic uncertainties. The company forecast revenue growth between 1% and 3% for fiscal year 2025. Infosys' largest market, North America, reported a 2.1% revenue decline. The company's operating margin contracted 90 basis points year on year to 20.1%. CEO Salil Parekh attributed the decline to weak demand for discretionary work and a "mixed outlook" for the macro environment.

images.alt_text: Tata Consultancy Services' net income rose to US$1.5 billion in the fourth quarter, an increase of more than eight per cent on-year that defied market expectations of a slowdown in the sector.

Indian tech companies are also looking to promote their capabilities in artificial intelligence (AI) as demand for such services picks up. “Almost every discussion with clients involves some element of generative AI,” says Infosys CEO Salil Parekh.
Infosys' consolidated net profit falls 7.3 per cent to 61.06 billion rupees (S$978 million) in the seasonally weak third quarter from a year earlier.

site_title: Princess Diana’s dresses on display in Hong Kong ahead of auction
summary: A collection of Princess Diana's dresses, shoes, and handbags is on display in Hong Kong as part of a 12-day exhibit ahead of an auction on June 27. The exhibit features six outfits, including a yellow suit worn in 1989 and a midnight blue tulle gown worn to the "Phantom of the Opera" premiere in 1986. The items are expected to fetch significant prices, with the yellow suit estimated to sell for up to $50,000. The exhibit aims to showcase Diana's enduring fashion influence and her charitable work, which remains popular among younger generations.

images.alt_text: Photo taken on April 17, 2024 shows outfits once worn by Princess Diana at a media preview ahead of the auction by Julian’s Auctions titled “Princess Diana's Elegance & A Royal Collection” on display in Hong Kong. (Photo by Peter PARKS / AFP)
Dresses that belonged to Princess Diana and a sketch study portrait are on display ahead of the auction Legends: Hollywood & Royalty at Julien's Auctions.

site_title: UBS shuts some China private funds, will lay off staff: sources
summary: UBS is shutting down up to 17 of its equity and bond private funds in China, returning investor money, and laying off one-third of its staff in the country. The move is part of the bank's efforts to cut operating costs and focus on alternative strategies, such as funds of funds and private funds investing in overseas markets. This decision follows other global asset managers cutting headcount in China due to cost-cutting pressure and intense competition.

images.alt_text: UBS’s shares have fallen in recent days on news that the Swiss government wants to impose an increase in regulatory capital requirements on the lender.

UBS has been adding to its structured rates offering over the past six months, while Nomura is also stepping up sales of products such as credit-linked notes, floating-rate notes, and inflation-linked bonds.
FILE PHOTO: The company's logo is seen at a branch of Swiss bank UBS in Zurich, Switzerland February 2, 2016. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann
The FSB is set to review its ranking of UBS among the list of global systemically important banks after the Credit Suisse takeover, which is due to close later this year.

site_title: Former China central bank’s deputy governor accused of taking bribes
summary: Former China central bank deputy governor Fan Yifei has been accused of taking bribes, allegedly receiving property worth over $72.5 million. The allegations, made in a court hearing, stem from a decade-long crackdown on corruption led by President Xi Jinping. Fan was first investigated in 2022 and has been referred for criminal prosecution, with his illegal income confiscated. A verdict will be announced later, with the case involving alleged bribery between 1993 and 2022.

images.alt_text: Xi Jinping's drive against corruption has ensnared former officials at state-owned banks, the banking regulator and state-owned oil and tobacco firms in recent weeks.
Tang Shuangning, former chairman at China Everbright Group, was expelled from China’s Communist Party earlier this month for severe violations and disciplines.
Li Tie, a former Everton midfielder who served as the national team’s head coach, is placed under investigation in 2022, accused by authorities of “serious violations of the law”.
China launched a sprawling campaign to counter graft in 2012, following the ascension of leader Xi Jinping to the top of the Communist Party.

site_title: Blackstone reports 1% rise in Q1 earnings
summary: Blackstone, the world's largest private equity firm, reported a 1% rise in first-quarter distributable earnings to $1.27 billion, driven by fee-related earnings growth and a slight increase in distributable earnings per share. Fee-related earnings rose 12% to $1.2 billion, while net profit from asset sales fell 25% to $293.3 million. The company's net income under GAAP surged to $847.4 million, with total revenues more than doubling. Blackstone raised $34 billion of new capital and declared a quarterly dividend of 83 cents per share.

site_title: Jaeger-LeCoultre debuts a trio of watches dedicated to the pursuit of accuracy
summary: Jaeger-LeCoultre has unveiled three new Duometre watches, the Heliotourbillon Perpetual, Chronograph Moon, and Quantieme Lunaire, which combine accuracy and precision with various complications. The new watches rely on the "two brains, one heart" principle, featuring two independent barrels and separate gear trains for timekeeping and complications. The Heliotourbillon Perpetual boasts a triple axis tourbillon and is limited to 20 pieces, while the Chronograph Moon features a monopusher chronograph and the Quantieme Lunaire has a flying seconds indicator and moon phase.

site_title: Christopher Lee – the design maverick
summary: Architect Christopher Lee, co-founder of Serie Architects, shares his design ethos shaped by his past, including growing up in a multicultural Malaysia and experiencing financial struggles. His conceptually rigorous approach, backed by research in archetypes and sustainability, has led to innovative buildings in Singapore, such as the National University of Singapore School of Design & Environment 4 and One Pearl Bank. Lee's designs blend traditional elements with modern ideas, reflecting his fascination with nature and his ability to absorb diverse cultural paradigms. His work aims to create a high-quality built environment, with a focus on public spaces and community development.

site_title: War insurance may attract more funds despite heightened risk, says underwriter
summary: Insurance underwriter Chris Lambe predicts that the appetite for war insurance may increase despite heightened risks, as people seek to profit from the segment. With rising geopolitical tensions, Lambe believes that more external sources will flow into the market, making it harder for brokers to choose a competent insurer. The maritime sector is currently under heightened risks, with attacks on merchant vessels in the Red Sea and Iran seizing a vessel, but Lambe expects the capacity for war protection to remain stable due to the commercial gains it offers.

images.alt_text: Insurance industry sources say the Rubymar, which had sunk in the Red Sea, was an ageing vessel with a low value, which was not believed to have been covered through the major London marine insurance market.
Houthi attacks have disrupted global shipping through the Suez Canal, forcing firms to re-route to longer and more expensive journeys around southern Africa.

site_title: Human cases of bird flu ‘an enormous concern’, says WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has expressed alarm over the growing spread of H5N1 bird flu to new species, including humans, with a 52% case fatality rate. The virus has infected humans through contact with animals, and experts warn of the potential for human-to-human transmission. Since 2023, 463 human cases have been reported, resulting in 889 deaths across 23 countries. The WHO is working to develop vaccines and therapeutics, and emphasizes the need for equitable access to these resources in the event of a pandemic.

images.alt_text: This is the first time we have detected this virus in humans in the UK, though it is very similar to viruses that have been detected in pigs,” says UKHSA incident director Meera Chand.
The rapid spread of the H5N1 bird flu strain is already stoking concerns.
Cambodian authorities on Thursday (Feb 23) reported the death of an 11-year old girl due to H5N1, and began testing 12 of her contacts.

site_title: China’s top lenders face 1.6 trillion yuan loss-absorbing capital shortfall by 2025, Fitch estimates
summary: China's five largest state-owned lenders face a 1.6 trillion yuan capital shortfall by 2025, according to Fitch estimates. To address this, the lenders plan to issue up to 440 billion yuan of TLAC bonds, which could be issued as soon as the second quarter this year. The lenders must hold at least 16% of risk-weighted assets in TLAC by 2025 and 18% by 2028. The shortfall highlights strains on the lenders' capital buffers and underscores the need for increased capitalization.

images.alt_text: The Communist Party has put an increasing focus on corruption among cadres and corporate executives.
State lenders including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China are telling the officers they won’t be held responsible if property loans eventually turn non-performing.

site_title: Tan Min Lan: Deftly navigating the complexities of leadership
summary: Tan Min Lan, head of chief investment office, Asia-Pacific at UBS Global Wealth Management, has navigated the complexities of leadership through various roles and challenges at the Swiss banking giant. With nearly 22 years at UBS, she has led by example, inspiring teams and making difficult decisions. Tan emphasizes the importance of women building financial confidence, particularly in retirement, and notes that they don't need to be rocket scientists to take action. As a private person, she values quiet time and focuses on her work, citing her superpower as being very focused.

images.alt_text: Sonia Cheng is no flash in the pan, and has grown the Rosewood brand into a portfolio of 31 hotels and resorts globally.

site_title: 💸 Is your money narrative influencing your financial decisions?
summary: A recent article in the Thrive newsletter discusses the impact of one's financial narrative on financial decisions. Research suggests that mental barriers and biases can influence spending habits and investment choices, particularly among young adults. The article emphasizes the importance of financial literacy and encourages readers to critically evaluate their financial decisions, including those related to CPF investments, life insurance, and investments in a volatile market. By being aware of their own biases and narratives, individuals can make more informed financial choices.

images.alt_text: bench, seaside, view

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 18)
summary: Singapore's rental volumes for condo and HDB flats recovered in March after a decline in February, with condo rents increasing slightly after 7 months of decline. The latest one-year T-bill offer yielded 3.58%, while the Straits Times Index rose 1.1% on Thursday. Singapore is poised to capitalize on economic opportunities in the Philippines, with Minister Vivian Balakrishnan stating the country's potential is "very fertile ground" for transformation. The first RoboCluster initiative was launched in facilities management, aiming to turn R&D into market-ready solutions.

site_title: Women redefining leadership
summary: Three women in Singapore's business world - Tan Min Lan, managing director of UBS Global Wealth Management, Lee Hui Li, managing director of Microsoft Singapore, and Charmain Kwee, group executive director of Eurokars Group - are redefining leadership and challenging the status quo. Despite the 14.3% pay gap between men and women in Singapore, these trailblazers have forged their own paths, embracing diversity, inclusivity, and authenticity. Their stories share a common refrain: believing in oneself and earning respect from others.

images.alt_text: Charmain Kwee of Eurokars.
Tan Min Lan heads the chief investment office, Asia-Pacific, at UBS Global Wealth Management.
Lee Hui Li of Microsoft uses her unique perspective to ascend the leadership ladder in the tech world – which, as it stands, is still dominated by men.

site_title: TAG Heuer – the master of chronographs excels again with three new creations
summary: TAG Heuer unveiled three new chronograph watches at Watches & Wonders 2024: the Monaco Split-Seconds Chronograph, TAG Heuer Carrera Chronograph, and Carrera Chronograph Skipper. The Monaco chronograph features a self-winding titanium movement and sapphire crystal case, while the Carrera Chronograph boasts a modern design with a panda dial and bi-directional winding. The Carrera Chronograph Skipper is a gold version of the Carrera Chronograph, inspired by the original 1968 model. The watches showcase TAG Heuer's expertise in chronograph timekeeping and avant-garde design.

images.alt_text: The Portugieser Eternal Calendar

site_title: Tata to use new US$1 billion plant to make Jaguar Land Rover cars
summary: Tata Motors plans to manufacture Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) luxury cars at a $1 billion plant in Tamil Nadu, India, marking the first time JLR-branded cars are made from scratch in the country. The plant, announced in March, will produce cars for domestic sales and export. JLR currently exports vehicles from Britain or assembles them in India. The move aims to increase the brand's presence in the Indian market, where it competes with Mercedes-Benz and BMW. Tata Motors acquired JLR in 2008 and the plant's production capacity and models have not been disclosed yet.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man stands next to a sign of the brand of  Tata Motors' passenger electric vehicles 'Tata.ev ' at Bharat Mobility Global Expo organised by India's commerce ministry at Pragati Maidan in New Delhi, India, February 1, 2024. REUTERS/Anushree Fadnavis/File Photo

site_title: Tudor unveils new line of Black Bay 58 watches
summary: Tudor unveiled two new watches in its popular Black Bay 58 collection: a GMT model inspired by the golden age of travel in the 1950s and an all-gold diving watch. The Black Bay 58 GMT features a 39mm stainless steel case with a burgundy and black bidirectional bezel and gilt 24-hour scale, while the solid gold Black Bay 58 18-ct. boasts a 39mm yellow gold case with a satin-finished gold bracelet. Both watches are certified by the Swiss Official Chronometer Testing Institute (COSC) and feature in-house mechanical movements with 65-70 hours of power reserve.

images.alt_text: TAG Heuer – the master of chronographs excels again with three new creations

site_title: CGS International aims to grow as a China-Asean nexus: CEO
summary: CGS International, a China-Asean investment house, aims to double its revenue to S$700 million by 2030, with a focus on expanding its presence in the region. The company, formerly known as CGS-CIMB Securities, has been acquired by China Galaxy Securities, a state-owned firm with over 16 million customers globally. CEO Carol Fong plans to position CGS International as the international arm of China Galaxy, leveraging its Chinese shareholder's reach to penetrate the Chinese market and expand regionally. The company is also considering a dual listing in Singapore and Malaysia, with plans to allocate more resources to Indonesia and Thailand to elevate its position in these markets.

images.alt_text: The higher March and Q1 2024 derivatives volume is attributed to record trading in commodity and forex derivatives.
High interest rates have boosted the performance of banks on the STI.
Carol Fong, group CEO of CGS-CIMB Securities said CGS and CIMB will continue to work together on stockbroking after the split.

site_title: Genting Singapore propels convincing Singapore market rebound; STI up 1.1%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.1% to 3,187.66 points, driven by a strong recovery from war jitters and interest rate fears. Jardine Cycle & Carriage was the top gainer, followed by Jardine Matheson Holdings and DFI Retail Group Holdings. Genting Singapore also saw a 2.2% gain, with analyst Tay Wee Kuang citing positive year-on-year momentum in profitability. The STI's rebound was mirrored across Asia, with the Nikkei 225 and Hang Seng Index also up, while the Korea Stock Exchange Kospi saw a nearly 2% gain.

images.alt_text: Genting is pledging to continue paying the state about 67 per cent of its slot machine revenue in taxes, an amount that includes administrative fees and other expenses.
Marina Bay Sands (left) is adding a fourth tower, while Resorts World Sentosa is expanding with a new waterfront lifestyle complex.
CGS-CIMB says on Thursday MBS' solid results could mean a positive surprise for competitor Genting Singapore’s Q4 performance.

site_title: Latest Singapore one-year T-bill offers cut-off yield of 3.58%
summary: Singapore's latest one-year Treasury bills offered a cut-off yield of 3.58%, with S$10.1 billion in applications for a total allotment of S$5.1 billion, resulting in a bid-to-cover ratio of 1.97. This is lower than the previous auction's ratio of 3.19. Analysts attribute the higher yield to the strong US economy, making it challenging for the Federal Reserve to cut rates. Expectations suggest Singapore T-bill yields will fall in the second half of 2024.

images.alt_text: Objects seen in the sky above Jerusalem on April 14 after Iran launched drones and missiles towards Israel hours earlier. The prospect of war in the Middle East has hurt investor sentiment, but is unlikely to affect stocks in the long run.
The previous auction, which closed on Mar 27, offered 3.8 per cent yield.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise as traders consider US rate outlook
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday as traders considered the outlook for US interest rates, with Federal Reserve officials expressing skepticism about a rate cut anytime soon. Oil prices edged up after a sell-off on Wall Street, where tech firms were hit by concerns about elevated borrowing costs. Analysts say the current earnings season is key to maintaining momentum, and expectations for rate cuts in 2024 have fallen to just two, down from six at the start of the year.

site_title: South Korea’s LG Electronics plans to raise up to US$1 billion with dollar bonds: sources
summary: LG Electronics plans to raise up to $1 billion through a US dollar bond deal, according to sources. The five-year bond is a sustainable bond focused on green and social projects. The company has mandated investment banks to work on a three-year and five-year bond deal. The proceeds will be used for environmentally friendly and social initiatives, but no specific details were provided.

images.alt_text: LG Display has received letters of intent (LOI) for the sale of the liquid crystal display (LCD) plant from four to five parties, including BOE Technology Group, TCL’s LCD unit CSOT as well as financial investors.

site_title: IWC unveils a breakthrough calendar watch that goes beyond perpetual
summary: IWC unveils the Portugieser Eternal Calendar, a breakthrough in perpetual calendar technology that tracks the calendar more accurately over a 400-year period. The watch features a 44.4 mm platinum case, a new 400-year corrector that skips centurial years, and a moon-phase display that deviates from the moon's orbit by only one day after 45 million years. The Portugieser Eternal Calendar is powered by IWC's in-house 52640 calibre, which has a 7-day power reserve. The collection also includes the Portugieser Hand-Wound Tourbillon, Portugieser Chronograph, and Portugieser Automatic 42, showcasing IWC's expertise in mechanical calendar complications.

images.alt_text: The World Time Date Reference 5330G has a date display synchronised with local time, a feature that is totally new to the world-time model.

site_title: Norway's wealth fund posts US$109 billion Q1 profit as tech stocks soar
summary: Norway's $1.6 trillion sovereign wealth fund posted a Q1 profit of $109 billion, driven by strong tech stocks. The fund's overall return on investment of 6.3% was 0.1 percentage point below its benchmark index. This marks a significant increase from the same period last year, when the fund reported a profit of $110.3 billion. The fund's strong performance is attributed to its equity investments, particularly in the tech sector, led by Deputy CEO Trond Grande.

site_title: Vacheron Constantin breaks record for most complicated watch
summary: Vacheron Constantin has broken the record for the most complicated watch, with its bespoke pocket watch featuring 63 functions, surpassing its previous record of 57 functions. The watch, called Les Cabinotiers – The Berkley Grand Complication, is housed in an 18-ct white gold case and features a Chinese perpetual calendar, a triple-axis tourbillon, and a grande sonnerie. The watch also has a sky chart with constellations, sidereal time, and the equation of time. The company has also unveiled other novelties, including the Grand Lady Kalla, a scintillating confection with 131 emerald-cut diamonds, and the Traditionnelle Tourbillon Chronograph, a limited edition with 50 pieces made from 950 platinum.

site_title: Swiss watch exports plunge as China and Hong Kong demand dries up
summary: Swiss watch exports plummeted 16% in March to 2 billion Swiss francs due to declining demand in key markets like China and Hong Kong. Shipments to China and Hong Kong fell 42% and 44%, respectively, with the decline in China being particularly concerning. This marks the biggest decline since 2020, attributed to higher interest rates, economic growth concerns, and geopolitical conflicts.

images.alt_text: Swiss watch exports to India could exceed 400 million francs by 2028, according to the audit firm Deloitte estimation.
The Watches and Wonders salon, which runs until Apr 15, will see 54 major watch brands show off their latest creations, including Rolex, Patek Philippe, Cartier, Chopard, Hermes and Chanel.

Watches of the Bioceramic Moonswatch Collection. Swatch makes high-end Omega, Tissot and Longines watches, as well the eponymous mass-market plastic models.

site_title: Europe’s red Letta day to consider major reforms
summary: Former Italian Prime Minister Enrico Letta has released a report that could lead to significant reforms in the European Union's single market. The report, titled "A Single Market with Teeth for a Big World," highlights the need for the EU to adapt to a rapidly changing global environment. Letta argues that the single market, which was created 30 years ago, needs to be rebooted to reflect today's challenges, including the rise of Asian emerging markets and growing global protectionism. The report proposes a range of reforms, including a new "fifth freedom" for the free movement of research, innovation, knowledge, and education, and a continental-scale energy market. The report's release comes as the EU faces growing economic and geopolitical challenges, including the ongoing war in Ukraine and the threat of a Trump re-election.

images.alt_text: A worker standing at a construction site in Vienna. There is no denying that lists of the top global technology companies, the world’s top universities, or semiconductor manufacturing capacity, tend to show Europe falling behind.
While the euro has delivered on some of its promises -- notably, maintaining price stability -- it has failed to facilitate the continent’s economic and political integration.

site_title: Reuters’ Mohammed Salem wins 2024 World Press Photo of the Year award
summary: Reuters photographer Mohammed Salem won the 2024 World Press Photo of the Year award for his poignant image of a Palestinian woman cradling her 5-year-old niece's body in a Gaza hospital morgue. The picture, taken on October 17, 2023, highlights the human cost of the Israel-Palestinian conflict. Salem's work was recognized for its high risk and humanitarian impact, following a year that saw a near-record high number of journalists killed covering the war. The award aims to acknowledge the trauma experienced by journalists in conflict zones.

images.alt_text: The Malaysian flag carrier will reroute flights to avoid airspace over parts of the Middle East, requiring more fuel and spurring the need to lighten its load.
Deep losses in Asia carried over into European trading, but Wall Street’s main indices wobbled as corporate earnings season continued.

A video grab taken on April 14, 2024 shows explosions lighting up Jerusalem sky during an Iranian attack on Israel. Iran launched a barrage of more than 100 medium-range ballistic missiles, more than 30 land-attack cruise missiles and more than 150 attack drones at Israel, a senior US military official said.

Iranian demonstrators show support during an anti-Israeli gathering at Palestine Square in Tehran, April 14, 2024, after Iran retaliated directly against Israel for the killings of its senior generals in Damascus, Syria, with an onslaught of more than 300 drones and missiles.

site_title: Japan banks' capital sufficient to withstand stresses, BOJ says
summary: The Bank of Japan stated that Japanese banks have sufficient capital and stable funding bases to withstand various types of stress. Banks have rebalanced their domestic bond portfolios, reducing interest rate risk, especially in the longer-term zone. This improvement comes as the central bank ended eight years of negative interest rates and shifts focus away from reflating growth. The analysis is part of the BOJ's semi-annual report on financial systems, highlighting the resilience of Japan's banking sector.

site_title: German home building permits tumble 18% in February, extending rout
summary: Germany's building permits for apartments dropped 18.3% in February from a year earlier, the third year of a slump in the construction and real estate industry. The decline is attributed to a sharp rise in interest rates, which has led to deals freezing, prices falling, and developers facing insolvency. The number of building permits is a key indicator of future construction, and the sector's downturn has resulted in a significant drop in employment, with the building sector's workforce shrinking for the first time in a decade.

images.alt_text: German builders want the subsidies to be used to build 100,000 social housing units and 60,000 new affordable homes.

site_title: Japanese firms agree to biggest pay hikes in 33 years, union group Rengo says
summary: Japanese companies have agreed to a 5.2% average pay hike, the largest in 33 years, according to union group Rengo. The move is seen as a barometer for inflation and spending, and may influence the Bank of Japan's monetary policy decisions. The pay raises, which include a 3.57% increase in base salary, are expected to boost durable inflation and wage growth, with some economists predicting the Bank of Japan may bring forward its next interest rate hike to the summer.

images.alt_text: The BOJ releases fresh quarterly growth and inflation forecasts at its next meeting in Apr 25 to 26.
The average growth of pay hikes tends to shrink from the initial round as an increasing number of smaller firms wrap up negotiations towards the April-to-June quarter.
Investors should embrace the BOJ's policy pivot as a sign that the country's struggle with deflation is finally ending – a change that has positive implications for the economy.
FILE PHOTO: Members of the Japanese union group Rengo, gather at their annual May Day rally to demand higher pay and better working conditions, in Tokyo on Apr 29, 2023.

site_title: Singapore shows off bumper crop of its artists at Venice Biennale 2024
summary: Singapore has achieved a record representation at the Venice Biennale 2024, with nine Singaporean artists showcasing their works alongside artists from Southeast Asia and globally. The exhibition, featuring iconic portrait paintings and works exploring themes of migration, identity, and belonging, is part of the biennale's 60th edition, which highlights "Foreigners Everywhere". The Singapore government has reaffirmed its commitment to the arts, with the National Gallery Singapore and Singapore Art Museum collaborating to present the country's diverse artistic talent to an international audience.

images.alt_text: Premier art fair Art SG is drawing collectors from around the world.
Cheong Soo Pieng's Life In A Longhouse (1978) is one of 30 works selected for materials analysis.
Boutique Fairs Singapore expects to draw between 25,000 and 30,000 visitors.

site_title: Norway wealth fund backs NatWest plan to buy more state-owned stock
summary: Norway's $1.6 trillion sovereign wealth fund has backed a proposal allowing NatWest to acquire up to 15% of its total stock from the British government in a 12-month period, up from a previous ceiling of 5%. This move is part of the government's efforts to speed up privatization and exit its stake in NatWest, which was once as high as 84%. The fund's vote supports NatWest's plan to increase its acquisition of state-owned stock, with the government planning to sell its remaining shares by 2026.

site_title: China reiterates need for steady yuan amid fragile confidence
summary: China's central bank reiterated the need to stabilize the yuan, citing fragile confidence in the currency after it slid to its weakest since November. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) said it will "resolutely" prevent excessive volatility and maintain a stable exchange rate. The yuan rose 0.1% to 7.2349 per US dollar as the US dollar surged. China's concerns come as neighboring Japan and South Korea expressed "serious concerns" over their own currency weaknesses. The PBOC aims to keep the yuan's value determined by supply and demand.

images.alt_text: Despite the support, the yuan remains close to the weak edge of its allowed 2 per cent trading range versus the US dollar.

site_title: Nokia sees stronger H2 after Q1 comparable profit grows less than expected
summary: Nokia reported a smaller-than-expected increase in first-quarter comparable operating profit, driven by cost cuts and a 19% decline in constant-currency sales. The company attributed the decline to reduced spending on 5G technology. Despite this, CEO Pekka Lundmark expressed confidence in a stronger second half of 2024, with a forecast for a comparable operating profit of 2.3-2.9 billion euros. Nokia's gross margin improved to 48.6% from 37.7% in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: The Nokia Oyj headquarters in Espoo, Finland, on Thursday, Oct. 19, 2023. Nokia Oyj plans to cut as many as 14,000 jobs, or 16% of its workforce, as a dearth of investment in fifth-generation mobile infrastructure forces it to take cost-cutting measures. Photographer: Roni Rekomaa/Bloomberg
Nokia currently supplies 4G and 5G technology that allows in-house communications or helps industrial companies connect to data from machine sensors, among other uses.

site_title: Copenhagen mayor to take lessons from Notre-Dame after Old Stock Exchange blaze
summary: A fire at Copenhagen's 400-year-old Old Stock Exchange on April 16 destroyed the building's spire and roof section, with firefighters continuing to battle remaining flames. The blaze, reminiscent of the 2019 Notre-Dame Cathedral fire, has left only outer brick walls standing. Copenhagen Mayor Sophie Haestorp Andersen plans to visit Paris next month to learn from the city's response to the Notre-Dame fire, and the building's owner has vowed to rebuild the iconic exchange, which originally opened in the 17th century. Police are investigating the cause of the blaze, which caused no injuries.

images.alt_text: The Borsen building, commissioned by King Christian IV and built between 1619 and 1640, is one of Copenhagen’s best known landmarks.

site_title: Micron poised to get over US$6 billion in chips grants in announcement next week
summary: US chipmaker Micron is set to receive a US$6.1 billion grant from the Commerce Department to build up to four factories in New York state and one in Idaho, part of an effort to bring semiconductor production back to the US. The grant is part of the 2022 Chips and Science Act, which aims to revitalise American chipmaking. Micron's CEO, Sanjay Mehrotra, has stated that the company needs sufficient funding to address cost differences compared to overseas expansion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Micron Technology's logo is seen on the U.S. chipmaker's offices in Shanghai, China, May 25, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

The HBM3E (High Bandwidth Memory 3E) will consume 30 per cent less power than rival offerings, and could help tap into soaring demand for chips that power generative AI applications, according to Micron.
The US too has been working with allies to prevent Beijing from obtaining the most advanced semiconductors and the latest chipmaking technologies.
Micron’s results reflect the beginning of a recovery in the memory market for memory and flash storage.

site_title: Singapore’s first RoboCluster launched for facilities management, to turn R&D into market solutions
summary: Singapore's first RoboCluster for facilities management was launched, bringing together researchers, end-users, and robotics companies to develop market-ready solutions. The initiative aims to facilitate design thinking workshops, R&D projects, and deployment of robots in the sector. The first event will be held in July, covering selected robotics applications such as surveillance and floor cleaning. The launch is part of the National Robotics Programme, which received a fresh S$60 million funding tranche. The RoboCluster will also be expanded to the manufacturing and logistics sectors, and for healthcare.

site_title: China national fined S$45,000 for having Singaporeans front plan to buy East Coast houses
summary: A Chinese national, Zhan Guotuan, has been fined S$45,000 for authorizing Singaporeans to front his purchase of landed properties worth millions of dollars. He pleaded guilty to the charge in 2007, using a Singapore-incorporated company, Hwampoa, to hold the properties in trust for him. The fine, which will go towards the Consolidated Fund, was imposed after Zhan's voluntary disgorgement of his financial benefit and his smaller role in the scheme.

site_title: Apple CEO to meet Lawrence Wong at end of whirlwind Asia tour; firm to invest US$250m to expand Ang Mo Kio campus
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook is set to meet Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong at the end of his Asia tour, as the company seeks to expand its presence in the region. Apple plans to invest US$250 million to expand its Ang Mo Kio campus in Singapore, creating space for new roles in artificial intelligence. Cook's visit aims to explore growth markets and manufacturing locations beyond China, which has seen weak demand for Apple's flagship iPhone.

images.alt_text: A rendering of Apple's upcoming, expanded campus in Ang Mo Kio.

Apple CEO Tim Cook (centre) walks with Indonesian Minister of Communication and Information Budi Arie Setiadi (left) to meet journalists after his meeting with Indonesia's President Joko Widodo at the Merdeka Palace in Jakarta on April 17, 2024.
Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh (R) meeting Apple CEO Tim Cook (L) at the Government Office in Hanoi on Apr 16, 2024. Apple is increasing its commitments to Vietnam by an unspecified amount.

site_title: TSMC posts first profit growth in a year after global AI boom
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) has reported its first profit growth in a year, with a 9% rise in net income to NT$225.5 billion in the first quarter. The company attributes the growth to strong demand for artificial intelligence (AI) chips, which is offsetting the decline in smartphone sales. TSMC's market value has increased by about US$340 billion since October 2022, driven by bets on its role in the global AI boom. The company expects revenue to grow by at least 20% this year, but faces uncertainty due to global macroeconomic volatility.

images.alt_text: TSMC has projects underway to build plants in the US, Japan and Germany as it moves to serve global demand.
The world’s largest contract chipmaker has benefited from a surge towards AI that has helped it weather the tapering off of pandemic-led electronics demand.

The world’s largest contract chipmaker, whose customers include Apple and Nvidia, has benefited from a surge towards AI that has helped it weather the tapering off of pandemic-led demand and pushed TSMC’s stock to a record high.

site_title: Danone beats Q1 sales forecasts, keeps 2024 goals
summary: Danone, the world's largest yoghurt maker, reported stronger-than-expected quarterly sales of 6.79 billion euros (S$9.85 billion), beating expectations for 3.4% growth. The company maintained its 2024 sales growth goals, with all businesses delivering volume growth and raising prices to cope with higher input costs. Danone's like-for-like sales rose 4.1% and its recurring operating margin is expected to improve moderately. The company's shares are expected to outperform peers.

images.alt_text: “Danone is going to write a letter to the Kremlin and is studying the legal remedies, but in this kind of country, it is not easy to exercise your rights,” the source says.

site_title: BP reshapes its leadership team as some executives leave
summary: BP has reshaped its leadership team with the departure of some executives, allowing new CEO Murray Auchincloss to implement changes. The company will reduce its executive leadership team to 10 members, simplifying its organizational structure. Key changes include William Lin taking over as head of gas and low-carbon energy, Emeka Emembolu leading the technology division, and Gordon Birrell, Emma Delaney, and Carol Howle maintaining their business units. The restructuring aims to deliver a simpler, more focused, and higher-value company.

images.alt_text: BP Pulse reduced the number of countries it operates in from 12 to four in recent months, focusing now on the US, Britain, Germany and China, where it expects the fastest growth in the EV market.

FILE PHOTO: The logo of British multinational oil and gas company BP is displayed at their booth during the LNG 2023 energy trade show in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, July 12, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren//File Photo
Last year, BP said its carbon emissions would not fall as quickly as anticipated, as it posted record annual profit thanks to soaring oil and gas prices.

site_title: Deliveroo returns to order growth on strong international demand
summary: Deliveroo reported a 2% increase in orders in the first quarter, driven by strong growth in its international segment. Users placed 73.5 million orders, up 1.4 million from the same period last year, with gross transaction value increasing 6% to £1.8 billion. The company attributed flat order growth in the UK and Ireland to a "more stable but still uncertain consumer environment." Deliveroo maintained its guidance for 2024, expecting earnings before interest and taxes to be between £110 million and £130 million.

site_title: After 185 years, Patek Philippe still rules
summary: Patek Philippe unveiled its latest novelties at Watches & Wonders 2024, showcasing innovation and style in watchmaking. The brand's new world-time watch features a date display synchronized with local time, a first for the model. The Golden Ellipse Reference 5738/1R boasts a chain-style bracelet design that took 15 years to develop. Other notable releases include the Alarm Travel Time Reference 5520RG, powered by a patented self-winding movement, and the Retrograde Perpetual Calendar Rare Handcrafts Reference 5160/500R, featuring hand-engraved work inspired by a pocket watch in the Patek Philippe Museum. The brand's Twenty-4 collection celebrates its 25th anniversary with a new cuff-style model.

images.alt_text: TAG Heuer – the master of chronographs excels again with three new creations
The Portugieser Eternal Calendar

site_title: Freddie Mac seeks regulatory approval to back home-equity loans
summary: Freddie Mac is seeking regulatory approval to back home-equity loans, which could lower funding costs for lenders and result in cheaper rates for customers. This move is a response to the impact of higher interest rates on the mortgage industry, where homeowners are turning to home-equity loans instead of refinancing entire mortgages. With 46.1% of mortgaged homes having significant equity, the shift could lead to an estimated $850 billion in second mortgage borrowing through Freddie Mac loans.

site_title: Adam Neumann moves to buy back WeWork as it seeks funds to exit bankruptcy: FT
summary: WeWork's founder Adam Neumann is preparing to buy back the company, beating any other offer by 10%, according to an attorney for Neumann's real estate firm Flow. WeWork seeks $400 million in funding to emerge from bankruptcy and avoid a sale, and aims to exit Chapter 11 bankruptcy by May 31. Neumann had previously submitted a bid of over $500 million to buy back WeWork. The company has negotiated a 40% reduction in rent commitments from landlords.

site_title: Singapore ready to tap economic opportunities in Philippines: Vivian Balakrishnan
summary: Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan has expressed the country's readiness to tap economic opportunities in the Philippines, a 2023 star growth performer in economic transformation, renewable energy, and carbon credits. During his four-day visit, Balakrishnan highlighted potential areas of collaboration, including smart cities, digital sectors, and renewable energy. The Philippines, with its large population and geographical size, offers significant opportunities for economic growth and development, according to the minister.

images.alt_text: Dr Balakrishnan (second from left) with his wife, Joy Balakrishnan, Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, and First Lady Louise Araneta-Marcos at Singapore's National Orchid Garden in 2022.

site_title: Chanel introduces an artistic collection inspired by its haute couture workshop
summary: Chanel introduces the Couture O'Clock capsule collection, inspired by its haute couture workshop. The collection features timepieces that reference the tools of the dressmaker's trade, such as the Mademoiselle's Workshop Musical Clock Couture Workshop, which combines a musical box, clock, and automaton. The collection also includes watches with intricate designs, such as the Bobbin Cuff Couture set with brilliant diamonds in a zig-zag design. The collection showcases Chanel's attention to detail and craftsmanship, highlighting the brand's rich legacy and heritage.

site_title: BHP to decide on future of nickel business by August, trims met coal estimates
summary: BHP Group, the world's largest listed miner, plans to announce the fate of its Western Australian nickel operations by August, amid a review of plans to optimize operations and preserve value. The company trimmed its fiscal 2024 output estimates for its Queensland coal operations due to significant wet weather impacts. BHP now expects to produce 21.5-22.5 million tonnes of metallurgical coal, down from previous estimates of 23-25 million tonnes. The company's iron ore production increased 3% year-over-year, with its South Flank mine on track to reach full production capacity by the end of fiscal 2024.

images.alt_text: BHP has suffered a sharp profit slump in its fiscal first half.
BHP declared an interim dividend of US$0.72 per share, compared with US$0.90 per share declared a year earlier.
Nickel is essential to the manufacture of stainless steel and of batteries that are fuelling the world’s transition to greener energy.
