site_title: Binance converts its billion-dollar ‘Safu’ emergency fund into USDC
summary: Binance, the world's largest crypto exchange, has converted its billion-dollar "Safu" emergency fund into USDC, a stablecoin issued by US firm Circle Internet Financial. The fund, established in 2018, was previously held in various assets including TUSD, BNB, Bitcoin, and USDT. The move is the latest strategic shift under new CEO Richard Teng, who has overseen the spinning off of Binance's venture capital unit and tightening of token listing requirements. The fund's value can now be tracked in real-time using a publicly available blockchain address.

images.alt_text: Crypto trading volumes are highly concentrated, with Binance accounting for about half the market.
Users can continue trading USDC on Binance, while deposits and withdrawals of USDC via other supported networks will not be impacted.
Binance’s prime brokerage partners can plug investors into the liquidity available on the exchange.

site_title: Amazon to push cashierless shopping tech into more third-party stores, while backing off itself
summary: Amazon plans to expand its cashierless shopping technology, Just Walk Out, into over 280 third-party stores this year, including stadiums and airports. The technology will be phased out in its own Fresh stores, instead relying on "smart" shopping carts that log items and charge customers. Amazon refuted a report that the technology relies on human reviewers in India, stating that computer vision algorithms handle receipt generation. The expansion aims to keep pace with competitors like Walmart, as Just Walk Out has faced issues with customer confusion and delayed receipts.

images.alt_text: The most recent data, showing 75 per cent of US shoppers have Prime memberships, is a clear indication that Amazon is still gaining new subscribers.

Amazon is looking to Subspace omega's lawsuit dismissed for a number of reasons, including its failure to show AWS had any requirement to provide free network connections to it in locations around the globe.
The story of Amazon's foray into AI-powered grocery shopping is a stark reminder that “artificial intelligence” still often requires armies of human babysitters to work properly.

site_title: Singapore loses ‘world’s best airport’ crown to Qatar
summary: Singapore's Changi Airport lost its title as the world's best airport to Qatar's Hamad International in the 2024 Skytrax World Airport Awards. Doha secured its second consecutive win, while Seoul Incheon took third place and Tokyo's Haneda and Narita airports placed fourth and fifth. Hong Kong's airport saw a significant boost, rising 22 positions to 11th place, and US airports were absent from the top 10.

images.alt_text: Lee Seow Hiang (left) and Yam Kum Weng.
The February passenger traffic was also 33.7 per cent higher than that for February 2023.

site_title: Huawei starts sales of new Pura 70 smartphone amid scrutiny on chips
summary: Huawei has started selling its Pura 70 smartphone series, featuring advanced cameras and sleek designs, amid scrutiny over its use of China-made chips. The Pro and Ultra versions were out of stock just a minute after sales began, with analysts expecting the handsets to contain a China-made chip similar to those in the Mate 60 series, which was seen as a triumph over US sanctions. The launch is seen as a significant move by Huawei to maintain its presence in the market despite ongoing scrutiny.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Smartphones are displayed in Huawei's first global flagship store in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, China October 30, 2019. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

Huawei's managing director and chairman of smart car solutions, Richard Yu, is expecting the unit to turn a profit from April.
Last year marks the third consecutive year of growth for Huawei, after revenue plummeted by almost a third in 2021.

site_title: Condo rents inch up after 7-month decline; volumes recover: SRX, 99.co
summary: Singapore's condo rental market rebounded in March after a 7-month decline, with rental volumes increasing 19.1% to 5,677 units. Condo rents rose 0.3% month-on-month, while HDB rents increased 0.6% for the second straight month. The recovery is attributed to a narrowing price gap between condos and HDBs, making condos more attractive to tenants. However, analysts predict a slower pace of growth due to the Singapore economy's slower growth and a steady supply of new housing units.

images.alt_text: MND said open market rents for HDB flats have stabilised in 2023 after spiking in 2022.
When it comes to renting, 4-room HDB flats and 2-bedroom condo units are the most popular among tenants.
Rents of HDB flats have grown 1 per cent month on month, but volumes are down 19.1 per cent.

site_title: Next steps
summary: Late-stage startups are seeking profitability amidst funding crunches, with Granite Asia and Ninja Van taking steps to expand their operations and revenue streams. Granite Asia, a rebranded venture capital firm, is launching a credit product and setting its sights across the Asia-Pacific. Ninja Van, a logistics company, is moving into the cold chain space to tap into higher-margin revenue streams. These moves reflect the growing pressure on startups to find profitability in a competitive market.

images.alt_text: search for profitability is a common mantra that almost all late-stage startups have been chanting as they navigate a funding crunch.

site_title: Indonesian volcano eruption forces evacuations, airport closure
summary: Indonesia's Mount Ruang volcano erupted, forcing evacuations and airport closures. The volcano belched explosive plumes of lava, rocks, and ash, prompting over 800 evacuations and a widening of the evacuation zone. Authorities raised the alert status, warning of a potential for further eruption and a risk of tsunami. Transport authorities shut the Manado airport and airlines cancelled flights to nearby airports due to ash showers. The disaster mitigation agency is evacuating more residents and cordoning off a 6km area around the volcano, citing a high risk of further eruption and damage.

images.alt_text: A man holds his new Rupiah bank notes, to be given to family members during the Eid festival which marks the end of the holy month of Ramadan, in Jakarta on March 28, 2024. (Photo by Adek BERRY / AFP)
Indonesia straddles the so-called “Pacific Ring of Fire”, an area of high seismic activity that rests atop multiple tectonic plates.

site_title: Singapore shares climb at Thursday’s open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% at the opening of trading on Thursday, April 18, with the Straits Times Index (STI) increasing 10.06 points to 3,164.75. The broader market saw 63 gainers and 43 losers, with Seatrium being the most heavily traded counter. The STI's gain was despite losses in the US market and mixed regional results.

images.alt_text: Delfi Orchard, which is majority held by City Developments, is on the market at a S$438 million guide price.

site_title: Australia regulator flags surge in company insolvencies to 11-year high
summary: Australia's corporate regulator reported a surge in company insolvencies, reaching an 11-year high. In the nine months to March 31, 7,742 companies entered administration, a 36.2% increase from the previous period. The construction and hospitality industries were the hardest hit, accounting for nearly 27.7% and 15.2% of insolvencies. Sluggish consumer demand and high operating costs contributed to the rise in insolvencies. The regulator expects the number of companies to exceed 10,000 by the end of the financial year, a level not seen since 2012-2013.

images.alt_text: Figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Thursday showed net employment dropped 6,600 in March from February, when it rose a revised 117,600.

site_title: Federal Reserve will cut interest rates at some point, but no hurry, says Mester
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President Loretta Mester stated that price pressures are expected to ease further this year, allowing the Fed to reduce borrowing costs. However, the Fed will not rush to cut interest rates, preferring to wait until it has confidence that inflation is heading sustainably towards its 2% goal. Mester emphasized the need for the economy to show itself before normalizing policy.

site_title: Bank of Japan’s Noguchi says future rate hikes likely to be slow
summary: Bank of Japan board member Asahi Noguchi stated that future rate hikes by the central bank are likely to be slow, unlike other major central banks. The pace of policy rate adjustment is expected to be slow, taking time to reach a 2% inflation trend. This shift marks a departure from the BOJ's previous focus on reflating growth with massive monetary stimulus. Noguchi's comments come as investors await clues on when the central bank will raise short-term interest rates again, with bets ranging between July and the final quarter of this year.

site_title: Philippine Coast Guard to join military drills with United States
summary: The Philippine Coast Guard will participate in the annual Balikatan joint military exercise with the US for the first time, alongside over 16,700 Filipino and American troops. The drills, starting Monday, will focus on the northern and western parts of the Philippines, near the South China Sea and Taiwan. The exercises will simulate an armed recapture of an island and the sinking of a vessel, marking the first time the drills will extend beyond the Philippines' territorial waters. The move aims to counter China's growing assertiveness and deepen US defense cooperation with regional allies.

images.alt_text: BRP Gregorio Del Pilar (above) and USS Gabrielle Giffords sailing during the 3rd AFP-USINDOPACOM Maritime Cooperative Activity in the disputed South China Sea, February 9, 2024. The United States has been working to strengthen defence cooperation with its allies in the Asia-Pacific region to counter China’s growing influence.

(From left) Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos Jr., US President Joe Biden and Japan Prime Minister Fumio Kishida arrive for a trilateral meeting at the White House in Washington, DC, April 11, 2024.
Xi Jinping has pledged to bring Taiwan under China's control someday, by force if necessary.
Among individual nations, Beijing garnered some three out of four votes in Muslim-majority Malaysia, Indonesia and Brunei.
President Ferdinand Marcos Jr vows to implement countermeasures against “illegal, coercive, aggressive and dangerous attacks” by China’s coastguard.

site_title: China’s better economic growth hides reasons to worry
summary: China's economic growth appears to be on track to meet its 5% target for the year, with the country's manufacturing sector experiencing a significant boost in the first quarter. However, experts warn that this growth is not sustainable, citing concerns over deflation, which has been exacerbated by a decline in the property market and falling prices. Despite China's efforts to promote manufacturing and reduce reliance on foreign suppliers, the country's economy remains vulnerable to protectionist backlash from trading partners, and its leaders seem complacent about the risks of deflation.

images.alt_text: China’s manufacturing drive has exacerbated tensions with trading partners.

“China’s export of electric vehicles, lithium batteries and solar products have enriched supplies to the global market and eased inflationary pressure, as well as made a great contribution for global efforts to tackle climate change and green transition,” President Xi told Chancellor Olaf Scholz.
The figures suggest domestic demand is struggling to maintain any momentum it picked up during the holiday season.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, DFI Retail Group, Cordlife, First Resources
summary: Several companies saw developments on Thursday (Apr 18) that may impact trading of their securities. City Developments Ltd (CDL) is up for collective sale of its strata-titled building, Delfi Orchard, at a S$438 million guide price. DFI Retail Group has put its last two Singapore properties on the market with a total guide price of S$48.5 million. Cordlife Group filed a police report against former employees over alleged "potential wrongdoings". First Resources denied allegations of clearing rainforests in Indonesia and appointed a sustainability consulting firm to investigate.

images.alt_text: City Developments (CityDev) on Thursday reported that its net profit for the third quarter ended September 30, 2016 rose 60.1 per cent to S$170.3 million, from S$106.4 million a year ago.

site_title: Japan’s Uniqlo opens Rome store as part of European expansion
summary: Uniqlo has opened its second store in Italy, a 1,300 sqm shop in Rome, as part of its European expansion plans. The store, one of five new openings in the spring-summer season, aims to cater to local shoppers and tourists. This milestone marks a significant step in Uniqlo's growth in Europe and North America, following record performances in these regions. The store features collaborations with local artists and designers, leveraging the appreciation for Japanese style and culture in Italy.

images.alt_text: People walk past a Fast Retailing Co. Uniqlo store in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday, Oct. 4, 2011. Most global investors predict Chinese growth will slow to less than half the pace sustained since the government began dismantling Mao Zedong's communist economy three decades ago, a Bloomberg poll indicated. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Fast Retailing is not giving up on ambitions in mainland China either, where it already has more than 900 stores.

Fast Retailing has climbed 15 per cent this year to become the best-performer among 10 other clothing companies worldwide that have a market value of more than US$10 billion, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.
Fast Retailing, owner of Quniqlo, is seeking “immediate cessation of sales of the imitation products and compensation for damages incurred.

site_title: China education firms learn tough lessons overseas
summary: China's education firms are struggling to replicate their business model overseas after a dramatic shift in government policy sent the sector into disarray. The sector, once worth tens of billions of US dollars, has been hit by a crackdown that eliminated revenue streams and forced companies to become non-profits. As a result, firms are opening offline learning centers in cities like Singapore and Malaysia to cut costs and tap into local markets. However, they face challenges such as localizing products, finding local staff, and adapting to diverse cultural norms. Growth expectations have been tempered, with investors now expecting 20-30% growth for a full year.

images.alt_text: graduation cap, graduation, cap

Harvard president Claudine Gay resigned from her post after she was accused of plagiarism and for her widely criticised testimony about antisemitism at the college at a congressional hearing in December.

site_title: New Cadence supercomputers aim to speed creation of chips, software
summary: Cadence Design Systems introduced the latest version of supercomputers, Palladium Z3 and Protium X3, to speed up chip and software creation. The systems emulate chips virtually, allowing companies like Nvidia to start writing software while waiting for physical chips to return from the factory. This enables faster product delivery. The systems are crucial for electronics design, with Cadence CEO Anirudh Devgan stating they are "critical" to the industry. Nvidia is already testing the new systems, which can emulate chips twice as large as previous generations, and has the largest installation of Palladiums.

images.alt_text: AMD said the new chips are expected to be available in platforms from HP and Lenovo starting in the second quarter of 2024.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Samsung Electronics is seen at its office building in Seoul, South Korea, March 23, 2018.   REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo

site_title: Concord to buy Hipgnosis in US$1.4 billion deal
summary: Concord has agreed to buy Hipgnosis Songs Fund in a deal valued at approximately US$1.4 billion. The bidders offered Hipgnosis investors US$1.16 per share in cash, representing a 32% premium from the last closing price. Hipgnosis' board has unanimously agreed to the deal, citing "numerous company-specific and certain market issues" that make a share price increase unlikely. The acquisition is a result of Hipgnosis' struggles to recoup investments on music rights after purchasing song catalogues for artists such as the Red Hot Chili Peppers and Journey.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A headset is seen in front of displayed Hipgnosis logo in this illustration taken, June 28, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: US economy growing at ‘modest’ pace in many regions: Federal Reserve
summary: The US economy is showing "modest" growth in many regions, according to the Federal Reserve's "beige book" report. Ten of the 12 regional districts experienced slight or modest economic growth, up from two more than the previous report. The labor market also showed a slight pace of growth, and prices in many regions saw modest increases. The economy is expected to continue growing at an annual rate of 2.9% in the first quarter, driven by a resilient labor market despite high interest rates.

images.alt_text: Cleveland Federal Reserve Bank President Loretta Mester said that she expects price pressures to ease further this year, allowing the Fed to reduce borrowing costs.
FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage rose 12 basis points to 7.13 per cent in the week ended Apr 12.

Objects seen in the sky above Jerusalem on April 14 after Iran launched drones and missiles towards Israel hours earlier. The prospect of war in the Middle East has hurt investor sentiment, but is unlikely to affect stocks in the long run.
The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index, which tracks the US currency against 12 of its major peers, has risen by more than 4 per cent this year.
BOE officials have cautioned that they have lingering concerns about price pressures in the economy.
The US economy continues to surprise Fed officials with its resilience.

site_title: UBS plans next round of layoffs in Credit Suisse integration
summary: UBS plans another round of layoffs, this time affecting over 100 positions across its global investment bank, wealth management, and markets units. The move is part of the firm's efforts to save around US$6 billion in staff costs in the coming years. The job cuts follow previous reductions, including a January cut in senior investment bankers and staff trimming across Asia private wealth and investment banking teams. The move comes as UBS continues to integrate Credit Suisse, increasing its global workforce by around 45,000 to about 120,000.

images.alt_text: UBS has been adding to its structured rates offering over the past six months, while Nomura is also stepping up sales of products such as credit-linked notes, floating-rate notes, and inflation-linked bonds.
FILE PHOTO: The company's logo is seen at a branch of Swiss bank UBS in Zurich, Switzerland February 2, 2016. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann
The FSB is set to review its ranking of UBS among the list of global systemically important banks after the Credit Suisse takeover, which is due to close later this year.
UBS put the Credit Suisse venture up for sale after taking control of its smaller Swiss rival when it collapsed last year.

site_title: Europe: Adidas, LVMH steer shares higher on earnings relief
summary: European stocks rose 0.2% on Wednesday, rebounding from a 9-month low on Tuesday, driven by strong quarterly results from luxury brands LVMH and Adidas. Adidas surged 8.6% to a two-year high after beating earnings expectations, while LVMH climbed 2.8%. The personal and household goods sector gained 1.8%, but technology stocks fell 3.2% due to weaker-than-expected bookings from ASML. Investors remain cautious ahead of interest rate decisions and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: When titans clash, can Asean gain?
summary: Asean can benefit from the reconfiguration of global supply and value chains as companies shift investments away from China, with 11% of respondents in a survey citing Asean as their destination. Asean's advantage lies in its lower-cost environment, large populations, developed industries, and supply chains, as well as its friendly stance towards China, the US, and Europe. However, this shift may not be beneficial for the global economy, potentially leading to a more fragmented and decoupled world economy, according to the International Monetary Fund. Asean can play a key role in preventing this by strengthening economic integration and pursuing common interests on the multilateral stage.

images.alt_text: TSMC, which makes integrated circuits for various products, is a good example of a company outside China that is vital for the digital revolution.
The recent supply-chain reconfiguration has presented opportunities – and risks – for economies, especially in South-east Asia.

site_title: Boeing whistleblower details his concerns to Congressional panel
summary: A Boeing quality engineer, Sam Salehpour, testified before the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee, detailing his concerns about the company's 787 Dreamliner. Salehpour alleged that Boeing took manufacturing shortcuts that could lead to planes breaking apart during flights, despite acknowledging the risks. Boeing has acknowledged changes in the manufacturing process but claims the airframe's durability was not affected. The subcommittee is seeking transparency from Boeing and the FAA regarding the integrity of Boeing aircraft, amid safety concerns following recent crashes and allegations of a "cozy" relationship between Boeing and regulators.

images.alt_text: Sam Salehpour, quality engineer at Boeing, prior to a Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, April 17, 2024. US lawmakers challenged Boeing Co. to expend the necessary time and effort to reset its safety culture and criticized the planemaker's relationship with regulators as too cozy. Photographer: Graeme Sloan/Bloomberg
A Boeing 787 Dreamliner being built at the aviation company's North Charleston, South Carolina, assembly plant on May 30, 2023.
United Airlines was impacted more than rivals by the MAX 9 grounding, which followed a January emergency landing of an Alaska Airlines flight after a panel on the fuselage blew out midair.
Several Chinese carriers including Air China operate direct flights to and from the US.
Airbus is targeting a roughly 50 per cent increase in production of its A320neo cash cow to 75 planes a month by 2026.
Boeing has slowed the pace of work on the 737 family to give workers and suppliers breathing room to catch up on damaged or missing parts and get its production lines back in order.
The planemaker has been grappling with a full-blown safety crisis that has undermined its reputation following a Jan 5 mid-air panel blowout on a 737 MAX plane.
Boeing has come under intense criticism since a door plug panel tore off a new Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9 jet at 16,000 feet on Jan 5.
FILE PHOTO: The Boeing logo is displayed on a screen, at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., August 7, 2019. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo
An Alaska Air-operated MAX 9 jet experienced a mid-air cabin panel blowout in January, which led the US aviation regulator to order grounding of 171 jets for inspections.
Boeing has slowed production of its bestselling model to address quality lapses tied to a near-disaster on a 737 Max 9 in January.

site_title: China slams US move to investigate its shipbuilding industry
summary: China has criticized the US for launching a formal review of its maritime, logistics, and shipbuilding sector, calling it a "mistake based on domestic politics." The US Trade Representative's office announced the probe in response to a petition from five major union groups, amid President Joe Biden's plans to increase tariffs on Chinese steel and aluminum. China's Commerce Ministry spokesperson stated that the investigation is "full of false accusations" and will take necessary measures to protect its rights and interests.

site_title: A deep dive into China’s expectations-beating GDP growth
summary: China's GDP grew 5.3% year-on-year in the first quarter, surpassing market expectations of 4.9%, driven by stronger-than-expected infrastructure investment and accelerating economic recovery. However, the growth was partly dragged down by weak prices, with the consumer price index remaining unchanged and the producer price index falling 2.7%. The economic recovery has been patchy, with persistent low prices, weak credit and social financing, and a protracted real estate slump weighing on the sector's investment.

images.alt_text: Total air passenger traffic reached almost 180 million trips in the first three months of 2024.
China’s manufacturing drive has exacerbated tensions with trading partners.

The yuan has lost about 1.9 per cent in value against the US dollar so far this year, pressured by its relative low yields versus other currencies and outflows of foreign investment from an anaemic stock market.
Average monthly salaries offered by companies to new recruits in 38 key Chinese cities rose 2.2 per cent from a year before to 10,323 yuan (S$1,941).
An aerial view of residential buildings under construction in Hangzhou, in eastern China's Zhejiang province.

site_title: Billionaires selling cheap stuff get richer from inflation pain
summary: Billionaires behind budget stores in Asia are accumulating wealth as customers seek affordable items amid inflation. Owners like Radhakishan Damani, Trial Holdings' founder, and Miniso Group Holding's Ye Guofu have seen their fortunes rise, with Damani's wealth surging by about one-third in the past year. Asung Daiso, a South Korean retailer with over 1,500 stores, has benefited from the trend, with its revenue and profit increasing 17% and 27% respectively last year, despite a 38% profit slump in 2019 due to a name issue.

images.alt_text: Closely held Daiso, with revenue of 589.1 billion yen (S$5.28 billion) in the year ended February 2023, had 4,360 domestic stores and 990 overseas locations by the end of December.

site_title: IMF says US, China debt pose risks for global public finances
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that the US and China's debt pose significant risks for global public finances over the next five years. Higher interest rates in the US, driven by American spending, will strengthen the US dollar and increase debt burdens for other countries. China's slowdown and fiscal imbalances also pose risks, particularly through lower international trade and investments. The IMF singles out the US, China, UK, and Italy as nations with serious fiscal risks, emphasizing the need for policy action to address imbalances between spending and revenues.

images.alt_text: (FILES) The International Monetary Fund (IMF) logo is displayed outside its headquarters in Washington, DC, on October 8, 2022. The International Monetary Fund officially launched the selection process to find the organization next leader on March 13, 2024, with current managing director Kristalina Georgieva widely tipped for a second five-year term. (Photo by Stefani Reynolds / AFP)

We hope to continue discussions with the bondholders with a view to reaching common ground ahead of the IMF board consideration of the second review of Sri Lanka’s EFF (extended fund facility) programme,” says state finance minister Shehan Semasinghe in a statement.
Fund officials estimate that the changes will reduce the time between staff agreement and board signoff on an IMF programme to as little as two months.
The IMF forecasts global real GDP growth of 3.2 per cent for 2024 and 2025 – the same rate as in 2023

site_title: Gold gains as Middle East tensions lift safe-haven appeal
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to US$2,369.93 per ounce as Middle East tensions increased, boosting demand for the safe-haven metal. The increase follows concerns about the war's potential to spread to other regions, with Western countries urging restraint. US gold futures dipped 0.1% to US$2,385.10 per ounce. The price surge is a response to heightened global uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Spot gold held its ground at US$2,383.29 per ounce.

site_title: Taylor Swift sells a rainbow of vinyl albums and fans keep buying them
summary: Taylor Swift has sold a total of 35 physical products for her album "Midnights," including six vinyl variants, earning her $3.5 million in the US. The album's success has fueled a growing trend of fans buying collectible versions of new releases, with Swift's albums being particularly sought after. This phenomenon has been driven in part by the higher revenues artists can earn from physical products compared to streaming. Fans, like Taylor Hammers, a 24-year-old collector, are willing to spend hundreds of dollars on unique versions of Swift's albums, with some editions featuring bonus tracks, autographed photos, and even trinkets.

images.alt_text: Victims are asked to pay upfront for the tickets, but once the payment is made, the scammers disappear.

Live Nation’s subsidiary Ticketmaster, which for decades has been condemned for hardball tactics and high prices, was also widely criticised in 2022 after botched ticket sales for Taylor Swift’s “Eras” tour.
No Doubt – the group fronted by Gwen Stefani – played together for the first time in 15 years on the second day of Coachella.
Taylor Swift performing  in Sydney on Feb 23.
Taylor Swift, 34, also has a significant real estate portfolio, with homes in New York, Beverly Hills, Nashville and a coastal mansion in Rhode Island.
Hybe, based in Seoul, has been releasing more English songs for K-pop bands and promoting artists including Jung Kook in the United States.
UOB says credit card applications among 25- to 29-year-olds are up four percentage points from Jun 21 to Jul 7

site_title: Finding a growth vector with digital solutions
summary: Vector InfoTech, a 30-year-old Singaporean company, has expanded its digital solutions to include areas such as cybersecurity, energy efficiency, and sustainable technologies. Founded by Lau Kok Hui in 1992, the company has 15 offices across Asia and the Middle East, with over 200 employees and annual revenue exceeding S$40 million. Vector InfoTech has continued to grow, particularly during the Covid-19 pandemic, and plans to list on the US Nasdaq or Singapore Exchange to fund its expansion. The company aims to generate more than S$100 million in revenue in the next five years and outlast its founder for a thousand years.

images.alt_text: Crayon Data's team at work in the company's development centre in Chennai, India.

The management of Hisaka (Singapore) pose with awards that the company has won. (L-R) Director of finance and IT Jessica Ong; director of office and administration Joanna Tan; managing director Anthony Cheng; director of business strategy Jackie Cheng; and director of operations Andy Yong.

site_title: Australia’s March employment unexpectedly falls 6,600, jobless rate ticks up to 3.8%
summary: Australia's employment numbers unexpectedly fell 6,600 in March, with the jobless rate rising to 3.8% from 3.7%. This marks a reversal from the previous month's gain of 117,600. Full-time employment rose 27,900, but the labor market remains tight, according to analysts. The Reserve Bank of Australia has left interest rates unchanged at 4.35% despite expectations of a loosening job market. Markets remain confident that interest rates have peaked, with only a 65% probability of a rate cut in December.

images.alt_text: The policy will be a pillar of next month’s budget, as well as a major feature of a second-term agenda for Albanese’s government, ahead of an election due by mid-2025.

FILE PHOTO: Australian Treasurer Jim Chalmers poses for a photograph as he arrives to attend a G20 finance ministers' and Central Bank governors' meeting at Gandhinagar, India, July 18, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo
Confidence in the economic outlook has slipped in April.

site_title: Philippine central bank’s deputy governor sees upside risks to inflation
summary: The Philippine central bank's deputy governor, Francis Dakila Jr, warns of upside risks to inflation, despite the BSP's aggressive tightening campaign. Inflation may breach the target of 2-4% in the second quarter before easing back to within the range in the second half of the year, with an average inflation rate of 3.8%. The central bank remains committed to maintaining price stability and is not in a rush to lower borrowing costs, with Governor Eli Remolona signaling potential rate cuts in 2025.

images.alt_text: Eli Remolona, Governor of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, speaks at an event at the Central Bank in Manila, Philippines, on Friday, July 28, 2023. Remolona said upside risks to inflation persist, in comments that indicate the monetary authority is open to further tightening. Photographer: Lisa Marie David/Bloomberg
The Philippines last week trimmed the economic growth forecasts for this year and next while widening fiscal deficit estimates to support higher spending.
Costlier food due to El Nino, along with higher transport and power costs, remains a key risk to the price outlook.
The Philippines now expects the economy to grow between 6 and 7 per cent in 2024, from a 6.5 to 7.5 per cent projection last December.

site_title: ‘No trade war’, says Biden, pushing to triple tariffs on Chinese steel
summary: US President Joe Biden announced new actions to protect American steel and shipbuilding industries, including tripling tariffs on Chinese steel. The move comes amid a probe into China's trade practices in the shipbuilding, maritime, and logistics sectors. Biden stated there is no trade war with Beijing, but China has expressed strong opposition to the probe and tariffs. The US Trade Representative's investigation aims to address "unreasonable and discriminatory" policies and practices used by Beijing to dominate these industries.

images.alt_text: A healthy portion of the purchases by Chinese tourists occurred in Japan, where the well-heeled took advantage of the weak yen to buy Louis Vuitton bags and other costly items for less.

US President Joe Biden and Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida review the honour guard during an official ceremony in Washington.
President Joe Biden is also calling for higher tariffs on Chinese steel and aluminium.

site_title: Microsoft-OpenAI deal set to dodge formal EU merger probe: sources
summary: Microsoft's $13 billion investment in OpenAI is not considered an acquisition, according to EU antitrust regulators, avoiding a formal probe that could have led to onerous remedies for Microsoft. The deal was initially subject to merger rules, but Microsoft maintains it does not own any portion of the ChatGPT maker. The EU competition enforcer still reviews partnerships between large digital market players and generative AI developers, with informal scrutiny in other regions, including the UK and US.

images.alt_text: Rubrik is aiming to raise up to US$713 million by selling 23 million shares priced between US$28 and US$31 each.
Microsoft president Brad Smith will join G42’s board, and G42 will use the US software maker’s Azure cloud for its AI applications.
FILE PHOTO: Microsoft offices in Issy-les-Moulineaux near Paris, France, February 9, 2024. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo

site_title: How war and Fed fund rates may impact your Singapore stock portfolio
summary: War and Fed fund rate changes may impact Singapore stock portfolios, but the effects are unlikely to be lasting. Research shows that wars and major geopolitical shocks tend to correct themselves quickly, with the S&P 500 index recovering its losses within 47 days. The US dollar is expected to remain resilient, driven by reduced Fed action and Middle East uncertainties. Investors should consider diversifying their portfolios and stress testing them, rather than making short-term decisions based on market fluctuations.

images.alt_text: The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index, which tracks the US currency against 12 of its major peers, has risen by more than 4 per cent this year.
Spot gold held its ground at US$2,383.29 per ounce.
Without the tailwind of immediate Fed rate cuts, there is likely to more scrutiny of corporate profitability and stock valuations in the remaining months of 2024

site_title: Google lays off employees, shifts some roles abroad amid cost cuts
summary: Google is laying off an unspecified number of employees as the company cuts costs amid investment in artificial intelligence. The layoffs follow previous job cuts in January and affect employees in multiple teams, including real estate and finance departments. A small percentage of impacted roles will move to hubs in India, Chicago, Atlanta, and Dublin. Google CEO Sundar Pichai reportedly warned employees of more job cuts at the start of the year. The company aims to become more efficient and align resources to its biggest product priorities.

site_title: Oil falls over US$1 as demand worries outweigh Middle East supply risks
summary: Oil prices dropped over $1, with Brent futures for June falling to $89.01 a barrel and US crude futures for May falling to $84.48 a barrel. The decline was driven by concerns over global demand, following weaker economic data from China and dimmed prospects of interest rate cuts. Middle East supply risks were also weighed, but did not outweigh demand worries. Oil prices have softened this week due to economic headwinds and market uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for June delivery settled 8 cents lower, or 0.1 per cent at US$90.02 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: Elon Musk stakes fortune on cult following who made him rich
summary: Elon Musk is seeking to reapprove a 2018 compensation package worth $40.2 billion, which was previously voided by a Delaware court. The package, which includes 12 tranches of stock options, was approved by 73% of disinterested shareholders in 2018. However, with the market's values having surged since then, the proposal now faces scrutiny. Tesla's board argues that the package demonstrates alignment with long-term investors' interests, while institutional shareholders have expressed support for the plan. Rejection of the package could impact Musk's future as CEO and lead to a delay in any potential compensation.

images.alt_text: South African businessman Elon Musk arrives at the Tenth Breakthrough Prize Ceremony at the Academy Museum of Motion Pictures in Los Angeles, California, on April 13, 2024. (Photo by ETIENNE LAURENT / AFP)
Musk, who runs six companies, said early this year he preferred to work on artificial intelligence and robotics products elsewhere unless he owns a 25 per cent stake in Tesla.

FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk, CEO of SpaceX and Tesla and owner of X, formerly known as Twitter, attends the Viva Technology conference dedicated to innovation and startups at the Porte de Versailles exhibition centre in Paris, France, June 16, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo
India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi shakes hand with Tesla chief executive Elon Musk during their meeting in New York, US, June 20, 2023. Musk is expected to visit India this month.
Elon Musk says a lack of advanced chips was hampering the training of Grok’s version 2 model.

site_title: Banks told to anticipate risks from using AI, machine learning
summary: Banking regulators are warning banks to anticipate risks from using artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) due to potential amplification of future banking crises. According to Bank of Spain governor Pablo Hernandez de Cos, banks must incorporate AI/ML risks into their day-to-day risk management and governance arrangements. A comprehensive report on the digitalisation of finance is expected from the Basel Committee, which will require collaboration among central banks and regulators to achieve an appropriate regulatory baseline for AI and ML oversight.

images.alt_text: “The proposed revisions aim at constraining banks’ ability to lower their G-SIB scores through window-dressing,” the Basel Committee says.

“In total, it will be 20 years since the Great Financial Crisis by the time the last element of the outstanding Basel III standards is expected to be implemented in 2028,” Basel Committee chair Pablo Hernandez de Cos says.

site_title: Pacific International Lines posts US$277.6 million earnings for FY2023, expects to stay profitable in FY2024
summary: Pacific International Lines (PIL) reported a net profit of US$277.6 million for FY2023, 10% of its FY2022 earnings, due to a 53% decline in revenue. Cargo rates fell 58% on a per 20-foot-equivalent-unit basis. PIL mitigated the impact by controlling costs and leveraging digitalization. The carrier expects to stay profitable in FY2024 and plans to set up representative offices in eight Latin American countries. PIL aims to increase refrigerated container shipping to 10-12% of volume and refresh its brand with an updated logo and website.

images.alt_text: Shipping contributes 3 per cent of current total emissions; that number could balloon to 10 per cent by 2050 unless alternative fuels are rapidly developed, commercialised and scaled.
Houthi attacks have disrupted global shipping through the Suez Canal, forcing firms to re-route to longer and more expensive journeys around southern Africa.

site_title: Apple to invest US$250 million into expanding Ang Mo Kio campus
summary: Apple plans to invest over US$250 million in expanding its Ang Mo Kio campus in Singapore, with construction set to begin later this year. The expansion will provide space for growth and new roles in artificial intelligence and other key functions, and will be powered by 100% renewable energy. With over 3,600 staff, the campus will continue to play a crucial role in enriching the lives of Apple's customers in Singapore. The expansion is seen as a new chapter in Apple's history in Singapore, where the company made its initial foray in 1981.

site_title: Climate impacts set to cut 2050 global GPD by nearly a fifth
summary: Climate change is projected to shrink global GDP by nearly a fifth by 2050, amounting to approximately $38 trillion, regardless of the level of carbon pollution cuts. The study, published in Nature, warns that if the planet warms significantly beyond 2°C above mid-19th century levels, economic impacts could increase by tens of trillions of dollars per year by 2100. The researchers found that limiting warming below 2°C could limit regional income loss to 20% compared to 60% in a high-emissions scenario, highlighting the importance of near-term action.

images.alt_text: Research shows that temperature affects cognitive performance and decision-making. Hotter days are linked to more mistakes, more local crime, and even more use of profanity on social media.

site_title: ECB firmly behind June rate cut but views diverge on July
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has reaffirmed plans for a rate cut in June, but policymakers are divided on future moves due to uncertainty over inflation and risks from the US Federal Reserve. Bundesbank chief Joachim Nagel and ECB board member Piero Cipollone suggested a potential rate cut in July, while others, including ECB Chief Christine Lagarde, have pushed back on discussing future moves beyond June. The ECB's decision on June's rate cut is seen as a significant move, with markets anticipating just three rate cuts this year.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians pass the Euro logo in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany, on March 7, 2024 ahead of the European Central Bank (ECB) governing council meeting. (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)

site_title: Rich China tourists drive luxury demand in Japan on weak yen
summary: Wealthy Chinese tourists are driving luxury demand in Japan due to the country's weak yen, with LVMH's sales in the country surging by almost a third in the first quarter. Demand from Chinese tourists also boosted luxury spend in Japan, with analysts predicting that Chinese shoppers will make up 23% of global luxury goods spending this year. The trend suggests that luxury consumers are adapting to economic uncertainty at home by shopping abroad, particularly in Japan, where the yen is at 34-year lows.

images.alt_text: The total of 3.08 million represented an increase of 69.5 per cent from March 2023 and a 11.6-per cent gain compared to March 2019 before the pandemic battered global tourism.

LVMH, owner of Louis Vuitton, Tiffany and Bulgari, said sales for the quarter ending in March were up 3 per cent year-on-year on an organic basis to 20.69 billion euros (S$30 billion), matching analyst expectations.
Total air passenger traffic reached almost 180 million trips in the first three months of 2024.

site_title: Delfi Orchard up for collective sale at S$438 million guide price
summary: Delfi Orchard, a 40-year-old strata-titled building in Orchard Road, Singapore, is up for collective sale at a guide price of S$438 million. The property comprises 150 units, with 126 owned by City Developments Ltd (CDL), who will receive between S$2.2 million and S$4.6 million each. The sale price works out to S$3,397 per square foot per plot ratio, and could include redevelopment of up to 131,186 sq ft. The sale is the third major divestment by CDL in two years, following the sale of Tanglin Shopping Centre and Golden Mile Complex.

images.alt_text: The changing face of orchard road
The S$910 million collective sale of Far East Shopping Centre is said to have fallen through.

site_title: ‘Huge role’ for lawyers in green transition, carbon markets: Temasek CEO
summary: Temasek's CEO Dilhan Pillay emphasizes the significant role lawyers will play in shaping governance standards and legal frameworks for the green transition and carbon markets. As companies navigate complex regulatory landscapes, lawyers will guide clients on managing potential liabilities and addressing reputational risks. Pillay highlights the need for lawyers to exercise judgment in minimizing greenwashing and advising clients on ESG efforts. Countries are developing legal frameworks to support the green transition, and lawyers will play a crucial role in shaping climate-friendly policies and influencing legislative changes.

images.alt_text: The Singapore city skyline in the evening on April 4, 2023.
Minister Grace Fu said the election year will throw up challenges for implementing climate policies.
DBS chief executive officer Piyush Gupta (left) speaking at a panel session during Ecosperity, a sustainability conference organised by Temasek.
Panellists at Ecosperity highlighted corporate buy-in as important for securing funding.

site_title: In AI-copyright battle, an existential crisis emerges
summary: The US Copyright Office has rejected copyright applications for art created using AI, requiring "human creation" for authorship protection. A proposed bill would require disclosure of copyrighted works used in training generative AI models. Detractors argue that AI models are not different from humans inspired by others' work, while proponents see this as a test of what it means to be human. The rejection highlights the societal implications of AI's role in creative processes, sparking debate about the value of human contribution in art and existence.

images.alt_text: The US film, television and animation industry employs some 550,000 people.
Some copyright holders have cut deals with OpenAI for using their work.

site_title: US: Wall Street slips as dour earnings, chip stocks weigh
summary: US stocks slipped on Wednesday, with chip stocks leading the decline, as earnings reports from major companies, including Travelers and JB Hunt Transport Services, missed expectations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.37% to 37,659.49, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the Nasdaq dropping 0.59%. Despite this, some airline stocks, including United Airlines, gained ground, and investors see a 43% chance that the Fed may start easing monetary policy in July.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 0.2 per cent higher, after notching its biggest one-day drop in over nine months on Tuesday, with the personal and household goods sector jumping 1.8 per cent.

site_title: Michelin challenges EU’s hunt for evidence of tyre cartel
summary: Michelin is challenging the European Union's antitrust raids on its facilities, claiming the decision was based on "vague and insufficient elements." The French tyre firm was part of a surprise inspection in January, alongside rivals Bridgestone, Continental, and Goodyear Tyre & Rubber. Michelin claims the raids were not proportionate and did not meet EU competition rules. If successful, the appeal could void evidence gathered during the inspections, potentially hindering regulators' efforts to build a case.

images.alt_text: Michelin has already invested more than 1 billion euros in Thailand with five plants and 8,000 workers, the government said in a statement issued during Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin’s visit to France.
Sales at Michelin dipped 0.9 per cent last year to 28.3 billion euros (S$41 billion).

site_title: IMF calls for fiscal restraint in year with most elections ever
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged countries to implement fiscal restraint in 2024, dubbed the "Great Election Year," due to the record number of elections, which may lead to budget overruns and increased social spending. The IMF forecasts global real GDP growth of 3.2% for 2024 and 2025, but warns that slowing growth prospects and high interest rates will constrain fiscal space in most economies. Countries are advised to unwind pandemic-era support measures and rebuild fiscal buffers to avoid rising public debt, which is projected to approach 99% of GDP by 2029.

images.alt_text: Fund officials estimate that the changes will reduce the time between staff agreement and board signoff on an IMF programme to as little as two months.
The IMF forecasts global real GDP growth of 3.2 per cent for 2024 and 2025 – the same rate as in 2023

site_title: Earthquake jolts southern Japan’s Ehime, Kochi prefectures
summary: A 6.4-magnitude earthquake struck southern Japan's Ehime and Kochi prefectures late on Wednesday, April 17, with its epicenter in the Bungo Channel separating the islands of Kyushu and Shikoku. No tsunami warning was issued, and some water pipes burst, but no major damage was reported. Local media reported that the Ikata nuclear plant in Ehime prefecture, where one reactor is operational, showed no irregularities. Japan is one of the world's most seismically active areas, with earthquakes common in the region.

images.alt_text: The Pacific Tsunami Warning Centre said there was “no tsunami threat” from the quake in the Molucca Sea.
Semiconductor companies in Singapore supply equipment makers instead of foundries, which could limit any impact from disruptions caused by the Taiwan earthquake.
Technological advancements in Taiwan appear to have kept damage and casualties relatively low after the 7.4-magnitude quake on early Wednesday.

site_title: DFI puts its last 2 Singapore properties up for sale at S$48.5 million
summary: DFI Retail Group is selling its last two Singapore properties, an 8-unit retail complex at Siglap V and a 1-unit HDB retail unit in Toa Payoh, for a total guide price of S$48.5 million. The Siglap V units have a guide price of S$32 million and will be leased back to CS Fresh and Guardian supermarkets. The Toa Payoh unit, currently occupied by a Giant supermarket, will be sold on a vacant possession basis and closed by the end of the year. The sale is part of DFI's commitment to growing its retail operations in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The 127-metre-high Solitaire on Cecil will have about 190,000 sq ft of office space, and two strata restaurant units at street level.

krmall - Jelita Shopping Centre 

Copyright: JLL
OneTen Paya Lebar will have redevelopment potential if the height restriction on the site is lifted and the plot ratio increased, after the relocation of Paya Lebar Air Base.
Income Insurance, formerly known as NTUC Income Insurance Co-operative, acquired 30 Prinsep Street in 2001 for S$42.4m. It refurbished the building in 2013.

site_title: British actor Hugh Grant settles privacy lawsuit against publisher of the Sun
summary: Hugh Grant has settled a lawsuit against the publisher of The Sun, News Group Newspapers (NGN), over claims that journalists used private investigators to tap his phone, burglarize his house, and obtain confidential information. The lawsuit, which was one of several eligible to go to trial, was settled after Grant's lawyer, David Sherborne, announced the agreement. This settlement raises questions about NGN's long-held denial of wrongdoing, as the company has settled over 1,000 cases without admitting liability. Grant, a prominent press reform campaigner, had previously sued NGN over alleged wrongdoing at another tabloid, News of the World.

images.alt_text: Hugh Grant a 'curiosity', not a sex symbol

site_title: Bank of Korea chief signals readiness to deal with volatile currency moves
summary: Bank of Korea Governor Rhee Chang-yong stated that the South Korean won's exchange rate deviated slightly from market fundamentals, citing recent volatility. The move was attributed to receding US interest rate cut expectations and pressure from declining Japanese and Chinese currencies. Authorities have the resources and tools to manage any volatile currency moves, according to Rhee.

images.alt_text: The won extended declines against the dollar to hit the lowest in a year and a half.

site_title: TikTok divest-or-ban bill heads to fast track in US congress
summary: The House-passed TikTok legislation, aimed at forcing the Chinese parent company ByteDance to divest its ownership of the social media platform, is set to quickly become law. House Speaker Mike Johnson plans to include the bill in a package of fast-moving bills, with the Senate expected to consider the legislation soon. Senate Commerce Committee Chair Maria Cantwell has proposed changes to the bill, including giving ByteDance up to a year to divest itself of TikTok, longer than the six-month time frame in the House measure.

images.alt_text: The US Capitol Building in Washington, DC Photographer: Ting Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on megacaps boost; earnings, Fed comments
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by gains in megacap growth stocks. The S&P 500 rose 0.35%, the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.49%, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.40%. Investors awaited Federal Reserve commentary on the economy, while corporate earnings continued to roll in.

site_title: Jamie Dimon has a new vision for money in an AI world
summary: Jamie Dimon, CEO of JPMorgan, is laying out his vision for the future of money in an AI world. He likens AI to revolutionary technologies like the printing press, steam engine, and internet, and believes it will significantly improve banking processes, including trading, research, and customer service. Dimon envisions a future where AI is embedded in every JPMorgan process, making dramatic improvements in workers' quality of life, but also potentially displacing some jobs. He does not envision a single "finance super app" but rather a series of "mini super apps" that integrate various services, including AI-driven technologies.

images.alt_text: FILE Ñ Jamie Dimon, chairman and C.E.O. of JPMorgan Chase, during a Senate Banking Committee hearing on Capitol Hill in Washington, Dec. 6, 2023. Dimon used his annual letter to shareholders to flag higher-for-longer inflation, uncertain growth prospects and widening political divisions. (Al Drago/The New York Times)

site_title: Cordlife files police report against former employees for ‘potential wrongdoings’
summary: Cordlife Group has filed a police report against former employees over potential wrongdoings related to the exposure of a storage tank to temperatures above acceptable limits. The incident occurred at Tank A, which was exposed at different periods from November 2020. An internal investigation by an external consultant has uncovered preliminary evidence, prompting the company to convene a committee of inquiry. The police report is part of Cordlife's efforts to investigate the incident further.

images.alt_text: One of the
In letters seen by ST, parents who have been paying their storage fee annually have been offered refunds of $537.50.
The arrests of Cordlife's directors and group chief executive are related to alleged breaches-of-disclosure obligations regarding irregular temperatures in its storage tanks.
Cordlife said it cannot be certain of the viability and potency of every CBU stored in the high-risk tanks and will deem that the CBUs in these tanks are impacted by temperature excursions.

site_title: First Resources denies allegations of links to firms clearing forests in Indonesia
summary: First Resources, a Singapore-listed palm oil producer, has denied allegations of links to firms clearing Indonesian rainforests. The company responded to allegations made by The Gecko Project, a nonprofit newsroom, which claimed First Resources operated "shadow companies" responsible for clearing tens of thousands of hectares of rainforest since 2008. First Resources stated it has no ownership stake or management roles in the accused companies and has not entered into any transactions with them. The company has appointed a sustainability consulting firm to investigate the allegations.

images.alt_text: First Resources' earnings per share stands at US$0.0472 for the half year, down from US$0.1254 the previous year.
First Resources has bought mills, plantations and an unplanted land bank spanning 17,600 hectares in Indonesia.

site_title: Liberalise South-east Asia’s energy sector to attract more private finance: BlackRock official
summary: South-east Asia's energy sector, largely nationalized, needs to liberalize to attract private finance and support the energy transition, according to Philipp Hildebrand, BlackRock's vice-chairman. The region faces challenges in connecting renewable energy projects to the grid, hindering private capital investment. The Philippines' liberalization of its energy market is a model for other countries, with successful projects such as the Philippines' first coal phase-out transaction. Experts suggest creating a registry of successful projects and experimenting with innovative financing mechanisms to close the financing gap.

images.alt_text: Workers installing solar panels on the roof of Changi Airport Terminal 3 on February 14, 2024. Changi Airport will be home to Singapore’s largest array of rooftop solar panels in a single site. When completed in early 2025, the solar photovoltaic (PV) system will have a generation capacity of 38 Mega-Watt peak (MWp). This project will reduce Changi Airport Group (CAG)’s carbon emissions by approximately 20,000 tonnes each year, or about 10% of CAG’s consumption in 2019.

site_title: Mobileye set to ship at least 46 million new assisted driving chips
summary: Israeli automotive tech company Mobileye has secured orders to ship 46 million of its EyeQ6 Lite assisted-driving chips over the next few years. The chips will be used in vehicles launched in the middle of this year, with Volkswagen and Porsche among the customers. The EyeQ6 Lite system offers features such as automated cruise control and lane-changing, but is not designed for fully autonomous vehicles. The chip's manufacturing process is more power-efficient and cost-effective, with 4.5 times more computing horsepower than its prior generation.

images.alt_text: Mobileye, which counts auto parts suppliers Aptiv and Magna International among its customers, said the downturn forced it to reduce the annual shipment forecast for its driver-assist system SuperVision.

site_title: US 30-year mortgage rate rises to a four-month high of 7.13%
summary: US mortgage rates surged to a four-month high of 7.13% in the week ended Apr 12, with a 12 basis point increase to 7.13%, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. Despite this, purchase activity stabilized, with a 5% gain in mortgage applications for home purchases. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell indicated that higher inflation rates will delay interest rate cuts, potentially keeping mortgage rates elevated and tempering housing demand.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Residential single family homes construction by KB Home are shown under construction in the community of Valley Center, California, U.S. June 3, 2021.   REUTERS/Mike Blake/
Elevated mortgage rates have been a persistent market challenge, holding back first-time homebuyers and repeat homebuyers alike.
The Commerce Department says that construction spending dropped 0.3 per cent after an unrevised 0.2 per cent decline in January.
New home sales slipped 0.3 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 662,000 units last month, the Commerce Department’s Census Bureau says.

The figures indicate the resale market is breaking out of a protracted slump due to high mortgage rates that discouraged homeowners from moving and giving up a lower rate that they had locked in in the past few years.
Mortgage rates have fallen from an October peak near 8 per cent, but remain more than twice as high as they were in 2021.
Despite the hurdle created for many first-time buyers by higher mortgage rates, builders are cutting prices and offering other incentives to increase sales.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines looks to lighten plane loads on Middle East detour
summary: Malaysia Airlines will reroute flights from Kuala Lumpur to London to avoid airspace over parts of the Middle East, following Iran's attack on Israel, which requires more fuel and necessitates lightening plane loads. The measure, in effect from April 17 to April 30, is one of the most drastic airline responses to the fallout, joining Qantas, Singapore Airlines, and Air France in alternative plans. Regional airspace has reopened, but tensions persist.

images.alt_text: The diversion comes as Israel braces for a direct and unprecedented attack by Iran on government targets as soon as Saturday, according to people familiar with western intelligence assessments.
Deep losses in Asia carried over into European trading, but Wall Street’s main indices wobbled as corporate earnings season continued.

Pieces of an Iranian missile in a pickup truck outside Arad, Israel, on Sunday, April 14, 2024. On Saturday, Iran launched a retaliatory missile and drone attack on Israel; most of the missiles and drones were intercepted.
Explosions lighting up Jerusalem sky during an Iranian attack on Israel. Teheran has insisted the attack was an act of “self-defence”.
An Israeli Air Force fighter aircraft at an undisclosed airfield after a mission to intercept incoming airborne threats, April 14, 2024.

Iranian demonstrators show support during an anti-Israeli gathering at Palestine Square in Tehran, April 14, 2024, after Iran retaliated directly against Israel for the killings of its senior generals in Damascus, Syria, with an onslaught of more than 300 drones and missiles.
Iran says its latest attack follows an offensive on its diplomatic premises in Damascus on Apr 1.

site_title: Sri Lanka to consult with IMF on latest bondholders' proposal
summary: Sri Lanka will consult with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to assess a bondholders' proposal that was rejected due to being outside the parameters of its bailout program. The proposal aimed to restructure over $12 billion in debt. The rejection puts at risk critical IMF support and delays efforts to resolve a debt crisis. Finance Minister Shehan Semasinghe hopes to continue discussions with bondholders to reach common ground ahead of the IMF board's consideration of the second review of Sri Lanka's extended fund facility program.

site_title: High Court dismisses China businessman’s claims against Huttons and agent in misrepresentation suit
summary: A Chinese businessman, Chen Qiming, claimed Huttons property agent Ong Jianlong made misrepresentations about a condominium unit he purchased for S$1.5 million. However, Justice S Mohan dismissed all claims, stating Chen misunderstood Ong's statement about constructing a loft. Chen also claimed Ong promised he could resell the unit without difficulty, but the judge found no evidence to support this claim. Huttons and Ong were also found not liable for vicariously assisting Chen. The judge acknowledged gaps in the narrative, particularly contemporaneous WeChat messages exchanged between Chen and Ong.

images.alt_text: Lloyd Sixtyfive is a freehold condominium unit in the Orchard area where Chinese businessman Chen Qiming bought a unit in 2018.

site_title: Tesla asks investors to approve Musk’s US$56 billion pay again
summary: Tesla is seeking to reapprove Elon Musk's $56 billion compensation package, which was previously voided by a Delaware court in 2018. The company's annual meeting will take place on June 13, and shareholders will also vote on moving Tesla's incorporation from Delaware to Texas. Musk, who now owns 13% of the company, has stated his preference to focus on AI and robotics products unless he owns a 25% stake in Tesla. The company's shares rose 1.1% following the announcement, despite the stock tumbling 37% this year.

images.alt_text: Tesla shares are the second-biggest decliner on the S&P 500 Index in 2024, erasing about US$290 billion in shareholder wealth.
FILE PHOTO: Visitors check a Tesla Model 3 car next to a Model Y displayed at a showroom of the U.S. electric vehicle (EV) maker in Beijing, China February 4, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk, CEO of SpaceX and Tesla and owner of X, formerly known as Twitter, attends the Viva Technology conference dedicated to innovation and startups at the Porte de Versailles exhibition centre in Paris, France, June 16, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo
India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi shakes hand with Tesla chief executive Elon Musk during their meeting in New York, US, June 20, 2023. Musk is expected to visit India this month.

site_title: US dollar edges down but still close to 5½ month high; Fed, Middle East in focus
summary: The US dollar edged down 0.2% to 106.12 against a basket of currencies, near a 5½-month high, as Federal Reserve officials reiterated the rate-cutting cycle was on hold. The dollar's appeal as a safe-haven asset increased due to concerns of a broadening Middle East conflict. Analysts remain bullish on the dollar, with some predicting it could strengthen further if markets price out Fed cuts for this year. The euro/dollar index is expected to fall below 1.05, while the yen hovered near its weakest level in 34 years.

images.alt_text: The yen last hovered around 154.64 per US dollar, its weakest level in 34 years, and close to what analysts say is the new resistance level of 155.

site_title: US homebuilding retreats as housing recovery stalls
summary: US single-family homebuilding declined in March, with permits falling 5.7% to a five-month low, and starts dropping 12.4% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.022 million units. The housing recovery appears to have stalled due to a resurgence in mortgage rates and a shortage of previously owned houses for sale. Economists expect housing to make a small contribution to GDP growth in the first quarter, and warn that supply remains low, keeping prices elevated.

images.alt_text: FILE Ñ Apartment buildings under construction in the Mott Haven neighborhood of the Bronx on Oct. 7, 2021. More lawmakers have come to agree that more construction is sorely needed to solve a housing crisis.  (Karsten Moran/The New York Times)

site_title: Abbott beats quarterly profit estimates on strong medical device sales
summary: Abbott Laboratories reported a quarterly profit of 98 cents per share, beating Wall Street estimates, driven by strong sales of medical devices, including glucose monitors. Sales of medical devices rose to $4.45 billion, exceeding analyst estimates of $4.30 billion. The company raised its full-year profit forecast to $4.55-$4.70 per share, surpassing analyst expectations of $4.60 per share. The resurgence in joint replacements and delayed surgeries during the Covid-19 pandemic contributed to the strong demand for Abbott's medical devices.

site_title: G7 foreign ministers meet in Italy amid calls for sanctions on Iran
summary: G7 foreign ministers met on the Italian island of Capri for three days of talks amid escalating tensions between Israel and Iran, and ongoing wars in Gaza and Ukraine. The ministers, from the US, Britain, France, Italy, Germany, Canada, and Japan, pushed for a ceasefire in Gaza and de-escalation of Middle East tensions. However, Israel is expected to retaliate against Iran's missile and drone attacks, despite Western calls for restraint. Italy's presidency of the G7 is focused on finding a solution to the crisis.

images.alt_text: With AI and inequality being a key focus of Italy’s G7 economic agenda, Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni  says that she wants to focus on creating “ethical guard rails” for the development of the technology, including a potential steering committee to ensure greater G7 coordination.

site_title: China Vanke seeks to sell 21.4% stake in logistics operator GLP
summary: China Vanke, a state-backed developer, is seeking to sell its 21.4% stake in logistics firm GLP, amid a debt crisis and concerns about its ability to avoid default. Vanke purchased the stake in 2018 for about S$3.4 billion. The company is exploring options to raise cash, including selling non-core assets and pledging assets as collateral for new loans. GLP has demonstrated financial resilience, redeeming recent bonds, but Vanke's longer-term financial position may deteriorate if it fails to carry out planned asset sales.

images.alt_text: Vanke has recently been hit by various market rumours and controversies involving a local partner.
A China Vanke development in Hefei, China. Source: Bloomberg
Vanke’s Shenzhen-listed stock closed down 1.8 per cent at 7.4 yuan after dropping in early trade to 7.31 yuan – the lowest since May 2014.
Contracted sales for March were 24.5 billion yuan (S$4.6 billion), Vanke says. That represents a 43 per cent decline from a year earlier.
There have been other signs of concerns among financial institutions, with the property firm’s credit ratings cut to junk level by Fitch Ratings and Moody’s last month.

Investors have been dumping Vanke’s shares and bonds in the past few weeks on cash flow concerns, triggering a rare central government directive to help the Shenzhen-based company beat a liquidity crisis.

site_title: Adidas shares surpass two-year high as 'terrace' sneaker trend boosts brand heat
summary: Adidas shares surged 8% on Wednesday, reaching a two-year high, driven by strong demand for its "terrace" retro styles such as Samba, Gazelle, and Campus, as well as performance categories. The company reported quarterly results above expectations and increased its 2024 guidance. Analysts attribute the growth to Adidas' brand building and the clearance of remaining Yeezy stock, rather than the Yeezy line itself. The company expects no further profits from the sale of remaining Yeezy inventory.

images.alt_text: The bet is that athletes breaking records in Puma gear will nudge spectators towards its whole range of products, creating a potential “halo effect” for everything from marathon shoes to everyday sneakers.
Adidas says its board would propose a dividend of 0.7 euros (S$1.1) per share, unchanged from last year, despite a difficult 2023.
The offerings will include some of the most popular Yeezy designs, including the 350 V2 sneaker in steel gray.

site_title: UK inflation slows less than expected
summary: UK inflation slowed less than expected, falling to 3.2% in March, its lowest level since September 2021. Despite a drop in food prices, inflation remains above the Bank of England's 2% target, fueling concerns about interest rate cuts. Analysts say a June cut is still possible, but the risk of inflation stalling has increased, potentially delaying rate cuts. The Conservative government trails in polls ahead of a general election, with opposition Labour party criticizing the government's handling of inflation.

images.alt_text: Crowds of shoppers on Oxford Street in London, UK, on Monday, Dec. 18, 2023. The Office for National Statistics are due to release the latest UK retail sales figures on Friday. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Vinci to buy majority of Edinburgh Airport in UK expansion
summary: Vinci agreed to purchase a majority stake in Edinburgh Airport for £1.27 billion (S$2.15 billion), furthering the company's UK expansion. Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which owns the airport, will retain a 50% stake. This deal marks Vinci's second major aviation investment in the UK, following its purchase of London Gatwick in 2018. Vinci operates 70 airports globally and has significant European and Latin American operations. The acquisition is part of a broader trend of airport assets regaining appeal in the UK after the pandemic.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 17)
summary: Singapore's key exports shrank 20.7% year on year in March, driven by a 20.7% decline in the non-electronics sector. This marks a steeper contraction from February's 0.2% fall. Economists predict a recovery in key exports, despite the surprise drop.

site_title: Japan records best-ever monthly visitor numbers
summary: Japan recorded a record 3.08 million foreign visitors in March, a 69.5% increase from the previous year and a 11.6% gain from 2019. The surge is attributed to the spring cherry blossom season and Easter break. Record numbers arrived from India, Germany, Taiwan, and the US. However, this boost has been met with criticism, particularly in Kyoto, where locals complain of harassment by tourists. The government has been working to boost visitor numbers since lifting pandemic-era border restrictions, but some cities are now considering additional fees for tourists.

images.alt_text: People visit the shopping street in Asakusa district near Sensoji Temple, a popular tourist location, in Tokyo on January 18, 2024. (Photo by Philip FONG / AFP)

site_title: Dubai’s record rain floods expensive homes and halts flights
summary: Dubai experienced its heaviest rainfall since records began in 1949, causing widespread flooding and disruption. The city's expensive homes and underground car parks were flooded, leaving some buildings without power. One person died after being swept away by flash floods, and at least 18 people have died in neighboring Oman due to heavy rains. Dubai airport and flights have been severely disrupted, with many arrivals and departures canceled or delayed. The UAE's National Center of Meteorology carried out cloud seeding operations, but the lack of drainage in the area can trigger flooding.

images.alt_text: Dubai is seeking to grow its economy through tourism, building a local financial centre and by attracting foreign capital, including into property.

“Hong Kong is very advanced in so many aspects and has so much to offer in terms of investment opportunities and business expansion,” says Sheikh Ali Al Maktoum, chairman of Family Offices of Sheikh Mohammed Bin Rashid Al Maktoum.
Dubai can provide complementary benefits to Singapore, even as competition spurs both on to become leading financial hubs in Asia, say industry players.
Nakheel, the group behind Dubai’s palm-shaped islands, was taken over by the government in 2011 as part of a US$16 billion rescue plan in the aftermath of a 2009-2010 real estate crash.

site_title: Singapore seeks methanol licensees, plans ammonia bunkering project
summary: Singapore aims to become a hub for cleaner marine fuels by launching licence applications for methanol bunkering by the end of 2024 and selecting a lead developer for an ammonia project on Jurong Island by early 2025. The country's largest bunkering hub, Singapore, plans to commercially adopt methanol and ammonia as alternatives to petroleum-derived fuel oil. This move is part of Singapore's efforts to meet carbon-emissions goals set by the International Maritime Organization, aiming for a net-zero maritime industry by 2050.

images.alt_text:
lng / ST20210823_202127136955 / Alphonsus Chern //

Generic photograph of a Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) tanker. 23 August 2021.
Vopak owns and operates Singapore’s only ammonia tank currently. The tank is situated at its Banyan terminal, the biggest of the three terminals it operates on Jurong Island.
Arsenio Dominguez, secretary-general of the International Maritime Organisation, says that two issues he has prioritised are decarbonisation and terrorist attacks in the Red Sea.

The Ane Maersk, an A.P. Moller-Maersk A/S methanol-powered container ship, moored at the HD Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. shipyard in Ulsan, South Korea, on Thursday, Jan. 25, 2024. A.P. Moller-Maersk A/S’s newest methanol-powered vessel will soon set sail from South Korea as the shipping giant seeks to reduce emissions in one of the world’s most-polluting industries. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg
Vopak has commissioned 40,000 cubic metres of capacity at its Sebarok terminal for the blending of biofuels into marine fuels.

site_title: High on awareness, low on volume: MAS’ Gillian Tan on blended finance
summary: Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) chief sustainability officer Gillian Tan stated that the region has done "fairly well" in raising awareness about blended finance, but it still faces a significant need for financing in areas such as coal asset retirement. Tan emphasized the need for risk-tolerant investors to support blended finance, particularly in green ambitions, to achieve success in this capital-raising approach.

images.alt_text: DBS chief executive officer Piyush Gupta (left) speaking at a panel session during Ecosperity, a sustainability conference organised by Temasek.
Panellists at Ecosperity highlighted corporate buy-in as important for securing funding.
Generic photos for Budget 2024
Temasek CEO said lawyers will be integral in shaping governance standards and legal frameworks for ESG.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's largest Islamic bank in talks to buy US$1.1 billion stake in Indonesian lender
summary: Abu Dhabi Islamic Bank (ADIB) is in talks to acquire a 15% stake in Indonesian lender Bank Syariah Indonesia (BSI) for $1.1 billion. The potential deal aims to tap into the fast-growing Islamic banking market in South-east Asia, particularly in Indonesia, which has a large Muslim population and significant sharia financial assets. Discussions are in the early stages, and there is no guarantee a deal will be finalized. This acquisition would mark ADIB's entry into the Indonesian market and align with the bank's strategy to expand its presence in the region.

images.alt_text: Growth of the Islamic financing industry in South-east Asia is mainly led by Malaysia and Indonesia, amid supportive regulatory environment and strong government support.
