site_title: Toshiba to cut 5,000 jobs in latest bid to restructure
summary: Toshiba plans to cut 5,000 jobs, roughly a tenth of its domestic workforce, in Japan to focus on infrastructure and digital technology operations. The move is part of the company's restructuring efforts, which include booking a one-time loss of approximately 100 billion yen (S$881.3 million). Toshiba, which was privatized last year, has struggled with management missteps and scandals, including a 2015 penalty for falsifying financial statements.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Toshiba Corporation is displayed at the company's building in Kawasaki, Japan, April 5, 2023. REUTERS/Androniki Christodoulou/File Photo

site_title: ASML profits, bookings down amid China chip spat
summary: ASML, a leading chip-making equipment manufacturer, reported a decline in net profits and bookings in the first quarter due to a high-tech trade spat between China and the West. Net profits dropped to 1.2 billion euros, while bookings fell to 3.6 billion euros. The company's CEO, Peter Wennink, remains upbeat for the second half of the year, citing a "transition" year before a stronger 2025. The trade spat has restricted ASML's exports to China, with the US reportedly pressuring the Dutch government.

images.alt_text: Biden officials are urging the Netherlands to stop ASML Holding from servicing and repairing sensitive chipmaking equipment that Chinese clients purchased.
With “Operation Beethoven”, the Dutch Cabinet presumes that ASML will continue to invest and keep its statutory, fiscal and actual headquarters in the Netherlands .
ASML and other tech firms that depend on foreign staff argue that the immigration restrictions have undermine the country’s future prosperity.

site_title: VW unveils new China EV software in bid to regain lost ground
summary: Volkswagen has unveiled a new digital architecture for its electric vehicles in China, aiming to regain lost ground in the country's largest auto market. The "China Electrical Architecture" will enable advanced features such as autonomous driving to be continuously upgraded over-the-air, starting with four entry-level compact cars in 2026. VW is partnering with Xpeng to integrate the new platform with China's industrial ecosystem and reduce electronic control unit costs by up to 30%. The move follows VW's decision to cede market share in China last year and its willingness to give up market share in the next two years to improve its business.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen says the Hefei site would help bring technologies to market around 30 per cent faster as the carmaker boosts electric vehicle production there.

site_title: Malaysia’s DPM saw order to move Najib to house arrest
summary: Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi has confirmed that he saw an order from the previous king to move former Prime Minister Najib Razak to house arrest due to his 1MDB-linked jail sentence. Najib filed a judicial review, claiming the order was not made public. The court will decide on June 5 whether to hear Najib's request, which could draw attention to Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's commitment to fighting graft. The royal leniency granted to Najib in January had sparked a backlash against Anwar.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak escorted by prison officers, waves to photographers as the jailed politician leaves the court after court proceedings in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia January 19, 2024. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain/File Photo

site_title: Global regulators want to better prepare funds for margin calls
summary: Global regulators, led by the Financial Stability Board, proposed measures to prepare hedge funds and other investors for margin and collateral calls in times of market stress. The FSB recommends conducting liquidity stress tests for "extreme but plausible" scenarios and ensuring sufficient collateral is held and operationally ready. This comes after a series of shocks outside the banking sector, including the pandemic, Archegos collapse, and UK fund stress in 2022. The goal is to reduce excessive pro-cyclical behavior and improve risk management and governance.

images.alt_text: The Swiss government and regulator opted not to put Credit Suisse into a wind-down procedure as it faced a collapse in confidence last year, instead brokering the takeover by UBS.
The Swiss authorities choose to engineer a takeover of Credit Suisse by UBS, rather than use a set of global rules from the FSB to wind it down.

A picture taken on September 29, 2023 in Bern shows a logo of Credit Suisse bank. Credit Suisse, absorbed last June by its ex-rival UBS, suffered a pre-tax loss of 2.4 billion Swiss francs in its investment bank in the first half of the year. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP)

site_title: Passenger car COE premiums rise as Category A reaches new 2024 high of S$94,010
summary: COE premiums for passenger cars in Singapore have risen in April's second round of bidding, driven by sales from The Car Expo show last weekend. Category A, the mainstream car category, saw the largest increase of 5.6% or S$5,010 to S$94,010, its highest price in 2024. Category B, applicable to larger cars, rose 0.7% or S$667 to S$102,001. Industry observers attribute the rise to the Car Expo, citing strong sales of mainstream brands. However, market demand remains weak, with a decline in bids for categories A and B.

images.alt_text: The government says that having a separate Certificate of Entitlement (COE) category for private hire cars is possible, but the trade-offs must be studied carefully.
Traffic on the Pan Island Expressway westbound.
The price for Category A rose to S$83,000, eclipsing the previous high of S$81,589 in January’s first round of bidding.
Industry watchers say that forthcoming regulatory changes will reduce operating costs for taxis, but will not give them a significant advantage.
Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars rose, while those for commercial vehicles and motorcycles remained flat.

site_title: Maserati launches artful open-top EV, with help from Da Vinci
summary: Maserati has launched the GranCabrio Folgore, its third electric vehicle, with an estimated price tag over S$1 million in Singapore. The convertible features a triple motor setup, producing 760 horsepower, and is designed to accelerate to 100 km/h in under three seconds. The car's T-shaped battery pack is positioned between the passengers, allowing for a low-slung stance. Maserati aims to electrify its entire line-up, with plans to launch a Folgore version of the MC20 supercar and a large electric SUV by 2027. The brand's CEO declined to comment on when it would stop selling combustion cars, citing varying timelines for different markets.

images.alt_text: In 2008, BMW engineers set out to develop an electric city car from scratch.
Tesla shares are the second-biggest decliner on the S&P 500 Index in 2024, erasing about US$290 billion in shareholder wealth.
China’s biggest automaker unveiled the Super 3 and Bao 8 SUVS at its Shenzhen headquarters on Tuesday (Apr 16) night in a glitzy livestreamed event.

Nissan expects to make its first solid-state batteries at the site from March 2025 and will deploy 100 workers per shift to step up production to 100 megawatt hours per month from the financial year starting April 2028.

site_title: Swedish homebuilding may be on brink of recovery, data shows
summary: Sweden's homebuilding sector is showing signs of recovery after two years of sharp declines. Data from Byggfakta indicates that construction starts have stabilized in March, with the housing indicator suggesting a modest recovery. However, the number of homes started remains far below demand, with authorities estimating a need for 67,300 units annually, but only about a third being produced. The sector's recovery is considered modest, driven by developers needing to start subsidized projects or stabilizing costs.

images.alt_text: Residential apartment blocks in Stockholm, Sweden, on Tuesday, June 13, 2023. Swedish households are becoming more optimistic about the development in the housing market, according to a survey from the country’s largest bank. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

site_title: Central bankers’ 2 per cent inflation target regime should now be retired
summary: Central bankers are considering abandoning their 2% inflation target regime due to the failure of their economic models during the energy shock. A more flexible inflation range could be beneficial, allowing for a combination of fiscal policy restraint and monetary instruments. The US Federal Reserve previously trialed flexible average inflation targeting, which was abandoned amid the pandemic. The Bank of Japan is already moving away from its 2% target, and the Bank of England should consider a more tolerant approach, especially given the UK's economic recovery from a technical recession.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.2 per cent at 37,798.97 on Tuesday.
BOJ officials, including governor Kazuo Ueda, have said the focus would be on whether wage increases will broaden, and prod firms to hike prices not just for goods but services.

Crowds of shoppers on Oxford Street in London, UK, on Monday, Dec. 18, 2023. The Office for National Statistics are due to release the latest UK retail sales figures on Friday. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Swiber founder fined S$100,000 over false project announcement, listing rule breaches
summary: Swiber founder Raymond Goh, 56, was fined S$100,000 for making a false announcement on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in 2014 about securing a US$710 million award for an offshore field development project. Goh pleaded guilty to the charge related to a project that was materially false, as the company's unit had only signed a letter of intent authorizing expenditure of up to US$2 million. He faces one month's imprisonment if he fails to pay the fine by April 24.

images.alt_text: Swiber is put under judicial management in 2016 and delisted on Jun 23, 2023 after listing for about 17 years.
SGX centre taken on January 8, 2020
Built in 2009, the Swiber Quetzal is a pipe lay and accommodation work barge registered under the Mexico flag.
Oil services firm Swiber's headquarters in Jurong East. The group is using just one storey of the 5-storey building, and most of it has been standing empty.
Swiber enters MOU to sell its Jurong headquarters for S$30.8m
Swiber Holdings' judicial management extended to Jan 14

site_title: We don’t see what climate change is doing to us
summary: Climate change's hidden effects, including hotter days, are causing significant harm to human health and productivity. Research shows record-breaking heat waves are less damaging than unremarkably hot days, which contribute to excess deaths, workplace injuries, and decreased cognitive performance. Heat can also impact cognitive abilities, decision-making, and crime rates. Additionally, climate change is affecting education, with hotter school years leading to slower learning gains, particularly for disadvantaged students. The cumulative effects of climate change, including wildfires and air pollution, are expected to cause significant economic and health costs, highlighting the need for local adaptation and mitigation efforts.

images.alt_text: Australia last month confirmed its iconic Great Barrier Reef was experiencing a new mass bleaching, the fifth since 2016.
The World Meteorological Organization confirmed that 2023 was by far the hottest year ever recorded.
Cracked earth at al-Massira dam in Morocco. A quarter of the global population experienced drought conditions over 2022 and 2023.

site_title: Vietnam’s EV maker VinFast reports narrowing losses even as sales fall
summary: Vietnam's EV maker VinFast reported a net loss of US$618.3 million in the first three months of 2024, decreasing 12.3% from the fourth quarter. Despite declining car sales, the company's revenue rose 269.7% year-over-year to US$302.6 million. VinFast aims to sell vehicles in 50 global markets by the end of the year, amid declining demand for electric vehicles. The company's efforts to expand globally come as Tesla cuts its workforce and Chinese EV makers engage in a price war.

images.alt_text: The deal comes as the group is investing billions of dollars to develop loss-making VinFast, the fledgling electric-vehicle maker.
Vinfast boasts a network of 150,000 charging ports installed all across Vietnam.
The vehicles being recalled were manufactured from March to December last year, VinFast says.
VinFast aims to expand in more markets in the Middle East, Latin America and Asia, including Indonesia.
First deliveries of the vehicle in Vietnam are due in the third quarter.

site_title: Indonesia central bank open to buying government bonds to steady market
summary: Indonesia's central bank is intervening in the foreign exchange market to stabilize the rupiah, which has reached its weakest level in four years. The rupiah dropped 0.28% on Wednesday to 16,215 per dollar. Senior deputy governor Destry Damayanti attributed the weakness to global market conditions, but stated that the domestic economy remains resilient. The central bank is also open to buying government bonds to support the bond market, with the yield on Indonesia's benchmark 10-year bond reaching 7.037% earlier in the day.

images.alt_text: The rupiah currency weakened on Tuesday (April 16) to its lowest point in four years against the US dollar.

site_title: Indonesia’s Jago Coffee raises US$6 million in Series A funding
summary: Indonesia-based mobile cafe company Jago Coffee has secured US$6 million in Series A funding from Intudo Ventures, Beenext Accelerate, Orzon Ventures, and D Global Ventures. The funding will be used to expand its service coverage, establish production depots, launch more mobile carts, and enhance its technology stack. Jago aims to increase its cart deployment to 1,500 and depot count to 15, with a goal of achieving 50% coverage of Jakarta by end-2024. The funding is seen as a vote of confidence in the company's vision and team, according to co-founder and CEO Yoshua Tanu.

images.alt_text: Coffee trees, like other plants, absorb carbon dioxide form the atmosphere, but chemicals such as nitrogen fertilisers are heavy on emissions.
Cotti Coffee has expanded its footprint to more than 330 of China’s nearly 400 county-level cities,

site_title: Japan's Nikkei ends below 38,000 points for first time since February
summary: Japan's Nikkei index ended at 37,961.80, its lowest level since February 14, and on track for its biggest weekly loss since December 2022. The index fell 1.3% due to tensions in the Middle East and investors taking profit ahead of the earnings season. The broader Topix index also declined 1.3% to 2663.15. Key companies such as Advantest and chip-related firms led the declines, while Resonac Holdings rose 12% after raising its revenue forecast.

images.alt_text: A man walks past an electronic board showing the Nikkei index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo, Japan, April 16, 2024. Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta stocks were all sharply down on Tuesday.

site_title: Rebound relief for Asian stocks; STI up 0.3% led by DBS, UOB
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 3,154.69 on April 17, driven by gains from local banks DBS and UOB, which were the most heavily traded counters. DBS and UOB ended 1.2% and 1.3% higher, respectively. The rebound follows a potential war in the Middle East, which may be coming to an end. Asian markets were mixed, with Hong Kong, China, Taiwan, Malaysia, and the Philippines closing higher. US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell's hawkish comments kept the US dollar elevated.

images.alt_text: 星展银行（DBS）、大华银行（UOB）和华侨银行（OCBC）大巴窑中心分行、标志。

site_title: Fannie Mae’s new mortgage-scoring system aims to lift MBS demand
summary: Fannie Mae has launched a new mortgage-scoring system, the Mission Index, to increase demand for mortgage-backed securities (MBS) and attract socially minded investors. The system gives extra weight to mortgages with characteristics such as affordable rental housing or loans to borrowers in rural areas with high poverty levels. The goal is to make MBS more attractive to investors, potentially leading to lower interest rates for borrowers with these types of mortgages. Fannie Mae's CEO Priscilla Almodovar aims to incentivize lenders to originate mortgages to underserved borrowers.

images.alt_text: Many independent lenders have managed their risk well, and for lenders that work extensively with government-backed companies like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the situation is less dire.

site_title: UBS, Nomura battle to sell rate products to Europe’s ultra rich
summary: UBS and Nomura are competing to sell sophisticated fixed-income products to Europe's ultra-rich, expanding their structured rates offerings. UBS has been adding to its rates offering over the past six months, while Nomura is stepping up sales of credit-linked notes, floating-rate notes, and inflation-linked bonds. The move aims to capitalize on expertise acquired during UBS's rescue of Credit Suisse last year and expand into new markets, including France, Luxembourg, and Italy.

images.alt_text: The FSB is set to review its ranking of UBS among the list of global systemically important banks after the Credit Suisse takeover, which is due to close later this year.
The goal is in line with Nomura’s strategy to increase investments in private markets and diversify sources of revenue to cushion the impact.

In its third quarter, which ended in December, Nomura wholesale unit delivered a pretax profit of 23 billion yen (S$206 million) following a loss of 1.9 billion yen in the same quarter of the previous year.
Nomura is reorganising its US investment management business.
UBS put the Credit Suisse venture up for sale after taking control of its smaller Swiss rival when it collapsed last year.

site_title: BMW’s surprise electric-car success started with an early setback
summary: BMW's surprise electric-car success began with an early setback in 2008 when the company introduced the i3, a quirky electric city car with a high price tag and limited range. After slowing its EV plans due to criticism, BMW has since adapted its approach, designing EVs that are almost indistinguishable from combustion engine-powered siblings and building them on the same factory line. This has paid off, with BMW shipping more EVs than its rivals Audi and Mercedes-Benz in the first quarter, despite a broader slowdown in demand for EVs in Europe.

images.alt_text: BMW delivered a total of 594,671 vehicles in the first quarter, a year-on-year rise of 1.1 per cent.
FILE PHOTO: BMW logo is seen during Munich Auto Show, IAA Mobility 2021 in Munich, Germany, September 8, 2021. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay
Chinese mainstream electric vehicle (EV) brand BYD went from 12th to fifth in passenger car registrations for 2023.
BMW spent 3.6 billion euros in 2022 to lift its stake in the joint venture to 75 per cent from 50 per cent.

site_title: Canada hikes capital gains tax to raise billions for housing
summary: Canada's government has increased capital gains tax rates to help fund housing affordability and youth development programs. The new tax rate applies to companies and individuals with gains exceeding C$250,000 annually, with corporations facing a two-thirds tax rate instead of half. The move aims to raise C$6.9 billion in revenue this fiscal year, with the long-term goal of generating C$19.4 billion. The tax changes have sparked concerns about the impact on businesses and investment, but Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland defends the decision as necessary to address "structural inequality."

images.alt_text: Condominiums stand along the shore of Lake Ontario in this aerial photograph taken above Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Monday, Oct. 2, 2017. Toronto housing prices fell for a fourth month in September as sales remained sluggish, particularly in the detached-home segment that has borne the brunt of the correction in Canada's biggest city. Photographer: James MacDonald/Bloomberg
Rapid growth in Canada’s immigrant population has driven the housing shortage along with inflation and high interest rates.

site_title: Women game changers
summary: Three female trailblazers, Lee Hui Li, Tan Min Lan, and Charmain Kwee, share their stories of leadership and redefining it in their own ways. They discuss forging their paths, challenging the status quo, and empowering others. Meanwhile, the Watches and Wonders 2024 watch fair showcased new novelties, while articles explore destinations such as Sichuan, Kazakhstan, and Higashi-Iwase in Japan, highlighting unique experiences and design perspectives.

site_title: MAS sets aside S$35 million to develop sustainable finance talent
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has set aside S$35 million to develop sustainable finance talent in the city-state's financial sector over the next three years, creating over 4,000 new jobs in the next 10 years. The initiative aims to address the growing demand for sustainable financing in South-east Asia, where the region is projected to require S$4 trillion to S$5 trillion in sustainable financing over the next decade. The report highlights 20 job roles that should be prioritised for upskilling, including relationship managers and portfolio managers, to support financial institutions in their transition to a low-carbon economy.

images.alt_text: Ant International hopes to leverage its ecosystem to help MSMEs improve the accuracy of their sustainability reports.
Chia Der Jiun, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore, speaking at the launch of the Singapore Sustainable Finance Association on January 24, 2024.
FILE PHOTO: A view of the Monetary Authority of Singapore's headquarters in Singapore June 28, 2017. Picture taken June 28, 2017. REUTERS/Darren Whiteside/File Photo

The partnership will deploy blended finance, crowding in both concessional capital from the philanthropic and public sectors, as well as private capital towards green and sustainable projects in Asia.
The Monetary Authority of Singapore had proposed a phased approach towards regulating the ESG rating providers as Capital Markets Services licensees under the Securities and Futures Act

site_title: Prudential Financial’s PGIM struggles to sell Singapore towers
summary: PGIM Real Estate, a subsidiary of Prudential Financial, has struggled to sell a pair of office towers in Singapore, 78 Shenton Way and another location, due to a softening property market. Despite efforts since last year, prospective buyers have bid below the purchase price of S$680 million. This marks the latest sign of a weakening market, with office demand staying relatively resilient but tenants paring space to save costs. Office rents in Singapore are expected to fall this year as occupancy slips from high levels, according to Bloomberg Intelligence.

images.alt_text: PGIM Real Estate has put three floors for sale at a guide price of S$54.6 million.

site_title: Making housing in New York more affordable
summary: New York state officials have proposed a housing package to address the state's housing crisis, which includes measures to make it easier to build homes, curb skyrocketing costs, and protect tenants. The package includes a new tax break for developers, increased protections for tenants, and more flexible development rules. The goal is to increase the supply of affordable housing, particularly in New York City, where the median rent for market-rate apartments is over $2,000. The package aims to address the shortage of homes, with estimates suggesting the city needs hundreds of thousands of additional units.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Residential single family homes construction by KB Home are shown under construction in the community of Valley Center, California, U.S. June 3, 2021.   REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Apple CEO meets Indonesia leader to talk investments
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook met with Indonesia's President Joko Widodo to discuss investments and diversify supply chains away from China. Cook stated that Indonesia is a "very important market" for Apple and expressed the company's commitment to the country. The visit comes as the US seeks to boost Asian trade partners' roles in the global tech supply chain. Apple plans to expand its developer academies in Indonesia to four locations, including a new facility on the island of Bali.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh (R) meeting Apple CEO Tim Cook (L) at the Government Office in Hanoi on Apr 16, 2024. Apple is increasing its commitments to Vietnam by an unspecified amount.
Apple CEO Cook will also meet users of Apple products to better understand how they are employed, online newspaper VietnamNet said.
India has also fast emerged as an alternative to China for global manufacturing, with the likes of Apple beefing up its production facilities in the country.
Apple shipped 5 million fewer iPhones than it did a year earlier, according to IDC’s preliminary figures.

site_title: Telegram platform to hit one billion users within year, founder says
summary: Telegram's founder, Pavel Durov, predicts the app will reach 1 billion active monthly users within a year. The Dubai-based messaging app, which currently has 900 million users, aims to remain a "neutral platform" and not a player in geopolitics. Durov fled Russia in 2014 due to government interference. Telegram has become a key tool for governments and public figures in both Russia and Ukraine, but has also been criticized for spreading misinformation and manipulation. A US listing is reportedly planned once the company reaches profitability.

images.alt_text: "The focus [among Telegram trading bots] is usually on low-market-cap coins, meme coins, and others with low volume," says Philipp Zentner, CEO at cross-chain liquidity routing firm Li.Fi.

site_title: Jailed Myanmar leader Suu Kyi moved to house arrest: source
summary: Myanmar's junta has moved jailed democracy icon Aung San Suu Kyi from prison to house arrest, according to a source. The 78-year-old Nobel laureate is serving a 27-year sentence for corruption and breaching Covid-19 rules. The move comes after a military source revealed she and former president Win Myint had been transferred from prison to house arrest, citing hot weather as the reason. Suu Kyi has reportedly suffered health problems, including a tooth infection, and was previously held at a specially constructed compound in Naypyidaw.

images.alt_text: Thai Foreign Minister Parnpree Bahiddha-Nukara at a border checkpoint on the Thai-Myanmar boder. He is working with Asean on a stalled peace plan for Myanmar, known as its five-point consensus.
The Philippines, South-east Asia's fastest-growing economy in 2023, is expected to grow 6 per cent in 2024, up from 5.6 per cent last year.
Myanmar is in the throes of an insurgency on multiple fronts, with allied anti-junta groups backed by a pro-democracy parallel government seizing control of several military posts and towns.
Asean+3's current sunny growth prospects offer a timely opportunity for the region's economies to rebuild policy space, says Amro.

Apple CEO Tim Cook (centre) walks with Indonesian Minister of Communication and Information Budi Arie Setiadi (left) to meet journalists after his meeting with Indonesia's President Joko Widodo at the Merdeka Palace in Jakarta on April 17, 2024.

site_title: Asian gas prices surge near highest this year amid conflict risk
summary: Asian liquefied natural gas (LNG) prices have surged to their highest level since early January amid concerns of a potential conflict between Israel and Iran. The North Asian spot rate reached $11 per million British thermal units, a 40% increase since February. Traders are exiting short positions as they assess the risk of a broader Middle East conflict, which could curb supply to Asia. The rally may be short-lived, as the higher cost of LNG is expected to reduce demand from price-sensitive emerging nations.

site_title: Navigation firm TomTom Q1 operating result turns to loss on higher R&D costs
summary: TomTom, a digital mapping specialist, reported a wider-than-expected loss in its first quarter due to increased research and development costs. The company posted a loss of 4.9 million euros, missing expectations of 2 million euros, and saw revenue fall 1% to 139.3 million euros. Its automotive business, accounting for 60% of revenue, reported a 6% drop in operational revenue. TomTom is undergoing restructuring and developing high-definition self-driving maps.

site_title: Asia: Stocks swing after latest selloff as Fed, Middle East dampen sentiment
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on Wednesday, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul down but Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Wellington, Taipei, and Manila rising. The mixed market sentiment was fueled by Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell's indication that interest rates could stay higher for longer, offsetting a rebound following the latest bout of Middle East-fuelled selling. Powell's comments also sparked concerns about a wider conflict in the region.

images.alt_text: A Boeing 787 Dreamliner being built at the aviation company's North Charleston, South Carolina, assembly plant on May 30, 2023.

site_title: TSMC capex outlook key to next phase of US$330 billion stock rally
summary: TSMC, the world's largest chip foundry, is expected to drive its stock further higher with its upcoming results, as it has projects underway to build plants in the US, Japan, and Germany to serve global demand. Analysts estimate the company's revenue to grow at least 20% and its capital expenditure forecasts may be raised, providing evidence of sustained growth fueled by artificial intelligence. Despite trading at a low valuation, TSMC is seen as a prime beneficiary of the AI boom, with its dominance and technological leadership in advanced chip nodes leaving it well-placed to compound earnings at high rates.

images.alt_text: The world’s largest contract chipmaker has benefited from a surge towards AI that has helped it weather the tapering off of pandemic-led electronics demand.

The world’s largest contract chipmaker, whose customers include Apple and Nvidia, has benefited from a surge towards AI that has helped it weather the tapering off of pandemic-led demand and pushed TSMC’s stock to a record high.
FILE PHOTO: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) logo is seen near computer motherboard in this illustration taken January 8, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Taiwanese equities have soared 14 per cent this year, with almost two thirds of the advance coming from a rally in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.

site_title: Vietnam mounts ‘unprecedented’ US$24 billion rescue for bank engulfed in giant fraud, documents show
summary: Vietnam's central bank has injected US$24 billion into Saigon Joint Stock Commercial Bank (SCB) to stem a run on the bank sparked by the October 2022 arrest of real estate tycoon Truong My Lan. The massive rescue effort, described as "unprecedented" for its volume and complexity, aims to prevent SCB's collapse and protect Vietnam's financial system. The bank's deposits have plummeted 80% to US$6 billion, and bad loans have surged to 97.08% of SCB's credit balance. Lan was sentenced to death for masterminding a US$12.5 billion fraud, and a restructuring plan is being sought to address the bank's liquidity problems.

images.alt_text: Vietnamese property tycoon Truong My Lan is expected to appeal the verdict announced on Thursday.

Vietnam's property tycoon Truong My Lan (C) arrives at a court in Ho Chi Minh city on March 5, 2024. A top Vietnamese property tycoon went on trial on March 5, 2024 along with dozens of others, accused of embezzling $12.5 billion in the country's biggest ever fraud case. (Photo by AFP)

Truong My Lan, the chairwoman of Van Thinh Phat (VTP) Group, one of Vietnam’s most influential real estate empires, was brought to court for allegedly misappropriating 304 trillion dong (S$16.54 billion) from Saigon Commercial Bank.
Chairman of Tan Hoang Minh group Do Anh Dung (centre) is escorted by police officers to a court for his trial on fraud charges in Hanoi on March 19, 2024.

site_title: An economy transformed: Lee Hsien Loong’s 20 years as Singapore’s Prime Minister
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is set to hand over the reins to Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong on May 15. During his 20-year tenure, Lee transformed the economy, measured by GDP, which grew from $194.4 billion in 2004 to $673.3 billion in 2023, with GDP per capita more than doubling. Despite global crises and a rapidly changing world order, Singapore's economy has remained competitive and resilient. The city-state has diversified its industries, invested in advanced manufacturing and digital transformation, and maintained a global mindset. However, demographic challenges, including a low birth rate and aging population, have led to increased social spending and the introduction of social transfers to mitigate income inequality.

site_title: China starts inspections of financial regulators, largest banks
summary: China has launched a three-month inspection of its largest financial regulators, banks, and key market authorities, marking the first broad probe since 2021. The inspections will target 34 entities, including the Industrial & Commercial Bank of China and major stock exchanges in Shanghai and Shenzhen. The move is part of the Communist Party's increasing focus on anti-corruption, with President Xi Jinping seeking to stabilize the economy while preventing systemic financial risks. The inspections follow a 2021 probe that led to sweeping arrests and penalties across the industry, with at least 130 financial officials and executives investigated or punished.

images.alt_text: china economy Photographer: Raul Ariano/Bloomberg
Total air passenger traffic reached almost 180 million trips in the first three months of 2024.
China’s manufacturing drive has exacerbated tensions with trading partners.
Consumer prices fell for several months from August, before rising 0.7 per cent in February.

The yuan has lost about 1.9 per cent in value against the US dollar so far this year, pressured by its relative low yields versus other currencies and outflows of foreign investment from an anaemic stock market.

site_title: South Pole, GenZero launch Asia centre for carbon project development
summary: South Pole and GenZero have launched the Asia Centre of Carbon Excellence (ACCE) in Singapore to develop carbon projects in the region, including the early decommissioning of coal power plants and green shipping. The hub aims to boost Asia's leadership in international carbon trading and mitigation, and collaborate with regional companies and governments to explore opportunities for carbon project development. The projects will enable clients to meet their emission-reduction targets cost-effectively, with the goal of supporting the roll-out of carbon-pricing instruments.

images.alt_text: Panellists at Ecosperity highlighted corporate buy-in as important for securing funding.
sbnature28 - The Nature Conservancy works with local partners in East Kalimantan to protect forests and wildlife such as the orangutan.

site_title: Malaysia to push ahead with long-awaited subsidy cuts in 2024
summary: Malaysia's government plans to cut petrol subsidies this year to narrow its fiscal deficit and boost investor confidence. The country aims to reduce its budget deficit to 4.3% of GDP, with a focus on helping the needy rather than providing blanket subsidies. The move comes as the Malaysian ringgit trades near a 26-year low, and the government seeks to create a favorable environment for startups and digital sectors.

images.alt_text: Over the past five decades, Malaysia’s fertility rate has markedly decreased from 4.9 children per woman in 1970 to 1.6 children in 2022.
The data is enough to enable authorities to determine where handouts should be directed once the nation limits subsidies on the cheapest form of petrol.
Bank Negara Malaysia governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour said: "Our prospects are good. We have reason to cautiously anticipate a better year ahead."

site_title: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit posts 8.8% fall in distributable income for Q1
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (Kore) reported a 8.8% decline in distributable income for Q1, primarily due to increased financing costs amid higher interest rates. Gross revenue remained unchanged at US$37.1 million, while net property income declined 0.8%. The Reit's aggregate leverage was 43% and its weighted average term to maturity of debt was 2.5 years. Despite this, committed occupancy stood at 90.1% and three-year market rental growth remained stable.

images.alt_text: Intellicentre Campus is located in Macquarie Park in the north of Sydney at 17-23 Talavera Road.
City Developments' associate company Cityview Place Holdings says it sold 65 units of The Residences at W Sentosa Cove Singapore within a week.

site_title: Boeing safety in spotlight at US Senate hearing
summary: The US Senate is holding a hearing to scrutinize Boeing's safety practices, following a near-disastrous January incident on an Alaska Airlines 737 MAX flight. Boeing engineer Sam Salehpour testified that the 787 Dreamliner should be grounded due to risk of "falling apart" mid-air, citing gaps between parts exceeding company standards. Boeing defends its safety record, stating that 99% of gaps conform to standards and testing showed no fatigue. Former FAA and Boeing employees will also testify, criticizing the company's practices.

images.alt_text: United Airlines was impacted more than rivals by the MAX 9 grounding, which followed a January emergency landing of an Alaska Airlines flight after a panel on the fuselage blew out midair.
Airbus is targeting a roughly 50 per cent increase in production of its A320neo cash cow to 75 planes a month by 2026.
Boeing has slowed the pace of work on the 737 family to give workers and suppliers breathing room to catch up on damaged or missing parts and get its production lines back in order.
Airbus says it won 170 new orders in the first quarter, with no cancellations.
The planemaker has been grappling with a full-blown safety crisis that has undermined its reputation following a Jan 5 mid-air panel blowout on a 737 MAX plane.
Boeing has come under intense criticism since a door plug panel tore off a new Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9 jet at 16,000 feet on Jan 5.

site_title: Gold steady as geopolitical risks counter higher Treasury yields
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $2,383.29 per ounce, despite rising US Treasury yields, as safe-haven demand amid the Middle East conflict offset the pressure. Benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields hovered near five-month highs, while top Federal Reserve officials expressed caution on cutting interest rates. The conflict in Gaza and Israeli tanks' push into the northern strip contributed to safe-haven demand, while lower-than-expected gold production from Canadian miner Barrick Gold and Shanghai Futures Exchange's trading limit changes also supported prices.

images.alt_text: The State Bank of Vietnam will restart gold bar auctions after an 11-year suspension, amid efforts to increase the supply of the precious metal to the market.

site_title: Wall Street’s deals rebound is missing something
summary: Wall Street's dealmaking rebound is patchy, with investment banking revenue increasing 27% in the first quarter from last year, but private equity firms remain quiet, a major driver of M&A fees. The big five US investment banks reported a 74% increase in fees, with debt markets thriving and stock sales recovering well. However, dealmaking remains tough, and executives are nervous about conflicts in the Middle East, Europe, and the US presidential election, as well as inflation and interest rates. Private equity firms are expected to return to providing a significant portion of global investment banking fees, but their absence has kept M&A fees stagnant.

Morgan Stanley’s total revenue increased to US$15.14 billion in the first quarter.
Goldman Sachs' profit rose to US$4.13 billion, or US$11.58 per share, for the three months ended Mar 31, compared with US$3.23 billion, or US$8.79 per share, a year ago.

site_title: IMF sees slow, steady 2024 global growth; China, war escalation pose risks
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) forecasts global real GDP growth of 3.2% for 2024 and 2025, the same rate as in 2023. The US is expected to drive growth with a revised upward forecast of 2.7% in 2024, while Europe is expected to experience slower growth due to weak consumer sentiment. China's growth is forecast to fall to 4.6% in 2024 and 4.1% in 2025, with risks posed by the country's troubled property sector. A potential escalation of the Middle East conflict could limit global growth, with oil prices and inflation rising.

site_title: B2K’s second-generation leaders paw a new path in pet products
summary: B2K, a Singaporean pet products company, has transitioned from a distributor to a brand owner, launching its own products such as Kit Cat. Founded by brothers Kenneth and Kevin Koh in 2007, the company started as an import business and distributed brands from overseas. Under Kenneth's leadership as CEO, B2K has forged its own path in the pet industry, marking a new direction for the family business.

images.alt_text: Rising pet ownership means growing demand for pet products and services – but not all parts of the industry are experiencing the same boom, as high costs, price wars and space limitations bite.

Malcolm Ong, chief executive and founder of The Fish Farmer, with a water quality monitoring sensor that detects changes in water conditions on his farms.

site_title: Is Grab’s ride-hailing business future-proof?
summary: Grab, the Singapore-based ride-hailing company, faces competition from local players in South-east Asia. Despite holding a 70% market share, Grab faces challenges from companies like Be Group, GSM, and Tada, which are investing in electric vehicles and alternative commission models. Grab has responded by introducing new initiatives, such as a group rides feature and a variable commission structure, to boost drivers' willingness to accept longer trips. The company's focus on South-east Asia and its ability to adapt to changing market conditions may help it maintain its dominance.

images.alt_text: Discontinuing the GrabPay Card can be seen as Grab consciously stepping away from areas of overlap with GXS.
Market reactions to tech earnings suggest that the bar is high for both profitability and growth.

site_title: Cordlife to raise S$8.2 million from private placement
summary: Cordlife Group is proposing to raise S$8.2 million through the issuance of 51.2 million new ordinary shares at S$0.16 apiece, with net cash proceeds of S$8 million. The company entered into subscription agreements with Charming Global Enterprises and Darren Ng, who will collectively hold about 16.6% of Cordlife's enlarged capital. The funds will be used for working capital and rebuilding the Singapore brand, with 50.3% reserved for contingency purposes.

images.alt_text: The arrests of Cordlife's directors and group chief executive are related to alleged breaches-of-disclosure obligations regarding irregular temperatures in its storage tanks.
In letters seen by ST, parents who have been paying their storage fee annually have been offered refunds of $537.50.
Cordlife said it cannot be certain of the viability and potency of every CBU stored in the high-risk tanks and will deem that the CBUs in these tanks are impacted by temperature excursions.

Two of Cordlife's non-independent non-executive directors, Yiu Ming Yiu and Chow Wai Leong, were also nominee directors of TransGlobal.
TransGlobal’s Mar 26 letter marks the third requisition notice received by Cordlife.

site_title: US, China defence chiefs hold first talks in nearly 18 months
summary: US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin held a video teleconference with Chinese Defence Minister Dong Jun, the first substantive talks between the two countries in nearly 18 months. The talks focused on US-PRC defense relations, regional and global security issues, and the importance of maintaining open lines of military communication. Austin emphasized the US's commitment to international law and freedom of navigation in the South China Sea, while Dong called for greater trust and respect between the two powers, particularly on the Taiwan issue. The talks aimed to prevent tensions from spiraling out of control and promote regional peace.

images.alt_text: Moscow and Beijing have declared a “no limits” friendship that has so far helped Russia to weather unprecedented international sanctions.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 37,735.11 on Monday, down 0.7 per cent after notching a 650-point fall from its peak earlier in the session.

A video grab taken on April 14, 2024 shows explosions lighting up Jerusalem sky during an Iranian attack on Israel. site_title: Japan’s exports rise 7.3% year/year in March
summary: Japan's exports rose 7.3% year-over-year in March, marking the fourth consecutive month of growth, according to Ministry of Finance data. In contrast, imports fell 4.9% in the same period, surpassing the expected decline of 4.7%. The strong export growth suggests a positive trend for Japan's economy.

site_title: Thousands of Taylor Swift fans hit by UK ticket scams
summary: Thousands of Taylor Swift fans have been targeted by UK concert ticket scams, with at least 3,000 victims losing over £1 million (S$1.7 million) since July. The scams, which often start with fake adverts or posts on Facebook, involve victims paying upfront for tickets only to have the scammers disappear. Lloyds Bank warns that paying by bank transfer from a social media seller should raise alarm bells, and advises buyers to use debit or credit cards for protection. The average loss per victim is £332, with some cases exceeding £1,000.

site_title: Strengthening interaction: Singapore’s role in EU-Asean ties
summary: Singapore plays a pivotal role in EU-Asean ties, having been the first country in Asean to forge a trade deal with the European Union and negotiating a digital trade agreement. The EU-Singapore relationship is seen as a model for future digital components in the EU's free trade agreements with other Asean member states, with European businesses seeking to expand into the region through Singapore as their launching pad. Singapore's strategic position as a conduit to the broader Asean landscape and its role in enhancing EU ties have made it a key player in fostering increased trade, investment flows, and technological exchanges between the EU and Asean.

images.alt_text: DPM Wong at a reception for Singaporeans living in France on Thursday – one of many events he attended over the week.

Despite the elevation to a “strategic partnership”, the relationship between Asean and the EU is often rocky with several irritants at play.

site_title: France hopes to develop green and digital shipping corridor with Singapore: French maritime chief
summary: France aims to develop a green and digital shipping corridor with Singapore, as part of a broader maritime sustainability and digitalization cooperation. The corridor, which Singapore has already established with other countries, would reduce the carbon footprint of ships using cleaner fuels and automated clearance. French director general Eric Banel is meeting with Singaporean representatives to discuss decarbonization and digitalization, with a focus on ammonia, cybersecurity, and international cooperation. The move is part of France's efforts to achieve neutral carbon shipping and prepare for the United Nations Ocean Conference in 2025.

site_title: Morgan Stanley, HSBC cutting dozens of Asia investment banking jobs as deals slump
summary: Morgan Stanley and HSBC are cutting dozens of investment banking jobs in Asia due to weaker deal activities and sluggish markets in China and Hong Kong. Morgan Stanley is cutting at least 50 jobs, affecting 13% of its Asia investment banking workforce, while HSBC is laying off around 30 dealmakers. The job cuts follow similar measures by other banks stung by a decline in deal-making activities in China amid a slowing economy. The cuts are among the largest to the two banks' China-focused investment banking teams and are part of a new round of staff cuts in the region.

site_title: Amazon Prime memberships in US gain 8% to new high after lull
summary: Amazon Prime membership in the US reached a new high of 180 million in March, a 8% increase from the previous year, according to Consumer Intelligence Research Partners. Despite inflation and increased competition from online retailers, Prime's promise of fast delivery continues to appeal to US shoppers, who pay $140/year or $15/month for the service, which includes shipping discounts and Prime Video.

images.alt_text: Photo illustration for cybersecurity stories

Amazon CEO Andy Jassy has focused the company’s investments on a few big initiatives such as building data centres to help fuel the artificial intelligence boom and efforts to develop build out an Amazon franchise in groceries and healthcare.
The story of Amazon's foray into AI-powered grocery shopping is a stark reminder that “artificial intelligence” still often requires armies of human babysitters to work properly.

site_title: It’s time to lift the veil on incompetence
summary: Incompetence is a pervasive issue in various fields, including governments and companies, often benefiting those who exploit it. A new study in the British Journal of Sociology highlights the lack of formal research on incompetence, despite its significant impact on outcomes. Incompetence can be a form of bias, particularly when institutions prioritize fixing mistakes over addressing systemic issues. Examples include the UK government's compensation schemes for Windrush scandal victims and Boeing's repeated delivery failures. As incompetence is often used as a shield to delay payments or frustrate scrutiny, it's essential to understand how to reduce and prevent its weaponization.

images.alt_text: Leaders who have shown vulnerability include Jack Ma, Elon Musk and Tim Cook.

site_title: New Zealand’s central bank consulting on development of digital currency
summary: New Zealand's central bank is consulting on the development of a digital currency, which would be the country's first government-backed digital currency. The digital currency, expected to be introduced in 2030, would be available to the public and would complement the existing banknotes and coins. According to Reserve Bank of New Zealand director Ian Woolford, it would be a new type of money that would not replace existing currency but rather coexist alongside it.

site_title: Singapore’s key exports on track for recovery despite March’s surprise 20.7% tumble: economists
summary: Singapore's key exports contracted 20.7% year-over-year in March, driven by declines in the non-electronics sector, according to data from Enterprise Singapore. This marks a steeper contraction than the 0.2% fall in February and worse than expected by private-sector economists. Excluding volatile components, non-oil domestic exports (NODX) would have contracted by 1.4%.

images.alt_text: Simulations by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have showed that even if the nominal exchange rate had not been raised, the Singapore dollar would still have appreciated similarly in real terms, chief economist Edward Robinson said.
In 2023, total merchandise trade fell 11.7 per cent year on year, after expanding 17.7 per cent the year before, driven by declines in both oil and non-oil trade.
Seasonally-adjusted, NODX was up x per cent sequentially in February.

site_title: Powell signals rate-cut delay after run of inflation surprises
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signaled that interest rate cuts may be delayed, citing the lack of progress on inflation after a series of high readings. Powell stated that policymakers will wait longer to achieve the 2% inflation goal, and if price pressures persist, rates may remain steady for "as long as needed." This shift in message comes after a third straight month of inflation exceeding forecasts, leading to a decrease in expected interest rate cuts for 2024.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Federal Reserve building stands in Washington April 3, 2012. REUTERS/Joshua Roberts/File Photo
Asian central banks are unlikely to lower rates ahead of the Fed to protect their currencies.
Without the tailwind of immediate Fed rate cuts, there is likely to more scrutiny of corporate profitability and stock valuations in the remaining months of 2024

With the US labour market strong and inflation falling more slowly than it did last year, the Fed will maintain its current stance “as long as necessary” to bring down inflation, said San Francisco Federal Reserve President Mary Daly.

site_title: China says new market rules won’t lead to massive delistings
summary: China's Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has stated that only about 30 companies may be delisted next year due to financial metrics, contradicting investor concerns about new stock exchange rules. The amended rules target "zombie" companies or "bad actors" and not small-cap firms, and are expected to have a minimal impact on the market in the near term. The CSRC also announced that another 100 firms could be tagged with a delisting warning, but will have 18 months to improve before a deadline at the end of next year.

images.alt_text: To improve the quality of listed companies, the CSRC says it plans to moderately increase requirements for operating income and net profit for companies listing on the main board and tech-focused ChiNext.

The latest round of inspections, conducted by local branches of the China Securities Regulatory Commission, is comprehensive in nature, covering daily operations, training, and Chinese Communist Party building, the 21st Century Business Herald said.

site_title: IMF changes rules to speed debt revamps, avoid China delays
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has changed its process for supporting countries struggling with debt restructurings, aiming to avoid recent delays blamed on China. The reforms, approved by the IMF executive board, are expected to reduce the time between staff agreement and board signoff on an IMF programme to as little as two months. This change allows the IMF to accept a "credible official creditor process" from creditors, such as China, to avoid waiting for their approval. The move is seen as an attempt to accommodate China's internal processes while addressing delays in debt restructuring.

site_title: United reports loss on US$200 million hit from Boeing grounding
summary: United Airlines reported a first-quarter loss of $124 million due to a $200 million hit from the temporary grounding of Boeing's 737 MAX 9. Revenues rose 10% to $12.5 billion. The airline expects 61 narrow-body aircraft in 2024, down from 101, and plans to lease 35 new Airbus A321neos in 2026 and 2027. Despite the loss, United said it enjoyed a "strong" operational performance and a "strong" demand environment.

Boeing has slowed production of its bestselling model to address quality lapses tied to a near-disaster on a 737 Max 9 in January.
CEO Izham Ismail has built a C-suite leadership with an average age of 46, which he is banking on to provide “continuity” to the business plan he has put in place.

The maintenance, repair and overhaul business is set to grow by more than 19 per cent within the next decade, according to consulting firm Oliver Wyman.

site_title: Tesla’s value dips below US$500 billion in blow to stock bulls
summary: Tesla's market valuation briefly fell below $500 billion, erasing about $290 billion in shareholder wealth, after the company announced a round of job cuts and reported first-quarter sales significantly below analysts' expectations. The layoffs underscore the slowing growth of the electric-vehicle maker, with analysts citing lower demand and supply as the main factors. The company's troubles are exacerbated by its decision to focus on robotaxis instead of making a cheaper EV, and investors are awaiting the launch of a lower-cost platform to drive growth.

site_title: Bailey hints BOE may be able to cut rates before Fed
summary: Bank of England (BOE) governor Andrew Bailey hinted that the UK may lower interest rates before the US, citing diverging inflation dynamics between the two economies. Bailey stated there is more "demand-led inflation pressure" in the US and "strong evidence" of UK price pressures retreating. He attributed the UK's slower inflation to lingering supply shocks from the war and COVID-19. The BOE's decision to cut rates would be a significant move, as it would likely precede the US Federal Reserve's potential rate hikes.

images.alt_text: A bigger question is whether Ben Bernanke, who was head of the Fed from 2006 to 2014, will recommend that the BoE move closer to the US central bank’s ‘dot plot’ where each rate-setter anonymously publishes their own forecasts for interest rates, growth and inflation.

The BOE’s Financial Policy Committee (FPC) says finance for riskier corporates could be particularly vulnerable to a deterioration in investor risk sentiment as the possibility of a sharp correction in a broad range of asset prices has increased.

site_title: US industrial production up on manufacturing boost
summary: US industrial production increased 0.4% in March, steady from February's revised figure, according to the Federal Reserve. Manufacturing output rose 0.5% and motor vehicles and parts gained 3.1%, while mining output fell 1.4% and utilities rose 2.0%. The manufacturing sector faces headwinds from higher borrowing costs and tighter credit conditions, but is expected to benefit from lower interest rates and supply network build-up in 2024.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit, Cordlife
summary: CDL's associate company Cityview Place sold 65 units of The Residences at W Sentosa Cove Singapore within a week, fetching an average selling price of S$1,780 per square foot. This news led to CDL's shares closing S$0.09 or 1.6% lower at S$5.61. Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's distributable income for the first quarter fell 8.8% to US$11.9 million due to increased financing costs from higher interest rates.

site_title: Climate startups need more corporate help to compete for infrastructure funding
summary: Climate-tech startups require corporate buy-in, such as offtake agreements, to secure traditional infrastructure funding. Corporates committing to purchasing output or products from startups can enable them to compete for capital. Companies like Southwest Airlines have signed offtake agreements, securing investment-grade funding. Industry experts emphasize the need for common principles to evaluate pricing and project quality to improve the bankability of climate-tech projects, with high-quality carbon credits potentially playing a role in this process.

site_title: China’s exports to Russia slump amid US threat of war sanctions
summary: China's exports to Russia plummeted 16% in March, the first year-on-year decline since mid-2022, amid US threats of war sanctions due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The slowdown is attributed to Russia's difficulties with international payments and the US's secondary sanctions on banks and businesses aiding Moscow. Trade between Russia and China reached a record $240 billion last year, with China's imports of Russian oil and exports of cars and electronics driving the growth. The decline is seen as a temporary setback, with Russia viewing it as a result of US pressure, and China's state-owned banks tightening curbs on funding to Russian clients.

images.alt_text: Beijing argues its companies are being penalised by developed nations that cannot compete on price.

Robotic arms assemble cars in the production line for Leapmotor's EVs at a factory in China's Zhejiang province. Western alarm at Beijing’s intention to build up its technology industries has been rising for a while now.

site_title: US and China lock horns again on industrial overcapacity claims
summary: US and China disagree over industrial overcapacity claims, with the US accusing China of having too much manufacturing capacity, while Beijing argues its companies are being penalized by developed nations. The US Treasury Department expressed concerns to China, but Beijing rejects the accusations, citing the "international division of labor" and market demands. The economic working group meeting between the two countries agreed to further discuss the issues, but a change in Beijing's policies seems unlikely. China's leader Xi Jinping cited a surge in clean-technology exports as a positive impact on the world's inflation.

images.alt_text: Stacks of aluminum ingots sitting in a stockyard in Wuxi, China. Source: Bloomberg

Robotic arms assemble cars in the production line for Leapmotor's EVs at a factory in China's Zhejiang province. Western alarm at Beijing’s intention to build up its technology industries has been rising for a while now.
The sales of new metal disguised as scrap, which started in December, are reflected in a discrepancy between Chinese and Russian data.
The potential collision occurs at a time when China’s economy is struggling with a housing crisis and a loss of confidence among consumers and entrepreneurs.
Janet Yellen says companies that provide material support for Russia’s war, will be at risk for US sanctions.

site_title: Voting technology firm Smartmatic, One America News settle election defamation lawsuit
summary: Smartmatic, a voting technology firm, has settled a defamation lawsuit against One America News, a right-wing TV network, over false claims that Smartmatic rigged the 2020 US presidential election. The settlement terms are confidential, but Smartmatic had estimated that OAN's false claims reduced its business value to less than $1 billion from $3 billion. The lawsuit was voluntarily dismissed after Smartmatic filed it in 2021, with the company's lawyer stating that the claims caused irreparable harm by spreading disinformation.

images.alt_text: Former President Donald Trump appears in the courtroom for the first day of his criminal trial at Manhattan Criminal Court in New York, April 15, 2024. Trump faces charges he falsified business records to cover up a sex scandal while serving as president. More than half of the first group of prospective jurors was dismissed almost immediately. (Jefferson Siegel/The New York Times)
Trump, 77, is required to attend the trial, which is expected to last through May and could complicate his bid to win back the White House as the Republican 2024 candidate.
While former US president Donald Trump (left) has promised to debate, his opponent, incumbent President Joe Biden, has declined to commit to the three debates.
The political prediction markets – which allow traders to place bets on the outcome of the election – show the US presidential race is tight.
Donald Trump is accused of falsifying business records in a scheme to cover up an alleged sexual encounter with porn star Stormy Daniels so as not to doom his 2016 election campaign.
US President Joe Biden is working to shore up support among Black voters ahead of his November rematch with former President Donald Trump.

The US Commerce Department added six Chinese companies to its entity list on Thursday, bringing the tally of new targets during the Biden administration to 319. That compares to the 306 entities added during Donald Trump’s time in the White House.
If Trump wins a second term, America will have a leader invested in his own personal power, both financial and punitive, and supported by a much more capable team.
A lifelong Democrat, Robert F Kennedy initially sought to challenge Joe Biden for the party’s nomination when he entered the presidential race in April 2023. He later switched to an independent bid.

site_title: ‘Rare’ Churchill study goes on UK display ahead of auction
summary: A rare portrait of Winston Churchill, created by artist Graham Sutherland in 1954, is on display at Blenheim Palace in the UK ahead of its auction in June. The painting, which is one of the best surviving portraits of the former British prime minister, is estimated to fetch up to £800,000. The artwork, which shows Churchill in a moment of absent-minded thoughtfulness, was part of a commission to mark Churchill's 80th birthday and was gifted to an unnamed owner after being kept by a framer for over 60 years.

images.alt_text: epa11281609 A painting of former British Prime Minister Winston Churchill by artist Graham Sutherland in Churchill’s birth room at Blenheim Palace, Britain 16 April 2024. The painting was a preparatory sketch for a painting to be gift from the Houses of Parliament. The finished work was disliked so much by Churchill he had his private secretary destroy it in a fire. The painting can be viewed at Blenheim Palace, Churchill’s birthplace, and will be auctioned on 6 June 2024 by Sotheby’s. It is valued at 500,000 - 800,000 pounds sterling.  EPA-EFE/NEIL HALL EMBARGOED UNTIL 1200 BST

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 slides in broader market decline on geopolitical jitters
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell 1.6% on Tuesday, its lowest level since March 7, due to heightened geopolitical tensions and investor caution. The decline was driven by losses in miners and banks, as well as higher euro zone bond yields. Copper prices retreated on weak China factory data and a strong US dollar, contributing to the market downturn.

images.alt_text: The US economy continues to surprise Fed officials with its resilience.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.2 per cent at 37,798.97 on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.1% to 3,143.14. The broader market saw gainers outnumber losers 53 to 41, with Macro Polo Marine rising 1.5% after announcing the delivery of a new commissioning service operations vessel. Banking stocks were muted, with DBS and UOB losing 0.03% and 0.2% respectively. The decline followed overnight losses in European markets, which were pressured by heightened tensions in the Middle East and higher eurozone bond yields.

images.alt_text: City Developments' associate company Cityview Place Holdings says it sold 65 units of The Residences at W Sentosa Cove Singapore within a week.

site_title: ‘Grand Theft Auto’ maker Take-Two to let go 5% of staff, scrap some projects
summary: Take-Two Interactive Software, the publisher of the Grand Theft Auto franchise, plans to lay off around 600 employees, approximately 5% of its workforce, and scrap several projects as part of a cost-reduction plan. The move is expected to result in annual cost savings of over $165 million and total charges of up to $200 million. The company aims to drive efficiency and adapt to the challenging video-gaming industry, which has seen more than two years of job cuts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: NBA 2K22 and Grand Theft Auto 5 by Take-Two Interactive Software Inc are seen for sale in a store in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., February 7, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo
Netflix begun its push into gaming by launching Netflix games on mobile phones in November 2021.
With the deal, famed franchises like StarCraft, Diablo, Hearthstone and Overwatch will once again be live for players in China.
“Fallout” starts streaming on Prime Video on Apr 11.
Gamers have been recording fewer hours of play, with the average quarterly playtime falling 26 per cent from 2021 to 2023.
Game companies have been coping with layoffs, mergers and product cancellations.

site_title: Why the dollar is causing chaos in Asia
summary: The US dollar has surged by over 4% this year, causing chaos in emerging markets, with currencies such as Taiwan's, India's, and Malaysia's plummeting. The dollar's rally is attributed to the US economy's "exceptionalism" and the Federal Reserve's interest-rate hikes, which has led to investors seeking safe-haven assets. Asian currencies, particularly those with lower interest rates, have been particularly vulnerable, with some experiencing record declines. Central banks in the region are struggling to support their currencies, with many depleting their foreign-exchange reserves to intervene in the market.

images.alt_text: Despite the support, the yuan remains close to the weak edge of its allowed 2 per cent trading range versus the US dollar.
The yen last hovered around 154.64 per US dollar, its weakest level in 34 years, and close to what analysts say is the new resistance level of 155.
The rupiah currency weakened on Tuesday (April 16) to its lowest point in four years against the US dollar.

Shunichi Suzuki, Japan's finance minister, speaks during a council meeting at business lobby Keidanren (Japan Business Federation) in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, Dec. 25, 2023. Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda pointed out some positive potential aspect of having higher interest rates under normal economic conditions while also reiterating his pledge to continue with monetary easing patiently in the pursuit of stable inflation. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg
The rupiah weakened as much as 2.27 per cent to 16,200 per US dollar, its weakest level since early April 2020, leading the decline among emerging Asia currencies.

site_title: US: Stocks flat as Powell warns of longer inflation fight
summary: US stocks ended little changed on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.2% at 37,798.97, despite Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell warning that reining in inflation could take "longer than expected". Powell's comments followed mixed economic data, including a rise in US industrial production and a decline in building permits and housing starts. The S&P 500 fell 0.2% and the Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 0.1%. The International Monetary Fund lifted its US growth forecast to 2.7% for 2024, citing a "quite resilient" global economy.

images.alt_text: The US economy continues to surprise Fed officials with its resilience.
Deep losses in Asia carried over into European trading, but Wall Street’s main indices wobbled as corporate earnings season continued.

site_title: GrabPay’s retreat is GXS Bank’s gain
summary: Grab is discontinuing its GrabPay Card issued by Mastercard on June 1, sparking concerns about the company's profitability drive. However, the move may be a strategic decision to utilize payment methods offered by GXS Bank, a digital bank backed by Grab and Singtel. This suggests Grab is shifting its focus towards its own payment platform, potentially reducing overlap with GXS Bank. The discontinuation may be a calculated move to promote GXS Bank's services and enhance Grab's own financial offerings.

images.alt_text: Jenn Ong, head of retail at GXS Bank said the acquisition of the mass and mass affluent segment will be key for Flexiloan growth.
Grab is shuttering the GrabInvest business and its two investment products AutoInvest and Earn+ after concluding they were commercially unviable.
GXS' move to adjust interest rates signal its intention to be more than just a bank to save with.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P open higher as upbeat earnings obscure Mid-east jitters
summary: The US stock market opened higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 257.11 points, or 0.68%, to 37,992.22, and the S&P 500 opening 2.77 points, or 0.05%, at 5,064.59. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 28.64 points, or 0.18%. The gains were driven by upbeat earnings from health insurer UnitedHealth, overshadowing concerns about the Middle East conflict.

site_title: AMD introduces AI chips for business laptops and desktops
summary: AMD introduces AI chips for business laptops and desktops, expanding its presence in the lucrative "AI PC" market. The new Ryzen PRO 8040 Series and Ryzen PRO 8000 Series chips are expected to be available in platforms from HP and Lenovo starting in the second quarter of 2024. AI-enabled PCs can run large-language models and apps directly on the device, and AMD's shares rose over 2% in early trading. The move is seen as a possible recovery in the PC market, driven by the advent of generative AI technology and intense competition from Intel and Nvidia.

images.alt_text: Beijing has introduced guidelines to phase out US chips from Intel and AMD from government personal computers and servers.
Blackberry, which now generates revenue from its cybersecurity offerings and licensing software to a range of sectors, has struggled to grow in the recent years.
The US has been aiming to boost domestic semiconductor output and reduce reliance on China and Taiwan with the Biden administration’s 2022 Chips and Science Act.
The US has been working to limit Chinese access to cutting-edge semiconductors that can develop AI models, out of fear that Beijing will gain a military edge.
The company is seen as one of the primary beneficiaries of AI, and last month, optimism about new AI processors helped AMD shares recover from a weak forecast.

site_title: Microsoft-backed Rubrik targets up to US$5.4 billion valuation in US IPO
summary: Microsoft-backed cybersecurity software firm Rubrik is targeting a valuation of up to US$5.44 billion in its US initial public offering. The company plans to raise up to US$713 million by selling 23 million shares priced between US$28 and US$31 each. This follows a two-year lull in new listings, with technology companies driving the revival. Rubrik provides data security solutions to over 6,100 customers and competes with major vendors like Cohesity and IBM.

images.alt_text: Microsoft made an equity investment in Rubrik in 2021 in a financing round that valued the startup at US$4 billion.

site_title: China’s loosening grip on yuan allows currency to test a key milestone
summary: China has loosened its grip on the yuan, allowing the currency to potentially test a 7.30 US dollar milestone by the end of the quarter, according to 10 analysts polled by Bloomberg. The move comes after the People's Bank of China guided the yuan weaker on Tuesday through its daily reference rate, amid a battle to find the optimal pace for yuan weakness without triggering market panic or capital outflows. Analysts expect a gradual weakening path, allowing the PBOC to balance growth with market sentiment, but the yuan remains close to its 2% trading range versus the US dollar.

images.alt_text: The yen last hovered around 154.64 per US dollar, its weakest level in 34 years, and close to what analysts say is the new resistance level of 155.
The spot rate is currently allowed to trade within a 2 per cent range above or below the official fixing on any given day.
China’s policymakers have always been vigilant of currency pressure which can spill over to local stocks and bonds, despite the fact that the country’s export engine would benefit from a weaker yuan.

site_title: Transition credits need to be at least US$30 to close coal phase-out financing gap: CIX
summary: Climate Impact X CEO Mikkel Larsen says transition credits need to be priced at at least US$30 to finance the early retirement of coal-fired power plants and ensure a "just" transition to renewable energy. Current studies estimate the price should be around US$14 per credit, but Larsen believes the price needs to be higher to factor in the "just transition". Governments and compliance markets must also be willing to purchase and accept transition credits to make them tradable at this price.

images.alt_text: MAS forms global coalition to develop transition carbon credits for coal-plant closures

Senior Minister and Coordinating Minister for National Security Teo Chee Hean delivering Singapore's national statement at the UN Climate Change Conference at Expo City Dubai on December 2, 2023, in Dubai, United Arab Emirates.
