site_title: Anxiety over Middle East hits global stocks
summary: Global stocks sank on Tuesday, April 16, amid heightened tensions in the Middle East, following Israel's vow to respond to Iran's attack on its army chief. Despite oil prices holding steady, the threat of escalation and potential US involvement fueled market uncertainty. The US retail sales data, released Monday, reinforced the world's top economy's health, but failed to ease hopes for interest rate cuts this year. Markets will closely watch Israel's response to gauge the extent of the retaliation.

images.alt_text: A woman walks past an electronic board displaying stock prices of Nikkei 225 listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange along a street in Tokyo on April 16, 2024. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, less vocal than usual, has yet to define any shape, form, or timing for a response to the first direct Iranian attack on Israeli soil.

Pieces of an Iranian missile in a pickup truck outside Arad, Israel, on Sunday, April 14, 2024. On Saturday, Iran launched a retaliatory missile and drone attack on Israel; most of the missiles and drones were intercepted.
Explosions lighting up Jerusalem sky during an Iranian attack on Israel. Teheran has insisted the attack was an act of “self-defence”.
An Israeli Air Force fighter aircraft at an undisclosed airfield after a mission to intercept incoming airborne threats, April 14, 2024.

A video grab taken on April 14, 2024 shows explosions lighting up Jerusalem sky during an Iranian attack on Israel. Iran launched a barrage of more than 100 medium-range ballistic missiles, more than 30 land-attack cruise missiles and more than 150 attack drones at Israel, a senior US military official said.

Iranian demonstrators show support during an anti-Israeli gathering at Palestine Square in Tehran, April 14, 2024, after Iran retaliated directly against Israel for the killings of its senior generals in Damascus, Syria, with an onslaught of more than 300 drones and missiles.
Iran says its latest attack follows an offensive on its diplomatic premises in Damascus on Apr 1.
Jerusalem's Old City, after Iran launched more than 200 drones and missiles on Israel.

site_title: LVMH’s first quarter sales growth slips to 3% on luxury slowdown
summary: LVMH, the world's largest luxury group, reported a 3% year-on-year rise in first-quarter sales to 20.69 billion euros (S$30 billion), matching analyst expectations. The slowdown was attributed to rising prices prompting consumers to hold back on luxury purchases. Sales in LVMH's fashion and leather goods division, including Louis Vuitton and Dior, climbed 2%, while purchases of Louis Vuitton products by Chinese buyers globally grew by 10%. The company's chief financial officer stated that demand from Chinese shoppers was "quite happy".

images.alt_text: Antonio Belloni will give up his roles as group managing director and chairman of the executive committee at LVMH.

FILE PHOTO: The logo of LVMH is seen at the Viva Technology conference dedicated to innovation and startups at Porte de Versailles exhibition center in Paris, France, June 15, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo
The most expensive luxury goods makers such as LVMH and Cartier-owner Richemont have shown the most resilience to a downturn in consumer spending.

site_title: China air travel hits fresh record on Chinese New Year boost
summary: China's airlines recorded a record 180 million air passenger trips in the first quarter of 2024, a 37.7% year-over-year growth, driven by government efforts to boost tourism and strong demand for holidays at home. This represents a 10.2% increase from 2019. The Chinese New Year holiday, which typically falls in the first quarter, saw 83.5 million air trips, a 51% increase from 2023 and 14.5% from 2019. Domestic routes saw a 14.3% increase, while international routes saw a 78% recovery from 2019 levels.

images.alt_text: Major tourist attractions have been instructed to accept overseas bank cards, as well as support payments in cash and increase foreign-exchange services.
ICBC signed a cooperation pact with China’s culture and tourism ministry on Tuesday (Apr 2) to “stimulate” tourism investment and spending.
Per-capita tourism revenue over the eight-day festival in China this year slumps 9.5 per cent versus a similar timespan in 2019.

Even a year after Chinese borders re-opened, the lure of duty-free shopping in Hainan remains strong as flight restrictions, visa delays and the high cost of travel to far-flung international destinations have kept many Chinese travellers home.

site_title: BYD unveils two models in latest luxury sport utility push
summary: China's largest automaker BYD unveiled two new luxury sport utility vehicles, the Super 3 and Bao 8, in a livestreamed event on April 16. The models are part of BYD's expansion into the high-end luxury SUV market, with the Super 9 concept car also displayed. This follows the launch of the high-performance electric supercar, Yangwang U9, earlier this year. The Super 3 and Bao 8 are expected to compete with luxury brands like Jaguar Land Rover Automotive, with details on their hybrid or electric powertrains to be revealed later.

images.alt_text: epa11247954 A visitor inspects Chinese automaker BYD's Seal electric car displayed at the 45th Bangkok International Motor Show 2024  in Nonthaburi province on the outskirts of Bangkok, Thailand, 28 March 2024. More than 49 leading brands of the world's major automakers attend to exhibit and unveil their automotive products and technology including the new electric vehicles, in the annual automobile showcase amid Thailand's sluggish domestic car sales continuing to decline to the lowest level in two years by 26 percent year-on-year in February 2024, according to the Federation of Thai Industries.  EPA-EFE/RUNGROJ YONGRIT
Chinese carmakers were in the spotlight amid the growing challenge to Japanese auto giants that have long dominated Thailand’s vehicle market.
While BYD vehicles are not available in the US, the automaker has been pushing into markets in Asia, Australia and South America, where pickups are popular.
BYD has responded since February to the price war Tesla started early last year in China by cutting prices on the latest versions of its lineup.

site_title: Lagarde says ECB moving toward rate cut
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said the ECB is moving towards a rate cut as long as inflation remains under control, aiming to return consumer-price growth to 2% by mid-2025. Lagarde expressed caution due to geopolitical developments, but noted that officials are observing a disinflationary process, which should sustainably return to the target. This comes after the ECB bolstered expectations of a rate cut in June, the first reduction since 2022, and ahead of potential moves by the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: A view shows the logo of the European Central Bank (ECB) outside its headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany March 16, 2023. REUTERS/Heiko Becker
The ECB insists that it sets policy independently, but prolonged divergence with the Fed could be counterproductive.

site_title: From field to fork: Net zero starts in our food chain
summary: As Earth Day approaches, the public and private sectors must lead in reducing global greenhouse gas emissions to meet ambitious net-zero targets. However, food and climate change are inextricably linked, accounting for one-third of anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions. Supermarkets rely on globally sourced ingredients, resulting in extensive packaging, preservatives, and food miles. To mitigate this, consumers can choose locally sourced produce, reduce food waste, and consider growing their own food. A small shift in behavior can bring about genuine change, and collaboration between industry, NGOs, and governments is crucial in building sustainable food systems to reach net zero.

images.alt_text: The Temasek logo at the Temasek Holdings office at The Atrium@Orchard on 9 February 2021.
Tuesday’s proposal will kick off political debate on the target, but it will be up to a new EU Commission and parliament, formed after EU elections in June, to pass the final target.
Urban farming goes high-tech

site_title: Yellen says US working to mitigate risks to global economy
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the US labour market is healthy and inflation is down significantly from its peak, despite remaining work to be done. The US economy has contributed to the global economy's growth, but the global recovery has been uneven with risks remaining. Yellen plans to engage with international officials at the International Monetary Fund and World Bank meetings to mitigate short-term risks and support sustainable long-term growth.

site_title: No letting-up: South-east Asia’s war against corruption
summary: Vietnam's 10-year anti-corruption campaign, "Blazing Furnace", has reached a milestone with the sentencing of property tycoon Truong My Lan to death for masterminding the largest-ever fraud case in the region, involving nearly S$17 billion. The crackdown has ensnared hundreds of senior officials and influential business figures, and its impact is expected to spread to other countries in the region. Vietnam's Communist Party has made it clear that it will brook no mercy in its fight against corruption, which is a significant challenge for countries in South-east Asia, where widespread corruption can hurt businesses, public morale, and economic growth.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's recent graft investigations involved prominent businessmen and political leaders.
Vietnamese property tycoon Truong My Lan is expected to appeal the verdict announced on Thursday.

site_title: Europe shows diversifying from China’s economy is hard to do
summary: European nations' efforts to diversify their economies away from China's are proving challenging. Despite total Chinese imports falling by 20% between 2022 and 2023, Germany's dependence on China remains high, with 200 goods relying on the Asian giant for more than 50% of imports. A recent study found that Germany's dependence on China has increased in areas such as pharmaceuticals and rare earths. European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and High Representative Josep Borrell face a difficult task in finding common ground on Beijing across the continent, with differing views on engagement and diversification.

images.alt_text: “China’s export of electric vehicles, lithium batteries and solar products have enriched supplies to the global market and eased inflationary pressure, as well as made a great contribution for global efforts to tackle climate change and green transition,” President Xi told Chancellor Olaf Scholz.
The EU’s approach aligns with some Western allies, who are taking a firmer stance with Beijing.

While overall imports from China dropped by nearly a fifth between 2022 and 2023, the share of product groups for which Germany relies on China for more than half of its imports has barely changed, including chemicals, computers and solar cells.

site_title: US single-family housing starts plunge in March
summary: US single-family housing starts plummeted 12.4% to 1.022 million units in March, according to the Commerce Department. This drop is attributed to a resurgence in mortgage rates, pushing potential buyers to the sidelines. Permits for future single-family construction fell to a five-month low, suggesting the housing recovery is losing steam. Experts warn that home prices will become increasingly unaffordable without more supply, as home builder expectations of lower interest rates this year have faded.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: New contemporary attached residential homes are shown under construction by Beazer Homes USA Inc. in Vista, California, U.S., October 24, 2023. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: IMF steps up its warning to US over spending and ballooning debt
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has issued a direct warning to US policymakers, citing the country's unsustainable fiscal policy as a major driver of global growth. The report notes that the US's recent standout performance is largely due to strong demand factors, including overspending, which risks reigniting inflation and undermining long-term fiscal stability worldwide. The IMF warns that "something will have to give" as the US debt is expected to reach 114% of GDP by 2033, with public debt reaching $45.7 trillion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) logo is seen outside the headquarters building in Washington, U.S., September 4, 2018. REUTERS/Yuri Gripas/File Photo

site_title: Moody’s affirms Indonesia’s long-term issuer ratings at Baa2
summary: Moody's has affirmed Indonesia's long-term issuer ratings at Baa2, citing continued economic resiliency and prudent fiscal and monetary policies. The agency expects Indonesia's fiscal discipline to support a stabilisation in the debt burden around current levels. The rating agency also maintains a stable outlook for Indonesia, predicting annual economic growth of around 5% for 2024 and 2025, driven by solid domestic demand. The proposed free meal programme for students, proposed by president-elect Prabowo Subianto, could have wide-ranging implications for Indonesia's fiscal policy.

images.alt_text: The rupiah currency weakened on Tuesday (April 16) to its lowest point in four years against the US dollar.

The Vietnamese dong registered a year-to-date drop of about 3 per cent.

site_title: Fintech funding in South-east Asia falls 13% in Q1 amid economic slowdown: report
summary: South-east Asia's fintech startup funding decreased 13% to $530 million in Q1 2024, with a 40% drop in late-stage funding to $270 million. Seed-stage investments fell 59% to $19.4 million, while early-stage investments more than doubled to $240 million. The decline is attributed to economic slowdown, reduced consumer spending, and shifting investor interest. Despite this, the cryptocurrency sector saw a 138% increase in funding to $91.9 million, with companies in banking tech and alternative lending also attracting significant investments.

images.alt_text: Laku6 acquisition by Carousell
Late-stage funding declined, data intelligence platform Tracxn said in its report released on Wednesday (Mar 27).

site_title: Rupiah plummets to 4-year low, breaches 16,200 per US dollar following week-long Eid break
summary: The Indonesian rupiah plummeted to a four-year low of 16,200 against the US dollar, prompting Bank Indonesia to intervene in the market. The currency's decline is attributed to persistent US dollar strength and foreign capital outflows, which could lead to a rate hike by Bank Indonesia at its upcoming meeting on April 24. Analysts predict a 25-basis-point rate hike to 6.25% to support the weakening rupiah and mitigate the impact of a potential balance-of-payments deficit.

images.alt_text: A man holds his new Rupiah bank notes, to be given to family members during the Eid festival which marks the end of the holy month of Ramadan, in Jakarta on March 28, 2024. (Photo by Adek BERRY / AFP)
As at 6.59pm on Thursday, the rupiah was trading at 16,002.

site_title: US dollar rises to five-month high, puts heat on yen
summary: The US dollar reached a five-month high, surpassing 154.64 per dollar, its weakest level in 34 years, and close to a resistance level of 155. The yen's weakness has raised concerns of intervention from Tokyo, but analysts say it won't be a long-term solution. The Federal Reserve is unlikely to cut interest rates this year, and investors are pricing in a 41% chance of a rate cut in July. The euro and sterling also rose, but remain under pressure due to European Central Bank rate cuts and British core wage growth.

images.alt_text: Shunichi Suzuki, Japan's finance minister, speaks during a council meeting at business lobby Keidanren (Japan Business Federation) in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, Dec. 25, 2023. Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda pointed out some positive potential aspect of having higher interest rates under normal economic conditions while also reiterating his pledge to continue with monetary easing patiently in the pursuit of stable inflation. The US currency rose 1.6 per cent against a basket of six major currencies last week after a small but unnerving upside surprise in US inflation cast doubt over bets on US rate cuts.
The won extended declines against the dollar to hit the lowest in a year and a half.

site_title:
New pathway sponsors faster professional
qualifications for Singapore accounting undergrads
summary: Singapore's Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (Isca) is launching a sponsored, accelerated pathway for accounting undergraduates to attain professional qualifications in about 18 months, instead of the usual 3 years. The 2-year trial aims to sponsor 4,000 students, with S$5 million set aside for this initiative. All fees for the Singapore Chartered Accountant Qualification (SCAQ) program will be waived for students under this pathway, allowing them to complete most requirements during their undergraduate studies.

Isca president Teo Ser Luck hopes that the programme will attract students from the "best universities" globally.
Many foreign accountants in Singapore – most of whom were Malaysians – left in the early days of the pandemic, and could not return when borders closed.
In the autonomous universities, annual enrolment in accountancy degree programmes has fallen to 5,182 in 2021, down from 5,650 in 2017.

site_title: IMF lifts global growth forecast but signals pessimism over medium term
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has raised its global growth forecast to 3.2% for this year, a 0.1 percentage point increase from its previous forecast in January. The IMF also expects the economy to grow by 3.2% in 2025. However, it maintains a pessimistic outlook for the medium term, citing elevated interest rates and expected easing of global headline inflation from 5.9% to 4.5% in 2025.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) logo is seen outside the headquarters building in Washington, U.S., September 4, 2018. REUTERS/Yuri Gripas/File Photo

IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva says that global 
growth will be “marginally stronger” in the IMF’s new predictions.

epa11147146 Managing Director of International Monetary Fund (IMF) Kristalina Georgieva attends a session at the World Governments Summit in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, 12 February 2024. The World Governments Summit Organization is an international, impartial, nonprofit group whose goal is to influence how governments operate in the future. The summit is held in Dubai between 12-14 February.  EPA-EFE/STRINGER

site_title: J&J profit beats Wall Street estimates
summary: Johnson & Johnson's first-quarter profit beat Wall Street estimates, with adjusted quarterly profit reaching $2.71 per share. The company's drug sales exceeded expectations, driven by higher-than-expected sales of medicines. J&J's consumer health unit was split last year, allowing the company to focus on higher-margin sales of drugs and medical devices. The company narrowed its adjusted profit guidance for the year to $10.57-$10.72 per share, citing the impact of declining revenues from its top-selling psoriasis drug Stelara.

site_title: Massive fire engulfs Copenhagen's historical stock exchange
summary: A massive fire engulfed Copenhagen's 17th-century Borsen building, toppling its 54-meter spire and causing widespread destruction. The building, commissioned by King Christian IV in 1619, is one of the city's best-known landmarks. The fire, which started at 7:30 am, is currently being fought by police, who have blocked off parts of the city center. Renovation work was underway when the fire broke out, but efforts are underway to save art treasures and iconic paintings from the building. The cause of the fire remains unknown.

site_title: Data gaps, privacy needs of the rich make anti-money laundering checks tough, say agencies
summary: Singapore's anti-money laundering (AML) checks are facing challenges due to data gaps and the need for greater transparency from high-net-worth individuals. Real estate agencies and professionals have expressed difficulties in detecting suspicious transactions and verifying client identities, particularly when dealing with offshore companies and foreign investors. The inter-ministerial committee established to strengthen Singapore's AML regime is seeking feedback from various sectors to address these gaps, with a goal of sharing its findings by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Chinese passport holder Wang Baosen (left) was handed 8 charges related to money laundering, forgery and lying to the authorities.

site_title: Geopolitics overshadows the shipping industry
summary: The shipping industry is facing disruptions due to geopolitical events. A recent massive Iranian missile and drone attack on Israel has overshadowed discussions about decarbonisation at the Singapore Maritime Week. The attack has raised concerns about the impact of global events on the shipping industry, which has seen its fair share of disruptions in recent times. The industry's focus is now on navigating these uncertain times.

images.alt_text: Pieces of an Iranian missile in a pickup truck outside Arad, Israel, on Sunday, April 14, 2024. On Saturday, Iran launched a retaliatory missile and drone attack on Israel; most of the missiles and drones were intercepted.
Explosions lighting up Jerusalem sky during an Iranian attack on Israel. Teheran has insisted the attack was an act of “self-defence”.

site_title: Carousell’s Laku6 laid off 17% of workforce in January
summary: Carousell's subsidiary Laku6 laid off around 17% of its workforce in January 2024 due to "long-term success and sustainability" concerns. The decision was made after evaluating industry trends and reallocating resources. Affected staff will receive compensation and employment assistance. This move follows other Indonesian companies reducing headcounts amid harsh macroeconomic conditions. Laku6 was acquired by Carousell in July 2022 for $25 million, with the goal of expanding into the pre-owned phone and electronics market.

site_title: Costly high-tech climate solutions can be partially funded with carbon credits: report
summary: A report by the International Energy Agency (IEA) and GenZero suggests that carbon credits can be used to attract private investors to finance high-tech climate solutions, such as low-carbon hydrogen, sustainable aviation fuel, and direct air capture and storage. To reach a level aligned with limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, investments need to increase to $300 billion annually by the early 2030s and $700 billion by 2050. The report recommends that governments develop regulations to provide clarity and certainty for investors, while carbon crediting programmes and project developers should accelerate efforts to develop methodologies with robust quality criteria.

images.alt_text: sbnature28 - The Nature Conservancy works with local partners in East Kalimantan to protect forests and wildlife such as the orangutan.
The decision marked a policy reversal and sparked an angry letter from SBTi staff to the leadership of the global nonprofit on Wednesday.
The United Nations-backed Science Based Targets initiative says it will allow the use of credits to cut emissions from value chains, otherwise known as Scope 3 emissions.

site_title: CDL unit sells 65 units of The Residences at W Sentosa after slashing prices
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) sold 65 units of The Residences at W Sentosa Cove Singapore at an average selling price of S$1,780 per square foot. This surpasses the 58 units put on the market on April 9, with 94% of buyers being Singapore citizens and permanent residents. The units were sold after a strong demand, with 3,200 visitors to the property between April 10 and 14. This marks a significant increase from the previous 20 units sold since April 2010, with the two-bedroom and three-bedroom units being the most popular.

site_title: PM Lee to stay on as senior minister; Cabinet reshuffle due ‘a few days’ before May 15: Lawrence Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced that Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will remain in Cabinet as a senior minister after his transition on May 15. Wong plans to recruit new members to form a "best possible team" and make room for younger ministers. The Cabinet will largely remain unchanged, with only minor adjustments, and bigger changes will occur after the next General Election (GE) before November 2025. Wong's priorities include addressing immediate concerns, charting Singapore's future, and taking concrete steps towards the country's shared aspirations.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong began his career in the civil service and entered politics after the 2011 General Election.
Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong's TikTok account has helped him reach out to a younger generation of Singaporeans.

site_title: Court lets OK Lim’s daughter leave Singapore, bail doubled to S$100,000
summary: A Singapore court granted conditional permission to Lim Huey Ching, daughter of fallen oil tycoon OK Lim, to leave the country to attend her children's graduation ceremonies in Australia. The 56-year-old, who faces a US$3.5 billion civil trial, was initially charged with obstructing justice in 2021. Her bail was doubled to S$100,000, and she must provide a surety and travel itinerary before departure. She will also surrender her passport upon return to Singapore.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Pipelines run down the deck of Hin Leong's Pu Tuo San VLCC supertanker in the waters off Jurong Island in Singapore July 11, 2019.  Picture taken July 11, 2019.  REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo/File Photo

Seng was one of the witnesses called to take the stand by the prosecution in the criminal trial where PwC liquidators and top creditor HSBC are suing Lim, his two children and Seng for a total of US$3.5 billion.

Liquidators are alleging in the civil suit that Hin Leong concealed losses of more than US$800 million over the past few years through the creation of fictitious gains, forgery of documents, improper accounting entries and the overstatement of its inventory.
In April last year, Hin Leong former employee Serene Seng admitted in court that she had lied to the CAD on some instances in a bid to protect her children.

In response to a question from Navin Thevar of Davinder Singh Chambers – one of Lim’s lawyers –, Dr Yeo said he knew Lim was suffering from depression as soon as he had walked into the clinic’s consultation room.
OK Lim’s health has been deteriorating since the collapse of Hin Leong; he has also said he has depression and anxiety.

DPP Ong suggested that Lim had been untruthful when responding to certain questions in the interview, and that he was trying to distance himself from being involved in the likes of approving Hin Leong’s trades, as well as managing the company’s cash situation and financing matters.
The prosecution says OK Lim was trying to use his medical conditions as “an excuse to undermine the value” of his statements that were recorded during his interviews with the CAD.

Resuming his cross examination of Lim, deputy public prosecutor Christopher Ong had asked Lim about his involvement in Hin Leong’s day-to-day operations right up to the time he had stepped down as the company’s managing director in April 2020.
OK Lim's GCB in Third Avenue was sold for just below S$26.5 million to a Singapore family.
Prosecutors led by DPP Christopher Ong on Friday (Nov 3) began their cross-examination of OK Lim.

site_title: Morgan Stanley profit beats estimates with higher investment banking, wealth revenue
summary: Morgan Stanley's first-quarter profit beat estimates, driven by a 16% increase in investment banking revenue and growth in wealth management. The bank reported a profit of $2.02 per share and total revenue of $15.14 billion, surpassing analysts' average estimate. CEO Ted Pick expects a "multi-year M&A cycle" and cited geopolitical risks and the US economy's growth as factors fueling deal activity. The bank's wealth management division saw a 4% rise in revenue, while investment management revenue increased by 7%.

images.alt_text: The conversions come as Morgan Stanley seeks to expand its footprint in the increasingly competitive US$9 trillion ETF market.
This would be the first time Morgan Stanley has cut staff at the China fund unit since it bought out its local partner’s 36 per cent stake in the loss-making business for about US$54 million in 2023.
The Morgan Stanley headquarters in New York. Photographer: Angus Mordant/Bloomberg
Private market trades let employees and some institutional investors sell their stakes to accredited investors.

site_title: Regime shift marks start of new era for bond investors
summary: A new era for bond investors has begun, with higher interest rates bringing "sanity" to the market, according to experts. The US Federal Reserve's efforts to curb inflation have resulted in a more stable economy, and fixed-income investors can now expect elevated yields and returns. Key areas to watch include commercial mortgage-backed securities, financials, and emerging markets, which are poised to benefit from stable or falling rates. While geopolitical headwinds may strain supply chains, the odds of a US recession are low, at 25%. Investors are advised to lock in higher rates now, as a massive shift into bonds is expected once central banks cut rates.

images.alt_text: A sign for JPMorgan Chase & Co. is displayed near the sidewalk outside their Park Avenue office building in New York, U.S., on Friday, October 7, 2016. Mark Kauzlarich/Bloomberg
Singapore banks remain compelling as an investment class given that their strong fundamentals and capital position remain unchanged.

site_title: UBS faces capital hit as high as US$25 billion, minister says
summary: UBS Group faces a potential capital hit of US$15 billion to US$25 billion under proposed reforms in Switzerland, following the collapse of Credit Suisse. The Federal Council proposes significantly increased capital requirements for systemically important banks, effectively singling out UBS as the country's sole globally systemic lender. The reforms aim to address a weakness that contributed to Credit Suisse's demise last year and would require UBS to boost its regulatory capital levels.

images.alt_text: The FSB is set to review its ranking of UBS among the list of global systemically important banks after the Credit Suisse takeover, which is due to close later this year.

site_title: EMA inks MOU to cooperate on LNG procurement, supply chains for Singapore and Japan
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Japan's largest utility company Jera to cooperate on liquefied natural gas (LNG) procurement and supply chains. The agreement aims to share best practices and explore opportunities in LNG procurement and supply management, enhancing the security and reliability of natural gas supply in both Singapore and Japan. The partnership is part of Singapore's efforts to scale up lower-carbon sources and strengthen its energy mix.

images.alt_text: Generic photos of ports and martime in Singapore
Jamie Dimon also called LNG exports a “great economic boon” for the US as well as a “realpolitik goal”.
Aramco believes the deal would position it as a global LNG player.
This project is Asia’s first gas-to-power project using an FSRU, MOL says.

site_title: 13 months’ jail for third money launderer who lied to CAD about wealth source
summary: A Chinese and Vanuatu passport holder, Wang Baosen, was sentenced to 13 months' jail for money laundering offenses related to a S$3 billion case. He pleaded guilty to two charges and was found to have possessed nearly S$600,000 in benefits from unlawful remote gambling. Wang lied to authorities about the source of the funds, and his wife's assets totaling around S$8 million were seized. The court considered general deterrence and noted Wang's lower overall criminality compared to another money launderer, Su Haijin, who was sentenced to 14 months' jail.

images.alt_text: Singapore's pro-business reputation has been instrumental in helping it attract a sizeable amount of investment year after year.
Located in the prime Bukit Timah area, D’Leedon has seven blocks which are 36-storeys high.
Su, originally from China, holds a Cambodian passport.
Su Haijin was formerly a director of Catalist-listed food and beverage operator No Signboard.

site_title: Bank of America profit falls on lower customer interest payments
summary: Bank of America's first-quarter profit fell to $6.7 billion, down from $8.2 billion a year earlier, due to weaker consumer division and higher loan write-offs. The bank's net interest income declined 3% to $14 billion, impacted by higher deposit costs and modest loan growth. Revenue in investment banking and wealth management rose, offsetting the decline in interest payments. Industry executives remain optimistic about a dealmaking recovery, despite a resilient US economy and potential interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley’s total revenue increased to US$15.14 billion in the first quarter.
Goldman Sachs' profit rose to US$4.13 billion, or US$11.58 per share, for the three months ended Mar 31, compared with US$3.23 billion, or US$8.79 per share, a year ago.

site_title: URA awards Zion Road, Upper Thomson sites to sole bidders at lower-than-expected offers
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) awarded two large sites, one at Zion Road and the other at Upper Thomson Road, to sole bidders at lower-than-expected offers. City Developments Ltd-Mitsui Fudosan won the Zion Road site at S$1.1 billion or S$1,202 per square foot, while a GuocoLand-Hong Leong joint venture secured the Upper Thomson Road site at S$779.6 million or S$905 per square foot. The tenders reflect the current market conditions, with sharply increased Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty eroding demand and higher construction costs.

images.alt_text: If participation by housing developers at state land tenders is weak, there may be insufficient private home completions in a few years time.

The Marina Gardens Crescent site (in orange and dark grey) drew just one bid at a URA tender that closed on Jan 18, 2024. In contrast, the nearby Marina Gardens Lane plot (in purple) received four bids at a URA tender In June 2023.,
The Upper Thomson Road land parcel is a stone's throw from the new Lentor Hills estate, where six plots have been sold so far and five projects launched.
At 15,276.8 square metres ( sq m), the Zion Road site can house up to 1,170 residential units, including 435 serviced apartments.

site_title: Sri Lanka fails to agree on restructuring terms with bondholders
summary: Sri Lanka failed to reach an agreement with bondholders on restructuring its $12 billion debt, causing its bonds to decline between 2.3 and 2.8 cents. The government said it couldn't agree to an extension of discussions, leaving bonds at half their original face value. This setback hinders Sri Lanka's progress in finalizing its second IMF review and receiving $337 million in funds. The government vowed to continue talks with bondholders in good faith to reach a common ground in the next few weeks.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka Photographer: Jonathan Wijayaratne/Bloomberg
Sri Lankan dollar debt has been on a tear amid optimism that the nation can successfully rework US$12 billion in defaulted global bonds.

site_title: Japan’s Nissan bets on solid-state batteries, gigacasting for next-gen EVs
summary: Nissan plans to start mass-producing solid-state batteries for electric vehicles by early 2029, aiming to increase efficiency and reduce costs. The company will deploy 100 workers per shift to produce 100 megawatt hours per month by 2028. Nissan will also use gigacasting machines to produce rear body structures, lowering manufacturing costs by 10% and reducing component weight by 20%. The automaker aims to launch 30 new models, including 16 electrified vehicles, by 2027, with the goal of making EVs comparable to internal combustion engine models by 2030.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Nissan Motor is seen on a car wheel at the automaker's showroom in Tokyo, Japan, Nov. 11, 2020. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo
“We want to further our growth in Europe, we want to further have the leverage from the alliance,” Nissan CEO Makoto Uchida says.
The share sale is its second as Renault looks to cut its Nissan stake to 15 per cent from around 43 per cent as the two firms reshape their longstanding partnership.

Announcing an update to its medium-term business plan, Nissan says it would target an operating profit margin of over 6 per cent by end of the financial year to March 2027 and total shareholder returns of more than 30 per cent.

This photo taken on December 8, 2023 shows workers inspecting a car on the production line during a media tour of the "Nissan Intelligent Factory" at the Nissan Motor Tochigi plant, the company's largest in Japan, in Kaminokawa, Tochigi prefecture, some 105 kms (65 miles) north of Tokyo. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: Honda to launch next-generation EVs in China by 2027
summary: Honda plans to launch six next-generation electric vehicle (EV) models branded Ye in China by 2027, aiming to have 100% EV sales in the country by 2035. The company also plans to roll out a total of 10 Honda-brand EV models in China by 2027. This move comes as Honda faces increasing competition from Chinese EV makers and follows its January unveiling of the "Honda 0 Series" EVs and two concept models at the CES trade show in Las Vegas.

site_title: UN trade body warns of further economic slowdown this year
summary: The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development warned of a global economic slowdown this year, citing falling investment and subdued trade dynamics. The body called for multilateral strategies to revive investment and trade, support full employment and fair income distribution, and address sovereign debt and growing inequality and climate change. Interest rate cuts may ease budget pressure but cannot solve the challenges alone.

site_title: The new Middle East: Emergence of the coalition to contain Iran
summary: Iran has launched a direct military attack on Israel, firing over 170 drones, 120 ballistic missiles, and 30 cruise missiles in retaliation for the killing of seven Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps officers in Damascus, Syria. Most of the Iranian drones and missiles were intercepted by Israel's sophisticated air-defence system and critical assistance from the US and other Western and Arab partners. This marks a strategic shift in the Middle East, with Iran forming a coalition with other pro-American Arab powers, including Jordan, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates, to contain its regional ambitions and counter US influence.

images.alt_text: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, less vocal than usual, has yet to define any shape, form, or timing for a response to the first direct Iranian attack on Israeli soil.

A video grab taken on April 14, 2024 shows explosions lighting up Jerusalem sky during an Iranian attack on Israel. Iran launched a barrage of more than 100 medium-range ballistic missiles, more than 30 land-attack cruise missiles and more than 150 attack drones at Israel, a senior US military official said.
Iran says its latest attack follows an offensive on its diplomatic premises in Damascus on Apr 1.

site_title: Paris 2024 Games flame lit in ancient Olympia
summary: The sacred flame for the Paris 2024 Olympics was lit in Olympia, Greece, on April 16, 2024, in a ceremony inspired by antiquity. Greek actress Mary Mina, playing the High Priestess, lit the flame, symbolizing the event's message of hope and peaceful competition. International Olympic Committee president Thomas Bach emphasized the Games' ability to unite the world, even during times of conflict. The ceremony marked the beginning of the Paris 2024 Olympics, which aim to bring the world together amidst global crises.

images.alt_text: Each individual Olympic champion will receive US$50,000 and relay teams will receive the same amount, to be shared among the team members.

The bet is that athletes breaking records in Puma gear will nudge spectators towards its whole range of products, creating a potential “halo effect” for everything from marathon shoes to everyday sneakers.
Over US$350 million of the ad sales are coming from new sponsors.

The new Centre Aquatique Olympique, with its wooden inward-curving roof that saves on heating by reducing enclosed space, in the northern Paris suburb of Saint-Denis, March 5, 2024. Organizers of the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris say that with measures like more space for bicycling and less for cars, solar panels on the Seine, more plant-based foods — and perhaps most significantly, less construction of new facilities — the Games will generate no more than half the greenhouse gas emissions of other recent Olympics. (Yulia Grigoryants/The New York Times)

site_title: Bain proposes IPO of Japan’s Kioxia to clear way for US$5.8 billion loan refinance: source
summary: Bain Capital has proposed an initial public offering (IPO) of Japan's Kioxia Holdings to refinance a US$5.8 billion loan coming due in June. Kioxia, a money-losing chipmaker, expects to return to profit in the year to March 2025 with earnings of around 130 billion yen. The plan aims to avoid defaulting on the loan, which is tied to a 500 billion yen net asset requirement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese chipmaker Kioxia's logo is displayed at its headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, September 30, 2021. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon

site_title: EU to spend 3.5 billion euros to protect the ocean, environment chief says
summary: The European Union plans to spend 3.5 billion euros to protect the ocean and promote sustainability through 40 initiatives, including fighting marine pollution and supporting sustainable fisheries. EU Commissioner for Environment, Oceans and Fisheries Virginijus Sinkevicius emphasized that the ocean is a shared responsibility. The commitments include investments and reforms in Cyprus, Greece, Poland, Portugal, and five other countries to combat marine pollution and support the blue economy. The initiatives aim to address threats such as overfishing and plastic pollution, and will be announced at the "Our Ocean" conference in Athens.

images.alt_text: Danielle Welsh-Rose, Head of sustainability for Asia-Pacific at abrdn

site_title: No market cheer for China data; STI down 1.2%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.2% on April 16, marking its fourth consecutive decline, as investors reacted to China's positive gross domestic product figure. The STI ended at 3,144.76 points, down 38.85 points, with Asian indices uniformly down. China's real GDP rose 5.3% in Q1, beating expectations, but the real estate sector showed weakness. The market's lack of comfort from the data release was attributed to previous disappointing economic reports, raising concerns about China's economic recovery and stimulus measures.

images.alt_text: China’s manufacturing drive has exacerbated tensions with trading partners.

site_title: Will the Fed still cut interest rates?
summary: The US Federal Reserve appears to be considering a rate cut to address rising debt sustainability and financial system stability concerns. Despite no traditional catalysts for a rate-cutting cycle being met, the Fed's quantitative tightening programme is slowing, and interest costs on the national debt have reached a record $1 trillion. The Fed's goal may be to strike a balance between inflation and debt sustainability, potentially easing monetary policy and stimulating the real economy. A decision is expected soon, with some predicting three rate cuts by end-2024, and investors should expect continued interest volatility and potential upgrades to earnings expectations.

images.alt_text: Financials like banks stand to benefit from stable or falling rates in the new regime. Banks have been able to rebuild capital and should soon see increased stability with Basel III Endgame.
Asian central banks are unlikely to lower rates ahead of the Fed to protect their currencies.

site_title: China national who had Singaporeans front plan to buy East Coast houses pleads guilty
summary: A Chinese national, Zhan Guotuan, pleaded guilty to authorizing the purchase of landed properties in East Coast Road worth over S$6 million through a Singaporean company, Hwampoa. Zhan, a shareholder in two property development companies, gave his employee Tan Hui Meng general authorization to manage the affairs of the companies in Singapore. He was found to have evaded the law for seven years before returning to Singapore and was charged under the Residential Property Act. The prosecution is seeking a fine of S$50,000, while Zhan's defense argued that his intention was to acquire the properties for his property development business, not to speculate.
