A munitions factory of the British defense giant BAE Systems in the north of England is running at full capacity, boosted by the war in Ukraine and an increasingly gloomy geopolitical outlook. (Photo by Oli SCARFF / AFP)

site_title: US retail sales up more than expected in March
summary: US retail sales rose 0.7% in March to $709.6 billion, exceeding expectations, despite predictions of weaker consumer demand due to cost fatigue and high interest rates. The increase was driven by a 2.1% rise in gas station sales. Excluding gas stations, overall sales grew 0.6%. However, motor vehicle and parts dealers saw a 0.7% decline, and electronics and appliance stores' sales slid 1.2%. Analysts expect consumption to slow in the first three months of the year, but the March sales boost suggests resilience in consumer spending.

images.alt_text: Without the tailwind of immediate Fed rate cuts, there is likely to more scrutiny of corporate profitability and stock valuations in the remaining months of 2024

site_title: Bitcoin’s share of crypto market highest since 2021 partly due to ETFs
summary: Bitcoin's share of the US$2.4 trillion cryptocurrency market reached a three-year high of nearly 55% due to the success of US exchange-traded funds (ETFs) holding the largest digital asset. The ETFs, launched by issuers like BlackRock and Fidelity Investments, have amassed about $56 billion in assets and helped propel Bitcoin to a mid-March record of $73,798. Bitcoin rose 4.3% to $66,575, while Ether jumped 6.2% to $3,260, following indications of upcoming Hong Kong-listed ETFs for both tokens.

images.alt_text: Representations of cryptocurrency Bitcoin are seen in this illustration picture taken in Paris, France, March 9, 2024. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/Illustration
The Bitcoin halving, set to happen later this month, is coming after the digital currency has more than quadrupled since November 2022.

site_title: JPMorgan, Wells Fargo tap US high-grade bond market
summary: JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo are tapping the US high-grade bond market, offering bonds in multiple tranches. JPMorgan is offering bonds in up to four parts, including an 11-year fixed-to-floating rate security that may yield 1.4 percentage points above Treasuries. Wells Fargo is selling bonds in two tranches, including a four-year fixed-rate security that may yield 1.2 percentage points above Treasuries. The moves follow the release of first-quarter results from the two banks, and are expected to be followed by other major banks.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Chase’s profit was US$13.42 billion, or US$4.44 per share, for the three months ended Mar 31.

site_title: Samsung to get up to US$6.4 billion in US grants for chip plants
summary: The US government plans to award Samsung Electronics up to $6.4 billion in grants to increase chip production in Texas, as part of efforts to bolster domestic semiconductor manufacturing. The project will feature two foundry fabrication sites and an advanced chip packaging facility, supporting US aerospace, defense, and automotive industries. The award is part of President Biden's plans to bring leading-edge semiconductor manufacturing back to the US, with the goal of countering China's growing semiconductor industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) logo is seen near computer motherboard in this illustration taken January 8, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: China's CNOOC stockpiles Russian oil at new reserve base, traders, tanker trackers say
summary: China's state-run oil company CNOOC has stockpiled over 10 million barrels of Russian oil at its Dongying port reserve base, according to traders and tanker trackers. This is the first reported stockpiling of Russian oil at the base, which has helped lift China's seaborne imports of Russian oil to a record high in March, supporting prices. The stockpile cements Russia's position as China's top oil supplier, despite slowed sales to India due to western sanctions.

images.alt_text: The discovery was made at the Qinhuangdao 27-3 oilfield located in the north-central waters of the Bohai Sea, CNOOC says.

site_title: China's CATL sees profit swing back to growth in Q1
summary: Chinese electric vehicle battery giant CATL reported a 7% increase in first-quarter profit to 10.5 billion yuan (S$2 billion), reversing a profit decline in the fourth quarter. Revenue dropped 10.4% to 79.8 billion yuan, despite a tussle with smaller rivals in the world's largest auto market. CATL's market share in China-made EVs stood at 44.9% in March, well above its 2023 levels, with Moody's upgrading the company's credit ratings to A3 from Baa1.

images.alt_text: CATL supplies batteries to almost every major automaker, including Tesla, Volkswagen and Toyota Motor.
The Chinese company’s existing partnership with Ford Motor will be the model for similar cooperation with other US carmakers, the report says.
The partnership will leverage technologies from both companies seeking to lower the so-called “full life cycle” costs of batteries.

The potential R&D expansion in Hong Kong aligns with CATL’s strategy to place greater emphasis on exporting battery technologies, not just batteries, as Chinese electric vehicles (EVs) and batteries face intensifying scrutiny from foreign governments.
CATL says Yichun lithium mine is producing normally as planned after the holiday.

site_title: Goldman Sachs’ profit beats as investment banking fuels highest earnings since 2021
summary: Goldman Sachs' profit for the first quarter of 2024 rose to $4.13 billion, or $11.58 per share, beating Wall Street estimates. The increase was driven by a recovery in underwriting and dealmaking in its investment banking unit, which posted the highest earnings per share since 2021. CEO David Solomon attributed the success to the firm's focus on its core strengths and serving clients. The strong earnings beat expectations and marked a significant improvement from the previous year.

images.alt_text: Advisers at Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley are working to identify potential bidders for the B&B Hotels chain, which opened its first hotel in France in 1990.
Goldman currently provides cash-settled Bitcoin option and Ether option trading, in addition to CME-listed Bitcoin and Ether futures.
The closed-end fund is part of Goldman Sachs Asset Management's US$340 billion External Investing Group.

site_title: BNP Paribas to become top investor in Belgian insurer Ageas
summary: BNP Paribas, the eurozone's largest bank, has agreed to buy a 9% stake in Belgian insurer Ageas from China's Fosun Group for approximately $780 million. The deal marks BNP Paribas' entry as the largest shareholder in Ageas and fits its strategy of expanding its insurance business. The acquisition follows Fosun's efforts to reduce its debt burden by selling non-core assets, including its stake in Ageas, which will be reduced to about 1%. Ageas' shares rose by over 3% in morning trading.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo on a BNP Paribas bank branch in Paris, France, February 9, 2022. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo
Major banks in Singapore have long preferred to locate their back-end staff outside the city centre where rents are cheaper.

site_title: Ringgit lurching towards 4.80 again as US dollar rallies
summary: The Malaysian ringgit has depreciated 0.55% over the past 5 days, reaching a 26-year low of RM4.8053 against the US dollar. The currency's fall has been attributed to a rallying US dollar and a wide interest rate differential gap with the world's largest economy. Economists predict that the US Federal Reserve's anticipated rate cuts and China's economic recovery could stem the slide, but the ringgit may see more headwinds due to stubborn inflation. Analysts expect the ringgit to hit the 4.80 level in the near term, with some predicting a rebound to RM4.55 by end-2024.

images.alt_text: Ringgit, despite depreciating 0.55 per cent for the past 5 days, is not the worst performing currency in the Asia region.

site_title: Sabana Reit’s occupancy falls to 83%; more staff resign from manager amid internalisation uncertainties
summary: Sabana Reit's portfolio occupancy has declined to 83% in Q1 2024, down from 91.2% in Q4 2023, due to the repossession of properties at Penjuru Lane. The manager also reported high staff attrition amid uncertainties following Quarz Capital's bid to internalize the manager function of the Reit. The decline in occupancy and staff turnover have raised concerns about the Reit's performance and future prospects.

images.alt_text: Analysts told The Business Times that operational performance for Reits are expected to stay resilient, but distributions per unit (DPU) would likely remain under pressure from financing costs.

site_title: Philippine central bank chief sees rate cut more likely in 2025
summary: Philippine Central Bank Governor Eli Remolona expects inflation to breach the 2-4% target for a third consecutive year, making a rate cut in the second half of 2024 less likely. Instead, Remolona forecasts a rate cut in the first quarter of 2025, with cuts expected to be small to bring the benchmark rate closer to neutral, around 6%. This decision is influenced by the need to address the inflation risk, which currently stands at over 56% and is a reason for the central bank to maintain a hawkish stance.

images.alt_text: Eli Remolona, Governor of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, speaks at an event at the Central Bank in Manila, Philippines, on Friday, July 28, 2023. Remolona said upside risks to inflation persist, in comments that indicate the monetary authority is open to further tightening. Photographer: Lisa Marie David/Bloomberg

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 15)
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong will be sworn in as Singapore's fourth prime minister on May 15. Green investments in Asean rose 20% to US$6.3 billion in 2023, while Singapore plans to train international maritime personnel in low-emission fuels. The city-state also launched a greenhouse gas emissions database to improve reporting accuracy. In local news, developers sold 718 private homes in March, the highest level in four months, and the Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1% due to war worries weighing on Asian markets.

site_title: Greenback jumps; yen weakest since 1990 after strong US retail sales
summary: The US dollar surged to its highest level since November 2023, reaching 106.16 on the dollar index, and sent the Japanese yen to its lowest level since 1990, after strong US retail sales data. The dollar index rose 0.07% and the yen fell 0.69% against the US dollar. Investors are optimistic about the US economy, with economists expecting fewer interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve, and are pricing in a weaker yen. This dollar strength is also driven by escalating tensions in the Middle East, which could boost the safe-haven dollar and Swiss franc.

images.alt_text: The won extended declines against the dollar to hit the lowest in a year and a half.
The Canadian dollar weakened to a near five-month low against the greenback.
The dollar index gained 0.75 per cent at 106.06, after reaching 106.09, its highest since Nov 3.

site_title: Gold is back –  and it has a message for us
summary: Gold prices have surged amid higher-than-expected US inflation and growing geopolitical anxiety. Historically, gold acts as an inflation hedge and a safe-haven asset when investors are concerned about the stability of the status quo. Analysts predict a massive run-up in gold, with some forecasting a price increase to $4,000 per ounce, driven by factors such as the end of the Washington consensus, rising tensions between the US and China, and the unsustainable US debt and deficit. The US dollar's weakness could also benefit gold, which tends to rise when the greenback weakens.

images.alt_text: As gold hits record prices, prices of commodies such as cocoa have also risen.
Spot gold was up 0.6 per cent at US$2,386.38 per ounce, as of 0111 GMT. Bullion hit a record high of 2,389.29 earlier in the session.

site_title: World Bank sounds alarm on ‘historical reversal’ of development for poorest nations
summary: The World Bank warns of a "historical reversal" of development for the world's poorest nations, where half of the 75 poorest countries are experiencing a widening income gap with the wealthiest economies. For the first time in a century, these countries are getting poorer, with a widening differential in per capita income growth over the past five years. The International Development Association (IDA) countries account for 92% of the world's people without access to affordable, nutritious food.

images.alt_text: Desynchronised US and euro area growth and price performance and possible divergences in Fed and ECB reactions could spur global financial market volatility and underpin the US dollar.
World Bank Group President Ajay Banga speaks during the World Governments Summit, in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, February 12, 2024. REUTERS/Amr Alfiky

The United States and other countries are pushing World Bank and its sister development banks to focus on climate change alongside poverty reduction and development, and to take on more risk to expand their lending.
FILE PHOTO: The World Bank logo is seen at the 2023 Spring Meetings of the World Bank Group and the International Monetary Fund in Washington, U.S., April 13, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz

site_title: Hot commodity markets are dogging inflation-wary central banks
summary: Commodity markets have surged, complicating central bankers' efforts to combat inflation. Brent crude has traded above $92 a barrel for the first time since October 2023, driving up petrol and electricity prices, key contributors to the US core consumer price index. This boom in oil, precious metals, and raw materials has pushed the Bloomberg Commodity Spot Index to a seven-month high, potentially delaying interest rate cuts. Rising costs for industries such as copper, coffee, and cocoa are also affecting various sectors.

images.alt_text: As gold hits record prices, prices of commodies such as cocoa have also risen.
Gold is historically an inflation hedge, but it’s also something investors turn to when they are worried about the stability of the status quo.

site_title: Singapore car startup Carro seeks value over US$1.5 billion ahead of IPO
summary: Singapore-based used-car marketplace Carro is raising approximately US$100 million in a pre-IPO funding round, aiming to increase its valuation to over US$1.5 billion ahead of a potential initial public offering (IPO). The company, which has posted its first annual operating profit, is betting on innovations such as a car health analysis tool and a five-day return policy to stand out in a highly competitive market. Carro plans further expansion in Japan and Hong Kong, with CEO Aaron Tan stating that the company is ready for an IPO but will wait for the "broader macro environment" to be favorable.

images.alt_text: A view of the Carro signage at their showroom in Singapore June 15, 2021. REUTERS/Edgar Su

site_title: OpenAI comes to Asia with new office in Tokyo
summary: OpenAI, the creator of ChatGPT, has opened its first Asian office in Tokyo, marking the company's international expansion. The Japan office aims to bring OpenAI closer to enterprise clients, including Toyota and Rakuten, to automate complex business processes. The company also announced a Japanese-language version of ChatGPT and hailed Japan as a "key global voice on AI policy." This move follows OpenAI's existing offices in London and Dublin, and is part of the company's efforts to expand revenue sources and capitalize on the growing demand for its corporate version of ChatGPT.

images.alt_text: Sam Altman, who became the face of the global AI frenzy when his company released ChatGPT in 2022, was in 2,692nd position in Forbes' annual list of billionaires.
Taking text from the transcripts of YouTube videos suggests OpenAI has been digging between the proverbial couch cushions, even at the risk of breaking someone’s rules.
Microsoft is paying Inflection US$650 million in licensing fees in a deal designed to make investors whole.
FILE PHOTO: OpenAI logo is seen in this illustration taken, February 3, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: India’s trade deficit narrows to 11-month low in March
summary: India's trade deficit narrowed to an 11-month low in March, reaching $15.6 billion, as imports fell 6% to $57.28 billion and exports fell 0.7% to $41.68 billion. The country's economy is expected to grow over 8% in the fiscal year, driven by a recovery in global demand. Despite rising crude prices, lower gold imports helped tame the overall import bill. India's exports are moving in a "positive cycle," with outbound shipments remaining above $40 billion for the second consecutive month.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker carries a sack of sugar at a food warehouse in Mumbai July 11, 2008.  REUTERS/Arko Datta (INDIA)/File Photo

site_title: Time to pay heed to weak participation in state land tenders
summary: Singapore's government land sales (GLS) programme, which aims to maintain an adequate supply of private homes, has seen weak participation from housing developers, with several sites drawing only one bid. This could lead to a shortage of completed private homes in a few years, driving up prices. The government may need to explore ways to raise interest, such as revising the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates or implementing an open-bidding process. If developers are inactive, many residents will struggle to afford private homes, and the government may need to consider alternative measures to ensure a sufficient supply.

images.alt_text: At 15,276.8 square metres ( sq m), the Zion Road site can house up to 1,170 residential units, including 435 serviced apartments.

site_title: GIP said to halt plan to buy stake in Malaysian ports operator
summary: Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP) has halted its plan to buy up to 49% of Malaysian port operator MMC Port Holdings due to valuation concerns. The New York-based investment firm completed due diligence on the company but failed to reach an agreement on a price, with MMC Port's owner seeking a valuation of RM15 billion to RM20 billion. This deal would have been Malaysia's biggest-ever ports deal. Other bidders could emerge, and GIP's decision comes after BlackRock agreed to buy GIP for US$12.5 billion in January.

images.alt_text: Malaysian tycoon Syed Mokhtar Al-Bukhary's conglomerate MMC may sell a stake of up to 30 per cent in MMC Ports.
The acquisition of GIP, which manages US$100 billion, is the biggest deal in more than a decade for BlackRock.

site_title: From guitar covers to TikTok, Lawrence Wong has found his own tune
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong has leveraged his social media presence, particularly on TikTok, to connect with a younger generation of Singaporeans. The 4G politician, known for his guitar-playing skills, has posted comedy videos, explained complex policies, and even collaborated with foreign leaders on the platform. His efforts have helped him reach a broader audience, but it remains to be seen if his social media presence will translate to staying relevant with younger voters as he prepares to take over as prime minister.

images.alt_text: PM Lee Hsien Loong and DPM Lawrence Wong mingling with party members after the PAP’s convention on Nov 5.
TikTok is especially popular among younger audiences. A report by online marketplace Oberlo has found that nearly 40 per cent of the app’s users are between the ages of 18 and 24.

site_title: PAP ministers, MPs pay tribute to PM Lee’s decades-long leadership
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will step down on May 15, marking the end of nearly two decades of leadership. Over 13 PAP MPs paid tribute to him, praising his quiet wisdom, steady hand, and contributions to the country's growth, including investments in infrastructure, education, and social policies. The government has expressed confidence in the transition, with Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong set to take over as the new Prime Minister. Tributes highlighted PM Lee's leadership, character, and impact on Singapore's development, with many praising his vision and commitment to the nation's future.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong speaks during the National Day Rally held at the Institute of Technical Education (ITE) College Central  on Aug 20, 2023.

site_title: BP’s EV charging arm cuts jobs, reduces global ambitions
summary: BP has cut over 10% of its workforce in its electric vehicle charging business, BP Pulse, as part of efforts to focus on profitable segments and adapt to slower-than-expected EV growth. The division reduced its global workforce from 900 to 810, with over 100 jobs axed, and shifted focus to the US, Britain, Germany, and China. Despite this, BP remains committed to its EV ambitions, aiming to reach 100,000 charging points by 2030, and expects returns from its EV charging and convenience stores operations to exceed 15% by 2025.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A BP Pulse electric vehicle charging point is seen in London, Britain, July 16, 2021. Picture taken July 16, 2021.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo

FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk, CEO of SpaceX and Tesla and owner of X, formerly known as Twitter, attends the Viva Technology conference dedicated to innovation and startups at the Porte de Versailles exhibition centre in Paris, France, June 16, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo

FILE PHOTO: The logo of British multinational oil and gas company BP is displayed at their booth during the LNG 2023 energy trade show in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, July 12, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren//File Photo
Last year, BP said its carbon emissions would not fall as quickly as anticipated, as it posted record annual profit thanks to soaring oil and gas prices.

site_title: China EV maker Nio urges openness in US speech amid tensions
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker Nio's founder, William Li, urged openness in the US market during a speech at Harvard University, citing Tesla's success in China as an example of how competition can boost EV penetration and sustainability. Li stated that China will not adopt policies to protect domestic players, as openness will ultimately benefit industries and sustainability. Tensions are rising between China and the West over Chinese EV exports, which Washington and Brussels say are heavily subsidised by the state and could harm domestic automakers.

images.alt_text: The potential collision occurs at a time when China’s economy is struggling with a housing crisis and a loss of confidence among consumers and entrepreneurs.
Janet Yellen says companies that provide material support for Russia’s war, will be at risk for US sanctions.

The US Commerce Department added six Chinese companies to its entity list on Thursday, bringing the tally of new targets during the Biden administration to 319. That compares to the 306 entities added during Donald Trump’s time in the White House.
The news came out a day before Brite’s shares were set to begin trading on the Shanghai Stock Exchange.

site_title: War worries weigh on Asian markets; STI down 1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1% to 3,183.61, following regional markets, as investors weighed escalating Middle East tensions and higher-than-expected US inflation. China bucked the trend, rising 1.3%, while Japan and Hong Kong's markets declined 0.7% and 0.6%, respectively. The US federal funds rate cut expectations were dashed, contributing to the market weakness.

images.alt_text: Explosions lighting up Jerusalem sky during an Iranian attack on Israel. Teheran has insisted the attack was an act of “self-defence”.
Tokyo, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei and Manila stocks were at least one per cent down, while there were also losses in Hong Kong, Sydney and Wellington.

Brent futures for June delivery fell 20 cents, or 0.2 per cent, to US$90.25 a barrel while West Texas Intermediate (WTI) futures for May delivery were down 33 cents, or 0.4 per cent, at US$85.33 a barrel by 0225 GMT.
Spot gold was up 0.3 per cent at US$2,350.59 per ounce.
Airlines are contending with a set of challenges after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine severed access for many carriers forcing lengthy diversions which exist to this day.

site_title: Expect underwhelming spring meetings in Washington
summary: Global finance ministers and central bank governors are gathering in Washington, DC for the spring meetings of the IMF and World Bank, amid a mixed and tepid global growth outlook. The IMF forecasts 3% global growth, while the US is expected to grow at 2.1% and the euro area remains stagnant. Geopolitical tensions and rising inflation could lead to global financial market volatility and underpin the US dollar. The meetings are expected to focus on addressing these challenges, but little concrete action is expected.

images.alt_text: pixgenerics/ST20231017_202316586050/Ng Sor Luan/Skyline of Singapore's Business District taken from Marina Bay Sands on Oct 17, 2023. For stories on sustainability, garden city, air quality and more.

IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva says that global 
growth will be “marginally stronger” in the IMF’s new predictions.

site_title: Hong Kong approves first bitcoin, ether spot ETFs
summary: Hong Kong has approved its first spot bitcoin and ether exchange-traded funds (ETFs), making it Asia's first city to accept the popular cryptocurrencies as a mainstream investment tool. At least three offshore Chinese asset managers will launch the virtual asset spot ETFs soon, following the US' lead in launching its first ETFs to track spot bitcoin just three months prior. The move is expected to provide investors with new asset allocation opportunities and reinforce Hong Kong's status as an international financial centre.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is vying with the likes of Singapore and Dubai to create a digital asset centre.
Bitcoin has gained more than 60 per cent this year and hit an all-time high of US$73,803 in March.

site_title: Pay attention to commodities in an inflationary environment
summary: Commodity prices are expected to benefit from an inflationary environment as the demographic structure of inflation in developed markets shifts. Unlike previous disinflationary cycles, which have lasted at least a decade, the current cycle may be more sustained due to Japan's recent experience with reflation. As baby boomers retire, they will spend more and save less, causing structurally higher inflation. The Bank for International Settlements predicts a sustained inflationary impulse over the next 20 years. Investors should consider diversifying their portfolios with commodity exposure, particularly gold and other commodities, as interest rates may remain high and inflation becomes more sticky.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cocoa pods are pictured at a farm in Sinfra, Ivory Coast April 29, 2023. REUTERS/Luc Gnago/File Photo
Commodities have made a modest advance in the first quarter, with crude strengthening, gold hitting a record, and copper topping US$9,000 a tonne.
Gold is one of market watchers' top picks, as they expect central bank demand to remain strong while the downside risks for the previous yellow metal are limited.

site_title: Gaza’s historic treasures saved by ‘irony of history’
summary: The ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas has resulted in significant damage to Gaza's historical treasures, with 41 sites damaged since the Oct 7 Hamas attack. Despite the destruction, some of Gaza's greatest historical treasures, including 4,000 objects from Jawdat Khoudary's collection, are safely stored in a warehouse in Switzerland, thanks to the blockade that has been in place since 2007. The UN cultural organization believes the blockade has inadvertently preserved the artifacts, which were unable to return to Gaza due to the blockade.

site_title: Back to the Pacific: Notwithstanding Ukraine and Gaza wars, US geostrategic priorities remain in Asia
summary: US President Joe Biden reaffirmed the country's commitment to its geostrategic priorities in Asia, despite the ongoing wars in Ukraine and Gaza. During a meeting with Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida and Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, Biden vowed to strengthen defense cooperation with Japan and the Philippines in the face of potential threats from China. The US and Japan agreed to establish a joint command structure, develop a joint air and missile defense network, and participate in three-way military exercises. The meeting also marked a significant upgrade in US-Japan relations, with Biden calling the alliance "the closest of friends."

images.alt_text: (From left) Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos Jr., US President Joe Biden and Japan Prime Minister Fumio Kishida arrive for a trilateral meeting at the White House in Washington, DC, April 11, 2024.
US President Joe Biden and Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida review the honour guard during an official ceremony in Washington.
The popularity of Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida with the Biden administration goes well beyond routine backslapping for a close ally.

site_title: Vietnam to restart gold bar auctioning to increase market supply
summary: Vietnam's central bank, the State Bank of Vietnam (SBV), plans to restart gold bar auctions after an 11-year suspension to increase market supply. The move comes amid a 15% gain in gold bar prices this year, with prices peaking at 85 million dong (S$4,575.36) per tael. The SBV aims to stabilize the market, which has been affected by an imbalance between supply and demand. Fifteen commercial banks and gold trading enterprises have been qualified to participate in the auction.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Gold bars from the vault of a bank are seen in this illustration picture taken in Zurich November 20, 2014. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Private finance needs to step up on climate action in 2024 as election year constrains governments: Grace Fu
summary: Singapore's Sustainability and Environment Minister Grace Fu stated that private finance needs to step up on climate action in 2024 due to government constraints. The need for ambitious climate plans is hindered by election years, but global momentum from COP28 in Dubai suggests the private sector must fill this gap.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of Bukom island on Feb 9, 2023. Can use for stories on oil refinery plant, pollution, shell, burn, carbon emissions, gas, environment, climate change, transportation, ship, trains, planes, carbon polluter, carbon footprint, atmosphere.
The Singapore city skyline in the evening on April 4, 2023.

site_title: UK beating US on inflation fight and may cut rates sooner
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) is expected to cut interest rates sooner than the US Federal Reserve, as the UK's inflation rate eases to 3.1% in March, the lowest since March 2022. The UK's unemployment rate ticked up to 4% in the quarter through February, while wages grew at a slower pace. In contrast, the US reported an unexpected rise in inflation and a falling jobless rate. Analysts argue that the BOE's position has shifted, and it may cut rates in June or sooner, due to the UK's different inflation dynamics and policy track record.

images.alt_text: Higher food prices have prompted even affluent shoppers to switch to cheaper grocers such as Aldi and Lidl.

site_title: BOJ’s new policy approach takes shine off its inflation forecasts
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is shifting towards a more discretionary approach in setting monetary policy, focusing less on inflation forecasts and more on data-driven decisions. The central bank's policy meeting on April 25-26 will provide hints on whether it will hike interest rates again this year. While inflation is expected to stay around 2% through early 2027, BOJ officials, including Governor Kazuo Ueda, will scrutinize wage increases and consumption data to guide future rate hike decisions. The BOJ's new approach may require market players to closely monitor subtle changes in its economic and inflation outlook.

images.alt_text: Impact of the central bank’s reduction in purchases on short-term borrowing costs for corporates underscores how Japanese markets are adapting after years of ultra-easy money.

Bank of Japan (BoJ) governor Kazuo Ueda speaks during a press conference after a two-day monetary policy meeting at the BOJ headquarters in Tokyo on March 19, 2024. Japan's central bank pulled the plug on March 19 on its ultra-aggressive monetary stimulus programme, hiking rates for the first time since the global financial crisis. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)
Wage negotiations in Japan are likely to show salaries rising by more than 5 per cent
Kazuo Ueda’s BOJ has shown it will seize opportunities to act when they arise.

site_title: AI software startup Staple raises US$4 million in pre-Series A round
summary: Singapore-based startup Staple has raised US$4 million in a pre-Series A funding round led by Wavemaker Partners. The company, which provides document processing solutions using artificial intelligence, plans to use the funds to expand into new markets, particularly in regions with linguistic diversity, and improve its AI technology. Founded in 2018, Staple's technology can handle data in over 200 languages and process various document types. The startup aims to break down language barriers and simplify complex document processing tasks, reducing errors and unnecessary expenses.

images.alt_text: Peptobiotics intends to use its fresh funds to produce larger commercial volumes.
Tin Men Capital's co-founders Jeremy Tan (left) and Murli Ravi invest in AI software startup Ailytics, marking their eleventh investment in a B2B tech startup.
Cybersecurity firm StealthMole intends to use its fresh Series A funds to expand across countries and sectors.

site_title: Apple CEO Tim Cook arrives in Vietnam to meet users, boost supplier ties
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook arrived in Hanoi, Vietnam on Monday for a two-day visit, meeting with local suppliers, students, and content creators to boost ties and explore education opportunities. Cook stated Apple aims to enhance connections with suppliers, clean water projects, and education initiatives. His visit comes amid criticism from human and environmental rights groups over Vietnam's detention of climate experts.

site_title: Climate investors target Japan’s top banks, this time on board oversight: sources
summary: A coalition of climate groups has filed shareholder proposals with Japan's top three banks, including Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, calling for stricter board oversight of climate-related risks. The proposals, filed by Market Forces, Kiko Network, and Rainforest Action Network, aim to improve the banks' disclosure of how they evaluate director competency for climate oversight. This marks a shift in strategy from last year's proposals, which focused on mandating banks disclose credible transition plans to meet 2050 carbon neutral targets. The proposals are likely to face high hurdles at the banks' annual general meetings in June.

images.alt_text: Japan’s biggest lender is nearing the purchase of a 20 per cent stake in HDB Financial Services, which offers personal, gold and auto loans.
FILE PHOTO: A man walks past a signboard of Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and MUFG Bank at its headquarters in Tokyo, Japan April 3, 2018. REUTERS/Toru Hanai/File Photo

site_title: Bullish Asean growth; Thai PM, central bank lock horns again
summary: ASEAN growth is forecasted to be robust, with the Asian Development Bank and Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office predicting firm domestic demand and easing inflation in most economies. However, the Bank of Thailand maintained its decade-high interest rate, defying Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin's calls for cuts. Rate cuts are expected in June, but interest rate differentials keep economies on alert. Meanwhile, corruption investigations are ongoing in Malaysia, and a new green tourism destination in Indonesia is set to be completed by 2060, drawing inspiration from Singapore's Sentosa.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s outgoing leader Joko Widodo (left) will hand over the baton to incoming President Prabowo Subianto while Vietnam's President Vo Van Thuong (right) has resigned.
The Langkawi archipelago, one of Malaysia’s best-known holiday destinations, is also a popular choice among retired expatriates.

Jakarta-Bandung HSR
The 142-km-long Jakarta-Bandung HSR was launched in October 2023. The plan to extend the project to Surabaya is still under consideration.

site_title: India's wholesale prices rise at fastest pace in three months
summary: India's wholesale prices rose 0.53% in March, the fastest pace in three months, driven by food and primary articles. Food prices increased 4.65% year-on-year, while primary articles rose 4.51%. Manufactured product prices fell 0.85% and fuel and power prices dropped 0.77%. The wholesale inflation index fell 0.70% for the fiscal year ended March 31, a significant improvement from the 9.41% rise the previous year.

site_title: Israel presses on in Gaza as world awaits response to Iran attack
summary: Israel launched airstrikes on Gaza on April 14, following Iran's unprecedented attack on Israel, which included over 300 drones and missiles. The attack was in retaliation for a deadly strike on Iran's Damascus consulate on April 1. World leaders have urged restraint and de-escalation, awaiting Israel's response. Iran claims the attack was an act of self-defense. The conflict has heightened fears of a wider conflict in the region, with months of violence involving Iranian proxies and allies supporting Palestinians in Gaza.

images.alt_text: Brent futures for June delivery fell 20 cents, or 0.2 per cent, to US$90.25 a barrel while West Texas Intermediate (WTI) futures for May delivery were down 33 cents, or 0.4 per cent, at US$85.33 a barrel by 0225 GMT.
Spot gold was up 0.3 per cent at US$2,350.59 per ounce.
An Israeli Air Force fighter aircraft at an undisclosed airfield after a mission to intercept incoming airborne threats, April 14, 2024.

site_title: Russia and China trade new copper disguised as scrap to skirt taxes, sanctions
summary: Russia and China have been trading new copper wire rod disguised as scrap to avoid taxes and sanctions. The wire rod, mainly used for making power cables, was shredded to resemble scrap and sold to Chinese firms at lower tariffs. This has resulted in a discrepancy between Chinese and Russian data, with Chinese customs showing significant increases in copper scrap imports from Russia, while Russian data shows minimal scrap exports. The practice allows Russian companies to profit from the difference in tariffs and avoids providing funds to Russia, which is subject to Western sanctions.

images.alt_text: The potential collision occurs at a time when China’s economy is struggling with a housing crisis and a loss of confidence among consumers and entrepreneurs.
Janet Yellen says companies that provide material support for Russia’s war, will be at risk for US sanctions.
The news came out a day before Brite’s shares were set to begin trading on the Shanghai Stock Exchange.

site_title: Developers’ sales jump to highest level in 4 months in March amid uptick in launches
summary: Developer sales in Singapore reached their highest level in four months in March, with 718 private homes sold, a 45.9% year-on-year increase. This surpasses February's sales of 149 units, but is 13.6% lower than the five-year average. The Outside Central Region accounted for 84.3% of total sales, with Lentor Mansion being the top-selling project. However, overall sales remain tepid due to cautious buyers and longer decision-making periods, with prices rising 1.5% in Q1.

images.alt_text: The XXX continued to lead in condo and private apartment sales, accounting for XXX per cent of sales in February.

site_title: Singapore, US ink MOU to boost environmental and climate protection cooperation
summary: Singapore and the US have signed a memorandum of understanding to boost environmental and climate protection cooperation, covering topics from coastal science to heat resilience. The agreement, signed by US Undersecretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere Richard Spinrad and Singapore's Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu, aims to enhance bilateral cooperation on climate monitoring, coastal protection, and environmental monitoring. Technical exchanges, information sharing, and joint publications and projects will also be conducted under the MOU.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Elite Commercial Reit, Seatrium, Sabana Reit
summary: Elite Commercial Reit expands its investment strategy to include other UK real estate asset sectors, focusing on the living sector. Seatrium will collaborate further with Shell on floating production systems. Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) will convene a requisitioned extraordinary general meeting on or before May 25.

site_title: Lawrence Wong to be Singapore’s fourth prime minister from May 15
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong will be sworn in as Singapore's fourth prime minister on May 15, succeeding Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Wong, 51, has the unanimous support of the People's Action Party Members of Parliament and was chosen by his peers to lead the fourth-generation team in 2022. He has served in various roles, including minister of finance and co-chair of the government's Covid-19 task force, and has pledged to devote "every ounce of my energy" to serving the country and its people.

images.alt_text: PM Lee Hsien Loong and DPM Lawrence Wong mingling with party members after the PAP’s convention on Nov 5.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong (left) and PAP Deputy Secretary General Lawrence Wong at the PAP Awards and Convention at Singapore Expo on November 5, 2023.
PM-in-waiting Lawrence Wong will be taking over Singapore at a critical juncture, said watchers.

site_title: Muji bets its minimalist retail will work for homes, hotels
summary: MUJI, a Japanese minimalist brand, plans to expand its retail presence into homes and hotels, betting on the demand for no-frills accommodations. The company aims to build a large accommodation service, both domestically and abroad, with its simple and monotone aesthetic. This move is part of a broader strategy to diversify its business beyond traditional retail, which has been boosted by the revitalization of Japan's danchi (public or semi-public housing) using MUJI's minimalist products.

images.alt_text: Nike has stumbled badly over the past several quarters, with a sales slowdown and inventory issues rattling its operations.

site_title: China set to post slowing growth on housing, consumption woes
summary: China's economy is expected to slow in the first quarter, with analysts predicting around 4.6-4.8% growth, down from 5.2% in the final three months of last year. The slowdown is attributed to a debilitating property sector crisis and flagging consumer activity, with home prices continuing to fall and top developers struggling with debt. Despite some bright spots, such as strong industrial production, policymakers have announced targeted measures and issued billions of US dollars in sovereign bonds to boost infrastructure spending and spur consumption.

images.alt_text: epa11271670 An elderly woman buys clothes at a clothing shop in Beijing, China, 11 April 2024. According to the report on 11 April by National Bureau of Statistics, China's Consumer Price Index (CPI), which is a main gauge of inflation, rose by 0.1 percent year on year in March 2024, compared with market forecasts of 0.4 percent and after a 0.7 percent increase in the prior month.  EPA-EFE/WU HAO

site_title: Oil prices fall after Iran attack as market draws down risk premium
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday after Iran's attack on Israel, which caused limited damage and no loss of life, reducing concerns about a broader regional conflict affecting oil traffic through the Middle East. Brent futures fell 0.2% to $90.25 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate futures fell 0.4% to $85.33 a barrel. Despite the attack, analysts expect limited price effects, citing ample spare capacity and elevated geopolitical risk premiums. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate outlook also weighed on prices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Oil rig pumpjacks, also known as thirsty birds, extract crude from the Wilmington Field oil deposits area near Long Beach, California July 30, 2013.  REUTERS/David McNew//File Photo

site_title: ‘Expensive’ India lures investors avoiding China risks
summary: India has emerged as a preferred investment destination for global manufacturers, including Apple, as investors seek alternatives to China due to rising risks and costs. A Bloomberg Markets Live survey found that 196 out of 390 respondents preferred India over China and Japan, citing its ability to turn economic expansion into corporate profits. The survey comes as India prepares for general elections, which could impact investor confidence.

images.alt_text: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is widely tipped to win a record-equalling third term in the general election, which begins on Friday.
Manufacturing output in February rose 5 per cent year on year, slower than the 5.9 per cent rise posted in the same month last year.

site_title: Apple’s iPhone shipments plunge 10% as Android rivals rise
summary: Apple's iPhone shipments dropped 10% in the first quarter of 2024, reaching 50.1 million units, due to intensified competition from Android smartphone makers. Samsung took the top spot with a 20.8% market share, while Apple fell to second place with 17.3%. Chinese brands like Huawei and Xiaomi gained market share, with Samsung's Galaxy S24 series contributing to the growth. The decline marks a reversal from Apple's strong performance in the previous quarter.

images.alt_text: Apple has faced mounting pressure from regulators in the US and Europe over the fees it charges third-party developers distributing apps via the App Store.
FILE PHOTO: Smartphones are displayed in Huawei's first global flagship store in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, China October 30, 2019. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
Apple jumped nearly four per cent following a JPMorgan Chase report that pointed to improving investor sentiment on the company.
Foxconn in March has adopted a more bullish outlook for this year, saying it expected a significant rise in revenue driven by demand for AI servers.

site_title: Court rules against Three Arrows liquidators in ownership dispute over DeFiance Capital assets
summary: The Appellate Division of the High Court of Singapore has dismissed Three Arrows Capital (3AC) and its liquidators' application to appeal a court order allowing DeFiance Capital's Arthur Cheong to serve the liquidators in the British Virgin Islands (BVI). The ruling finds that the Singapore Court is the appropriate forum to handle Cheong's civil claim over the beneficial ownership of 3AC-linked fund DeFiance Capital's assets. The court rejected the liquidators' arguments that Singapore was not the appropriate jurisdiction due to the BVI court's jurisdiction over 3AC's liquidation proceedings.

images.alt_text: Claims by Three Arrows’ creditors into the crypto hedge fund’s liquidation currently stand at over US$3 billion.
Cheong incorporates DeFiance Capital in Singapore in May 2022, following Three Arrows’ relocation to Dubai, as he wants to continue operate DC Fund in Singapore.
Kyle Davies, co-founder of crypto hedge fund Three Arrows Capital. The claims by Three Arrows’ creditors into the fund’s liquidation remain in excess of US$3 billion, according to Teneo.
Zhu Su, co-founder of failed crypto hedge fund Three Arrows Capital
Zhu Su (above) and Davies are among the onetime darlings of crypto’s pandemic-era bull run whose reputations subsequently suffered as boom turned to bust, exposing risky practices.

site_title: Apollo’s Asia expansion has lured in US$35 billion from region
summary: Apollo Global Management has successfully expanded its presence in Asia, raising $35 billion in private market investments since 2022. The company has recruited over 50 investment staff and boosted its regional team to over 650, focusing on credit and hybrid financing for insurers and institutions. Key markets include Japan, where Apollo sees significant demand for reliable yields, and Australia, where the company has partnered with Challenger and FWD Group Holdings. Apollo's expansion aims to capitalize on changing market trends, including the shift away from easy monetary policy and low interest rates.

images.alt_text: Paramount Pictures has attracted interest from many suitors over the years.
Mubadala and an affiliate of Apollo have contributed more than US$290 million into the fund, which has over US$790 million in assets.

site_title: China central bank keeps policy rate unchanged, drains cash from banking system
summary: China's central bank kept its key policy interest rate unchanged, draining cash from the banking system through a bond instrument. The decision maintains currency stability amid an economic recovery and pushes back on market expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate cut this year. Despite signs of loosening in cash conditions, the People's Bank of China (PBOC) chose not to ease monetary policy due to a weakening yuan and constrained efforts to boost economic momentum.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Dollar and China Yuan notes are seen in this picture illustration June 2, 2017. REUTERS/Thomas White/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: China’s private builders face four trillion yuan gap to complete homes
summary: China's private builders face a four trillion yuan ($766 billion) funding gap to complete pre-sold homes, exacerbating the country's housing oversupply crisis. Despite government easing measures, metrics tracking the industry continue to worsen, and developers' funding conditions remain stretched. Analysts at Goldman Sachs Group suggest that the government must boost developer funding and bring housing demand to normal levels to mitigate the crisis, but large-scale plans could incur substantial costs.

images.alt_text: constuction property Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Gold edges higher as Middle East tensions spur demand
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to US$2,350.59 per ounce, driven by escalating Middle East tensions and safe-haven demand. This follows a record high of US$2,431.29 set on Friday. US gold futures fell 0.3% to US$2,366.40 per ounce. The tensions in the Middle East, particularly the first direct attack on Israel by Iran, have increased concerns about a potential larger conflict, boosting gold's appeal as a safe-haven asset.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.6 per cent at US$2,386.38 per ounce, as of 0111 GMT. Bullion hit a record high of 2,389.29 earlier in the session.

site_title: Seatrium, Shell ink MOU to boost collaboration on floating production systems
summary: Seatrium, an offshore and marine engineering group, has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with energy company Shell to boost collaboration on floating production systems. The partnership aims to promote best practices in design and construction by driving product standardization and replication. Seatrium and Shell will leverage their experience from past projects to realize further benefits of replication, utilizing their engineering capabilities and technologies. This collaboration follows previous collaborations, including the construction of the Sparta floating production unit.

site_title: Salesforce eyes Informatica to boost data capabilities
summary: Salesforce is pursuing a deal to acquire data integration and management company Informatica, with talks potentially reaching a final agreement within a week. The deal would add to Salesforce's capabilities and compete against its third-largest acquisition, MuleSoft. Informatica has a market value of $11.4 billion and has seen its shares jump 36% this year. The acquisition could push further consolidation in the software-as-a-service industry and attract regulatory scrutiny, as it would be one of the company's biggest-ever deals.

images.alt_text: SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA - FEBRUARY 28: A sign is posted at Salesforce headquarters on February 28, 2024 in San Francisco, California. Salesforce will report fourth quarter earnings today after the closing bell.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Analysts racing to catch up with world’s top delivery stock Zomato
summary: Zomato, the world's top delivery stock, has surged nearly 260% since last April, outpacing gains in major delivery stocks. Analysts have upgraded price targets, shifting earnings estimates into the black, and optimism grows for operations beyond its core business. However, some see the bull run as stretched, with the stock trading at 115 times forward earnings, and valuations justified by projected revenue and profits growth. Despite a sell rating from four analysts, the rich valuations are seen as justified by the Indian market's strong growth potential.

images.alt_text: Antfin, which held a 6.42 per cent stake in Zomato as of December-end, sold 176.4 million shares in the price range of 160.11 (S$2.59)  to160.40 rupees each.

FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A delivery worker of Zomato, an Indian food-delivery startup, prepares to leave to pick up an order from a restaurant in Mumbai, India, July 13, 2021. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo

site_title: Singapore companies to report more accurate emissions with launch of database
summary: Singapore is launching a greenhouse gas emissions registry to help companies report their emissions more accurately. The registry, developed by the Singapore Business Federation, will contain emission factors tailored to the city-state's context, replacing international sources. The initial set of data will be ready by the end of the year, covering transportation, water, general waste, and energy. The registry aims to empower businesses to make informed sustainability decisions, addressing the difficulties in reporting Scope 3 emissions, which were identified by companies as a major challenge.

images.alt_text: The Sustainability Reporting Grant is for large companies with annual revenues of S$100 million and above.
The green balancing act: How Singapore SMEs can navigate sustainability and costs
The emissions intensity of aviation-sector activities financed by DBS and OCBC have fallen sharply in 2022 and 2023.

ST20230427_202353509919 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the Singapore skyline as seen from SkyVille @ Dawson HDB near Queenstown and Dawson on April 27, 2023.
Can be used for stories about green plan, green economy, green city.

site_title: Singapore to train international maritime personnel in use of low-emission fuels
summary: Singapore is set to establish a Maritime Energy Training Facility (METF) to train international maritime personnel in the use of low-emission fuels such as methanol and ammonia. The facility, expected to be operational by 2026, will be a network of planned and existing training facilities, including simulators and centers of excellence. The move aims to support the industry's transition to cleaner fuels, with around 10,000 personnel expected to be trained through the 2030s. The facility's cost will be borne by industry partners, with the goal of reducing training costs for ship owners and operators.

images.alt_text: Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat announces a new facility which will allow global maritime personnel to gain competency in the use of cleaner marine fuels.

site_title: Green investments in Asean rise 20% to US$6.3 billion in 2023: Bain, Temasek report
summary: Green investments in South-east Asia increased 20% to $6.3 billion in 2023, a joint report by Bain and Temasek found. This marks a reversal from two consecutive years of declining investments between 2021 and 2022. The report highlights 13 investable opportunities that could generate $150 billion in annual revenue and reduce 1,000 tonnes of carbon emissions by 2030. Despite this progress, the region still lags behind in scaling capital flows, with only $45 billion in cumulative investments made since 2021.

images.alt_text: The Singapore city skyline in the evening on April 4, 2023.

site_title: US warns China is providing Russia with drone, missile components
summary: The US has warned that China is providing Russia with significant quantities of components to build cruise missiles and drones, as well as optical parts for tanks and armoured vehicles. These components, including nitrocellulose and machine tools, are crucial for Russia's military industrial base, allowing it to ramp up defence production in its war against Ukraine. The White House is urging Chinese firms to cease their support and encouraging European allies to put pressure on Beijing to end sales.

images.alt_text: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un (left) and China's third-ranking official Zhao Leji underscored the importance of the two countries’ bilateral relationship at their meeting, Xinhua News reports.
Jerusalem's Old City, after Iran launched more than 200 drones and missiles on Israel.
Several Chinese carriers including Air China operate direct flights to and from the US.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit expands investment strategy to other UK real estate asset classes
summary: Elite Commercial Reit plans to expand its investment strategy to include other UK real estate asset classes, particularly the living sector, with a focus on purpose-built student accommodation and build-to-rent residential assets. This move will allow the Reit to diversify its portfolio and capitalise on emerging market trends. The Reit will become a UK pure-play real estate investment trust, delineating a clear geographic boundary in terms of operations. The name change to Elite UK Reit is planned in due course.

images.alt_text: The new funds will be used to refinance the Reit's existing loan facilities, says the manager.

site_title: Playing it cool
summary: Singapore's office market has shown resilience despite market cooling measures, with rentals and capital values remaining stable. Recent government land sales saw only one bidder for each site, with developers exercising caution due to risk aversion. The prime office building market may be overvalued, with some experts suggesting a 3% yield is too high. Meanwhile, OCBC is exploring a redevelopment of its iconic Chulia Street property, while GuocoLand secured a site in Upper Thomson with conservation and environmental requirements. The government is set to announce new property measures to revive Thailand's economy.

images.alt_text: In the public housing sector, market forces appear to be regrouping, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
In today’s private housing market, the luxury condominium segment is struggling, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.
Senior correspondent Leslie Yee has been following developments surrounding the push to internalise the management of Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust.
Singapore has long relied on the fame of its shopping street to draw visitors, but the tourist belt needs to really up its game.
New home sales at the year’s first few project launches have gone much slower than they used to, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: ‘Civil War’ leads the charge at North American box office
summary: "Civil War" tops the North American box office, earning US$25.7 million in its first weekend, more than twice the average for a dystopian thriller. The film, directed by Alex Garland, is set in a dystopian near-future and has sparked partisan feelings, provoking emotional engagement among audiences. It knocked "Godzilla x Kong" into second place, while "Ghostbusters: The Ice Menace" took third place.

images.alt_text: The feature, which sees the enormous gorilla and reptilian giant set their differences aside and team up to save their species.

site_title: Ringgit’s drop towards 26-year low spurs BNM to pledge support
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM), pledged support for the ringgit after it dropped to a 26-year low, nearing 4.78 to the US dollar. The currency's decline was attributed to broad US dollar strength and bets on higher interest rates. BNM will ensure the foreign exchange market's orderly functioning with support from government-linked firms and corporations. The ringgit is outperforming regional peers, but its sluggish economic outlook, particularly with China, remains a concern.

site_title: Does tech still pay?
summary: Tech salaries remain competitive, with top deep-tech professionals commanding high salaries, but not as high as pre-pandemic levels. Deep-tech funding is on the rise, with investors closely monitoring the sector's growth. Google acquires Windsurf licence after OpenAI deal fails, while OpenAI plans to release a web browser to challenge Google Chrome. Chinese AI startups, such as Manus, accelerate their moves to Singapore amidst an intensifying AI race. Startup partnerships can help corporations unlock deep tech innovation, and some companies, like Bluebird, focus on alternative business models.

images.alt_text: With AI on the rise, investors are keeping a close eye on the deep-tech sector.
A key missing piece in the funding picture is large deals of over US$100 million, a sign that late-stage deals are not coming through.

site_title: Asia: Stocks hit by Iran’s Israel strike, hopes for containment stem losses
summary: Asian stocks fell on Monday after Iran launched a barrage of rockets at Israel, sparking fears of a wider conflict. Despite hopes for containment, losses were reported in Tokyo, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei, and Manila, with some markets recovering later in the day. Oil prices dipped, but experts warned they could spike back above $100 if the crisis worsens. US interest rates remain a concern, with analysts saying the market is holding on to hope that the crisis can be contained.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 132 to 22.
Without the tailwind of immediate Fed rate cuts, there is likely to more scrutiny of corporate profitability and stock valuations in the remaining months of 2024

site_title: South Korea finance ministry vows measures to stabilise market volatility if needed
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Choi Sang Mok, has vowed to take measures to stabilize market volatility if needed, following the won's decline against the dollar to its lowest in a year and a half. The government will review contingency plans and extend a tax cut on fuel consumption until June to curb inflation amid escalating global geopolitical risks. This comes after Iran launched a direct attack on Israeli territory, raising the threat of a wider regional conflict. The finance minister's comments were made in response to escalating tensions in the Middle East.

site_title: Oil traders weigh risks of Iran-Israel conflict in tight market
summary: Oil prices may spike as the Iran-Israel conflict escalates, adding a risk premium to a market already driven by tight supply-demand fundamentals. Iran's direct attack on Israel marks a new phase of hostilities, prompting traders to reevaluate geopolitical risks. The Strait of Hormuz, a key oil chokepoint, may be targeted, adding to oil's risk premium. Prices could increase by $2-$5 a barrel due to concerns of further Israeli reprisals or Iranian interference with shipping.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up 71 cents at US$90.45 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 64 cents to US$85.66 on Friday.

site_title: Buyout giant CVC seeking more than one billion euros in Amsterdam IPO
summary: CVC Capital Partners, a leading European private equity firm, is planning to list in Amsterdam, potentially raising €1-1.5 billion, according to sources. The firm is targeting a valuation of €13-15 billion and may offer a 10-15% stake in the IPO. This move could pave the way for other private equity firms to go public, following recent successful listings by peers such as Bridgepoint Group and EQT. The listing comes as European IPOs have rebounded from a 18-month slowdown, and CVC aims to capitalize on this trend.

images.alt_text: CVC had disposed of the remaining stake of Asia Commercial Bank via a unit called Sather Gate.
CVC has financed two acquisitions with loans from banks such as UniCredit, Credit Agricole and Deutsche Bank.

site_title: Airlines confront new Iran-Israel risks as disruption grows
summary: Airlines are facing new challenges as disruptions grow due to Iran's direct attack on Israel, forcing rerouting and adding to fuel costs. Several Middle Eastern countries, including Jordan, Iraq, and Lebanon, temporarily closed their airspace, while Israel and Iran imposed restrictions. Airlines such as Qantas, Singapore Airlines, and Lufthansa are adjusting their routes, prolonging flight times, and increasing fuel costs. Some airlines, like Qatar Airways and Emirates, resumed suspended services on Sunday after airspaces reopened. The disruptions come amid ongoing tensions between Israel and Iran, with the US and its allies responding to suspected Israeli attacks.

images.alt_text: Several Chinese carriers including Air China operate direct flights to and from the US.
Most carriers give military personnel additional free bags and other benefits such as priority boarding or discounted fares.
CEO Izham Ismail has built a C-suite leadership with an average age of 46, which he is banking on to provide “continuity” to the business plan he has put in place.

site_title: Nepalese billionaire who made his fortune making instant noodles aims to list India unit by 2026
summary: Nepalese billionaire Binod Chaudhary plans to list his Indian food unit, CG Foods India, by 2026, after bolstering its market share and product portfolio. The firm aims to grow its revenue by 15% this year and is looking to acquire smaller companies in the noodle-related industry. Chaudhary Group's India unit, which has a 28% share in the local instant noodles market, plans to roll out new products and expand its operations, following a trend of food makers going public in India.

images.alt_text: Global IPO proceeds are 7 per cent higher year on year in Q1 at US$23.7 billion.
Elsewhere in the region, new share sales set to raise several hundred million US dollars are surfacing.
India has emerged as the second busiest market in the world for equity capital market (ECM) deals after the United States.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Monday’s open; STI down 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.9% at Monday's open, tracking US market losses amid Middle East tensions. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 30.02 points to 3,186.89, with losers outnumbering gainers 132 to 22. Key decliners included Singtel (-0.8%), Thai Beverage (-2%), and banking stocks like DBS (-1.1%), OCBC (-0.9%), and UOB (-0.7%). Global markets also fell, with the Nasdaq Composite Index down 1.6% and the S&P 500 retreating 1.5%.

images.alt_text: Elite商用投资信托计划收购在英国58栋商业建筑，这些建筑位于伦敦及其他主要城市，大部分租户皆政府机构。（Elite商用投资信托提供）

site_title: Yellen says nothing off table in response to China overcapacity
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warns that the US will consider additional tariffs on Chinese goods if China's manufacturing capacity becomes a threat to the US market. She also reiterates that US companies providing material support to Russia's war in Ukraine will be at risk of US sanctions. Yellen defends the administration's efforts to boost domestic manufacturing, stating it will have a modest influence on inflation. Her visit to China last week aimed to address concerns over unfair economic practices and distortion of global markets.

images.alt_text: The US Commerce Department added six Chinese companies to its entity list on Thursday, bringing the tally of new targets during the Biden administration to 319. That compares to the 306 entities added during Donald Trump’s time in the White House.
The news came out a day before Brite’s shares were set to begin trading on the Shanghai Stock Exchange.
In acting as the standard-bearer for this policy, Yellen is rejecting fundamental principles of economics to justify a policy of restricting public access to affordable and clean technology.

site_title: Markets weigh risk of retaliation-cycle after Iran hits Israel
summary: Global markets are bracing for a potential escalation in the Middle East conflict between Iran and Israel, which could lead to increased volatility and higher oil prices. Investors are seeking safe-haven assets such as gold, the US dollar, and Treasuries, and are also looking to oil as a guide for how to respond. The S&P 500 fell 1.5% on Friday, with banks and chipmakers leading losses, and Brent crude rose to above $90 a barrel. Analysts expect a flight to Treasuries and gold, and a potential flight to risk assets if the situation doesn't escalate.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - APRIL 09: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during afternoon trading on April 09, 2024 in New York City. The stock market closed with mixed results as Wall Street awaits the release of the latest inflation data.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Tech’s cash crunch sees creditors turn ‘violent’ with one another
summary: Software and services companies are issuing distressed debt totaling almost $30 billion, with creditors resorting to "creditor-on-creditor violence" as they compete for repayment. Troubled firms like Alvaria, GoTo Group, and Rackspace Technology are set to agree to restructuring deals, offering select lenders better terms on debt swaps. This trend is driven by loose agreements with debt investors, allowing companies to move assets out of reach of creditors, and is exacerbated by high borrowing costs and excessive leverage.

images.alt_text: Marisa Drew, chief sustainability officer at StanChart, says that the goal with the guidelines around adaptation finance is that they become “a catalyst for that capital flowing.”
CNV offers digital transformation software-as-a-service products and marketing services targeting enterprises in Vietnam, among others.
Data scientist roles snagged the highest increase in median salary as most tech roles saw a dip.

site_title: Japan’s machinery orders rise sharply, may ease concerns about domestic demand

Compared to last year, core orders declined 1.8% in February, less than the economists' forecast of a 6.0% drop.

site_title: German business is tangled in red tape
summary: Germany's businesses are struggling with excessive red tape, with companies spending 64 million hours annually filling out forms to comply with 375 official databases. The issue is particularly pressing for small and midsize firms, which often lack in-house legal departments to handle paperwork. The German government has proposed legislation to reduce bureaucracy, which could save companies and citizens an estimated 3 billion euros each year. Industry estimates suggest that the current system is hindering economic growth, with the International Monetary Fund citing "too much red tape" as a major impediment to reviving the German economy.

The new products, which include improved track spikes and basketball shoes, are part of a three-year product-development cycle aimed at shaping Nike's future. The company expects revenue to fall by a low-single-digit percentage in the first half of its fiscal year, but hopes the new products will help it regain market share.

summary: Delivery-only restaurants, once pandemic successes, face uncertainty as customers return to dining inside restaurants. site_title: Canada to lease government land in plan to add millions of homes
summary: Canada plans to lease public land to developers for the construction of nearly 3.9 million affordable houses by 2031, aiming to ease the country's housing shortage. The land, which includes underutilized industrial parks, defunct government sites, and low-enrollment schools, is expected to cover a shortfall of 1.2 million units from 2023 to 2030. The plan, unveiled by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, aims to address the housing shortage driven by rapid growth in Canada's immigrant population and inflation.

images.alt_text: Condominiums stand along the shore of Lake Ontario in this aerial photograph taken above Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Monday, Oct. 2, 2017. Toronto housing prices fell for a fourth month in September as sales remained sluggish, particularly in the detached-home segment that has borne the brunt of the correction in Canada's biggest city. Photographer: James MacDonald/Bloomberg

site_title: Unpopular Sunak in ‘doom loop’ as UK PM stares at election defeat
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak faces a looming general election defeat despite a slightly improving economy and two tax cuts. His popularity has plummeted to a record low, and criticism from former Prime Minister Boris Johnson and speculation about Brexit figurehead Nigel Farage's intentions are adding to his woes. Professor Rob Ford describes Sunak as "hapless" in the face of "unstoppable political momentum" away from the ruling Tories, suggesting an impending loss for the Conservative leader.

images.alt_text: “These figures are a welcome sign that the economy is turning a corner,” finance minister Jeremy Hunt said in response to Friday’s data.

A bigger question is whether Ben Bernanke, who was head of the Fed from 2006 to 2014, will recommend that the BoE move closer to the US central bank’s ‘dot plot’ where each rate-setter anonymously publishes their own forecasts for interest rates, growth and inflation.
If the prediction by the new poll comes true, it would mean that Labour leader Keir Starmer will have a majority of 286 lawmakers when Labour will sweep into power.

British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak speaks during Prime Minister's Questions at the House of Commons in London, Britain, March 20, 2024. UK Parliament/Maria Unger/Handout via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. MANDATORY CREDIT. IMAGE MUST NOT BE ALTERED.

site_title: US regional banks dramatically step up loans to oil, gas and coal
summary: US regional banks are increasing lending to oil, gas, and coal clients, gaining market share from European rivals that are pulling back due to stricter climate regulations. Since 2022, the combined number of fossil-fuel loans provided by these banks has risen over 70% on an average annualized basis. This shift challenges assumptions around divestment policies and highlights the continued access to credit for fossil-fuel companies. The move also suggests that smaller banks and private credit managers are filling the gap left by larger banks.

images.alt_text: The region has a complicated history with nuclear power, and there are reasons for both optimism and caution.
Smoke from a chimney in Harbin, China.
