site_title: Blackstone leads US$2 billion private loan for data centre firm
summary: Blackstone led a $2 billion financing package for Park Place Technologies, refinancing the company's debt and funding a payout to private equity owners GTCR and Charlesbank Capital Partners. The deal includes a $1.7 billion loan, a revolving credit facility, and a delayed-draw term loan. This marks a win for private credit firms against Wall Street lenders, who have convinced borrowers to swap loans for more affordable debt from banks. Park Place will use the proceeds to refinance a $845 million loan and pay a dividend to its owners.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index is the world’s worst-performing major equity gauge over the past 12 months.
India has become a key market for HSBC as it looks to expand its operations in Asia.
Apartment landlords are now the best-performing group among the Reit industry.
The Blackstone headquarters in New York, US, on Monday, Jan. 8, 2024. Blackstone Inc. released earnings figures on January 25. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg

site_title: I embarked on a PhD at 53; this is what I learned
summary: At 53, Dr. James Tan embarked on a PhD journey, overcoming doubts about his age and academic abilities. He chose this path after feeling unfulfilled in semi-retirement and seeking a sense of validation and self-satisfaction. The PhD journey was a humbling experience that challenged his mind and reactivated his learning muscles. Tan believes that age is not a barrier to learning and that finding the time, discipline, and enthusiasm to pursue a new journey is key.

site_title: Fintech giant Stripe says raised US$694 million in tender offer
summary: Stripe, a fintech giant, raised US$694.2 million in a tender offer, valuing the company at US$65 billion, a 30% increase from last year's valuation. The deal will provide liquidity to employees, who typically receive stock-based compensation. The tender offer is seen as a rare bright spot in a subdued venture capital market, where investors have been cautious due to high interest rates. The funds will be used to improve the company's finances before a potential initial public offering (IPO).

images.alt_text: There's a resurgence of interest in bitcoin of late, never mind that crypto’s effectiveness as a reliable payment system is unproven (beyond black market purchases or the funding of terrorists).
Several large firms could see big losses from their bets on Instacart, including Fidelity Investments and T Rowe Price, which put money into the startup near its highs.

site_title: The quiet magic of middle managers
summary: Middle managers are often overlooked as unsung heroes in modern society, but they play a crucial role in resolving tensions and keeping communities united. These leaders embody "ethical leadership," prioritizing people over process and fostering a moral ecology. Key features of this approach include knowing that moral formation is part of the job, creating a moral ecology, being hyperattentive, and preserving the moral lens. Ethical leaders also communicate a posture of joy, demonstrating warmth and generosity, and demonstrate humility, recognizing that their work is not heroic but a duty undertaken with sober enthusiasm.

images.alt_text: Putting careers on hold or giving them up altogether is a reality for some caregivers.

site_title: Biotech executive gets 7 years’ prison for false claims about rapid Covid-19 test
summary: A former biotech executive, Keith Berman, was sentenced to 7 years in prison for securities fraud. He falsely claimed to have invented a rapid Covid-19 test, GenViro, and issued 12 "false and misleading" news releases in March and April 2020, which led to a 1,500% increase in Decision Diagnostics' stock price. Berman's scheme defrauded people into investing in his company, causing significant financial losses.

images.alt_text: Lim Oon Kuin, better known as O.K. Lim arriving at State Courts on Apr 12, 2024.
Former FTX chief executive Sam Bankman-Fried convicted by a federal jury in New York in November 2023 on seven counts of fraud, embezzlement and criminal conspiracy.

Shohei Ohtani (right) of the Los Angeles Angels arrives with his translator Ippei Mizuhara (left) at Peoria Stadium on Feb 26, 2018 in Peoria, Arizona. Mizuhara was charged with bank fraud on April 11, 2024, for stealing more than US$16 million from Ohtani to pay gambling debts.

site_title: Iran warns Israel against reprisals, world powers urge restraint
summary: Iran has warned Israel against retaliation for a recent drone and missile attack on Israeli territory, threatening a larger response if Israel retaliates. The attack, which killed top Revolutionary Guards commanders, was sparked by a suspected Israeli strike on Iran's consulate in Syria. Israel has vowed to retaliate, with its Minister Benny Gantz saying it will build a regional coalition to exact revenge. Global powers, including the US, Russia, China, and Arab states, have urged restraint, with the US saying it does not seek a war with Iran but will protect its forces and Israel.

images.alt_text: Some market watchers say investors have been much too complacent about geopolitical issues.
Iran says its latest attack follows an offensive on its diplomatic premises in Damascus on Apr 1.
The diversion comes as Israel braces for a direct and unprecedented attack by Iran on government targets as soon as Saturday, according to people familiar with western intelligence assessments.
Iran warns the US "not to get dragged into Netanyahu’s trap".

site_title: Coachella heavy on indie rock nostalgia, Taylor Swift buzz
summary: Taylor Swift created buzz at Coachella by making a surprise appearance as a fan, dancing and singing along to Bleachers' performance with her boyfriend Travis Kelce. The 34-year-old billionaire's presence sparked speculation about her upcoming album, "The Tortured Poets Department," set to drop on Friday. Meanwhile, the festival's second day featured a reunion of No Doubt, Blur, and Sublime, with indie rock roots and nostalgia dominating the lineup.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift performing  in Sydney on Feb 23.
Taylor Swift, 34, also has a significant real estate portfolio, with homes in New York, Beverly Hills, Nashville and a coastal mansion in Rhode Island.

Hybe, based in Seoul, has been releasing more English songs for K-pop bands and promoting artists including Jung Kook in the United States.

Denim ensembles on display at Levi’s flagship store on Market Street in San Francisco, Feb. 1, 2024. Under a new chief executive, the brand known for jeans is aiming to be a full outfitter, working primarily through its own stores and e-commerce. (Marissa Leshnov/The New York Times)

site_title: India's TCS profits rise on AI, cloud contracts
summary: India's IT giant Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) reported a 2.3% increase in consolidated revenue to $7.36 billion in the March quarter, exceeding market expectations. Net income rose 8% to $1.5 billion, driven by growth in cloud computing and artificial intelligence projects. TCS attributed the results to "broad-based deal wins" and attributed growth in AI, cloud, enterprise solutions, and cyber security. The company's operating margin reached 26%, with CEO K. Krithivasan describing the results as "validating the robustness of our business model and execution excellence".

images.alt_text: Consolidated revenue rises to 605.83 billion rupees (S$9.7 billion) in the three months to Dec 31 from 582.29 billion rupees a year earlier, TCS says.

site_title: As ‘Sex and the City’ ages, some find the cosmo glass half-empty
summary: A new generation of viewers is discovering 'Sex and the City' on Netflix, but long-time fans remain devoted, finding the show relatable despite its outdated references. The show's impact on women's relationships and dating has endured, with many original fans still relating to the characters' experiences. Despite some character arcs aging poorly, the show's frank discussions of sex and gendered expectations have had a lasting influence on television and popular culture, inspiring shows like 'Girls' and 'Insecure.' The show's nostalgic appeal has also led to a resurgence in interest, with fans continuing to analyze and discuss the series on social media and in podcasts.

images.alt_text: “Fallout” starts streaming on Prime Video on Apr 11.
“We’re eager to focus 100 per cent of our attention on our most important priorities, growth and value creation for our shareholders and creative excellence,” Disney CEO Bob Iger says.

site_title: India’s Modi promises to create jobs, boost infrastructure if BJP wins third term
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi has promised to create jobs, boost infrastructure, and expand welfare programs if the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) wins a record-equalling third term in the general election, which begins on Friday. Modi's 10-year record includes strong economic growth, infrastructure projects, and welfare handouts, but surveys suggest unemployment, inflation, and rural distress remain major concerns. The BJP manifesto focuses on creating jobs in various sectors and addressing discontent over rising unemployment levels. Modi faces a challenge in addressing these issues, which are likely to be key voter concerns ahead of the elections.

images.alt_text: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi shakes hand with Tesla chief executive Elon Musk during their meeting in New York, US, June 20, 2023. Musk is expected to visit India this month.

Job applicants give a mock test for railway entrance exams at Platform coaching centre at Musallahpur Haat in Patna, the capital city of the eastern state of Bihar in India in 2022. Over half of India’s 1.4 billion people are aged under 30, according to government health figures.
Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is confident of victory in the upcoming parliamentary elections; many Indians are buying into the hope his party has raised.

site_title: World Bank chief pushes internal reforms at spring meetings
summary: World Bank President Ajay Banga is pushing internal reforms to speed up loan approvals, improve employee accountability, and attract private capital. The World Bank aims to triple its guarantee issuances to $20 billion by 2030 and has adjusted its loan-to-equity ratio to unlock $40 billion of lending capacity. Banga also plans to launch a new enterprise-wide platform for loan and insurance guarantees and reform its business planning processes to find savings. These reforms are part of the lender's expansion into climate change and global crises, requiring greater resources and lending capacity.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The World Bank logo is seen at the 2023 Spring Meetings of the World Bank Group and the International Monetary Fund in Washington, U.S., April 13, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz

site_title: Planning to combine business and leisure travel? You’re not alone
summary: As business travel resumes, companies are struggling to define the boundaries of their duty-of-care obligations when employees combine work and leisure trips, known as "bleisure" travel. With the rise of remote work, companies are trying to balance business objectives with employee well-being and legal considerations. Employers are unclear on when their liability ends, and employees may be responsible for their own expenses and emergencies, even if the trip started with business. Companies are developing policies to address the grey area, but it remains a challenge.

images.alt_text: As employees increasingly add leisure time to their business trips, companies are trying to figure out where their duty of care obligations begin and end. site_title: OpenAI’s Sam Altman declared billionaire by Forbes
summary: Sam Altman, CEO of OpenAI, has become a billionaire according to Forbes' annual list, ranking 2,692nd. His wealth primarily comes from investments in startups like Reddit and Stripe, with Stripe estimated to be worth $65 billion. Altman's rise to billionaire status comes after his company released ChatGPT in 2022, making him a prominent figure in the global AI frenzy.

images.alt_text: Adobe is requesting more than 100 short clips of people engaged in actions and showing emotions as well as simple anatomy shots of feet, hands or eyes.

site_title: Upgraded ties with France, Germany to benefit tech, sustainability, defence: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced upgrades in ties with France and Germany, marking a new phase in bilateral relationships. The upgrades include Strategic Partnerships with Germany and Comprehensive Strategic Partnerships with France, focusing on areas like artificial intelligence, sustainability, and defense. The France-Singapore Joint Year of Sustainability highlights cooperation in sustainable development and green financing. Wong emphasized the importance of engaging Europe in the era of great power politics, seeking to understand the EU's independent perspectives and views on various issues.

images.alt_text: Wong called on German Chancellor Olaf Scholz in Berlin on Tuesday evening.
Wong and Macron also launched a new year-long initiative to highlight cooperation in sustainable development.

site_title: Musk to meet Modi, spurring Tesla investment in India talk
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk is set to visit India and meet with Prime Minister Narendra Modi, sparking speculation about potential investments in the country. Musk may announce plans for a manufacturing facility, including a possible electric vehicle plant, and discuss his company's satellite business, Starlink. The visit comes ahead of India's national elections and aims to boost the government's claims of attracting global capital. Conditions for Starlink's satellite communications license may include data routing and information sharing restrictions.

site_title: Three key global macro drivers for the rest of 2024
summary: Singapore's economy has started 2024 on a firmer note, with GDP growing 2.7% year-on-year in the first quarter. This growth is broad-based, with all five industry sector aggregates expanding year-over-year. Key sectors include construction, information and communications, finance and insurance, and professional services. The growth follows a 1.1% growth in 2023 and 3.8% growth in 2022.

images.alt_text: pixgenerics/ST20231017_202316586050/Ng Sor Luan/Skyline of Singapore's Business District taken from Marina Bay Sands on Oct 17, 2023. For stories on sustainability, garden city, air quality and more.

site_title: Apple loses bid to throw out UK lawsuit over App Store fees
summary: A UK judge rejected Apple's bid to dismiss a nearly $1 billion lawsuit alleging the company charged unfair commission fees to 1,500 UK-based developers on purchases of apps and content. The lawsuit, led by competition law professor Sean Ennis, claims Apple abused its dominant market position by charging up to 30% commission. The decision allows the case to proceed, with Apple facing pressure from regulators in the US and Europe over its App Store fees.

images.alt_text: Under Apple’s proposal, the Swedish music streaming service Spotify and others can include a link to their websites to inform users of other ways to purchase digital goods or services, away from Apple’s App Store.
The iPhone maker is fined 1.84 billion euros (S$2.69 billion) by the EU for thwarting competition from music streaming rivals via restrictions on its App Store.
Apple temporarily resumes sales of the watches the next day after persuading the Federal Circuit to pause the ban.

site_title: US consumer sentiment slips in April; inflation expectations rise
summary: US consumer sentiment decreased to 77.9 in April, down from a final reading of 79.4 in March, according to the University of Michigan's survey. One-year inflation expectations rose to 3.1% from 2.9% in March, indicating increased concerns about inflation. This marks the third consecutive month of declining sentiment, which has remained within a narrow 2.5-point range since January. Economists had forecast a preliminary reading of 79.

site_title: Star-studded England, France on course to dominate Euro 2024
summary: The 2024 European Championship is just nine weeks away, with England, France, and host nation Germany among the top contenders. England, with a talented young squad, is joint favourite to win, while France seeks redemption after their 2022 World Cup loss. Germany aims to overcome their recent poor performances, and Spain, despite a tough group, has a strong team with new manager Luis de la Fuente. The tournament will kick off on June 15 with Germany vs. Scotland, and the final will be held on July 15 at Berlin's Olympiastadion.

images.alt_text: Premier League clubs will likely be limited to spending 85 per cent of their revenue on transfers, wages and agents fees.
Nike aims to sell more entry-level running shoes, which tend to run between US$100 and US$150 a pair.
Each individual Olympic champion will receive US$50,000 and relay teams will receive the same amount, to be shared among the team members.
Heineken, Carlsberg and Budweiser maker Anheuser-Busch InBev are among the beer companies that will benefit if good weather coincides with the Euro 2024 football tournament in June and July.

site_title: Georgieva selected for second term as IMF managing director
summary: The International Monetary Fund's executive board confirmed Kristalina Georgieva for a second five-year term as managing director, starting on October 1, 2024. Georgieva, a Bulgarian economist, was the only candidate for the job and has been endorsed by European Union finance ministers. She will be the second woman to head the IMF and the first person from an emerging market economy.

IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva says that global

IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva says China’s investment-led economic growth model might have worked in the past but could not be sustained in future.

site_title: Boustead Singapore looks ahead following re-merger with Boustead Projects
summary: Boustead Singapore has completed the re-merger with its subsidiary Boustead Projects, following a voluntary unconditional offer to acquire all shares at a final price of S$1.18 per share. The initial offer price was S$0.90, but was later bumped up due to investor concerns that the discount to asset value was too large. Despite initial market resistance, the re-merger was completed, and the company's shares are now listed under a single entity. The move aims to simplify operations and improve liquidity. Boustead Singapore's key businesses include energy engineering, geospatial technology, real estate, and healthcare.

images.alt_text: Wong Fong Fui, chairman and group chief executive officer of Boustead Singapore.

site_title: The worst part of a Wall Street career may be coming to an end
summary: Artificial intelligence is replacing much of Wall Street's entry-level white-collar work, raising concerns about the future of finance. AI tools can automate tasks such as assembling PowerPoint presentations, crunching numbers, and fine-tuning financial documents. Investment banks, accustomed to cultural change, are rapidly adapting to the new technology, which could supplement or supplant entire ranks of workers. This shift raises questions about the impact on the industry and the workforce, with potential consequences for job security and career prospects.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers exit the Citi Headquarters in New York, U.S., January 22, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Blame game continues as 62-day trial involving Hin Leong founder O.K. Lim wraps up
summary: A 62-day trial of Hin Leong founder Lim Oon Kuin has concluded, with Deputy Chief Prosecutor Christopher Ong stating that Lim instructed employees to make fraudulent discounting applications to HSBC, inducing the bank to disburse US$111.6 million. Lim faces 130 charges involving US$2.7 billion in alleged fraudulent loans. Prosecutors argue that Lim's former personal assistant Serene Seng also played a role in the transactions. Lim's lawyers dispute the prosecution's claims, saying Lim had nothing to do with the transactions. The verdict will be delivered on May 10.

images.alt_text: In April last year, Hin Leong former employee Serene Seng admitted in court that she had lied to the CAD on some instances in a bid to protect her children.

Liquidators are alleging in the civil suit that Hin Leong concealed losses of more than US$800 million over the past few years through the creation of fictitious gains, forgery of documents, improper accounting entries and the overstatement of its inventory.

Seng was one of the witnesses called to take the stand by the prosecution in the criminal trial where PwC liquidators and top creditor HSBC are suing Lim, his two children and Seng for a total of US$3.5 billion.

site_title: Less than half of US banks ready to borrow from Federal Reserve in emergency
summary: US banks have made progress in establishing borrowing capacity from the Federal Reserve's discount window, but less than half have done so. As of end-2023, 1,996 banks had pledged collateral, but only 3,900 had signed up. The total value of collateral pledged by banks rose to $2.63 trillion, while credit unions increased their pledged collateral to $130 billion. However, regulators still urge banks to have ready access to the discount window, citing the need to address preparedness following the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank last year.

JPMorgan Chase’s profit was US$13.42 billion, or US$4.44 per share, for the three months ended Mar 31.
State lenders including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China are telling the officers they won’t be held responsible if property loans eventually turn non-performing.

site_title: Too busy for politics? South Korea’s young voters on what motivates them
summary: South Korea's young voters, who make up a minority of the electorate, were motivated by high youth unemployment, a cost of living crisis, and feuding politicians. At the recent election, younger voters were outnumbered by those over 60, with visible older voters casting ballots in Seoul. The lack of job opportunities and dissatisfaction with politics were key concerns, with some voting for the first time. The election cycle saw a significant disparity in voter demographics, with the younger generation facing significant challenges in their daily lives.

images.alt_text: The won has been one of Asia’s worst performers this year, slipping by 5.9 per cent.
South Korea’s President Yoon Suk Yeol is facing growing criticism for sticking to a hardline stance on a number of hot-button issues and scandals in the run-up to Wednesday’s elections.
Lee Jae-myung has won a seat in the city of Incheon to the west of the capital, Seoul.

site_title: Mapletree Investments acquires 8,192 student housing beds in UK, Germany for £1 billion
summary: Mapletree Investments has acquired 8,192 student housing beds in the UK and Germany for £1 billion, increasing its overall portfolio to 33,000 beds across 47 cities. The acquisition positions Mapletree as one of the largest owners of student housing in the UK, with over 17,000 beds. The deal is part of Mapletree's strategy to grow the student accommodation sector in the UK and Europe, driven by a fundamental demand-supply imbalance and defensive characteristics.

HarbourFront Centre was known as World Trade Centre before it was revamped two decades ago.

site_title: Absolutely no urgency to cut US interest rates: Federal Reserve’s Daly
summary: US Federal Reserve President Mary Daly stated there is "absolutely" no urgency to cut interest rates, citing a strong labor market and inflation falling more slowly than expected. She emphasized the need to maintain the current policy stance "as long as necessary" to bring down inflation to the Fed's 2% goal, before considering a rate cut. Daly also noted that the Fed's commitment to restoring price stability remains unchanged, despite recent inflation data.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Federal Reserve Building stands in Washington April 3, 2012. REUTERS/Joshua Roberts/File Photo

site_title: Biden hails work to reduce racial wealth gap as he seeks voter support
summary: US President Joe Biden hailed his administration's efforts to close the racial wealth gap, saying Black wealth has increased by 60% and the gap has narrowed the most in 20 years. However, new data shows the gap is still present, with a 40% cut in home appraisal disparities after the Federal Housing Finance Agency cracked down on appraisal bias. Biden's efforts to shore up support among Black voters ahead of his November rematch with Donald Trump are underway, despite recent data showing the wealth gap is not closing as quickly as hoped.

site_title: Ninth floor of Solitaire on Cecil sold to China buyer for S$51.48 million
summary: The ninth floor of Solitaire on Cecil in Singapore has been sold to Long Twinkle Trading for S$51.48 million, or S$4,130 per square foot. The office floor is part of the 127-metre-high development, which features about 190,000 sq ft of office space and two strata restaurant units. The buyer is a Singapore-incorporated company wholly owned by Shanghai Langning Trading Co, a metal company. The sale is part of a previous attempt to sell three floors, which were put back on the market after initial buyers were linked to a police probe into a S$3 billion money laundering case.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of Solitaire On Cecil.

site_title: US dollar jumps on central bank divergence, euro hits five-month low
summary: The US dollar surged 0.75% to a 106.09 high, its highest since November 3, due to the European Central Bank's potential rate cut, diverging from market expectations for the US Federal Reserve to keep rates higher. This led to a five-month low for the euro and a 34-year low for the Japanese yen as investors sought signs of central bank intervention. The dollar's strength was attributed to recent US economic data showing a dialing back of market expectations for a rate cut from the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: The greenback slid below 153 yen after the data and was last at 152.92, down 0.2 per cent.
The yen has been under pressure for years as US interest rates have climbed and Japan's have stayed near zero.

site_title: Oil settles up on Middle East tensions, posts weekly loss
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Friday due to geopolitical tensions in the Middle East, with Brent crude futures up 71 cents at $90.45 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures up 64 cents at $85.66. However, the weekly loss was attributed to a bearish world oil demand growth forecast from the International Energy Agency and worries about slower US interest rate cuts. Oil prices neared a six-month high amid concerns about a potential Iranian retaliation for a suspected Israeli warplane attack on Iran's embassy in Damascus.

site_title: Huawei teases launch of new smartphone, high-end model anticipated
summary: Huawei has started allowing customers to register interest in its upcoming high-end P70 smartphone, sparking anticipation for the latest version of its premium P series phones. The P70 is expected to feature an advanced China-made chip, similar to the Mate 60, and will likely contain advanced cameras and a sleek design. Huawei's decision to launch without prior advertising or disclosure of specifications has generated excitement and mystery, with analysts noting that the move helps the company maintain a lower profile amid US-Sino trade tensions.

Last year marks the third consecutive year of growth for Huawei, after revenue plummeted by almost a third in 2021.

site_title: Race for AI supremacy in Middle East is measured in data centres
summary: The Gulf region, particularly the UAE and Saudi Arabia, are racing to build data centers to support artificial intelligence (AI) development, with both countries aiming to become regional AI superpowers. The UAE has already built 52 data centers, while Saudi Arabia has 60, with plans to expand capacity. The economic stakes are high, with AI expected to contribute $96 billion to the UAE's economy and $135 billion to Saudi Arabia's by 2030. However, the region faces challenges, including ensuring the heat-producing computing facilities can operate effectively in the desert and attracting skilled technicians.

site_title: Qantas diverts Australia-London flight to avoid Iran airspace
summary: Qantas has diverted its direct Perth-London flight to avoid Iran's airspace amid fears of an imminent Iranian attack on Israel. The QF9 flight will fly via Singapore for a fuel stop, while the QF10 return flight remains unaffected. The carrier will inform affected flyers directly if there are any changes to their bookings. The move comes as Israel prepares for a potential attack, which could trigger a regional war and has prompted the US to prepare defenses and intensify diplomatic efforts.

site_title: Landmark Trump hush money criminal trial starts in New York on Monday
summary: US ex-President Donald Trump is set to go on trial in New York for allegedly falsifying business records in a scheme to cover up a sexual encounter with Stormy Daniels in 2016. Trump, accused of illegally paying Daniels to keep quiet, denies the charges and could use the trial as a platform to decry "lawfare" and election interference. The trial, which could last up to two months, is one of four criminal cases hanging over Trump and could potentially result in a conviction and jail time.

site_title: The hidden costs of ‘slowbalisation’
summary: Countries that engage in discriminatory trade practices, such as the US and China, ultimately bear the costs, while other nations benefit. Despite the war in Ukraine and supply chain disruptions, global trade reached a record high in 2022, driven by "slowbalisation" - the slowing down of globalization due to trade barriers and sanctions. Tariffs and trade restrictions have boosted trade volumes, but at the expense of higher production and logistics costs, and reduced welfare. The EU is likely to recognize the adverse effects of trade barriers first, while the US and China must change course to prevent losing the most in their trade wars.

site_title: US import prices post third straight monthly gain in March
summary: US import prices rose 0.4% in March, marking a third straight monthly gain, driven by increases in energy products and food costs. This rebounded from a 0.9% decline in February. Import prices excluding tariffs rose 0.1% in February, while core import prices fell 0.4% year-over-year in March. The increases were attributed to firmer-than-expected consumer price inflation data and the US central bank's continued interest rate hikes.

site_title: US: Stocks fall sharply on geopolitical worries
summary: US stocks fell sharply on Friday due to geopolitical worries, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 1.2% and the S&P 500 falling 1.5%. The decline came amid concerns over a potential escalation of conflict in the Middle East, particularly between Iran and Israel. The Nasdaq Composite Index also fell 1.6%. Large financial companies like JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup reported declines, with CEOs citing geopolitical and inflationary risks.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after mixed big bank earnings
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday, April 12, 2024, as megacap growth stocks and chipmakers declined, while some big banks fell after reporting dour quarterly results. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 139.94 points, or 0.36%, to 38,319.14, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell.

site_title: Actively managed credit strategies can meet impact goals, alpha targets
summary: A study by Desislava Vladimirova and Jieyan Fang-Klingler found that sustainability-oriented investors can meet their goals with corporate debt strategies, while profit-oriented factor investors can achieve a portfolio with a certain sustainability level at a low cost. The study reveals a concave relationship between outperformance and sustainability, and a non-linear relationship between sustainability and factor investing. This means that investors can balance returns and sustainability targets without sacrificing performance, and that there is an optimal solution for investors with different green preferences.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 flat on rising Middle East tensions, energy stocks spike
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 ended the session 0.1% higher, logging its second straight weekly decline, amid rising Middle East tensions. The market initially rose 1.2% but reversed as concerns over European Central Bank rate cuts diminished. Benchmark indexes in Germany and France closed in the red, while Italy and Spain's markets closed near their highs. Energy stocks surged, offsetting losses in mining and healthcare sectors.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 1.2 per cent, or 475 points, lower at 37,983.24 on Friday.

site_title: China wages snap three-quarter slide, signalling upturn in labour
summary: China's labour market shows signs of improvement, with average monthly salaries offered to new hires rising 2.2% to 10,323 yuan (S$1,941) in 38 key cities, the first increase since 2023. Employment conditions also improved in Shanghai, according to a survey. This suggests a potential boost to consumer spending, a key driver of China's economy, which has been weakened by a weak job market. However, China's economic data remains mixed, with rapid industrial output growth and weak inflation. The country's central bank is expected to make efforts to expand demand and boost confidence.

site_title: Citi profit drops as costs rise for employee severance, deposit insurance
summary: Citi's net income fell to US$3.4 billion, or US$1.58 per share, in the first quarter due to increased costs from employee severance payments and deposit insurance fund replenishment. The bank's revenue fell 2% to US$21.1 billion, with performance in its services and banking divisions standing out. Despite a 7% decline in trading revenue, Citi's consumer banking division grew revenue, and the bank's stock rose 1% before the bell, up 18% this year.

site_title: Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan to visit the Philippines from Apr 15 to 18
summary: Singapore's Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan will visit the Philippines from April 15 to 18, marking the 55th anniversary of diplomatic ties. During the four-day trip, he will meet with Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, Vice-President Sara Duterte, and other officials. He will also engage with the business community and visit New Clark City, SIA Engineering, and Clark International Airport. This visit aims to strengthen economic ties and promote cooperation between the two countries.

images.alt_text: Philippine Ambassador to Singapore, Medardo G Macaraig, believes more opportunities will arise for Singapore investors in sectors they are already familiar with.

site_title: Thailand's Central buys German luxury retail property KaDeWe
summary: Thailand's Central Group has acquired the KaDeWe luxury retail property in Berlin from insolvent Austrian company Signa, as part of its efforts to acquire the entire KaDeWe Group. Central, which already holds a 50.1% majority stake, is optimistic about completing the deal. The acquisition is seen as another step towards Central's goal of buying the entire KaDeWe Group, which also includes Alsterhaus in Hamburg and Oberpollinger in Munich.

images.alt_text: Central Group wants to lift its stake in Selfridges to 60 per cent and take control of the operating business.

site_title: India’s industrial output grows at fastest rate in four months in February
summary: India's industrial output grew 5.7% year-over-year in February, the fastest annual rate in four months, according to government data. Manufacturing output rose 5%, while electricity generation increased 7.5%. Mining activity expanded by 8%, and infrastructure goods production grew 8.5%. Consumer durables, such as automobiles, saw a 12.3% rise, while consumer non-durables contracted 3.8%. The first 11 months of the fiscal year saw a 5.9% rise in industrial output, in line with expectations.

site_title: Lionsgate Studio raises PIPE amount to US$225 million ahead of closing SPAC deal
summary: Lionsgate Studio has increased its private investment in public equity (PIPE) amount to US$225 million ahead of its merger with Screaming Eagle Acquisition, a special purpose-acquisition company (SPAC). The deal, initially expected to raise US$175 million, signals strong investor confidence and improved liquidity. The merger is valued at about US$4.6 billion, including debt, and includes about 18,000 film and television titles. The amount of proceeds expected to be delivered to Lionsgate has also been upsized to between US$350 million and US$409.5 million.

site_title: Notre-Dame nears re-opening five years after fire
summary: Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris is nearing completion of its five-year restoration five years after a devastating fire in 2019. The fire damaged the cathedral's roof, spire, and main bell towers, but the facade held. Restoration works, funded by donations, including from luxury sector billionaires, have been intense and on schedule, with a re-opening scheduled for December. The project has cost 550 million euros and will have funds left over for further investment. The restoration aims to lift the nation's mood and improve the government's approval ratings, with the Olympic Games set to take place in Paris.

images.alt_text: epa11017366 Scaffolding inside the nave of the Notre-Dame de Paris Cathedral, as restoration works continue in Paris, France, 08 December 2023. French President Emmanuel Macron is visiting Notre Dame Cathedral on 08 December, to mark the one-year countdown to its reopening in 2024 following extensive restoration after the fire four years ago. Macron's visit, continuing his annual tradition since the blaze on 15 April 2019, is aimed to highlight the progress in the works, including the near completion of the cathedral spire. site_title: CVC Capital Partners exits Vietnam’s Asia Commercial Bank: sources
summary: CVC Capital Partners has exited its investment in Vietnam's fourth-largest private commercial lender, Asia Commercial Bank (ACB), by selling its remaining 4.99% stake for approximately $220 million. The sale was made through a unit called Sather Gate, with a US-based institutional investor being the buyer. This exit follows a similar stake sale by another CVC investment vehicle, Whistler Investment, in early April. The sale is seen as part of the growing investor interest in Vietnam, which aims to enter emerging market indexes or upgrade its status by 2025.

site_title: Singapore’s Q1 growth disappoints, but economists more optimistic about full-year figures
summary: Singapore's economy grew 2.7% year-on-year in Q1 2024, surpassing expectations but slower than the previous quarter. The better performance was attributed to "favourable base effects." Economists, however, remain optimistic about full-year growth, with some revising their forecasts upwards, despite a slowdown in manufacturing and a marginal 0.1% quarterly growth rate. Full-year forecasts now range from 1 to 3% and are expected to be supported by a gradual improvement in external-led sectors and stronger financial sector performance.

images.alt_text: The central bank last adjusted its monetary policy stance in 2022.

site_title: JPMorgan profit beats estimates even as interest income misses predictions
summary: JPMorgan Chase's profit for the first quarter beat estimates, reaching $13.42 billion or $4.44 per share. However, the bank's forecast for interest income fell short of analyst expectations, causing shares to drop. High borrowing costs have boosted net interest income, but banks are preparing for potential interest rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve later this year.

site_title: Visiting Chinese trade official warns EU on greentech probe
summary: Chinese Commerce Minister Wang Wentao warned the EU against protectionism on Friday, stating that Brussels' probes into green tech exports threaten China's domestic solar panel, wind turbine, and electric vehicle industries. Wang expressed puzzlement at the EU's actions, saying they generate more risks and contradict the bloc's commitment to sustainable development. The EU's investigation into China's electric vehicle industry is expected to conclude by June 5, with possible provisional duties to be imposed. Wang urged the EU to oppose unilateralism and protect the global supply chain.

Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore and Wellington stocks were all in the red, while Tokyo, Taipei and Manila edged up on Friday.
Elsewhere in the region, new share sales set to raise several hundred million US dollars are surfacing.

site_title: Harmonised standards can affect Asean’s potential as supplier of carbon credits: GenZero
summary: A single, global harmonised set of standards for carbon markets could limit South-east Asia's potential to be a large supplier of carbon credits due to the region's reliance on nature-based solutions, which have higher uncertainties in quantifying carbon and permanence. Three possible scenarios for carbon markets are: a collaborative, climate-centric world where technology-based solutions dominate; a bifurcated market with the western and eastern blocs focusing on different approaches; or a fragmented market with bilateral agreements between countries. To address these challenges, GenZero recommends greater regulatory oversight, clearer demand signals, and a balanced approach to quality climate solutions.

site_title: China banks won’t blame staff if developer loans go bad
summary: Chinese state banks, including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, are assuring their staff that they won't be held responsible if property loans become non-performing. This move aims to encourage credit officers to approve loans for developers as the government tries to prop up the embattled real estate market. However, lenders remain cautious about a potential build-up of non-performing loans, which has been rising, and the move may not lead to a significant increase in lending. China's commercial banks have seen declining profits and narrowing margins amid the crisis.

site_title: Wells Fargo profit shrinks more than 7% on lower interest income
summary: Wells Fargo's net income declined 7% to $4.62 billion in the first quarter, driven by lower interest income. The bank's net interest income fell 8% to $12.23 billion, amid rising US interest rates. Shares dropped 3% in premarket trading. CEO Charlie Scharf attributed the decline to the changing interest rate outlook and ongoing regulatory issues, with the bank still operating under a $1.95 trillion asset cap.

site_title: China tells telecom firms to phase out foreign chips in blow to Intel, AMD
summary: China has introduced guidelines for state-owned telecom carriers to phase out foreign chips from Intel and AMD from government personal computers and servers by 2027. This move is part of Beijing's efforts to replace Western technology with domestic alternatives amid Sino-US trade tensions. China's largest telecom carriers are expected to replace foreign semiconductors with domestic options, which have shown improved quality and stability. The move is seen as a blow to US chip giants Intel and AMD, which were previously China's largest market.

images.alt_text: Commerce Department says the companies are “involved with providing AI chips to China’s military modernisation programmes” and military intelligence users.

site_title: 2024 Lexus LBX review: Little but luxe
summary: The 2024 Lexus LBX is a compact and agile luxury crossover designed for self-indulgence, despite being the cheapest Lexus option. Priced from S$228,800, it features a hybrid drivetrain, luxurious interior, and advanced technology. The car's interior is dominated by a responsive touchscreen and a high-resolution 12.3-inch screen, while its exterior is sporty and precise. However, the LBX is slow and has limited rear space, making it less practical for some users. Its fuel efficiency is impressive, with an official rating of 5.1 L/100 km.

site_title: India’s Tamil Nadu state to pull out all stops to attract Musk
summary: India's Tamil Nadu state is aggressively pitching itself to attract Tesla's investments ahead of Elon Musk's visit, aiming to establish the state as the country's EV capital. The state has the "best electric vehicle policies and ecosystem," according to Minister TRB Rajaa. Tesla's visit comes as the company weighs setting up an EV plant in India, which is seen as a potential new growth driver for the company. India has cut import duty on EVs and offers tax concessions to foreign companies investing at least $500 million, with a goal of producing EVs from local plants within three years.

This improvement suggests the banks are taking steps to mitigate their environmental impact. The findings highlight the need for more nuanced approaches to evaluating the environmental sustainability of financial investments.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 12)
summary: Singapore's services sector experienced a 3.2% growth rate in the latest quarter, up from 2% in the previous quarter, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. The country's overall economy grew 2.7% year-over-year in the first quarter of 2024, with a 0.1% sequential improvement.

site_title: 🏠 Should I apply for a BTO before I graduate?
summary: The Singapore government has introduced a policy change allowing young couples who are schooling or serving national service to apply for a Build-To-Order (BTO) flat with a reduced initial down payment of 2.5% of the flat's purchase price, down from 5%. This aims to encourage couples to settle down earlier. However, critics argue that this may encourage couples who are not ready for marriage to apply for a BTO, and that students should not commit to financing a home without stable employment.

site_title: Clobbered Fed rate cut bets wipe out even last year’s bond gains
summary: Investors have seen a significant decline in global sovereign debt since January, wiping out last year's 4.2% gains, as expectations of higher US interest rates have shifted. The Bloomberg gauge for government debt has fallen 4.7% due to investors anticipating under two Fed interest rate cuts this year. The selloff in bonds has been driven by a hot inflation print and the Bank of Japan's interest rate hike, with yields on 10-year US Treasuries currently at 4.57%. Some analysts predict further declines in bond markets until the Fed eases interest rates.

site_title: China strengthens stock market trading, listing regulations
summary: China's securities regulator has issued draft rules to strengthen regulations on company listings, delistings, and quant trading, aiming to improve the stock market and protect investor interests. The rules include moderately increasing requirements for operating income and net profit, expanding on-site inspections, and implementing stricter regulatory requirements for high-frequency trading. The move follows China's stock market falling to five-year lows in February and aims to revive investor confidence. The regulations will also include both domestic and foreign capital in the transaction reporting system and subject them to the same monitoring standards.

site_title: Historic BOJ move drives up short-term costs for Japanese firms
summary: The Bank of Japan's historic move to end ultra-accommodative policy has driven up short-term borrowing costs for Japanese firms. Companies are paying higher premiums to raise money from shorter-term notes, as investors seek higher yields now that the central bank's corporate bond purchase programme is set to end within a year. This marks a significant shift in Japanese markets after years of easy money, with investors adapting to the new policy. The BOJ's reduction in purchases has led to wider spreads on corporate bonds, contrasting with tightening spreads on municipal bonds.

images.alt_text: Of the households surveyed by the Bank of Japan, 83.3 per cent said they expected prices to rise a year from now, up from 79.3 per cent in the previous survey conducted three months ago.

site_title: Chinese airlines slump on US move to curb flight frequencies
summary: US airlines have asked the Biden administration to block the approval of new flights between the US and China, citing "damaging anti-competitive policies" by Beijing. Chinese airlines, including Air China, China Eastern, and China Southern, have responded with a significant decline in shares. The US and China currently have around 340 flights per week, a quarter of the pre-pandemic levels. China's aviation regulator has pushed for a significant increase in direct flights between the two countries, and some analysts argue that blocking further flights would be reciprocated.

images.alt_text: China Southern’s international route network has to date recovered to 80 per cent of 2019 levels.

site_title: China property crisis deepens with Vanke in market crosshairs
summary: China Vanke, a state-backed property developer, is facing intensifying concerns over its ability to stave off default, despite efforts by authorities to shore up its finances. The company's stocks and bonds tumbled after S&P Global Ratings cut it to junk territory, the third major ratings company to do so. This move highlights the struggle officials face in restoring investor confidence in the industry, which is affected by plunging sales, falling property prices, and soaring debt costs. Vanke, once considered one of China's most creditworthy property giants, is now under market crosshairs.

images.alt_text: A China Vanke development in Hefei, China. Source: Bloomberg
Vanke’s Shenzhen-listed stock closed down 1.8 per cent at 7.4 yuan after dropping in early trade to 7.31 yuan – the lowest since May 2014.
Contracted sales for March were 24.5 billion yuan (S$4.6 billion), Vanke says. That represents a 43 per cent decline from a year earlier.
There have been other signs of concerns among financial institutions, with the property firm’s credit ratings cut to junk level by Fitch Ratings and Moody’s last month.

Investors have been dumping Vanke’s shares and bonds in the past few weeks on cash flow concerns, triggering a rare central government directive to help the Shenzhen-based company beat a liquidity crisis.

site_title: Singtel, Viettel to develop Singapore-Vietnam submarine cable system
summary: Singtel and Viettel have signed a memorandum of understanding to develop the Vietnam-Singapore Cable System, a submarine cable connecting the two countries. The system, scheduled for Q2 2027, will use advanced wavelength division multiplexing technology and feature eight fibre pairs. It will be the shortest cable directly connecting both countries, providing a direct link between Vietnam and Singapore.

images.alt_text: Singtel intends to move its customers to its first new artificial intelligence data centre in Tuas.
Singtel's latest consortium project is to build a 6,000km undersea fibre optic cable system worth US$300 million connecting Singapore and Hong Kong to Brunei, the Philippines, and Hainan, China.
Singtel to redevelop its Comcentre HQ for more than S$2b
Singtel in consortium for Singapore-France submarine cable system to be ready by 2025

site_title: Europe's top firms see timid, patchy recovery, ECB survey shows
summary: The European Central Bank's survey of 57 leading companies reveals a timid and patchy recovery in the eurozone economy, driven by increased spending but hindered by lacklustre investment and labor demand. Companies expect modest growth of 0.5% this year, with some sectors, such as consumer goods and electronics, showing signs of improvement. However, retailers remain downbeat, and investments remain weak, with firms citing declining demand and cost containment. The overall outlook remains cautious, with a weak employment outlook and limited recruitment needs.

images.alt_text: epa11204097 An exterior view of the European Central Bank (ECB) building before a press conference following the meeting of the ECB Governing Council in Frankfurt am Mainn, Germany, 07 March 2024.  EPA-EFE/CHRISTOPHER NEUNDORF

site_title: IMF sees growth edging higher but still warns of ‘Tepid Twenties’
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has revised its global growth forecasts, predicting a "marginally stronger" 3.2% expansion this year, up from 3.1% in January. Managing director Kristalina Georgieva warns that the world economy risks a "Tepid Twenties" if inflation and debt challenges aren't addressed. Georgieva calls for policymakers to avoid premature monetary easing, urging countries to reduce debt and boost productivity growth through green and digital transformation.

images.alt_text: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva says China’s investment-led economic growth model might have worked in the past but could not be sustained in future.

epa11147146 Managing Director of International Monetary Fund (IMF) Kristalina Georgieva attends a session at the World Governments Summit in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, 12 February 2024. The World Governments Summit Organization is an international, impartial, nonprofit group whose goal is to influence how governments operate in the future. The summit is held in Dubai between 12-14 February.  EPA-EFE/STRINGER
The IMF in January warned that overall growth in the global economy and trade remained well below the historical average.

site_title: Vietnam to increase gold bar supplies to stablise market
summary: Vietnam's central bank, the State Bank of Vietnam (SBV), plans to increase gold bar supplies to stabilize the domestic market, which has seen prices surge to US$3,401.36 per tael, significantly higher than the global market price of US$2,388. The decision comes after Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh ordered the SBV to act immediately to reduce the price gap, citing concerns over market sentiment and potential cross-border smuggling. The move aims to address the imbalance between supply and demand, a cause identified by adviser Can Van Luc.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.6 per cent at US$2,386.38 per ounce, as of 0111 GMT. Bullion hit a record high of 2,389.29 earlier in the session.

site_title: BlackRock hits record assets of US$10.5 trillion with bond inflows
summary: BlackRock has reached a record US$10.5 trillion in client assets, driven by US$76 billion in net inflows in the first quarter, including US$67 billion to ETFs and US$42 billion to fixed-income funds. Despite missing analysts' average estimate, CEO Larry Fink cited strong growth potential in infrastructure, technology, and retirement solutions. This growth comes as investors seek to move out of cash and into longer-term investments amid persistent inflation.

images.alt_text: The BlackRock USD Institutional Digital Liquidity Fund invests in cash, US Treasury bills and repurchase agreements.
Tokenisation is a method of purchasing securities in the form of digital assets using blockchains.
Abaxx has been working for about five years to set up the technology and obtain regulatory approvals to run a futures exchange and clearinghouse.

site_title: SGX derivatives volume up in March on record commodity, forex activity
summary: SGX derivatives volume rose 10% month-over-month and 12% year-over-year to 24 million contracts in March 2024, driven by record commodity and forex trading activity. Commodity derivatives traded 32% higher than the prior month, reaching a record 6.4 million contracts. Forex futures volume also hit a record 4.3 million contracts, with SGX USD/CNH futures leading the gains. This brought total Q1 volume to 70.4 million contracts, a 12% increase over the same period last year.

images.alt_text: CMG20240327-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.受限股票（restricted stock unit）

site_title: Vietnam tycoon’s death sentence: Key takeaways from 300t dong fraud case
summary: Vietnamese property tycoon Truong My Lan has been sentenced to death for masterminding the largest fraud case in Vietnam's history, embezzling 304 trillion dong (S$16.7 billion) from private lender Saigon Joint Stock Commercial Bank. Lan, 67, was found guilty of bribery, violations of banking regulations, and embezzlement. The case, part of Vietnam's "Blazing Furnace" graft crackdown, also implicated hundreds of senior officials and business figures. Lan's assets, including properties, yachts, and luxury cars, have been seized, and she has pledged to compensate the bank with her family's assets.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's property tycoon Truong My Lan (C) arrives at a court in Ho Chi Minh city on March 5, 2024. A top Vietnamese property tycoon went on trial on March 5, 2024 along with dozens of others, accused of embezzling $12.5 billion in the country's biggest ever fraud case. (Photo by AFP)

site_title: Singapore stocks end week in red; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to close at 3,216.91 on Friday, ending a shortened trading week. Despite a mid-week public holiday, the market was affected by a US inflation report showing consumer prices rose 0.4% in March. The Singapore Central Bank left its monetary policy unchanged for the month. Regional bourses also declined, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index falling 2.2% and South Korea's Kospi dipping 0.9%.

images.alt_text: The higher March and Q1 2024 derivatives volume is attributed to record trading in commodity and forex derivatives.
Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore and Wellington stocks were all in the red, while Tokyo, Taipei and Manila edged up on Friday.
Spot gold was up 0.6 per cent at US$2,386.38 per ounce, as of 0111 GMT. Bullion hit a record high of 2,389.29 earlier in the session.

A bigger question is whether Ben Bernanke, who was head of the Fed from 2006 to 2014, will recommend that the BoE move closer to the US central bank’s ‘dot plot’ where each rate-setter anonymously publishes their own forecasts for interest rates, growth and inflation.
On a seasonally adjusted quarterly basis, Singapore's gross domestic product rose by a marginal 0.1 per cent in the first quarter of 2024.

Tom Barkin is one of the 12 members of the Fed’s rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) with a vote on setting US interest rates this year, and his words are closely scrutinised by traders looking to predict the direction of travel of US monetary policy.
The Stoxx 600 closed 0.4 per cent lower in volatile trade, with the banking sector taking the biggest hit, falling 2.4 per cent and notching its steepest one-day drop in over eight months.
The central bank last adjusted its monetary policy stance in 2022.

site_title: US topples China as Taiwan's largest export market due to chips, AI demand
summary: Taiwan has surpassed China as Taiwan's largest export market for the first time in four months, according to December data from the Finance Ministry. The US took the top spot due to high demand for microchip products and AI technology, with exports reaching $8.49 billion. Taiwan has been a microchip-manufacturing powerhouse, producing advanced silicon wafers for various industries. This marks a significant shift from the past two decades, when China held the top export market spot.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A cargo ship is pictured at a port in Keelung, Taiwan, January 7, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) logo is seen near computer motherboard in this illustration taken January 8, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: IEA trims oil demand forecast on weakness in wealthier countries
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) trimmed its forecast for 2024 oil demand growth by 130,000 barrels per day to 1.2 million bpd, citing lower-than-expected consumption in OECD countries and a slump in factory activity. The forecast falls short of Opec's prediction of 2.25 million bpd, but exceeds the US government's forecast of 950,000 bpd. Demand growth is expected to edge down to 1.1 million bpd in 2025, with global GDP growth forecast to remain steady and electric vehicle expansion expected to gather pace.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled down 74 cents, or 0.8 per cent, to US$89.74 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settled down US$1.19, or 1.4 per cent, to US$85.02 on Thursday.
Brent crude futures settled up US$1.06, or 1.2 per cent, to US$90.48 per barrel.
Brent crude futures fell 79 US cents.
Oil has rallied this year, driven by tighter supply, attacks on Russian energy infrastructure and war in the Middle East.
“The US produced more crude oil than any nation at any time, according to our International Energy Statistics, for the past six years in a row,” the EIA says.
A view of the logo of the International Energy Agency in Paris, France, December 15, 2023. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier
IEA's new office in Singapore will focus on scaling up the deployment of renewables and other clean energy technologies, among other things.

site_title: China's March exports and imports shrink, miss forecasts by big margins
summary: China's March exports and imports shrank, missing forecasts by large margins. Shipments fell 7.5% year-on-year, the largest decline since August last year, while imports declined 1.9% year-on-year. The data highlights the need for policymakers to implement targeted policy stimulus to meet China's ambitious 5% growth target. Analysts warn that China's economic recovery remains uneven, with a protracted property sector crisis and concerns over overcapacity in some industries. The central bank faces challenges in stimulating demand, with more credit flowing to production than consumption.

images.alt_text: Challenges facing the economy are rife, despite activity improving at the start of 2024.

site_title: Biden vows ‘ironclad’ defence of Philippines, Japan as China tension mounts
summary: US President Joe Biden pledged to defend the Philippines from any attack in the South China Sea, calling his country's defense commitments "ironclad." The statement came during a trilateral summit with Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida and Filipino President Ferdinand Marcos, amid growing tensions with China. Biden reiterated that any attack on Philippine forces would invoke the US-Philippines mutual defense treaty, and the US, Japan, and Philippines are expected to announce new joint naval exercises and economic cooperation measures.

images.alt_text: If Trump wins a second term, America will have a leader invested in his own personal power, both financial and punitive, and supported by a much more capable team.
A lifelong Democrat, Robert F Kennedy initially sought to challenge Joe Biden for the party’s nomination when he entered the presidential race in April 2023. He later switched to an independent bid.
US President Joe Biden and Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida review the honour guard during an official ceremony in Washington.
New York prosecutors charge that Trump (right) covered up his former lawyer's US$130,000 payment to porn star Stormy Daniels (left).

site_title: More Japan households see higher prices a year from now: survey
summary: Japanese households' inflation expectations rose to 83.3% in a Bank of Japan survey, up from 79.3% in the previous survey. 80.6% of households expect prices to rise five years from now. The increase is seen as a factor in the BOJ's inflation assessment, with Governor Kazuo Ueda predicting prices will accelerate from summer to autumn due to bumper pay hikes. This suggests sustained inflation may be a concern for the central bank.

site_title: MUFG to discuss buying US$1.7 billion stake in HDFC unit
summary: Japan's Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) is in talks to acquire a 20% stake in HDFC Bank's consumer lending unit, HDB Financial Services, for approximately $1.7 billion. This deal would be one of the largest financial sector deals involving lenders from the two countries. The move aims to tap into India's booming demand for personal finance loans and is part of MUFG's strategy to expand its presence in the Asian market. Negotiations are in the final stages, but terms may change or no agreement may be reached.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past a signboard of Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and MUFG Bank at its headquarters in Tokyo, Japan April 3, 2018. REUTERS/Toru Hanai/File Photo

site_title: Thailand will not tolerate border violations after clashes in Myanmar
summary: Thailand has vowed to protect its sovereignty along its border with Myanmar, following clashes that have dislodged junta troops from their positions in the neighboring country. Foreign Minister Parnpree Bahiddha-Nukara stated that Thailand's soldiers are on high alert to prevent any border violations. The clashes, sparked by the military's 2021 coup, have sent people fleeing into Thailand, with artillery shells and gunfire audible from the border town of Myawaddy. Thailand's stance aims to deter further incursions and maintain stability in the region.

images.alt_text: Myanmar is in the throes of an insurgency on multiple fronts, with allied anti-junta groups backed by a pro-democracy parallel government seizing control of several military posts and towns.

site_title: Australian prosecutors drop billionaire Forrest's case against Meta
summary: Australian prosecutors have dropped a case against Meta Platforms, accusing the social media giant of allowing third-party scammers to use its software and platform to advertise fake cryptocurrency schemes featuring billionaire Andrew Forrest's face. Forrest had accused Meta of breaking Australia's anti-money laundering laws and had pursued the case with the consent of the attorney general. The decision is a setback for Forrest, who will continue to pursue a separate civil lawsuit in California. Meta had argued that a US law exempts internet platforms from responsibility for content posted by third parties.

images.alt_text: Meta’s pivot to AI services has brought increased demand for computing power.

site_title: Japan’s finance minister says authorities are looking at factors behind yen moves
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki said authorities are analyzing factors behind the yen's recent moves and are prepared to respond to excessive volatility. Suzuki emphasized the importance of stable exchange rates reflecting fundamentals, warning that excessive volatility is undesirable. He is coordinating with top currency diplomat Masato Kanda to address yen moves, which can bring benefits and drawbacks to the economy, particularly in terms of inflation. Suzuki did not rule out any options for responding to excessive exchange-rate moves.

site_title: Canada’s 30-year mortgages seen helping ‘sliver’ of market
summary: Canada's relaxation of mortgage rules may increase the attainable purchase price for first-time buyers by 6% due to 30-year amortisation periods on new builds. However, this change will only affect a small "sliver" of the highly priced housing market. Analysts say the policy won't be a game-changer, and the 5% GST on new homes will offset most of its benefit. The policy may influence builders to focus on first-time buyer projects, but overall market impact is expected to be limited, as juicing demand is not the right solution for a market already struggling with excess demand.

images.alt_text: Housing is becoming the central issue ahead of Canada’s next general election, with a lack of dwellings and rapid population growth driving up prices.

Condominiums stand along the shore of Lake Ontario in this aerial photograph taken above Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Monday, Oct. 2, 2017. Toronto housing prices fell for a fourth month in September as sales remained sluggish, particularly in the detached-home segment that has borne the brunt of the correction in Canada's biggest city. Photographer: James MacDonald/Bloomberg

site_title: Between the US and a hard place, Germany’s Scholz reheats China ties
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz is visiting China on April 13, aiming to strengthen ties amid US and EU pressure to restrict Chinese goods. The visit comes as the German economy struggles, with companies seeking fairer access to the Chinese market. China is also under pressure to support Russia's wartime economy, and Scholz may push Beijing on this issue. The trip is seen as a "re-engaging" and stabilizing of relations, with Scholz emphasizing Germany's special role within the EU and cautioning against taking tough action in trade disputes.

images.alt_text: While overall imports from China dropped by nearly a fifth between 2022 and 2023, the share of product groups for which Germany relies on China for more than half of its imports has barely changed, including chemicals, computers and solar cells.
The revised 2023 budget will now be sent to parliament for approval, with an initial debate scheduled for Friday morning.

REUTERS/Annegret Hilse

site_title: Vietnam EV maker VinFast's challenges escalate risk for parent Vingroup
summary: Vietnam's largest conglomerate Vingroup is facing growing financial risks due to its loss-making unit VinFast Auto, which received $11.4 billion in capital injections from 2017 to 2023. VinFast's rapid growth relies heavily on sales to affiliated companies and is struggling to attract retail buyers, with global EV demand weakening. The company lost $5.7 billion over the past three years and its share price has plummeted 38% since its US listing last year. Vingroup's net profit margin nearly halved last year, and the company aims to nearly triple vehicle sales this year, which now looks challenging due to sharply weakening global EV demand.

images.alt_text: First deliveries of the vehicle in Vietnam are due in the third quarter.

site_title: Singapore economy grows 2.7% year on year in Q1, but just 0.1% sequentially
summary: Singapore's economy grew 2.7% year-over-year in Q1, but 0.1% sequentially, missing economists' expectations. Services sector growth improved to 3.2% year-over-year, driven by increases in accommodation and food services, real estate, and other services. Manufacturing growth slowed to 0.8% year-over-year, while construction grew 4.3% year-over-year. The sequential decline in manufacturing and construction sectors was attributed to decreases in the electronics and private construction sectors, respectively.

images.alt_text: xxx
The economy has expanded by 1.1 per cent year on year in the third quarter of this year, faster than the 0.5 per cent clocked in Q2.

site_title: US coffee chain Bluestone Lane to offer beanless espresso as sustainable option
summary: US coffee chain Bluestone Lane will start selling beanless espresso in August, made from date seeds, guava, and sunflower. The sustainable option is supplied by startup Atomo Coffee, which replicates the molecular structure of conventional coffee using raw materials that would otherwise go to waste. This move aims to reduce the carbon footprint of agriculture and aligns with Bluestone Lane's commitment to environmental stewardship.

site_title: China’s top legislator meets senior North Korea official: KCNA
summary: China's top lawmaker Zhao Leji met with North Korea's senior official Choe Ryong Hae in Pyongyang, discussing cooperation in politics, economy, and culture. The meeting is one of the most high-level between the two countries in years, as China and North Korea mark 75 years of diplomatic ties. The talks focused on regional and international issues, and China expressed willingness to intensify legislative exchanges and cooperation. Zhao signed cooperation documents in areas such as trade and tourism, with China being North Korea's largest trading partner.

images.alt_text: The popularity of Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida with the Biden administration goes well beyond routine backslapping for a close ally.

A new surface-to-sea missile at an undisclosed location in North Korea in this picture released by the Korean Central News Agency on Feb 15, 2024. North Korea fired a medium-range ballistic missile on Tuesday, Seoul’s military said.

site_title: Biden surpasses Trump’s record for blacklisting Chinese entities
summary: US President Joe Biden has surpassed former President Donald Trump's record for blacklisting Chinese entities, adding 319 companies and individuals to the export blacklist since taking office. The milestone reflects the Biden administration's efforts to restrict China's access to cutting-edge technology, particularly in the AI sector, citing national security concerns. China has responded with its own sanctions against US companies, including freezing assets and denying visas to executives. The escalating tensions highlight the growing economic and security complexities between the world's two largest economies.

site_title: UK economy's growth in February points to exit from recession
summary: The UK economy has shown signs of exiting its recession, with GDP growing for a second month in February and January, with a revised growth of 0.3% in January. This growth is a welcome sign, according to finance minister Jeremy Hunt, but the economy remains below its pre-recession level and has stayed flat since early 2022. Business surveys suggest continued growth in March, but economists caution that the long-term outlook is still challenging due to interest rate hikes and supply constraints.

images.alt_text: Workers on a Bellway Plc residential construction site in Tongham, UK, on Monday, Feb. 26, 2024. Britain’s top antitrust enforcer has opened an investigation into eight housebuilders to probe potential information sharing, sharpening scrutiny of a sector that’s failing to deliver enough affordable housing to meet demand. site_title: Nuclear power debate heats up in South-east Asia
summary: Nuclear power debate heats up in South-east Asia, with countries considering the clean but controversial energy source as a potential solution to energy security fears and climate change. Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand are planning regulatory changes and signing deals to import nuclear technology, while Singapore aims to train 100 nuclear safety experts and potentially deploy small modular reactors (SMRs) by 2050. Proponents argue that nuclear power is safer and more stable than renewable energy, but obstacles include high costs, waste management, and public concerns. Experts point to advancements in reactor technology, including Generation III and Generation IV reactors, and SMRs, which could be more economically viable and sustainable. However, regional cooperation and standardization of regulations will be crucial for the adoption of nuclear power in South-east Asia.

site_title: Singapore, France to work at elevating ties to Comprehensive Strategic Partnership
summary: Singapore and France will work towards elevating their relations to a Comprehensive Strategic Partnership (CSP) by 2025, ahead of the 60th anniversary of their diplomatic ties. The move reflects the countries' "strong and substantive ties" and will deepen existing cooperation areas while enabling new ones. A year-long initiative, the France-Singapore Joint Year of Sustainability, was also launched to promote bilateral cooperation in sustainable development and the green transition, with a focus on five priority sectors: the circular economy, renewable energy, and sustainability in various domains.

site_title: Educated and unemployed: India’s angry young voters
summary: India, with over 1.4 billion people aged under 30, is facing a growing unemployment crisis among its educated youth, with 29% of young university graduates unemployed in 2022. Despite the country's fast-growing economy, there are not enough white-collar jobs, leading many to seek government positions, which are seen as secure and well-paid. The issue is exacerbated by the lack of job creation in the private sector, with many young people resorting to illegal channels to seek work abroad. The upcoming general elections have highlighted the challenge for politicians, with many young Indians feeling disenfranchised and frustrated with the lack of opportunities.

images.alt_text: Plastic sachets of Unilever's Sunsilk and Clinic Plus shampoo hang outside a shop in Mumbai, India, May 7, 2022. India’s elite classes are becoming pickier consumers, fueling the success of organic personal-care brands backed by slick social media marketing campaigns.
Musk (left) and Modi last met in New York in June, and Tesla for months lobbied India to lower import taxes on electric vehicles.

site_title: The hotshots of Watches and Wonders 2024
summary: Watches and Wonders 2024 unveiled several highly anticipated novelties, including the Rolex Perpetual 1908 in platinum, featuring an ice-blue dial with a rice-grain guilloché motif. Tudor introduced a smaller Black Bay 58 GMT with a Coke bezel and gilt accents, while Patek Philippe released the Golden Ellipse with a subtle update and bracelet. IWC showcased the Portugieser Eternal Calendar, boasting an accuracy of 45 million years, and Cartier introduced the Tortue Monopusher Chronograph with a new movement and slimmer profile. Other notable releases include Vacheron Constantin's Les Cabinotiers: The Berkley Grand Complication and TAG Heuer's Split-Seconds Monaco, featuring an in-house movement crafted from Grade 5 titanium.

site_title: More climate experts object to emissions target watchdog’s offsets policy
summary: A group of 21 technical advisers to the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) has urged the organization to retract its decision to allow companies to offset greenhouse gas emissions from their supply chain with carbon credits. The policy reversal sparked an angry letter from SBTi staff, who called for the CEO and board members who backed the decision to resign. The advisers claim the decision was made without their advice and that the use of environmental attribute certificates (EACs) is "premature and not supported by the TAG".

The policy will be a pillar of next month’s budget, as well as a major feature of a second-term agenda for Albanese’s government, ahead of an election due by mid-2025.
