The EU's proposed sustainability rules will apply to firms that have more than 1,000 employees, and net worldwide turnover above 450 million euros (S$654.2 million).

site_title: Gold prices hit record highs on safe-haven demand
summary: Gold prices reached a record high of $2,389.29 per ounce due to safe-haven demand amid geopolitical tensions. Spot gold rose 0.6% to $2,386.38 per ounce, while US gold futures gained 1.3% to $2,403.90 per ounce. Strong economic data failed to deter bullion's allure, with inflation concerns and interest rate uncertainty contributing to the demand surge. The Federal Reserve's reluctance to cut interest rates further supports gold's appeal, with expectations for policy easing decreasing.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was unchanged at US$2,337.99 per ounce.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Jardine C&C, Sabana Reit
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage's board will gain a new non-executive independent director, Jean-Pierre Felenbok, effective April 29. Felenbok, founder of Bain Indonesia, has been an advisory partner for Bain South-east Asia since 2022. Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust saw its units close 2.8% higher at S$0.37 following a letter from a former director expressing concerns over a proposed extraordinary general meeting by a few unitholders.

site_title: Singapore stocks little changed at Friday’s open; STI up 0.04%
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Friday, with the Straits Times Index rising 1.15 points or 0.04% to 3,228.76. The country's gross domestic product grew 2.7% year-over-year in the first quarter, but only 0.1% sequentially. The Monetary Authority of Singapore left its monetary policy unchanged, as expected. Gainers outnumbered losers 60 to 39, with notable movers including Marco Polo Marine, Beverly JCG, and King Wan.

images.alt_text: Jardine Cycle & Carriage is nominating Jean-Pierre Felenbok as a non-executive independent director.

site_title: Sam Bankman-Fried appeals fraud conviction, 25-year jail term
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, former FTX CEO, has appealed his federal conviction and 25-year jail sentence on seven counts of fraud, embezzlement, and criminal conspiracy. Bankman-Fried was convicted in November 2023 and ordered to pay $11 billion in forfeiture. He had become a billionaire before age 30 and turned FTX into the world's second-largest exchange platform. The appeal comes after Bankman-Fried was sentenced by US District Court Judge Lewis Kaplan.

site_title: Bernanke urges BOE to speak more clearly on direction of rates

site_title: MAS stands pat at April monetary policy review, as expected
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) maintained its monetary policy settings unchanged in April, as expected, extending the pause for the fourth straight meeting. MAS left its headline and core inflation projections unchanged, with core inflation expected to average 2.5-3.5% this year. The central bank will maintain the prevailing rate of appreciation of the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) policy band, citing a need to keep a restraining effect on imported inflation and domestic cost pressures. The decision reflects a cautious stance from MAS, with some economists speculating that the central bank may practice "stealth easing" in the future.

site_title: US producer prices rise 2.1% from a year ago, most in 11 months
summary: US producer prices rose 2.1% from a year ago, the largest increase in 11 months, according to the Labor Department's data. The core PPI, excluding volatile food and energy categories, rose 2.4% from March 2023. A third straight increase in services costs is driving inflation, prompting traders to lower expectations for interest rate cuts. Rising crude oil prices and commodity costs threaten to stall goods deflation, which could impact consumers.

images.alt_text: Job seekers speak with prospective employers during a City of Los Angeles career fair offering to fill vacancies in more than 30 classifications of jobs on November 2, 2023 in Los Angeles, California. The US Bureau of Labour Statistics will release on November 3 the October jobs report amid expectations employment remains quite healthy. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

site_title: OJ Simpson, football star turned celebrity murder defendant, dead at 76
summary: OJ Simpson, the former American football star and actor, died on April 10, 2024, at 76 after a battle with cancer. He was acquitted of murdering his ex-wife Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ronald Goldman in 1995, but was found liable for their deaths in a civil lawsuit and served nine years in prison for armed robbery and kidnapping. Simpson's acquittal in the highly publicized trial was seen as a victory for his "dream team" of lawyers, but was also criticized for its impact on the justice system and public perception of Simpson's guilt.

images.alt_text: Disgraced US football star OJ Simpson to be released from prison

site_title: Global credit outlook for 2024 worsens, new survey finds
summary: A new survey by the International Association of Credit Portfolio Managers (IACPM) found that portfolio managers at major financial institutions have a worsening outlook for global credit conditions in 2024. More than half of respondents expect corporate credit defaults to rise in Europe and North America, with 57% expecting defaults to increase in Europe and 51% in North America. Despite this, only 25% of respondents expect North America to enter a recession this year, while 37% expect Europe to do so. Overall credit spreads are also expected to widen.

images.alt_text: Crypto trading volumes are highly concentrated, with Binance accounting for about half the market.

site_title: ECB holds rates at record highs, signals upcoming cut
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) maintained its deposit rate at 4.0% for a 1½-year effort to control inflation, but signaled a possible rate cut as eurozone inflation falls. ECB President Christine Lagarde stated that "just a few" members of the Governing Council believe it's time to loosen policy, but the bank will wait for further data. With inflation near the 2% target, the ECB hinted at a possible rate cut at its June 6 meeting if inflation continues to moderate.

images.alt_text: While banks were slowly turning less cautious – at least about extending home loans – households and companies showed little appetite for taking on fresh debt, the ECB’s quarterly Bank Lending Survey showed.

epa11204097 An exterior view of the European Central Bank (ECB) building before a press conference following the meeting of the ECB Governing Council in Frankfurt am Mainn, Germany, 07 March 2024.  EPA-EFE/CHRISTOPHER NEUNDORF

site_title: IMF chief sees inflation dropping further in 2024, not yet fully defeated
summary: IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva says inflation in advanced economies is easing faster than expected, but not yet fully defeated, with headline inflation at 2.3% in the final quarter of 2023. Georgieva urges central bankers to carefully calibrate interest rate cuts, warning that premature easing could lead to new inflation surprises. The IMF expects global growth to marginally strengthen in 2024, with strong labor markets and household consumption, but warns that the global environment has become more challenging due to geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: The IMF in January warned that overall growth in the global economy and trade remained well below the historical average.

site_title: Space startups see funding surge as government spending remains high: report
summary: Funding for space startups more than doubled in the first quarter to $6.5 billion, driven by geopolitical uncertainties and the growing demand for geospatial intelligence. This surge is expected to contribute to the space economy's growth, which is projected to triple to $1.8 trillion by 2035, rivaling the global semiconductor industry. Key milestones include successful Starship flight tests and the first lunar touchdown by a US spacecraft in over 50 years. The increased investment is also expected to benefit investors, businesses, and government entities.

images.alt_text: A Starlink dish and router in California. The company has 5,600 active satellites deployed, but plans to add tens of thousands more.
The contract to supply SpaceX’s Starlink communications terminals runs from June of last year through next month, and the official declined to say if it would be renewed.

site_title: Sabana Reit unitholders urge EGM requisitionists to respect trust deed, court process
summary: Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) has urged EGM requisitionists to respect the trust deed, following a letter from unitholder Chan Wai Kheong. Chan, a former independent non-executive director, called on the requisitionists to adhere to the trust deed's details. This comes after four other unitholders, including Quarz Capital, requisitioned a third EGM. The move is seen as a response to concerns from some unitholders about the requisitionists' actions.

images.alt_text: In a statement addressed to the Sabana Real Estate Investment Management – the current manager of Sabana Reit – that was posted to the bourse on Tuesday (Apr 9), the trustee outlined a “workplan” over the next six months pertaining to the internalisation timeline
ESR Group maintains that its entire episode with Quarz Capital has “resulted in a diminished value” of Sabana Reit’s unit price.
More than three quarters of Suntec Reit's assets consist of offices, shops and convention space in Singapore
Quarz urged unitholders to vote for all the resolutions at the EGM to “ensure it can successfully execute on internalisation with as few obstacles as possible”.
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio. The Reit's trustee is HSBC Institutional Trust Services.

site_title: Boutique Fairs: Long-running showcase of Singaporean creativity
summary: Boutique Fairs Singapore, now in its 42nd edition, will feature 300 independent design-led brands across seven rooms at the F1 Pit Building, attracting 25,000 to 30,000 visitors. This year's event includes 80 new brands, with 25 international labels from Thailand, Japan, Denmark, and the US. The fair aims to provide exposure for Singaporean designers competing with larger brands, according to founder Charlotte Cain.

images.alt_text: Hock Siong & Co is one of several places to find solidly-built furniture from eras past.
Graye's gender-neutral clothes have helped the company expand its business to two stores, including a flagship in Wheelock Place.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall more than expected; continuing claims rise
summary: US weekly jobless claims fell 11,000 to 211,000 in the week ended April 6, beating economists' forecasts. The labor market remained tight, despite a 525 basis point interest rate hike to tame inflation. Job growth accelerated in March, while the unemployment rate dropped to 3.8% from 3.9% in February. However, the number of people receiving benefits after an initial week of aid increased to 1.817 million. The strong labor market and high inflation have led financial markets to push back expectations for the first rate cut to September from June.

images.alt_text: The resilient data generally increases confidence among economists and market investors that the US economy has reached a healthy equilibrium.

site_title: Time is running out for adaptation finance: StanChart
summary: Standard Chartered, KPMG, and the UN Office for Disaster Risk Reduction have unveiled guidelines for adaptation finance, aiming to increase capital flow into protecting critical infrastructure from climate change. The guidelines define adaptation finance as any financial service supporting asset resilience, operations, customers, or supply chains. With less than 10% of climate finance dedicated to adaptation, the annual funding gap is approximately $360 billion. The goal is to frame adaptation finance in a way that finance professionals can think about in "classic market terms" and consider it a profitable investment.

images.alt_text: In letters seen by ST, parents who have been paying their storage fee annually have been offered refunds of $537.50.
The EU's proposed sustainability rules will apply to firms that have more than 1,000 employees, and net worldwide turnover above 450 million euros (S$654.2 million).

site_title: China Vanke shares, bonds fall after rating cut and government probe
summary: China Vanke's shares and US dollar bonds dropped after S&P downgraded its rating to BB+ from BBB+, citing weakening competitive position and surging leverage. The developer's stock fell 1.8% to 7.4 yuan, while its Hong Kong-listed stock dropped 1.9% to HK$4.14. A general manager was being investigated by police, fueling concerns among investors. Despite this, S&P estimated China Vanke's sales would continue to fall over the next 12 months amid a property market slump.

images.alt_text: Contracted sales for March were 24.5 billion yuan (S$4.6 billion), Vanke says. That represents a 43 per cent decline from a year earlier.
There have been other signs of concerns among financial institutions, with the property firm’s credit ratings cut to junk level by Fitch Ratings and Moody’s last month.

Investors have been dumping Vanke’s shares and bonds in the past few weeks on cash flow concerns, triggering a rare central government directive to help the Shenzhen-based company beat a liquidity crisis.

site_title: Chinese factory shreds wedding photos for fuel
summary: A Chinese factory is shredding and recycling wedding photos into fuel, offering a unique solution for those seeking to destroy memories of failed marriages. The service, launched a year ago, receives an average of 5-10 orders daily, with clients mostly seeking closure after divorce. The factory's owner, Liu Wei, emphasizes the importance of respecting clients' choices and providing a safe space for them to process their emotions. The shredded photos are then converted into biofuel, generating electricity for the local community.

images.alt_text: epa10990532 Students are dismissed from a school in Beijing, China, 23 November 2023. The World Health Organization (WHO) made an official request to China for detailed information following an increase of respiratory diseases and reported clusters of pneumonia in children in northern China.  EPA-EFE/MARK R. CRISTINO

site_title: UK banks boost mortgage supply at fastest pace since 2021
summary: UK lenders boosted mortgage supply by the most since 2021, as borrowers respond to falling mortgage rates and a fading cost-of-living crisis. The Bank of England's credit conditions survey showed a rise in demand from borrowers and lenders expect further increases in mortgage supply. Mortgage rates have been creeping up, but demand remains strong, with property surveyors reporting optimism about new buyer demand.

images.alt_text: uk property housing Photographer: Betty Laura Zapata/Bloomberg
UK renters are concentrated among younger generations and face a further squeeze.
Two stalled sales in London’s office market are a sign of its stultified nature, amid higher interest rates and concerns around a trend towards hybrid working.
For London's prime properties, which account for the top 10 per cent of rents, rates are forecast to grow by 2.9 per cent this year.
Almost half of UK house hunters are set to accelerate their purchase plans this year to beat any potential rebound in prices.
Homes in Britain have less floor space per person than many other developed economies, trailing France, Germany, Japan, the United States and Taiwan.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 11)
summary: Temasek Holdings opened its new Paris office, aiming to invest S$20-25 billion in the EMEA region over five years. The move enhances access to deal flow and partnership opportunities. Meanwhile, a proposed S$910 million deal for Far East Shopping Centre fell through after the Urban Redevelopment Authority rejected the redevelopment proposal. Indonesia's Agung Sedayu Group's multibillion-dollar project, inspired by Singapore's Sentosa Island, is set to transform Jakarta's north coast. The Asian Development Bank expects sustained growth in South-east Asia and South Asia to offset China's economic slowdown.

site_title: Cambodian PM says country to build US$1.7 billion canal
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet announced plans to build a US$1.7 billion canal linking Phnom Penh to the sea, despite concerns from Vietnam about facilitating Chinese warship travel near the Vietnamese coastline. The Funan Techo canal is the latest Chinese-backed infrastructure project in Cambodia, following billions of dollars in investments from Beijing. The project's completion is expected to push forward despite previous concerns.

images.alt_text: A rendering of the new Techo International Airport in Phnom Penh that is due to be the ninth-largest in the world when it opens its doors next year.

site_title: Jardine Cycle & Carriage names Jean-Pierre Felenbok as independent director
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage has appointed Jean-Pierre Felenbok as a non-executive independent director, effective April 29. Felenbok, 67, is a management consultant with experience in Southeast Asia, having founded Bain Indonesia and served as managing partner of Bain South-east Asia. The appointment was recommended by the company's nominating committee after reviewing his background and qualifications. Shares rose 2.3% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Citi Research is optimistic about Jardine C&C's investments in Vietnam.
The board has proposed a final one-tier tax-exempt dividend of US$0.90 per share for the year, up from US$0.83 per share in 2022.

site_title: US dollar weakens after producer prices data, falls below 153 against yen
summary: The US dollar fell below 153 yen after weaker-than-expected producer prices data for March, easing market concerns about inflation. The producer price index rose 0.2% month-over-month, lower than expected, and 2.1% year-over-year. This data suggests inflationary pressure may have been less widespread in March than initially thought. The US dollar index was down 0.2% at 105.09, with interest rate cut expectations still high, as the Federal Reserve is expected to cut rates in September with a 72% chance, according to FedWatch tool.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Banknotes of Japanese yen and U.S. dollar are seen in this illustration picture taken September 23, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: OCBC, Lion Global to launch Apac financial sector-focused ETF
summary: OCBC Securities and Lion Global Investors are launching the world's first exchange-traded fund (ETF) focused on Asia-Pacific financial services companies. The Lion-OCBC Securities Apac Financials Dividend Plus ETF tracks the iEdge Apac Financials Dividend Plus Index, with a minimum dividend payout of 5% per annum for the first two years. The fund is expected to provide exposure to high-performing banks, insurance, and investment services companies in the region, and is set to list on the Singapore Exchange on May 13.

images.alt_text: Having a wider range of products could attract the attention of more investors who sometimes lament about the stable but unexciting offerings available in the local market.
OCBC Securities, Lion Global to list low carbon ETF on SGX

site_title: ShareInvestor’s holding company rebrands as AlphaInvest; to expand to other asset classes
summary: AlphaInvest, the holding company of retail investor platform ShareInvestor, has rebranded with a new logo and tagline reflecting its evolution beyond traditional equities-based products. The company aims to expand into other asset classes such as currencies, commodities, and digital assets, serving growing investing communities in Malaysia, Indonesia, and Thailand. AlphaInvest plans to enhance its market data portal and broaden its reach to 300,000 retail investors and 700 publicly listed companies, with subsidiaries retaining the ShareInvestor name in certain markets.

images.alt_text: The previous auction, which closed on Mar 27, offered 3.8 per cent yield.
The Lion-OCBC Securities APAC Financials Dividend Plus ETF is OCBC’s fourth ETF launched in less than four years.
Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 112 to 44.

site_title: China vows strong support for equipment, consumer goods trade-in plans
summary: China has pledged strong financing support for firms involved in equipment upgrades and trade-in of consumer goods, aiming to boost domestic investment and consumption. The move follows an action plan issued by the cabinet last month, which includes measures to promote the initiative. The National Development and Reform Commission's deputy head, Zhao Chenxin, stated that financial support will be provided through central investment, fiscal funds, and other sources, with a strong emphasis on large-scale upgrades and trade-ins. This effort is part of China's efforts to spur economic growth and address slowing GDP growth.

images.alt_text: The spot rate is currently allowed to trade within a 2 per cent range above or below the official fixing on any given day.
The figures suggest domestic demand is struggling to maintain any momentum it picked up during the holiday season.

site_title: Euro 2024 will help beer reign over cocktails this summer
summary: Major European brewers, including Heineken and Carlsberg, expect a surge in beer sales this summer due to the Euro 2024 football tournament and warmer weather. The tournament, which will take place in June and July, is expected to boost sales in countries like the UK, France, and Germany, where football is a significant cultural phenomenon. In contrast, spirit makers may face challenges due to economic uncertainty and changes in consumer behavior, with the US market being particularly vulnerable.

images.alt_text: Budweiser, despite producing some of the US’s most popular and affordable beers, is considered a status product by label-hungry Chinese drinkers.

The maker of Budweiser, Corona and Stella Artois will be a Worldwide Olympic Partner, the highest level of Olympic sponsorship, for this year’s Paris Olympic Games as well as the 2026 Winter Olympics in Milan and the 2028 Olympics in Los Angeles.

site_title: Nike pins hopes on Olympics in race to take back market share
summary: Nike aims to boost sales by unveiling new Olympic kits and focusing on performance products, particularly entry-level running shoes priced between $100 and $150. The company seeks to capitalize on the attention generated by top athletes wearing Nike gear at the Paris Olympics. However, Nike faces competition from brands like Adidas, On Running, and Lululemon, which are taking market share from the sportswear giant. Analysts expect Nike's annual sales growth to lag those brands in 2024 and 2025.

images.alt_text: The bet is that athletes breaking records in Puma gear will nudge spectators towards its whole range of products, creating a potential “halo effect” for everything from marathon shoes to everyday sneakers.
Nike is shifting its sneaker offerings as it tries to find sweet spots across categories.
The job cuts follow an announcement in December that the company is looking for as much as US$2 billion in cost savings.

site_title: Millennials and Gen-Z drive trend towards low-alcohol drinks
summary: Millennials and Gen-Z drive the trend towards low-alcohol drinks, with younger generations prioritizing health-conscious alternatives to traditional boozy binges. A 20.5% year-on-year increase in interest in low and no-alcohol drinks globally is reflected in the US, where Gen Zers show a 53% year-on-year increase in planning to drink less alcohol. Bars are adapting by offering creative cocktails and alcohol-free liqueurs, with many incorporating non-alcoholic options into their menus. Experts believe the trend is here to stay, with consumers seeking low-ABV and non-alcoholic drinks that cater to their health-conscious lifestyles and social media aesthetics.

site_title: Ferrari owner Exor’s boss is telling investors that his company still loves cars
summary: Exor's CEO John Elkann stated that cars remain the company's first love, despite years of diversification. Ferrari and Stellantis, controlled by Exor, contributed nearly 60% to the company's gross asset value last year, with a combined increase of 8.2 billion euros. Elkann's annual letter to shareholders comes at a tense time for Italy's car industry, with Stellantis potentially reducing its number of plants in the country if a Chinese electric vehicle manufacturer sets up shop. Exor remains supportive of Philips' leadership and strategy, seeing the stake as a good fit for its healthcare portfolio.

images.alt_text: “We are working together with SK On to explore new frontiers,” Ferrari chief executive Benedetto Vigna says.

California resident Iliya Nechev claims his 2010 Ferrari 458 Italia (not pictured), which he bought in 2020, had “brake issues” from the day he got it and “would experience partial or total loss of braking capability”.
The top seller during the live auctions is a 1903 Mercedes-Simplex 60 HP Roi Des Belges at Gooding & Co, which achieved US$12.1 million including premiums.

site_title: Trafigura consortium in talks to buy Exxon oil refinery in France
summary: Trafigura, a consortium of commodity trader Trafigura and Entara, is in exclusive negotiations to acquire ExxonMobil's Esso Saf refinery in southern France and terminals in Toulouse and Villette de Vienne. The deal includes a 10-year exclusive crude oil supply and product offtake agreement and ownership of crude oil and product stocks. The refinery has a capacity of 140,000 barrels per day. Regulatory approvals are needed for completion, expected by the end of 2024. This is Trafigura's second major acquisition this year, following its agreement to buy Greenergy's European business.

images.alt_text: Trafigura Beheer BV, the parent company of Trafigura Group during the relevant period, has agreed to pay a criminal fine of US$80.5 million and forfeit another US$46.5 million after pleading guilty to a conspiracy to violate the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.
The revelation is the latest twist in a case that has shocked the commodity trading world, after Trafigura in February accused Gupta of perpetrating a massive fraud against it.

site_title: Multilateral development banks still need work on implementing reforms, group says
summary: The World Bank and six other multilateral development banks still need to implement reforms, according to a tool tracking progress. The Center for Global Development's tracker assessed 28 specific items under five categories, finding highly uneven results among institutions. No single MDB excelled in all reform categories. The US and other countries are pushing the banks to focus on climate change, poverty reduction, and development, while taking on more risk to expand lending. Despite progress, the banks have "miles to go" in implementing reforms.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The World Bank logo is seen at the 2023 Spring Meetings of the World Bank Group and the International Monetary Fund in Washington, U.S., April 13, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz

site_title: German builders demand billions in subsidies to stem housing crisis
summary: German builders are demanding 23 billion euros in annual subsidies to address the country's housing crisis, which threatens to derail the economic recovery. The subsidies aim to build 100,000 social housing units and 60,000 new affordable homes. Industry groups warn that if nothing is done, the crisis will worsen, affecting the entire economy. A decline in residential construction volume is expected, resulting in a 5.4% drop in construction volume and a loss of almost 5 billion euros in tax revenue for the state.

images.alt_text: The number of transactions dropped 19 per cent in the first quarter compared with a year earlier.

A construction site for apartment buildings in the HafenCity district in Hamburg, Germany, on Thursday, July 6, 2023. Germany’s efforts to increase housing supply are faltering as higher materials costs triggered a decline in residential construction orders by more than one third in the first quarter, according to the country’s main builders lobby. Photographer: Maria Feck/Bloomberg
The price of owner-occupied residential property falls by just over 4 per cent last year according to industry data.

site_title: Vietnam property tycoon sentenced to death in multibillion-dollar fraud case
summary: Vietnamese property tycoon Truong My Lan was sentenced to death for swindling an estimated US$27 billion from Saigon Commercial Bank (SCB) over a decade. Lan, chair of major developer Van Thinh Phat, was found guilty of embezzling US$12.5 billion and was accused of setting up fake loan applications to withdraw money from SCB. The verdict is part of a national corruption crackdown in Vietnam, with 85 others facing charges and sentencing.

images.alt_text: Truong My Lan is the chairwoman of Van Thinh Phat (VTP) Group, one of Vietnam’s most influential real estate empires.

site_title: Japan says it won’t rule out any FX action as yen hits 34-year low
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki said the country won't rule out any FX action to address excessive yen swings, following the currency's 34-year low against the US dollar. Suzuki emphasized the importance of stable currency movements reflecting fundamentals, while acknowledging the yen's impact on prices. This comes after the yen weakened past 153 yen per US dollar following strong US inflation data, with market participants on alert for any signs of yen intervention.

images.alt_text: The yen has largely been trading in the 151 range against the US dollar since Japan’s central bank raised interest rates last month for the first time since 2007.

FILE PHOTO: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida speaks during a news conference at the prime minister's office in Tokyo, Japan, 13 December 2023. Prime Minister Kishida said he will replace several ministers implicated in a political fundraising scandal.    FRANCK ROBICHON/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: BASF starts layoff process at Finland site after permit problems
summary: BASF has begun a layoff process at its Harjavalta site in Finland due to permitting issues. The company, which employs a double-digit number of people, will start the change negotiations process on Monday and will last for six weeks. All employees at the site are potentially affected by the move. BASF did not specify the number of employees who may be laid off. The company is facing permitting issues from Finnish authorities.

images.alt_text: BASF says the cost-cutting measures will lead to further job cuts.
It says that its audits have not found any evidence of human rights violations at the two joint ventures and that it has no indication that employees at them were involved in such violations.

site_title: Chinese firms helping military get AI chips added to US export blacklist
summary: The US Commerce Department has added four Chinese companies to an export blacklist for allegedly providing AI chips to China's military modernization programs and military intelligence users. The companies, including LINKZOL, Xi'an Like Innovative Information Technology, Beijing Anwise Technology, and SITONHOLY, will need licenses to ship goods and technology to the US Entity List. China has opposed the move, calling it a "containment" and "suppression" of Chinese companies. The US has also restricted exports to five other companies, including those helping Russia and Iran with military activities.

images.alt_text: Yellen says that concerns are growing over the global economic fallout from China’s excess manufacturing capacity.
U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen arrives at Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport, in Guangzhou, Guangdong province, China April 4, 2024. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

US President Joe Biden (right) and China's President Xi Jinping (left) have managed to maintain a veneer of diplomatic stability despite deep mutual suspicion between their countries, and as their governments pursue export controls, sanctions and tariffs.
The rules seek to halt shipments to China of more advanced artificial intelligence chips designed by Nvidia and others.

site_title: Lufthansa agrees to pay rise with flight attendants after strike
summary: Lufthansa has agreed to pay a 16.5% total pay rise to its 19,000 flight attendants in three stages, retroactively from January 1, as well as an inflation compensation bonus and increased allowances. The agreement, reached with the cabin crew union UFO, ends the threat of strikes and runs until the end of 2026. This comes after a strike by UFO earlier this month, affecting tens of thousands of passengers, and follows similar wage agreements with ground staff at Verdi for Lufthansa.

site_title: HKEX proposes plan for multiple clearing banks for cash trades
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEX) proposes allowing investors to enlist multiple clearing banks for cash trades, aiming to encourage lower fees and better services. The proposal, currently under review by the Securities and Futures Commission, would increase the number of clearing banks from eight to potentially 10 or more, including international and Chinese firms. This move is part of Hong Kong's efforts to revive its struggling stock market, which has slid for four years.

images.alt_text: The city is typically hit by about six typhoons each year from June to October.
The 69-year-old Carlson Tong, who is HKEX’s non-executive director, has emerged as the frontrunner to take over from current Chair Laura Cha, two sources say.
Spin-off listings have boosted Hong Kong’s competitiveness by increasing the number of new-economy listings.

site_title: HSBC changes insurance head after Hingston’s surprise exit
summary: HSBC has replaced Greg Hingston as global chief executive of its insurance business, effective immediately. Ed Moncreiffe, a veteran insider with 18 years of experience at HSBC, will take over the role. Hingston's surprise exit comes as HSBC continues to pivot its business towards Asia, where it makes most of its money. The bank has been expanding in the region with billions of US dollars in fresh investments, and has recently completed acquisitions in Singapore and China. The change is part of HSBC's strategy to become a leading global wealth manager.

images.alt_text: India has become a key market for HSBC as it looks to expand its operations in Asia.
Quinn is hosting the bank’s three-day inaugural Global Investment Summit that kicked off in Hong Kong earlier Monday.
India will reach the maximum 10 per cent weighting in the gauge, making it crucial for funds tracking the index to add the nation’s debt to their portfolios.
HSBC says the majority of its institutional and retail investor base backed the board and the structure of the bank.

site_title: Asia: Market tracks Wall Street losses as US data deals blow to rate cut hopes.
summary: Asian markets reversed losses on Thursday, following a sell-off on Wall Street after disappointing US inflation data dealt a blow to rate cut hopes. The data showed a 0.4% month-on-month and 3.5% year-on-year rise in consumer prices, above consensus, and raised concerns about a worrying trend. The US dollar surged to a 34-year high against the yen, fueling speculation that Japanese authorities may step in to support their currency. The US Federal Reserve's recent guidance of three rate cuts this year is now in doubt, with investors now eyeing two at most.

site_title: What worries me most about a Trump presidency
summary: US President Donald Trump's potential second term poses significant threats to the US government, particularly the transformation of it into a modern-day Tammany Hall, characterized by kleptocratic leadership. Trump's history of enriching himself through business dealings and his practice of using government funds for personal gain will likely continue, leading to a decline in trust in institutions and impairing the country's ability to address global crises. The presence of loyal employees and lack of accountability mechanisms will allow Trump to entrench himself in the bureaucracy, potentially destroying the mechanisms of accountability and cementing a kleptocratic system.

images.alt_text: ATLANTA, GEORGIA - APRIL 10: Former U.S. President Donald Trump speaks to the media as he arrives at the Atlanta Airport on April 10, 2024 in Atlanta, Georgia. Trump is visiting Atlanta for a campaign fundraising event he is hosting.   Megan Varner/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Megan Varner / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: China’s Harvest may get Hong Kong approval for spot-Bitcoin ETF later in April
summary: China's Harvest Fund Management may receive approval from Hong Kong to launch a spot-Bitcoin exchange-traded fund (ETF) later in April, according to sources. This is the second step in a two-part process, following the recent approval of virtual-asset related fund management services. The launch of spot-Bitcoin ETFs in Hong Kong "could be imminent" as Bitcoin's bull run drives demand, with global assets expected to reach $100 billion.

images.alt_text: The impacted staff at the Hong Kong unit receive notices this week to leave the firm within three months, in a move that comes as foreign investors’ appetite for Chinese stocks remain weak.

site_title: Higher for longer after all? Investors see Fed rates falling more slowly
summary: Investors now expect the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates higher for longer, with market pricing suggesting a year-end rate of 4.75%. The Fed is balancing the need to control inflation with the risk of a recession by being patient in cutting rates. Despite recent inflation data, Fed officials remain focused on the goal of 2% inflation and are considering the impact of sustained economic growth on interest rates. Economists and investors, including Jamie Dimon and William Dudley, believe interest rates could remain higher than predicted in the coming years, with potential implications for borrowing costs and the economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell holds a press conference following a two-day meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee on interest rate policy in Washington, U.S., March 20, 2024. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz/File Photo
Former President Donald Trump faces legal challenges in his 2024 campaign for president. But this has galvanised his supporters.
Petrol and shelter costs, which include rents, accounts for more than half of the increase in the US consumer price index.

site_title: Chinese Premier Li to visit Australia in June, SCMP says
summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang will visit Australia in the third week of June, coinciding with the lifting of an unofficial three-year ban on Australian live lobsters. This visit marks a thawing of ties between the two nations, which have been rebuilding relations after strained relations in 2020. The move comes as Australia seeks to increase trade with China, its largest trading partner. The visit is seen as a positive step in strengthening bilateral relations between the two countries.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Bottles of Australian wine are seen at a store selling imported wine in Beijing, China November 27, 2020. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: Latest Singapore 6-month T-bill cut-off yield falls to 3.75%
summary: The Singapore 6-month T-bill cut-off yield fell to 3.75% in the latest auction, down from 3.8% in the previous auction. Demand increased, with a total of S$16 billion applied, while the allotted amount stood at S$6.3 billion. Despite expectations of higher-for-longer rates, short-term Singdollar rates are likely to remain stable. The US Federal Reserve is expected to wait until September to cut interest rates, with just two rate cuts anticipated this year, according to rates-futures markets.

images.alt_text: The disappointing data sent all three main indexes on Wall Street deep into the red, and Asia followed suit.
Market participants have been on alert for any signs of yen intervention from Japanese authorities.
Traders bet the backtracking on price pressures rules out June for a first Federal Reserve rate cut, and makes even a July rate cut as less than likely.

site_title: Thai PM says rate cut would have been right for economy, public ‘suffering’
summary: Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin said the country's economy would have benefited from a rate cut, despite the Bank of Thailand's decision to hold interest rates steady at 2.5%. The BOT revised down its 2024 GDP forecast to 2.6% from 2.5-3%. Thavisin urged the central bank to cut rates to help exports, tourism, and the economy, citing regional peers' growth. The government projects 4% growth this year, while the BOT sees a more conservative 2.6%.

images.alt_text: Buildings inside the Bank of Thailand complex. The Monetary Policy Committee voted five to two to maintain the one-day repurchase rate steady at a decade-high 2.5 per cent.
The central bank has so far resisted government pressure to ease policy.
Bank Negara Malaysia is expected to keep its interest rate steady given the economy's robust fundamentals and positive prospects.

site_title: Singapore-based AI startup Mindverse obtains US$5 million in seed funding
summary: Singapore-based AI startup Mindverse has secured US$5 million in seed funding led by venture capital firm Square Peg. Founded in 2022 by former Meta executives and AI researchers, Mindverse will utilize the funding to advance its large personalisation model. The startup's flagship products include MindOS Studio and Mebot, which offer AI-native websites and productivity tools. This investment supports Mindverse's research and product development, aiming to further enhance its AI capabilities.

site_title: Adobe is buying videos for US$3 per minute to build AI model
summary: Adobe is purchasing videos for $3 per minute to build its AI text-to-video generator, aiming to catch up with competitors like OpenAI. The company is seeking over 100 short clips of people engaging in everyday actions and simple anatomy shots, with a pay rate of $2.62 per minute. This move aims to source assets for AI training, differentiating Adobe's models from those trained on user-generated videos. Adobe has previously procured images and videos for AI training, but this new effort highlights the need for vast data to build AI models.

images.alt_text: The deal, which is a mix of cash and stock, is valued at “several hundred million pounds”.
The longtime leader in software for creative arts professionals has faced anxieties that new generative AI-based startups will cut into its market.
IBM said it was using Adobe’s tools, which can generate images from text-based prompts, to help with marketing campaigns.
“It is clear that no realistic remedy would satisfy the concerns the CMA is maintaining,” says Adobe.

site_title: AstraZeneca unveils dividend hike ahead of CEO pay vote at AGM
summary: AstraZeneca announced a 7% increase in its annual dividend for 2024 to $3.10 per share, aiming to maintain or increase the dividend each year as part of its progressive dividend policy. The move comes ahead of its annual general meeting, where investors will vote on a policy that could raise CEO Pascal Soriot's pay package by £1.8 million. Influential proxy advisers Glass Lewis and ISS have urged shareholders to vote against the company's pay policy.

images.alt_text: AstraZeneca has been working on cancer treatments that are more targeted than radiotherapy and chemotherapy, which have been mainstays.

The deal, which includes an US$800 million upfront payment and an additional contingent payment of US$250 million on achieving a specified regulatory milestone, is expected to close by the third quarter of 2024.

site_title: Indonesia’s US$2.5 billion Singapore-inspired oasis to woo tourists, transform Jakarta’s north coast
summary: Indonesian property developer Agung Sedayu Group is launching a $2.5 billion tourism estate, Pantai Indah Kapuk 2, on Jakarta's north coast. The 1,775-hectare project, inspired by Singapore's Sentosa Island, will feature a 27-hole golf course, a Formula 1 racetrack, and a sports complex. The estate aims to attract tourists from Singapore and Malaysia, with the golf course set to open in 2027. The project is one of 14 national initiatives to boost economic activity across key sectors.

images.alt_text: Indosat’s CEO has provided information of the investment plan to Surakarta mayor Gibran Rakabuming Raka.

site_title: Uniqlo operator Fast Retailing’s Q2 profit climbs 7.2%
summary: Fast Retailing, the parent company of Uniqlo, reported a 7.2% increase in Q2 operating profit to 110.4 billion yen (S$976.09 million), driven by a recovery in China and a weaker yen boosting overseas sales. The company expects a third consecutive year of record earnings and maintains its full-year forecast of 450 billion yen. Sales in Western markets, including Europe and North America, are gaining momentum, with flagship stores among the company's top 10 best-sellers.

images.alt_text: Fast Retailing has climbed 15 per cent this year to become the best-performer among 10 other clothing companies worldwide that have a market value of more than US$10 billion, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.
Fast Retailing is not giving up on ambitions in mainland China either, where it already has more than 900 stores.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Thursday’s open tracking Wall Street sell-off; STI down 0.9%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.9% on Thursday, tracking a Wall Street retreat after US inflation data exceeded expectations, dashing hopes for near-term rate cuts. The STI lost 28.11 points to 3,209.41, with losers outnumbering gainers 112 to 44. Banking stocks declined, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index also fell, while European shares rebounded on Wednesday ahead of the European Central Bank's monetary policy decision.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Frasers Property expects a significant profit drop for the first fiscal half.

site_title: Gold flat as sticky US inflation tempers hopes for early rate cut
summary: Gold prices remained unchanged at US$2,337.99 per ounce, as the US dollar and Treasury yields increased following hotter-than-expected inflation data. This tempered hopes for an early interest rate cut, making non-yielding bullion less attractive. The US consumer prices increased more than expected in March, casting doubt on a June interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. Higher interest rates reduce the appeal of holding non-yielding gold.

images.alt_text: Bullion is considered a hedge against inflation and geopolitical uncertainties, but higher interest rates tend to dull the appeal of holding the non-yielding asset.

site_title: Bankers find one bright spot in Hong Kong as buyouts multiply
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index is the world's worst-performing major equity gauge over the past 12 months. Despite a slowdown in dealmaking activity, buyouts of companies listed on the Hong Kong stock exchange are on the rise. Recent deals include L'Occitane International, which is set to go private, and Samsonite International, which is exploring a dual listing in the US. Other potential buyers, such as Carlyle Group and KKR & Co, are also interested in taking control of the luggage-maker. This trend offers a glimmer of hope for Hong Kong bankers.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has gained more than 60 per cent this year and hit an all-time high of US$73,803 in March.

Pedestrians cross a street in the Central district in Hong Kong, China, on Monday, Nov. 20, 2023. In a bad year for deals globally, the value of mergers and acquisitions in mainland China and Hong Kong has fallen 6% to about $185 billion, Bloomberg-compiled data show. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg
The expected rivalry between major bourses to draw new listings comes at a time when the number of companies making it to market has dwindled over the past two years.

Hong Kong customs officers display smuggled gold after seizing 146 kilogrammes of the precious metal disguised as air compressor parts at the city's international airport in Hong Kong on Monday (Apr 8).

site_title: Temasek opens Paris office, plans to invest S$20-25 billion in region over next five years
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore state investor, has opened its new office in Paris, aiming to invest S$20-25 billion in the Europe, Middle East, and Africa (EMEA) region over the next five years. The office, its third in Europe, will enhance Temasek's access to deal flow and partnership opportunities. Temasek chairman Lim Boon Heng described the Paris office as a "significant milestone" for the company, which is celebrating its 50th anniversary this year. The investment will focus on clean energy, digitization, and sustainable living trends, with an emphasis on Europe's leadership position in energy transition technologies.

images.alt_text: The Singapore-Germany relationship is one “that we truly value", Wong told attendees of the reception.
Wong called on German Chancellor Olaf Scholz in Berlin on Tuesday evening.
Wong will visit Berlin from Monday (Apr 8) to Wednesday, and be in Paris from Wednesday to Saturday

site_title: Chinese cities further ease homebuying policies to spur sales
summary: Chinese cities have further eased homebuying policies to boost sales amid a protracted slump in the housing market. As of April 10, 15 cities have removed the lower limit for mortgage rates on first-home purchases, and four cities have relaxed policies on housing provident fund loans. These moves aim to entice homebuyers as prices fall, but investors remain cautious, with China property developer stocks falling 2% on Thursday morning. The residential sales slump has worsened a liquidity crisis at builders and swelled bad loans at state-owned banks.

site_title: China ramps up yuan support as fixing tops estimates by record
summary: China's central bank set the onshore yuan's daily reference rate at 7.0968 per US dollar, its weakest since November and just outside its fixed trading range. This move signals continued support for the currency as the US dollar strengthens, despite forecasts suggesting the yuan would be weaker. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) aims to maintain currency stability, which could limit room for interest rate cuts, with analysts predicting no rate cut until the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: China’s policymakers have always been vigilant of currency pressure which can spill over to local stocks and bonds, despite the fact that the country’s export engine would benefit from a weaker yuan.

site_title: China consumer price gains fade with industry stuck in deflation
summary: China's consumer prices rose 0.1% in March from the prior year, a slowdown from the previous month's 0.7% increase, and industrial prices continued to slump, indicating deflationary pressures persist. This challenges the economy's recovery momentum, with domestic demand struggling to maintain growth after the holiday season.

images.alt_text: Major tourist attractions have been instructed to accept overseas bank cards, as well as support payments in cash and increase foreign-exchange services.
Analysts sat the spending data could be a turning point, as consumption in China has struggled to recover since the lifting of Covid curbs.
Challenges facing the economy are rife, despite activity improving at the start of 2024.

site_title: UK housing market recovery gains more ground, RICS survey shows
summary: The UK housing market saw significant growth in buyer interest, with a net balance of +8 in March, the strongest reading since February 2022. This marks a recovery in the market, driven by cooling inflation and falling mortgage costs. House prices also rose to their highest level since October 2022, with a gauge of +4. A growing share of surveyors expect house prices to rise in the next 12 months. The RICS survey suggests the market will continue to support itself to a certain degree.

images.alt_text: Residential properties in Guildford, UK, on Monday, Sept. 4, 2023. The downturn gripping the UK housing market steepened in August as the cost-of-borrowing squeeze sapped demand, according to a major mortgage lender. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
UK renters are concentrated among younger generations and face a further squeeze.

site_title: Foxconn considers rotating CEOs in management reshuffle
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, is considering introducing a rotating chief executive system as part of a major management overhaul. The move aims to nurture future talent and prevent leadership from becoming entrenched. The company, which assembles iPhones for Apple, has been exploring options for a rotating CEO system, potentially with four CEOs on a six-month rotating basis. This change could end the "one-man rule" system under CEO Young Liu, who has held both CEO and chairman roles since 2019.

images.alt_text: epa10933931 The logo of Foxconn is pictured on a building in Taipei, Taiwan, 23 October 2023. According to state media, Foxconn, a Taiwan-based Apple iPhone manufacturer, has reportedly been subject to a Chinese inquiry regarding tax audits and land use investigations.  EPA-EFE/RITCHIE B. TONGO
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Foxconn is seen outside the company's building in Taipei, Taiwan November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo

Foxconn says overall operations in this year’s first quarter are “gradually entering the traditional off-peak season, and seasonal performance is expected to be similar to that of the past three years”.
Foxconn chairman Liu Young-way says that production capacity for chips for servers is limited, even with strong demand.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, Frasers Property, ESR-Logos Reit, Sabana Reit, Centurion, LHN
summary: Frasers Property expects a significant fall in profit for the first fiscal half-year due to fair value losses and impairment on certain commercial properties in the UK. The real estate company also announced a tie-up with SP Group to install solar panels across seven properties in Singapore. Meanwhile, ESR-Logos Reit is divesting its Australian property for A$65.5 million, and Sabana Reit's trustee presented an indicative timeline for the internalisation of its management function.

images.alt_text: CMG20240327-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.受限股票（restricted stock unit）

site_title: Vietnam orders Netflix to stop advertising, distributing its games
summary: Vietnam's Authority of Broadcasting and Electronic Information ordered Netflix to stop advertising and distributing its games in the country by April 25, as the US streaming platform has not yet secured a license for game services. This decision comes despite Netflix's plans to open an office in Vietnam. The company had launched its gaming services on mobile phones in November 2021. A response from Netflix was not immediately available.

site_title: Airbus facing upfront costs to support jet output increase
summary: Airbus is investing heavily in production capacity, aiming to increase A320neo output to 75 planes per month by 2026, a 50% rise. The company is hiring thousands of new workers and building new assembly lines to support the increase, but is incurring upfront costs. Airbus' finance chief, Thomas Toepfer, expects these costs to pay off over time as the company reaches its production goal. Toepfer also aims to maintain production at 75 planes per month for a certain period to "drive out" ramp-up costs.

images.alt_text: Airbus says it won 170 new orders in the first quarter, with no cancellations.
Spirit Airlines commercial airliners are shown at Las Vegas International Airport in Las Vegas, Nevada, U.S., February 8, 2024.  REUTERS/Mike Blake

Any agreement to split and absorb Spirit would accelerate a change of strategy in the aerospace industry as planemakers bring airplane structures in-house ahead of the next wave of costly investments in digital manufacturing.

site_title: Singaporean writers object to IMDA using their works to train a large language model
summary: Singaporean writers are objecting to the Infocomm Media Development Authority's (IMDA) plan to use their works to train a large language model (LLM) with regional context. The LLM aims to understand Singapore's and Southeast Asia's unique linguistic characteristics and multilingual environment. Writers are frustrated with the short timeframe and lack of clarity about usage and payment terms, citing concerns over copyright infringement and its potential impact on their livelihoods. IMDA has launched a survey to gather views, but writers are demanding more consultation and safeguards.

images.alt_text: Chan Yeng Kit, who is currently permanent secretary of the Ministry of Health, will be appointed to the board of SPH Media Holdings from Mar 15.
More than half a million households are expected to sign up and benefit from the higher-speed Nationwide Broadband Network by 2028.
Thirteen generative AI solutions identified by EnterpriseSG and IMDA will be progressively onboarded to the sandbox by end February.
Carbon emissions from ICT infrastructure, such as data centres (pictured), could grow if not managed.

site_title: US sees imminent missile strike on Israel by Iran, proxies
summary: The US and its allies believe an imminent missile or drone strike by Iran or its proxies against Israeli military and government targets is likely, marking a significant escalation of the six-month-old conflict. The potential assault, possibly using high-precision missiles, may occur in the coming days. Iran has threatened retaliation for an attack on a diplomatic compound in Damascus, and Israel has vowed to retaliate if Iran hits its soil. US officials are helping Israel with intelligence and planning, and Western allies are preparing for potential strikes, including evacuating diplomatic missions.

images.alt_text: Iran warns the US "not to get dragged into Netanyahu’s trap".

site_title: Bank of Korea set to hold interest rates during transition after elections
summary: The Bank of Korea is expected to keep its benchmark interest rate at 3.5% in its upcoming meeting, maintaining its cautious stance on inflation as the country undergoes a major political transition. The decision is in line with market expectations and reflects the central bank's concerns about the potential for inflation to flare up again, despite a rebound in exports and industrial production. The bank's policy settings are unlikely to change soon, with two board members set to depart and the governor signaling no rate cuts in the first half of 2024.

images.alt_text: Lee Jae-myung has won a seat in the city of Incheon to the west of the capital, Seoul.
South Korean authorities have been trying to introduce reforms across financial markets as the export powerhouse attempts to improve governance, transparency and communication.
Housing prices are a key barometer of risks for developers.
The Bank of Korea said a premature shift away from tighter monetary settings could undermine policy credibility and send the wrong message to financial markets about debt and risk-taking.

site_title: US to consider concerns about China’s Brite in trade sanction decisions
summary: The US Commerce Department is considering concerns about Brite Semiconductor's ties to Chinese chipmaker SMIC and its connections to Chinese military suppliers, amid reports that American firms, including Wells Fargo, have invested in the company. Brite's shares were set to begin trading on the Shanghai Stock Exchange the following day, prompting the department's review. This development may impact the company's potential addition to a trade sanction list.

images.alt_text: In acting as the standard-bearer for this policy, Yellen is rejecting fundamental principles of economics to justify a policy of restricting public access to affordable and clean technology.
Trump has floated an increase in China tariffs to at least 60 per cent if he is elected.
Biden officials are urging the Netherlands to stop ASML Holding from servicing and repairing sensitive chipmaking equipment that Chinese clients purchased.
The US imposed rules last October barring exports and companies such as Nvidia and AMD have been affected by the spat.

site_title: ESR-Logos Reit to divest Australia property at 7.4% premium in A$65.5 million deal
summary: ESR-Logos Reit is divesting a logistics property in Australia for A$65.5 million, a 7.4% premium to its independent valuation of A$61 million. The sale will be used to repay borrowings, finance acquisitions, and fund asset improvement. The divestment is not expected to impact the Reit's net asset value or distribution per unit for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2024. The Reit will retain 71 properties across Singapore, Japan, and Australia, and investments in three property funds in Australia.

images.alt_text: Frasers Property expects a significant profit drop for the first fiscal half.

site_title: US SEC warns Uniswap Labs of potential enforcement action
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has warned Uniswap Labs, the developer of the largest cryptocurrency exchange, of potential enforcement action. The reason for the warning is unclear but is part of the SEC's campaign to apply US securities law to digital asset companies, such as Coinbase. Uniswap's decentralized finance platform operates on a peer-to-peer system and has expressed concerns that the SEC's actions target "even the best actors building technology on blockchains." The SEC declined to comment on the warning.

site_title: ECB to set up June rate cut after rapid inflation fall
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is likely to keep borrowing costs at a record high on Thursday but signal a possible rate cut as early as June, following a sharp slowdown in inflation and economic weakness. The ECB has kept rates steady since September but is awaiting more comfortable wage indicators before making a decision. A June cut could be a compromise between dovish and hawkish policymakers, with markets pricing in 80 basis points of cuts this year. The Fed's policy easing could disrupt the ECB's plans, but a June cut would pre-empt the Fed and maintain the ECB's credibility.

images.alt_text: While banks were slowly turning less cautious – at least about extending home loans – households and companies showed little appetite for taking on fresh debt, the ECB’s quarterly Bank Lending Survey showed.
In June, the ECB will also have its own updated forecasts on inflation and economic growth.
While ECB policymakers are likely to firm up expectations for a June rate cut next week, they are unlikely to commit to any subsequent moves.

site_title: Money laundering accused slapped with 6 new charges for forgery, lying to CAD
summary: Wang Baosen, one of 10 foreign nationals accused of money laundering, has been slapped with six new charges, bringing the total to eight. He is set to plead guilty on April 16, despite his lawyer's indication that he will proceed with the plea. The new charges include forgery and lying to the officer in charge of his case, related to allegedly possessing S$600,000 in benefits of criminal conduct and using S$1.5 million in criminal proceeds to purchase a condominium. Wang faces a total of eight charges, including money laundering.

site_title: Europe: Shares rebound from one-month low; ECB rate verdict up next
summary: European shares rebounded 0.1% after hitting a near one-month low, with banks and energy sectors leading the gains. The recovery comes after a high US inflation reading on Wednesday and ahead of the European Central Bank's monetary policy decision on Thursday. Investors now expect the ECB to hold rates steady, with a possible June rate cut on the table. Technology stocks also rebounded, while the real estate and utilities sectors fell.

images.alt_text: A gauge of European aerospace and defence stocks slumped 3.7 per cent, logging its steepest one-day slide in over a year.

site_title: UBS faces tougher rules in Swiss response to Credit Suisse rescue
summary: The Swiss government has proposed tougher capital requirements for UBS, one of the country's largest banks, following the Credit Suisse takeover. The new measures aim to prevent a repeat of the Credit Suisse collapse, which was the biggest merger of banks of systemic importance since the 2007-2009 financial crisis. The government's report recommends tightening capital requirements, giving extra powers to the market regulator, and strengthening the financial position of subsidiaries. UBS shares fell 2.7% after the announcement, but the bank's stock is still up 58% since it took over Credit Suisse last year.

images.alt_text: UBS put the Credit Suisse venture up for sale after taking control of its smaller Swiss rival when it collapsed last year.
UBS provides wealth management services for clients with accounts of more than US$2 million, and this standard will be applied to clients held by Credit Suisse Securities.
The new programme, which would usually run for two years, is set to begin on April 3.
UBS chief executive officer Sergio Ermotti received 14.4 million Swiss francs (S$21.4 million) for his first nine months on the job, including 12.3 million francs in variable compensation.

site_title: Cordlife seeks to extend AGM, sustainability report deadlines as it fails to finalise accounts
summary: Cordlife, a Singapore-based cord-blood bank, is seeking a two-week extension for its annual general meeting (AGM) and sustainability report deadlines due to ongoing investigations and unfinalized financials. The company aims to hold the AGM and issue the sustainability report by May 14, rather than the original deadline of April 30. This extension is necessary to finalize audited FY2023 financials and assess the impact of test results. The company has also submitted an application to the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority for an extension to convene the FY2023 AGM and file its annual return.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei

site_title: S$910 million Far East Shopping Centre deal falls through after URA rejects redevelopment proposal
summary: The S$910 million collective sale of Far East Shopping Centre has fallen through after the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) rejected a redevelopment proposal by Glory Property Developments, citing that the site does not meet the eligibility criteria for the Strategic Development Incentive (SDI) scheme. The deal was conditional on URA's approval to extend the site's gross floor area under the SDI scheme, which was rejected on January 24. Glory Property will avoid any forfeiture of its deposit, and the Collective Sale Committee will consider next steps for the collective sale.

images.alt_text: Land betterment charge rates for non-landed residential use were raised by 0.1 per cent on average.
PGIM Real Estate has put three floors for sale at a guide price of S$54.6 million.
More than 60 per cent of owners are in favour of lowering the reserve price of Island View condominium (pictured) to S$532 million.

site_title: Google investing US$1 billion to boost connectivity to Japan via two subsea cables
summary: Google is investing US$1 billion in two subsea cables, Proa and Taihei, to improve digital connectivity between the US and Japan, and multiple Pacific island countries and territories. The cables will be built in collaboration with the US and Japan, aiming to create trusted and resilient networks in the Pacific region. This investment follows a joint US-Japan commitment to fund subsea cables last October, with the goal of enhancing global internet connectivity.

images.alt_text: The experts say it is very likely that a Google deal for HubSpot would trigger challenges from US and European antitrust regulators, given their growing aversion to technology giants getting bigger through acquisitions.
Alphabet has met with Morgan Stanley investment bankers in recent days about a potential offer for HubSpot.
The potential move suggests the Alphabet unit still has not figured out how to incorporate the new, fast-growing technology.
Google’s agreement to retroactively delete user information is a significant concession as it forms the backbone of the company’s lucrative advertising business.

site_title: Private equity money finding sweet deals in mid-market
summary: Private equity firms are increasingly targeting mid-market companies, defined as those with an enterprise value between $50 million and $3 billion. Healthcare and tech-related services are the most popular investment themes. In emerging markets, such as India, private equity has been profitable due to the country's large domestic market and stable economy. Mid-market returns are a few percentage points higher than large-cap deals, but with wider dispersion, making it an attractive space for smaller funds. Experts predict that the mid-market space will continue to be a key area for private equity deal-making, driven by structural attributes and cyclical factors.

images.alt_text: The Blackstone headquarters in New York. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg
Keppel's chief executive Loh Chin Hua said Keppel, which had its roots in the oil and gas industry, has made “significant progress” over the years to transform and adapt to the changing environment.
Market data shows private equity and private credit have significantly outperformed traditional asset classes in recent years.

site_title: Toyota puts US$300 million into VC funds for climate, science startups
summary: Toyota Motor is investing $300 million into its venture arm, Toyota Ventures, to support early-stage startups focused on climate and deep technologies. The investment will be split evenly between a climate fund and a deep technology fund, increasing total assets under management to over $800 million. The move comes as companies worldwide have pulled back on venture activities amid a downturn, with 122 venture units launching in 2022, compared to about 60 last year. Toyota Ventures aims to provide access to disruptive companies and capitalize on long-term opportunities.

images.alt_text: A trainer working with students in Volkswagen’s lab for high-voltage technology in Zwickau; new technologies are shaking up the auto industry in ways that could still be very painful for established companies and their workers.
Chinese brands now make up 10 per cent of the entire market.

site_title: McKinsey begins hundreds of job cuts with client demand muted: sources
summary: McKinsey is cutting approximately 360 jobs globally, affecting 3% of its specialist and technical staff. The reductions are across various divisions, including design, data engineering, and software. Traditional consultants will not be impacted. The move comes as client demand for consulting services slows, following a trend among firms such as Ernst & Young and Accenture. Despite generating a record $16 billion in revenue last year, McKinsey has warned of performance issues for 3,000 consultants and offered early retirement packages to some UK staff.

site_title: Australia plans IRA-style act to drive green manufacturing tilt
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese plans to announce an Inflation Reduction Act-style program to stimulate green manufacturing industries and drive the nation's economy beyond its traditional minerals extraction base. The "Future Made in Australia Act" aims to boost investment and create jobs in green manufacturing and high-tech by year's end, with the policy set to be a major feature of the government's second-term agenda. The move aims to capitalize on Australia's vast renewable energy resources and compete with nations like the US, which has a similar program.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Australian Treasurer Jim Chalmers poses for a photograph as he arrives to attend a G20 finance ministers' and Central Bank governors' meeting at Gandhinagar, India, July 18, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo
Confidence in the economic outlook has slipped in April.
Michele Bullock knows the RBA has only one chance to get the timing of the easing cycle right.

site_title: South Korea opposition wins landslide parliamentary vote in resounding blow to Yoon
summary: South Korea's liberal opposition, led by Lee Jae-myung, has won a landslide victory in the parliamentary election, securing 175 seats and dealing a significant blow to President Yoon Suk-yeol's conservative party. The Democratic Party fell short of a supermajority but will control parliament, allowing them to block Yoon's legislation and implement their own economic recovery plans. Yoon's popularity has suffered amid a cost-of-living crisis and scandals, and his ability to pass legislation is likely to be further inhibited by the poor showing of his party.

images.alt_text: Lee Jae-myung, leader of the main opposition Democratic Party, speaks during a campaign rally for the upcoming 22nd parliamentary election in Seoul, South Korea, April 9, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Soo-hyeon
The Democratic Party of Lee Jae-myung and its satellites are forecast to win between 184 and 197 seats, up from 156 in the last parliament.

Nearly 25 million people had cast their ballots as of 2pm (0500 GMT), including 14 million who had voted before election day, making it highest ever turnout for a parliamentary election at this point.
South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol casts his early vote on Apr 5 for the country's elections. A major poll shows his party has 37 per cent of the country's support.

site_title: Crypto trading concentration a ‘considerable concern’, EU watchdog says
summary: The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) has expressed concerns over the high concentration of crypto trading, with Binance alone accounting for about half the market, and 10 exchanges processing 90% of trades. The bloc is introducing comprehensive rules to regulate trading in cryptoassets, requiring exchanges to be authorized. The lack of diversity in trading volumes, with the euro playing a minor role, raises concerns about the impact of a failure on the sector, highlighting the need for greater regulation and oversight.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has gained more than 60 per cent this year and hit an all-time high of US$73,803 in March.
Branding for Bitcoin cryptocurrency. Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

site_title: Post-rebranding, Granite Asia’s veteran partners dig in for the long haul
summary: Granite Asia, the rebranded Asia unit of GGV Capital, has expanded its asset classes beyond venture capital to include funding and supporting founders with equity financing, credit products, and other forms of support. Senior managing partners Jenny Lee and Foo Jixun, who co-founded GGV from 2000, will leverage their expertise to invest in various themes, including consumer growth and transformation, and energy transition. The firm aims to provide multifaceted financing and support to entrepreneurs and companies in the Asia-Pacific region, where Lee and Foo believe they have an edge in operating.

images.alt_text: Granite Asia will be led by senior managing partners Jenny Lee (above) and Foo Jixun.
GGV Capital's Jenny Lee will co-lead the firm's Asia partnership investing mainly in China, South-east Asia and South Asia.

site_title: Singapore financial institutions consistent with global trends for gender balance: report
summary: Singapore's financial institutions have achieved a balance consistent with global trends for gender diversity, according to the 2023 Global Gender Balance Index. Despite a 14% increase in female appointees, only 9% of new appointees were women. Singapore's institutions, including the CPF Board, OCBC, DBS, MAS, GIC, and Temasek, have seen improvements in their scores over the past three years, with the country's overall scores on par with other Asean countries.

images.alt_text: Female representation on the Singapore companies’ boards have strengthened, with one in four board seats being filled by women last year, versus one in five in 2022, in line with the regional trend.
MOM data showed that the pay gap in the accommodation and food services industry as well as the manufacturing industry widened in 2023 compared to 2018.

The Goldman Sachs & Co. logo is displayed at the company's booth on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., on Friday, July 19, 2013. U.S. stocks fell after benchmark equities gauges rose to records yesterday, after disappointing earnings from Google Inc. and Microsoft Corp. overshadowed better-than-forecast results from General Electric Co. Photographer: Scott Eells/Bloomberg

site_title: Hedge fund manager Larry Robbins fears hit to NYC as he joins wealth migration
summary: Hedge fund manager Larry Robbins, founder of Glenview Capital Management, is relocating to Florida, where he plans to keep New York as his professional home. Robbins, 54, will commute to Manhattan and largely follow his firm's three-day office policy. He's concerned about the impact of wealth migration on New York, citing a dwindling pool of cash for education and the potential loss of high-earning individuals. Robbins aims to create a public-private partnership, exemplified by his new ice hockey facility in Palm Beach Gardens, to cultivate and develop the next layer of financially successful individuals in New York.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians cross a street in the Central district in Hong Kong, China, on Monday, Nov. 20, 2023. In a bad year for deals globally, the value of mergers and acquisitions in mainland China and Hong Kong has fallen 6% to about $185 billion, Bloomberg-compiled data show. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title: KKR, HSBC talk up China opportunities after lengthy sell-off
summary: KKR & Co and HSBC Asset Management expressed optimism about China's economy, despite global investors withdrawing billions. They noted signs of rebounding confidence in China, with investors gradually returning to the market. The firms see opportunities in sectors such as tech, growth stocks, and the "new economy" in China, with India also emerging as a key market for HSBC. Both investment managers advise clients to invest in private credit, a nascent asset class gaining traction in the region.

images.alt_text: “This transaction is another important step in the execution of our strategy and enables us to focus our resources on higher value opportunities across our international network,” says chief executive Noel Quinn.
Quinn is hosting the bank’s three-day inaugural Global Investment Summit that kicked off in Hong Kong earlier Monday.
India will reach the maximum 10 per cent weighting in the gauge, making it crucial for funds tracking the index to add the nation’s debt to their portfolios.
HSBC says the majority of its institutional and retail investor base backed the board and the structure of the bank.

site_title: Meta debuts new AI chip, aiming to decrease reliance on Nvidia
summary: Meta has unveiled a new AI chip, the Meta Training and Inference Accelerator (MTIA), to power its AI services and reduce reliance on Nvidia's expensive chips. The move is part of a broader trend among tech giants, including Amazon, Microsoft, and Google, to develop in-house AI chips.
