Meta's investment in AI is expected to reach $35 billion in 2024, with the new chip aimed at supporting its AI services, including content ranking and recommendation. The company's shift is driven by the growing demand for computing power in AI.

images.alt_text: The government reported more than 50,000 such cases to various social media platforms, including Meta’s Facebook and TikTok, in the first three months of this year alone.

(FILES) This photograph taken on January 12, 2023, shows a smartphone and a computer screen displaying the reflected logos of Instagram app and its parent company Meta in Toulouse, south-western France. Meta on March 5, 2024, said that it was looking into widespread outages of its Facebook, Instagram and Threads platforms after users around the world were locked out of their accounts. (Photo by Lionel BONAVENTURE / AFP)
Meta sued the FTC in November in a broad constitutional challenge against the agency’s ability to be both an investigative body and an adjudicative one.
FILE PHOTO: A 3D printed Facebook's new rebrand logo Meta is seen in front of displayed Google logo in this illustration taken on November 2, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Green vs growth: Can Singapore’s maritime sector decarbonise without losing pace?
summary: Singapore's maritime sector aims to decarbonize without losing pace, with ports setting a 60% reduction in emissions by 2030 and net-zero by 2050. However, challenges persist due to limited availability and high costs of alternative fuels, with liquefied natural gas currently holding the top spot. The sector faces technical, cost, and regulatory hurdles, but the government is committed to supporting the transition, including discounts for ships using cleaner fuels and investments in port automation and digitalization. Coordination among stakeholders is crucial to achieve operational efficiency and reduce fuel consumption.

images.alt_text: There will be a lot to talk about on decarbonisation next week, including about the relative advantages of various alternative fuels and technologies.
In the past three or four weeks liner shipping companies' costs have soared due to the Red Sea crisis. Unsurprisingly, they are passing on these rises through increased rates.
The Keppel Sakra Cogen Plant is projected to abate 220,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide a year – the equivalent of taking some 47,000 motor cars off the road.

site_title: Biden welcomes Japan, Philippines leaders at White House summit
summary: US President Joe Biden welcomed Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida and Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos Jr at a White House summit on April 10. The meeting focused on joint defence cooperation to deter China's aggressive actions, including South China Sea incursions. The US and Japan have agreed on 70 defence cooperation agreements, including upgrading the US military command structure in Japan. The leaders also announced plans for a joint lunar space mission and artificial intelligence research projects. The summit aims to counter China's efforts to isolate Japan and the Philippines, and is seen as a significant boost to Japan's global influence.

images.alt_text: (FILES) People walk past a Taiwanese flag in New Taipei City on January 13, 2024. Taiwan's freshly elected lawmakers will meet from February 1, 2024 with a new party emerging with an outsized influence over legislation after breaking through the self-ruled island's long-entrenched two-party system. (Photo by Sam Yeh / AFP)
Japan’s economy is at an inflection point, with the central bank raising interest rates in March for the first time in 17 years and stocks hitting a record high, Kishida said.

site_title: Preventing a war over Taiwan
summary: The US and China's diplomatic formula of "one China" has helped keep the peace over Taiwan for 50 years, but its effectiveness is being questioned. China considers Taiwan a renegade province and may try to attack it by 2027. The US has reaffirmed its commitment to defending Taiwan, but its policy of "strategic ambiguity" is being reevaluated. To deter China, Taiwan needs to become a strong military power, and the US should bolster its military deterrence and position its forces in the region to reduce ambiguity. The goal is to extend the status quo indefinitely, but a failed invasion of Taiwan could jeopardize China's control of the Communist Party.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden (right) and China's President Xi Jinping (left) have managed to maintain a veneer of diplomatic stability despite deep mutual suspicion between their countries, and as their governments pursue export controls, sanctions and tariffs.
Lai Ching-te (middle) of the Democratic Progressive Party won the recent elections in Taiwan, but did not secure an outright majority.
Speaking to reporters at the airport before his departure, Ma described his trip to China as “a journey of peace and a journey of friendship”.

site_title: Oil settles higher after Israeli strike overshadows ceasefire talks
summary: Oil prices rose 1.2% on April 10, settling at $90.48 per barrel, amid concerns that a ceasefire in Gaza might stall after an Israeli airstrike killed three Hamas operatives. Brent crude futures and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures also increased, with Brent up $1.06 and WTI up $0.98. A potential conflict could draw in Iran, a key OPEC producer, and support prices. US crude stocks rose by 5.8 million barrels, while Mexico's decision to curb exports to supply domestic refineries contributed to the price increase.

images.alt_text: Brent posts its first decline in five sessions and WTI its first in seven as a fresh round of Israel-Hamas ceasefire discussions in Cairo raises hopes of a breakthrough.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat after hot inflation report
summary: US stocks retreated on Wednesday after a report showing US consumer prices rose 0.4% in March, exceeding expectations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.1%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index declined 1.0% and 0.8%, respectively. Futures markets now see only a slim chance of a Federal Reserve interest rate cut in June, dampening expectations for imminent rate cuts. Individual stocks, such as Delta Air Lines, fell despite reporting better-than-expected earnings.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - APRIL 10: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on April 10, 2024 in New York City. As new inflation data released today showed a continued rise, stocks fell across the board with the Dow falling over 400 points.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: South-east Asia to drive growth in developing Asia, offset China’s slowdown: ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) forecasts South-east Asia to drive growth in developing Asia, offsetting China's slowdown, with the subregion expected to grow 4.6% in 2024 and 4.7% in 2025. The Philippines and Vietnam are expected to chart the highest growth, with both countries projected to expand by 6% in 2024 and 6.2% in 2025. Inflation in South-east Asia is expected to cool to 3.2% in 2024 and 3% in 2025, driven by the lagged effects of tight monetary policy and moderating inflation.

images.alt_text: Asean+3's current sunny growth prospects offer a timely opportunity for the region's economies to rebuild policy space, says Amro.

site_title: More robust laws will help, not hurt, Singapore’s business-friendly reputation
summary: Singapore's business-friendly environment has attracted significant investment, but recent high-profile cases of money laundering and corporate malfeasance have raised concerns. The country's pro-business reputation has been tarnished, and the government has proposed new measures to strengthen anti-money laundering regulations, including harsher penalties for corporate service providers. Industry players have raised concerns that stricter rules could hinder the ease of doing business, but robust laws and guidelines are seen as necessary to protect legitimate businesses and ensure the country's edge.

images.alt_text: Commercial buildings in the central business district in Singapore, on Saturday, Feb. 17, 2024. Singapore expects its budget to swing back to a surplus in the fiscal year beginning April, as recent tax increases shore up revenue and help pay for social assistance seen as priority for the city-state's new generation of leaders. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: Fed seen waiting until September to cut rates
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to wait until September to cut interest rates, with traders betting on a first quarter-point rate cut at its September 17-18 meeting. The Fed's decision comes after a government report showed inflation rose 0.4% in March, exceeding expectations, and accelerating to 3.5% from a year earlier. This makes a June or July rate cut unlikely, with analysts predicting only one more rate cut by the end of the year.

site_title: To ease AGM crunch, SGX RegCo should push listcos to hold meetings early, and on weekends
summary: SGX RegCo is urging listed companies to hold AGMs early and on weekends to alleviate congestion. A review last year found that about half of STI-listed companies held AGMs within the last two weeks of April, resulting in four clashes. To address this, SGX RegCo maintains a calendar of AGMs for large issuers, requiring companies to choose alternative dates if clashes occur. This move aims to ensure shareholders' ability to attend AGMs without being curtailed by clustering events.

images.alt_text: SGX RegCo will require large issuers to take the lead, to ensure that their AGMs do not conflict with the AGM of another large issuer

site_title: What if global emissions went down instead of up?
summary: Global greenhouse gas emissions may finally stop rising and head into long-term decline, with a 70% chance of a global peak in emissions by 2024. This could lead to profound shifts in politics, psychology, and financing of climate action, making fossil fuel investments look like a dead end and green investments a competitive necessity. A global decline would also counter the argument that cutting emissions is pointless, as China, the biggest emitter, is experiencing a surge in wind and solar power growth. However, a global peak in emissions is unlikely to be enough to contain warming, with years of steep and prolonged falls needed to meet the Paris Agreement's 1.5-degrees-Celsius temperature goal.

site_title: Ping An Trust delays payment due to property market downturn
summary: Ping An Trust, a Chinese insurance subsidiary, delayed a trust product repayment due to the property market downturn. The "Funing 615" trust plan, launched in 2021, matured on March 29 but failed to meet repayment obligations. The firm is actively following up on project development and filing a lawsuit against the property developer. Despite this, Ping An Trust's overall performance remains stable, with 14.55 billion yuan in revenue last year and 662.5 billion yuan of assets under management. The delayed repayment adds to concerns about the financial market's stress caused by China's property crisis.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Ping An Insurance is seen at the Global Mobile Internet Conference (GMIC) at the National Convention Center in Beijing, China April 27, 2018. Picture taken April 27, 2018. REUTERS/Damir Sagolj/File Photo

site_title: Striking while the flat iron’s hot
summary: Eleven Seventeen Capital, a Singaporean food and beverage group, was founded by husband-and-wife duo Stanley Seow and Andryl Foo, both former commercial bankers. The group's concept is built around business needs, with each concept tailored to specific locations. Fat Belly, a casual steakhouse, was born out of the group's need to efficiently use space and cater to a specific customer base. Since its launch, Fat Belly has become the group's most successful concept, with a strong value proposition and cannibalizing growth from other brands. The group has expanded to other concepts, including Meadesmoore and Market Bistro, but faces challenges from post-pandemic spending slowdowns.

images.alt_text: Soon Lee Heng’s 80,000 sq ft headquarters in Tampines, which in 2017 marked its initial foray into property management.
Lim Tian Wee, founder of Gryphon is leading the brand's pivot towards beverages.

site_title: Why carbon management matters to businesses
summary: International efforts to accelerate climate action have intensified, with over 149 countries committing to net-zero targets. Corporates are also committing to decarbonization, with 929 companies from the Forbes 2000 list setting net-zero targets in 2023. Carbon management is becoming a key facet in corporate strategy, driven by regulatory mandates, client demands, and unlocking financial incentives. Companies must understand and measure their emissions, set reduction targets, and disclose progress to meet these pressures, with support from initiatives such as Enterprise Singapore's Enterprise Sustainability Programme.

images.alt_text: There will be a lot to talk about on decarbonisation next week, including about the relative advantages of various alternative fuels and technologies.
Bain & Company surveyed more than 600 executives in oil and gas, utilities, chemicals, mining, and agribusiness during the 2023 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Dubai and the weeks after.

site_title: Tesla’s Musk to meet Modi in India and announce investment plans: sources
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk is set to meet Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi in New Delhi on April 22, where he is expected to announce plans to invest and open a new factory in the country. This visit comes after Tesla's lobbying efforts to lower import taxes on electric vehicles in India. Musk's announcement is expected to include details on his investment plans, although the trip details are currently confidential.

images.alt_text: A Starlink dish and router in California. The company has 5,600 active satellites deployed, but plans to add tens of thousands more.
The contract to supply SpaceX’s Starlink communications terminals runs from June of last year through next month, and the official declined to say if it would be renewed.
Elon Musk says a lack of advanced chips was hampering the training of Grok’s version 2 model.

site_title: Hard math is driving Thailand’s race to reinvention
summary: Thailand is facing a demographic crisis due to a low fertility rate, with a total fertility rate of 1.3, barely half the replacement level. The country's population is projected to shrink by 50% over the next six decades if urgent measures are not taken. To address this, the government is overhauling surrogacy services, lifting a ban on foreigners using surrogates, and allowing gay and lesbian couples to have children. The government is also pushing for interest rate cuts and fiscal policy changes to boost economic growth and stimulate tourism, with a proposed 500-billion-baht stimulus package.

images.alt_text: Thai prime minister Srettha Thavisin leaves after a presser regarding the governments proposed 10,000 baht digital wallet scheme at Government House in Bangkok on April 10, 2024. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)
The report may prompt the House of Representatives to push ahead with a bill to legalise casinos and other forms of gambling.
Many in the industry believe a legal casino market in Thailand would be a huge success in drawing overseas visitors, providing strong competition for the world’s biggest gambling hub Macau.

site_title: Elon Musk’s Starlink profits are more elusive than investors think
summary: Elon Musk's Starlink satellite business is reportedly losing hundreds of dollars on each ground terminal, contradicting Musk's claims of profitability. The company's accounting practices have been described as "more of an art than a science," with some quarters showing less consistent cash flow than reported. Despite plans to add tens of thousands of satellites, capacity constraints and performance issues continue to plague the service, with speeds decreasing in urban areas and increasing in less-populated regions. Starlink is struggling to secure lucrative corporate contracts, and investors expect the company to raise more money or receive a cash infusion from Musk to meet growing revenue projections.

images.alt_text: The contract to supply SpaceX’s Starlink communications terminals runs from June of last year through next month, and the official declined to say if it would be renewed.

site_title: China’s mammoth effort to get foreigners to spend, spend, spend
summary: China's digital payment system, dominated by Alipay and WeChat Pay, has created obstacles for foreign visitors who struggle to pay for goods and services using QR code scanning. Foreign bank cards and cash are largely unusable, forcing visitors to rely on Chinese colleagues or find alternative methods. Despite efforts to improve services, including linking international cards and increasing limits on mobile payments, concerns over cost and security remain. The central bank has urged banks and payment platforms to streamline registration processes and offer more payment options, but progress has been slow due to high fees and technical issues.

images.alt_text: Cotti Coffee has expanded its footprint to more than 330 of China’s nearly 400 county-level cities,
The Francis Scott Key Bridge’s collapse has severely disrupted Baltimore post operations, with US officials saying it could take weeks to a month to clear the waterway.
The exterior of Jinxin Reproductive Hospital in Chengdu, in China's Sichuan province. Jinxin Fertility Group is expanding in South-east Asia with an investment in an Indonesian company.
An aerial view of residential buildings under construction in Hangzhou, in eastern China's Zhejiang province.

site_title: Economists sound the alarm on valuations as stock market approaches bursting point
summary: Economists warn of a potential stock market bubble, citing "parabolic" price charts and astronomical valuations. Notable companies like Nvidia, Palantir, and MicroStrategy are trading like small caps, with Nvidia poised to become the world's most valuable company. The AI boom differs from the dotcom boom due to the leaders' profitability. The meme stock market, including Trump Media & Technology, is also showing signs of a bubble. Strategists, such as Paul Dietrich, are sounding the alarm about valuations, citing the S&P 500's "bizarre" overvaluation and the impending expiration of the bull market's lifespan.

images.alt_text: In early Asian trade, Hong Kong piled on more than one percent, while Sydney, Taipei and Wellington were also in the green, though Shanghai edged lower.
Brent posts its first decline in five sessions and WTI its first in seven as a fresh round of Israel-Hamas ceasefire discussions in Cairo raises hopes of a breakthrough.
When you buy shares there will be times you are unwittingly fooled by the stock market. Having the right mindset is key.
Branding for Bitcoin cryptocurrency. Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

site_title: European ports turned into ‘car parks’ as vehicle imports pile up
summary: European ports are experiencing congestion due to a surge in imported vehicles, with Chinese electric car makers contributing to the issue. Executives say some companies are booking shipping slots without onward transportation, leading to delays and "car parks" at ports. Congestion is also caused by a lack of truck drivers and equipment, and some vehicles have been stuck in ports for up to 18 months. Industry experts attribute the problem to a slowdown in sales and logistical bottlenecks, and Chinese carmakers' struggles to adapt to the European market.

images.alt_text: The Francis Scott Key Bridge’s collapse has severely disrupted Baltimore post operations, with US officials saying it could take weeks to a month to clear the waterway.

site_title: US accounting watchdog hits KPMG affiliate with record penalty over exam cheating
summary: The US accounting watchdog, PCAOB, has imposed a record $25 million civil penalty on KPMG Netherlands for widespread improper answer sharing and "multiple misrepresentations" during exams from 2017-2022. This marks the first time an individual has been sanctioned in connection with exam cheating. KPMG's former head of assurance has been permanently barred from the industry. The penalty is a result of an "egregious" and widespread nature of the misconduct, exceeding the PCAOB's previous record of $8 million.

site_title: Can Taylor Swift offset the climate impact of her private jets? It is complicated
summary: Taylor Swift has purchased over double the credits needed to offset her travel emissions from her private jet, which emits around 1,216 metric tonnes of carbon dioxide per year. However, the carbon offset market lacks transparency and has a wide variance in credit quality. Experts say that the market's opacity makes it difficult to verify the effectiveness of offsets, and that not knowing specific credits is "basically meaningless." Swift's publicist has not clarified the details of her credits, and critics argue that her purchase of offsets may not be enough to counter her emissions, with some projects potentially having little impact on reducing greenhouse gases.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift, 34, also has a significant real estate portfolio, with homes in New York, Beverly Hills, Nashville and a coastal mansion in Rhode Island.

site_title: Switzerland stops short of giving regulator power to fine banks
summary: Switzerland's government has stopped short of granting its banking regulator, Finma, the power to fine lenders, despite backing from the finance minister. The move comes after the near-collapse of Credit Suisse and its takeover by UBS Group, highlighting concerns over the country's financial sector dominated by a single behemoth bank. The government plans to expand Finma's powers, including introducing a senior manager regime, making leaders liable for misconduct, and strengthening the regulator's ability to obtain information from banks.

images.alt_text: UBS put the Credit Suisse venture up for sale after taking control of its smaller Swiss rival when it collapsed last year.

site_title: US: Wall Street drops over 1% after hot consumer prices data
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday after a stronger-than-expected inflation reading dampened hopes of the Federal Reserve's monetary easing cycle. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 221.39 points, or 0.57%, to 38,662.28. The CPI rose 0.4% month-over-month, exceeding expectations, and yields on government bonds spiked. Traders slashed bets on the Fed cutting interest rates in June, citing the possibility of no rate cuts this year.

images.alt_text: Allocations to stocks have surged since an October low on the back of upbeat projections for economic growth.

site_title: US consumer prices rise more than expected in March
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.4% in March, exceeding expectations, driven mainly by increases in petrol and shelter costs, including rents. This surge casts doubt on a potential interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve in June. Petrol and shelter costs accounted for more than half of the increase in the Consumer Price Index (CPI).

images.alt_text: Allocations to stocks have surged since an October low on the back of upbeat projections for economic growth.

site_title: Hong Kong set to approve its first spot Bitcoin ETFs in April: sources
summary: Hong Kong is set to approve its first spot Bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs) in April, according to sources. This would make Hong Kong the first city in Asia to offer the popular ETFs, faster than industry expectations. Regulators have sped up the approval process, driven by Hong Kong's efforts to improve its attractiveness for financial trading. At least four mainland Chinese and Hong Kong asset managers have submitted applications to launch the ETFs, which could bring in fresh global investment and push crypto adoption.

images.alt_text: South Koreans have been active in the latest digital-asset bull market and are famed for their ardor for smaller cryptocurrencies, not just market-leader Bitcoin.
Branding for Bitcoin cryptocurrency. Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

The neon logos of Bitcoin and Ethereum cryptocurrencies in the window of a crypto exchange in Warsaw, Poland, on Thursday, March 14, 2024. Bitcoin extended a retreat from its latest record high amid an intensifying debate about whether the bull run in cryptocurrencies is evidence of speculative froth in global markets. Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

site_title: In an era of great power politics, countries must cooperate to protect multilateralism: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of international cooperation in a world of great power politics. He highlighted the strong Singapore-Germany relationship, citing shared values such as upholding the rule of law, multilateralism, and open trading systems. Wong's comments come as countries navigate increased competition, underscoring the need for global collaboration to achieve better outcomes.

images.alt_text: Wong called on German Chancellor Olaf Scholz in Berlin on Tuesday evening.
Wong will visit Berlin from Monday (Apr 8) to Wednesday, and be in Paris from Wednesday to Saturday

site_title: Wee Hur looks beyond construction and real estate to drive future growth
summary: Wee Hur Holdings, a Singapore-based construction company, has diversified into various sectors, including fund management, property development, and student housing. The company's revenue and net profit grew 4.1% and 45.1% year-over-year, respectively, in its latest financial year. Wee Hur sold a 49.9% stake in its Australian-focused student accommodation fund for A$567.9 million. The company's CEO, Goh Wee Ping, believes that diversification is key to its future growth and has invested in around 10 venture capital funds and 14 startups globally. Despite challenges in the construction industry, Wee Hur's diversification has proven successful, and the company is now exploring opportunities in other sectors.

images.alt_text: Emilia Teo, managing director of real estate investment firm TE Capital.
The Assembly Place's CEO Eugene Lim wants to hit 4,000 rooms by end of 2024 and be the number one in the market.
The Seletar Mall, which opened  about nine years ago, is owned by Cuscaden Peak Investments and United Engineers.

site_title: IMF warns industrial policy no magic cure for slow economic growth
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that industrial policy initiatives, such as subsidies and tax breaks, are not a magic cure for slow economic growth. The IMF cautions that these policies can lead to high fiscal costs, capture by special interests, and negative spillovers. Instead, the IMF recommends a broader mix of policies, including public funding for fundamental research, R&D grants, and tax incentives to support innovation. Boosting public spending on fundamental research could raise GDP by up to 2% and reduce debt-to-GDP ratios for advanced economies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past the International Monetary Fund (IMF) logo at its headquarters in Washington, U.S., May 10, 2018. REUTERS/Yuri Gripas/File Photo

site_title: Singapore’s largest car show The Car Expo returns on Apr 13-14
summary: The Car Expo, Singapore's largest car show, returns on April 13-14 at The Singapore Expo's Halls 4 and 5. 34 booths and 41 participating brands will showcase the latest models, including four new pre-owned exhibitors and a new electric-vehicle car brand, GAC Aion. Visitors can receive up to S$1,000 worth of fuel and lubricant vouchers and a limited edition portable neck fan with a minimum purchase. The event is free and runs from 10 am to 8 pm.

images.alt_text: The new Smart #1 electric cars are planned for a public launch on Apr 22.

Announcing an update to its medium-term business plan, Nissan says it would target an operating profit margin of over 6 per cent by end of the financial year to March 2027 and total shareholder returns of more than 30 per cent.
People walk past a booth of Zeekr, Chinese automaker Geely's premium electric vehicle (EV) brand, at a shopping mall in Beijing, China November 3, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: US weighs ban on charging homebuyers for lender title insurance: sources
summary: The US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is considering banning mortgage bankers from charging homebuyers for title insurance, a practice that could offer relief to Americans struggling to purchase affordable homes. The proposal, still in its early stages, aims to lay the groundwork for a ban on closing costs, including title insurance, which would not be finalized until 2025. Industry opposition is expected, with mortgage lenders and title insurers facing a housing market slump that has squeezed profits.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez speaks to the press as he attends a European Union leaders summit in Brussels, Belgium March 21, 2024. REUTERS/Johanna Geron/File Photo/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Condominium buildings are seen in Bangkok, Thailand, September 25, 2018. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo
Dublin’s docklands have been radically altered in recent years, with an economically deprived quarter of the city transformed into a business and residential neighbourhood beside the River Liffey.

site_title: Carbon credits market to get a huge boost as rules relaxed
summary: The United Nations-backed Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) has relaxed its guidelines to allow companies to use carbon credits to reduce full scope of emissions, including value chain emissions (Scope 3). This move is expected to boost the carbon credits market, which has faced turbulence following revelations of failed emission-cutting projects. SBTi's decision is seen as a significant step forward in scaling carbon markets and climate action, with some experts welcoming the flexibility for companies to continue engaging with climate action. However, others have expressed concerns about the lack of guardrails and potential for companies to appear to improve their climate performance without reducing actual emissions.

images.alt_text: Compliance carbon credits are effectively permits to pollute, but VCCs offer additional opportunities for companies to support climate-positive initiatives.

Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu and Papua New Guinea Minister of Environment, Conservation and Climate Change Simo Kilepa at a ceremony kicking off Singapore's cooperation with more than 20 countries to create a supply of carbon credits.

site_title: In first, World Athletics to pay prize money for Olympic golds
summary: World Athletics has announced it will pay prize money to Olympic gold medal winners for the first time, starting at this year's Paris Olympics. Each individual gold medal winner will receive $50,000, with relay teams also receiving the same amount. The total prize fund of $2.4 million comes from the International Olympic Committee's revenue share allocation. This move marks a significant shift for the international federation, with the prize money also to be awarded to silver and bronze medal winners from the 2028 Los Angeles Olympics.

images.alt_text: The bet is that athletes breaking records in Puma gear will nudge spectators towards its whole range of products, creating a potential “halo effect” for everything from marathon shoes to everyday sneakers.
Over US$350 million of the ad sales are coming from new sponsors.

site_title: ByteDance profit jumps 60%, taking it past archrival Tencent: sources
summary: ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, reported a 60% profit surge in 2023, surpassing rival Tencent in revenue and profit for the first time. The company's successful rollout of TikTok Shop in the US and Southeast Asia unlocked new revenue sources, with earnings reaching over $40 billion and sales reaching nearly $120 billion. This growth demonstrates ByteDance's resilience in the face of an economic downturn, solidifying its position as one of the world's fastest-growing tech giants.

images.alt_text: With European elections approaching in June, mainstream politicians are wary of ceding ground to fringe parties who have successfully exploited its short video format.

(FILES) In this photo illustration the social media application logo for TikTok is displayed on the screen of an iPhone in front of a US flag and Chinese flag background in Washington, DC, on March 16, 2023. China on March 14, 2024 slammed the approval of a US bill that would ban TikTok unless it severs ties with its Chinese parent company, blasting Washington's "bandit" mentality and vowing Beijing would "take all necessary measures" to protect the interests of its companies overseas. (Photo by OLIVIER DOULIERY / AFP)

site_title: China’s Xi meets ex-Taiwan leader Ma Ying-jeou in Beijing
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping met former Taiwan President Ma Ying-jeou in Beijing, a symbolic gesture amid growing tensions between China and Taiwan. The meeting highlights Xi's willingness to engage with Taiwan's opposition, but its significance is largely symbolic. Xi has pledged to bring Taiwan under China's control, by force if necessary, and has been increasing pressure on the island. The meeting comes as the US, Japan, and the Philippines discuss China's growing assertiveness.

images.alt_text: China has by far the world's largest wind turbine production capacity, accounting for 60 per cent of the 163 gigawatts globally in 2023.
China's electric-vehicle sector has been criticised by officials in the US and Europe for exporting overcapacity, as Chinese automakers increasingly look to sell abroad.

site_title: South Korea opposition set for big win in legislative election in blow to Yoon
summary: South Korea's main opposition party, the Democratic Party, is projected to win a majority in the country's legislative election, securing between 178 and 197 seats, a significant blow to President Yoon Suk Yeol. The opposition's expected landslide victory could hamper Yoon's policy efforts, including boosting the economy and reforming the medical system. The opposition has accused Yoon of mismanaging the economy and failing to curb inflation, with the opposition leader Lee Jae-myung vowing to "watch till the end with a humble heart."

images.alt_text: Nearly 25 million people had cast their ballots as of 2pm (0500 GMT), including 14 million who had voted before election day, making it highest ever turnout for a parliamentary election at this point.
South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol casts his early vote on Apr 5 for the country's elections. A major poll shows his party has 37 per cent of the country's support.

site_title: US dollar soars to highest versus yen since mid-1990 after inflation data
summary: The US dollar surged to its highest level against the yen since 1990, reaching 152.47 yen, following the release of US inflation data that showed a 0.4% monthly increase in the consumer price index. The data exceeded expectations, pushing the yen to a 32-year low. The dollar's strength is attributed to Japan's near-zero interest rates, which has driven investors to seek higher returns in the US. Traders have been watching for possible intervention by the Japanese authorities, but for now, the yen remains under pressure.

images.alt_text: This photo illustration taken on April 10, 2024 shows Japanese yen coins and 10,000 yen notes (65 USD) on display in Tokyo. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: TSMC’s sales surge most since 2022 after riding AI chip boom
summary: TSMC, Taiwan's largest company, has seen its sales surge most since 2022, with a 16% rise in March-quarter revenue to NT$592.6 billion, surpassing projections. The company expects revenue to grow at least 20% this year, reversing its 2023 decline, driven by sustained demand for AI chips. TSMC's AI revenue has grown 50% annually, and the company is building plants in the US, Japan, and Germany to meet this demand. Despite some concerns about the sustainability of AI chip demand, the company's stock has more than doubled in value since an October 2022 trough.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) logo is seen near computer motherboard in this illustration taken January 8, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Taiwanese equities have soared 14 per cent this year, with almost two thirds of the advance coming from a rally in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.
Technological advancements in Taiwan appear to have kept damage and casualties relatively low after the 7.4-magnitude quake on early Wednesday.

site_title: Spain to scrap ‘golden visas’ for foreign real estate investors
summary: Spain is set to scrap its "golden visa" program, which granted residency rights to foreign investors who made large investments in real estate. The program, which was launched in 2013, awarded non-EU citizens with a special permit after investing at least 500,000 euros in Spanish real estate. The move aims to make access to affordable housing a right, rather than a speculative business. The program has been criticized for favoring wealthy foreign investors, and Spain's housing problem is attributed to a lack of supply and high demand.

images.alt_text: Policymakers want to help Dubai shed its reputation of being a transient city by attracting expatriates and encouraging some of them to set up businesses.

site_title: China has been closing idled auto output capacity, industry body says
summary: China's auto factories had over 70% capacity utilisation in 2023, with idled capacity being closed, according to the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers (CAAM). This move aims to improve capacity utilisation rates faster. China's electric-vehicle sector has faced criticism for exporting overcapacity, with US and European officials expressing concerns. CAAM's deputy secretary-general, Chen Shihua, believes the closures will help address this issue, while the China Passenger Car Association's secretary general, Cui Dongshu, notes that severe overcapacity levels have yet to be reached.

site_title: Starbucks is designing quieter stores to make sure it gets your order right
summary: Starbucks is designing quieter stores with acoustic treatments, such as baffles on the ceiling, to improve order accuracy and customer experience. The company plans to add 650 stores in the US and 20,000 globally, with a focus on "purpose-defined stores" that cater to trends like iced beverages and to-go orders. The US$3 billion capital expenditures will also include the development of drive-throughs, with 80% of new locations set to have them, and the implementation of the Siren System to increase productivity in existing stores.

images.alt_text: Berjaya Food owns 100 per cent of Starbucks’ Malaysian operations.
Cotti Coffee has expanded its footprint to more than 330 of China’s nearly 400 county-level cities,

site_title: What happens when a German car factory goes all electric
summary: Volkswagen's Zwickau factory, Germany's largest private employer, successfully converted to producing only electric vehicles, contradicting concerns that such a shift would lead to mass unemployment. Despite initial skepticism, the factory's workers and suppliers have adapted, with many finding new jobs in the production of electronic components. While some suppliers have suffered, others have benefited from the shift. The experience offers hopeful lessons for other areas dependent on the auto industry, but new technologies continue to disrupt the industry, with established companies facing challenges in competing with younger, more agile rivals like Chinese electric carmakers.

images.alt_text: Related effects from the closer cooperation should bolster results this year, Volkswagen says, which also expects more sales due to a better raw materials and components supply.

site_title: Thailand to fund US$14 billion cash handout through state budget
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin approved a US$14 billion cash handout programme, equivalent to 2.9% of the country's GDP, to stimulate the economy through a state budget and state bank assistance. The programme, set to be implemented in the fourth quarter, will give 50 million adult Thais 10,000 baht each. The financing plan allocates 327.7 billion baht from the current and next fiscal year budgets, and the remaining amount will be sourced from the Bank for Agriculture and Agricultural Cooperatives. The stimulus aims to lift growth in Thailand, which has lagged its peers in the region, but may widen public debt and fan inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An aerial view shows a cityscape in Bangkok, Thailand January 27, 2023. REUTERS/Ilan Rosenberg/File Photo

site_title: Wall Street sees earnings propelling defiant stock rally onward
summary: US stocks are expected to be propelled by strong corporate earnings, with analysts predicting a 10% gain in S&P 500 earnings in the first quarter. Despite interest rate concerns and a volatile week, Wall Street strategists remain optimistic, citing solid projections for economic growth and robust tech earnings. Other sectors, such as economically sensitive ones, are also expected to perform well, leading to a broader and healthier rally. Market experts believe the momentum will continue for at least one more quarter, with some warning of a possible 2-3% pullback but not a sell-off.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Morning sunlight falls on the facade of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) building after the start of Thursday's trading session in Manhattan in New York City, New York, U.S., January 28, 2021. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo
After a down day on European bourses, both the S&P 500 and Nasdaq muster narrow gains.

site_title: No alcohol for Gen-Z drinkers
summary: Millennials and Gen-Zers are increasingly opting for low- or no-alcohol cocktails over hard liquor, driven by a focus on personal well-being and mental health. This trend has led bars in Singapore to create low-alcohol versions of their cocktails, with many now offering tea and alcohol-free spirit creations. The shift reflects a shift in attitudes towards health and balanced lifestyles among younger generations.

site_title: Amazon asks court to dismiss antitrust lawsuit over web traffic sharing
summary: Amazon has asked a US court to dismiss a lawsuit claiming its cloud-computing unit AWS stifled a startup, Subspace omega, that worked with Epic Games and other customers to provide fast internet connections. Subspace, a Wyoming-based web traffic optimisation company, sued Amazon, alleging it violated antitrust law by ending an arrangement with the company. Amazon argues that it had no requirement to provide free network connections and that Subspace failed to show AWS had any obligation to do so. Subspace seeks $417 million in damages.

images.alt_text: A logo for Amazon Web Services (AWS) is seen during the Amazon Web Services (AWS) Summit in Paris, France, April 3, 2024. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier

site_title: Hollywood animation, VFX unions fight AI job cut threat
summary: The US film, television, and animation industry employs 550,000 people, with unions representing animation and visual effects workers planning to demand rules for the deployment of generative artificial intelligence (AI) tools. A study found that 75% of industry bosses have eliminated or reduced jobs after introducing AI, with over 100,000 jobs expected to be disrupted by 2026. Unions aim to establish controls over AI deployment, citing concerns that studios could replace human work with cheaper AI versions without crediting or compensating workers. The issue highlights the need for labor agreements to govern AI's impact on the industry.

images.alt_text: Australian director George Miller sharing a few early details about 'Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga' at the CinemaCon movie theater convention in Las Vegas on Monday.
The feature, which sees the enormous gorilla and reptilian giant set their differences aside and team up to save their species.
Some copyright holders have cut deals with OpenAI for using their work.

site_title: Fintech Revolut receives Mexican banking authorisation, eyes expansion
summary: Revolut, a fintech company, received a banking license in Mexico, allowing it to offer a range of financial products and services to users in the country. With over 40 million customers worldwide, Revolut aims to establish itself as a multiple banking institution. The company is preparing for a third-party audit process by Mexican authorities, signaling the start of expansion plans in Latin America's second-largest economy.

site_title: Kishida urges US executives to boost tech investments in Japan
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida urged US business executives to increase investments in emerging technologies such as semiconductors, artificial intelligence, and quantum computing, citing the need for Japan's economic growth and cooperation between the two nations. Kishida met with US business leaders ahead of a summit with US President Joe Biden, where they are expected to tout the strength of economic cooperation. Japan's economy is at an inflection point, with the central bank raising interest rates for the first time in 17 years and stocks hitting a record high.

images.alt_text: The dollar has failed to make any headway despite a ton of hawkish signals from Fed officials last week and on Monday.

site_title: Elephant deaths trigger Kenyan call for Tanzania to curb hunts
summary: Kenyan officials are urging Tanzania to restrict trophy hunting near the border to protect elephants crucial to its tourism business. Three elephants have been shot across the border in recent months, sparking concerns about the impact on the Amboseli wildlife park's tourism industry. Conservationists argue that Tanzania's licensing system allows wealthy hunters to target "super-tuskers" near the Kenyan border, threatening the genetic diversity of the elephant population. Kenya's tourism sector, which relies on elephant sightings, is a major foreign exchange earner, making the issue a pressing concern for the country.

images.alt_text: Elephants walk at the Amboseli National Park in Kajiado County, Kenya, April 4, 2024. REUTERS/Monicah Mwangi

site_title: Puma hones focus on speed in Olympic battle with Adidas and Nike
summary: Puma is focusing on speed as it competes with Adidas and Nike for the Olympic market. The brand is using its sponsorship of Jamaica's Olympic team and sprint champions to associate itself with speed. Puma CEO Arne Freundt aims to boost sales of performance products, revamping its "Forever Faster" message for its first brand campaign in a decade. The brand's efforts aim to create a "halo effect" for everyday products, with athletes breaking records in Puma gear expected to nudge spectators towards its entire range.

images.alt_text: The new Centre Aquatique Olympique, with its wooden inward-curving roof that saves on heating by reducing enclosed space, in the northern Paris suburb of Saint-Denis, March 5, 2024. Organizers of the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris say that with measures like more space for bicycling and less for cars, solar panels on the Seine, more plant-based foods — and perhaps most significantly, less construction of new facilities — the Games will generate no more than half the greenhouse gas emissions of other recent Olympics. (Yulia Grigoryants/The New York Times)
These 222,000 spots are in addition to the 104,000 paying spectators who will watch the ceremony from the lower quays.
Over US$350 million of the ad sales are coming from new sponsors.

site_title: Strikes at Deutsche Bank’s Postbank escalate as labour demands 15.5% pay rise
summary: Deutsche Bank's Postbank arm is experiencing a month-long wage dispute, with labour union Verdi demanding a 15.5% pay raise. Strikes have escalated, affecting hundreds of branches across Germany, and negotiations are set to resume on April 16. The dispute comes as the bank tries to reduce costs and address customer service issues, including severe glitches that prompted regulatory oversight. Verdi officials say the strikes are having a massive impact on customer service, and the union has extended the strike to include Thursday, making it the 20th day of walkouts.

images.alt_text: The ECB has grown increasingly active in its efforts to get lenders to treat ESG risks – particularly climate change – as financially material.
Revolut Singapore is preparing to expand its footprint to India as remittances to that country account for roughly 14 per cent of the financial services app’s total.

Wall Street investors have welcomed Fraser’s overhaul, but warned the CEO has major challenges ahead to boost returns and catch up with rivals, including regulatory problems, lacklustre earnings and an unsettled workforce.

site_title: Japan’s former forex chief says intervention an option for overly weak yen
summary: Japan's former forex chief, Takehiko Nakao, suggests intervention in the currency market is an option to address the excessively weak yen, which has been trading in the 151 range against the US dollar. Nakao, who now chairs Mizuho Research & Technologies, believes intervention can deter speculation and help address the situation. This comes ahead of US inflation data that may impact the yen's value, with the 151 level closely watched by market players.

images.alt_text: The dollar has failed to make any headway despite a ton of hawkish signals from Fed officials last week and on Monday.
Kazuo Ueda’s BOJ has shown it will seize opportunities to act when they arise.

site_title: Vietnam aims to start work on high-speed rail lines to China by 2030
summary: Vietnam plans to start building two high-speed railway lines to China by 2030, with one line running from Hanoi to Lao Cai province and the other from Hanoi to Lang Son province, both bordering China. The projects aim to strengthen economic ties and boost trade between the two countries. The railway lines will also pass through densely populated areas with global manufacturing facilities, primarily owned by Chinese investors.

site_title: Thai central bank holds rate, deepening rift with government
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, held interest rates steady at a decade-high 2.5% despite Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin's demands for a rate cut. The decision, a 5-2 vote, puts the bank at odds with the government, which seeks to boost credit and consumption to lift growth to 5% during the term. The central bank argues that some growth issues are structural and cannot be addressed by monetary policy. The move deepens the rift between the bank and the government, which has implemented a US$14-billion cash handout program to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Fitch cuts China’s ratings outlook on growth risks
summary: Fitch Ratings cut China's sovereign credit rating outlook to negative, citing risks to public finances amid an uncertain economic shift. The rating agency forecasts China's general government deficit to rise to 7.1% of GDP in 2024, and expects the country's explicit central and local government debt to reach 61.3% of GDP. Fitch also lowered its ratings to negative from "stable", indicating a downgrade is possible over the medium term, but affirmed China's issuer default rating at A+.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the city skyline in Shanghai, China February 24, 2022. Picture taken February 24, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Alibaba founder Jack Ma steps out from shadows with long internal post
summary: Alibaba founder Jack Ma has penned a lengthy memo to employees expressing support for the company's restructuring efforts and praising CEO Eddie Wu and chairman Joe Tsai. The post suggests Ma may be willing to take a more active role after years out of the spotlight. Alibaba's Hong Kong-listed shares surged 5.5% in morning trade, their biggest one-day percentage gain since February. Ma's letter highlights the company's focus on innovation and agility, and his return to public life may signal a shift in the company's direction.

site_title: South Koreans vote for new parliament after campaign focused on economy, graft
summary: South Korea held its parliamentary election on April 10, with nearly 25 million people casting ballots, a record high turnout for a parliamentary election at this point. The Democratic Party, led by Lee Jae-myung, is expected to win a majority, potentially stripping President Yoon Suk Yeol of his veto power. The election is seen as a referendum on Yoon's government amid a cost-of-living crisis and political scandals, with corruption and mismanagement of the economy being major campaign issues.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol casts his early vote on Apr 5 for the country's elections. A major poll shows his party has 37 per cent of the country's support.
South Koreans have been active in the latest digital-asset bull market and are famed for their ardor for smaller cryptocurrencies, not just market-leader Bitcoin.

site_title: ‘World of Warcraft’ returns to China as Blizzard and NetEase end spat
summary: NetEase and Microsoft's Activision Blizzard have ended a 15-year spat over game distribution in China, allowing Blizzard's franchises, including World of Warcraft, to return to the market. The deal will also bring new NetEase titles to Xbox consoles. The agreement follows a 15% drop in NetEase shares after the two companies failed to agree on an extension. Blizzard games will "return to the market sequentially" starting in the summer, with account progress preserved when servers are available.

images.alt_text: Game companies have been coping with layoffs, mergers and product cancellations.

Microsoft quarterly profits soared, the company said on July 25, 2023, as its big push into artificial intelligence seemed to be bearing fruit, but growth in its key cloud computing business slowed. (Photo by GERARD JULIEN / AFP)

site_title: Hong Kong considers changing tax rules to lure private credit business
summary: Hong Kong's government is considering new tax rules to attract private credit and infrastructure businesses, offering tax exemptions on interest income to special purpose vehicles for alternative investments. This move aims to increase Hong Kong's jurisdiction and legal infrastructure, luring more asset management businesses amid economic headwinds and geopolitical tensions. The proposals are part of a broader effort to enhance tax regimes for funds, single family offices, and carried interest, following similar measures in Dubai and Singapore.

images.alt_text: More than 140 countries agreed at the end of 2021 to impose a minimum tax on multinational companies under the auspices of the OECD, to combat efforts by firms to shift profits to countries with low rates but there has been limited progress.

site_title: China’s Chery nearing deal to manufacture cars in Spain
summary: China's Chery Auto is nearing a deal to manufacture cars in Spain, its first European site, after positive talks with a Spanish delegation in China. The agreement is expected to create 1,600 direct jobs lost due to Nissan's 2021 plant shutdown in Barcelona. The talks focus on Chery producing vehicles at the Nissan site, and the Spanish government is confident an agreement will be formalized in the coming days. Chery has been selling cars in Spain earlier this year and is one of several Chinese automakers bringing lower-cost, mostly electric vehicles to Europe.

images.alt_text: Chery joins a growing number of Chinese automakers, with European expansion plans as competition intensifies at home and domestic growth eases.

Huawei's managing director and chairman of smart car solutions, Richard Yu, is expecting the unit to turn a profit from April.

site_title: Shell at disadvantage to US-listed rivals, says former CEO
summary: Former Shell CEO Ben van Beurden stated that European oil and gas companies face increasing difficulty competing with US-listed rivals due to a deeper pool of investors and capital in New York, and a more positive attitude towards oil and gas companies. This trend will make it challenging for European companies to remain competitive.

site_title: Netflix founder, ex-Alphabet CEO back African solar irrigation startup
summary: Netflix co-founder Reed Hastings and former Alphabet CEO Eric Schmidt have invested $27 million in Nairobi, Kenya-based solar irrigation startup SunCulture, alongside InfraCo Africa and Acumen Fund. SunCulture supplies small solar-powered water pumps to small-scale farmers, allowing them to boost yields in fields previously irrigated. The startup aims to install 274,000 systems in Kenya, raising $219 million in funding. With only 4% of Africa's 700 million small-holder farmers having access to irrigation, SunCulture helps farmers grow more food, promoting a business that prospers.

images.alt_text: Photovoltaic solar panels and windmills around the Spanish Navarre town of Milagro. The world still requires wind and solar to achieve its net zero goals, and developers are crucial to delivering that.

site_title: Taiwan appoints ruling party's former chairman as new premier
summary: Taiwan's President-elect Lai Ching-te appointed Cho Jung-tai, a former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman, as the new premier on April 10. Cho will announce his Cabinet members, including foreign minister and defense minister, in the coming days, aiming to reach across party lines. The new premier and Cabinet will not take office until Lai's inauguration on May 20. Cho emphasized the importance of a talented and innovative Cabinet, free from party affiliations, to uphold Taiwan's democratic spirit.

images.alt_text: Lai had faced two opponents for the presidency – Hou Yu-ih and former Taipei mayor Dr Ko Wen-je.
Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Lai Ching-te favors warmer ties with the US and has been branded a separatist by China.

site_title: Vietnam’s top three cities spark innovation race to bolster growth
summary: Vietnam's top three cities, Ho Chi Minh City, Hanoi, and Da Nang, are competing to boost innovation and growth. The cities are offering incentives for select technology sectors, including semiconductors and artificial intelligence. Ho Chi Minh City has implemented special mechanisms and policies, while Hanoi is finalizing its amended draft law and Da Nang is adjusting 26 special policies to bolster its growth. The cities are also pushing ahead to engage big investors and create innovation hubs, aligning with Vietnam's National Master Plan to double down on digital, high-tech, and green industries.

images.alt_text: Da Nang is home to nearly 900 foreign-invested projects with a total investment capital of US$5.9 billion.
Since fundraising from established foreign funds faced rocky path amid global economic distress, local venture capital firms took the lead to provide growth capital for Vietnamese early-stage startup
The skyline of Ho Chi Minh City.

site_title: China says EU’s wind turbine subsidy probe ‘discriminatory’
summary: China has expressed concerns over the European Union's investigation into subsidies for Chinese wind turbine suppliers, calling it "discriminatory" and urging the EU to abide by World Trade Organization rules. The EU's move is part of a push to protect its firms from unfair competition from state-subsidized clean technology imports from China. China, which accounts for 60% of the world's wind turbine production capacity, claims its products are cheaper, with prices 20% below rival US and European products.

images.alt_text: In acting as the standard-bearer for this policy, Yellen is rejecting fundamental principles of economics to justify a policy of restricting public access to affordable and clean technology.
Greece, which won back its investment grade status late last year, has seen tourism break record levels every year since the pandemic.

site_title: Isetan’s rich exit offer is a shining example of how to treat shareholders fairly in a privatisation
summary: Japan-listed Isetan Mitsukoshi's privatisation offer for Isetan Singapore surpasses major benchmark values, with an offer price of S$7.20 per share, 178.9% above the company's net asset value. This is a significant departure from recent lowball offers, including Best World's S$2.50 per share and Amara Holdings' S$0.60 per share. The offer is considered a breath of fresh air and sets a standard for future privatisation deals, potentially driven by Japan's corporate governance reforms aimed at improving valuations of listed companies.

images.alt_text: With depressed share prices, major shareholders will be tempted to take listed groups private.

Responding to queries from SGX, Amara has since come out to say that it does not consider the issue - which relates to an immediate family member of one of Amara's executive directors - as an unresolved matter as it is still under discussion.

site_title: Comcast sells US$1.2 billion in advertising for the Paris Olympics
summary: Comcast's NBCUniversal has sold a record-breaking $1.2 billion in advertising for the upcoming Paris Olympics and Paralympic games, with over $350 million coming from new sponsors. The opening and closing ceremonies are sold out, and digital ad revenue also set a record. Over half of prime-time events will feature women's sports, making it an attractive option for advertisers targeting this demographic.

site_title: KKR raises US$2 billion for US institutional evergreen fund
summary: KKR has raised over $2 billion from institutional investors in its US direct lending evergreen fund, its largest US direct lending evergreen fund to date. The fund focuses on senior secured debt of upper middle-market companies with earnings between $50 million and $100 million. This is part of KKR's direct lending strategy, which has raised over $10 billion in the last 12 months. Evergreen funds offer flexibility to investors, allowing them to redeem their stakes at any time. KKR has launched three funds with the same evergreen structure, including a levered US vehicle and a European version.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Trading information for KKR & Co is displayed on a screen on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., August 23, 2018. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: BMW sales up slightly in Q1 as carmaker hits electric milestone
summary: BMW reported a 1.1% year-on-year increase in Q1 sales, delivering 594,671 vehicles. The company also achieved a milestone by delivering its millionth fully-electric vehicle. Electric vehicle sales surged 27.9% to 82,700 units, driven by growing demand. Despite a slight increase in overall sales, BMW's Q1 results were seen as a step towards its goal of becoming carbon neutral by 2050.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A BMW Vision Neue Klasse is displayed next to the company's logo during an event a day ahead of the official opening of the 2023 Munich Auto Show IAA Mobility, in Munich, Germany, September 4, 2023. REUTERS/Angelika Warmuth/File Photo

site_title: SpaceX contract to supply Starlink in Ukraine is worth US$23 million
summary: The Pentagon has revealed a US$23 million contract with SpaceX to supply Starlink communications terminals in Ukraine, a vital part of the US's security assistance to the country. The contract, which runs from June last year through next month, provides critical communications infrastructure during the war with Russia. US military officials have praised the role of portable Starlink terminals in keeping the civilian population connected and providing crucial communications for the military. The contract's renewal is uncertain.

images.alt_text: SpaceX’s thousands of Starlink satellites in low-Earth orbit use inter-satellite laser links to pass data between one another in space at the speed of light, allowing the network to offer broader Internet coverage around the world with fewer ground stations.
Starlink’s network of low Earth orbit satellites can provide Internet to remote locations, or areas that have had normal communications infrastructure disabled.

site_title: In landmark climate ruling, European court faults Switzerland
summary: The European Court of Human Rights ruled that Switzerland's government violated citizens' rights by not taking sufficient action to reduce carbon emissions, in a landmark climate case. The ruling, brought by Senior Women for Climate Protection, found that Switzerland had failed to meet its 20% emissions target by 2020 and must now take measures to address this shortcoming. The court ordered Switzerland to pay €80,000 to the plaintiffs and to implement measures to reduce emissions. The ruling could set a precedent for climate-related lawsuits and may encourage more public members to sue governments over climate change.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Zurich Insurance is seen at its headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland January 13, 2022. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
