The ECB has grown increasingly active in its efforts to get lenders to treat ESG risks – particularly climate change – as financially material.
Over the past five years, the EU has introduced a welter of new regulations to make the region’s economy greener.

site_title: Airbus says first-quarter jet deliveries rose 12%
summary: Airbus reported a 12% increase in jet deliveries in the first quarter, reaching 142 aircraft, ahead of US rival Boeing, which delivered 83 commercial airplanes. Airbus won 170 new orders with no cancellations, including an order for 33 wide-body planes from Korean Air. The European planemaker's strong performance leaves Boeing behind, with Boeing reporting 131 gross orders and 126 net orders after cancellations.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise as traders jockey ahead of US inflation
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday ahead of US inflation data, with Hong Kong and Sydney gaining more than one percent, while Shanghai edged lower. Investors are awaiting the release of the critical consumer price index, which could influence interest rate decisions. Despite a strong US jobs report last week, there is nervousness about the Fed's potential to delay cutting borrowing costs if inflation remains high. Expectations for rate cuts have been pared to three at most, with some considering zero, and Atlanta Fed boss Raphael Bostic remains open to changing his policy stance based on data.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Sydney, Singapore and Taipei were also in positive territory, but Shanghai, Seoul and Wellington slipped.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly up ahead of key inflation data
summary: US stocks ended the day mostly higher ahead of key inflation data, despite a down day on European bourses. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq posted narrow gains, while the Dow was flat due to Boeing's decline. Investors await US consumer price data to gauge the possibility of Federal Reserve interest rate cuts, with analysts expecting a more cautious approach. The Fed's previous indication of seasonal factors contributing to inflation may not hold, and some now expect no rate cuts before 2025.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JANUARY 19: Traders and media work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on January 19, 2024 in New York City. Stocks closed up over 350 points while the S&P 500 closed at an all-time high on Friday.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Gold hits record high on buying momentum, geopolitical risks
summary: Gold prices hit a record high of US$2,365.09 per ounce on Tuesday, driven by buying momentum and geopolitical risks. Spot gold rose 0.3% to US$2,346.57 per ounce, while US gold futures settled 0.5% higher at US$2,362.4. The market expects a rate cut in June, with a 53% chance, and fundamentals such as growing geopolitical risk and steady central bank buying are underpinning the rally.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.1 per cent at US$2,340.09 per ounce after hitting a record high of US$2,353.79 on Monday.
Spot gold was down 1.1 per cent at US$2,305.09 per ounce.

site_title: US power use forecast to reach record highs in 2024 and 2025
summary: US power consumption is forecast to reach record highs in 2024 and 2025, according to the US Energy Information Administration (EIA). Power demand is projected to rise to 4,096 billion kilowatt-hours in 2024 and 4,125 billion kWh in 2025, surpassing 2022's record 4,067 billion kWh. This increase is attributed to growing energy demand, primarily driven by industrial and residential sectors. The EIA's Short Term Energy Outlook (STEO) report was released on April 9, 2024.

images.alt_text: Photovoltaic solar panels and windmills around the Spanish Navarre town of Milagro. The world still requires wind and solar to achieve its net zero goals, and developers are crucial to delivering that.
FILE PHOTO: A liquified natural gas (LNG) tanker leaves the dock after discharge at PetroChina's receiving terminal in Dalian, Liaoning province, China July 16, 2018.  REUTERS/Chen Aizhu/File Photo

site_title: Oil prices settle lower again, eyes on talks for Gaza ceasefire
summary: Oil prices settled lower for a second day, with Brent crude futures declining 1.1% to $89.42 per barrel and WTI crude futures falling 1.4% to $85.23 per barrel. Talks for a Gaza ceasefire in Cairo have raised hopes of a breakthrough, but the Egyptian and Qatari mediators have met resistance. The conflict's potential to draw in other countries, particularly Iran, has increased the risk of a tight oil market.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures fell 79 US cents.

site_title: Winner to winemaker for hardman former All Black Ashworth
summary: Former New Zealand rugby player John Ashworth, known for his hard-hitting style, has turned his passion for wine into a successful winemaking career. Ashworth discovered his love for pinot noir on a 1977 tour of France and went on to establish Junction Wines vineyard near Takapau. His signature wine, "Front Row" pinot noir, has won numerous awards, including a gold medal at the New Zealand International Wine Awards. Ashworth's son Leith, a viticulturist, helps with the vineyard's production, which also includes other six wines.

images.alt_text: China’s alcohol market is the world’s biggest, estimated at US$336 billion, though a fiery domestic spirit, baijiu, dominates it.
While typically associated with “highbrow” cuisine, champagne goes wonderfully with foods such as pizza and fried chicken.
China's tariffs on Australian wine, some of them as high as 218 per cent, will be lifted over the course of Friday.
New research shows a “substantial” risk that 49 to 70 per cent of wine-producing regions will become economically unviable, depending on the extent of global warming.

site_title: NYSE executive says ‘handful’ of AI startups are exploring IPOs
summary: A NYSE executive stated that a "handful" of AI startups are exploring initial public offerings (IPOs) as the market for tech listings gains momentum. These AI-focused companies, which have raised billions from venture capital firms and big tech companies, are considering going public despite being mostly self-funded in the private markets. The executive's comments come after the release of ChatGPT in late 2022, which has led to a surge in AI startups launching generative AI services for consumers and businesses.

site_title: US dollar flat as investors await inflation data; focus on yen action
summary: The US dollar remained flat on Tuesday ahead of inflation data, despite hawkish signals from Fed officials. Investors are cautious about the data, which is expected to show a 0.3% monthly rise in the consumer price index. The yen hovered near multi-decade lows, with traders watching for possible action from Japan to prop up its currency. The dollar index was flat at 104.12, and the dollar was flat to slightly lower against the yen at 151.755 yen. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to consider reducing monetary stimulus if inflation accelerates.

images.alt_text: The dollar index, which tracks the currency against six major peers, fell by 0.01 per cent to 104.05.

site_title: LHN unit bags tender for former Bukit Timah Fire Station site
summary: LHN Group's unit, LHN Facilities Management, has won a tender to transform a 0.86-hectare site at Upper Bukit Timah Road into a "vibrant mixed-use development" featuring co-living spaces and community-centric offerings. The project, expected to open in the first half of 2025, will incorporate environmentally friendly features and amenities such as a gym, pet-friendly spaces, and shared public spaces. The site will also house LHN's residential co-living space concept Coliwoo, part of the group's expansion plan in the co-living business.

images.alt_text: The company's appointment of Primepartners Corporate Finance as its continuing sponsor will also cease on Dec 13.

Coliwoo Hotel Pasir Panjang, by LHN. Lim & Tan Securities analyst Chan En Jie sees the two upcoming healthcare lodging facilities at 100 Ulu Pandan Road and 60 Boundary Close as a positive entry into a new revenue stream for LHN..
The agreement involves designing, retrofitting and operating two lodging facilities for healthcare professionals.

site_title: Further opportunities for banks in lending space amid stricter capital requirements, private credit growth
summary: Singapore banks remain a compelling asset class despite stricter capital requirements and the growth of private credit, with strong fundamentals and unchanged capital positions. Traditional banks face challenges in providing funding due to capital constraints and rising interest rates, but may leverage alternative financing options. The private debt market is expected to grow, with total assets under management projected to double to US$3.5 trillion by 2028. Singapore banks' healthy capital adequacy ratios and strong loan growth make them an attractive investment class, with dividends remaining relatively high.

images.alt_text: The California Public Employees' Retirement System will increase its private markets allocation to "maximise returns from the highest-performing asset classes".
Market data shows private equity and private credit have significantly outperformed traditional asset classes in recent years.

site_title: Decision on Petrobras CEO job is up to Brazil's president, says energy minister
summary: Brazil's energy minister Alexandre Silveira says the decision on Petrobras CEO Jean Paul Prates' future is up to President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. Prates has been under fire from parts of the government over fuel prices and job-creating investments. The minister also confirmed that extra dividends withheld from Petrobras shareholders in March will be issued when the state-run oil firm's board decides. The uncertainty has led to volatility in Petrobras' share prices, with some speculating Prates may not survive "to the end of the week".

site_title: CDL unit markets unsold units at The Residences at W Sentosa at 40% less than 2010 launch price
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) is selling 58 unsold units of The Residences at W Singapore Sentosa Cove at 40% less than the 2010 launch price. The units, ranging from two to five bedrooms, start at S$2.1 million and go up to S$3.5 million. This follows an increase in interest and sales activity in Sentosa Cove properties, with prices now comparable to those in Outside Central Region homes. The sale is seen as an opportunity for homebuyers and investors to acquire a unit in a luxury oceanfront development at a discounted price.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
More than three quarters of Suntec Reit's assets consist of offices, shops and convention space in Singapore
At 15,276.8 square metres ( sq m), the Zion Road site can house up to 1,170 residential units, including 435 serviced apartments.
Three plots of land form the Jurong Lake District master-developer site whose tender closed on Tuesday (Mar 26).

site_title: Peddling hope in India elections and economy
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is confident of winning a third term in the upcoming parliamentary elections, with opinion polls showing him likely to secure more than 400 seats. Modi's ruling BJP has promised to double the country's economy and exports, with a target of reaching the third-largest economy in the world by 2030. Many Indians are buying into the hope of better days ahead, with the stock market and mutual funds experiencing significant growth since Modi came to power in 2014. However, critics argue that the economic benefits are largely concentrated among the wealthy, leaving the poor and underprivileged behind.

images.alt_text: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi has highlighted economic growth as one of his biggest achievements in election rallies and has “guaranteed” making the economy the third largest in the world from fifth now if he wins a third term in a row as polls predict.

site_title: Italy cuts growth forecasts and says debt set to rise
summary: Italy's government has cut its growth forecast for this year and next to 1% and 1.2%, respectively, due to an uncertain international outlook. The government also confirmed its 2024 budget deficit projection at 4.3% of national output, slightly above the target. Public debt is expected to rise to 138.9% of GDP by 2026, driven by the "devastating impact" of costly fiscal incentive schemes. Economy Minister Giancarlo Giorgetti plans to intervene with corrective measures to meet previous deficit targets and raise 20 billion euros from asset sales.

images.alt_text: Sergio Ermotti says there are banks with the “breadth and capacity” to grow with cross-border operations, but that doing it organically is “practically impossible”.

site_title: Rare earths prices in China hit 7-week high on post-holiday restocking
summary: Rare earths prices in China reached a 7-week high due to post-holiday restocking among buyers. The price of praseodymium oxide jumped 9.7% week-over-week and 9.1% month-over-month to 395,000 yuan a tonne. Terbium oxide also rose, reaching its highest since January at 6,150 yuan a kilogramme. The price increases were attributed to reduced spot cargoes and some producers replenishing raw material supplies after China's QingMing Festival. This may lead to increased price volatility during peak demand season.

images.alt_text: Prices of rare earths surged to their highest in a decade in 2022 only to plunge last year on increased production in China and slower-than-expected demand growth crippled by the country’s patchy post-pandemic economic recovery.
China put technology for making rare-earth metals and rare-earth magnets on a list of items cannot be transfered overseas.

site_title: Quarterly monetary decisions are valuable even if – or precisely when – they bring no change
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has adopted a quarterly monetary policy decision schedule, with additional meetings in January and July, despite no policy changes since October 2022. This move is seen as a means of public signalling, allowing MAS to reassure markets that policy settings are on track without causing undue alarm. The flexibility provided by the new schedule will also enable MAS to more effectively time policy changes and signal its intentions, reducing speculation and worry between meetings.

images.alt_text: The facade of the Monetary Authority of Singapore Building on May 30, 2023.

site_title: Boeing quarterly jet deliveries dip to lowest since mid-2021
summary: Boeing delivered 29 aircraft in March, the lowest quarterly total since mid-2021, amid efforts to catch up on damaged or missing parts and improve production quality. The company's 737 Max deliveries were the majority, highlighting the model's importance for Boeing's bottom line. Rival Airbus delivered 142 aircraft in the first quarter, while Boeing's total orders rebounded with 113 gross orders in March. The US company's production is still below the capped 38-jet monthly pace, but bookings remain strong, with demand for new aircraft at a record.

images.alt_text: The planemaker has been grappling with a full-blown safety crisis that has undermined its reputation following a Jan 5 mid-air panel blowout on a 737 MAX plane.
FILE PHOTO: The Boeing logo is displayed on a screen, at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., August 7, 2019. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo
Boeing has faced increased scrutiny following the loss of a door plug on an Alaska Airlines jetliner in January.

site_title: Microsoft to invest US$2.9 billion to expand AI, cloud infra in Japan
summary: Microsoft plans to invest US$2.9 billion over two years to expand its cloud and AI infrastructure in Japan, its largest investment in the country's 46 years of operations. The investment will also focus on skilling three million people in AI and setting up a Microsoft Research Asia lab in Tokyo, aiming to support the development of artificial intelligence in the region.

site_title: EV maker Lucid beats Q1 delivery estimates
summary: Lucid Motors reported above-market Q1 deliveries of 1,967 vehicles, beating estimates of 1,745, thanks to price cuts on its luxury electric sedans. The company's deliveries were below estimates of 2,123 in the same quarter last year. Lucid also announced plans to raise $1 billion in capital from Ayar Third Investment Company. The company's demand for vehicles has remained resilient despite the price cuts, reflecting the strong interest in its flagship Air sedans.

site_title: US investor Baker, Beetz-led group to buy Germany's Galeria, sources say
summary: US investor Richard Baker, CEO of Hudson's Bay Company, will lead a consortium including NRDC Corp and German businessman Bernd Beetz to buy Germany's Galeria Karstadt Kaufhof, the country's most prominent retailer. Galeria filed for insolvency in April after its parent Signa, the Austria-based property empire, collapsed. This is Galeria's third insolvency filing in recent years, caused by soaring inflation and energy costs. The consortium will present a new investor at a press conference on Wednesday.

site_title: Thailand sees more than 4% growth this year on property measures
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow slightly more than 4% this year due to measures to boost the property sector, which is expected to lead to 800 billion baht in property trades, 400 billion baht in investment, and 120 billion baht in consumption. The measures include reduced transaction fees, home loans, tax breaks, and tax deductions for property developers and homeowners. The government aims to revive economic activity and lift growth by 1.7-1.8 percentage points.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Condominium buildings are seen in Bangkok, Thailand, September 25, 2018. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on easing bond yields; inflation data on tap
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by retreating Treasury yields, as investors await a key inflation print that could influence the Federal Reserve's stance on rate cuts. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 90.9 points, or 0.23%, to 38,983.66, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also saw gains. The inflation data, due later in the week, could shape the Fed's decision on rate cuts this year.

site_title: BlackBerry gains on partnership with AMD for robotics systems
summary: BlackBerry shares rose over 7% after partnering with AMD to develop a robotics platform for industrial and healthcare industries. The collaboration, announced at the Embedded World conference, utilizes BlackBerry's ONX platform. This move aims to improve robotics capabilities and follows BlackBerry's shift in focus to cybersecurity and licensing software revenue.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 9)
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong discussed navigating global complexities with German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier, calling Singapore and Germany "like-minded" countries. Meanwhile, Changi Airport Group's CEO LEE Seow Hiang is stepping down on July 1, replaced by Yam Kum Weng. Frasers Property is installing 4,500 sq m of solar panels in its properties through a tie-up with SP Group. Three Mainboard-listed companies, Seatrium, GSH Corporation, and Global Invacom, filed notices of consecutive losses for three years.

site_title: Sabana Reit trustee gives indicative timeline for internalisation, with EGM in Q3
summary: HSBC Institutional Trust Services, trustee of Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit), has outlined an indicative timeline for the internalisation of the trust's management function. The internalisation is expected to occur in Q3, with an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) likely to be held during this period. The trustee has also stated that the total costs incurred between January 1 and March 31 this year related to the implementation of the internalisation process were approximately S$2.1 million. The trustee has expressed concerns that certain proposed trust deed amendments could create uncertainty and prejudice for Sabana Reit and its unitholders.

images.alt_text: ESR Group maintains that its entire episode with Quarz Capital has “resulted in a diminished value” of Sabana Reit’s unit price.
More than three quarters of Suntec Reit's assets consist of offices, shops and convention space in Singapore
Quarz urged unitholders to vote for all the resolutions at the EGM to “ensure it can successfully execute on internalisation with as few obstacles as possible”.
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio. The Reit's trustee is HSBC Institutional Trust Services.
Giving an update to unitholders, Sabana Reit's trustee said it is working with the relevant parties to implement the resolutions passed at the EGM on Mar 8.
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.
A committee formed by Quarz Capital wants MAS and SGX RegCo to weigh in on whether ESR Group should be barred from voting on the extraordinary resolution to amend Sabana Reit's trust deed.

New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio. The Reit is due to hold an extraordinary general meeting requisitioned by a group of unitholders who call themselves the Sabana Growth Internalisation Committee.

site_title: Hong Kong considering ‘deepening’ some connect schemes with China: HKMA CEO
summary: Hong Kong's Monetary Authority (HKMA) is considering expanding its investment connection schemes with China, allowing more Chinese investors to buy into Hong Kong's financial markets. CEO Eddie Yue said the city aims to deepen southbound flows, or investments coming from China into the world, and increase potential for global bonds through the Hong Kong platform. The move is part of efforts to boost market competitiveness and liquidity, following a decline in Hong Kong's stock market last year.

images.alt_text: The Asian finance hub’s monetary policy moves in line with the US as the local currency is pegged to the greenback.
HKMA says the city’s financial and monetary markets continue to operate in a smooth and orderly manner.
A security guard walks past a directory board of Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) in Hong Kong December 20, 2012. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: 6.6-magnitude quake hits eastern Indonesia, no tsunami alert: USGS
summary: A 6.6-magnitude earthquake struck eastern Indonesia's Halmahera island in North Maluku province on April 9, with no tsunami warning issued. The quake occurred at a depth of 35 kilometers and caused no immediate damage or injuries. Indonesia's geophysics agency advised nearby residents of possible aftershocks, while the Pacific Tsunami Warning Centre declared no tsunami threat. The country experiences frequent earthquakes due to its location on the Pacific "Ring of Fire".

images.alt_text: A woman receives medical attention after being rescued from Taroko National Park, following an earthquake, in Hualien, Taiwan.

site_title: Seven & i to list supermarket unit Ito-Yokado, Kyodo reports
summary: Seven & i Holdings plans to list its supermarket unit Ito-Yokado, aiming to focus on its 7-Eleven convenience store operation. The move is expected to turn the superstore business profitable by the fiscal year ending February 2026. Ito-Yokado, struggling to compete with specialty outlets, has withdrawn from Japan's major northern island of Hokkaido and some other regions. The listing is set to be announced on Wednesday, when Seven & i will release its financial results, according to Kyodo news agency.

images.alt_text: Unlike their US counterparts, 7-Elevens in Japan offer everything from fresh food to concert tickets to delivery packages in one place.
The deal will allow Seven & i to establish “itself as the clear industry leader in the Australian convenience store market, which has significant growth potential,” the Japanese company says.

site_title: To build or not to build: Do e-commerce players need third-party logistics providers?
summary: E-commerce players in South-east Asia face a crucial decision: whether to build or partner with third-party logistics providers to scale and adapt to growing demand. With total revenue set to surpass S$280 billion by 2025, companies must weigh the benefits of cost savings and flexibility against the need for control and expertise. Partnering with 3PL providers can offer access to resources and networks, but may also lead to a loss of oversight and control. Developing an in-house logistics platform can provide faster decision-making and agility, but may require significant investment. Ultimately, the choice hinges on business priorities and the need for tailored solutions.

images.alt_text: South-east Asian logistics company Ninja Van has consolidated some parcel sorting stations, as parcel volumes get impacted by the economic slowdown.

site_title: MAS, Mastercard ink MOU to strengthen cyber resilience in financial services sector
summary: MAS and Mastercard signed a memorandum of understanding to enhance cybersecurity cooperation, focusing on strengthening cyber resilience in Singapore's financial services sector. The partnership aims to share cyber threat intelligence, analyze threats, and conduct joint cybersecurity exercises. Assistant Managing Director Vincent Loy emphasized the importance of public-private partnerships in fostering cyber resilience, particularly in the face of an evolving cyber threat landscape. The collaboration will raise situational awareness, produce actionable insights, and build competency among financial sector players.

images.alt_text: The value of more frequent scheduled meetings arguably has less to do with MAS’ own internal decision-making, and more to do with public signalling.
MAS' next monetary policy review is expected to take place this week.
OMFIF

site_title: Novartis to cut 680 jobs in product development
summary: Novartis plans to cut up to 680 jobs in its product development organization over the next two to three years, with around 440 jobs to be eliminated in Switzerland and up to 240 in the US. This is separate from a potential restructuring program that could affect up to 8,000 global employees. The company aims to reshape its capabilities to access local talent, particularly in data science and regulation. Despite the job cuts, Novartis remains committed to development work in both Switzerland and the US, with a net reduction of 1 to 2% globally.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat at the groundbreaking ceremony for Novartis' groundbreaking ceremony for its biopharmaceutical plant expansion.
Novartis will offer shareholders 68 euros per share in cash and take MorphoSys private after the deal.
FILE PHOTO: The company's logo is seen at the new cell and gene therapy factory of Swiss drugmaker Novartis in Stein, Switzerland, November 28, 2019. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: The company's logo is seen at the new cell and gene therapy factory of Swiss drugmaker Novartis in Stein, Switzerland, November 28, 2019. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
Richard Saynor, chief executive officer of Sandoz Group, speaking during the drugmaker's listing ceremony in Switzerland on Oct. 4.

site_title: Australia sets mandatory notification rule in M&A shakeup
summary: Australia has implemented mandatory notification rules for mergers and acquisitions, requiring large companies to seek clearance from the antitrust regulator before proceeding. The changes, set to take effect in 2026, will allow the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to block smaller deals that contribute to market power, rather than just larger ones. The new rules aim to strengthen Australia's merger laws and benefit consumers, businesses, and the economy, bringing the country's approach in line with most other developed nations.

images.alt_text: Confidence in the economic outlook has slipped in April.

site_title: China tells mid- to high-end hotels to accept foreign bank cards
summary: China's government has instructed mid- to high-end hotels to accept foreign bank cards, major tourist attractions to accept overseas bank cards and support cash payments, and increase foreign-exchange services. The move aims to make it easier for foreign visitors to travel in the country and boost the ailing economy. This move follows the widespread adoption of local payment systems such as WeChat Pay and Alipay, which have reduced the use of cash in China.

site_title: Frasers Property expects ‘significant’ drop in H1 earnings on fair value losses, impairment
summary: Frasers Property expects a "significant decrease" in net profit for the first half of its fiscal year due to fair value losses and impairment on certain commercial properties in the UK, primarily caused by "weaker market sentiments". The losses are non-cash in nature. The company is reviewing property valuations and will announce unaudited H1 financial results on May 10.

site_title: Europe: Slide in defence stocks knocks down Stoxx 600
summary: Europe's benchmark Stoxx 600 index fell 0.6% on Tuesday, its weakest session in nearly three weeks, as a gauge of defence stocks slumped 3.7% for its steepest one-day slide in over a year. Defence-related stocks such as SAAB, Leonardo, Rheinmetall, and Thales were among the top laggards, down between 4.9% and 9.8%. The decline dragged the pan-European Stoxx 600 index lower, with benchmark indexes in Germany, France, and Italy also losing ground. Investors braced for this week's US inflation data and the European Central Bank's monetary policy decision.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.5 per cent higher.

site_title: Issue of decarbonisation to dominate talks at Singapore Maritime Week
summary: The Singapore Maritime Week will focus on decarbonization, with discussions on alternative fuels and technologies. The European Union Emissions Trading Scheme (EU ETS) is causing industry concerns, with ship operators preferring a simple levy on bunker consumption. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to net-zero by 2027. Eight proposals for market-based measures were presented at the IMO Marine Environment Protection Committee (MEPC81) meeting, with the International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) seeking a flat-rate contribution system. A correspondence group on onboard carbon capture and storage (CCS) was also established, and the IMO's credibility on decarbonization will be crucial in October's MEPC82 meeting.

images.alt_text: Wreckage from the collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge resting on the cargo ship Dali in Baltimore, Maryland. The global supply chain impact of the bridge disaster may be limited but this is nevertheless a catastrophic event.
Having AI on the bridge might help vessels avoid collisions, but manning levels and fatigue are big issues that need addressing.
The issue of harassment and bullying should not be looked at in isolation – the culture onboard a ship is also crucial.

site_title: BP sees strong trading performance in Q1
summary: BP expects a strong trading performance in the first quarter, driven by rising oil and gas production and improved refining margins. The company's gas marketing and trading business maintained its strong performance, while oil showed improvement from a weak fourth quarter. Net debt is expected to rise due to a build in working capital. The trading update suggests a lower-than-expected impact from operational upsets, and shares are expected to report a positive earnings result.

images.alt_text: Former BP CEO Bernard Looney's remuneration totalled £1.175 million last year, but he lost bonuses and share awards totalling £3 million.

site_title: How the stock market can trip you up
summary: Warren Buffett advises investors to let the stock market serve them, not instruct them, emphasizing the importance of humility. Investors often fall for the "siren song" of falling share prices, which can lead to misinformed decisions. While opportunities may arise from lower prices, it's crucial to assess whether the fallen stocks deserve a place in the portfolio. Seasoned investors expect occasional mispricing, but it's essential to remain dispassionate towards short-term fluctuations and not get swayed by insider sales or dramatic price movements. Humility is key to successful investing, as it allows investors to acknowledge "I might be wrong" and adapt to market changes.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway owns a cornucopia of different companies, plus a portfolio of shares. It is arguably as diversified as a 30-stock index.
There is no thin line between arrogance and confidence, they are both sides of the same coin. You can be confident when you buy stocks, and be humble after you buy the stock.

site_title: Japan doubles down on US alliance as China looms
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's visit to Washington has strengthened the US-Japan alliance as China's growing influence in the Indo-Pacific region is a major concern. Japan has made significant changes in its foreign and security policies, including increasing defense spending and technological cooperation with the US and Australia. Kishida's speech to Congress will highlight the joint determination to support the Philippines, which is under increasing pressure from Beijing. The US and Japan are also working together to counter Chinese power, with plans for military commanders to work alongside each other and Japan's potential increase in technological cooperation with Aukus.

images.alt_text: Any deals that may be reached during the Australia-Asean summit are expected to be modest.
Under Philippines president Ferdinand Marcos Jr, the US is getting several new footholds in the country – a crucial link in the Pentagon’s “island chain” strategy for defensive lines in the Pacific.

US President Joe Biden (right) and China's President Xi Jinping (left) have managed to maintain a veneer of diplomatic stability despite deep mutual suspicion between their countries, and as their governments pursue export controls, sanctions and tariffs.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, April 9, 2024 (Ep 39)
summary: Japan's central bank hinted at another interest rate hike this year, while TSMC shares rose after securing a $6.6 billion US subsidy to expand in Arizona. Meanwhile, Cordlife's shares plummeted after 5,300 cord blood units were affected by temperature breaches, with the company offering refunds and fee waivers. The Singapore shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the STI up 0.3%.

images.alt_text: Chasen Holdings is the most actively traded counter on Tuesday morning.

Bank of Japan (BoJ) governor Kazuo Ueda speaks during a press conference after a two-day monetary policy meeting at the BOJ headquarters in Tokyo on March 19, 2024. Japan's central bank pulled the plug on March 19 on its ultra-aggressive monetary stimulus programme, hiking rates for the first time since the global financial crisis. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)
FILE PHOTO: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) logo is seen near computer motherboard in this illustration taken January 8, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Cordlife said it cannot be certain of the viability and potency of every CBU stored in the high-risk tanks and will deem that the CBUs in these tanks are impacted by temperature excursions.

site_title: US dollar struggles for direction ahead of data despite rise in yields
summary: The US dollar struggled for direction on Tuesday ahead of inflation data due on Wednesday, with the dollar index falling 0.01% to 104.05. US Treasury yields rose as markets scaled back bets on future Federal Reserve rate cuts. The yen hovered near multi-decade lows, sparking concerns of potential intervention. The prospect of a first 25 bps Fed rate cut in June decreased, while eurozone banks reported lower mortgage approvals amid stagnant economy, influencing ECB communications at its policy meeting.

images.alt_text: Wage negotiations in Japan are likely to show salaries rising by more than 5 per cent
The dollar index – which tracks the greenback against six major peers – was last broadly flat on Monday at 104.35.
Hong Kong, Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul and Taipei rose, but Shanghai, Singapore, Manila and Wellington were all down.

site_title: Centurion unit sets up JV company to lease, refurbish Hong Kong property
summary: Centurion Corporation has established a 60%-owned joint venture unit, Centurion-Lionrock (HK), to lease and refurbish a Hong Kong property. The 66-bed accommodation will primarily house students, with refurbishment expected to be completed in September at a cost of HK$11.5 million. Centurion Overseas Investments will fund the project with a shareholder loan at 8% interest. The venture marks Centurion's entry into the Hong Kong market, with LionRock Property holding the remaining 40%.

images.alt_text: Rental rates across the market have generally stabilised, but continue to increase with demand, says Centurion CEO Kong Chee Min.
Archer House, a student accommodation near the University of Nottingham, is one of Centurion's 34 purpose-built workers' and student accommodation assets.
Centurion says the expected increase in net profit comes on the back of "net fair value gains on the group’s investment properties expected to be recognised in FY2023".

Thilan Wickramasinghe, head of research for Singapore at Maybank Securities, said that while individual corporate strategies should be assessed based on their own merits, a higher debt ratio typically leads to higher risks for companies.
Centurion's Westlite Dormitory in Woodlands. The property player plans to develop the land owned by Oriental Amber into a workers' accommodation with 7,000 beds.

site_title: Geneva watch fair ticks to slower rhythm after three boom years
summary: The 2024 Geneva watch fair has kicked off with a slower rhythm, following three years of growth, amid lower demand in China for luxury Swiss timepieces and cautious consumer spending. 54 major watch brands, including Rolex and Patek Philippe, will showcase their latest creations. Despite a slowdown, high-end brands continue to grow, driven by wealthy clients, while the industry expects a "soft landing" with 4% market growth this year.

images.alt_text: This photograph taken on April 9, 2024, shows watches by Swiss watchmaker Rolex displayed during the opening day of the "Watches and Wonders Geneva" luxury watch fair, in Geneva. The "Watches and Wonders" fair, which runs until April 15, will see 54 major watch brands show off their latest creations, including Rolex, Patek Philippe, Cartier, Chopard, Hermes and Chanel. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP)

site_title: On economist Milton Friedman and a deeper understanding of economic theory
summary: Economist Milton Friedman, a Nobel laureate, is reevaluated in biography "Milton Friedman: The Last Conservative" by Jennifer Burns. Friedman's views evolved over time, challenging conservative orthodoxy, and his economic contributions, particularly on controlling the quantity of money, remain influential. His work, alongside Anna Schwartz, found that managing money was key to stable economic growth, despite other economists rejecting or modifying this thesis. Friedman's forceful defense of his ideas and criticism of opposing views cemented his place in economic theory discussions, offering a deeper understanding of economic theory to investment professionals.

site_title: Simon Harris elected new Irish PM
summary: Ireland's parliament has elected Fine Gael leader Simon Harris as the country's new prime minister, replacing Leo Varadkar. Harris, 37, received 88 votes to 69 and was officially installed at a ceremony with President Michael D Higgins, becoming Ireland's youngest ever prime minister. Harris has vowed to lead a partnership government, focus on unity and collaboration, and bring new ideas and energy to public life. He faces a challenging to-do list, including addressing housing and homelessness crises, and criticism of government policy on asylum seekers.

images.alt_text: Fine Gael leader and Ireland's incoming Prime Minster Simon Harris is greeted by colleagues and family members as he leaves the Dail, the lower house of the Irish parliament, in Dublin on April 9, 2024. Ireland's parliament on Tuesday voted in Simon Harris as the country's new prime minister, replacing Leo Varadkar after he abruptly quit last month citing personal and political reasons. Harris, 37, will become Ireland's youngest ever prime minister when he is formally installed in the role at a meeting with President Michael D. Higgins later on Tuesday. (Photo by PAUL FAITH / AFP)

site_title: Singapore stocks rise amid mixed regional sentiment; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.7% or 21.53 points to 3,237.52 on Tuesday, driven by a broader market gainers beating losers 382 to 210. Regional markets closed mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 gaining 1.1% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rising 0.6%. Investors remain cautious, awaiting a more meaningful recovery, with analysts citing incremental economic improvements and potential policy support in China.

images.alt_text: February’s slower industrial production growth in Malaysia could be due to shorter working days during Lunar New Year break.
Together with other better-than-expected manufacturing surveys, the data add to evidence that parts of China’s economy are gaining momentum in the first quarter.
The linchpin electronics sector improved by 0.4 point in March, posting a faster expansion at 50.8 and staying in expansion territory for the fifth consecutive month.

site_title: US small-business sentiment slides to lowest level in more than 11 years
summary: US small-business confidence fell to its lowest level in over 11 years in March, according to the National Federation of Independent Business, with the Small Business Optimism Index dropping 0.9 points to 88.5. Rising concerns about inflation and higher input and labor costs led to a 25% increase in reported inflation as a major problem, with 7-point increase in businesses raising average selling prices. Despite a weak hiring environment, some industries face acute worker shortages.

images.alt_text: Median year-ahead inflation expectations held at 3 per cent in March, a Federal Reserve Bank of New York survey showed on Monday (Apr 8).

According to a report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the U.S. labor market added 275,000 nonfarm payroll jobs in February, beating analyst expectations of 200,000. Elevated mortgage rates have been a persistent market challenge, holding back first-time homebuyers and repeat homebuyers alike.

Private payrolls rose by 184,000 jobs last month after advancing by an upwardly revised 155,000 in February, the ADP Employment report showed.
Official statistics show that the stuff a typical American buys now costs 20 per cent more since before the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Malaysian tycoon Vincent Tan is considering a Berjaya Food buyout
summary: Malaysian tycoon Vincent Tan is considering taking Berjaya Food private, the parent company of Starbucks' Malaysian operations, after talks with banks about financing a potential buyout deal. Berjaya Food's stock surged 6.5% following the report, its largest intraday gain since September. Tan's company, Berjaya Corp, has a 55% deemed interest in Berjaya Food, which owns Kenny Rogers Roasters and Jollibean brands. The decision is preliminary and Tan may still decide against pursuing a go-private deal.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of the upcoming Bandar Malaysia High Speed Rail station in Kuala LumpuR; the Sultan of Johor has been pushing for the revival of the high-speed rail project, which was cancelled in 2021.

site_title: Eurozone banks lower bar on mortgages but demand keeps falling: ECB
summary: Eurozone banks lowered mortgage approval standards for the first time in over two years, but demand for credit from households and companies remained low due to high borrowing costs and a stagnant economy. The European Central Bank's quarterly Bank Lending Survey showed a "substantial decline" in demand for corporate credit and a "small decline" in housing loans. Despite easing mortgage standards, banks expect a "moderate net decrease" in demand for corporate loans and an increase in demand for household loans in the next six months.

images.alt_text: The subindex, made up of eurozone lenders including Deutsche Bank, has risen more than 20 per cent in 2024, far outstripping the 7 per cent gain of the broader Stoxx 600 Index.

site_title: Still springtime for Japanese equities
summary: Japan's largest companies have agreed to raise wages by 5.28% in the spring wage negotiations, marking the second consecutive year of salary increases after decades of wage stagnation. This comes as the Bank of Japan (BOJ) lifted its deposit rate, set its new key interest rate, and removed its 10-year bond yield cap, signaling a shift towards a more accommodative monetary policy stance. Japanese equities have seen a 19% gain in the first quarter, with the MSCI Japan Index up 41% over the past year, driven by a conducive macro backdrop and corporate and shareholder reform.

images.alt_text: A visitor walks past Japan's Nikkei stock prices quotation board inside a building in Tokyo, Japan February 19, 2024. REUTERS/Issei Kato
The BOJ releases fresh quarterly growth and inflation forecasts at its next meeting in Apr 25 to 26.
The key nationwide gauge for consumer inflation has hovered at or above the Bank of Japan’s 2 per cent target for almost two years.

site_title: Malaysia orders Meta, TikTok to forge plans on harmful content
summary: Malaysia has ordered Meta and TikTok to present plans to combat harmful content online, following a significant increase in offensive material on social media platforms. The government reported over 50,000 cases of harmful content in the first three months of this year, mostly related to race, religion, and royalty. Tech firms have been required to step up monitoring efforts and remove posts linked to scams and illegal gambling. A meeting with the Communications Minister led to the demand for an improvement plan and strategy, but no specific timeframe or penalties were set.

images.alt_text: TikTok is the only social media company that sells goods directly on its app.
Since the violence erupted, both social media firms have taken steps to improve moderation and remove or label graphic visuals.
The concerns come two weeks after Fahmi said TikTok had not complied fully with Malaysia’s laws and had not done enough to curb defamatory or misleading content.
As TikTok faces pushback in South-east Asia, the company has to decide if the region is worth staying in.

site_title: China's Q1 EV sales growth slowest in a year
summary: China's electric vehicle (EV) sales in Q1 grew 10.5% in March, the slowest quarterly growth since 2023, with 1.03 million EVs sold. New energy vehicles made up 41.5% of passenger car sales in March. Authorities have launched initiatives to boost sales, including revising car loans and scrapping minimum down payments. BYD, the top EV seller in Q1, lowered starting prices for nine models, while Tesla increased Model Y prices but offered a zero-interest financing scheme.

images.alt_text: Chinese brands now make up 10 per cent of the entire market.

site_title: HSBC to book US$1 billion pre-tax loss from sale of Argentina business
summary: HSBC is selling its Argentina business to Grupo Financiero Galicia for $550 million, resulting in a $1 billion pre-tax loss. The divestment is part of the bank's Asia pivot strategy, focusing on India and China. HSBC's Hong Kong-listed shares rose 1.1% following the announcement. The sale marks the bank's exit from the Argentine market, which generates volatile earnings when translated into US dollars. This is the latest in HSBC's recent exits from business activities and countries, including Canada and French retail operations.

images.alt_text: Quinn is hosting the bank’s three-day inaugural Global Investment Summit that kicked off in Hong Kong earlier Monday.
India will reach the maximum 10 per cent weighting in the gauge, making it crucial for funds tracking the index to add the nation’s debt to their portfolios.

site_title: L’Occitane owner plans second try to take company private, sources say
summary: Austrian billionaire Reinold Geiger, chairman and controlling shareholder of French cosmetics company L'Occitane International, is planning to take the company private again, sources say. Geiger is in advanced discussions with investors and lenders, including US private equity giant Blackstone, which may provide debt financing. The plan, valued at around $5.55 billion, could be announced in coming days, but deal terms are not finalized and the plan may not proceed. L'Occitane halted trading in its Hong Kong shares ahead of the announcement.

images.alt_text: Apartment landlords are now the best-performing group among the Reit industry.

site_title: Ahead of Scholz trip, study shows German economy still dependent on China
summary: Germany's economy remains heavily reliant on China for certain products and raw materials, despite efforts to diversify, according to a study by the German Economic Institute. While imports from China dropped by nearly 20% between 2022 and 2023, the share of product groups reliant on China for more than half of imports has remained largely unchanged. Chancellor Olaf Scholz's trip to China this week aims to address concerns over fair access to the Chinese market, amidst growing European worries about Chinese excess capacity.

images.alt_text: Consumer prices rose an annual 2.3 per cent last month, according to the statistics office – down from 2.7 per cent in February.
The number of transactions dropped 19 per cent in the first quarter compared with a year earlier.

Germany's economic problems are largely down to the cutoff of Russian energy supplies, weak Asian demand for exports, problems among the country’s car manufacturers in adapting to the green transition and high interest rates.
Weak demand contributed to further factory job losses and a sustained draw-down of pre-production inventories.
The revised 2023 budget will now be sent to parliament for approval, with an initial debate scheduled for Friday morning.

site_title: Global accounting rule ends leeway over operating profit
summary: The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) has announced new requirements for global companies to publish standardized operating profit figures starting in 2027. This move aims to end the "misleading" numbers that Warren Buffett, chair of Berkshire Hathaway, has described as failing to include the cost of depreciation. The change will help investors rely on more accurate figures in their income statements, marking a significant shift in global accounting rules.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Warren Buffett, Chairman, CEO and largest shareholder of Berkshire Hathaway takes part in interviews before a fundraising luncheon for the nonprofit Glide Foundation in New York September 8, 2015.  REUTERS/Lucas Jackson/File Photo

site_title: Aviva completes takeover of AIG's UK life insurance business
summary: Aviva completed the £453 million acquisition of AIG's UK life insurance business, known as AIG Life UK, from Corebridge Financial, a New York-listed company majority-owned by AIG. This is the largest takeover under Aviva CEO Amanda Blanc. The deal was announced in September and marks Aviva's continued focus on "selective" acquisitions.

site_title: Tesla’s Musk predicts AI will be smarter than the smartest human next year
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk predicts that artificial intelligence (AI) will be smarter than the smartest human by 2026, or possibly next year. The development of AI is constrained by the availability of electricity and advanced chips, with Musk's startup xAI requiring 100,000 Nvidia H100 chips to train its next model. Musk also addressed various other topics, including the competitiveness of Chinese carmakers, a union strike in Sweden against Tesla, and his company's performance.

images.alt_text: The automaker faces lawsuits and investigations into crashes involving its Autopilot and Full Self-Driving driver-assistance systems, which are not fully autonomous.
Musk has long boasted of work Tesla is doing on its systems for electric cars to drive themselves.
Typically accounts must pay for X’s premium monthly subscription to receive a blue badge.

site_title: A different kind of property crash hits Dublin as Big Tech cuts space
summary: Dublin's North Docks area is experiencing a property crash, with troubled buildings and declining rents due to reduced space demand from US tech firms. Values have fallen 40-50% from their peak, and investors expect further price declines and financing strains. The downturn is attributed to a shift towards remote work, with tech firms leasing 90% less space in the fourth quarter of last year. Experts predict a two-year recovery, with demand favoring high-quality, energy-efficient buildings with green credentials. Ireland's central bank governor has expressed confidence in the resilience of the system, but insolvency experts warn that patience with borrowers will run out.

images.alt_text: Housing has become a thorny political issue for Europe, with struggles to find affordable living space contributing to social tensions and voter frustration.

site_title: BOJ's Ueda signals scope to reduce monetary stimulus
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda signaled the potential reduction of monetary stimulus, citing a need to address trend inflation that has yet to reach its 2% target. Ueda stated that the central bank may consider further interest rate hikes later this year if inflation accelerates, but also expressed optimism about Japan's economic outlook due to solid pay hikes boosting household income and consumption.

images.alt_text: Kazuo Ueda last week signalled the chance of raising interest rates again later this year, suggesting that his longer-term mission had yet to be fulfilled.

site_title: Singapore agritech startup Peptobiotics bags US$6.2 million in Series A
summary: Singapore-based agritech startup Peptobiotics has secured US$6.2 million in Series A funding, led by Hatch Blue's US$81 million Blue Revolution Fund. Existing investors, including Enterprise Singapore, French equity investor Seventure Partners, and Australian agribusiness GrainCorp Ventures, also participated. The funding aims to produce larger commercial volumes and address antibiotic abuse in the aquaculture industry. Peptobiotics' recombinant antimicrobial peptides can kill bacteria as efficiently as antibiotics, offering a potential solution to the industry's disease challenges and cutting antibiotics out of the food supply chain.

images.alt_text: Accredify aims to prevent scams and fraud in e-commerce, ticketing and news dissemination, says its CEO and co-founder Quah Zheng Wei.
RedDoorz, which plans to expand into Malaysia, follows a multibranding strategy.

site_title: Big Tech is trapped in a glass house on AI data snatching
summary: Big Tech firms, particularly OpenAI, are accused of exploiting user data by training their AI systems on YouTube video transcripts. The practice, which involves extracting conversational text from YouTube videos, is considered a breach of rules and raises concerns about data ownership. This move reverses the traditional flow of user data, with Big Tech firms now collecting data from each other. The practice has sparked debate about data ownership and the ethics of using user-generated content to train AI models.

site_title: Citigroup CEO faces growth challenge as overhaul rattles employees
summary: Citigroup CEO Jane Fraser's overhaul of the company's structure has been met with support from Wall Street investors, who have rewarded her with a share price boost. The overhaul, which included cutting 5,000 employees, aims to cut costs and boost growth in wealth management and investment banking. However, investors caution that Fraser faces significant challenges ahead, including regulatory issues, weak earnings, and an unsettled workforce. Analysts predict a "middle phase" of challenges for Fraser, with growth and returns needing to be boosted to catch up with rivals.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Jane Fraser, Chief Executive Officer of Citi, speaks during the Global Financial Leaders' Investment Summit, in Hong Kong, China November 7, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu//File Photo

site_title: France’s Atos plunges as refinancing plan fails to reassure
summary: Atos, a French IT consulting firm, saw its shares plummet 14% on April 9, 2024, after announcing a refinancing plan that would raise 1.2 billion euros and result in significant dilution for existing shareholders. The company aims to raise 600 million euros through debt and equity to sustain its business until 2025, with a potential long-term refinancing agreement by June. France has pledged an additional 50 million euro loan to Atos, giving the state a stronger say in strategic activities.

images.alt_text: Atos says a global refinancing agreement could lead to the issuance of new equity, adding that this will likely result in a dilution of the existing shareholders.

site_title: Changi Airport Group founding CEO to step down on Jul 1, replacement named
summary: Changi Airport Group's founding CEO, Lee Seow Hiang, will step down on July 1, 2024, after 15 years in the role. Yam Kum Weng, current executive vice-president of airport development, will succeed him as CEO. Lee will also step down as CAG board director and chairman of Changi Airports International and Jewel Changi Airport Development. The board believes Yam is best suited to lead the group in tackling mega-development programmes and ensuring smooth airport operations, following the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Ascend Elements, Elemental Strategic Metals form European EV battery recycling venture
summary: Ascend Elements and Elemental Strategic Metals have formed a joint venture, AE Elemental, to recycle electric vehicle batteries in Europe. The first plant in southern Poland has a capacity of 12,000 tonnes annually, equivalent to 28,000 EVs, with a second plant planned in Germany. The venture aims to reduce waste and extract lithium and other materials for new EVs. The companies are seeking EU and local government funding to support their investments.

site_title: China’s ICBC plans US$5.5 billion sale of loss-absorbing bonds
summary: China's Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) plans to issue up to $7.45 billion in loss-absorbing bonds (TLAC) as part of efforts to bolster capital and comply with global regulatory requirements. The bank's move comes after China's big banks posted scant gains in earnings for 2023, weaker net interest margins, and rising bad loans. ICBC will issue 20 billion yuan in TLAC bonds redeemable in three years and 10 billion yuan in bonds redeemable in five years, with the option to extend the redemption period.

images.alt_text: ICBC signed a cooperation pact with China’s culture and tourism ministry on Tuesday (Apr 2) to “stimulate” tourism investment and spending.
ICBC's profit of 363.99 billion yuan (S$67.9 billion) slightly exceeded an estimate of 359 billion yuan in a poll of 19 analysts.

site_title: Chevron hands Myanmar gas field stake to junta, Thailand’s PTTEP
summary: US energy company Chevron has withdrawn from its stake in Myanmar's Yadana natural gas field, transferring 41.1% of its interest to Thailand's PTTEP and state-owned Myanma Oil and Gas Enterprise. Chevron had previously condemned violence and human rights abuses in Myanmar but failed to sell its stake, instead exiting the country. The move comes amid ongoing humanitarian crisis and sanctions imposed by the US administration.

Despite the nearly 40 per cent fall in annual profit, Chevron announces it would increase its dividend by 8 per cent in a sign of confidence.

site_title: Malaysian PM Anwar’s anti-graft crusade: seven down, more to go?
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's anti-graft crusade has led to the arrest of seven influential figures, including former finance minister Daim Zainuddin, tycoon Robert Tan, and opposition leader Muhammad Sanusi Md Nor. The arrests are part of a broader probe into corruption and financial irregularities, with some accusing the move of being politically motivated. The seven individuals are being investigated or charged under Anwar's administration, with assets worth millions of dollars being seized, including RM3 billion from Daim Zainuddin.

images.alt_text: “I do not concede or compromise on this,” Anwar said at the Milken Institute Asia Summit in Singapore on Wednesday (Sep 13), when asked how recent legal decisions favourable to his allies fit into his anti-graft stance.
Daim served as finance minister from 1984 to 1991 and from 1999 to 2001.

Muhammad Adlan Berhan faces several charges for criminal breach of trust according to Malaysia's Anti-Corruption agency.

site_title: ‘Mad Max’ director readies for fifth instalment in ‘addictive’ series
summary: Director George Miller is preparing to premiere the fifth film in the 'Mad Max' series, 'Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga', an origin story for the character Furiosa. The film, set to release in late May, follows the younger Furiosa, played by Anya Taylor-Joy, and is described by Miller as "addictive". This marks the first spin-off film in the series, following the success of 'Mad Max: Fury Road'.

images.alt_text: The “hero floating wood panel” was designed to mimic the most famous complete piece of debris salvaged from the 1912 shipwreck

site_title: South Korea election hinges on urban voters and inflation worries
summary: South Korea's parliamentary elections, set for April 10, are expected to hinge on urban voters and inflation concerns. President Yoon Suk Yeol's ruling People Power Party (PPP) has 37% support, but must reclaim ground in the capital, Seoul, where the Democratic Party (DP) has a majority. Key issues include tackling inflation, reining in housing prices, and supporting the country's export-driven economy. The PPP has proposed pro-business policies, while the DP has promised to raise taxes on chaebol conglomerates and increase fiscal support for daily necessities. The outcome will determine the government's ability to pass policies and potentially end Yoon's term.

images.alt_text: South Koreans have been active in the latest digital-asset bull market and are famed for their ardor for smaller cryptocurrencies, not just market-leader Bitcoin.

site_title: Singapore, Germany to work towards upgrading relations to a Strategic Partnership
summary: Singapore and Germany have agreed to work towards upgrading their relations to a Strategic Partnership, recognizing the "growing depth and breadth" of bilateral ties. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong's six-day visit to Germany and France aims to intensify cooperation in existing and emerging areas. The two countries have strengthened ties over the decades, with Germany being Singapore's largest goods trading partner in the EU and third-largest investment destination. The partnership will focus on upholding rule of law, multilateralism, and open trading systems, amidst growing global complexities and competition.

images.alt_text: Wong will visit Berlin from Monday (Apr 8) to Wednesday, and be in Paris from Wednesday to Saturday

site_title: China’s CDH buys minority interest in Vietnam grocery chain Bach Hoa Xanh
summary: China's CDH Investments completed a minority investment in Vietnam's grocery chain Bach Hoa Xanh, valued at 1.8 trillion dong (S$97.2 million), representing 5% of the firm's charter capital. The deal confirms earlier talks and allows Mobile World to maintain control as a co-shareholder alongside CDH and management. CDH's head of South-east Asia, Thomas Lanyi, stated that consumer needs are shifting towards modern alternatives, positioning Bach Hoa Xanh to capitalize on this trend.

images.alt_text: CDH is best known for its dealmaking in traditional industries such as consumption and manufacturing in the early years.

site_title: Cloud-based startup CNV secures US$1 million seed funding from Wavemaker Partners
summary: CNV, a Vietnamese cloud-based business and marketing solutions provider, secured US$1 million in seed funding from Wavemaker Partners. The funding comes after the company's "stellar performance" in 2022 and 2023, with notable milestones including the launch of Zalo mini apps in 2023. CNV aims to help enterprises optimize their customer data and achieve sustainable growth through marketing, loyalty, and e-commerce activities. With the funding, the company plans to expand its offerings to become a "no-code sales and customer care platform" and support hundreds of thousands of businesses in Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Late-stage funding declined, data intelligence platform Tracxn said in its report released on Wednesday (Mar 27).
Some international investors are backing South-east Asian startups for the first time.

site_title: Singapore court’s verdict was wrong; Credit Suisse unit did ‘incompetent best’ for client: lawyer
summary: A lawyer for a Credit Suisse trust is challenging a US$743 million damages award to Georgian billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili, citing staff as having done their "incompetent best" in handling rogue banker Patrice Lescaudron. The lawyer, Lee Eng Beng, stated that staff informed their superiors about Lescaudron's illicit payments but failed to notify Ivanishvili. The lead lawyer's concession marks a surprise in the bank's appeal over its mishandling of Lescaudron.

images.alt_text: Since the litigation began, Credit Suisse has been taken over by rival UBS Group.

The Singapore Court’s decision is another blow for Credit Suisse, which is taken over by its rival UBS, Switzerland’s biggest bank, in June to prevent a financial collapse following a series of scandals.

site_title: Bitcoin seen below US$20,000 in consumer survey by Deutsche Bank
summary: Deutsche Bank's survey found consumers are divided on Bitcoin's future, with 40% confident it will thrive and 38% expecting it to disappear. About 1/3 expect the token to slide below $20,000 by the end of the year, a $50,000 drop from its current price. Despite a 67% rise this year, only 10% predict it will reach $75,000 by December. The upcoming halving event is seen as a potential bullish factor by some investors.

images.alt_text: The neon logos of Bitcoin and Ethereum cryptocurrencies in the window of a crypto exchange in Warsaw, Poland, on Thursday, March 14, 2024. Bitcoin extended a retreat from its latest record high amid an intensifying debate about whether the bull run in cryptocurrencies is evidence of speculative froth in global markets. Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as ‘critical’ US inflation data looms
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Tuesday as investors awaited US inflation data, which could impact the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions. Stocks surged in New York after strong March job numbers, but a disappointing consumer price index report could send markets into turmoil. Analysts expect around 60 basis points of interest rate cuts this year, with some considering no cuts before 2025, adding uncertainty to the market outlook. The European Central Bank is also expected to maintain its stance, with bets on a potential rate cut rising.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul and Taipei rose, but Shanghai, Singapore, Manila and Wellington were all down.

site_title: Frasers Property to install 4,500 sq m of solar panels in its properties in SP Group tie-up
summary: Frasers Property has partnered with SP Group to install approximately 4,500 square meters of solar panels across seven of its retail and commercial properties in Singapore, including Alexandra Technopark, Causeway Point, and Hougang Mall. The installation aims to reduce the properties' energy consumption and carbon footprint. This partnership is part of Frasers Property's efforts to adopt sustainable practices and contribute to Singapore's environmental goals.

site_title: Yellen junks 200 years of economics to block China clean tech
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is rejecting 200 years of economics to justify restricting public access to affordable and clean technology from China. Yellen claims China's clean tech investments are excessive and damaging, citing a surplus in production capacity for solar panels, EVs, and lithium-ion batteries. However, experts argue that the US and EU are cracking down on a sector where private companies are dominant and where reducing global emissions is good. Yellen's policy is seen as protectionist and a "disaster in the making" for both the US and the planet.

images.alt_text: Analysts sat the spending data could be a turning point, as consumption in China has struggled to recover since the lifting of Covid curbs.
Challenges facing the economy are rife, despite activity improving at the start of 2024.
The People’s Bank of China will support banks to replenish capital and guide financial institutions to increase medium- and long-term loans to the manufacturing industry.
Together with other better-than-expected manufacturing surveys, the data add to evidence that parts of China’s economy are gaining momentum in the first quarter.

site_title: Is DBS Singapore’s indispensable stock?
summary: DBS Singapore, the country's largest listed company by market capitalization, is considered an indispensable stock due to its size, regulated industry, and strong reputation. The bank's focus on Asia, particularly China, India, and Indonesia, offers growth prospects. With a history of achieving higher return on equity (ROE) than peers, DBS is expected to outperform OCBC and UOB. The bank's management is confident of achieving ROE of 15-17% over the next 3-5 years, driving sustainable growth in profits and dividends.

images.alt_text: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta speaks during a Reuters Newsmaker event in Singapore September 14, 2023. REUTERS/Mindy Tan
Investors should have much to cheer with DBS' strong financial performance, proposed bonus issue and plans to pay higher dividends.

site_title: Total solar eclipse: North Americans celebrate with cheers, music and matrimony
summary: A total solar eclipse swept across North America on April 8, 2024, visible from the contiguous United States until 2044. The event drew throngs of skywatchers, with some 2,000 people gathering at Niagara Falls State Park and 400 couples tying the knot in a mass wedding event. Thousands more attended events across the US and Mexico, witnessing the rare spectacle of the moon blocking the sun's corona. The eclipse's path of totality spanned 4,000 km, with clear skies prevailing in some areas, while overcast skies added to the challenge for many.

images.alt_text: An artist illustration of the SLIM (Smart Lander for Investigating Moon) landing phase on the Moon, provided  by the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA).

site_title: Lilly’s US$2.5 billion German plant will boost obesity-drug supply
summary: Eli Lilly is investing $2.5 billion in a new plant in Germany to boost production of its weight-loss blockbuster Zepbound, which faces shortages in the US. The plant, set to open in 2027, will create 1,000 jobs and supply worldwide. The move comes as the company races against Novo Nordisk to supply the growing demand for injected obesity medicines, with Lilly executives anticipating shortages in the US this year. The plant will produce injectable medicines and injector pens, addressing the growing need for these medicines.

site_title: Singapore to face tough fight for IPOs from US, HK and London as markets recover
summary: Singapore's stock exchange faces increased competition from major bourses in the US, Hong Kong, and London as markets recover from a decline in new IPOs over the past two years. Experts predict a rivalry for new listings, with Singapore Exchange (SGX) needing to innovate to attract companies. The decline in IPOs is attributed to central banks' interest rate hikes. The SGX must work harder to attract good listings, according to OCBC's managing director of investment strategy Vasu Menon.

images.alt_text: Global IPO proceeds are 7 per cent higher year on year in Q1 at US$23.7 billion.
Despite booking a net loss of US$90.8 million in 2023, Reddit shares have traded as high as double its IPO price of US$34 apiece.

site_title: Australian consumer confidence slumps as prices, rates take toll
summary: Australian consumer confidence declined 2.4% in April to 82.4 points, the lowest reading in over two years, due to persistent inflation and high interest rates. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) continues to raise interest rates, and economists expect little relief until late this year. Despite tax cuts set to take effect on July 1, households remain pessimistic, with a "finances vs a year ago" sub-index at 65.5. The RBA's policy stance suggests sticky inflation worries remain.

images.alt_text: Michele Bullock knows the RBA has only one chance to get the timing of the easing cycle right.
Australia’s government has pledged to build 1.2 million new homes between July this year and mid-2029.
Poor productivity growth has boosted unit labour costs which is putting upward pressure on inflation at a time.
The RBA’s implementation of monetary policy is an area of confusion for professional economists, commentators and educators alike, particularly following the pandemic.

site_title: China’s EV makers bet they can dethrone Japan brands in Thailand
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) manufacturers are gaining traction in Thailand, with Chinese brands now accounting for 10% of the market. This growth is attributed to the country's public initiative offering subsidies and tax breaks for EVs, which has led to a significant increase in EV sales from less than 10,000 units in 2020 to 76,000 units last year. As a result, Japanese legacy carmakers like Toyota and Isuzu are facing threats to their market share, with some predicting that Chinese brands could eventually dethrone them.

images.alt_text: China has a significant lead over European companies in developing low-cost EV models in particular.
FILE PHOTO: Visitors check a Tesla Model 3 car next to a Model Y displayed at a showroom of the U.S. electric vehicle (EV) maker in Beijing, China February 4, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo
Xiaomi’s SU7 enters a crowded China EV market with an attention-grabbing price tag – under US$30,000 for the base model, cheaper than Tesla’s Model 3 in China.

site_title: Night tours spotlight Casablanca’s architectural heritage
summary: Casablanca, Morocco, is offering guided night tours to highlight its rich architectural heritage, including Moorish tiles, ancient minarets, and French colonial facades with Art Deco touches. The tours, organized by the heritage association Casamemoire, aim to promote preservation and appreciation of the city's unique heritage. Many historical buildings, such as the Wilaya hall and the central bank building, showcase a blend of European and Moroccan architectural styles. Despite official efforts, some buildings remain abandoned or closed, sparking public outrage, with conservation battles ongoing to preserve the city's architectural gems.

images.alt_text: Must Farm Quarry, a Bronze Age site on a river channel in eastern England, is the subject of two monographs published on Mar 19 by Cambridge University.

site_title: Thailand approves new measures to boost property sector
summary: Thailand's government has approved new measures to boost the country's property sector, including increasing the threshold for lower transaction fees for houses and condominiums priced up to 7 million baht (S$258,053) and extending tax incentives for individuals and companies that build or develop properties. The measures aim to revive the nation's residential real estate market and speed up property transfers in the 3-7 million baht price range. The government expects to forego about 1.99 billion baht of fees per month from the fresh incentives, which will last until December 31.

images.alt_text: Global real estate has taken a hit over the past year, in part due to interest rate hikes, which are keeping office towers empty and new buyers away

site_title: Gold prices edge higher as markets await Fed minutes, CPI data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to a record high of $2,353.79 per ounce, hovering slightly below the level as investors await the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes and key inflation data. The US CPI data and Fed minutes are due on Wednesday, which may influence interest rate cuts. Americans' inflation outlook is mixed, and futures traders have reduced bets on rate cuts. China's central bank added 160,000 troy ounces of gold to its reserves, supporting the recent rally.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was down 1.1 per cent at US$2,305.09 per ounce.

site_title: Dimon calls push to stop all oil and gas enormously naive
summary: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase CEO, criticized the US delay of liquefied natural gas (LNG) projects as "naive" and "wrong", calling them a "political goal" to pacify those seeking to stop oil and gas projects. Dimon supports LNG exports as a "great economic boon" and "realpolitik goal", citing their importance for US allies and the nation's energy security. The US permitting freeze, imposed by President Biden, has halted new approvals for pending LNG projects.

site_title: Donald Trump’s media company falls 12%, extends sell-off
summary: Donald Trump's media company, Trump Media & Technology Group, fell 12% on Monday, extending a sell-off that reduced the value of his stake to US$2.9 billion. The company disclosed millions in losses and struggled to meet financial liabilities, leading to a decline in its stock price to US$37.17. The market value of the company is now below US$5.6 billion, a significant drop from its record high of US$79 in March. This decline is welcome news for short-sellers, who have suffered losses on the stock this year.

images.alt_text: File photo of then-US President Donald Trump holding up a Bible outside of St John's Episcopal church in Washington, DC on June 1, 2020. Trump reposted a news article titled, “The Crucifixion of Donald Trump” - only the latest in a series of references made or disseminated by Trump in which he is compared to Christ.
Trump Media & Technology Group posted a net loss of US$58.2 million in the year ended December 2023, compared with a net profit of US$50.5 million a year earlier.

site_title: TerraPay wins Singapore licence for money transfer, account issuance services
summary: TerraPay has secured a payment institution (MPI) licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore, allowing it to offer financial services such as account issuance, remittances, and e-money distribution. This comes after the company won preliminary approval for the licence less than a year ago. TerraPay plans to strengthen existing partnerships and forge new deals to expand its presence in Asia Pacific, with a focus on international remittance services. The company joins a growing list of MPI licence holders in Singapore, including Payoneer and Circle.

site_title: US inflation expectations stabilise, but debt concerns pick up
