summary: US inflation expectations remain stable at 3% for the next year, according to a Federal Reserve Bank of New York survey. However, Americans are increasingly concerned about paying off debt, with the probability of missing a minimum debt payment rising to 12.9% in March. Concerns are most pronounced among households aged 40-60, who tend to have higher debt and slower income growth. Expected price growth for various goods and services also increased in March, reflecting ongoing inflation uncertainty.

images.alt_text: SAN RAFAEL, CALIFORNIA - MARCH 08: Home Depot customers walk by a posted now hiring sign on March 08, 2024 in San Rafael, California. According to a report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the U.S. labor market added 275,000 nonfarm payroll jobs in February, beating analyst expectations of 200,000. The unemployment rate inched up to 3.9% from 3.7% in January.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
Elevated mortgage rates have been a persistent market challenge, holding back first-time homebuyers and repeat homebuyers alike.
Most of the imported goods will likely ended up as inventories, which could offset the anticipated hit on gross domestic product from the widening trade gap.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits rose 9,000 to a seasonally adjusted 221,000 for the week ended Mar 30.
A measure of new orders received by services businesses slipped to 54.4 last month from 56.1 in February.
Private payrolls rose by 184,000 jobs last month after advancing by an upwardly revised 155,000 in February, the ADP Employment report showed.

site_title: UBS weighs Credit Suisse China stake swap with Beijing government
summary: UBS is in talks to acquire full ownership of its China platform by swapping its 33% stake in Credit Suisse Securities (China) with a Beijing government investment fund. UBS would sell up to its entire 51% position in the venture in exchange for the stake. This proposal comes as UBS seeks to avoid a strong global player like Citadel Securities, which is vying for the platform. The Beijing government has been reluctant to sell due to the venture's growth and earnings potential, but the worsening US-China tensions may favor a foreign buyer.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of Swiss bank UBS is seen in Zurich, Switzerland March 29, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: Seatrium, GSH and Global Invacom report 3 straight years of losses
summary: Three Singapore Exchange-listed companies, Seatrium, GSH Corporation, and Global Invacom, have reported consecutive years of losses, prompting a potential listing on the SGX watch list. Seatrium's net loss widened to S$1.7 billion in H2 FY2024, while GSH's net loss narrowed to S$11.2 million in FY2023. Global Invacom posted a narrowed net loss of US$963,000 in FY2023. If notified, the companies will make an immediate announcement and have 36 months to rectify the situation to avoid delisting.

images.alt_text: Seatrium logo at their office’s lobby, Oct 19, 2023.

site_title: Tesla settles case over fatal Autopilot crash of Apple engineer
summary: Tesla has settled a lawsuit over a 2018 fatal car crash involving its Autopilot system, which killed 38-year-old Apple engineer Walter Huang. The settlement ends a five-year legal battle and comes as Tesla faces a flurry of lawsuits over Autopilot crashes, potentially setting a precedent for others suing over the system. The case follows previous trials won by Tesla, which has argued that drivers misused the Autopilot system. The settlement may signal a shift in Tesla's approach to handling Autopilot-related lawsuits.

images.alt_text: Musk has long boasted of work Tesla is doing on its systems for electric cars to drive themselves.
A greater emphasis on robotaxis comes with more risk, say analysts.
FILE PHOTO: Visitors check a Tesla Model 3 car next to a Model Y displayed at a showroom of the U.S. electric vehicle (EV) maker in Beijing, China February 4, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: Blackstone bet spurs biggest apartment rally since December
summary: Blackstone's plan to acquire Apartment Income Reit for $10 billion has sparked the largest rally in nearly four months for apartment landlords, with the industry index rising over 4% and erasing this year's losses. The move is seen as bolstering investors' confidence in the sector, following Blackstone's previous acquisition of Tricon Residential. The rally is also expected to spur additional bullish sentiment for the group, with analysts predicting a pick-up in deal activity in the real estate industry in 2024.

images.alt_text: The Blackstone headquarters in New York, US, on Monday, Jan. 8, 2024. Blackstone Inc. released earnings figures on January 25. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg
The Blackstone headquarters in New York, US, on Monday, Jan. 8, 2024. Blackstone Inc. released earnings figures on January 25. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg
The Blackstone headquarters in New York. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg
Crown Resorts, which was taken private in 2022 by Blackstone for A$8.9 billion, is Victoria’s biggest single-site private sector employer, with about 11,500 staff.

site_title: Only 12% of Asia’s investors plan to invest more into climate solutions: AIGCC
summary: Only 12% of Asia's institutional investors plan to increase their investments in climate solutions, despite showing strong interest in the global net-zero push. A survey by the Asia Investor Group on Climate Change found that 28% have set policies on transition finance and phase-down of fossil fuels, but only 12% have integrated deforestation into their investment approach. Lack of data, unclear definitions, and limited tools hinder investors from allocating more funds to climate-aligned investments, with 57% citing data as the most significant barrier.

images.alt_text: Tan Jenn-hui says the just transition is a helpful part of Fidelity’s analytical toolkit, as it helps the manager understand the challenges investee companies face when they undertake their decarbonisation journeys.
The ECB has grown increasingly active in its efforts to get lenders to treat ESG risks – particularly climate change – as financially material.

Photovoltaic solar panels and windmills around the Spanish Navarre town of Milagro. The world still requires wind and solar to achieve its net zero goals, and developers are crucial to delivering that.
The EU's proposed sustainability rules will apply to firms that have more than 1,000 employees, and net worldwide turnover above 450 million euros (S$654.2 million).
Prospects for US offshore wind remain uncertain due to inflation and supply-chain issues.

This picture taken on January 22, 2024 shows a section of JT-60SA, the world's biggest experimental nuclear fusion reactor Naka Fusion Institute in Naka city of Ibaraki Prefecture. (Photo by Philip FONG / AFP)

site_title: Stocks to watch: Cordlife, Seatrium, Global Invacom, Zico
summary: Cordlife Group announced it will refund and waive annual fees for clients whose cord-blood units are at high risk of being adversely affected by temperature excursions. Seatrium and Global Invacom filed notices of consecutive years of losses. Zico made new board appointments, including Mohamed Nasser Ismail, former SGX global head of equity capital markets. The moves may impact trading of these companies' securities.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% to 3,224.06 on Tuesday, following a mixed global market overnight. The most actively traded counter was Chasen, a logistics service provider, which increased 8.5% after 8.8 million shares were traded. US stocks ended largely unchanged, while European shares climbed 0.5% after strong industrial production data from Germany.

images.alt_text: Generics of SGX [Raffles Place]

site_title: US: Wall St ends flat as investors await CPI, earnings
summary: US stocks ended flat on Monday, with the S&P 500 and Dow posting minimal losses, while the Nasdaq ended nominally higher. Investors await the release of the March Consumer Price Index (CPI) report, which is expected to show a slight cooldown in price growth. The Federal Reserve may delay its first interest rate cut, with the July FOMC meeting now the most likely time for a rate cut. The first-quarter earnings season is set to kick off on Friday, with major US banks expected to report earnings growth of 5.0% year-on-year.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average gains 0.8 per cent to 38,904.04.

site_title: BOJ’s timing for next hike in focus as Ueda starts second year
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda marked his first anniversary, having successfully dismantled a stimulus experiment without destabilizing financial markets. Under his leadership, the BOJ ended a 17-year hiatus in rate hikes and restored interest rates as its main policy tool. Analysts praise Ueda's steady approach, citing his ability to keep markets informed and avoid shocks. As he navigates the next four years, Ueda faces challenges such as shrinking the balance sheet and addressing the weak yen, which could prompt a rate hike to support the currency.

images.alt_text: Kazuo Ueda last week signalled the chance of raising interest rates again later this year, suggesting that his longer-term mission had yet to be fulfilled.
The BOJ releases fresh quarterly growth and inflation forecasts at its next meeting in Apr 25 to 26.

site_title: Grocery giants including Tesco, Woolworths team up to launch US$125 million VC fund
summary: Global supermarket chains Tesco, Woolworths, and Shoprite have teamed up to launch a $125 million venture capital fund, W23 Global, to invest in start-ups and scale-ups deploying technology for faster, more personalized, and connected consumer experiences. The fund will focus on overhauling the grocery value chain and addressing sustainability. Each retailer is an equal funder and partner, with CEOs on the investment committee, aiming to provide investors with access to transformative innovation in grocery and sustainability globally.

site_title: Ted Baker to close 15 stores, cut 245 jobs
summary: Ted Baker, a British clothing chain, is closing 15 stores in Britain and cutting about 245 jobs due to debts and difficult trading. The company, which was acquired in 2022 for £211 million, has been in crisis for several years. Administrators said 11 stores will close by April 19, resulting in the loss of 120 store jobs and 25 roles at the headquarters. Landlords had previously served closure notices on four stores, leading to further redundancies. The company is seeking a new operating partner for its retail and e-commerce business in the UK and Europe.

images.alt_text: Signage is seen at a Ted Baker retail store in London, Britain, March 19, 2024. REUTERS/Toby Melville
Ted Baker is owned by Authentic Brands Group, the US company which is also behind brands such as Reebok.

site_title: Gloomy New Zealand firms raise risk of hard landing for economy
summary: New Zealand's economy may be heading for a hard landing, according to the NZ Institute of Economic Research (NZIER). Business confidence slumped in the first quarter, with 25% of firms pessimistic about the economy's outlook over the next six months. The central bank has kept interest rates high to curb inflation, resulting in squeezed company profits and job cuts. The Reserve Bank is expected to keep interest rates at 5.5% until at least May 2025, increasing the risk of a hard landing for the economy, which has contracted for four of the past five quarters.

images.alt_text: Migration to New Zealand last year was a near record 173,000 non-New Zealand citizens. The country’s population stands at about 5.1 million.
New Zealand expects the deal to benefit its beef, lamb, butter and cheese industries, as well as removing tariffs on other exports such as its iconic kiwi fruit.
New Zealand's gross domestic product dipped in the last two quarters of 2023, partly fuelled by a downturn in the country’s crucial agricultural sector.

site_title: Europe: Stocks gain on German data as focus turns to ECB policy meeting
summary: European stocks rose 0.5% on Monday, led by Germany's strong industrial production data, which showed a 0.8% gain for the DAX index. Cyclical sectors such as automobiles and industrial goods gained 1.3% and 0.8% respectively, while basic resources rose 2% due to copper prices hitting a 14-month high. However, analysts remain cautious, expecting a moderate recovery in the second half of the year and no rate cuts from the European Central Bank (ECB) in the near future.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, April 4, 2024.     REUTERS/Staff

site_title: Oil falls on renewed push for Middle East ceasefire
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday, April 8, after Israel reduced its troops in southern Gaza and began fresh ceasefire talks with Hamas. Brent crude futures dropped 79 US cents, or 0.9%, to settle at US$90.38 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude closed down 48 US cents, or 0.6%, at US$86.43. The decline marked the first in five sessions for Brent and the first in seven for WTI, as investors focused on Israel's decision to withdraw more soldiers from southern Gaza.

images.alt_text: Oil prices gained about 4 per cent last week on escalating geopolitical tensions.

site_title: UK’s Sunak faces huge test on May 2
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak faces a significant test on May 2, as the country prepares for local elections that could lead to a major Conservative party loss. This outcome could intensify pressure on Sunak's leadership, potentially triggering a leadership challenge. Alternatively, a House of Commons no-confidence vote could be triggered by Labour leader Keir Starmer, which has not happened in over 40 years. Sunak may also consider calling an early general election, but this is uncertain given King Charles' potential refusal to grant permission. The Conservative party's performance is seen as weak, with a growing momentum for Labour, and the likelihood of a Labour majority is 96%.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak could lose his own constituency and his party will not win a single seat in Scotland or Wales, according to a recent survey.
Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak must defy political gravity, and history, as he seeks to win a fifth term of office for the Conservatives.

site_title: Stock market trading – faster and cheaper is not necessarily better
summary: A generation of investors has grown accustomed to low or zero-commission trading, which has led to a "race to the bottom" in the stock market. While faster and cheaper trading may seem appealing, experts warn that it's not necessarily better for all retail investors. Discount brokers and zero-commission platforms often make money through margin charges, settlement fees, and payment for order flows, which can result in customers not receiving the best possible prices. This trend may lead to increased trading frequency, contradicting conventional market wisdom that "time in the market is better than timing the market."

images.alt_text: The number of structured warrants on SGX stocks has declined considerably from when the STI hit a peak 16 years ago.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as growth stocks rise, higher yields weigh
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Monday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gaining 0.14% and 0.23% respectively. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.03%. Gains were tempered by rising Treasury yields, which fueled speculation that the US Federal Reserve may delay rate cuts this year.

site_title: JPMorgan says CEO transition is a top priority, cites potential Dimon successors
summary: JPMorgan Chase's board prioritizes an orderly CEO transition, citing potential successors such as Jennifer Piepszak and Marianne Lake. The bank has gradually built succession plans since Jamie Dimon's emergency surgery in 2020. Dimon, who has led the bank for over 18 years, is expected to step down within two to five years, with Piepszak seen as the likely front-runner due to her role in the investment bank. The bank's shares rose slightly in morning trading ahead of its first-quarter results report on Friday.

images.alt_text: The new unit – Chase Media Services – will allow advertisers to target the JPMorgan’s customers based on their past purchase history.
JPMorgan started building its China securities and investment bank in 2016.
The firm has sent about US$60 billion to shareholders through dividends and stock buybacks over the past three years.

site_title: Income Insurance sells 30 Prinsep Street for S$142 million
summary: Income Insurance sold its 999-year leasehold commercial building at 30 Prinsep Street for S$142 million, reflecting about S$2,900 per square foot. The 11-storey building, refurbished in 2013, is a short walk from Bencoolen MRT station and has flexible workspace operator WeWork as its biggest tenant. The buyer is linked to the Lim family of Midview group, with potential to add value through redevelopment, such as using the roof terrace for an F&B outlet or converting parking space into leasable areas.

site_title: Bain Capital to sell US$429 million stake in India’s Axis Bank, term sheet shows
summary: Bain Capital plans to sell a 1% stake in Indian private lender Axis Bank worth US$429 million through a stake sale. The private equity firm will sell 33.40 million shares at an offer price of 1,071-1,076.05 rupees per share. This sale marks Bain Capital's exit from its entire holding in Axis Bank, following previous sales in 2017 and 2022. The deal is being led by BofA Securities India, and shares of Axis Bank have more than doubled since Bain Capital's initial investment, but are down 2.4% this year.

images.alt_text: Bain has invested capital in the country across a range of sectors including IT services, financial services, pharmaceuticals and industrials.

site_title: Cordlife says another 5,300 cord blood units deemed to be at high risk, offers refund and fee waiver
summary: Cordlife, a Singapore-based cord blood bank, has identified 5,300 cord blood units at high risk due to temperature excursions. The units, stored in one high-risk tank and a dry shipper, were tested, with only 4 out of 12 samples showing viability and potency. Cordlife will offer refunds and waive fees for affected clients until their service agreements mature. The company expects a $9.2 million decrease in revenue and profit. MOH has also announced that it will test an additional 200 samples from low-risk tanks to provide more assurance.

images.alt_text: The arrests of Cordlife's directors and group chief executive are related to alleged breaches-of-disclosure obligations regarding irregular temperatures in its storage tanks.
Two of Cordlife's non-independent non-executive directors, Yiu Ming Yiu and Chow Wai Leong, were also nominee directors of TransGlobal.
CAD agreed to postpone the interviews of non-independent non-executive directors Zhai Lingyun and Chen Xiaoling to May 21.
TransGlobal’s Mar 26 letter marks the third requisition notice received by Cordlife.
Cordlife says it will consider the possibility of appointing new independent directors to “serve as additional checks and balances”.
Cordlife is serving a six-month suspension from collecting, testing, processing and/or storing new cord blood and human tissue.

site_title: With UK polls looming, polls put Labour on course for landslide victory
summary: A new poll in the UK suggests Labour is on course for a landslide victory in the upcoming general election, potentially giving Keir Starmer a majority of 286 lawmakers. The survey predicts Labour will win 468 seats, with the Conservative party retaining just 98 seats. This is a significant drop from the 365 seats it held in 2019. The poll also predicts that up to 13 ministers could lose their seats, including Rishi Sunak. Labour has consistently polled ahead of the Conservatives, with Starmer's party leading by at least 20 points in recent polls.

images.alt_text: Workers on a Bellway Plc residential construction site in Tongham, UK, on Monday, Feb. 26, 2024. Britain’s top antitrust enforcer has opened an investigation into eight housebuilders to probe potential information sharing, sharpening scrutiny of a sector that’s failing to deliver enough affordable housing to meet demand. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Zurich Insurance to cease coverage of new fossil-fuel exposures
summary: Zurich Insurance has announced it will no longer underwrite new oil and gas projects, but will continue to cover existing ones. The move aims to align with the insurer's goal of achieving net zero emissions by 2050. Zurich plans to target high-emitting corporate clients to reduce their carbon footprints, and will provide more cover for clean-energy infrastructure. The decision reflects a shift in the insurance industry's approach to tackling climate change, with Zurich CEO Sierra Signorelli stating that "further exploration and development of fossil fuels isn't required for the transition."

images.alt_text: Operating profit at Europe’s fifth-largest insurer rose 21 per cent to a record US$7.4 billion for the year to Dec 31, beating the US$7.1 billion average estimate in an analyst poll compiled by the company.

site_title: SMEs: Innovate with AI or risk stagnation
summary: Singapore is investing S$1 billion in AI over the next five years to boost productivity, fuel innovation, and equip businesses with digital tools to dominate the digital economy. However, many small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are struggling to adopt AI due to lack of digital literacy and fragmented data. To overcome this, the government is introducing initiatives such as the SkillsFuture programme and an Enterprise Support Package to upskill the workforce and defray digitalisation costs. SMEs must also take steps to adopt AI-powered technologies, such as streamlining their financial tech stack, to remain competitive and future-ready.

images.alt_text: Areas where SMEs can adopt AI include marketing and customer engagement, says Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling.

site_title: US to award Samsung up to US$6.6 billion chip subsidy for Texas expansion: sources
summary: The US government plans to award Samsung a chip subsidy of up to $6.6 billion for expanding its chip output in Taylor, Texas, as part of the Chips and Science Act. The deal will include construction of four facilities, including a $17 billion chipmaking plant, and an investment in another undisclosed location, doubling Samsung's US investment to over $44 billion. This is the third-largest subsidy, following Taiwan's TSMC, which received $6.6 billion, and Intel, which received $8.5 billion. The announcement is part of the US effort to boost domestic chip production and reduce reliance on China and Taiwan.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A flag bearing the logo of Samsung flutters in front of its office building in Seoul, South Korea, October 25, 2020.  REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo
Samsung will announce full earnings with divisional breakdowns later this month.
Samsung began selling its latest flagship Galaxy S24 smartphones at the end of January, with a bevvy of AI functions to compete with rival Apple.
Key Samsung rival SK Hynix is already supplying Nvidia with the latest version of high-bandwidth memory, HBM3E.
The Toronto-headquartered startup helps its 775 healthcare-provider clients exchange images covering some 1.5 million patients, aiming to cut down on delays and costs.

site_title: Pegatron in talks with Tata to sell its only India iPhone plant, sources say
summary: Pegatron, a Taiwanese electronics manufacturer, is in talks with Tata Group to sell its only iPhone plant in India, which employs around 10,000 people and produces 5 million iPhones annually. Under the proposed deal, Tata will hold at least a 65% stake in a joint venture, with Pegatron providing technical support and holding the remaining 35%. The deal is backed by Apple and is seen as part of the company's efforts to diversify its supply chain beyond China amid geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: Tata’s first iPhone assembly plant is in the southern state of Karnataka which it took over from Taiwan’s Wistron last year.

site_title: China's central bank adds more gold to its reserves in March
summary: China's central bank added 160,000 troy ounces of gold to its reserves in March, increasing the value to US$161.07 billion, its highest since 2022. This move supports the World Gold Council's view that central banks see value in gold. The rally in gold prices, up 9.3% in March, has continued with record highs, driven by elevated demand from global central banks, including China, Turkey, India, and some eastern European countries.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was down 1.1 per cent at US$2,305.09 per ounce.

site_title: Spirit Airlines to defer Airbus deliveries, furlough 260 pilots to save cash
summary: Spirit Airlines has agreed with Airbus to delay aircraft deliveries from 2025 to 2030-2031, aiming to save cash. As a result, the airline is furloughing 260 pilots, effective September 1. The move comes amid strong travel demand, rising operating costs, and supply chain issues. The company expects the deferrals to improve its liquidity by $340 million over two years. Spirit CEO Ted Christie said the deferrals allow the airline to "reset the business and focus on the core airline" while adjusting to the competitive environment.

images.alt_text: Any agreement to split and absorb Spirit would accelerate a change of strategy in the aerospace industry as planemakers bring airplane structures in-house ahead of the next wave of costly investments in digital manufacturing.
Boeing has slowed production of its bestselling model to address quality lapses tied to a near-disaster on a 737 Max 9 in January.
Japan Airlines says the new aircraft should enhance and expand the capacity of its international operations., with a focus on North America, Asia and India.

site_title: Zico Holdings appoints 3 new directors, including former SGX executive Nasser
summary: Zico Holdings appointed three new directors, including former SGX executive Mohamed Nasser, effective immediately. Nasser, 51, brings extensive experience in the capital equity market, while Veerinderjeet Singh, 67, is a noted authority in Malaysian taxation. Shweta Nandy, 29, was also appointed as a non-independent non-executive director. The new appointments aim to sharpen the company's focus on the capital market and wealth management sector in the region.

images.alt_text: Reasons for the expected losses include a provision for loss allowance related to its investment in the Philippines.
Having joined in November, Nasser heads JP Wilson’s newly established capital markets strategy arm.

site_title: Oil steadies after dip on Middle East ceasefire talks
summary: Oil prices steadied above $91 a barrel on Monday, reversing early losses sparked by Israel's withdrawal of soldiers from Gaza and renewed ceasefire talks in the Middle East. Despite a 4% gain last week on escalating geopolitical tensions, prices were down 0.2% due to a decline in US West Texas Intermediate crude. Ceasefire talks between Israel and Hamas were revived, but no progress was made, and the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision this week is expected to influence oil demand.

images.alt_text: As traders weigh the possibility that US$100-a-barrel crude could make a comeback, the momentum is diverting their attention from the possibility of a cease-fire in the Middle East, as well as the impact of higher prices on refinery margins.
Oil rose on Thursday following news reports that Israeli embassies across the world have been placed on high alert due to increasing threats of an Iranian attack on Israeli diplomats.
Brent futures rose 43 US cents, or 0.5 per cent, to settle at US$89.35 a barrel.

site_title: Swiss National Bank’s chairman against issuing retail central bank digital currency
summary: Swiss National Bank Chairman Thomas Jordan expressed opposition to issuing a retail central bank digital currency (CBDC), citing concerns over its potential to fundamentally alter the monetary system and the role of central banks and commercial banks. Jordan stated that consumers and businesses already have access to efficient payment instruments from the private sector, and the risks of a retail CBDC outweigh its potential benefits. The SNB has no need for a CBDC, according to Jordan.

images.alt_text: Around 90 per cent of the world’s central banks are now exploring digital versions of their currencies.
While many perceive no real advantages to CBDCs, a significant number of people in many countries go even further and consider them to be a potential threat.
“No final decision has been made to pursue a digital pound – also called a central bank digital currency,” the BOE and finance ministry say.
Most, if not all, central banks are conducting research into developing their own digital currencies.

site_title: Containers are being removed from ship that hit key bridge
summary: Workers began removing containers from the Dali, a 985-foot-long cargo ship, from the Port of Baltimore, nearly two weeks after it struck and collapsed Baltimore's Key Bridge. The removal is a "critical step" in reopening the main channel, with the goal of fully reopening the channel by the end of May. The process will allow for safe access to remove the bridge pieces and then move the ship. Container removal is expected to take several days, with limited marine traffic still allowed at the site.

site_title: Israel holds rates to protect shekel as war spending soars
summary: Israel's central bank left interest rates unchanged at 4.5% to protect the shekel, which rose 2.4% to 3.68 per dollar, amid escalating war spending and geopolitical uncertainty. The decision was seen as a cautious move to heighten inflation expectations, despite the economy experiencing an uneven recovery from the war. The Bank of Israel's governor, Amir Yaron, expressed concerns over fiscal policy and the impact of defense spending on the economy, citing a widening fiscal deficit and inflation expectations above the central bank's target range.

images.alt_text: McDonald’s fourth-quarter sales missed expectations as growth decelerated, hurt in part by the conflict in the Middle East.

site_title: Blackstone US$10 billion deal is latest bet on property
summary: Blackstone has agreed to acquire Apartment Income Reit (Air Communities) in an all-cash deal worth US$39.12 per share, a 25% premium from the company's share price. The deal values the company at around US$10 billion and includes a US$400 million investment to maintain and bolster the apartment portfolio. Blackstone Real Estate Partners X, a fund that raised over US$30 billion, will purchase the shares. The acquisition is seen as a sign of the real estate investor's confidence in the property market.

images.alt_text: The Blackstone headquarters in New York, US, on Monday, Jan. 8, 2024. Blackstone Inc. released earnings figures on January 25. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg
The Blackstone headquarters in New York. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: EU regulators assess Apple’s plan for complying with music streaming order
summary: EU regulators are assessing Apple's proposal to comply with an order to let music streaming services like Spotify inform users of payment options outside the App Store. The proposal, announced last Friday, would allow Spotify and others to include links to their websites to purchase digital goods or services. However, such links would carry a 27% fee to Apple. If the proposal fails to satisfy regulators, Apple risks antitrust charges and fresh fines, including a 1.84 billion euro fine issued last month. The EU is currently assessing whether Apple has fully complied with the decision.

images.alt_text: The iPhone maker is fined 1.84 billion euros (S$2.69 billion) by the EU for thwarting competition from music streaming rivals via restrictions on its App Store.

site_title: Google’s contemplated mega deal would prompt new fight with regulators
summary: Google's contemplated acquisition of HubSpot, a marketing software company worth $34 billion, is likely to face opposition from US and European antitrust regulators due to their growing aversion to technology giants acquiring more power. Despite experts agreeing the deal won't curb competition, regulators may challenge the acquisition, requiring Google to open a new front in its battle with antitrust watchdogs. The deal would also give HubSpot access to Google's cloud-computing resources, potentially making it a more formidable player in the CRM software market.

images.alt_text: Alphabet has met with Morgan Stanley investment bankers in recent days about a potential offer for HubSpot.
The potential move suggests the Alphabet unit still has not figured out how to incorporate the new, fast-growing technology.
Google’s agreement to retroactively delete user information is a significant concession as it forms the backbone of the company’s lucrative advertising business.

site_title: Genting pledges US$1 billion in taxes to win New York casino licence
summary: Genting Malaysia has pledged to pay more than US$1 billion in taxes annually if it wins a casino licence in New York City. The company, which operates the Resorts World casino, plans to increase its slot machine revenue tax payments to 67% and expand its offerings, including table games like blackjack. The decision comes after the Gaming Commission approved Genting as a strong contender for the licence, alongside other bidders like Las Vegas Sands and Wynn Resorts. The one-time licensing fee will be US$500 million.

images.alt_text: Genting Singapore says its Q4 gaming revenue for FY2023 is "very respectable".
Genting Singapore’s shares fell as much as S$0.105 to S$0.925 as at 9.52 am, with 75.8 million shares changing hands.
Genting Singapore said Resorts World Sentosa has bounced back to levels nearing the pre-pandemic period.
CGS-CIMB says on Thursday MBS' solid results could mean a positive surprise for competitor Genting Singapore’s Q4 performance.

site_title: Cocoa climbs as shortages in Ivory Coast keep market on edge
summary: Cocoa futures surged 4.1% in New York amid persistent concerns over shortages in Ivory Coast, the world's top cocoa producer. Prices reached a record high above $10,000 a ton due to poor West African harvests, putting the world on course for a third straight annual deficit. The Ivory Coast regulator has asked buyers to wait for the mid-crop harvest to receive 130,000 tons of beans, further exacerbating the shortage. This has led to concerns that certified stocks will run dry soon.

site_title: Citi upgrades Japan to overweight, downgrades emerging markets to neutral
summary: Citi upgraded Japan's shares to an "overweight" rating due to favorable macro environment, high wage growth, and recovering domestic demand. Japan's Nikkei 225 index remains close to a record high, gaining over 17% this year. In contrast, Citi downgraded emerging markets to a "neutral" rating, except for Asian emerging markets, which it remains "overweight".

site_title: MOH Permanent Secretary Chan Yeng Kit to be SPH Media’s new CEO from Jul 15
summary: Permanent Secretary for Health Chan Yeng Kit will become the new CEO of SPH Media on July 15, succeeding outgoing CEO Teo Lay Lim, who is retiring. Chan, 59, brings extensive experience from the public sector and private sector to the role. He previously led Covid-19 safe management efforts and was awarded the Meritorious Service Medal. Chan will focus on digital transformation and building a sustainable commercial model, while Teo will relinquish her concurrent appointments as chairman of MOH Holdings and deputy chairman of the Central Provident Fund Board.

images.alt_text: Chan Yeng Kit, who is currently permanent secretary of the Ministry of Health, will be appointed to the board of SPH Media Holdings from Mar 15.

Tech in Asia staff paid a lunchtime visit to The Business Times following the announcement of the acquisition by SPH Media.  For new ideas to emerge from the acquisition, teams from both entities will need to come together and allow cultural diffusion to take place.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, April 8, 2024 (Ep 38)
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed day after the release of a strong US jobs report. In Hong Kong, Chinese property developer Shimao Group faces a liquidation petition over a HK$1.6 billion loan. The Philippine central bank maintained its interest rate at 6.5% despite inflation concerns and a weakened peso.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 75 to 55.
Hong Kong, Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul and Taipei rose, but Shanghai, Singapore, Manila and Wellington were all down.
China’s property sector has been in crisis since 2021 after a regulatory crackdown on high leverage among developers triggered a liquidity crisis.
The Philippines last week trimmed the economic growth forecasts for this year and next while widening fiscal deficit estimates to support higher spending.

site_title: Thailand to announce property measures to boost economy: ministry
summary: Thailand's finance ministry will announce new property measures on April 9 to boost the economy, which has grown less than 1% in the first quarter of 2024. Proposed measures include extending lease periods to 99 years, allowing foreigners to buy housing, and reducing transaction fees. The government aims to stimulate the property sector and support the country's goal of becoming a global industrial center. The announcements come as the country seeks to revive its economy, which is the second-largest in Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Condominium buildings are seen in Bangkok, Thailand, September 25, 2018. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin speaks alongside Cambodia's Prime Minister Hun Manet during a joint press conference at the Government House in Bangkok on February 7, 2024. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

With most leaders positively responding to the single-visa concept, tourism-reliant Thailand aims to generate more revenue per traveller and cushion its economy from headwinds such as sluggish exports and weak global demand that’s hurt its manufacturing industry.
A total of 14,449 units worth 73.2 billion baht (S$2.68 billion) were sold in 2023, a 25 per cent jump from 2022.
The central bank last year maintained its inflation target of 1 to 3 per cent for 2024.

site_title: Greenback pauses ahead of US inflation data, yen nears 1990 lows
summary: The US dollar remained flat on Monday ahead of US inflation data, while the yen slipped close to 34-year lows due to potential Japanese intervention to support the currency. The dollar index was last at 104.35, and US Treasury yields rose. US consumer price inflation data on Wednesday and the European Central Bank policy meeting on Thursday will be key economic markers this week. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to lag behind other major central banks in lowering interest rates, and a surprise inflation increase could trigger a hawkish reassessment of Fed rate-cut expectations.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul and Taipei rose, but Shanghai, Singapore, Manila and Wellington were all down.
The dollar index was last up 0.048 per cent at 104.27, after rising to 104.69.

site_title: Are Singapore’s prime office buildings overpriced in offering 3 per cent yield?
summary: Singapore's prime office buildings may be overpriced with 3% yield due to looming threats to the office property sector. Despite Covid-related restrictions lifting, office rentals have been resilient, with the Urban Redevelopment Authority's office rental index rising 13.1% in 2023. However, the adoption of hybrid working arrangements and cost pressures pose challenges, with occupancy levels in top-grade office buildings expected to come under stress. The rising power of artificial intelligence could also displace knowledge workers, leading to potential job losses.

images.alt_text: The demand for commercial real estate is underpinned by a widespread return-to-office push and a boom in private wealth.
The bank's properties include OCBC Centre, OCBC Centre South and OCBC Centre East.
Major banks in Singapore have long preferred to locate their back-end staff outside the city centre where rents are cheaper.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 8)
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia is expected to maintain its interest rate steady, citing robust fundamentals and positive economic prospects. Meanwhile, South-east Asian central banks are also likely to keep interest rates unchanged, watching their currencies and waiting for the US Federal Reserve's next move. Resale prices for larger HDB flats rose for the sixth consecutive month in March, while industrial production in Malaysia beat expectations with a 3.1% growth in February. Ninja Van has diversified into cold chain and B2B logistics, and Ministry of Health Permanent Secretary Chan Yeng Kit will become CEO of SPH Media on July 15.

site_title: Microsoft to launch AI hub in London
summary: Microsoft has announced plans to launch an artificial intelligence (AI) hub in London, led by Mustafa Suleyman, the London-born co-founder of Google DeepMind. The unit aims to focus on product development and research, and may seek to poach AI talent from other companies. The move represents a win for Britain, which has sought to bolster its credentials as a technology superpower. Microsoft has invested £2.5 billion in data centre infrastructure and improving AI skills across Britain, and Suleyman's appointment reflects the company's commitment to advancing AI responsibly.

images.alt_text: Microsoft is paying Inflection US$650 million in licensing fees in a deal designed to make investors whole.
Microsoft and OpenAI are in the middle of the third phase of the five-phase plan.
The unusual deal resembled an “acqui-hire” – but without an acquisition.

Mustafa Suleyman is one of the biggest names in the artificial intelligence revolution that is taking the technology world by storm and his hiring is a major move by Microsoft, which already partners with ChatGPT creator OpenAI.

site_title: TikTok’s popularity among European politicians rises despite security fears
summary: Mainstream European politicians are embracing TikTok, despite security concerns, to reach younger voters ahead of the June European elections. Senior politicians, including Ireland's Simon Harris and France's Emmanuel Macron, have amassed millions of followers on the platform. However, their use of TikTok is complicated by fears that user data could be shared with the Chinese government, prompting Germany's security agencies to warn against using the app. Meanwhile, the AfD party has successfully exploited TikTok's short video format to gain traction among young voters, prompting mainstream politicians to "panick" about ceding ground to fringe parties.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this photo illustration the social media application logo for TikTok is displayed on the screen of an iPhone in front of a US flag and Chinese flag background in Washington, DC, on March 16, 2023. China on March 14, 2024 slammed the approval of a US bill that would ban TikTok unless it severs ties with its Chinese parent company, blasting Washington's "bandit" mentality and vowing Beijing would "take all necessary measures" to protect the interests of its companies overseas. (Photo by OLIVIER DOULIERY / AFP)
Aside from the payment integration between TikTok and Tokopedia, branding across the new entity’s platform has been made consistent to the Shop | Tokopedia brand.
TikTok is requiring that US entities registered by sellers be 51 per cent US owned and chaired by an US passport holder.
FILE PHOTO: The TikTok office building is shown in Culver City, California, U.S., April 26, 2023. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: ESR says ‘amicable approach’ with Quarz is to prioritise Sabana Reit and unitholders
summary: ESR Group has resolved a dispute with activist investor Quarz Capital through an "amicable" approach, prioritizing Sabana Reit and its unitholders. ESR maintains that the dispute has resulted in a diminished value of Sabana Reit's unit price, despite estimated costs of $3.3 million incurred from the Reit's internalization process. ESR seeks to work with all parties to ensure an outcome in the best interests of all unitholders, aiming to achieve unity and profitability for all stakeholders.

images.alt_text: New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio. The Reit's trustee is HSBC Institutional Trust Services.
Giving an update to unitholders, Sabana Reit's trustee said it is working with the relevant parties to implement the resolutions passed at the EGM on Mar 8.
While having more internally-managed listed-Reits can be welcomed, Sabana Reit should explore exit options instead of pursuing internalisation of its management.
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.
The Reit portfolio valuation for its 18 properties is up by 2.1 per cent on-year to S$903.9 million as at end-2023.

site_title: China says innovation built EV success, rejects EU subsidy probe
summary: China's commerce minister Wang Wentao rejected the European Union's probe into subsidies for the electric vehicle sector, citing "continuous technological innovation", advanced local supply chains, and intense competition as key factors behind the rapid growth of Chinese EV companies. Wang also criticized the EU's "protectionist" stance, saying it would undermine the bloc's environmental ambitions. The EU Commission's probe was launched in September, with accusations of overcapacity and government aid fueling the investigation, but Wang denied these claims, labeling them "groundless".

images.alt_text: Andi, the joint venture between DiDi Autonomous Driving and GAC Aion, will roll out a crossover electric sports utility vehicle (SUV) as its inaugural model and will produce the first batch in 2025.
FILE PHOTO: Visitors check a Tesla Model 3 car next to a Model Y displayed at a showroom of the U.S. electric vehicle (EV) maker in Beijing, China February 4, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo
BYD, which overtook Tesla to become the world’s largest EV producer in late 2023, saw sales jump 46 per cent year on year to 302,459 vehicles.
SAIC Motor hopes to cut 30 per cent of employees at SAIC-GM, 10 per cent at SAIC Volkswagen and more than half at its Rising Auto EV subsidiary, sources said.
Huawei's managing director and chairman of smart car solutions, Richard Yu, is expecting the unit to turn a profit from April.
During Thursday's two-hour event, Xiaomi CEO Lei Jun made a jibe at Apple for dropping its car project and declared Xiaomi's EV superior to Tesla's Model 3.

Mini EVs being charged on a street in Liuzhou, in China's Guangxi province. These tiny vehicles weave through traffic in southern China, their cheerful designs bringing a touch of colour to the EV revolution in the country.
People walk past a booth of Zeekr, Chinese automaker Geely's premium electric vehicle (EV) brand, at a shopping mall in Beijing, China November 3, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
The automaker is currently discounting almost every electric and hybrid car model it sells, as part of a marketing campaign declaring “electricity is cheaper than oil”.

site_title: ECB tipped to pause one last time before June rate cut
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to keep borrowing costs on hold one last time before a potential rate cut in June, driven by falling inflation. Eurozone inflation slowed to 2.4% in March, bringing the ECB's two-per-cent goal within reach. ECB President Christine Lagarde said the institution will have updated forecasts on inflation and economic growth in June, and economists predict at least three to four rate cuts this year. The ECB's benchmark deposit rate remains at a record four percent, which has taken a toll on the eurozone economy.

images.alt_text: While ECB policymakers are likely to firm up expectations for a June rate cut next week, they are unlikely to commit to any subsequent moves.

Consumer price growth in Eurozone slowed to 2.4 per cent in March from 2.6 per cent a month earlier, defying expectations for a steady rate as food, energy and industrial goods prices all pulled the headline figure lower.
Consumer prices rose an annual 2.3 per cent last month, according to the statistics office – down from 2.7 per cent in February.

site_title: Singapore shares fall despite regional rally; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.1% on Monday, despite a regional rally, closing at 3,215.99. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 2.27 points. Regional indices rose, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi gaining 0.9% and 0.1% respectively. Analysts attribute the regional rally to Wall Street's strong showing on Friday, driven by the US job report. However, further gains may be limited ahead of US consumer price index data due to potential interest rate cut hold-offs by the US Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: Citi Research is optimistic about Jardine C&C's investments in Vietnam.
The four trading sessions until Apr 4 inclusive has close to 90 changes to director interests and substantial shareholdings for nearly 50 primary-listed stocks.

site_title: Singapore begins pilot of electric harbour craft charging point in Marina South
summary: Singapore has launched a pilot project for an electric harbour craft charging point at Marina South Pier, owned by Pyxis Maritime and operated by SP Mobility. The 150 kilowatt direct-current fast charger is the same technology used in SP Group's electric vehicle charging stations. The pilot aims to reduce emissions in the maritime sector and is expected to run for two years. The project will mainly involve Pyxis' planned fleet of electric harbour craft, with plans to expand to 13 vessels over the next two years.

images.alt_text: From 2030, all new harbour craft will have to be fully electric, be capable of using pure biodiesel, or be compatible with net-zero fuels such as hydrogen.
The Hydromover is Singapore's first fully-electric cargo vessel. It can carry 25 tonnes of cargo, has space for 10 passengers and an operating speed of 8 to 10 knots.
The EOI will allow MPA to assess and validate proposals for the best and most cost-effective reference designs of full-electric harbour craft.
EnterpriseSG estimates that more than 100 local marine and offshore engineering companies are participating in, or exploring, projects in maritime decarbonisation and offshore renewables.
The expression of interest exercise is expected to help in driving the adoption of electric harbour craft among both owners and operators of harbour craft in Singapore.

site_title: Happy 20th anniversary, Gmail. I’m sorry I’m leaving you
summary: Gmail, launched 20 years ago, has become overwhelmed by vast storage and cluttered feeds, making it difficult to find important messages. The author, who has over 1 million unread emails, attributes this to the shift to algorithmic feeds and ad-based business models. They blame the digital giants for profiting off their passivity and lack of intention, leading to a "shame closet" of digital life. The author has started using a new email service, Hey, which forces them to make choices and prioritize their inbox, and is now seeking software that promotes intentional digital organization, likening it to tending a garden.

images.alt_text: How AI can help solve e-mail overload and expand customer base
Checking email less often may reduce stress
Why social media may be really bad for you

site_title: Evergreen funds: the future for private market investing
summary: Evergreen funds, also known as open-ended funds, are gaining popularity in private market investing due to their flexibility and lower minimum investment requirements. Unlike traditional closed-end funds, which have a fixed lifespan and require investors to commit capital upfront, evergreen funds allow for periodic redemptions and compound returns over 10 years. This structure enables individuals to access private market assets and achieve diversified exposure, similar to large institutional investors. With the potential for higher returns and lower minimums, evergreen funds are becoming an attractive option for individual investors, offering a more accessible and liquid alternative to traditional private market investing.

images.alt_text: Private asset managers seeking to win over individual investors must make more of an effort to educate clients and distributors, industry observers said.
Edwin Conway of BlackRock says:  “We think of decarbonisation as one of the best investment opportunity sets across private markets, because the world is in transition.”
Singapore banks remain compelling as an investment class given that their strong fundamentals and capital position remain unchanged.

site_title: TSMC wins US$6.6 billion US subsidy for Arizona chip production
summary: The US Commerce Department awarded Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) a $6.6 billion subsidy and up to $5 billion in low-cost government loans to support advanced semiconductor production in Arizona. TSMC plans to expand its investment to $65 billion and add a third fab by 2030, producing the world's most advanced 2 nanometer technology. The project is expected to create 6,000 direct manufacturing jobs and 20,000 construction jobs, and will support key customers like Apple and Nvidia.

images.alt_text: Taiwanese equities have soared 14 per cent this year, with almost two thirds of the advance coming from a rally in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.

site_title: Prabowo’s China visit; Asean currencies’ further retreat
summary: Indonesia's President-elect Prabowo Subianto visited China's President Xi Jinping in Beijing, marking his first overseas trip after the General Election Commission's official announcement of his victory. The visit aims to continue engagement and seek Chinese investments in infrastructure and security sectors. However, the extension of Indonesia's Jakarta-Bandung High-Speed Railway to Surabaya is facing challenges due to hefty costs and land issues. Meanwhile, Vietnam's growth in the first quarter reached 5.66%, the highest recorded since 2020, despite global economic turmoil. The exchange rate of the Vietnamese Dong has hit a new low, impacting other Asean currencies.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo paid a visit to VinFast manufacturing complex in Hai Phong on Jan 13, 2024.
Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto celebrates on stage as unofficial vote counts show that he is poised to become Indonesia's next president.

site_title: Eurozone companies expect wage increases to moderate, ECB says
summary: Eurozone companies expect wage growth to slow, with salaries predicted to rise 3.8% over the next 12 months, down from 4.5% in the previous poll. This moderation in wage growth offers policymakers some comfort that inflation is in retreat. The European Central Bank's survey also showed tightening financing conditions, but with a modest reduction in loan needs. The ECB is expected to stand pat on interest rates at this week's meeting, with a potential cut in June if wage pressures continue to ease.

images.alt_text: In June, the ECB will also have its own updated forecasts on inflation and economic growth.
The ECB has grown increasingly active in its efforts to get lenders to treat ESG risks – particularly climate change – as financially material.
While ECB policymakers are likely to firm up expectations for a June rate cut next week, they are unlikely to commit to any subsequent moves.

site_title: German property slump deepens with 19% drop in investment deals
summary: German property investment deals plummeted 19% in the first quarter, reaching 6.3 billion euros, the lowest since 2011. Slower economic growth, higher financing costs, and sluggish office trends contribute to the slump. Sellers are struggling to find buyers for larger portfolios, with deals down 50% in this segment. JLL predicts a significant increase in properties requiring restructuring, but expects deals to remain subdued throughout 2024, totaling around 40 billion euros, below record years.

site_title: Rising Federal Reserve chatter is not making life in markets easy
summary: US Federal Reserve interest rate chatter is fueling market uncertainty, with 10 Fed officials giving over 100 public appearances in the past two weeks. The Fed's rate-cutting timeline has become increasingly important, with market expectations ranging from no cuts to five quarter-point reductions. Fed Chair Jay Powell has signaled that the Fed's inflation battle is not yet over, but investors are growing impatient. The S&P 500 dropped 1.2% on April 4, its worst day in eight weeks, amid oil price hikes and hawkish comments from Fed officials.

images.alt_text: “Recent data do not, however, materially change the overall picture, which continues to be one of solid growth, a strong but rebalancing labour market, and inflation moving down towards 2 per cent on a sometimes bumpy path,” Fed chair Jerome Powell says.

US Federal Reserve Board Chair Jerome Powell announced the central bank stayed on track for three interest rate cuts this year and affirmed that solid economic growth will continue, Washington, DC, March 20, 2024.

site_title: Goldman says Trump’s new China tariff plan would slow US growth
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's proposed 60% increase in China tariffs would slow US growth and push inflation up, according to Goldman Sachs Group. The tariffs would reduce US growth by up to 0.15% if China retaliates, with a minimum 0.05% hit to gross domestic product. This would also lead to a 0.1% increase in core consumer prices and higher inflation for a year. Despite potential revenue gains, Goldman analysts conclude the tariffs would have a modestly negative impact on the economy.

site_title: Are US presidential elections bullish or bearish for markets?
summary: US presidential elections in November 2024 may have a bullish impact on markets, as former President Donald Trump's polling resilience suggests a tight race against President Joe Biden. Despite legal challenges, Trump's campaign remains strong, and his decision to run again makes him the oldest candidate in history. A potential Trump re-election could lead to changes in policies, which may positively affect financial markets. However, the outcome remains uncertain, and investors should remain cautious.

images.alt_text: The US presidential elections, where former president Donald Trump is a likely candidate, will be the most consequential election for global investors this year.
Roughly 40 per cent of the stocks in the S&P 500 are trading above where they were 12 months ago.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Citi initiates ‘buy’ on Jardine C&C with S$29 price target
summary: Citi Research has initiated a "buy" call on Jardine Cycle & Carriage (Jardine C&C) with a price target of S$29, representing a 25% discount to its estimated FY2024 net asset value of S$38.24 per share. The research house expects the group's non-Astra businesses, particularly investments in Vietnam, to contribute to profit growth, driven by vehicle manufacturer Thaco and refrigeration company REE. Citi forecasts a 7% compound annual growth rate in net profit from FY2024 to FY2026, driven by these investments and Astra's stability.

images.alt_text: The board has proposed a final one-tier tax-exempt dividend of US$0.90 per share for the year, up from US$0.83 per share in 2022.
Asean+3's current sunny growth prospects offer a timely opportunity for the region's economies to rebuild policy space, says Amro.
The rise in gold smuggling is fuelled by a combination of a lack of official supplies and flight-to-safety demands amid a struggling economy.
Malaysia has  ranked the third best global outsourcing location, , holding around 8 per cent market share of the Asia Pacific market.

site_title: Hong Kong customs makes largest-ever gold smuggling bust
summary: Hong Kong customs seized 146 kg of gold, the largest-ever gold smuggling bust, disguised as air compressor parts at the city's international airport. The estimated value of the gold is HK$84 million (S$14.5 million). This is the largest gold smuggling case in Hong Kong Customs' record, according to acting chief Lau Yuk-lung.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was down 1.1 per cent at US$2,305.09 per ounce.
Spot gold was up 0.1 per cent at US$2,300.53 per ounce.
The rise in gold smuggling is fuelled by a combination of a lack of official supplies and flight-to-safety demands amid a struggling economy.
The faltering equities have turned the industry orthodox of producers outperforming the underlying commodity on its head, baffling observers.

site_title: Hyundai Motor, Kia to partner with India's Exide Energy on EV batteries
summary: Hyundai Motor and Kia have signed a memorandum of understanding with India's Exide Energy Solutions to supply batteries for their electric vehicles, aiming to localise EV battery production in the country. The partnership, valued at an estimated $2.4 billion, will focus on lithium-iron-phosphate cells and is seen as a move to boost competitiveness in India's third-largest auto market. Exide Energy plans to produce EV battery cells by the end of this year, with Hyundai and Kia set to launch six EV models in India by 2028.

images.alt_text: SAN LEANDRO, CALIFORNIA - MAY 30: A new Hyundai car is displayed on the sales lot at San Leandro Hyundai on May 30, 2023 in San Leandro, California. A surge in Kia and Hyundai thefts began last year after viral videos appeared on social media sites showing how to exploit the lack of antitheft computer chips in the cars. Kia and Hyundai cars continue to be stolen more than three months after the auto manufacturers deployed software fixes to help curb the thefts.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: HSBC helps funds navigate India’s bond market as inclusion nears
summary: HSBC is helping over 200 overseas funds navigate India's bond market ahead of the nation's entry into global debt indexes. The bank is facilitating registration and other formalities as India's sovereign debt is added to JPMorgan's emerging market gauge in June. The inclusion will make it crucial for funds to add India's debt to their portfolios, with potential inflows of up to $40 billion. HSBC is holding road shows and meetings to promote India's bond market and assist with the "onboarding process" for foreign investors.

images.alt_text: HSBC says the majority of its institutional and retail investor base backed the board and the structure of the bank.
HSBC previously launched a US$200 million new economy fund in November 2021 for early-stage startups in Singapore.
Investment-banking-deal flows out of China have been muted across the tech sector and other industries amid a deteriorating macroeconomy and stricter regulations for new listings.

site_title: Alibaba slashes cloud prices globally as AI demand quickens
summary: Alibaba has slashed cloud prices globally by an average of 23% for international markets and up to 59% in China, amid increasing competition from rivals. The move comes as the company's cloud division, under CEO Eddie Wu, undergoes an overhaul to revive growth. Alibaba cancelled plans for a public offering and has been cutting prices to ward off rising competition from Tencent and Baidu. The discounts are now available in multiple countries, including Singapore, Japan, and the US.

site_title: US 'will not accept' flood of below-cost Chinese goods: Yellen
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that the US "will not accept" a flood of below-cost Chinese goods, warning that such a situation could stifle the growth of industries elsewhere. Yellen expressed concerns about China's excess industrial capacity and weak household consumption, which she believes are exacerbated by large-scale government support in specific sectors. China has pushed back, calling excess capacity fears "groundless," but the two countries have agreed to open channels for further talks on the issue.

images.alt_text: epa11263409 U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen (L) meets with Chinese Premier Li Qiang at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China, 07 April  2024. Yellen, who arrived in Beijing after starting her five-day visit in Guangdong province, one of China's major industrial and export hubs, said that talks will create a structure to hear each other's views and try to address American concerns about manufacturing overcapacity in China.  EPA-EFE/Tatan Syuflana / POOL
Yellen says that concerns are growing over the global economic fallout from China’s excess manufacturing capacity.

site_title: Malaysia’s industrial production beats expectation with 3.1% growth in February
summary: Malaysia's industrial production index rose 3.1% in February, exceeding forecasted 1.5% growth. The increase was driven by higher output from the mining and electricity sectors, with the mining sector accelerating by 8.1% year-over-year. The growth may be attributed to fewer working days during the Chinese New Year break. This beats the January growth of 4.3% and follows a 0.3% rise in May. The results indicate a positive outlook for Malaysia's economy despite global growth concerns.

images.alt_text: Asean+3's current sunny growth prospects offer a timely opportunity for the region's economies to rebuild policy space, says Amro.
Malaysia has  ranked the third best global outsourcing location, , holding around 8 per cent market share of the Asia Pacific market.

site_title: Chinese spending jumps over long holiday weekend, tops pre-Covid level
summary: Chinese consumers spent $7.5 billion domestically during the Qingming Festival holiday, with per capita spending reaching 101.1% of pre-Covid levels. This marks the highest per capita spending since China lifted Covid restrictions in 2022, indicating a strengthening of consumer confidence. Analysts see this as a turning point for China's sluggish economy, which has been weighed down by a property market downturn and high youth unemployment.

images.alt_text: Challenges facing the economy are rife, despite activity improving at the start of 2024.
The People’s Bank of China will support banks to replenish capital and guide financial institutions to increase medium- and long-term loans to the manufacturing industry.
Together with other better-than-expected manufacturing surveys, the data add to evidence that parts of China’s economy are gaining momentum in the first quarter.
ICBC signed a cooperation pact with China’s culture and tourism ministry on Tuesday (Apr 2) to “stimulate” tourism investment and spending.
Economic data over the January-to-February period and a factory owners survey for March offer relief to Chinese policymakers seeking to convince foreign investors.

site_title: HSBC’s Quinn targets lifting wealth business in China, India
summary: HSBC Holdings' CEO Noel Quinn is pushing to strengthen the bank's wealth management capabilities in China and India, aiming to match its performance in Hong Kong. The bank is expanding its operations in Asia and the Middle East, with a focus on insurance, asset management, and private banking. HSBC has also agreed to buy Citigroup's retail wealth management portfolio in mainland China and has been building out its wealth-management operations to offset volatile earnings from dealmaking and trading. The bank's pivot to Asia has been hindered by growing geopolitical tensions and sluggish economic growth in China.

images.alt_text: India will reach the maximum 10 per cent weighting in the gauge, making it crucial for funds tracking the index to add the nation’s debt to their portfolios.
HSBC says the majority of its institutional and retail investor base backed the board and the structure of the bank.
HSBC previously launched a US$200 million new economy fund in November 2021 for early-stage startups in Singapore.
Investment-banking-deal flows out of China have been muted across the tech sector and other industries amid a deteriorating macroeconomy and stricter regulations for new listings.

site_title: China’s Didi, GAC Aion to mass produce robotaxis next year
summary: Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Global has received a business license for its self-driving unit's joint venture with EV maker GAC Aion, allowing it to mass produce fully self-driving electric robotaxis in China. The joint venture, Andi, plans to roll out a crossover SUV in 2025 and will be the first to produce robotaxis in the country. This move comes as Tesla also plans to unveil its robotaxi in August. The Andi joint venture has positioned itself as a pioneer in the autonomous driving industry, enabling the creation of an early L4 commercial route and a closed-loop business model for L4 development.

site_title: Bangkok motor show reports 28% rise in orders, Toyota leads sales
summary: The Bangkok International Motor Show saw a 27.5% rise in orders, with Toyota leading sales with 8,540 car orders. Electric vehicles (EVs) accounted for 32.8% of car orders, up from 21.5% at the previous event. Chinese carmakers, particularly BYD, gained attention, with a significant presence at the show. This comes as Japanese auto giants face competition, with Chinese EV makers committing to invest over $1.4 billion in Thailand's auto manufacturing hub, aiming to convert 30% of annual vehicle production to EVs by 2030.

images.alt_text: People walk past a booth of Zeekr, Chinese automaker Geely's premium electric vehicle (EV) brand, at a shopping mall in Beijing, China November 3, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Thai PM says Myanmar regime 'losing strength'
summary: Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin says the Myanmar regime is "losing strength" as the country faces an insurgency on multiple fronts. Anti-junta groups, backed by a pro-democracy parallel government, have seized control of several military posts and towns, including parts of a key town on the border with Thailand. Thavisin suggests it's time to open talks with Myanmar, despite the regime's military power and weapons. Thailand has been engaging with Myanmar since the coup in 2021, aiming to pave the way for a unified, peaceful, and prosperous country that benefits Thailand most.

images.alt_text: Since a military coup in Myanmar in 2021, thousands of civilians and hundreds of troops have fled from there to Indian states, where people on both sides share ethnic and familial ties.

site_title: Larger flats bolster HDB resale prices in March; but volumes down again: SRX, 99.co
summary: Resale prices for HDB flats in Singapore rose 0.3% month-on-month in March, driven by demand for larger public housing flats. The proportion of resale flats transacted in mature estates reached a six-month high of 40.1%. Million-dollar resale transactions jumped 22% to 61 deals, with the highest transacted price being S$1.45 million for a five-room flat. Volumes fell 3.3% to 2,063 units, with four-room flats making up 43.6% of total volumes.

images.alt_text: HDB observes resale prices showing signs of stabilising.
Construction Site of HDB MacPherson Weave at Circuit Road (Top by 1 Mar 2026)
Luqman Hakim, chief data and analytics officer at 99.co, says the price growth in February 2024 is "much more modest" compared to the previous month.

From 2003 to 2023, prices of private non-landed housing and HDB resale flats increased by 143.1 per cent and 140.2 per cent respectively. Over the same period, prices of landed homes jumped by a steeper 180.6 per cent.

site_title: SAIC’s MG brand to bring in JSW and other local investors in India
summary: China's SAIC Motor plans to bring in local investors in India to create a more favorable operating environment for its MG brand. JSW Ventures will buy a 35% stake in MG Motor India for $580 million, while IndoEdge India Fund and a dealer trust will also invest. The move comes amid India's efforts to limit investments from Chinese companies due to geopolitical tensions. SAIC aims to increase MG's market share in India and prevent operating risks, following a decline in its home market to BYD and Tesla.

images.alt_text: MG Motor's logo is seen on the front grille of a car put on display at Bharat Mobility Global Expo organised by India's commerce ministry at Pragati Maidan in New Delhi, India, February 1, 2024. REUTERS/Anushree Fadnavis

site_title: Thai PM: Central bank should cut rates by at least 25 bps
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin urged the central bank to cut its key interest rate by at least 25 basis points to stimulate economic activity amid a $13.6 billion stimulus scheme. The "digital wallet" programme, worth $1.3 billion, will be rolled out in the fourth quarter of the year. Funding sources will be finalized on April 10, the same day as the central bank's monetary policy meeting. The government expects annual growth to slow to below 1% in the first quarter of 2024.

images.alt_text: With most leaders positively responding to the single-visa concept, tourism-reliant Thailand aims to generate more revenue per traveller and cushion its economy from headwinds such as sluggish exports and weak global demand that’s hurt its manufacturing industry.
The central bank last year maintained its inflation target of 1 to 3 per cent for 2024.
The plan has come under fire from experts who say it is fiscally irresponsible and fixing Thailand’s economy requires addressing structural problems.

site_title: Kirin to push deeper into healthcare after shoring up Asia
summary: Kirin Holdings, a Japanese brewer, aims to boost its healthcare business to 20% of total sales by 2030, with a goal of 500 billion yen (S$4.4 billion) in annual sales. The company will expand its presence in Asia and North America through recent acquisitions, including Australia-based Blackmores, and new deals. Kirin's new president, Takeshi Minakata, plans to accelerate growth in the sector, despite concerns from analyst Ada Li about the synergies between its beverage and health items.

images.alt_text: Kirin has offered A$95 cash per share, a 23.7 per cent premium to the stock’s last close, and has already entered a scheme implementation deed with Blackmores.

site_title: German industrial production rises in next turnaround signal
summary: German industrial production rose 2.1% in February, exceeding economists' expectations, suggesting a possible end to the country's shallow recession. Despite the increase, production remains below pre-pandemic levels due to factors like energy costs and weak foreign demand. Economists now hold moderate optimism, with some predicting a 0.1% contraction in the first quarter. The European Central Bank's interest-rate cuts starting in June and improved global conditions also contribute to the positive outlook.

images.alt_text: Germany's economic problems are largely down to the cutoff of Russian energy supplies, weak Asian demand for exports, problems among the country’s car manufacturers in adapting to the green transition and high interest rates.

site_title: TSMC drives Taiwanese equities to outperform tech rival South Korea
summary: Taiwan's stock market has surged 14% this year, outperforming South Korea's market, with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) driving the rally. The market-value gap between the two has widened to $363 billion, the largest since 2003. TSMC's dominance in advanced semiconductor manufacturing and its complete AI supply chain ecosystem make Taiwan the biggest AI beneficiary in Asia, surpassing South Korea's lower exposure to AI.

site_title: Ninja Van enters cold chain and B2B logistics in bid to diversify from e-commerce
summary: Ninja Van, a logistics platform, has launched a cold chain offering, Ninja Cold, and a business-to-business (B2B) offering, Ninja B2B, as part of its efforts to diversify and seek higher-margin businesses. The initiatives aim to drive profitability and were first explored in 2019. Cold chain services will be launched in Singapore and Malaysia, with plans to expand to Indonesia, the Philippines, and Vietnam. The B2B offering will aid businesses in restocking stores with the capability of delivering in small quantities. The move is expected to contribute 10% of revenue and 50% of total profit.

images.alt_text: South-east Asian logistics company Ninja Van has consolidated some parcel sorting stations, as parcel volumes get impacted by the economic slowdown.
Ninja Van recently opened a new parcel sorting hub in Thailand with a 4km-long semi-automated parcel sorting conveyor belt.
Extending the last mile: Can logistics players continue to deliver?
Alibaba invests US$200m in Ninja Van; GeoPost remains largest shareholder
Ninja Van 'a year away' from IPO: CEO

site_title: Large UK companies see lowest uncertainty in nearly three years
summary: Large UK companies have seen their lowest uncertainty levels in nearly three years, according to a Deloitte survey. The companies, with a £200 billion market capitalization, forecast rising profit margins and increased optimism for growth. However, investment plans are on hold, with businesses prioritizing cost reduction and cash reserves over expansion. Geopolitics, inflation, and energy prices remain major concerns, with executives expecting a decline in inflation to 2.9% in a year's time, allowing for interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Workers on a Bellway Plc residential construction site in Tongham, UK, on Monday, Feb. 26, 2024. (Photo by Oli SCARFF / AFP)
