site_title: Another Cordlife director arrested amid CAD probe; interviews for 3 others postponed
summary: CORDLIFE Group director Yiu Ming Yiu was arrested amid a probe by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) over potential breaches of disclosure obligations. Yiu's arrest brings the total number of arrested individuals linked to the probe to seven. Three other directors have postponed their interviews with CAD, while one, Joseph Wong Wai Leung, is uncertain about his next interview date due to health reasons. The company's board has decided to keep the implicated directors on the board, but will assess their suitability pending investigation developments.

images.alt_text: Cordlife says it will consider the possibility of appointing new independent directors to “serve as additional checks and balances”.
TransGlobal’s Mar 26 letter marks the third requisition notice received by Cordlife.
Two of Cordlife's non-independent non-executive directors, Yiu Ming Yiu and Chow Wai Leong, were also nominee directors of TransGlobal.

site_title: Apple asks US appeals court to reverse Apple Watch import ban
summary: Apple has asked a US appeals court to reverse a ban on importing some Apple Watches due to a patent dispute with medical-monitoring technology company Masimo. The ban, initially imposed in December 2022, was reinstated in January after the Federal Circuit paused the ban. Apple claims that the ban is based on "substantively defective patent rulings" and that Masimo failed to show it had invested in competing US products. The ban was temporarily lifted after the Federal Circuit paused the ban, and Apple has removed pulse oximetry capabilities from watches sold during the appeal.

images.alt_text: CHICAGO, ILLINOIS - MARCH 21: The Apple logo hangs in front of an Apple store on March 21, 2024 in Chicago, Illinois. The Justice Department today sued Apple claiming the iPhone maker has a monopoly over the phone market.   Scott Olson/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SCOTT OLSON / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Israel and US are on alert for Iran to strike back at Israel
summary: US and Israeli officials are on high alert for potential Iranian retaliation after an Israeli airstrike in Damascus, Syria, killing three senior Iranian commanders. Iran vowed to avenge the attack, with Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei saying that no act against Iran will go unanswered. US military forces in the region have been placed on heightened alert, and Israeli officials have canceled leave for combat units and recalled reservists. The US and Israel assess that Iran is more likely to strike Israel directly rather than targeting US troops in the region.

images.alt_text: The military officials say officers who order the strikes on the aid convoy have violated the army’s protocols.
Iran warns the US "not to get dragged into Netanyahu’s trap".
Global oil demand is expected to grow by 1.4 million barrels per day (bpd) in the first quarter, JPMorgan analysts say.

site_title: US job growth beats expectations in March; wages increase steadily
summary: US job growth exceeded expectations in March, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 303,000 jobs, beating forecasts of 200,000. Average hourly earnings rose 0.3% and wages grew 4.1% annually, consistent with the Fed's 2% inflation target. The unemployment rate fell to 3.8% and household balance sheets remain healthy, supporting consumer spending. Despite 525 basis points of rate hikes, economists suggest the economy may delay interest rate cuts, as businesses locked in lower borrowing costs and immigration continues to boost hiring.

images.alt_text: The foreign facility, such as the domestic RRP, is a place where counterparties can park cash overnight with the Fed.

site_title: Boeing CEO paid US$33 million in 2023, gave up bonus over MAX 9 incident
summary: Boeing CEO David Calhoun received a base salary of $1.4 million and over $30 million in stock awards for 2023, totaling $33 million. However, he declined a potential $2.8 million bonus following the January Alaska Airlines incident, where a 737 MAX 9 was forced to make an emergency landing. The company's board honored Calhoun's request, citing his focus on safety and quality, and his decision to take responsibility for the accident. Calhoun will step down as CEO at the end of 2024 as part of a leadership shakeup.

images.alt_text: Any agreement to split and absorb Spirit would accelerate a change of strategy in the aerospace industry as planemakers bring airplane structures in-house ahead of the next wave of costly investments in digital manufacturing.
An Alaska Air-operated MAX 9 jet experienced a mid-air cabin panel blowout in January, which led the US aviation regulator to order grounding of 171 jets for inspections.
Boeing has slowed production of its bestselling model to address quality lapses tied to a near-disaster on a 737 Max 9 in January.
GE starts a new chapter in its history with its split into three entities. The initial split took place in January 2023 with the creation of GE HealthCare.

site_title: Straits Trading sells Adelaide property; consideration is A$10 million below independent valuation
summary: Straits Trading Company is selling its Adelaide industrial property, 34 Share Street, Kilkenny, for A$52.7 million, which is A$10.3 million below an independent valuation of A$64.3 million. The sale aligns with the company's strategy to redeploy capital from low-yielding properties into higher return opportunities. The transaction is expected to have minimal impact on earnings per share and net tangible assets per share. The sale is for cash and will be completed after negotiations.

images.alt_text: Bourne Business Park, one of Straits Trading's assets in the UK. The real estate segment remains the main contributor to the group's performance in H2 FY2023.

site_title: Wall Street just doesn’t get retirement
summary: Wall Street fails to address the retirement problem, with many Americans unaware of how much money they need to retire. Despite increased employer offerings and automatic enrollment, the financial industry's focus on accumulating wealth rather than providing predictable income in retirement remains a significant issue. The industry's benchmarking of retirement accounts to wealth goals rather than income streams exacerbates the problem, leaving retirees vulnerable to financial risk. To address this, the industry needs to redefine retirement as a goal of future income, not current wealth, and offer more income-oriented investment strategies, better annuities, and creative solutions to manage risk.

images.alt_text: Adrian Low, product manager of DBS digiPortfolio, shares tips on how to invest for retirement.
In retirement, staying invested and figuring out how much you can withdraw can be challenging.

site_title: China’s CIC to back Investcorp’s US$800 million Mideast fund
summary: China's sovereign wealth fund, CIC, is backing Investcorp's US$800 million Gulf-focused pre-IPO fund, marking a growing trade tie between Gulf oil exporters and China. CIC's investment, along with others from Abu Dhabi and Saudi Arabia, could be announced soon. This partnership is part of CIC's plans to explore more deals in the Middle East, as China seeks to deepen ties amid US trade tensions and a slowing economy. Investcorp plans to broaden the fund's focus to Asia and increase its size to over US$1 billion.

site_title: Quarz, ESR reach resolution over alleged defamation during Sabana internalisation bid
summary: Quarz Capital and ESR have reached an amicable resolution over alleged defamation during Quarz's push to internalise the management function of Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit). Quarz clarified its statements were incorrect and not intended to defame ESR, and will withdraw publications as a gesture of goodwill. With the resolution achieved, Quarz will focus on completing internalisation as soon as possible, supporting Sabana unitholders and the trustee in the process.

images.alt_text: New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio. The Reit's trustee is HSBC Institutional Trust Services.

site_title: US: Stocks rally after blowout jobs data
summary: US stocks rallied on Friday, April 5, after a strong jobs report, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.8% to 38,904.04. The US economy added 303,000 jobs in March, exceeding analyst expectations. Despite lofty interest rates, the jobs report indicates labor market strength. Futures markets now suggest the Federal Reserve may keep interest rates flat at the June meeting, potentially paving the way for rate cuts. Large tech companies, including Meta, Netflix, Amazon, and Alphabet, also saw gains.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - FEBRUARY 29: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on February 29, 2024 in New York City. Stocks opened up on the rise as investors await the latest release of inflation data from the Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) index, the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation indicator.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

IRVINE, CALIFORNIA - OCTOBER 17: The Johnson & Johnson logo is displayed at company offices on October 17, 2023 in Irvine, California. Johnson & Johnson beat Wall Street’s quarterly revenue and earnings estimates as sales in its pharmaceutical and medical devices businesses grew.   Mario Tama/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by MARIO TAMA / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
FILE PHOTO: A flag bearing the logo of Samsung flutters in front of its office building in Seoul, South Korea, October 25, 2020.  REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after nonfarm payrolls data
summary: US stock indexes opened higher on Friday, April 5, 2024, after strong March jobs data indicated resilience in the labor market, despite potentially slowing down the Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.18%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased 0.23% and 0.29%, respectively.

site_title: Her art is at odds with museums, and museums can’t get enough
summary: Artist Gala Porras-Kim's solo exhibition at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Denver is the largest museum solo she has had in the US. Her work questions how museums collect and display artifacts from previous civilizations, and whether to keep them. Porras-Kim has worked with museums to develop "organic de-accession processes," such as releasing ancient air from ice cores and rehydrating ceremonial offerings. Her art also critiques the tension between regulating nature and the climate, as seen in a site-specific artwork created from a museum building's defect. The exhibition follows a busy year of one-person exhibitions for Porras-Kim.

images.alt_text: epa11249490 A woman takes photos of the artwork Kabinett, which is a site-specific installation that incorporates paintings and reconstructed found objects, by artist Zhou Yilun from Hangzhou of China, during the Art Basel exhibition in Hong Kong, China, 29 March 2024. Art Basel Hong Kong’s show features galleries from across continents and regions, including from the United States, Taiwan, Europe, the United Kingdom and beyond. It provides an in-depth overview of Asia-Pacific's astonishing diversity, as well as global artistic perspectives through Modern and contemporary works.  EPA-EFE/DANIEL CENG
Australian alternative protein firm Vow has received the regulatory approval from the Singapore Food Agency to sell their product here.
In January, the Louvre Museum raised the price of general-admission tickets by 29 per cent.

site_title: Meta overhauls rules on deepfakes, other altered media
summary: Meta is overhauling its policies on deepfakes and altered media, starting with applying "Made with AI" labels to AI-generated videos, images, and audio on its platforms in May. The company will also apply separate labels to digitally altered media that poses a high risk of deceiving the public. The new approach shifts from removing content to labeling it, providing viewers with information about how it was made. The changes come ahead of the US presidential election in November and amid growing concerns about AI-generated content.

images.alt_text: Meta sued the FTC in November in a broad constitutional challenge against the agency’s ability to be both an investigative body and an adjudicative one.

site_title: Yellen faces diplomatic test in urging China to curb green energy exports
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen urged China to curb exports of green energy technology, warning that cheap Chinese exports are threatening the US electric vehicle and solar sectors. Yellen, in her first meeting with Vice Premier He Lifeng, emphasized that the US is not adopting an "anti-China" policy, but rather seeking a level playing field for American workers and firms. The US is ramping up subsidies for domestic clean energy industries, and Yellen advised China to focus on supporting consumption within its own borders, rather than relying on exports. The issue of Chinese overcapacity has been a long-standing concern, with China's exports rising 7% in January and February.

images.alt_text: “Direct and indirect government support is currently leading to production capacity that significantly exceeds China’s domestic demand, as well as what the global market can bear,” US Treasury chief Janet Yellen told a gathering of the US business community in Guangzhou on Friday.
U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen arrives at Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport, in Guangzhou, Guangdong province, China April 4, 2024. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

US President Joe Biden (right) and China's President Xi Jinping (left) have managed to maintain a veneer of diplomatic stability despite deep mutual suspicion between their countries, and as their governments pursue export controls, sanctions and tariffs.

site_title: Biggest gold miners are missing out on bullion’s record run
summary: The world's largest gold miners, including Newmont Corp and Barrick Gold Corp, are missing out on the metal's record run due to their faltering equities. Despite gold hitting all-time highs, their shares have fallen 6% and 2% respectively this year, with some analysts questioning their investment strategy. The companies' high operating expenses and skepticism from investors have led to a disconnection between their stock prices and the underlying commodity. However, some experts suggest that a turnaround may be in the works, with inflationary pressures easing and gold prices expected to continue rising.

images.alt_text: Customers shop at a Kalyan Jewellers India Ltd. store during the festival of Dhanteras in Mumbai, India, on Friday, Nov. 10, 2023. Dhanteras is traditionally seen as the most auspicious day in the Hindu calendar to buy gold, with many shops remaining open until midnight and jewelers offering discounts and gifts. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg
Spot gold was down 0.2 per cent at US$2,284.84 per ounce.
Goldman’s annual meeting is Apr 24.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson to buy Shockwave Medical for US$12.5 billion
summary: Johnson & Johnson agreed to acquire medical device maker Shockwave Medical for approximately $12.5 billion. The deal, valued at $335 per share, represents a 4.7% premium to Shockwave's last close. Shockwave's device uses shockwaves to treat heart disease, similar to treating kidney stones. The acquisition is expected to boost J&J's portfolio of medical devices, with Shockwave having a market capitalization of around $12 billion.

site_title: Iran tells US to step aside as it readies response to Israel
summary: Iran has warned the US to "step aside" as it prepares a response to a suspected Israeli attack on its consulate in Syria, amid escalating tensions between the two countries. In a message to Washington, Iran's deputy chief of staff said the US should not get "dragged into Netanyahu's trap." The US has responded by asking Iran not to hit American targets. The situation has raised concerns about the potential for conflict between the US, Israel, and Iran, with Hezbollah warning Israel that it is prepared for war.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Iranian flag flies in front of the UN office building, housing IAEA headquarters, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, in Vienna, Austria, May 24, 2021. REUTERS/Lisi Niesner/File Photo

site_title: Never underestimate the nation-state
summary: The article emphasizes the importance of a strong nation-state in preventing economic crises and ensuring citizens' well-being. Contrary to the narrative that globalisation has rendered governments toothless, the author argues that well-run countries can protect their citizens against uncertainty. Examples of successful nation-states include East Asian countries that allowed their currencies to depreciate and curtailed foreign borrowing during financial crises, and Chile, which implemented stringent building codes and a culture of inspectors to prevent construction shortcuts. The author concludes that a welfare state, which provides social insurance and protection against unexpected events, is a key factor in preventing economic anxiety, and that governments must regain control over their own instincts to succeed.

images.alt_text: Brazil's former president and presidential candidate Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva at an election night gathering on the day of the country's presidential election run-off, in Sao Paulo, Oct 30, 2022.
A sense of national belonging is vital to nation-building
Haitian president assassinated at home, sparking fears of widespread turmoil

site_title: German factory orders increase, supporting hopes for a rebound
summary: Germany's factory orders rose 0.2% in February, beating the median estimate of 0.7% and supporting hopes for a mild and short-lived recession. This improvement was driven by the machinery and equipment sector, as well as pharma and chemicals. Despite this, economists predict another contraction of 0.1% in the first quarter, citing ongoing economic problems such as the cutoff of Russian energy supplies, weak Asian demand, and high interest rates.

images.alt_text: Consumer prices rose an annual 2.3 per cent last month, according to the statistics office – down from 2.7 per cent in February.

site_title: Charge+ partners ChargeSini to form largest Singapore-Malaysia EV charging network
summary: Charge+, Singapore's largest EV charging operator, has partnered with ChargeSini, Malaysia's largest EV charging operator, to form the largest Singapore-Malaysia EV charging network. The combined network, expected to begin in the fourth quarter of this year, will offer over 2,400 charging points across both countries. The roaming service will enable users to charge and pay at both companies' locations through their respective apps, with plans to expand the network to 4,000 points by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: (left to right): Goh Chee Kiong (CEO, Charge+) and James Goh (Founder & CEO, ChargeSini)

site_title: Dollar jumps as soaring US job growth beats expectations
summary: The US dollar strengthened on Friday after data showed US employers hired 303,000 workers in March, beating expectations of 200,000 jobs. This move potentially delays anticipated interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve this year. The dollar index rose 0.432% to 104.67, while US interest rate futures pared back odds of a rate cut in June to 54.5%. The stronger dollar also weighed on the Japanese yen, which fell 0.26% to 151.735, and other currencies, including the euro and sterling.

images.alt_text: The dollar index, which measures the US currency against six rivals, was down 0.15 per cent at 104.08 after hitting 104.05, its lowest level since Mar 26.

site_title: Collectibles – an enjoyable way to lose money
summary: A former professional fund manager warns that collecting items like books, coins, and classic cars is not investing, but rather a hobby that can lead to financial losses. He cites examples of individuals who bought items at auctions, only to see their value decrease after fees and taxes. The article highlights the high transaction costs associated with collectibles, often a multiple of the costs associated with investing in stocks. The author advises readers to collect for the joy of it, rather than as an investment, and to be aware of the potential risks involved.

images.alt_text: Linda Neo started collecting art as a means of sharing a common interest with her husband, Albert Lim.
The Hospices de Beaune auction last year netted US$32 million. Should Pierre Chen’s collection sell for its estimate, it will become one of the most expensive single-owner auctions in recent history.
The authenticity of certain watches, such as Panerai’s Radiomir Annual Calendar, can be verified through blockchain technology.
Nike has already seen “incredibly strong” demand for England’s uniforms and for now it continues to have supplies available.
While industry experts are slightly less bullish than in years past, few doubt collectibles’ longevity.

site_title: Jurong Island: In search of a new miracle
summary: Singapore's Jurong Island, a chemical production hub, is struggling to retain its competitive advantages as the industry shifts towards net-zero emissions. Shell's search for a buyer for its refinery and petrochemical assets in Singapore has eroded the island's proposition. Experts propose using carbon dioxide (CO2) as a feedstock for chemical production, potentially creating a new revenue stream. The government has set up a Low-Carbon Energy Research programme to support research and development of carbon capture, utilisation and storage (CCUS) technologies. Industry players, such as ExxonMobil and Croda Singapore, are exploring CCUS and renewable energy options, but face challenges in scaling up these technologies.

site_title: High Court orders Falcon Energy to wind up after multiple failed restructuring attempts
summary: The High Court of Singapore has ordered Falcon Energy Group to wind up after multiple failed restructuring attempts. The company had suspended trading of its shares over five years ago, promising a debt overhaul and restructuring. Despite a moratorium granted by the court, Falcon Energy failed to file an extension application, leading to the court's decision. The company's directors cited "cash-flow constraints" due to the sale of its marine division, but AmBank, a principal lender, argued that the company's restructuring attempts lacked good faith.

images.alt_text: Falcon Energy Group and subsidiary file affidavits ahead of Monday hearing
Falcon Energy to undertake complete debt revamp, suspends trading
Falcon Energy suspends coupon payment, share trading as it embarks on debt revamp
Falcon Energy presents new debt plan to Series 001 noteholders

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 5)
summary: Singapore-listed semiconductor companies expect minimal impact from a recent Taiwan earthquake due to their reliance on equipment suppliers rather than foundries. Retail sales in Singapore grew 8.4% year-over-year in February, boosted by Chinese New Year festivities. OCBC's financed emissions declined in six high-carbon sectors in 2022. Singapore shares ended Friday in the red, with the Straits Times Index falling 0.5%.

site_title: India EV sales to rise 66% this year after nearly doubling in 2023, report says
summary: India's electric vehicle (EV) sales are expected to rise 66% this year, nearly doubling in 2023, driven by state subsidies and supporting infrastructure. By 2030, EVs are forecasted to represent nearly a third of the country's personal vehicle market. Tata Motors, a domestic carmaker, dominated the market in 2023 but lost ground to Mahindra & Mahindra and Chinese automaker BYD. The Indian government's efforts, including lowering EV import taxes, have fueled demand and encouraged foreign automakers like Tesla to invest in the country.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Visitors check a Tesla Model 3 car next to a Model Y displayed at a showroom of the U.S. electric vehicle (EV) maker in Beijing, China February 4, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: BMW logo is seen during Munich Auto Show, IAA Mobility 2021 in Munich, Germany, September 8, 2021. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay
Tata Motors' investment would be spread over five years and could create up to 5,000 jobs.

site_title: Saudi Arabia hikes key oil prices further as market tightens
summary: Saudi Arabia increased the price of its flagship crude, Arab Light, by 30 US cents to a premium of US$2 a barrel for May sales. This is the second consecutive rise, following expectations of a 10 US cent increase. The move is attributed to Opec+ agreeing to maintain supply cuts, a tightening Middle Eastern market, and geopolitical risks. The price hike is expected to further squeeze the market for relatively dense and sulfurous crude, with many analysts predicting tighter global oil markets this year.

site_title: UK economy growing again in all major sectors, survey shows
summary: The UK economy appears to be growing again, with all three major sectors showing expansion in March for the first time in almost two years. The construction sector, which was hit hard by the property market, showed growth due to a stabilisation in housebuilding. The services sector continued to grow, while manufacturing also expanded. This suggests the UK has bounced back from last year's recession and is picking up at the end of the first quarter, providing a boost to Prime Minister Rishi Sunak ahead of an election later this year.

images.alt_text: (FILES) BAE Systems employees work on the tail section of 81mm High Explosive Mortar munitions at the BAE Systems factory in Washington, near Newcastle upon Tyne in north-east England on November 8, 2023. A munitions factory of the British defense giant BAE Systems in the north of England is running at full capacity, boosted by the war in Ukraine and an increasingly gloomy geopolitical outlook. (Photo by Oli SCARFF / AFP)

site_title: Flushed with pride, public toilets a tourist draw in Tokyo
summary: Tokyo has launched a unique tourist attraction: a curated tour of artistically enhanced public toilets. The Tokyo Toilet Shuttle, which began in March, takes visitors on a two-hour tour of 17 toilets in the Shibuya district, featuring advanced functions such as cleansing sprays, heated seats, and music. The project, started in 2020, aims to improve accessibility and artistry in public toilets, with some designed by renowned architects. Visitors pay $32.76 to experience the unique facilities, which have become a novelty for tourists and locals alike, showcasing Tokyo's attention to detail and innovative spirit.

images.alt_text: A participant looks around a public toilet which was redesigned as part of a project to transform public toilets into restrooms that can be used comfortably by everyone, during a Tokyo Toilet Shuttle Tour, at Shibuya ward, in Tokyo, Japan April 4, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon
While smart-toilet adoption in China has, for the past decade, been led by middle-aged, middle-class women, the next phase is expected to draw in younger buyers.

site_title: World food price index rebounds from three-year low, says UN agency
summary: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization's world food price index rebounded in March, rising 7.7% from the previous year, after a three-year low. The index, which tracks global traded food commodities, averaged 118.3 points, driven by increases in vegetable oil, meat, and dairy prices. This marks a seventh consecutive monthly decline in the index, which had fallen sharply from a record peak in March 2022.

images.alt_text: Higher food prices have prompted even affluent shoppers to switch to cheaper grocers such as Aldi and Lidl.

site_title: Director of corporate service provider fined for wrongly declaring individual’s consent to directorships in 3 companies
summary: A Singapore State Court has fined Li Baozhu, director of corporate service provider Corp Nergy, S$6,500 for misusing identity in appointing a director for three companies. Li failed to confirm consent before incorporation, relying on a third party instead. This breach came half a year after Acra cancelled her registration as a qualified individual and Corp Nergy's registration as a filing agent. Stricter regulations for corporate service providers are in the pipeline, including fines of up to S$100,000 for anti-money laundering obligations.

images.alt_text: Acra says its move to cancel LW Business Consultancy and Wang Junjie's registrations was in view of breaches of anti-money laundering and countering the financing of terrorism controls.
Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) logo

site_title: Samsung to hike Texas chip spending to US$44 billion, WSJ says
summary: Samsung plans to increase its investment in Texas to approximately $44 billion, with a focus on the city of Taylor. The company will build a second chipmaking plant and an advanced packaging hub. This mega-investment would hand a victory to the Biden administration, which has been offering incentives and policy support to global chipmakers to build on US soil. The move comes after Samsung initially announced a $17 billion project in Taylor in 2021.

site_title: Elon Musk reverses course, gives away some blue checkmarks for free
summary: Elon Musk has reversed his previous stance on free premium features on X, including the coveted blue verification checkmarks. Users with over 2,500 verified followers will now receive the blue badges for free, a change of strategy that contradicts his previous criticism of giving them out to prominent accounts. This move comes 18 months after Musk took over the company, and a spokesperson declined to comment on the change.

site_title: Singapore shares end Friday in the red; STI falls 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.5% to 3,218.26 on Friday, tracking regional market declines. The local bourse saw 291 decliners outnumbering 273 advancers, with 1.4 billion securities worth S$940.5 million changing hands. The decline follows a broader market trend, with global stocks experiencing similar losses.

images.alt_text: A visitor walks past Japan's Nikkei stock prices quotation board inside a building in Tokyo, Japan February 19, 2024. REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS upgrades GoTo to ‘buy’ on ‘undemanding’ valuation; expects fintech breakeven in FY2025
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded GoTo's rating to "buy" from "hold" due to its undemanding valuation and expected positive adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) in FY2024. The research team raised its price target to 99 rupiah and expects GoTo's fintech segment to breakeven in FY2025. DBS noted that GoTo's valuation is similar to competitor Grab, and the income from TikTok's revenue sharing will "flow directly" to Ebitda, making the valuation more attractive.

images.alt_text: Indonesian tech company GoTo is preparing to launch a BNPL product with social media platform TikTok.
GoTo Financial wants to be the preferred partner of TikTok Shop in Indonesia.
GoTo expects to achieve group adjusted Ebitda breakeven for the full year in 2024.
Grab and GoTo are reportedly discussing a range of scenarios under which both companies could merge.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, April 5, 2024 (Ep 37)
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 fell 2% due to a tech sell-off, while oil prices reached a 2024 high amid Middle East tensions. Seatrium's short interest levels surged on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) as investors adopted a bearish outlook. The tech sector's decline and oil price rise contributed to a weaker market sentiment, with Singapore's STI index down 0.8% at Friday's open.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Friday.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers
A visitor walks past Japan's Nikkei stock prices quotation board inside a building in Tokyo, Japan February 19, 2024. REUTERS/Issei Kato
Tokyo tanked more than two per cent, while Hong Kong, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington and Manila were also deep in the red.
Seatrium was the second most shorted stock on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for the week ended Apr 3, a report from S&P Global Market Intelligence showed.

site_title: Travel to add a record US$11.1 trillion to global economy in 2024
summary: The global travel industry is expected to reach a record-breaking US$11.1 trillion in 2024, surpassing its prior high of US$10 trillion in 2019. This growth is forecast to continue, with tourism projected to become a US$16 trillion industry by 2034, making up 11.4% of the global gross domestic product. The sector is expected to create 12.2% of global jobs by 2034, with 1 in 10 people currently employed in tourism-related jobs. The US travel sector is an exception due to the strengthening US dollar, while China's tourism economy is lagging behind due to ongoing visa delays.

images.alt_text: China was the top source of visitors to Singapore in February, followed by Indonesia, Malaysia, Australia and the UK.

site_title: Hon Hai sales slump offers little hope for iPhone rebound
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry, the world's largest iPhone contract manufacturer, reported a 9.6% decline in first-quarter revenue to NT$1.32 trillion, due to sagging iPhone sales in China. Despite this, the company expects sales to grow relative to the same period a year earlier and for the full year, driven by its focus on artificial intelligence and data centre server racks. Apple's iPhone shipments in China fell 33% in February, leading to discounts and price cuts from online resellers.

site_title: Kingsford to start previews for The Hill @ One-North, with prices from S$1.9 million
summary: Kingsford Real Estate Development will start previews for its condominium project, The Hill @ One-North, on April 6. The 142-unit project, located in District 5, will have prices starting from S$1.9 million for a two-bedroom unit. The site was previously awarded to Kingsford Development for S$162.4 million in 2021. The project is part of JTC's efforts to increase residential spaces in the one-north estate. Sales bookings will begin on April 20, with completion expected by the end of 2026.

images.alt_text: The rising level of unsold stock may signal bad news for some projects, such as the 99-year leasehold Cuscaden Reserve (above), with an impending sales deadline this year.
Landed home prices continued their surge in Q1, rising XX per cent after a 4.5 per cent increase in Q4.

site_title: Yellen blasts ‘coercive’ China moves on US firms, urges reforms
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen criticized China's government for "coercive" treatment of American and foreign companies, urging Beijing to return to pro-market reforms. A recent survey by the American Chamber of Commerce in China found that one-third of American firms in China report unfair treatment compared to local competitors. Yellen's comments come as ties between the two economies have shown signs of improvement, but deep differences remain, particularly over China's manufacturing drive and subsidies for key industries.

images.alt_text: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen arrives at Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport, in Guangzhou, Guangdong province, China April 4, 2024. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

site_title: Petrol bomb attacks on Malaysian retailer pressure Anwar
summary: In Malaysia, three KK Super Mart stores were attacked with molotov cocktail explosives after the sale of socks bearing the word "Allah" sparked calls for a boycott, targeting Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's fragile coalition. The attacks have raised concerns about the delicate balance Anwar must maintain between appeasing the majority Muslim population and retaining support from key allies. Police are investigating the perpetrators and a youth chief from the ruling coalition, while Anwar's allies call for tougher action against those responsible, fearing escalation of violence could harm the economy and Anwar's leadership.

site_title: India's central bank holds key rate steady on robust growth, above target inflation
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has kept its key interest rate unchanged for a seventh consecutive meeting, maintaining it at 6.5% as the economy is expected to remain robust with inflation above the 4% target. The RBI governor, Shaktikanta Das, stated that the policy space allows for focus on inflation, aiming to bring it down to the target. The economy is forecast to expand by 7% in fiscal year 2025, driven by strengthening rural demand and improving employment conditions.

images.alt_text: Reserve Bank of India says it had permitted users, for the ease of doing business, to take positions of up to US$100 million across exchanges without providing documentary evidence to establish the underlying exposure.
Barring the ultra-long duration which consists of bonds maturing in 30 years and above, the RBI conducted auctions for bonds through uniform-based pricing since July 2021.

The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) logo is displayed on a gate at the central bank's headquarters in Mumbai, India, on Tuesday, April 1, 2014. Indiaâs central bank left its key interest rate unchanged as consumer-price inflation eased to a two-year low and the rupee strengthened, increasing scope to support growth ahead of national elections starting this month. Photographer: Vivek Prakash/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan warns against excessive yen moves, repeats verbal intervention
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida warned against excessive yen moves, stating that authorities will use "all available means" to deal with significant declines, amid a recent two-week high of 150.81 against the dollar. The Bank of Japan's policy shift and dovish guidance have fueled speculation about potential interest rate hikes, while Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki has repeatedly warned of the risk of yen-buying intervention. BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda also hinted at the possibility of a rate hike later this year if yen declines significantly affect inflation and wages.

images.alt_text: The BOJ releases fresh quarterly growth and inflation forecasts at its next meeting in Apr 25 to 26.

site_title: How European football learned to embrace Ramadan
summary: European football has largely adopted accommodations for Muslim players fasting during Ramadan, with many top leagues and teams introducing bespoke nutrition plans, flexible practice schedules, and league-approved stoppages in play. The English Premier League, for example, allows clubs to arrange with referees for brief breaks at sunset, and the players union has produced a 30-page document on fasting best practices. This shift reflects the growing value of Muslim players and a new acceptance of diversity in wealthy competitions. However, some countries, like France, have faced criticism for not fully embracing Ramadan fasts, with the French football federation issuing guidelines directing teams to stop play.

images.alt_text: Physical activity improves cognitive and mental health in all sorts of ways.
Fireworks go off at the Birmingham 2022 Commonwealth Games opening ceremony held at Alexander Stadium.
Schooling is now a founding partner at Swaen Schooling Capital, along with investment banker Cliff Go and serial entrepreneur Ben Ling.
Swimming coach Vincent Poon (right) knew Joseph Schooling was a "special boy" from the start.
The acquisition is expected to be completed by the end of 2024 subject to clearances and approvals by competition and foreign investment law authorities in various jurisdictions.

site_title: Shell sees lower integrated gas performance in Q1
summary: Shell expects lower performance in its integrated gas division for the first quarter, with volumes between 7.2-7.6 million tonnes of liquefied natural gas. In contrast, the company expects significant growth in its chemicals and products business, with lower losses than in the last quarter of 2023. Shell also plans to take a US$600 million exploration write-off, primarily in Albania. The company's overall 2023 profit was US$28 billion.

site_title: Philippine inflation quickens for second month on costlier rice
summary: The Philippines' inflation rate accelerated for the second month in March, rising 3.7% year-over-year, driven by higher rice prices, which increased 24.4% during the month. This has raised concerns about the central bank's ability to prematurely ease interest rates, with Governor Eli Remolona stating that sufficient assurance is needed before declaring victory against inflation. The country's President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. also emphasized that inflation remains the country's biggest problem, and it's too soon to lower borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: Philippine  rice Photographer: Veejay Villafranca/Bloomberg

site_title: US wants airlines to boost travel benefits for military personnel
summary: US Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg urged major airlines to improve travel benefits for active-duty military personnel and their families. The Department of Transportation plans to post comparative information on travel benefits on a customer service dashboard in May. Airlines are expected to commit to full refunds and free baggage allowances for service members and their families who cancel travel plans due to military directives. Most carriers already offer additional benefits such as priority boarding and discounted fares, but Buttigieg claims these benefits are not consistently detailed in public-facing Customer Service Plans.

images.alt_text: The maintenance, repair and overhaul business is set to grow by more than 19 per cent within the next decade, according to consulting firm Oliver Wyman.
The greener fuel is essential to reduce emissions from long-haul flights, the source of most air-travel pollution, because electric planes do not have sufficient range.

site_title: Chinese, Russians push Thai condo sales to above pre-Covid level
summary: Thailand's condominium sales exceeded pre-Covid levels in 2023, with a total of 14,449 units worth 73.2 billion baht (S$2.68 billion) sold, a 25% jump from 2022. Chinese buyers dominated, purchasing 6,614 units, followed by Russians and US buyers. Temporary visa waivers for tourists from China and a permanent bilateral waiver with Beijing contributed to the surge in sales, driven by geopolitical conflicts and the tourism sector's potential to drive economic growth.

images.alt_text: Asset World’s hotel properties have seen revenue per available room grow to record highs this year, according to chief executive officer Wallapa Traisorat.

site_title: Thai March inflation misses central bank target for 11th month
summary: Thailand's headline consumer price index (CPI) dropped 0.47% in March, its sixth consecutive decline, missing the central bank's target range for the 11th month. The drop was driven by government cost of living subsidies, but global energy prices may push inflation up in April. The commerce ministry has tightened its 2024 inflation forecast to 0-1% from -0.3% to +1.7%. Core CPI, excluding food and energy prices, rose 0.37% year-over-year, while inflation is expected to turn positive in the second and third quarters.

images.alt_text: The plan has come under fire from experts who say it is fiscally irresponsible and fixing Thailand’s economy requires addressing structural problems.
The Bank of Thailand will review key interest rates next week.
The stimulus plan, delayed by several months over differences on how it will be funded, is set to be implemented in the fourth quarter of calendar year 2024.

site_title: Japan’s Mitsui OSK starts FSRU operations for Indonesian gas-fired power plant
summary: Mitsui OSK Lines (MOL) has started commercial operations of its floating storage and regasification unit (FSRU) in Indonesia, supplying liquefied natural gas to a power plant in West Java. This is Asia's first gas-to-power project using an FSRU. The Jawa Satu FSRU has a storage capacity of 170,000 cubic meters and a regasification capacity of 300 million standard cubic feet per day, supplying power to the 1,760 megawatt Jawa 1 power plant for 25 years.

site_title: South-east Asia rises as offshoring powerhouse amid MNCs’ cost-cutting drive: Knight Frank
summary: Malaysia solidifies its third spot as the world's best offshoring location, with India and China taking the top two spots. The country's strong digital ecosystem, competitive real estate prices, and skilled digital talents make it a hub for global companies. The Asia-Pacific region is expected to see the highest compound annual growth rate of 10.2% in the global offshoring market, with the Philippines, Malaysia, and Vietnam emerging as top destinations. Offshoring activities are expected to boost the region's office market, with companies seeking to reduce operating costs by up to 70% compared to mature markets.

images.alt_text: The World Trade Organization estimates that a disintegration of the global economy into separate blocs could reduce global gross domestic product by about 5 per cent over the long term.

site_title: OCBC cuts 2022 financed emissions in six ‘dirty’ sectors
summary: OCBC Bank has reported a decline in financed emissions in six high-carbon emitting sectors for 2022, meeting its carbon reduction targets. The bank's power sector emissions decreased by 19% to 337 kgCO2/MWh, while the oil and gas sector saw a 19% drop to 12.1 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent. The real estate sector's weighted emission intensity also fell, albeit slowly, while the shipping sector's emissions decreased despite a revised IMO net-zero trajectory. OCBC's chief sustainability officer Mike Ng notes the challenges ahead, but says the bank is on track to meet its targets.

images.alt_text: DBS chief sustainability officer Helge Muenkel speaks during a media briefing on the DBS sustainability report, on March 5, 2024.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 8.4% in February from Chinese New Year festivities
summary: Singapore's retail sales surged 8.4% year-over-year in February, driven by Chinese New Year festivities and increased tourist arrivals from China, which overtook Indonesia as the top source of visitors. February's total retail sales reached S$3.9 billion, with online sales accounting for 10.9% of the total. The growth was led by the food and alcohol category, with sales of food and beverage services rising 14.7% year-over-year. Excluding motor vehicles, retail sales grew 9.4% from the year-ago period.

images.alt_text: January’s total retail sales stood at S$4.3 billion.

site_title: Bank of Japan hints at near-term rate hike, pushing yields higher
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda hinted at a near-term interest rate hike, citing accelerating inflation and wage increases. He stated that inflation is likely to rise "from summer towards autumn" and that the central bank could respond with monetary policy if the yen falls significantly, affecting inflation and wages. This suggests that the BOJ may raise interest rates as early as July, with some analysts predicting a hike in October to December.

images.alt_text: A man walks past the Bank of Japan (BoJ) headquarters complex in central Tokyo on March 19, 2024. Japan's central bank was widely expected later on March 19 to scrap its maverick negative interest rate policy and hike borrowing costs for the first time in 17 years, according to economists and media reports. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)
The central bank is hopeful that smaller firms will hike wages by the same amount as last year or more, after bumper pay hikes were offered to employees by their bigger counterparts.
Although the BOJ’s bond holdings have often fallen in the last month of the quarter, a decrease for the entire period has not happened since the last three months of 2008.

site_title: Nvidia, Indosat plan US$200 million AI centre investment in Indonesia, government says
summary: NVIDIA and Indosat Ooredoo Hutchison plan to invest US$200 million in a US$200 million AI centre in Surakarta, Central Java, Indonesia, expected to be completed in 2024. The centre could include telecommunication infrastructure or a human resource centre. The investment was announced by Indosat's CEO and confirmed by the communication minister, citing the region's readiness, human resources, and 5G infrastructure.

images.alt_text: A man speaks on a mobile phone in front of a PT Indosat sign in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Monday, Nov. 19, 2007. Temasek Holdings Pte's unit expects Indonesia's competition regulator to decide today whether the company has broken the country's anti-monopoly laws, and said it will exhaust all legal avenues to defend the case.

site_title: Bearish outlook, conservative targets prompt spike in Seatrium’s short interest
summary: Seatrium, an offshore and marine giant, saw its short interest spike to 6.43% on the Singapore Exchange, making it the second most shorted stock. The company's recent full-year losses and conservative financial targets contributed to the increase. Seatrium's share price has declined 90% since 2020, and analysts are cautious about its prospects, citing a 20-to-1 share consolidation as a negative signal. Despite some analysts expressing optimism about the company's Ebitda target and potential benefits from stronger offshore marine dynamics, the bearish outlook and short interest levels suggest investor hesitation.

images.alt_text: The contracts include repair, upgrade and conversion works to be completed by the end of 2025.
Seatrium logo at their office’s lobby, Oct 19, 2023.
Seatrium logo at their office’s lobby, Oct 19, 2023.

site_title: Singapore-listed semiconductor players expect minimal impact from Taiwan earthquake
summary: Singapore-listed semiconductor companies are expected to be minimally impacted by the recent 7.4-magnitude earthquake in Taiwan, as they supply equipment makers rather than foundries. Companies such as Frencken, UMS, and Grand Venture Technology reported no production disruptions or exposure to Taiwanese clients. Analysts note that the impact on revenue is likely to be contained, with gross margins potentially falling more than revenue, due to strong demand for advanced nodes, particularly in AI-related applications.

images.alt_text: Technological advancements in Taiwan appear to have kept damage and casualties relatively low after the 7.4-magnitude quake on early Wednesday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GuocoLand, City Developments Ltd
summary: GuocoLand and Hong Leong Holdings are the sole bidders for an Upper Thomson site, offering around S$780 million or S$904.60 per square foot per plot ratio. City Developments Ltd's joint venture with Mitsui Fudosan placed a S$1.1 billion bid for a Zion Road site, below expected prices. GuocoLand's shares rose 0.7%, while City Developments Ltd's shares increased 1% following the news.

site_title: Apac investment banking fees tumble in Q1: London Stock Exchange
summary: Asia-Pacific investment banking fees fell 29% in Q1 2024, reaching a 15-year low, with estimated fees of $4.4 billion. Global fees rose 2% to $27.6 billion, driven by gains in the Americas and Europe. China's state-owned Citic led the region in overall investment banking fees, followed by Citi. M&A deal-making activity declined 20.9% to $127.9 billion, with the materials sector seeing a 39.5% drop in deals.

images.alt_text: The goal is in line with Nomura’s strategy to increase investments in private markets and diversify sources of revenue to cushion the impact.
Jefferies headquarters in New York. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg
Over the past five years, the EU has introduced a welter of new regulations to make the region’s economy greener.

The Goldman Sachs & Co. logo is displayed at the company's booth on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., on Friday, July 19, 2013. site_title: Asia: Equities tumble, oil extends gains on Middle East worries
summary: Asian stocks plummeted on Friday, with Tokyo tanking over 2% and other major markets also experiencing significant losses. The decline was fueled by concerns over a potential regional conflict between Israel and Iran, which has raised oil prices over 1%. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions are also under scrutiny, with traders awaiting key jobs data later in the day. The Middle East tensions and ongoing war in Ukraine have increased investor nervousness, leading to a broader sell-off on global markets.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore and Jakarta were all in the green, though there were small losses in Manila and Wellington.

site_title: Art market experts see rebound in confidence after 2023 slump
summary: The art market has seen a rebound in confidence after a 4% decline in global sales of art and antiques in 2023, down to $65 billion. Experts attribute the slump to tighter financial conditions and a lack of fresh trends, with dealers citing a "vibe economy" where collectors prioritize supporting established artists. A cautious optimism prevails, with some predicting an upswing in 2024, driven by a strong auction season, lower interest rates, and collectors' excitement. The market is expected to recover, with a focus on the primary market for quality artists and a return to more freewheeling economic conditions.

images.alt_text: epa11249490 A woman takes photos of the artwork Kabinett, which is a site-specific installation that incorporates paintings and reconstructed found objects, by artist Zhou Yilun from Hangzhou of China, during the Art Basel exhibition in Hong Kong, China, 29 March 2024. Art Basel Hong Kong’s show features galleries from across continents and regions, including from the United States, Taiwan, Europe, the United Kingdom and beyond. site_title: Japan's Nikkei slumps in worst week since Dec 2022 as tech tumbles
summary: Japan's Nikkei index plummeted 1.96% or 781 points to 38,992.08, its worst week since December 2022, due to a decline in tech shares and cautious investor sentiment ahead of a key US jobs report. The Nikkei's 25-day moving average turned lower, increasing the risk of further losses, according to equities strategist Kazuo Kamitani. The broader Topix index also declined 1.08%, with growth shares falling 1.49%.

images.alt_text: A visitor walks past Japan's Nikkei stock prices quotation board inside a building in Tokyo, Japan February 19, 2024. REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: Apple cut at least 600 workers when car, screen projects stopped
summary: Apple laid off over 600 workers in California as it ended its car and smartwatch display projects. The layoffs were part of a decision to wind down the initiatives, which were met with indecision and cost concerns. The car project was cancelled, while the display programme was shut down due to engineering, supplier, and cost challenges. The company filed reports with the California Employment Development Department to comply with the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification programme.

site_title: Work on Marina Bay Sands’ fourth tower, entertainment arena, to begin in July 2025
summary: Marina Bay Sands' expansion project, including a fourth hotel tower, entertainment arena, and additional Mice space, is set to begin construction in July 2025. The project, designed by Safdie Architects, aims to be completed by July 2029. The expansion will feature a luxury hotel tower, a 15,000-seat entertainment arena, and new food and beverage options, with the added space for Mice events. The project is part of the integrated resort's ongoing development and will enhance its offerings to visitors.

images.alt_text: The Marina Bay Sands resort (L) and Singapore Flyer observation wheel (R) are pictured with the city skyline in Singapore on February 16, 2024. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
Genting Singapore says its Q4 gaming revenue for FY2023 is "very respectable".
Marina Bay Sands (left) is adding a fourth tower, while Resorts World Sentosa is expanding with a new waterfront lifestyle complex.

site_title: Singapore stocks slide at Friday’s open; STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks slid 0.8% at the open on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 25.9 points to 3,209.11, as losers outnumbered gainers 89 to 31. The decline followed overnight losses in the US market, which was attributed to rising oil prices and worries over tensions in the Middle East. Banking stocks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, were among the biggest decliners.

images.alt_text: GuocoLand and Hong Leong Holdings are the sole bidders for an Upper Thomson site.

site_title: Gold takes breather after record run ahead of US jobs data
summary: Gold prices paused after reaching a record high, falling 0.2% to US$2,284.84 per ounce, ahead of US jobs data. The pause comes despite expectations of lower US interest rates this year. The US central bank has time to deliberate on its first rate cut, according to Powell. The jobs data, due later, may shed light on the timing of the Fed's rate cut. Meanwhile, Canada recorded a bigger-than-expected trade surplus in February, and gold product sales in Australia dropped to their lowest level in nearly five years.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.1 per cent at US$2,300.53 per ounce.

site_title: China’s crowded wine market offers no lifeline for struggling global industry
summary: China's wine market, the world's largest at $336 billion, has shown no signs of recovery from a downturn that began before the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite a recent drop in anti-dumping tariffs, the market remains crowded with domestic and global players, leading to a decline in wine consumption. Annual import volumes have shrunk two-thirds since 2017, and China's wine market now accounts for less than 1.5% of all alcohol consumption. Industry executives expect a stabilisation in the market, but growth is unlikely to reach pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Together with other better-than-expected manufacturing surveys, the data add to evidence that parts of China’s economy are gaining momentum in the first quarter.
Economic data over the January-to-February period and a factory owners survey for March offer relief to Chinese policymakers seeking to convince foreign investors.
Citi last week raised its forecast for China’s 2024 growth to 5.0 per cent from 4.6 per cent, citing “recent positive data and policy delivery”.
Recent indicators suggest a stabilisation in China, but overall gains remain tempered by the persistent fragility in the property market.

site_title: Thailand will consider all sources of funding for 500 billion baht handout scheme
summary: Thailand's government will consider all funding sources for its 500 billion baht handout scheme, which has been delayed to the fourth quarter of 2024 due to funding concerns. The plan, intended to give 10,000 baht to 50 million Thais, aims to stimulate the economy. Despite experts calling it fiscally irresponsible, Deputy Finance Minister Krisada Chinavicharana says the country's public debt will not exceed 70%. The government is also pressuring the Bank of Thailand to cut interest rates to stimulate growth, but the central bank has resisted so far.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Thailand will review key interest rates next week.
The stimulus plan, delayed by several months over differences on how it will be funded, is set to be implemented in the fourth quarter of calendar year 2024.

site_title: Hong Kong’s ZA Bank looks to offer Hong Kong accounts for stablecoin issuers
summary: Hong Kong's ZA Bank is exploring the possibility of offering Hong Kong accounts for stablecoin issuers, with a focus on corporate clients. The virtual lender is in touch with 5-8 existing and new clients considering creating stablecoins, which would be backed by fiat reserves. The move aims to support Hong Kong's development as a digital asset hub and is part of the city's efforts to restore its financial center status. ZA Bank plans to break even this year and has already handled over $1 billion in transfers from Web3 clients.

images.alt_text: Devon Sin, alternate chief executive of ZA Bank.Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

site_title: Filmmaker and fan Jonathan Nolan brings ‘Fallout’ games to TV
summary: Jonathan Nolan's live-action "Fallout" TV series premieres on Prime Video on April 11, based on the popular post-apocalyptic video game series. The eight-episode show, co-created by Nolan and Lisa Joy, follows three main characters: Lucy MacLean, Maximus, and The Ghoul. Nolan, who played the games and loved them, expressed nervousness and excitement about adapting the series for television, marking his latest project after the success of "Westworld."

images.alt_text: Gamers have been recording fewer hours of play, with the average quarterly playtime falling 26 per cent from 2021 to 2023.
Game companies have been coping with layoffs, mergers and product cancellations.

site_title: OCBC group chief Helen Wong’s pay in 2023 up 8% to S$12.1 million
summary: OCBC group CEO Helen Wong's 2023 annual pay rose 8% to S$12.1 million, with a base salary of S$1.4 million, a bonus of S$6.4 million, and deferred shares worth S$4.2 million. DBS CEO Piyush Gupta, who received S$11.2 million, saw a pay cut, making him the lowest-paid CEO among the three Singapore banks. UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong topped the list with S$15.9 million in total annual remuneration.

images.alt_text: DBS chief executive Piyush Gupta's lower salary for FY2023 comes after the bank announced it was cutting his variable pay by 30 per cent.

site_title: Goldman Sachs urged to separate CEO, chair roles by proxy advisers
summary: Proxy advisers Glass Lewis and Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) have urged Goldman Sachs to separate the CEO and chairman roles, citing potential conflicts of interest and the bank's recent missteps in consumer operations. The recommendations come as Goldman's CEO, David Solomon, scales down the bank's consumer operations, which have lost billions. The bank has urged investors to vote against the proposal, citing the need for flexibility in governance.

site_title: Amazon’s AI stores seemed too magical – and they were
summary: Amazon's Just Walk Out technology, which enabled customers to grab items and walk out of stores, was phased out due to its reliance on 1,000 contractors in India who labeled videos to ensure accuracy. This highlights the often-overlooked role of humans in training and operating AI systems. The practice of "AI washing" or exaggerating the capabilities of AI technology is widespread, with companies misrepresenting their use of machine learning and AI models. Regulators are now targeting startups that mislead investors about their AI use, and the industry's reliance on hidden workers remains a concern.

images.alt_text: Amazon will remove the system as it remodels existing Fresh grocery stores and will not feature it in new locations that will start opening later this year.

site_title: Why Tudor is going pink
summary: Tudor has unveiled the Black Bay Chronograph Pink, a luxury watch featuring a pink dial, at Watches & Wonders Geneva 2024. The watch is a limited edition, made in collaboration with Jay Chou, the King of Mandopop. The brand's decision to introduce a pink color to its lineup is seen as a bold move, aligning with Tudor's "born to dare" motto. The watch's release comes after a high-profile partnership with Inter Miami CF, and its positive response from the watch community suggests that Tudor's choice to go pink will be well-received.

images.alt_text: The Tudor Pelagos FXD Alinghi Red Bull Racing Edition watches come in time-only and chronograph versions.

site_title: Meta pushes back on US FTC’s bid to amend 2020 privacy settlement
summary: Meta has rejected the US Federal Trade Commission's attempt to amend a 2020 privacy settlement, citing voluntary disclosure of two technical errors in the Messenger Kids app. Meta disclosed the bugs in 2019 and spent $5.5 billion on its privacy program. The FTC had sought to tighten the settlement, which banned profiting from minors' data and expanded curbs on facial recognition technology. Meta has denied misleading parents about privacy risks and previously sued the FTC in November over its dual role as an investigator and adjudicator.

site_title: Japan warns against excessive yen moves, repeats verbal intervention
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki warned against excessive yen moves, reiterating the government's readiness to take action against sharp yen declines. The yen fell to a 34-year low of 151.975 yen against the US dollar, despite the Bank of Japan's recent policy shift. Suzuki and BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda have repeated verbal warnings about potential yen intervention, with Ueda suggesting the central bank could raise interest rates later this year if yen declines significantly affect inflation and wages.
