site_title: Google parent Alphabet weighs offer for HubSpot: sources
summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, is reportedly considering a potential offer for HubSpot, a US$35 billion online marketing software company. The acquisition would be Alphabet's largest ever and would allow the company to utilize its cash pile. The deal has sparked interest among investors, with HubSpot's shares rising 11% on the news. However, there is no certainty that Alphabet will submit an offer, and antitrust regulators would need to clear such a tie-up amid heightened regulatory scrutiny.

images.alt_text: The potential move suggests the Alphabet unit still has not figured out how to incorporate the new, fast-growing technology.
Google’s agreement to retroactively delete user information is a significant concession as it forms the backbone of the company’s lucrative advertising business.
EU industry chief Thierry Breton says the investigations should not be a surprise.

site_title: Bank of Korea considering forward guidance overhaul: sources
summary: The Bank of Korea is considering overhauling its forward guidance policy to provide more transparent and visual estimates of interest rate path, potentially extending the timeframe to six months or longer. The proposal aims to boost public understanding of monetary policy, but faces opposition from at least one governing board member, who is concerned it could undermine public confidence in policy. The new format may resemble the US Federal Reserve's "dot plot" and will need approval from the seven-member board.

images.alt_text: Housing prices are a key barometer of risks for developers.
The Bank of Korea said a premature shift away from tighter monetary settings could undermine policy credibility and send the wrong message to financial markets about debt and risk-taking.
The Bank of Korea held its key policy rate at 3.50 per cent at a policy review in Seoul, keeping it unchanged for a ninth straight meeting as expected by all 38 analysts polled by Reuters.

site_title: Baltimore shipping set to resume by end of April with full capacity by end of May
summary: The US Army Corps of Engineers expects to open a new channel to the Port of Baltimore by the end of April, freeing up commercial shipping blocked by a collapsed bridge. The channel will initially be suitable for roll-on/roll-off vessels, with full capacity restored by the end of May. The Port of Baltimore, the US' largest volume handler of cars and machinery, has suspended most shipping traffic since the March 26 bridge collapse that killed six workers.

images.alt_text: View of the Francis Scott Key Bridge which collapsed after being struck by the Dali cargo vessel in Baltimore, Maryland, U.S., April 4, 2024. REUTERS/Nathan Howard

site_title: Nomura aims to boost US credit portfolio to US$50 billion within 10 years, executive says
summary: Nomura Holdings aims to expand its US credit portfolio to $50 billion within 10 years, with current assets under management at $35 billion. The goal is part of the bank's strategy to increase investments in private markets and diversify revenue sources. Nomura Capital Management plans to grow the business through organic hiring and potential small acquisitions, focusing on niche areas like asset-based lending and real estate lending.

images.alt_text: In its third quarter, which ended in December, Nomura wholesale unit delivered a pretax profit of 23 billion yen (S$206 million) following a loss of 1.9 billion yen in the same quarter of the previous year.
Nomura is reorganising its US investment management business.
The Prudential Regulation Authority’s decision comes after Nomura made progress on a remediation plan that required it to improve its risk monitoring and control systems, one source said.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Nomura Securities is seen at the company's Head Office in Tokyo, Japan, November 28, 2016.  REUTERS/Toru Hanai//File Photo
The Nomura group as a whole brought in 2,277 new hires in Japan during the three years to March 2023.

site_title: Samsung Electronics expects 10-fold rise in Q1 profit
summary: Samsung Electronics expects its Q1 operating profits to rise 931.3% year-over-year to 6.6 trillion won (S$6.6 billion), driven by a chip price recovery. This represents a more than 10-fold increase from the same period last year, when profits were around 640 billion won. The company's flagship subsidiary is expected to release its final earnings report at the end of this month.

images.alt_text: Samsung began selling its latest flagship Galaxy S24 smartphones at the end of January, with a bevvy of AI functions to compete with rival Apple.
Key Samsung rival SK Hynix is already supplying Nvidia with the latest version of high-bandwidth memory, HBM3E.
The pending announcement only represents a preliminary agreement that could still change, and no final decision has been made.

site_title: Japan’s households continue to cut outlays as inflation hits
summary: Japan's households continued to cut back on spending in February, with outlays decreasing 0.5% from a year ago, marking a 12th consecutive month of decline. The decline narrowed from the previous month's 6.3% drop and was less than economists' forecast of a 2.9% retreat. Real wages have fallen for 22 consecutive months, but annual wage talks are expected to result in wage gains exceeding 5% later this year, potentially outpacing inflation. The Bank of Japan's decision to end its negative rate regime was partly driven by optimistic prospects for rising wages.

images.alt_text: The output gap is among data the BOJ watches closely in determining whether the economy is expanding strongly enough to propel a demand-driven rise in inflation.
The service sector has been the driving force behind the country’s recent economic growth, helping offset the drag in manufacturing hampered by weak global demand.
Japan’s economy expanded an annualised 0.4 per cent in the final quarter of last year, narrowly averting a technical recession as robust capital expenditure offset weaknesses in consumption.
Japanese manufacturers surveyed expect seasonally adjusted output to increase 4.9 per cent in March and rise 3.3 per cent in April.

site_title: Use of Fed central bank tool grows as cash stockpiling continues
summary: Foreign central banks have increased their cash holdings at the US Federal Reserve's reverse repurchase agreement facility for the third week, with a total of $2.95 trillion, up from $2.83 trillion a week earlier. This growth indicates that policymakers worldwide are building cash positions amid warnings of potential steps to bolster their currencies, as the US dollar remains strong. The move follows similar actions by central banks in Japan, Turkey, China, and Indonesia, and comes as emerging economies remain vulnerable to the US dollar's strength.

images.alt_text: “Recent data do not, however, materially change the overall picture, which continues to be one of solid growth, a strong but rebalancing labour market, and inflation moving down towards 2 per cent on a sometimes bumpy path,” Fed chair Jerome Powell says.
Fed officials are split: Nine now see two or fewer rate cuts this year, their projections show, after disappointing inflation data at the start of 2024.

site_title: 99 Cents Only Stores announces plans to wind down operations
summary: 99 Cents Only Stores has announced plans to wind down its business operations, striking a deal with Hilco Global to liquidate merchandise and dispose of fixtures and equipment at 371 stores, starting April 5. The retailer cited significant challenges in the retail environment, including the COVID-19 pandemic and inflationary pressures, as the reason for its decision. Hilco Real Estate will manage the sale of the firm's real estate assets, and Alvarez & Marsal has appointed Chris Wells as chief restructuring officer.

site_title: Malaysian telco Axiata to sell Myanmar telco tower business for US$150 million
summary: Axiata Group, a Malaysian telco conglomerate, will sell its entire stake in Edotco Myanmar for $150 million, exiting the telco tower business in the country. The decision was made due to deteriorating macroeconomic and operating environments in Myanmar. Axiata had entered Myanmar in 2015 with an enterprise value of $221 million and will redeploy the capital to reduce debt and enhance shareholder value. This move follows other corporations withdrawing from Myanmar, including fashion retailers and oil majors, amid a political and humanitarian crisis.

site_title: US officials to pressure Dutch government on China chip curbs
summary: US officials will visit the Netherlands next week to pressure the Dutch government to restrict ASML Holding from servicing and repairing chipmaking equipment sold to Chinese clients. The move aims to thwart Beijing's technology ambitions and tighten export controls on China's access to semiconductor technology. The US has already restricted US chip equipment suppliers from servicing equipment deployed at blacklisted Chinese entities, and the Netherlands is seen as a key ally in this effort. The visit is part of the Biden administration's campaign to limit China's technology advancements.

images.alt_text: With “Operation Beethoven”, the Dutch Cabinet presumes that ASML will continue to invest and keep its statutory, fiscal and actual headquarters in the Netherlands .
ASML and other tech firms that depend on foreign staff argue that the immigration restrictions have undermine the country’s future prosperity.
ASML's High NA EUV tools, which are the size of a double decker bus and cost more than US$350 million each, are expected to help enable new generations of smaller, faster chips.

site_title: McDonald’s to buy Israel franchise that became flashpoint in Hamas war
summary: McDonald's has agreed to acquire its Israel franchise from operator Alonyal, ending controversy surrounding the chain's involvement in the conflict. The deal brings the local chain in-house, with plans to find a new franchisee in a few months. The acquisition comes after McDonald's CEO Chris Kempczinski condemned violence and hate speech in the wake of the Hamas attack. The move is seen as a step towards ensuring a positive employee and customer experience in the Israeli market.

images.alt_text: The addition of Krispy Kreme is the latest change to McDonald’s bakery lineup.

On Friday, system outages plagued McDonald’s locations across some of its biggest global markets, including Japan, Australia and the UK, forcing many stores to temporarily take only cash or shut down entirely.
The outage appears to have affected some electronic kiosks at outlets here.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on worries over Middle East
summary: US stocks plummeted 1.4% on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 825 points, as concerns over the Middle East drove up oil prices. Analysts attribute the rise in oil to heightened tensions between Israel and Iran, as well as US criticism of Israel's handling of the Gaza war. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also fell, with all 11 sectors of the S&P 500 in the red, except for defense-related stocks.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JANUARY 19: Traders and media work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on January 19, 2024 in New York City. Stocks closed up over 350 points while the S&P 500 closed at an all-time high on Friday.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Boeing, Airbus exploring framework to divvy up Spirit Aero’s operations: sources
summary: Boeing and Airbus are exploring a framework deal to split Spirit AeroSystems' operations, potentially accelerating a shift in the aerospace industry. The deal would allow Boeing to regain control of its supply chain, including Spirit's Wichita plant, and Airbus to acquire Spirit's Kinston composite parts factory and Belfast wings factory. The agreement would require regulatory approvals and faces uncertainty, with industry sources suggesting that Airbus may need to invest $1 billion to make the Belfast wings more affordable.

images.alt_text: An Alaska Air-operated MAX 9 jet experienced a mid-air cabin panel blowout in January, which led the US aviation regulator to order grounding of 171 jets for inspections.
Boeing has slowed production of its bestselling model to address quality lapses tied to a near-disaster on a 737 Max 9 in January.

site_title: Cocoa price surge from supply crunch leaving bitter taste for chocolate makers and consumers
summary: Cocoa prices have surged due to a global supply crunch, with London cocoa futures up 125.6% and New York cocoa futures up 129.4% year-to-date. A supply shortfall from Ivory Coast and Ghana, two major cocoa-producing countries, is expected to lead to a global cocoa supply decline of 10.9% and a supply deficit of 374,000 tonnes. Chocolate makers and consumers may face higher costs and prices, with some companies opting to cut back on production or raise prices. Analysts predict that prices may not drop until the middle of next year, with cocoa prices forecasted to reach $9,000 per tonne for New York futures and $7,500 pounds per tonne for London futures.

images.alt_text: While a technical gauge shows cocoa prices may have skyrocketed too quickly, many analysts are not yet seeing a top to the market.
Gold is one of market watchers' top picks, as they expect central bank demand to remain strong while the downside risks for the previous yellow metal are limited.
Long the world's undisputed cocoa powerhouses, Ghana and Ivory Coast are both facing catastrophic harvests this season.
Cocoa prices have more than trebled over the last year as disease and adverse weather pushed the global market to a third successive deficit.
SGX-listed palm oil companies have booked positive total returns this year, despite weaker crude palm oil prices and lower average selling prices on a year-on-year basis.
FILE PHOTO: An employee shows a Hershey's chocolate bar made in USA in the "American lifestyle" store in Berlin, Germany, August 13, 2018. REUTERS/Fabrizio Bensch/File Photo

CHICAGO, ILLINOIS - FEBRUARY 02: In this photo illustration, chocolates packaged for Valentine's Day sit on a table on February 02, 2024 in Chicago, Illinois. Cocoa prices have surged over the past several years, recently reaching near record levels and driving up the cost of chocolate. (Photo Illustration by Scott Olson/Getty Images) (Photo by SCOTT OLSON / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Alaska Air says Boeing paid US$160 million in compensation after MAX 9 grounding
summary: Alaska Air says Boeing has paid US$160 million in compensation to address the financial impact of grounding 171 737 MAX 9 jets following a mid-air cabin panel blowout in January. The US aviation regulator initially ordered the grounding for inspections, which was lifted later that month. Alaska Air expects additional compensation.

site_title: Brent settles above US$90 for first time since October on geopolitical tension
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, settling above $90 for the first time since October, due to geopolitical tensions and output cuts. Brent futures for June rose $1.30, or 1.5%, to $90.65 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate futures for May rose $1.16, or 1.4%, to $86.59 a barrel. The increase was driven by heightened tensions between Israel and Iran, as well as US counter-terrorism sanctions on Iran and support for Ukraine's NATO membership.

images.alt_text: An idled oil pumping unit in Cabimas, on the East coast of Lake Maracaibo, Venezuela, is illuminated by the morning light Friday January 3, 2002. A nationwide strike has cut shipments from the fourt-biggest source of U.S. imports. Photographer: Ana Maria Otero Borjas/Bloomberg News.
Brent futures rose 43 US cents, or 0.5 per cent, to settle at US$89.35 a barrel.

site_title: Europe: Cyclicals drive modest gains across European stocks
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 0.2% on Thursday, driven by gains in cyclical sectors like mining and automakers. Copper prices hit their highest in 14 months, contributing to the basic resources sector's 1.7% gain. Automakers and banks also rose over 1%. The recovery in the eurozone economy and decreasing inflation are seen as encouraging signs.

images.alt_text: The continent-wide Stoxx 600 closed 0.3 per cent higher, recovering from a two-week intraday low.

site_title: How exercise strengthens your brain
summary: Physical activity improves cognitive and mental health by offering short-term boosts in cognition and benefiting mood. Research by Henriette van Praag, an associate professor of biomedical science, suggests that exercise can spur the growth of new brain cells in mature mice, although its effectiveness in adult humans remains debated. Physical activity, however, is proven to bring about numerous cellular changes that enhance mood and cognition, making it an excellent way to maintain brain health. Regular exercise can be achieved through various activities, such as CrossFit and running, and can have numerous benefits for overall well-being.

images.alt_text: There are a few tools that can trick our brain into lacing up and heading out.

site_title: Frugality bites for China’s cash-strapped local governments
summary: China's local governments are facing a tough year ahead due to growing fiscal strain, with many projecting revenue increases of 3-6% in 2024, down from last year's actual growth. The slump in land sales revenue, a major source of fiscal revenue, has exacerbated the strain. Local governments are being forced to cut back on general expenditure to ensure they have enough money to spend on mandatory expenditure, including basic livelihoods and daily operations. The government has also introduced new guidelines to prevent localities from investing in vanity projects and to tackle their explicit and hidden debt burdens.

images.alt_text: Together with other better-than-expected manufacturing surveys, the data add to evidence that parts of China’s economy are gaining momentum in the first quarter.
The net FDI reflects monetary flows into and out of the mainland connected to overseas-owned entities and used for investment in assets such as manufacturing and real estate.

The market downturn spells trouble for many IPO hopefuls, creating a rift between them and their PE/VC investors that is increasingly leading to arbitration or litigation when companies fail to follow an agreed timetable to go public and allow funds to exit.
As of June 30, 2023, Haidilao operates 1,382 restaurants in Greater China, all company owned.

site_title: The art of transitioning to a board
summary: Singapore-listed companies are expected to refresh their boards this year, with 20.9% of independent directors having served for over 9 years. Progressive boards recognize the importance of a cohesive mix of competencies, skills, and perspectives. To be effective, directors must possess strategic thinking, financial knowledge, intellectual rigour, emotional quotient, and unique value propositions. Effective board members must navigate boardroom dynamics, including diplomacy, tact, and emotional courage, and be prepared to debate and be proven wrong. Aspiring directors must exercise due diligence and understand the heavy responsibilities of being an independent director.

images.alt_text: A deliberate succession plan for the board and chair are critical, as businesses navigate an increasingly complex landscape.
The Singapore Exchange listing rules have required issuers to publish sustainability/ESG reports since 2016.
FILE PHOTO: OpenAI logo is seen in this illustration taken, February 3, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: B Capital appoints ex-Temasek MD Jeff Johnson as general partner
summary: B Capital, a global investment firm co-founded by Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin, has appointed former Temasek managing director Jeff Johnson as general partner. Johnson will lead the company's climate investment team, alongside BCG's Rich Lesser, who was appointed as vice-chair of climate and sustainability. The move aims to partner with and back leading climate entrepreneurs, with Saverin citing Johnson's investment leadership and Lesser's strategic direction as key assets.

site_title: The Nobel laureate who liked to collaborate with his adversaries
summary: Nobel laureate Daniel Kahneman, known for his path-breaking explorations of human judgment and decision-making, emphasized the value of working with those who disagree in his lifetime. His work showed that, for 85% of people, money does buy happiness, but only up to a certain threshold. However, his collaboration with Matthew Killingsworth found that a smaller group of people, particularly those with lower incomes, experience no increase in happiness with rising income. Kahneman advocated for "adversarial collaboration" over "angry science," which he believed led to a more nuanced understanding of complex issues and fostered a more civil discourse, encouraging teams to work together to uncover the truth.

images.alt_text: However, the researchers found that the overall emotional effect of more money on a person is small compared with other circumstances, even something as simple as two days off at the end of a week.

site_title: The ‘Land of Opportunity’ is now everywhere
summary: Singapore's venture capital funding per capita is the highest in the world at US$1,060, surpassing America's second-place ranking. The "Land of Opportunity" is no longer limited to big cities in the US, as technology has made it possible for anyone, anywhere, to build a world-bettering business. Globalization has reduced barriers to entry, with online platforms and pro-business climates facilitating access to capital. Despite a dip in 2023, Singapore's VC funding has tripled since 2019, and the trend is expected to continue, with opportunities available globally.

images.alt_text: Singapore's aging population can be a boon for its stock market.

Pedestrians walk past Arturo Di Modica's 'The Bund Financial Bull' sculpture on the Bund at night in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday, Oct. 22, 2013. China's economic expansion accelerated to 7.8 percent in the third quarter from a year earlier, the statistics bureau said Oct. 18, reversing a slowdown that put the government at risk of missing its 7.5 percent growth target for 2013. Photographer: Tomohiro Ohsumi/Bloomberg
Real risks must be big, economically significant events few fathom – stealth torpedoes unpriced by markets, says Ken Fisher.

site_title: Carrefour-PepsiCo dispute sheds light on key role of retailers’ ad business
summary: Carrefour and PepsiCo have resolved a three-month price dispute, with PepsiCo's products returning to Carrefour's shelves in France. The agreement highlights the growing interdependence between retailers and suppliers, particularly in the context of advertising space. Consumer goods executives note that retailers' removal of products can hurt suppliers' advertising budgets, making them less willing to spend on advertising services. This dynamic is particularly significant for retailers, as advertising budgets can provide higher margins than traditional store sales. The resolution comes amidst a trend of pricing disputes in Europe, with other retailers and suppliers also involved in similar negotiations.

images.alt_text: The soda and snacks giant forecast annual organic revenue growth of at least 4 per cent, compared to the 9.5 per cent growth reported for fiscal 2023.
From Thursday (Jan 4), shelves with PepsiCo products at Carrefour stores in France will be accompanied by a note saying “We are no longer selling this brand due to unacceptable price increases”.

site_title: US mortgage rates climb to 6.82%, squeezing homebuyers in market
summary: US mortgage rates have risen to 6.82%, further squeezing homebuyers in the market. This increase, from 6.79% last week, follows a pattern of rising borrowing costs and high home prices. The Federal Reserve is considering its next steps, but economists expect rates to remain high for the near term, citing improving inventory and tempered home-price growth. This challenges first-time and repeat homebuyers, with over a third of home purchases made in cash in February.

site_title: Disney CEO’s headaches abound even after major proxy war win
summary: Disney CEO Bob Iger has emerged victorious in his proxy war with billionaire activist investor Nelson Peltz, with all of management's choices to the board elected and Iger reelected with 94% support. Despite the win, Iger's legacy remains uncertain, with unresolved challenges including reviving the company's struggling movie business, identifying a new CEO, and turning a profit in Disney's streaming division. The company's focus will shift to growth and value creation for shareholders, with key initiatives including the release of upcoming films and a new streaming strategy.

images.alt_text: The settlement ends all litigation pending in state court of Florida between Disney and the Central Florida Tourism Oversight District.
Disney’s annual meeting, when voting will end, is scheduled for April 3.

FILE PHOTO: A screen shows the logo and a ticker symbol for The Walt Disney Company on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., December 14, 2017. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Currency angst goes global as strong dollar vexes officials
summary: The US dollar has gained against virtually every major peer in 2024, defying predictions of a dollar selloff, and has become a source of concern for central bankers and governments worldwide. In response, policymakers are intervening to defend their currencies, with Japan warning of "bold action" to bolster the yen, Indonesia intervening in interbank markets, and China's yuan being pushed to the bottom of its permitted trading band against the dollar. Experts warn that the dollar's dominance is likely to continue, with some predicting a synchronized rate-cutting cycle by central banks that would only further strengthen the dollar.

images.alt_text: The dollar index, which measures the US currency against six rivals, was down 0.15 per cent at 104.08 after hitting 104.05, its lowest level since Mar 26.

site_title: Musical ‘Mamma Mia!’ celebrates 25 years in London’s West End
summary: Musical 'Mamma Mia!' celebrates 25 years in London's West End, marking a significant milestone for the 'kitchen sink' show based on ABBA's songs. Produced by Judy Craymer, the musical has been seen in over 450 cities worldwide, leading to two hit movies. Craymer credits the show for changing a dynamic in musical theatre, earning its place in cultural history. The show's enduring success is a testament to its universal appeal and timeless music.

images.alt_text: Cast and crew members take a moment after their final performance of the "Phantom of the Opera", which closes after 35 years on Broadway, New York City, April 16, 2023.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as recent data fuels hopes of rate cuts
summary: US stock indexes opened higher on Thursday, driven by recent economic reports that fueled hopes of rate cuts later this year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 216.5 points, or 0.55%, to 39,343.6, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained ground. Investors await policymakers' clues on the timing of potential rate cuts, which could boost the market.

site_title: Gucci owner splashes out 1.3 billion euros for building on Milan’s iconic shopping street
summary: Kering, the French luxury group behind Gucci, is spending 1.3 billion euros (S$1.9 billion) to buy Via Monte Napoleone 8, a 5,000 square meter property on Milan's iconic shopping street. The 18th-century building already hosts high-end brands Cova and Prada, and Kering aims to secure key locations for its labels as part of a selective real estate strategy. The deal represents the single largest asset sale in the Italian real estate market, underscoring exceptional investor demand for high-quality real estate.

images.alt_text: The slowdown in China is affecting brands aside from Gucci as well, if not as dramatically.

site_title: Ford delays some North American electric SUV, truck production
summary: Ford has delayed the launch of its three-row electric SUV in Canada and its next-generation electric pickup truck in Tennessee due to a slowdown in EV demand globally. The company aims to scale a profitable EV business and will instead push back production to 2027 for the SUV and 2026 for the truck. Ford also plans to boost hybrid electric vehicle offerings and expects to offer hybrid powertrains across its lineup by 2030. The carmaker had previously lost nearly $4.7 billion on its EV business in 2023.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the Ford Halewood transmissions plant in Liverpool, Britain, December 1, 2022. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the Ford Halewood transmissions plant in Liverpool, Britain, December 1, 2022. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo

site_title: Mitsui, Rohto Pharmaceutical take 86% stake in Eu Yan Sang for S$687 million
summary: Japan's Mitsui & Co and Rohto Pharmaceutical have purchased an 86% stake in Eu Yan Sang International for S$687 million in cash. The deal values 100% of Eu Yan Sang at about S$800 million. Two members of the Eu family will roll over about 10% of their interest in the company to become shareholders of the consortium, providing guidance. The deal follows Eu Yan Sang's delisting from the Singapore Exchange in October 2016.

images.alt_text: The Singapore-headquartered company has over 170 retail outlets, about 25 TCM clinics and three medical centres across Greater China, Singapore and Malaysia.
The Singapore-headquartered company has over 170 retail outlets, about 25 TCM clinics and three medical centres across Greater China, Singapore and Malaysia.

site_title: Taiwan’s chips giant resumes operations day after deadly quake
summary: Taiwan's semiconductor industry has resumed operations after a 7.4-magnitude earthquake struck the island, with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) restarting production within 24 hours. Despite the quake, there has been minimal damage to critical equipment, and most operations at the Tainan Science Park have resumed. Emergency personnel are helping injured and trapped citizens, and the country is beginning to recover from its worst earthquake in 25 years.

images.alt_text: This handout from the Pingtung County Fire and Emergency Services taken and released on April 4, 2024, shows search and rescue personnel working on a mountainside during the search for the body of a hiker in Hualien, a day after a major earthquake hit Taiwan's east. Taiwan rescuers worked on April 4 to reach scores of people trapped in highway tunnels as engineers began a massive clear-up operation a day after the island's biggest earthquake in a quarter of a century. site_title: India central bank delays exchange-traded derivative rules implementation till May 3
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has delayed the implementation of its consolidated directions for exchange-traded currency derivatives (ETCD) by a month, from April 4 to May 3, 2024, to ease market panic. The decision comes after brokers asked clients to submit proof of underlying exposure on their derivative contracts or unwind existing positions. The RBI had previously permitted users to take positions of up to US$100 million without documentary evidence. The delay is seen as an extension to allow participants to close out their positions.

images.alt_text: Central bank governor Shaktikanta Das has repeatedly said that it is premature to ease policy before inflation returns to the 4 per cent target.
Barring the ultra-long duration which consists of bonds maturing in 30 years and above, the RBI conducted auctions for bonds through uniform-based pricing since July 2021.
The RBI’s inflation targeting framework has helped to keep price pressures moderate, Prime Minister Narendra Modi says.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims at two-month high
summary: US initial jobless claims rose 9,000 to a two-month high of 221,000 for the week ended March 30, according to the Labor Department. Despite this, fewer people remained on jobless rolls, suggesting laid-off workers continued to find work. Economists attribute the increase to an early Easter, which may have affected seasonal data. The labor market remains strong, with job openings exceeding unemployed individuals, and the economy is expected to grow at a brisk 3.4% annualized rate in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: A measure of new orders received by services businesses slipped to 54.4 last month from 56.1 in February.
Private payrolls rose by 184,000 jobs last month after advancing by an upwardly revised 155,000 in February, the ADP Employment report showed.
The reasons for the high demand for workers – an ageing workforce, lack of skilled labour and companies hoarding staff – are holding firm even as economies start to slow.

FILE PHOTO: Workers marry the body structure with the battery pack and the front and rear sub frames as they assemble electric vehicles at the Lucid Motors plant in Casa Grande, Arizona, U.S. September 28, 2021.  REUTERS/Caitlin O'Hara
Job openings, a measure of labour demand, edged up 8,000 to 8.756 million on the last day of February.
The ISM says its manufacturing PMI increased to 50.3 last month, the highest and first reading above 50 since September 2022, from 47.8 in February.

site_title: Eurozone banking stocks are the most overbought in history
summary: Eurozone banking stocks have reached an all-time high, with the Euro Stoxx Banks subindex rising over 20% in 2024, outpacing the broader Stoxx 600 Index. The relative strength index reached 90, exceeding the 70-level seen as a signal of overbought assets. Banks benefit from higher bond yields, easing inflation, and attractive dividends, making them relatively cheap compared to history. Despite concerns, analysts see a strong earnings outlook, with Bank of America predicting a strong first quarter for European banks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man holds a laptop computer as cyber code is projected on him in this illustration picture taken on May 13, 2017. REUTERS/Kacper Pempel/Illustration/File Photo
The ECB argues that banks’ exposure to rising corporate credit risk and the perception of the shares as value stocks play a big part in stagnant valuations.
Banks push on with tightening their standards for lending to businesses between July and September, according to the ECB’s quarterly bank lending survey.
FILE PHOTO: European flags are seen in front of the European Central Bank (ECB) building, in Frankfurt, Germany, July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

site_title: Sole low bids for large plots in River Valley, Thomson show developers turning frosty and defensive
summary: Developers have shown a chill in sentiment, with low bids for large residential plots in River Valley and Upper Thomson areas. A CDL-Mitsui Fudosan joint venture submitted the sole bid for a Zion Road site, with a S$1.1 billion offer 30.6% lower than the last government land sales site in the area. Another site in Upper Thomson drew a single bid from GuocoLand and Hong Leong Holdings, at around S$780 million or S$904.60 per square foot per plot ratio. Analysts attribute the low bids to a decline in developer sentiment, citing the doubling of Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty for foreigners and moderating rents.

images.alt_text: Stay awhile: How long-stay serviced apartments may change the housing landscape
The Upper Thomson Road land parcel is a stone's throw from the new Lentor Hills estate, where six plots have been sold so far and five projects launched.
To democratise real estate ownership, policymakers can perhaps nudge ownership of long-stay serviced apartments to rest with many individuals via vehicles such as widely held listed Reits.

site_title: Yellen faces tough road on China's vast overproduction problem
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen arrived in China with a message that the country's massive overproduction of clean energy goods, including electric vehicles and solar panels, is threatening global markets and the US economy. Yellen's meetings with Chinese officials will focus on the need for China to reduce excess production and support household spending, rather than investing in new manufacturing capacity. The US is concerned that China's policies are leading to "money-losing firms" that will have to sell production elsewhere, and Yellen has hinted at the possibility of new tariffs on Chinese goods.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden (right) and China's President Xi Jinping (left) have managed to maintain a veneer of diplomatic stability despite deep mutual suspicion between their countries, and as their governments pursue export controls, sanctions and tariffs.
US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen attends a session as part of the G20 Leaders' Summit at the Bharat Mandapam in New Delhi on September 9, 2023. (Photo by Ludovic MARIN / POOL / AFP)

site_title: US trade deficit widens in February on strong imports
summary: The US trade deficit widened for a second straight month in February, increasing 1.9% to $68.9 billion, as imports surged 2.2% to a record high of $331.9 billion. Exports rose 2.3% to an all-time high of $263.0 billion, driven by gains in industrial supplies, materials, and services. Despite the widening trade gap, most imported goods are expected to end up as inventories, potentially offsetting the impact on economic growth in the first quarter, which is estimated to be around 2.8%.

images.alt_text: Initial claims for state unemployment benefits rose 9,000 to a seasonally adjusted 221,000 for the week ended Mar 30.

site_title: US dollar edges down after data, yen squeezed, Swiss Franc at multi-month lows
summary: The US dollar edged down 0.15% to 104.08 against a basket of six major currencies, its lowest level since March 26, due to data supporting rate cut expectations in the US. The yen remained near its 34-year low against the dollar, while the Swiss franc hit a multi-month low due to a lower-than-expected inflation rate. The dollar's decline was attributed to market expectations of rate cuts, with futures pricing a 60% probability of a US Fed cut in June.

images.alt_text: The Vietnamese dong registered a year-to-date drop of about 3 per cent.
The Japanese yen was last at 151.7 per dollar, little recovered from last week’s slump to 34-year lows of 151.975

site_title: Global markets watchdog proposes closer scrutiny of stock exchanges
summary: Global securities watchdog Iosco proposed detailed guidance on supervising stock exchanges more closely to mitigate risks from changes in business practices. Over the past two decades, exchanges have become publicly listed companies while remaining self-regulatory, with some operating across borders and diversifying into technology services. Iosco warned that this shift could create conflicts of interest and operational dependencies, posing risks to regulatory functions and supervisory issues. The watchdog recommended six "good practices" for regulators to assess exchange structures and ensure independence in regulatory obligations.

images.alt_text: seedlings, soil, spring flowers
The rules, with some tweaks in the final recommendations, stipulate that redemption terms must reflect how long it would take to sell assets in a fund to avoid a liquidity “mismatch”.

VCMs cover pollution-reducing projects, such as reforestation, renewable energy, biogas and solar power, that generate carbon credits companies buy to offset their emissions and meet net-zero targets.

The Iosco panel discussion at the Singapore Fintech Festival. From left are Jean-Paul Servais, chair of the Iosco Board; Lim Tuang Lee, MAS assistant MD for  capital markets and chair of the Iosco Fintech Task Force; Matthew Long, director of payments and digital assets, Financial Conduct Authority; and Valerie Szczepanik, director of FinHub at the US SEC.
FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in this illustration, August 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Clinching Upper Thomson site could cement  GuocoLand, Hong Leong hold over the area
summary: A single bid of S$780 million or S$904.60 psf ppr was submitted by a joint venture between GuocoLand and Hong Leong Holdings for the Upper Thomson Road land parcel. The bid fell short of expectations, with consultants anticipating three to five bids with prices ranging from S$1,000 to S$1,100 psf ppr. The site's low bid may be due to site-specific requirements, but winning the plot would give GuocoLand and Hong Leong a head start in the emerging area, potentially allowing them to manage sales and pricing more effectively.

images.alt_text: At 15,276.8 square metres ( sq m), the Zion Road site can house up to 1,170 residential units, including 435 serviced apartments.
Typically, investors look at wealth preservation and capital appreciation when buying shophouses, said Savills Singapore.
Landed home prices continued their surge in Q1, rising XX per cent after a 4.5 per cent increase in Q4.

site_title: Bank of Japan offers bleaker view on economy, flags upbeat wage signs
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has cut its economic assessment for most regions, but remains hopeful that wage hikes will spread to smaller firms, potentially leading to another interest rate hike. The central bank believes strong wage hikes will encourage companies to boost investment and pass on labor costs, despite recent downgrades to its assessment for seven of Japan's nine regions. The BOJ's decision marks a shift away from its focus on reflating growth, as it ends eight years of negative interest rates.

images.alt_text: The output gap is among data the BOJ watches closely in determining whether the economy is expanding strongly enough to propel a demand-driven rise in inflation.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, April 4, 2024 (Ep 36)
summary: Asian markets rose on reassuring comments from the US Federal Reserve, with gold hitting a record high of $2,304 an ounce. The US dollar index nears a four-month high, while the yen approaches a decades-low. Best World shares jumped 10.8% after proposing a selective capital reduction, contributing to the overall market gains.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 79 to 32.
Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore and Jakarta were all in the green, though there were small losses in Manila and Wellington.
Spot gold was up 0.1 per cent at US$2,300.53 per ounce.
全美世界（Best World International）总部外观。

site_title: Modi sets ambitious India economic goals for probable third term
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi has set ambitious economic goals for a probable third term, aiming to double the economy and exports to US$6.69 trillion by 2030, from around US$3.51 trillion currently. The target includes raising per capita income to US$4,418 and increasing exports to US$1.58 trillion, with plans to improve workforce skills, literacy rates, and labor force participation. However, independent economists have expressed skepticism about the feasibility of these targets, citing the need for significant reforms and investment. Modi's victory in the upcoming elections is seen as likely, with polls predicting a strong win for his Hindu nationalist party.

images.alt_text: The RBI’s inflation targeting framework has helped to keep price pressures moderate, Prime Minister Narendra Modi says.
India has now signed four FTAs in quick succession since 2021 after a gap of about nine years where no agreements were inked.
Modi has made high growth and infrastructure development his key poll plank in his last two tenures and has promised to make India a developed country by 2047.

site_title: Jefferies, Japan’s Sumitomo Mitsui expand alliance to Canada
summary: Jefferies Financial Group and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, one of Japan's largest banks, have expanded their alliance to include Canada. Jefferies will leverage its industry and M&A expertise with SMBC Group's banking and debt capital markets knowledge to support clients. This partnership is the latest expansion of their strategic alliance, which began in 2021. Jefferies has a full-service investment bank in Canada, while SMBC Group has a significant economic ownership stake in the firm, now at 15%. The two firms will work together on corporate and investment banking deals in the Canadian market.

site_title: Home prices still on the up, and the changing dynamics in rentals
summary: Singapore's housing market continues to show resilience, with home prices rising 1.5% in Q1 2024 for private homes and 1.7% for public housing. The public housing sector is experiencing a surge in demand, with first-time homebuyers and private property owners contributing to the growth. Rental market trends indicate that HDB flat rents are expected to rise 10% in 2024, while private condo rents may fall 5%. The government has introduced measures to make public housing more accessible, including a new down payment scheme for Build-To-Order flats.

images.alt_text: In the public housing sector, market forces appear to be regrouping, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: India gives more than US$1 billion incentives to private firms under manufacturing scheme
summary: India's production-linked incentive scheme (PLI) has paid out over $1.02 billion in incentives to boost local manufacturing, with over $13 billion in investments from private firms. The scheme, launched in 2020, covers 14 sectors and has drawn participation from major firms like Apple and Samsung. India has seen a significant increase in exports, reaching $48.4 billion under the PLI scheme, with mobile phone exports reaching a record $15 billion. The scheme has shown positive results, but some sectors, such as textiles and specialty steel, require further tweaks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Visitors check a Tesla Model 3 car next to a Model Y displayed at a showroom of the U.S. electric vehicle (EV) maker in Beijing, China February 4, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: Banking bottleneck causing six-month delays for Russia-China payments: sources
summary: US secondary sanctions on Russia's financial system are causing a bottleneck at VTB Bank's Shanghai branch, leading to six-month delays for Russia-China payments. Companies are seeking alternative payment routes due to the risk of US sanctions, which has left Chinese banks wary of facilitating trade with Russia. This has resulted in a significant increase in delays for Russian oil firms to receive payments for their exports. The bottleneck is attributed to the 90% of Russian banks having yuan accounts in Chinese banks, which is now becoming increasingly difficult due to US sanctions.

images.alt_text: Russia is huge in geographic terms, but its economy is tiny relative to the economies of the West, with GDP amounting to just US$2 trillion.
Despite Putin’s extraordinary skills of political longevity in the last quarter of a century, a number of key Western intelligence veterans believe he is still vulnerable to a coup.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise amid regional rally; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,235.01 points, driven by a regional rally. Gainers beat losers 226 to 174, with Sembcorp Industries leading the gainers. Investors remain cautious about the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate cuts amid strong US economic data, but analysts expect three 25-basis-point cuts this year.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 79 to 32.

site_title: ECB continues to lay groundwork for June rate cut, March accounts show
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is preparing for a potential June rate cut, as policymakers believe inflation is heading back to its 2% target. The accounts from the March 6-7 meeting show that inflation growth is easing, wage pressures are moderating, and companies are absorbing wage growth. However, policymakers are unlikely to commit to further rate cuts, instead laying groundwork for a potential easing of borrowing costs in June. The ECB aims to bring borrowing costs down from record highs, which have been maintained since the last rate cut in 2022.

images.alt_text: Consumer price growth in Eurozone slowed to 2.4 per cent in March from 2.6 per cent a month earlier, defying expectations for a steady rate as food, energy and industrial goods prices all pulled the headline figure lower.
There is not yet a consensus among those in the ECB on interest-rate cuts this year, says a policymaker at the eurozone's central bank.

The ECB has long pointed to rapid wage growth as a source of concern and says that cutting rates from record highs becomes possible once data starts showing the long-forecast moderation in wage demands.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 4)
summary: Su Wenqiang, a Chinese national with three passports, has been convicted in a money laundering case and will be deported after serving his jail term. Dennis Wee, a 71-year-old Singapore real estate icon, has died after a battle with cancer. A joint venture of City Developments Ltd placed a bid for a residential plot in Zion Road, with the price below expectations. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong attended an Asean meeting of finance ministers in Luang Prabang, Laos. Singapore stocks rose 0.4% amid a regional rally, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,235.01 points.

site_title: 14 months’ jail for money launderer Su Haijin; S$165 million forfeited to state
summary: Su Haijin, a 41-year-old former director of No Signboard, was sentenced to 14 months in jail for resisting arrest and two counts of money laundering. As part of a plea bargain, he agreed to forfeit about 90% of S$170 million in seized assets to the state. Haijin was one of 10 foreign nationals prosecuted in Singapore's largest money-laundering case.

images.alt_text: Su Wenqiang is the first of the 10 foreign nationals arrested in the anti-money laundering bust to plead guilty.
Su Haijin allegedly refused to open his room door to the authorities and exited from the second-floor balcony of a Good Class Bungalow at 16 Ewart Park (pictured).
Wang Baosen was granted Cambodian citizenship on April 6, 2020.
DBS registered four charges – generally referring to a form of security interest usually taken by a lender to secure repayment of a loan – on Aug 18, 2021, to Aiqinhai Investment.
Cash seized by the police in the S$1 billion money laundering case
Seven detached bungalows in Sentosa Cove were among 105 properties issued with prohibition of disposal orders, the police said on Aug 18.

site_title: Cheong Soo Pieng: What lies beneath
summary: The National Gallery Singapore has launched an exhibition, "Cheong Soo Pieng: Layer By Layer," which analyzes 30 artworks from the artist's 1950s to 1980s using X-ray scans and infrared photography to reveal his creative processes and material use. The exhibition, featuring some of his most famous works, highlights the artist's innovative use of South-east Asian materials and Chinese, Malay, and Western aesthetic traditions. Interactive stations invite visitors to explore the elemental composition of pigments and mediums, shedding new light on Cheong's artistic legacy.

images.alt_text: The Chamber of the Arts House became the unexpected venue for a large-scale performance installation by This Humid House.
Hock Siong & Co is one of several places to find solidly-built furniture from eras past.
3 Body Problem feature's spectacular scenes of alien-altered skies and virtual reality landscapes.

site_title: Will GE do better as three companies than as one?
summary: General Electric (GE) has split into three entities: GE Aerospace, a maker of jet engines, and GE Vernova, a manufacturer of power-generation equipment. The initial split in January 2023 created GE HealthCare, a medical-devices firm. The new companies aim to focus on their respective strengths, potentially leading to improved performance and competitiveness. The split follows a long history of GE's evolution, with its first CEO Charles Coffin describing the challenges of merging three businesses in 1893.

images.alt_text: A GE Aerospace booth at the Singapore Airshow in Feb 21, 2024. The company will invest nearly US$450 million in 22 GE Aerospace facilities across 14 states in the US and US$100 million in some of its international sites. It will invest an additional US$100 million in its US-based suppliers.
FILE PHOTO: A man walks past a Reliance Industries Limited sign board installed on a road divider in the western Indian city of Gandhinagar, January 17, 2014. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo
Good governance could have saved GE
General Electric to split into 3 companies in latest restructuring

site_title: Singapore approves lab-grown quail for consumption
summary: Singapore has approved the sale of lab-grown quail by Australian alternative protein firm Vow, following regulatory approval from the Singapore Food Agency. The company's Forged Parfait, a cultured quail product, was unveiled in a media tasting and features a rich, umami flavor with gamey undertones. Vow's co-founder, George Peppou, aims to differentiate the product from traditional meat, while the company plans to expand its operations and launch products globally, despite facing challenges in the cultivated meat industry.

site_title: Taiwan rescuers try to reach scores trapped in tunnels after quake
summary: A magnitude-7.4 earthquake struck Taiwan on Wednesday, killing 10 people and injuring over 1,000. Rescuers worked to reach those trapped in highway tunnels, with engineers beginning a massive clear-up operation. Dozens of residents spent a night outdoors due to aftershocks, and a luxury hotel and youth activity center near Taroko National Park were also affected. The government warned of landslides and rockfalls, and China condemned Taiwan's response to the quake. The US offered assistance, and operations at Taiwan's chip-making foundries were minimally affected.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) logo is seen near computer motherboard in this illustration taken January 8, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The Uranus Building in Hualien, after a major earthquake hit Taiwan's east. It's the biggest earthquake in at least 25 years.

site_title: Not just cute: 20-somethings making money from original characters
summary: Local creatives in Singapore are developing original characters, selling merchandise such as stickers, keychains, and plush toys, with a growing international customer base. The success of global characters like Hello Kitty and Rilakkuma has inspired local artists to create their own unique characters. Technology and accessibility have made it easier for them to produce and market their work, with overseas buyers becoming a significant segment of their customers. This trend is expected to continue, with original characters offering lucrative merchandising opportunities for their creators.

images.alt_text: Designer, artist and maker Genevieve Ang (left) with Clement Zheng from Interactive Materials Lab.
Seven local designers will participate in Future Impact 2, which seeks to harness the evolving and transformative power of design for a more sustainable future.

site_title: Japanese firms agreed on 5.24% wage hike, biggest union group says
summary: Japanese firms have agreed to a 5.24% wage hike, the largest union group Rengo reported. This is the third announcement of pay hikes, following 5.25% and 5.28% initial rounds. The average growth tends to decrease as smaller firms wrap up negotiations, with the next result scheduled for April 18. The wage growth is seen as crucial for Japan's exit from deflation and a pullback from monetary stimulus, with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida and Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda emphasizing its importance.

site_title: A US$290 billion ESG bond market faces EU snub in new proposal
summary: The European Union's Platform on Sustainable Finance is proposing to exclude $290 billion ESG bonds from an EU review of sustainable flows due to concerns over their environmental impact. The proposal suggests that sustainability-linked bonds (SLBs) require an in-depth assessment of their materiality and ambition, rather than green bonds, which target specific projects. This decision aims to ensure the EU's green rules are effectively implemented and to maintain the integrity of its sustainable finance framework.

images.alt_text: Judges at The Hague District Court ruled three years ago that Shell must reduce its carbon emissions by 45 per cent by 2030, as it was contributing to the “dire” effects of climate change.

site_title: BYD plans to launch first electrified pickup truck this year
summary: BYD plans to launch its first electrified pickup truck for the global market later this year, targeting Toyota's HiLux, Ford's Ranger, and Isuzu's D-Max. The mid- to full-size truck will be BYD's first "new energy" pickup and will join its broad lineup of EVs. BYD has been expanding into Asian, Australian, and South American markets, where pickups are popular, and has dominated China's EV market with a 33% market share last year. The company has not released details on the powertrain, performance specifications, or pricing.

site_title: Best places in Singapore to find vintage furniture
summary: Singapore's vintage furniture market is thriving, with several stores offering unique and authentic pieces from past eras. Journey East's annual Vintage Fair returns this weekend, featuring local vendors selling vintage bags, jewelry, toys, and collectibles. Stores like Noden, Lorgan's The Retro Store, and Hock Siong & Co are popular destinations for vintage furniture enthusiasts, with pieces from Scandinavian designers, mid-century modern, and art deco eras. The appeal of vintage furniture lies in its character, sophistication, and connection to history, making it a sought-after item for Gen Z and millennials seeking statement pieces and sustainability.

images.alt_text: Designer, artist and maker Genevieve Ang (left) with Clement Zheng from Interactive Materials Lab.
The house with its distinct, barn-like cantilever terrace.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank upgrades AEM to ‘buy’, lifts target on higher order expectations
summary: Maybank Securities upgraded AEM to 'buy' with a target price of S$2.78, citing higher order expectations due to a contract win from a major fabless provider. The brokerage raised its FY2024 profit projections by 50% and estimated revenue by 23.5% to S$505.3 million. Analysts expect AEM's performance to beat expectations, with a potential rerating of the stock upwards.

images.alt_text: AEM, which provides advanced chip testing solutions, announced a contract win from a “major fabless provider”.
Semiconductor equipment maker AEM Holdings reported a net loss of S$20.9 million for H2 2023, as the group grapples with the global tech downturn and inventory surplus.
Dyna-Mac's offshore floating production, storage and offloading (FPSO).

site_title: Airlines desperate for planes paying more for older models
summary: Airlines are facing a shortage of popular narrow-body aircraft due to production issues at Boeing, exacerbating a global shortage. The company has slowed production of its 737 Max 9 model to address quality lapses, increasing the cost of used-jet rentals. Leased aircraft, such as the 737 Max 9 and Airbus A321neo, are now commanding higher monthly rents, with prices approaching pre-pandemic levels. The shortage has forced airlines to search for alternative models, leading to a shift of planes from struggling airlines to those willing to pay a premium.

images.alt_text: Boeing has faced increased scrutiny following the loss of a door plug on an Alaska Airlines jetliner in January.
An United Airlines Airbus A319 taxis in Chicago International Airport (ORD) in Chicago, Illinois on January 18, 2024. (Photo by Daniel SLIM / AFP)
The maintenance, repair and overhaul business is set to grow by more than 19 per cent within the next decade, according to consulting firm Oliver Wyman.

site_title: March Swiss inflation lowest in two-and-a-half years
summary: Switzerland's inflation eased to its lowest level in two-and-a-half years in March, with consumer prices rising by 1% from March 2023, down from 1.2% in February. This supports the Swiss National Bank's decision to cut interest rates for the first time since 2015. The country's inflation has been shielded by a strong franc, and the SNB expects inflation to remain low over the next few years. The central bank's vice-chairman cited low inflation pressure as the reason for the rate cut, but analysts expect more rate cuts this year.

images.alt_text: For 2023 as a whole, the Swiss economy has expanded by 1.3 per cent.

site_title: US homeowners see biggest property tax rise in five years
summary: US homeowners paid an average of $4,000 in property taxes in 2023, a 6.9% increase from the previous year, with total levies reaching $363 billion. This marks the largest rise in property taxes in five years. The increase is attributed to inflationary pressures, rising public employee wages, and other expenses. The highest effective property tax rates were found in Illinois, New Jersey, Connecticut, New York, and Nebraska, with some counties seeing increases of over 31.5%.

images.alt_text: MALIBU, CALIFORNIA - FEBRUARY 05: Workers shore up Pacific Ocean coastline next to homes as a powerful long-duration atmospheric river storm, the second in less than a week, continues to impact Southern California on February 5, 2024 near Malibu, California. The storm is delivering widespread flooding, landslides and power outages while dropping heavy rain and snow across the region.   Mario Tama/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by MARIO TAMA / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Vietnam dong hovers near historic low as greenback strengthens
summary: Vietnam's Vietnamese dong has hovered near a historic low against the US dollar, driven by hawkish expectations over the US Federal Reserve's rate trajectory. The USD/VND spot rate reached a peak of 25,010 on Wednesday, with the dong depreciating by 3% since the start of the year. Analysts expect the pressure to persist due to the wide interest rate differential and recent political developments, with the State Bank of Vietnam expected to hold policy rates in 2024 while defending the dong.

images.alt_text: Trade-reliant Vietnam's exports in March surge by 14.2 per cent from a year ago to roughly US$34.01 billion.

site_title: Asean currencies hammered again as rosy data lifts US dollar further
summary: Asean currencies have plummeted, with the Vietnamese dong hitting a historic low of 25,010 against the US dollar, and the Indonesian rupiah reaching a four-year low. The decline follows positive US manufacturing data, which showed a 16-month expansion, boosting confidence in the US dollar. The US dollar index climbed 50 basis points to 105, further weakening Asean currencies.

images.alt_text: Most Malaysian business owners have felt the pinch of the rising cost due to weakening ringgit.
The Thai baht has fallen some 5 per cent against the US dollar to a range of 36 per greenback.

site_title: Eurozone business activity returned to growth in March
summary: Eurozone business activity returned to growth in March, with the composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 50.3 from 49.2 in February. The services sector, which accounts for the majority of the eurozone's economy, showed a stronger-than-expected upturn, while manufacturing activity declined. The recovery is seen as a positive sign, with optimism about the year ahead increasing. The future output index jumped to 61.8, its highest level in over two years, driven by wage growth outpacing inflation.

site_title: Indonesia’s Prabowo pledges fiscal prudence, eyes broader coalition
summary: Indonesia's president-elect Prabowo Subianto has pledged fiscal prudence, vowing to keep public debt below 60% of GDP and annual budget deficits at 3% of GDP. Chairman of Golkar party Airlangga Hartarto, who is also chief economics minister, emphasized the need to follow laws and manage the macroprudential side. The government has set a fiscal gap of 2.48-2.8% of GDP for next year, with this year's deficit expected to be 2.8% of GDP. Prabowo's coalition won 48% of seats in parliament, and he is planning to broaden his coalition, potentially reaching 60% control, if necessary.

images.alt_text: During their meeting on Wednesday, Kishida (R) “stated that Japan attached great importance to cooperation with Indonesia in maintaining and strengthening the free and open international order based on the rule of law”.
Chinese President Xi Jinping and Indonesia's President-elect Prabowo Subianto shake hands at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China April 1, 2024.
China becomes the first foreign nation Prabowo has visited as president-elect, ahead of Indonesia’s neighbours in the region

site_title: Important to understand motivations for choosing a career in real estate: SEAA
summary: Real estate salespersons in Singapore are motivated to choose a career in the industry for reasons beyond commission incentives, including wanting a more fulfilling job, providing value-added services to clients, and transforming lives. Starting a career in real estate is relatively affordable, with costs ranging from $2,000 to $10,000. However, the industry requires skills such as in-depth knowledge, communication, marketing, and problem-solving. The Singapore Estate Agents Association (SEAA) aims to support its members through training programs and technological tools, and remains confident in the long-term prospects of the real estate sector.

images.alt_text: Close to a third of the respondents who took part in the survey felt that there is an oversupply of property agents in the market.

site_title: BNP Paribas to cut space in Keppel Reit’s Singapore tower as high rents bite
summary: BNP Paribas is set to give up space in a prime office tower in Singapore's Central Business District (CBD) due to rising commercial rent. The bank, which currently occupies six floors at Ocean Financial Centre, plans to not renew some space when the lease expires at the end of the year, moving at least 300 staff to a business park in the south. This move aims to curb costs as companies seek to control expenses amid the city-state's rising commercial rents, which reached a 15-year high in Q1.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo on a BNP Paribas bank branch in Paris, France, February 9, 2022. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo
BNP Paribas intends to generate the additional savings this year, increasing its cumulated savings goal over the 2022-to-2025 period to 2.7 billion euros.

site_title: 📢 Should resignations be a noisy affair?
summary: The "Quit-Tok" trend, where employees record their resignation experiences live on camera, aims to promote authenticity and transparency in the workplace. While it has good intentions, it can also have negative implications, such as affecting job prospects and creating a bad digital footprint. Experts warn that Quit-Toks should be executed with caution, as a petty or immature tone can damage one's professional reputation. Instead, it's recommended to focus on providing constructive feedback during exit interviews and maintaining respect for colleagues and leaders.

images.alt_text: An exit interview is fundamentally a tricky conversation that you’re going to have with your soon-to-be ex-employer.

site_title: BlackBerry reports surprise profit on demand for cybersecurity services
summary: BlackBerry reported a surprise profit for its fourth quarter, driven by higher demand for its cybersecurity services amid growing online crimes and high-profile hacks. The company earned an adjusted net profit of 3 US cents per share, beating analysts' average estimate of a loss. Quarterly revenue rose to US$173 million, with cybersecurity revenue increasing 5% and IoT revenue jumping 25%. BlackBerry expects first-quarter revenue of US$130-138 million and full-year revenue of US$586-616 million.

images.alt_text: Blackberry in December scrapped its IPO plans for its Internet of Things (IoT) business, but still expects to split the IoT and cybersecurity businesses into fully standalone divisions.

site_title: Money laundering convict Su Wenqiang to be deported to where his passport allows him to travel
summary: Su Wenqiang, a Chinese national and convicted money launderer, will be deported to a country where his valid passport allows him to travel after serving his 13-month jail term. The exact location of deportation depends on his passport's admissibility, with the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) stating that foreigners convicted of offenses in Singapore will typically be repatriated to their country of citizenship.

images.alt_text: Su Wenqiang is the first of the 10 foreign nationals arrested in the anti-money laundering bust to plead guilty.

Su Haijin faces one charge of unlawfully evading arrest and another charge of money laundering.

site_title: Indonesia’s 2024 fiscal deficit will not exceed 2.8% of GDP: minister
summary: Indonesia's Economic Affairs Minister Airlangga Hartarto has stated that the country's 2024 fiscal deficit will not exceed 2.8% of GDP, slightly above the previous estimate of 2.29%. The increase is attributed to rising social assistance and fertilizer subsidies, which will boost spending in the food and agriculture sectors. The actual deficit may be between 2.6% and 2.7% of GDP.
