Profile of Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs of Indonesia, Airlangga Hartarto during the Indonesia- Singapore Business themed- Forum 2024 Beyond the Ballot: Shaping the Future of Business and Investment in Indonesia held at the Hilton Orchard Hotel on March 27, 2024.

site_title: Rakuten boosts junk bond sale to US$2 billion with juicy yield
summary: Rakuten Group raised its junk bond sale to $2 billion, attracting investors with a 9.875% yield, significantly higher than comparable bonds. The company's debt insurance costs fell, and shares rose 0.4% as investors responded positively to the sale. The bond proceeds will be used to redeem or repurchase Rakuten's senior notes due in 2024 or later. The move is seen as a positive sign for the company's credit risk, with its shares extending gains to 37% this year.

images.alt_text: Rakuten has been tapping financial markets this year to raise fresh funds to pay down its obligations.
Rakuten Group and Rakuten Bank entered into a memorandum of understanding on the re-organisation, which is set to take effect in October, the companies said in statements.
Rakuten Bank has been enjoying growth in its customer base thanks to the group’s reward point system designed to lock in users.

site_title: Volvo Cars posts record March sales
summary: Volvo Cars reported a record-breaking 78,970 car sales in March, up 25% from the previous year, with fully electric cars accounting for 23% of global sales, a 43% increase. The company's majority owner, Geely Holding, a Chinese conglomerate, saw its electric car sales rise significantly. Volvo's shares rose 4% in early trading following the announcement.

site_title: A multisensory journey through time with Grand Seiko
summary: Grand Seiko recently hosted its "Alive in Time through the Five Senses" event, a four-day private exhibition in Singapore, where 150 guests experienced the brand's heritage, innovation, and craftsmanship through a multisensory journey. The event featured interactive sections, including Sight, Sound, Touch, Taste, and Smell, where guests could engage with Grand Seiko's three core movements, mechanical complications, and exquisite timepieces. The event marked Grand Seiko's first large-scale exhibition in the region, with managing director Ida Idris-Low stating it embodies the brand's commitment to inspire and lead in luxury watchmaking.

images.alt_text: The Grand Seiko Spring Drive GMT SBGE295 is inspired by Mount Hotaka.

site_title: Chinese IVF specialist expands into South-east Asia with investment in Indonesia
summary: Chinese IVF specialist Jinxin Fertility has signed an equity investment deal to become a significant shareholder of PT Morula Indonesia, expanding into South-east Asia. The move comes as demand for IVF services declines in China due to a low birth rate, with 9.02 million babies born on the mainland in 2023. The investment will also leverage expertise in assisted reproduction to explore business opportunities in other South-east Asian countries.

images.alt_text: Together with other better-than-expected manufacturing surveys, the data add to evidence that parts of China’s economy are gaining momentum in the first quarter.
The net FDI reflects monetary flows into and out of the mainland connected to overseas-owned entities and used for investment in assets such as manufacturing and real estate.

The market downturn spells trouble for many IPO hopefuls, creating a rift between them and their PE/VC investors that is increasingly leading to arbitration or litigation when companies fail to follow an agreed timetable to go public and allow funds to exit.
The loosely regulated exchanges had been set up over the years by local state-owned enterprises and were initially designed for local financial asset transactions.

site_title: Philippines lowers growth target for 2024, raises deficit ceilings
summary: The Philippines has lowered its economic growth target for 2024 to 6-7% from a previous projection of 6.5-7.5%, citing high inflation and a potential slowdown in the global economy. The country's growth range for 2026-2028 remains unchanged at 6.5-8%. The government has also raised its budget deficit ceilings for 2024-2028 to allow for greater flexibility to fund infrastructure projects, with a planned 7.5% increase in the national budget for 2025.

images.alt_text: President Ferdinand Marcos Jr vows to implement countermeasures against “illegal, coercive, aggressive and dangerous attacks” by China’s coastguard.

The Philippines faced the most severe inflation and the most aggressive monetary tightening cycle among all Asean members in 2023. However, the country emerged as Southeast Asia’s fastest-growing economy with a growth rate of 5.6 per cent.

site_title: Sanofi to settle 4,000 Zantac cancer lawsuits in US state courts
summary: Sanofi has reached an agreement in principle to settle approximately 4,000 US lawsuits linking the discontinued heartburn drug Zantac to cancer. The settlement, which still needs to be finalized, will resolve most of the lawsuits against Sanofi in US state courts, except for those in Delaware where around 70,000 cases are pending. Sanofi did not admit liability and is settling to avoid ongoing litigation costs. The company still faces about 20,000 lawsuits in Delaware state court.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of French drugmaker Sanofi is seen a the Sanofi Genzyme Polyclonals in Lyon, France, September 30, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo

site_title: Thai central bank seen cutting rates by 50 bps this year, bond market association says
summary: The Bank of Thailand is expected to cut interest rates by 50 basis points this year, starting from June, according to the Thai Bond Market Association. The central bank has resisted government pressure to ease policy, maintaining the key interest rate at 2.50% since February. The economy, which unexpectedly shrank 0.6% in the final quarter of 2023, is expected to grow at 2.5-3% this year, lower than the 2.5% growth in 2022.

site_title: Asia: Markets lifted by US data and fresh rate cut hopes
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday, driven by US data showing signs of easing inflation and Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell's comments on rate cuts this year. Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, and Jakarta saw gains, while Manila and Wellington experienced small losses. The equities rally, which started in 2023, has stuttered in recent weeks due to concerns about the economy being too strong and inflation being too sticky. However, Powell's comments suggest that the Fed may still cut interest rates this year, boosting market confidence.

images.alt_text: Tokyo sank around one per cent, while Sydney and Seoul were off more. Hong Kong, Shanghai, Singapore, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta were also well in the red.

site_title: ExxonMobil signals weaker oil and gas prices to hit first-quarter profit
summary: ExxonMobil reported a 41% drop in first-quarter operating profit to $6.7 billion, primarily due to weak natural gas prices and fuel derivatives. The company's profits were down $4.9 billion from the same quarter last year, with oil and gas prices alone cutting profits by $600 million. Fuel derivatives costs also increased, costing $1.1 billion compared to the fourth quarter. Despite the decline, ExxonMobil's shares rose 16.2% during the quarter.

images.alt_text: ExxonMobil is developing what is expected to be the world’s largest low-carbon hydrogen production plant at its Baytown Complex east of Houston in Texas.
ExxonMobil’s pay model is moving closer to that employed by the broader industry, which typically pays traders large bonuses tied to profit, and lower base salaries.

site_title: Google considers fees for AI-fuelled search features: FT
summary: Google is considering charging for premium AI-fueled search features, marking the first time it would put a core product behind a paywall. The tech giant is developing the technology but has not decided whether or when to launch it, with ads remaining alongside search results even for subscribers. The move aims to generate additional revenue without cannibalizing its core search ad business, following the success of OpenAI's subscription-based service, ChatGPT.

images.alt_text: Google’s agreement to retroactively delete user information is a significant concession as it forms the backbone of the company’s lucrative advertising business.
EU industry chief Thierry Breton says the investigations should not be a surprise.
Apple and Google have not decided on the terms of an AI agreement or finalised how it would be implemented.

site_title: How Hertz’s bet on Teslas went horribly sideways
summary: Hertz Global Holdings, a struggling rental-car company, underwent a significant turnaround under new owners Tom Wagner and Greg O'Hara, who purchased the company in a June 2021 bankruptcy auction for $1.3 billion. The new owners bet on electric vehicles (EVs), ordering 100,000 Teslas and partnering with Uber to supply EVs. However, the massive bet on electrification has proven disastrous, with Tesla prices plummeting and the value of Hertz's EVs declining. The company's stock has fallen 74% since the IPO, and its CEO, Stephen Scherr, has stepped down. Hertz is now doubling down on gas-guzzling cars, with its sixth CEO in 10 years, Gil West, taking the helm.

images.alt_text: Hertz’s CEO to step down as car renter unwinds bet on EVs
Hertz plans to use some of the money raised by selling off EVs to buy petrol-powered vehicles.

site_title: OCBC, UOB should privatise listed insurance arms Great Eastern and United Overseas Insurance
summary: Singapore-listed insurance groups Great Eastern Holdings and United Overseas Insurance could benefit from privatization by their banking parents, OCBC and UOB. The groups' depressed share prices and lack of liquidity may make privatization an attractive option. By taking over the insurance arms, OCBC and UOB can offer minority shareholders a premium price and superior dividend yields. Privatization would also allow the groups to focus on their businesses without the costs associated with maintaining a separate listing.

images.alt_text: The Great Eastern logo on the facade of Great Eastern Centre located at Pickering Street on 4 Dec 2019.
GEH says its management is "aware that while GEH shares currently trade above its NAV, they trade below its estimated (embedded value) as at end-2023".

site_title: Beijing nudged Syngenta to withdraw 65 billion yuan Shanghai IPO on market weakness: sources
summary: China's securities regulator prompted Swiss agrichemicals and seeds group Syngenta to withdraw its $9 billion IPO in Shanghai due to market weakness concerns. The listing, which would have been China's largest and one of the world's biggest flotations this year, was withdrawn after Syngenta received informal instructions to pull its bid. The decision reflects Beijing's priority on boosting investor confidence in the secondary market over the launch of new equity offerings, and follows a sharp tightening of scrutiny on IPOs this year.

images.alt_text: Syngenta's products are important building blocks for improving the quality and quantity of China’s agricultural production.

site_title: Paramount in exclusive merger talks with Skydance: reports
summary: Paramount Global has entered exclusive merger talks with Skydance, bypassing a proposed $26 billion takeover offer from Apollo. The negotiations, which include unnamed sources, mean Paramount will not consider other potential acquirers for 30 days. In response, Paramount shares surged 15% on Wednesday. The move aims for a transaction to be acquired by Skydance, according to The Wall Street Journal.

images.alt_text: Paramount Pictures has attracted interest from many suitors over the years.
Paramount Nickelodeon and other networks, has been looking to reduce its debt by selling noncore assets such as its Simon & Schuster book publishing arm.
Paramount, the parent of CBS, MTV and other networks, has been selling assets, such as its Simon & Schuster book publishing arm, to reduce debt.

site_title: Gold prices touch record high after Powell’s comments
summary: Gold prices reached a record high of $2,302.29 per ounce after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that recent job gains and inflation readings do not significantly alter the central bank's monetary strategy. This led to a 0.1% increase in spot gold to $2,300.53 per ounce. Traders are pricing in a 62% probability of the Fed cutting interest rates in June, which may reduce the opportunity cost of holding bullion.

images.alt_text: Spot gold edged 0.2 per cent higher to US$2,283.47 per ounce.

site_title: Chinese cargo owners may face huge bill after Baltimore bridge collision
summary: Chinese cargo owners may face significant financial risks after a container ship, Dali, collided with a Baltimore bridge, causing severe disruptions to post operations. The accident could lead to a "general average" declaration, where cargo owners, including Chinese owners, proportionately share losses. This means many Chinese cargo owners may have to pay out of pocket for the accident, which could take weeks to a month to clear the waterway. The incident highlights the financial risks involved in international shipping.

images.alt_text: Wreckage from the collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge resting on the cargo ship Dali in Baltimore, Maryland. The global supply chain impact of the bridge disaster may be limited but this is nevertheless a catastrophic event.

The collapse of the Francis Scott Key bridge in the US city of Baltimore on Mar 26 that left six workers dead could involve “sizeable” compensation, given the extent of the damage to the infrastructure, its surrounding area and any loss of life, experts have said.

Demolition crews cut the top portion of the north side of the collapsed Francis Scott Key bridge into smaller sections for safe removal by crane in the Patapsco River, in Baltimore, Maryland, March 30, 2024.
Wreckage from the Francis Scott Key Bridge will be lifted away and processed at a Baltimore shipping site before being taken to a disposal site.

site_title: Levi Strauss raises profit forecast on cost saving initiatives, fewer discounts
summary: Levi Strauss raised its annual profit forecast by 8% after cost-cutting measures, including job cuts and reduced discounts, helped the company recover 13% this year. The apparel maker reported a 26 cents per share adjusted profit in the first quarter, beating expectations, and plans to focus on top-selling items and expand its direct-to-consumer business. However, sales through wholesale channels fell 19% on a constant-currency basis, and the company expects full-year revenue to grow 1-3%.

images.alt_text: Levi will continue to sell other products at the retailer.
Gloomy consumer spending has hit retailers such as Macy’s and Nordstrom as high prices and borrowing rates squeeze budgets, denting demand for Levi’s denims bottoms, tops and cargo pants.

site_title: Australia apartment permits hit 12-year low due to cost blowouts
summary: Australia's apartment permits dropped to a 12-year low in February, with private sector dwellings excluding houses plummeting 24.9% to 3,771. Total building approvals slid 1.9% in February, with 12,520 dwellings approved, nearly half the March 2021 peak. The government has pledged to build 1.2 million new homes between July this year and mid-2029 to meet demand. Experts say annual approvals need to reach 400,000 by 2027 to meet the target, highlighting capacity constraints and rising costs due to labor and material shortages.

images.alt_text: Poor productivity growth has boosted unit labour costs which is putting upward pressure on inflation at a time.
China's tariffs on Australian wine, some of them as high as 218 per cent, will be lifted over the course of Friday.
Seven sold-out Taylor Swift shows in Sydney and Melbourne led to increased spending on clothing, merchandise, accessories and dining out.

site_title: Singapore real estate icon Dennis Wee dies at 71
summary: Dennis Wee, a renowned Singapore real estate icon, died at 71 after a battle with cancer. Wee, known for his colourful personality and entrepreneurial spirit, built his own business and was remembered by family and friends as a humorous and vibrant individual. His daughter Daphne Wee announced his passing in an Instagram post, stating he passed away peacefully surrounded by loved ones.

images.alt_text: PropNex now Singapore's largest property agency
Dennis Wee Realty hit with record S$66,000 fine

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Thursday’s open; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.5% at the opening bell on Thursday, driven by a gainers-to-losers ratio of 79 to 32. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 15.47 points to 3,238.13, with banking stocks such as DBS, OCBC, and UOB advancing. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index and pan-European Stoxx 600 also rose, following mixed overnight results in US and European markets, amid concerns over interest rate cuts and trade tensions.

images.alt_text: Cromwell E-Reit divests an office asset in Poland for 15.9 million euros (S$23.1 million).

site_title:
Hot stock: Best World jumps 10.8% after exit offer at 
S$2.50 per share via selective capital reduction
summary: Best World's shares jumped 10.8% after the company proposed a selective capital reduction to privatize the business via an offer of S$2.50 per share. The offer, which represents a premium of 42.9% over the last traded price, aims to provide flexibility to focus on longer-term strategies. Approximately 150.1 million shares will be cancelled, reducing the company's shares by 34.9%. The company will use retained earnings to finance the S$375.4 million cash distribution to eligible shareholders.

images.alt_text: Best World says it will take no further action relating to the Mar 21 requisition letter.
Semaglutide, developed by Novo Nordisk, is the active ingredient in Ozempic as well as the Danish firm’s powerful weight-loss drug Wegovy.
The reasons for the high demand for workers – an ageing workforce, lack of skilled labour and companies hoarding staff – are holding firm even as economies start to slow.

site_title: RBA sees small firms as key to Australia productivity turnaround
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) believes small firms are key to boosting Australia's productivity and turning around the country's economic performance. Productivity growth has been lagging for decades, leading to high unit labour costs and inflation. Small businesses are spending more on research and development, and large firms are increasingly looking to acquire and scale up innovative ideas from smaller firms. This trend could place a greater emphasis on the SME sector as a driver of innovation in Australia.

images.alt_text: The RBA’s implementation of monetary policy is an area of confusion for professional economists, commentators and educators alike, particularly following the pandemic.
China's tariffs on Australian wine, some of them as high as 218 per cent, will be lifted over the course of Friday.

site_title: DPM Wong visits Luang Prabang for  Asean meeting of finance ministers
summary: DPM Lawrence Wong attended a two-day Asean finance ministers' meeting in Luang Prabang, Laos, focusing on enhancing monetary and financial cooperation and integration. The meeting aimed to implement the Asean Economic Community Blueprint 2025 and deepen economic ties among member states. Wong discussed the state of global and regional economies with counterparts, including Vietnam's Minister of Finance Ho Duc Phoc and Malaysia's Second Finance Minister Amir Hamzah Azizan. The meeting concluded on April 5, with Wong accompanied by officials from the Ministry of Finance and Monetary Authority of Singapore.

images.alt_text: Street vendors sell their wears in front of an ATM in Vientiane, Laos. The IMF estimates the country's public debt to be 122 per cent of GDP in 2023.

Laos Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs Saleumxay Kommasith (left) shares about the country’s plans for its upcoming Asean chairmanship year, and participated in a question-and-answer segment moderated by Choi Shing Kwok, director and chief executive officer of Iseas-Yusof Ishak Institute.

site_title: Tokopedia, TikTok Shop complete backend integration
summary: TikTok Shop and Tokopedia have completed the integration of their systems as part of a merger, resulting in the Shop | Tokopedia brand. The integration, completed on March 27, allows for seamless e-commerce activities, including payments and transactions, on Tokopedia's electronic systems. Social media accounts have also been separated from e-commerce accounts, with users able to choose their privacy settings.

images.alt_text: TikTok is requiring that US entities registered by sellers be 51 per cent US owned and chaired by an US passport holder.
Indonesian tech company GoTo is preparing to launch a BNPL product with social media platform TikTok.
GoTo Financial wants to be the preferred partner of TikTok Shop in Indonesia.

site_title: Singapore’s region-lagging bonds face little near-term relief
summary: Singapore's region-lagging bonds face little near-term relief, according to a Bloomberg report. The debt has lost over 4% in US dollar terms this year, and an upcoming policy review by the Monetary Authority of Singapore is unlikely to provide significant relief due to sticky inflation and solid economic data. The US Federal Reserve's expected rate cuts are also unlikely to boost Singaporean yields, as local yields tend to follow US Treasury yields. Experts expect two to three Fed rate cuts in 2024, which may not translate to significant changes in Singaporean bond yields.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the Monetary Authority of Singapore's headquarters in Singapore June 28, 2017. Picture taken June 28, 2017. REUTERS/Darren Whiteside/File Photo

site_title: Stocks to watch: Cromwell E-Reit, Best World, OCBC
summary: Cromwell E-Reit divested a non-core office property in Poland for 15.9 million euros (S$23.1 million). Best World International proposed to cancel 150.1 million shares for S$2.50 in cash each. OCBC confirmed it is exploring the redevelopment of its Chulia Street property. Units of Cromwell E-Reit and Best World International closed down 0.7% and 2.2% respectively, while OCBC's counter closed 0.3% lower. The announcements were made on Thursday, April 4, 2024.

site_title: BIS and seven central banks to test tokenisation of cross-border payments
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) and seven central banks, including the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, will test tokenization to increase the speed and integrity of international payments. The project, called Project Agora, aims to overcome difficulties in cross-border payments due to different legal, regulatory, and technical requirements. By combining messaging and settlement aspects in one transaction, tokenization has the advantage of recording assets on a blockchain. The BIS and participating central banks will explore a unified, programmable platform to improve cross-border payments.

site_title: SK Hynix plans to spend US$4 billion on first US chip plant
summary: SK Hynix plans to invest US$3.87 billion in its first US chip plant in West Lafayette, Indiana, marking a significant step for the Biden administration's efforts to increase semiconductor output on American soil. The plant will focus on next-generation high-bandwidth memory chips for AI systems, with mass production expected to begin in 2028. This investment is part of SK Hynix's US$15 billion commitment to build chip facilities and research programs in the US, following a 2022 announcement.

images.alt_text: HBM chips are advanced memory chips in high demand for use in the GPUs produced by Nvidia and others that process vast amounts of data in generative AI.
The new type of chip – called the HBM3E – is a focal point of intense competition.
The demand for high bandwidth memory chips has boomed with the growing popularity of generative AI.
Stacking chips to derive greater performance has long been  Lee Kang-wook’s passion.

site_title: Cordlife to table all but one of TransGlobal’s proposed resolutions at next general meeting
summary: Cordlife Group will table proposed resolutions from its controlling shareholder TransGlobal Real Estate Group at its upcoming annual general meeting, except for one resolution that seeks to remove Shally Chen as a non-independent director due to discrepancies in her name. Chen's name is listed as "Xiaoling Chen" on LinkedIn, but "Chen Xuanli" in TransGlobal's notice. Cordlife will not table TransGlobal's first resolution, which proposes to reject seven ordinary resolutions from Nanjing Xinjiekou Department Store, as it would be in breach of the Companies Act.

images.alt_text: TransGlobal’s Mar 26 letter marks the third requisition notice received by Cordlife.

Cordlife is at the centre of a shareholder dispute, with separate requisition letters to remove directors from its board by Phillip Securities – acting as a nominee for Nanjing Xinjiekou – and TransGlobal.
Cordlife is serving a six-month suspension from collecting, testing, processing and/or storing new cord blood and human tissue.
The arrests of Cordlife's directors and group chief executive are related to alleged breaches-of-disclosure obligations regarding irregular temperatures in its storage tanks.
Cordlife says it will consider the possibility of appointing new independent directors to “serve as additional checks and balances”.

site_title: US: Stocks little changed after mixed data as Disney falls
summary: US stocks remained little changed on Wednesday after mixed economic data, with a buoyant first quarter in the market. A survey showed slowing growth in the services sector, while payroll firm ADP reported stronger-than-expected hiring in March. Disney fell after winning a high-profile proxy fight. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell cautioned against lowering interest rates too soon, keeping the door open for potential cuts later in the year.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JANUARY 19: Traders and media work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on January 19, 2024 in New York City. Stocks closed up over 350 points while the S&P 500 closed at an all-time high on Friday.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Oil settles at five-month high; gains capped by jump in US crude stocks
summary: Oil prices settled at a five-month high on Wednesday, with Brent futures rising 43 US cents to $89.35 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate futures gaining 28 US cents to $85.43 a barrel. The increase was driven by concerns over supply disruptions from worsening geopolitical tensions, particularly in Ukraine and the Middle East. However, a jump in US crude oil inventories eased some concerns, and technical indicators signaled the market was overbought. Analysts expect oil prices to remain high due to market fundamentals pointing upwards, despite a cautious approach from the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: Oil has rallied this year, driven by tighter supply, attacks on Russian energy infrastructure and war in the Middle East.
Brent futures for June delivery settled up US$1.50, or 1.7 per cent, at US$88.92 after touching a peak of US$89.08.

site_title: Opec+ ministers keep oil output policy steady
summary: Opec+ ministers have kept oil output policy steady, with the group's oil output remaining unchanged despite a rally in prices to nearly $90 a barrel, the highest in five months. The decision comes after the group's Joint Ministerial Monitoring Committee reviewed market trends and member compliance with output cuts. Opec+ members, led by Saudi Arabia and Russia, agreed to extend voluntary output cuts of 2.2 million barrels per day until the end of June to support the market. The group also urged countries to boost compliance with output cuts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A 3D-printed oil pump jack is seen in front of displayed OPEC logo in this illustration picture, April 14, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo
Brent futures for June delivery settled at US$87.42 a barrel on Monday, up about 42 cents, or 0.5 per cent, from the April 28 settlement price for the June contract.
US oil exports have set five new monthly records since Western nations began imposing sanctions on Russia in 2022.
Brent crude futures for May settled at US$87.48 a barrel, its highest level since Oct 27, after gaining US$1.39, or 1.6 per cent.
Brent crude futures for May shed 16 cents, or 0.2 per cent, to settle at US$86.09 a barrel while the more actively traded June contract was down 22 cents to US$85.41.

site_title: To boost trading liquidity, waive commissions and fees on trading of structured warrants
summary: A Singapore investor suggests waiving commissions and fees on trading structured warrants to boost trading liquidity and valuation of SGX stocks, citing a 2005 incident where a pricing error in a structured warrant led to a 13% decline in underlying shares. The investor notes that the number of structured warrants on SGX stocks has declined since the STI peaked 16 years ago. If implemented, waiving fees on structured warrants could recover lost commissions from underlying shares, and is considered a low-hanging fruit while longer-term measures are studied.

images.alt_text: October’s securities daily average value climbed 4 per cent on the month to S$897 million, in contrast to declines across Southeast Asian markets
The Singapore Exchange (SGX).

site_title: Samsung profit likely biggest in six quarters on higher chip prices
summary: Samsung Electronics is expected to post a nearly nine-fold increase in first-quarter profit, reaching 5.7 trillion won (S$5.7 billion), its highest since the third quarter of 2022. The profit boost is attributed to rebounding semiconductor prices, particularly for memory chips, which have risen 20-28% due to strong demand for AI-enabled devices. Samsung's chip division is expected to report its first quarterly profit in five quarters, while its mobile business likely reported an operating profit of around 3.8 trillion won.

images.alt_text: Key Samsung rival SK Hynix is already supplying Nvidia with the latest version of high-bandwidth memory, HBM3E.
The Toronto-headquartered startup helps its 775 healthcare-provider clients exchange images covering some 1.5 million patients, aiming to cut down on delays and costs.
The pending announcement only represents a preliminary agreement that could still change, and no final decision has been made.

site_title: DJT: Will common cause trump common stock?
summary: Donald Trump's media firm, Trump Media & Technology Group (TMTG), began trading as a public company under the ticker symbol "DJT" on April 26, 2024. Despite initial euphoria, the stock has faced a sell-down after disclosing losses and "greater risks" associated with Trump's involvement. Despite this, Trump supporters may provide a price floor to the stock, as a piece of DJT is seen as a piece of the man himself. The listing could allow Trump to monetize his identity without campaign finance restrictions and potentially pay off mounting legal bills, but the stock's value could be volatile due to Trump's history of controversy and potential for impeachment or lawsuits.

images.alt_text: Trump Media & Technology Group posted a net loss of US$58.2 million in the year ended December 2023, compared with a net profit of US$50.5 million a year earlier.

Trump Media & Technology Group, which generated less than US$4 million in revenue for the first nine months of last year, was worth US$8.4 billion on Thursday, bringing — on paper — a massive windfall to its largest shareholder: Donald Trump himself.

site_title: Drugmaker seeks approval for China’s first biosimilar Ozempic
summary: Hangzhou Jiuyuan Gene Engineering, a Chinese drugmaker, has applied for approval to sell its biosimilar version of Novo Nordisk's diabetes drug Ozempic, Jiyoutai, in China. The injectible drug has a structure similar to Ozempic but is not identical, and its approval would make it China's first locally developed biosimilar semaglutide drug. The move comes as demand for semaglutide, the active ingredient in Ozempic, surges globally, and Novo Nordisk faces patent expiration in China in 2026.

images.alt_text: Ozempic, made by Novo Nordisk, is a huge boon to the Danish economy.
FILE PHOTO: Flags with the Novo Nordisk logo flutter outside their Danish company's offices in Copenhagen, Denmark, September 26, 2023. REUTERS/Tom Little/File Photo

site_title: Tesla to scout sites in India for US$2 billion-US$3 billion EV factory
summary: Tesla plans to scout sites in India for a proposed $2 billion to $3 billion electric car plant, as the company seeks to expand its presence in the growing Indian market. The move comes amid slowing EV demand in the US and China, and follows Tesla's interest in building a factory to produce an EV priced at $24,000. Tesla officials have been in talks with government officials, including a meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi in June, and the company has been exploring ways to lower taxes on more expensive models.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Visitors check a Tesla Model 3 car next to a Model Y displayed at a showroom of the U.S. electric vehicle (EV) maker in Beijing, China February 4, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: Boeing 737 output drops on quality checks, more FAA audits: sources
summary: Boeing 737 production has dropped sharply in recent weeks due to increased scrutiny from the FAA and quality checks. The FAA has imposed a cap of 38 jets a month, but Boeing's monthly output has fluctuated below this level, with production falling as low as single digits in late March. The production slowdown is expected to ripple through the airline industry, with carriers shaving flights from their schedule or extending existing jet leases. Boeing's European rival, Airbus, has extended its lead in the market for single-aisle jets, and engine maker CFM International faces potential repercussions from the prolonged output slump.

images.alt_text: An United Airlines Airbus A319 taxis in Chicago International Airport (ORD) in Chicago, Illinois on January 18, 2024. (Photo by Daniel SLIM / AFP)
Dave Calhoun, CEO of Boeing, has been under pressure ever since the Jan 5 incident, when a door plug ripped off an Alaska Airlines flight about 16,000 feet above the ground.
Boeing is seeking a preliminary injunction requiring Virgin Galactic to destroy, or at least sequester, all copies of the documents as well as any work derived from the proprietary information.
Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun (above) supports the meetings with major airline chiefs but will not attend, a company official said.

site_title: Ten years after MH370, Malaysia Airlines seeks to shed troubled past
summary: Malaysia Airlines aims to shed its troubled past after posting its first net profit in over a decade. CEO Izham Ismail seeks to prove that the airline's consecutive years of operating profit were not a fluke, and plans to transform it into a premium carrier by the end of the decade. The airline has undergone five turnaround programmes since the 1997 Asian financial crisis and has a cash reserve of RM5 billion. Izham aims to increase frequency of flights to Australia and expand its international market revenue share to 85% from 55% since 2021.

images.alt_text: Malaysia Airlines carried 14.5 million passengers in 2023, up 46 per cent from a year earlier.
The disappearance of MH370, even a decade on, is described as one of the world's greatest aviation mysteries.

Visitors look at the wreckage of an aircraft believed to be from the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 during a remembrance event marking the 10th anniversary of its disappearance, Subang Jaya, Malaysia, March 3, 2024.

site_title: Russian revisionism and the sources of Western weakness
summary: Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine marked a new geopolitical epoch, violating post-Cold War agreements on trade and investment. Despite its tiny economy ($2 trillion) compared to the West's ($60 trillion), Russia benefits from trade and investment links with Europe and other industrial democracies. Western economic sanctions have failed to stop Russia's aggression due to dependence on oil, unwillingness to confront China, and moral poverty among business leaders. The West must lower the oil-price cap, put greater pressure on China, and tighten sanctions to effectively counter Russia's efforts to revise the post-Cold War order.

images.alt_text: The Lukoil oil refinery in Volgograd, Russia. High oil prices enable Vladimir Putin to test Western democracies’ resolve to reduce Russian oil revenues, and the dysfunction on Capitol Hill plays into his hands.
Demonstrators in Warsaw demanding more restrictive sanctions against Russia and arms supplies for Ukraine, on Jan 8, 2024.
Putin’s Silk Road around sanctions

site_title: Apple explores home robotics as potential ‘next big thing’ after car fizzles
summary: Apple is exploring personal robotics as its next big thing, following the cancellation of its electric vehicle project. The company has teams investigating a mobile robot that can follow users around their homes and a table-top device that uses robotics to move a display around. This move aims to find new sources of revenue as the company's push into mixed-reality goggles is expected to take years to become profitable. The effort is still in its early stages, and it's unclear if the products will be released.

images.alt_text: The AI craze has meant big gains in companies such as Nvidia, as investors see the sector at a crucial point of growth.
Apple is expected to unveil its next major software updates for the iPhone, iPad, Mac, Vision Pro headset and smartwatch.

site_title: Crayon Data handles data with art
summary: Crayon Data, a Singapore-India dual-shored data analytics startup, has achieved significant growth and recognition since its inception in 2012. The company's flagship software platform, maya.ai, uses patented algorithms and machine learning to generate insights from consumer data, serving five main industry verticals. Crayon Data has doubled its revenue to US$11 million in 2021 and has become an Enterprise 50 Award winner in Singapore and India. The company prioritizes customer longevity, has a 100% customer retention rate, and aims to expand in the Middle East and Africa, while diversifying into other sectors and embracing a flat organizational structure.

images.alt_text: The management of Hisaka (Singapore) pose with awards that the company has won. (L-R) Director of finance and IT Jessica Ong; director of office and administration Joanna Tan; managing director Anthony Cheng; director of business strategy Jackie Cheng; and director of operations Andy Yong.
Business Edge founder and chief executive officer John Koh (holding award) with direction of operations Joel Koh (fifth from right) and other team members at the Enterprise 50 Awards.

site_title: US service sector expands moderately in March; price pressures easing
summary: The US service sector expanded moderately in March, with a non-manufacturing PMI index of 51.4, down from 52.6 in February. This indicates a slowdown in growth, following 525 basis points of interest rate hikes since March 2022. Prices paid by businesses for inputs dropped to 53.4, the lowest reading since March 2020, suggesting easing price pressures. Production remained strong, and employment levels ticked up, but the service sector's growth is expected to continue at a moderate pace as the economy expands.

images.alt_text: Private payrolls rose by 184,000 jobs last month after advancing by an upwardly revised 155,000 in February, the ADP Employment report showed.

site_title: At 75, Nato enters new ‘pre-war era’ of challenges
summary: NATO marks its 75th anniversary amidst growing concerns that the alliance is facing its biggest challenges, with the Ukraine war turning in Russia's favor. Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk warns that Europe is in a "pre-war era" and that Ukraine must not be defeated by Russia. NATO is reportedly drawing up plans for a $100 billion military aid package for Ukraine, with a new secretary-general, Mark Rutte, expected to take over in the second half of the year. The alliance is also pushing for member states to increase defense spending to 2% of GDP, as the US has criticized its current spending levels, amid concerns about China's growing international presence.

images.alt_text: The Hungarian parliament ratifies Sweden's membership of Nato, the final step for the Nordic country keen to join the Atlantic Alliance since the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Fed’s Powell repeats there is time to deliberate over rate cuts
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell reiterated that the US central bank has time to deliberate over its first interest rate cut, citing solid economic growth and inflation moving towards 2% despite recent high inflation readings. Powell stated that recent data do not significantly alter the overall economic picture, and decisions will be made meeting by meeting, with a potential lower interest rate considered if inflation is moving sustainably down. A rate cut is expected at the June 11-12 policy meeting, but the timing may be influenced by upcoming economic data.

images.alt_text: Jerome Powell indicated the February report did not undermine the Federal Reserve's baseline outlook.
Fed chairman Jerome Powell did not make any promises about his next move, and said it was unlikely that the days of ultra-low monetary policy would return any time in the foreseeable future.

US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell’s remarks, the most explicit so far about plans to slow a process that has seen about US$1.4 trillion of bonds roll off the Fed‘s balance sheet, was seen by several Wall Street analysts as a signal that a tapering plan will be unveiled as early as the Fed‘s next meeting on April 30-May 1.

US Federal Reserve Board Chair Jerome Powell announced the central bank stayed on track for three interest rate cuts this year and affirmed that solid economic growth will continue, Washington, DC, March 20, 2024.

site_title: Fewer transactions, but firmer prices as CBD shophouses hold sway among investors
summary: Singapore's CBD shophouse market has seen fewer transactions but firmer prices in 2023, with the average transacted unit price rising by nearly 18% to S$11,098 per square foot. Freehold shophouses have more than doubled in price since Q1 2020, leading some investors to opt for leasehold shophouses for better yields. Leases for 99-year shophouses are not a major concern for buyers, and lease decay is not a significant factor. The market is expected to stabilize, with prices ranging from S$3,500 to S$4,500 psf for freehold shophouses and S$2,500 to S$3,300 psf for 99-year leasehold shophouses.

images.alt_text: The three adjoining shophouses in Duxton Road are nearing the completion of a refurbishment.
The trio of shophouses at 4, 5 and 6 Stanley Street are being put up for sale for S$61.1 million
There were 37 shophouses sold in Q3, Urban Redevelopment Authority data shows.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise after soft US services data, easing eurozone inflation
summary: European stocks rose 0.3% on Wednesday, rebounding from a two-week low, after softer-than-expected US services sector data and softening eurozone inflation data. The Stoxx 600 index hit record highs, with hopes of interest rate cuts and improving domestic growth. Banks led sectoral gains, with eurozone banks also rising 1.5%. ECB policymaker Pablo Hernandez de Cos hinted at potential rate cuts in June, while markets see a 71% chance of a 25-basis-point rate cut.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, April 3, 2024.     REUTERS/Staff

site_title: Canada’s housing crisis will persist on tradespeople shortage, CBRE says
summary: Canada's housing crisis is expected to persist due to a shortage of skilled tradespeople, according to CBRE. The country needs an additional 3.5 million homes, but cannot build at the required pace without enough tradespeople. CBRE's chairman in Canada, Paul Morassutti, stated that the country will likely not meet its housing targets, despite the need for over 3,000 new units per day to meet demand. The housing shortage is driving up prices ahead of Canada's next general election in 2025.

site_title: US: Wall St falls at open as private payrolls beat estimates
summary: US stocks fell at the opening on April 3, 2024, as strong private payrolls data raised concerns about interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve this year. The S&P 500 dropped 0.22% to 5,194.37, while the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.38% to 16,178.80. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.08% to 39,139.59. The lower opening was attributed to investors' fears of fewer-than-expected interest rate cuts, despite the strong private payrolls data.

site_title: World labour markets defy odds and force a reset of rate-cut bets
summary: World labour markets continue to defy expectations, with unemployment rates near record lows in developed economies. Despite slowing economies, demand for workers remains high due to an ageing workforce, lack of skilled labour, and companies hoarding staff. This has led to a sell-off in stocks and bonds, pushing back bets on interest-rate cuts. The US economy added over 200,000 payrolls in March, double the level Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell has said is sustainable, further supporting the notion of a soft landing.

images.alt_text: Job openings, a measure of labour demand, edged up 8,000 to 8.756 million on the last day of February.
The share of British firms expecting to increase wages by 3 per cent or more over the next 12 months fell slightly to 33 per cent from 35 per cent, according to the Lloyds Bank Business Barometer.
MOM data showed that the pay gap in the accommodation and food services industry as well as the manufacturing industry widened in 2023 compared to 2018.

Industries such as manufacturing and construction rely heavily on staffing agencies and contractors to provide workers, and franchisers such as McDonald’s that are not typically involved in franchisees’ day-to-day workplace issues.
Japan’s chronic labour crisis is worsening as the ageing and shrinking of the population accelerates.

The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. logo atop a building at the Hsinchu Science Park in Hsinchu, Taiwan, on Tuesday, Jan. 9, 2023. TSMC is scheduled to release earnings results on Jan. 18. Photographer: Mike Kai Chen/Bloomberg

Under an amendment proposed by the Australian Greens, an employee would now have the right to “refuse to monitor, read or respond to contact, or attempted contact, from an employer outside of the employee’s working hours unless the refusal is unreasonable.”

Job seekers register at a Disabled American Veterans (DAV) and RecruitMilitary LLC job fair in Detroit, Michigan, U.S, on Thursday, Oct. 31, 2019. The Department of Labor is scheduled to release initial jobless claims figures on November 7. Photographer: Anthony Lanzilote/Bloomberg via Getty Images

site_title: US private payrolls beat expectations in March
summary: US private payrolls rose by 184,000 jobs in March, beating expectations of 148,000 jobs, according to the ADP Employment report. This increase follows an upwardly revised 155,000 jobs added in February. The stronger-than-expected jobs report suggests continued labor market strength, ahead of the release of the Labor Department's more comprehensive employment report for March on Friday.

images.alt_text: Official statistics show that the stuff a typical American buys now costs 20 per cent more since before the Covid-19 pandemic.
The reasons for the high demand for workers – an ageing workforce, lack of skilled labour and companies hoarding staff – are holding firm even as economies start to slow.
China's factory activity has expanded for five months; exports are picking up, and the longest streak of deflation since the 1990s has been broken.

FILE PHOTO: Workers marry the body structure with the battery pack and the front and rear sub frames as they assemble electric vehicles at the Lucid Motors plant in Casa Grande, Arizona, U.S. September 28, 2021.  REUTERS/Caitlin O'Hara
Job openings, a measure of labour demand, edged up 8,000 to 8.756 million on the last day of February.
FILE PHOTO: Warehouse workers deal with inventory stacked up to the ceiling at an ABT Electronics Facility in Glenview, Illinois, U.S. December 4, 2018.  REUTERS/Richa Naidu
Though consumer confidence had been generally improving in recent months, still-high prices and soaring borrowing costs are weighing on Americans’ purchasing power.
Orders for durable goods, items ranging from toasters to aircraft meant to last three years or more, rose 1.4 per cent last month amid increases in transportation equipment and machinery orders.

site_title: Singapore aims to train 100 nuclear safety experts; no decision yet on nuclear energy deployment: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore plans to train 100 nuclear safety experts, with the goal of having at least 100 experts by the medium to long term. However, a decision on deploying nuclear energy in Singapore has not been made. The country is studying small modular reactors and Generation IV thermal reactors, which "could potentially suit our needs." The government is also sending local talent overseas for training and collaboration to learn from other countries' expertise.

images.alt_text: S$3.4 million disbursed over 90 projects under Energy Efficiency Fund: Tan See Leng
The EU's proposed sustainability rules will apply to firms that have more than 1,000 employees, and net worldwide turnover above 450 million euros (S$654.2 million).

site_title: JPMorgan creating marketing agency built on purchase data
summary: JPMorgan Chase is launching Chase Media Services, a marketing agency that leverages the bank's vast purchase data to target customers based on their past buying history. The new unit allows brands to create personalized ads and track the effectiveness of each ad, providing a "comprehensive view of purchase behaviour." The division was created after JPMorgan acquired marketing platform Figg in 2022, enabling brands to deliver offers that " Stoke consumer interests."

site_title: China Vanke extends housing sales slump with 43% decline
summary: China Vanke, the country's largest listed developer, reported a 43% decline in contracted home sales for March to 24.5 billion yuan (S$4.6 billion), compared to the same period last year. This follows a 53% year-on-year decline in February. The company's net profit for 2023 plummeted 46%, and its credit rating was downgraded to junk by Fitch Ratings. JPMorgan Chase downgraded Vanke's shares to underweight, citing concerns over liquidity and a lack of evidence for a turnaround in the property sector.

images.alt_text: There have been other signs of concerns among financial institutions, with the property firm’s credit ratings cut to junk level by Fitch Ratings and Moody’s last month.

Investors have been dumping Vanke’s shares and bonds in the past few weeks on cash flow concerns, triggering a rare central government directive to help the Shenzhen-based company beat a liquidity crisis.
FILE PHOTO: The company logo of Chinese developer Country Garden is pictured at the Shanghai Country Garden Center in Shanghai, China August 9, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
Overall housing sales declined 6.5 per cent in 2023 from the previous year and 35.9 per cent from the industry high in 2021.

site_title: Amazon is cutting hundreds of jobs in cloud computing division
summary: Amazon is cutting hundreds of jobs in its cloud computing division, primarily affecting sales and marketing employees and those working on brick-and-mortar store technology. This move comes a year after the company slashed 27,000 corporate roles as part of a cost-cutting drive following the pandemic-era hiring boom. Amazon aims to find new roles for affected employees and has identified "targeted areas" to streamline the organization.

images.alt_text: Amazon will remove the system as it remodels existing Fresh grocery stores and will not feature it in new locations that will start opening later this year.
In a move to attract startup customers, Amazon now allows its cloud credits to cover the use of models from other providers including Anthropic, Meta, Mistral AI, and Cohere.
An Amazon data centre under construction near homes in Stone Ridge, Virginia.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit divests Poland office for 15.9 million euros
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) has divested a non-core office property in Poland for 15.9 million euros, representing a 7.5% premium over its valuation. The sale comes despite low transaction activity in Europe and will reduce the Reit's exposure to Poland to 7.4%. The divestment will be used to repay debt and working capital, and Cromwell E-Reit will retain mortgage rights until final payment. This is the Reit's 253.3 million euros worth of divestments since early 2022, accounting for 63% of its 400 million euros sales pipeline target.

images.alt_text: Cromwell E-Reit's distribution will be paid on Mar 28 after record date on Mar 5.
Artist's impression of Via Nervesa 21 in Milan, Italy, after redevelopment. The property is now largely completed, says Cromwell European Reit's manager.
Cromwell European Reit's Haagse Poort office building. Declines across the Reit’s overall portfolio value as at end-2023 largely comes from its office assets.

site_title: Steady US dollar has yen pinned near key level of 152
summary: The US dollar index remains near its highest level in over four months, pinning the Japanese yen close to its 34-year lows of 151.975. The yen has been under pressure due to the Bank of Japan's historic policy shift and the still-wide Japan-US yield gap. Despite the Bank of Japan's rate hike, policymakers' slow pace of further increases has further weakened the yen. The dollar index is flat on the day, while the euro and pound remain steady.

images.alt_text: Fears of intervention by Japanese officials slowed the dollar’s gains against the yen.
FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: US cancels latest oil reserve refill plan amid high prices
summary: The US Biden administration has canceled its plan to buy oil for the Strategic Petroleum Reserve due to rising oil prices. The Energy Department, citing a target to buy oil at $79 or lower, will not award contracts for 2.8 million barrels of oil to be delivered in August and September. Oil prices have broken above $85 a barrel, a 5-month high, and the department believes domestic crude prices will remain high for the remainder of the year, making it unlikely to resume refilling the reserve.

images.alt_text: Oil has rallied this year, driven by tighter supply, attacks on Russian energy infrastructure and war in the Middle East.
Brent futures for June delivery settled at US$87.42 a barrel on Monday, up about 42 cents, or 0.5 per cent, from the April 28 settlement price for the June contract.
US oil exports have set five new monthly records since Western nations began imposing sanctions on Russia in 2022.

site_title: Ford’s US sales rise on big jump in deliveries of hybrid models
summary: Ford's US auto sales rose 7% in the first quarter driven by strong demand for gas-electric hybrids, despite a 10% decline in F-Series truck sales. The company handed over 504,815 light vehicles to American buyers, with hybrid models increasing by 42%. The delayed delivery of the F-150 Lightning pickup truck due to quality issues also contributed to the sales decline.

images.alt_text: Ford is recalibrating its EV strategy as mainstream US consumers baulk at the high price of battery-powered models and the spotty charging infrastructure

site_title: Spotify changing how it charges customers, with new plans and prices
summary: Spotify plans to increase prices by $1 to $2 per month in five markets, including the UK, Australia, and Pakistan, by the end of April, and later in the US. The price hike will help cover the cost of audiobooks, which the company introduced last year. Spotify will also introduce a new basic tier offering music and podcasts for $11 per month, with audiobooks available as an add-on. The move aims to reach long-term profitability, despite the company losing money every year since its public listing in 2018.

images.alt_text: Tencent Music Entertainment reports revenue of 6.89 billion yuan (S$1.3 billion) for the quarter.

site_title: Singapore’s deep-tech deal volume up in 2023 as rationalisation returns to S-E Asia: report
summary: Singapore's deep-tech deal volume increased 31.4% in 2023 to 159 deals, with the majority being early-stage startups. Despite a 21% decrease in deal value to $1.5 billion, Singapore dominated the region's deep-tech market. The country's research institutes have significant intellectual property, with 90% of deals focused on startups. Venture capital investment in deep tech in Singapore accounts for 25% of global averages.

images.alt_text: From left: Professor Chen Tsuhan, deputy president (innovation and enterprise), NUS; Professor Tan Eng Chye, NUS president; Heng Swee Keat, deputy prime minister; Professor Aaron Thean, deputy president (academic affairs) and provost, NUS; and Professor Benjamin Tee, associate vice-president of NUS Enterprise at the NUS Deep Tech Venture Showcase.
Major markets in Apac like China all register dampening PE dealmaking activities in 2023.
Singapore had more than 800 AI startups in 2021, the latest year for which Enterprise Singapore has data, with the number having grown at a compounded 18 per cent a year since 2018.

site_title: Aircraft lease rates yet to peak: BOC Aviation CEO
summary: Aircraft lease rates have yet to peak, according to BOC Aviation CEO Steven Townend, but could reach a plateau within the next 12 months. This is due to the current imbalance of supply and demand in the industry, which is less pronounced than in previous cycles such as the Great Financial Crisis and pre-pandemic periods. The industry's recovery from the pandemic has resulted in fewer new airline entrants, contributing to the current supply-demand balance.

site_title: Vintage furniture hunting
summary: Vintage furniture is highly prized for its classic pieces made from durable materials that have largely disappeared. These pre-loved handcrafted items have lasted decades and are expected to last many more. The article highlights places to hunt for vintage furniture, including Scandinavian and South-east Asian pieces. Meanwhile, local creatives are flourishing, selling original characters on various products and gaining a growing fan base for their work. The article also covers other topics, including Restaurant Início, Nanyang master Cheong Soo Pieng's artwork, and corporate purpose.

site_title: Let’s applaud the good news for the world economy
summary: The global economy appears to have avoided a protracted downturn, with key indicators showing expansion in manufacturing for five consecutive months. China's factory activity has expanded, exports are picking up, and deflation has been broken, offering a welcome boost. The US economy, which has been performing well despite monetary tightening, has also seen a positive manufacturing report. While challenges persist, particularly in China, the data suggests a more optimistic outlook for the global economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers marry the body structure with the battery pack and the front and rear sub frames as they assemble electric vehicles at the Lucid Motors plant in Casa Grande, Arizona, U.S. September 28, 2021.  REUTERS/Caitlin O'Hara
Together with other better-than-expected manufacturing surveys, the data add to evidence that parts of China’s economy are gaining momentum in the first quarter.
The service sector has been the driving force behind the country’s recent economic growth, helping offset the drag in manufacturing hampered by weak global demand.

site_title: Jailed Malaysian ex-PM Najib makes legal bid to serve sentence under house arrest
summary: Malaysian former Prime Minister Najib Razak has filed a judicial review application seeking to obtain a document that would allow him to serve his remaining six years of a 12-year jail sentence under house arrest. Najib's sentence was halved in February by a pardons board chaired by Malaysia's then king, Al-Sultan Abdullah Ahmad Shah. He claims to have received an "addendum order" from the king that would entitle him to serve under house arrest, and is seeking the court to compel the government to confirm its existence and execute the order if it exists.

images.alt_text: PetroSaudi executives Tarek Obaid (left) and Patrick Mahony will plead not guilty, their lawyers have indicated.
The looting of the 1MDB investment fund by officials in Malaysia after Goldman helped it raise money spawned a multibillion-dollar scandal and probes across continents.

site_title: French shipper CMA CGM acquires 10% of Volvo-Renault electric van business
summary: French shipping company CMA CGM has acquired a 10% stake in the Flexis electric van business, a joint venture between Renault and Volvo Group. The acquisition reduces Renault and Volvo's share to 45% each. CMA CGM plans to invest 300 million euros over the next three years, while Flexis will be sold under Renault and Volvo Group's brands and possibly rebranded. The move expands CMA CGM's presence in the logistics industry, following its recent acquisition of Bollore Logistics for $5.25 billion.

images.alt_text: Faster charging times are seen as key to persuading more customers to switch to EVs.
“In coordination with French naval forces, the CMA CGM Jules Verne transited the Red Sea without incident, escorted by the frigate Alsace,” CMA CGM says.
Wincanton says its board intends to unanimously recommend that its shareholders vote in favour of CMA CGM’s bid.

site_title: HSBC chairman says Asia business spinoff ‘will not happen’
summary: HSBC chairman Mark Tucker stated that a spinoff of the bank's Asian business will not happen, citing the lack of shareholder support. Despite a previous attempt to spinoff the business last year, which was backed by major investor Ping An, the bank's majority institutional and retail investor base has since backed the board and structure of the bank. This decision comes after HSBC reported a 78% increase in 2023 pretax profit to $30.3 billion, despite missing a consensus estimate due to a $3 billion impairment on its stake in China's Bank of Communications.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: HSBC's logo is seen on a branch bank in the financial district in New York, U.S., August 7, 2019. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: China’s central bank says it will make efforts to expand demand, boost confidence
summary: China's central bank announced plans to expand domestic demand and boost confidence, supporting banks to replenish capital and increase medium- and long-term loans to the manufacturing industry. The move aims to address inadequacy of effective demand and weak social expectations, as the economy continues an upward trend despite facing deflationary pressure. The People's Bank of China will guide major banks to provide financial services to the real economy, with a focus on prudent monetary policy and counter-cyclical adjustments.

images.alt_text: Xi’s call for the PBOC to “gradually increase the buying and selling of government bonds” in its open market operations sparked a frenzy of speculation among traders last week.
The central bank has taken several steps to shore up confidence in an ailing economy.

site_title: US blames Microsoft 'cascade of errors' for Chinese hack
summary: A US government report blames Microsoft's "cascade of avoidable errors" for a Chinese hacking group's breach of senior US officials' emails, including Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo and US Ambassador to China Nicholas Burns. The Cyber Safety Review Board found that Microsoft's corporate culture was "at odds" with its centrality in the technology ecosystem and customer trust. The report criticizes operational and strategic decisions, such as failing to identify a compromised laptop, and recommends Microsoft develop a plan to enact wide-ranging security reforms.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Microsoft offices in Issy-les-Moulineaux near Paris, France, February 9, 2024. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo

site_title: Indonesia’s Jakarta-Bandung high-speed rail extension to Surabaya not a priority: official
summary: Indonesia is considering extending its Jakarta-Bandung high-speed rail to Surabaya, but it may face significant challenges due to high costs and land issues. The proposal, currently under discussion with China, is no longer on the country's national strategic list of projects. The existing Jakarta-Bandung HSR, launched in October 2023, has been profitable, with over 1.5 million passengers transported since its launch. However, extending the line to Surabaya, a 760 km expansion, would require an estimated $5.1 billion investment and is uncertain due to the new president-elect's administration.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Indonesia's President-elect Prabowo Subianto shake hands at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China April 1, 2024.

site_title: Tesla losing ground in China as it disappoints globally
summary: Tesla's market share in China has shrunk from 10.5% in the first quarter of 2023 to around 6.7% as of December, due to local competition and weakened consumer sentiment. The company's sales and production are consistently backloaded, with the third month of each quarter being the strongest for local shipments. Tesla's reliance on two models, the Model 3 and Model Y, has also hindered its growth in the market. The company's global delivery numbers, 386,810 vehicles in the first three months of the year, also fell short of estimates, with Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives describing the period as an "epic disaster" for Tesla.

images.alt_text: BYD has responded since February to the price war Tesla started early last year in China by cutting prices on the latest versions of its lineup.

FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Visitors check a Tesla Model 3 car next to a Model Y displayed at a showroom of the U.S. electric vehicle (EV) maker in Beijing, China February 4, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo
Sotheby's Motorsport will offer a Tesla Cyberbeast electric truck for sale at an online auction beginning Apr 2.
In China, Tesla is struggling to keep pace with BYD, which became the world’s top-selling EV maker at the end of last year.

site_title: Singapore stocks slide on Wednesday; STI retreats 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.8% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index falling 25.06 points to 3,222.66, following a slide in US stocks. Regional indices, including Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi Composite Index, also fell. Local stocks such as Singtel, DBS, and UOB retreated due to concerns over a potential deal with Optus.

images.alt_text: Singtel is trading as the top traded counter as at 9.31 am.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.6 per cent to 39,566.85, while the broad-based S&P 500 shed 0.2 per cent to 5,243.77 on Monday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 3)
summary: Australian media reports that Singtel's talks with Canadian PE firm Brookfield to sell its 20% stake in Optus have fallen through. Singtel shares slid 4.3% in early trading, despite the company's denial of reports. OCBC is exploring redevelopment of its Chulia Street property, and Singapore is proposing amendments to designate critical transport firms through legislation. Passenger car COE premiums rose, and 44 housing projects were granted a sales deadline extension.

site_title: OCBC exploring redevelopment of Chulia Street property
summary: OCBC is exploring the redevelopment of its iconic Chulia Street property, including 63, 65 Chulia Street, and 18 Church Street, to rejuvenate a strategic area in the central business district. Any redevelopment plans will include preserving the rich heritage of OCBC Centre, a landmark designed by IM Pei. OCBC has no certainty that the plans will result in a redevelopment, and the bank may need to partner with a property group to carry out the project, potentially transferring ownership of the property to the partner.

images.alt_text: OCBC Centre South in the foreground. To the left behind it is the 50-storey OCBC Centre, where the bank's head office is located/

site_title: Temasek appoints two new directors to its board
summary: Temasek Holdings has appointed two new directors to its board: Tan Chong Meng, with a 40-year executive career, and Geoffrey Wong, a seasoned investment manager with experience at UBS. The new board members will provide overall strategic guidance to the management, complementing the current board's operating and investment capabilities. Temasek chairman Lim Boon Heng described Tan and Wong as "recognised leaders" who will help the firm achieve its portfolio and institutional priorities. Their appointments take effect on April 1 and May 10, respectively.

site_title: Swedish bankruptcies increase by 55% in Q1 as rates hurt economy
summary: Swedish bankruptcies increased by 55% in Q1, reaching 804 companies, a 41% rise from the previous year. High interest rates, at a 15-year high, are affecting construction and service spending. Default rates have hit three-decade highs, with managing director Henrik Jacobsson describing the first quarter as "worrying and hard for many entrepreneurs."

site_title: Central banks of Brunei, Laos join regional payment connectivity initiative: Bank Indonesia
summary: Central banks of Brunei and Laos have joined a regional payment connectivity initiative, aiming for more inclusive cross-border payments in the South-east Asia region. This is the latest addition to the initiative, which now includes eight central banks: Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam, Brunei, and Laos. The move is part of efforts to enhance financial integration in the region.

site_title: Hong Kong February retail sales rise 1.9% as tourism extends recovery
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales rose 1.9% in February to HK$33.8 billion, driven by tourism and consumption growth. This marks the 15th consecutive month of sales growth. The government expects inbound tourism to revive further, benefiting the retail sector. The economy is forecast to grow 2.5-3.5% this year, following a 3.2% expansion in 2023. The government plans to roll out over HK$1 billion in support measures for the tourism industry, including staging mega events and travel schemes with Chinese cities.

images.alt_text: Local bars and restaurants are struggling to stay afloat.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, April 3, 2024 (Ep 35)
summary: A Taiwan earthquake hit the world's largest chipmaker, causing Asian markets to fall as investors reduced bets on a June rate cut. Singtel shares slid on reports of a failed Optus sale.

images.alt_text:

Tokyo sank around one per cent, while Sydney and Seoul were off more. Hong Kong, Shanghai, Singapore, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta were also well in the red.
Singtel is trading as the top traded counter as at 9.31 am.

site_title: Priced out? Don’t worry; be happy
summary: US economist Justin Wolfers explains that despite rising prices, the US economy is actually thriving, with wages increasing by 22% since the pandemic, allowing Americans to afford 2% more goods and services. This trend is part of a "play" of inflation and wage growth, where prices rise, followed by a surge in wages to keep up. Younger Americans, unfamiliar with sustained inflation, may be experiencing anxiety, while older Americans understand that inflation is temporary. Wolfers, an economist and professor, advises breathing through anxiety and recognizing that this too shall pass.

images.alt_text: China's factory activity has expanded for five months; exports are picking up, and the longest streak of deflation since the 1990s has been broken.
Fed officials are split: Nine now see two or fewer rate cuts this year, their projections show, after disappointing inflation data at the start of 2024.
Roughly 40 per cent of the stocks in the S&P 500 are trading above where they were 12 months ago.

site_title: Taiwan quake to hit some chip output, cause Asia supply chain disruptions
summary: A 7.2-magnitude earthquake struck Taiwan's eastern coast, killing 9 people and injuring over 900. The powerful quake may cause disruptions across Asia's semiconductor supply chain, with major chipmakers like TSMC and UMC halting operations for inspections. Disruptions to TSMC's facilities in Hsinchu, Tainan, and Taichung may lead to delayed shipments and increased wafer input. Analysts predict a "short-term hiccup" in electronics manufacturing, affecting economies such as Japan, Korea, China, and Vietnam, but potentially allowing Taiwanese and Korean chipmakers to raise prices.

images.alt_text: The Uranus Building in Hualien, after a major earthquake hit Taiwan's east. It's the biggest earthquake in at least 25 years.

site_title: Hot stock: AEM climbs as much as 13.4% following contract win
summary: AEM, a mainboard-listed company providing advanced chip-testing solutions, announced a contract win from a "major fabless provider" of high-performance compute and AI semiconductor chips. The contract win led to a 13.4% jump in AEM's shares, reaching a high of S$2.45. The company's shares were trading 10.7% higher at S$2.39 by 10:52 am.

images.alt_text: Semiconductor equipment maker AEM Holdings reported a net loss of S$20.9 million for H2 2023, as the group grapples with the global tech downturn and inventory surplus.
While Cordlife is in good financial shape at the moment, it should begin weighing its strategic options before too much value is lost
AEM faces weak outlook at Intel after reports of a shortfall in its inventory.
Excess inventory and profits are estimated at between S$18 million and S$25 million.

site_title: Eurozone inflation unexpectedly eases, boosting rate cut case
summary: Eurozone inflation unexpectedly eased to 2.4% in March, defying expectations, boosting the case for the European Central Bank to lower borrowing costs. Consumer price growth slowed due to lower prices for food, energy, and industrial goods. Underlying inflation, closely watched by the ECB, fell to 2.9% from 3.1%. Despite steady services inflation, policymakers are likely to acknowledge the improved outlook but may not cut rates immediately, with a possible move expected in June.

images.alt_text: Consumer prices rose an annual 2.3 per cent last month, according to the statistics office – down from 2.7 per cent in February.
HCOB’s final eurozone manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) dipped to 46.1 in March from February’s 46.5, beating a preliminary estimate of 45.7.
FILE PHOTO: A sign outside the European Central Bank building in Frankfurt, Germany October 27, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo
The recovery was uneven with a strong rebound in services activity offsetting a more severe downturn in manufacturing.

A worker standing at a construction site in Vienna. There is no denying that lists of the top global technology companies, the world’s top universities, or semiconductor manufacturing capacity, tend to show Europe falling behind.

A worker moves equipment and materials on a cart at the factory of Schuko H. Schulte-Sdhoff GmbH, a manufacturer of extraction systems for the the craft and industrial sectors, in Bad Laer, Germany, on Friday, May 26, 2023. Without a major shift, Germany’s labor force will shrink dramatically in the coming years, undermining economic growth, boosting inflation pressures and posing especially tough challenges to the manufacturing firms like Schuko that are the backbone of Europe's biggest economy.
