site_title: S$3.4 million disbursed over 90 projects under Energy Efficiency Fund: Tan See Leng
summary: The Energy Efficiency Fund (E2F) has disbursed S$3.4 million over 90 projects since January 2022, according to Second Minister for Trade and Industry Tan See Leng. The fund, previously administered by the National Environment Agency, has been "subsumed under" the Energy Efficiency Grant. This move aims to support companies in transitioning to a low-carbon economy under Singapore's carbon tax framework.

images.alt_text: A view of Pasir Panjang Terminal.
To be sure, revenue from carbon tax should be channeled towards climate mitigation measures as well as incentives to encourage both companies and consumers to go green.

site_title: Japan PM talks security with Indonesia's Prabowo
summary: Japan Prime Minister Fumio Kishida reaffirmed the country's commitment to deepening security ties with Indonesia, stating that Japan attaches great importance to cooperation in maintaining the free and open international order based on the rule of law. Indonesia's president-elect Prabowo Subianto expressed gratitude for Japan's assistance and hopes to enhance bilateral cooperation in various areas, including security, agriculture, and disaster prevention. This visit marks Prabowo's second stop in Asia after Beijing, where he met Chinese President Xi Jinping.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Indonesia's President-elect Prabowo Subianto shake hands at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China April 1, 2024.

site_title: Singtel slides amid heavy trading on news of scuppered Optus deal; company denies reports again
summary: Singtel's shares fell as much as 4.3% amid reports that talks with Canadian private equity firm Brookfield to sell its 20% stake in Australian subsidiary Optus failed to result in a deal. Singtel denied the reports, stating there was "no impending deal to divest Optus" and the Australian unit remains a "strategic and integral part of the Singtel group". The company will explore options to maximize shareholder value.

images.alt_text: Analysts believe Singtel’s shares remain undervalued. They add that it would take a stronger recovery from Optus for markets to have greater confidence in the stock.
Singtel expects to receive Nvidia’s GB200 Grace Blackwell Superchips in early 2025.
Singtel says Optus remains an "integral and strategic" part of the group.

site_title: Europe’s IPO market not yet open to unprofitable tech: Bank of America
summary: Bank of America says Europe's IPO market is not yet open to unprofitable tech companies, despite a tentative rebound in 2024. Tech companies have struggled to raise money on European exchanges for two years, with only significant IPOs coming from semiconductor companies like Astera Labs and Rubrik. In contrast, US-based companies like Reddit and Trump Media & Technology Group have successfully listed despite being loss-making. Experts say profitability remains key for tech IPOs in Europe, with interest-rate decreases and sustained primary market activity needed before the segment reopens.

images.alt_text: Zeekr is now holding a non-deal roadshow with potential investors ahead of the IPO, according to two Reuters' sources.
Startup Cerebras System's new AI supercomputer Andromeda is seen at a data center in Santa Clara, California, U.S. October 2022.  Rebecca Lewington/Cerebras Systems/Handout via REUTERS
Microsoft made an equity investment in Rubrik in 2021 in a financing round that valued the startup at US$4 billion.
Banks are unwinding some of the hiring they did during the pandemic when technology deals were red hot.
Shein has successfully penetrated a global market that spans over 150 countries, but concerns have been raised about its business practices and ethics.
During January-March 2024, money raised via China IPOs plunged two-thirds from a year ago to just US$2.4 billion.

site_title: India's central bank likely to keep rates on hold
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), is likely to keep interest rates on hold for the seventh consecutive meeting, with economists predicting a rate of 6.5% until July. Strong economic growth and moderating inflation have given the RBI room to keep rates unchanged, despite inflation remaining above the 4% target. The RBI has maintained a "withdrawal of accommodation" stance, signaling tight monetary policy, but some economists suggest it may consider easing policy if inflation falls further.

images.alt_text: Barring the ultra-long duration which consists of bonds maturing in 30 years and above, the RBI conducted auctions for bonds through uniform-based pricing since July 2021.
The RBI’s inflation targeting framework has helped to keep price pressures moderate, Prime Minister Narendra Modi says.

The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) logo is displayed on a gate at the central bank's headquarters in Mumbai, India, on Tuesday, April 1, 2014. Indiaâs central bank left its key interest rate unchanged as consumer-price inflation eased to a two-year low and the rupee strengthened, increasing scope to support growth ahead of national elections starting this month. Photographer: Vivek Prakash/Bloomberg

site_title: 5 Questions with Fandy Cendrajaya, partner at Kopital Ventures
summary: Fandy Cendrajaya, partner at Kopital Ventures, has run a $12 million fund with fellow angel investor James Prananto, backing early-stage startups through the firm. Kopital Ventures complements larger funds by being a "gatekeeper" for proprietary deal flow. Cendrajaya emphasizes empathy in early-stage investing and the importance of being helpful to founders beyond just their business. He believes Indonesia's venture capital landscape still needs improvement, including instilling trust among local and foreign funds, and more companies focusing on growth through acquisitions.

images.alt_text: Minette Navarrete, president of Kickstart Ventures, gives us a crash course on the Philippines' startup ecosystem.
Willis Wee founded Tech in Asia in 2009 during the social media boom.
Knowing the difference between a difficult or a uncomfortable decision is a key piece of advice Vinod Nair, founder and CEO, MoneySmart received.
From doctor to running deep tech ecosystem builder SGInnovate, Lim Jui's journey has been less than conventional.

site_title: China’s services activity growth speeds up in March, Caixin PMI shows
summary: China's services sector activity growth accelerated in March, with the Caixin/S&P Global services purchasing managers' index (PMI) rising to 52.7 from 52.5 in February. This marks the 15th consecutive month the index has expanded, driven by improving demand and efforts to boost new orders. Business confidence also increased, but employment levels shrank for a second month, with job shedding easing. The data adds to evidence of parts of China's economy gaining momentum in the first quarter, but sluggish demand persists.

images.alt_text: Economic data over the January-to-February period and a factory owners survey for March offer relief to Chinese policymakers seeking to convince foreign investors.
Citi last week raised its forecast for China’s 2024 growth to 5.0 per cent from 4.6 per cent, citing “recent positive data and policy delivery”.
Recent indicators suggest a stabilisation in China, but overall gains remain tempered by the persistent fragility in the property market.

site_title: Singapore rules out hosting the 2026 Commonwealth Games
summary: Singapore has ruled out hosting the 2026 Commonwealth Games, citing the feasibility of hosting the event as a factor in its decision. The original host, Victoria in Australia, pulled out due to escalating costs, which had ballooned to A$7 billion. This is the latest setback for the event, which remains in limbo.

site_title: Setback for Thailand's Move Forward Party as court accepts dissolution case
summary: Thailand's Constitutional Court accepted a case seeking the dissolution of the opposition Move Forward Party, citing its controversial campaign to reform a law shielding the monarchy from criticism. The ruling follows a January court decision finding the party's plan to amend the law unconstitutional. Move Forward has denied attempting to overthrow the system, but faces dissolution and lengthy bans if the court rules against it. The party's progressive platform, including reforming the royal insults law, has resonated with young and urban voters.

images.alt_text: Pita Limjaroenrat of the opposition Move Forward Party is ranked first with an approval rating of 42.75 per cent in a quarterly survey by the National Institute of Development Administration, up from 39.4 per cent in the last poll.

site_title: Retailer Express holds talks for bankruptcy financing
summary: Express, a mid-priced apparel retailer, is seeking bankruptcy financing from its lenders to address cash burn issues as it attempts to fix troubled operations. The company may file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy as early as next week, with plans subject to change. Express has been burning through cash, and negotiations are private, according to sources. The outcome of the bankruptcy process is uncertain, and the company's future operations remain unclear.

images.alt_text: Central Group wants to lift its stake in Selfridges to 60 per cent and take control of the operating business.

site_title: Abu Dhabi’s Lunate buys stake in Adnoc pipeline assets
summary: Abu Dhabi's Lunate has acquired a 40% stake in Adnoc Oil Pipelines, a 23-year lease on 22 pipelines, from US private equity firms BlackRock and KKR for an undisclosed amount. The deal returns the stake to local hands after the US funds bought it for $4 billion in 2019, marking the first foreign investors to acquire infrastructure assets of a Gulf national oil company. This investment aligns with Lunate's long-term capital strategy to identify and invest in premium infrastructure assets, and demonstrates its confidence in the UAE economy.

images.alt_text: Adnoc says it has already integrated more than 30 AI tools across processes, from field operations to corporate decision-making, and plans to roll out the technology further.
“The increased allocation will include investments to grow the company’s domestic and international carbon management platforms,” Adnoc says.

site_title: Car shows drive COE hikes; Category B back above S$100,000
summary: COE premiums in Singapore rose in April's first round of bidding, with Category B, larger and more powerful cars, increasing 5.5% to above S$100,000. Category A premiums rose 4.1% to S$89,000, while Category E premiums increased 5.4% to S$101,002. The rise is attributed to car shows, including the Singapore Motorshow and The Car Expo, which may have led to dealers bidding more aggressively to secure COE prices. The Land Transport Authority expects passenger car COE prices to continue to fluctuate as retail demand remains strong.

images.alt_text: The price for Category A rose to S$83,000, eclipsing the previous high of S$81,589 in January’s first round of bidding.
The trade-offs of a one-time rise will need to be studied carefully, says Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat.
Industry watchers say that forthcoming regulatory changes will reduce operating costs for taxis, but will not give them a significant advantage.
Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars rose, while those for commercial vehicles and motorcycles remained flat.
Generic photo of vehicles for COE bidding, car pollution, carbon tax related stories.

site_title: From leasing steel plates to renting out buildings
summary: Soon Lee Heng Trading & Transportation, a Singaporean SME, has expanded into property and financial asset management. The company, affiliated with the Soon Li Heng Group, has diversified its operations and now manages an 80,000 sq ft industrial building in Jurong, with up to 60% of its lettable area rented out. The company's headquarters in Tampines also marks its initial foray into property management. Soon Lee Heng's stock portfolio has contributed significantly to its revenue, with annualized returns in the "high single digits". The company aims to build and operate more industrial properties and is actively bidding for land sale tenders.

images.alt_text: Singapore's construction industry grew 7.4 per cent in real output in 2023, says Linesight.
The pressure to adopt greener materials may eventually have to come from end-users of these buildings.

The recovery in construction activity comes on the back of the lifting of a Heightened Safety Period (HSP) put in place by the Ministry of Manpower from Sep 1, 2022 to May 31, 2023, after a spate of workplace fatalities in the sector.

site_title: China’s Zeekr renews plans to raise up to US$500 million in US IPO, sources say
summary: Zeekr, a Chinese premium electric vehicle brand, is restarting plans to raise up to $500 million in a US IPO. The company had previously put the plans on hold due to valuation mismatch and volatile financial markets. Zeekr is now holding a non-deal roadshow with potential investors ahead of the IPO. The company aims to raise funds to support its business growth and expansion.

images.alt_text: Zeekr, Chinese automaker Geely's premium electric vehicle (EV) brand, on display in a shopping mall in Beijing last November.

site_title: Thai business group maintains growth outlook at 2.8%-3.3%, urges stimulus and rate cut
summary: Thailand's economy is forecast to grow 2.8-3.3% this year, driven by 2-3% exports growth, despite weak domestic demand. The Joint Standing Committee on Commerce, Industry and Banking urged stimulus measures and lower interest rates to support growth. This outlook is in line with the central bank's revised forecast of 2.5-3% growth. The economy shrank 0.6% in the final quarter of 2023, lower than the 1.9% growth in 2022.

images.alt_text: The stimulus plan, delayed by several months over differences on how it will be funded, is set to be implemented in the fourth quarter of calendar year 2024.

site_title: Trudeau offers billions to boost homebuilding, with strings attached
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced a C$5 billion funding package to boost homebuilding, contingent on provinces agreeing to "key actions" including approving four units as-of-right, freezing development charges, and adopting changes to the national building code. The move puts Trudeau's government at odds with Ontario Premier Doug Ford, who opposes the plan, calling it a "massive mistake." Provinces must agree to these reforms by January 1, 2025, to qualify for the funding.

images.alt_text: Canadian home sales fall 3.1 per cent in February from January, giving back some of the cumulative 12.7 per cent increase posted in the previous two months.

site_title: Rivian beats EV production estimates with shipments rebounding
summary: Rivian Automotive exceeded quarterly electric vehicle production estimates, delivering 13,980 EVs and handing over 13,588 to customers. Despite the positive results, Rivian's shares fell 4.6% due to unchanged full-year outlook and investor concerns about the EV market. The company plans to halt work on its Atlanta factory to accelerate the introduction of a new, lower-priced model, which may not extend into the second quarter. Analysts see Rivian's stock as range-bound until it demonstrates sustainable gross margin improvement.

images.alt_text: Attendees look at the new Rivian R2 electric vehicle at the Rivian South Coast Theater in Laguna Beach, California, on March 7, 2024. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)
Rivian tanked 25 per cent to a record low after it forecast flat growth in annual production, also hurt by a shutdown of its assembly line for upgrades.

site_title: Asia: Markets hit by dimming US rate hopes, Taiwan quake
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Wednesday as investors lost hope for US Federal Reserve interest rate cuts this year, despite central bank officials' assurances of three cuts. A massive earthquake in Taiwan also contributed to the decline, with Tokyo, Sydney, and Seoul falling around 1%. The earthquake caused damage and halted production at major chip manufacturers, while gold prices hit a fresh record high. Traders now expect fewer than six expected interest rate cuts this year, with some predicting as few as two.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong led most Asian markets higher on Tuesday.

site_title: Swedish housing prices rise again as rate cuts expected
summary: Sweden's housing prices rose 1.9% in March, according to state-owned lender SBAB, indicating a nascent recovery from a 15% slump in 2022. The data suggests optimism about borrowing costs amid expectations of monetary policy easing, with Sweden's Riksbank set to cut its benchmark interest rate to 3.75% as early as next month. However, the Riksbank warned consumers not to increase spending in anticipation of lower rates, citing a potential rebound in inflation. A large supply of homes for sale and pent-up demand could influence prices in both directions.

site_title: Philippine Airlines sets US$450 million of spending as tourism rebounds
summary: Philippine Airlines has set a spending budget of $450 million for 2024, more than doubling its 2023 budget, as it gears up for the continued recovery in tourism and increased competition. The airline plans to refurbish existing planes and expand capacity by 10-12% this year, financing its spending through internally generated cash, bank loans, and lease financing. The airline's recovery in air travel was reflected in its 2023 passenger numbers, which reached nearly 15 million, and it now expects to attract 7.7 million international visitors this year.

images.alt_text: President Ferdinand Marcos Jr vows to implement countermeasures against “illegal, coercive, aggressive and dangerous attacks” by China’s coastguard.
This satellite image dated Mar 23 shows the waters where the Philippines says  China's coast guard blocked its supply vessel and damaged it with a water cannon.

site_title: Scion of UOB’s Wee family buys mansion for S$39.5 million
summary: Grant Wee, scion of Singapore's Wee family, has purchased a S$39.5 million mansion, taking advantage of the country's lull in high-end real estate market. The Good Class Bungalow (GCB) at Ford Avenue, co-owned by Choo Chiau Beng, was last sold in 2019 for S$17 million. The transaction comes amid a tepid 2023 property market, dented by a money laundering scandal and high interest rates. Grant Wee, a former consultant at Boston Consulting Group, runs a wellness club in Singapore and is not actively involved in UOB's banking business.

images.alt_text: The late Wee Cho Yaw left his mark in many areas including the property sector.

site_title: Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi starts delivering the first of more than 100,000 EVs ordered
summary: Xiaomi has begun delivering the first of over 100,000 EVs ordered for its SU7 electric vehicle, with the first batch of 5,000 "Founder's Edition" cars being handed over in Beijing. The SU7, priced under $30,000 for its base model, marks Xiaomi's entry into the crowded China EV market, with CEO Lei Jun hailing it as a "revolution" in smart cars. Despite analysts predicting a loss of nearly $10,000 per car, Xiaomi's shares surged after the launch, valuing the company at $55 billion.

images.alt_text: BYD, which overtook Tesla to become the world’s largest EV producer in late 2023, saw sales jump 46 per cent year on year to 302,459 vehicles.
Xiaomi has advised potential buyers of its sedan that they could face wait times of four to seven months, a sign of strong interest.

The logo of NIO seen on an EL6 car model is pictured at the NIO House, the showroom of the Chinese premium smart electric vehicle manufacture NIO Inc. in Berlin, Germany August 17, 2023. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse
Xiaomi built a Beijing factory capable of producing 200,000 cars annually before it had regulatory approval to start manufacturing in China.

site_title: Amended Cybersecurity Act to mandate more disclosures, expand list of regulated organisations
summary: Singapore's Cybersecurity Act is set to be amended to regulate more organizations, including those managing vaccine distribution and temporary systems of high-profile events. The amendments will require organizations to report incidents and provide cybersecurity-related information, and will designate certain targets as entities of special cybersecurity interest (ESCI) to enhance situational awareness. The changes aim to improve the Cyber Security Agency of Singapore's (CSA) oversight and response to cyber threats, including those targeting critical information infrastructure (CII) and systems of temporary cybersecurity concern (STCC).

images.alt_text: A photo illustration showing streaks of which depicts cybersecurity or computer hacking.
Local organisations recognised the importance of cybersecurity, but there is still “much room for improvement” given partial adoption of measures, said the Cyber Security Agency of Singapore.
Interpol has observed an “explosion” of cyber-enabled crime in recent years, says secretary-general Jurgen Stock.
The US Treasury Department says the sanctions are on Wuhan Xiaoruizhi Science and Technology as well as on two Chinese nationals.

site_title: Japan’s economy recovers to full capacity, keeps alive BOJ rate hike prospects
summary: Japan's economy has recovered to full capacity for the first time in about four years, according to the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) estimate. The BOJ's output gap, measuring the difference between actual and potential output, stood at 0.02% in the final quarter of last year, a positive sign that may allow the central bank to raise interest rates again. This historic shift away from its focus on quashing deflation and reflating growth marks a significant change in the BOJ's unorthodox policy.

images.alt_text: The service sector has been the driving force behind the country’s recent economic growth, helping offset the drag in manufacturing hampered by weak global demand.
Japan’s economy expanded an annualised 0.4 per cent in the final quarter of last year, narrowly averting a technical recession as robust capital expenditure offset weaknesses in consumption.
In Japan, except for startups and other exceptions, banks are banned from owning a stake bigger than 5 per cent in a company.
Japanese manufacturers surveyed expect seasonally adjusted output to increase 4.9 per cent in March and rise 3.3 per cent in April.

site_title: Gold extends record rally on safe-haven appeal, weaker US dollar
summary: Gold prices extended their record rally, edging 0.2% higher to $2,283.47 per ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar and safe-haven demand amid escalating tensions in the Middle East. US gold futures rose 1% to $2,303.80 per ounce, while the US dollar eased 0.1%. Investors await US economic data for policy clues, with a 64% probability of the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates by June, according to the CME Group's FedWatch Tool.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was unchanged at US$2,250.26 per ounce.

site_title: Chipmaker Hailo raises US$120 million riding on AI boom
summary: Israel-based chipmaker Hailo raised US$120 million in a funding round, valuing it at US$1.2 billion. The company released a high-performance generative AI chip and plans to use the funds to accelerate growth and potentially become a publicly traded company. Hailo's CEO Orr Danon stated the company aims to execute faster on its roadmap based on market conditions. The total investment since Hailo's inception in 2017 exceeds US$340 million, led by existing and new investors including the Zisapel family, Comasco, and OurCrowd.

images.alt_text: Intel has now switched over to using EUV tools, which will cover more and more production needs as older machines are phased out.

site_title: Four disruptive forces for markets to watch in 2024
summary: Global equity markets are off to a strong start in 2024, with the MSCI World Index up over 8% and the S&P 500 up over 10%. However, experts at four private banks warn that several events could disrupt the market, including economic weakness, generative AI, climate change, and geopolitical tensions. Economic weakness is a concern, with some countries potentially slipping into recession, while generative AI could both disrupt and benefit businesses. Climate change is creating new winners and losers, and geopolitical tensions, including US-China elections and conflicts in the Middle East and Ukraine, should be watched.

images.alt_text: While the attributes of a Bani world may seem daunting at first glance, with the right mindset, affluent families can navigate the challenges to uncover new opportunities.
Sustainable investing can be a way to bring family members across generations together for a common purpose.
Benjamin Graham describes the market as a voting machine in the short run and a weighing machine in the long run.
Trust-based philanthropy relies on donors’ confidence in the probity, intentions and capabilities of recipients.

site_title: Japan’s service activity growth fastest in seven months as demand picks up: PMI
summary: Japan's service sector activity expanded at its quickest pace in seven months in March, driven by strong demand for inbound tourism, according to a business survey. The service sector has been the driving force behind Japan's recent economic growth, helping offset weak global demand in manufacturing. The final au Jibun Bank Service purchasing managers' index (PMI) rose to 54.1 in March, marking the 19th consecutive month of increase.

images.alt_text: Japan’s economy expanded an annualised 0.4 per cent in the final quarter of last year, narrowly averting a technical recession as robust capital expenditure offset weaknesses in consumption.
In Japan, except for startups and other exceptions, banks are banned from owning a stake bigger than 5 per cent in a company.
Japanese manufacturers surveyed expect seasonally adjusted output to increase 4.9 per cent in March and rise 3.3 per cent in April.
The rise in the core consumer price index in Tokyo, an early indicator of nationwide figures, matched a median market forecast and followed a 2.5 per cent increase in February.

site_title: TSMC halts some chipmaking, evacuates plants after major quake
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) halted chipmaking operations and evacuated staff after a 7.4-magnitude earthquake struck its home island, the first major quake in 25 years. The company, the world's largest chipmaker, moved staff out of affected areas and is assessing the impact. Smaller rival UMC also halted machinery and evacuated facilities. The quake highlights the risks of centering advanced semiconductor production in a quake-prone island, prompting industry calls for diversification.

site_title: Country Garden extends sales slump as financial woes pile up
summary: Country Garden Holdings reported a 83% decline in contracted home sales for March, extending its sales slump. The company's financial woes worsen its cash crunch, following a missed deadline for annual results and a wind-up petition from a Hong Kong court. This decline exacerbates China's property sector slump, with private data showing a steep decline in home sales and a 9% drop in property investment. Country Garden's sales drought threatens its operational cash flow, and the company is utilizing the regulator's latest property funding programme for financing support.

images.alt_text: “At the request of the company, trading in the shares of the company on the stock exchange will be suspended... pending publication of the 2023 Annual Results,” Country Garden says.
FILE PHOTO: The company logo of Chinese developer Country Garden is pictured at the Shanghai Country Garden Center in Shanghai, China August 9, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
Country Garden's operations focus on smaller cities, which expand faster in good times but have been harder hit by the housing slump and economic slowdown.

site_title: Nine dead in Taiwan’s strongest earthquake in 25 years, 50 missing, more than 900 hurt
summary: A 7.2 magnitude earthquake struck Taiwan's east, killing nine people, injuring over 900, and leaving 50 missing. The quake, the strongest in 25 years, hit just offshore and caused widespread damage, including building collapses and massive landslides. Rescuers used ladders to bring trapped people to safety, and a tsunami warning was issued for southern Japan and the Philippines, although later lifted. The quake also affected Taiwan's capital, Taipei, with strong tremors forcing the subway system to close briefly.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's central bank hiked the benchmark discount rate to 2 per cent from 1.875 per cent, where it has stood since last March.

site_title: Thriving in a Bani world
summary: Affluent families can navigate the challenges of a "Bani world," characterized by volatility, anxiety, and non-linearity, by adopting an innovative mindset. Key strategies include cultivating resilience, flexibility, and adaptability, and embracing innovation through creative problem-solving and open-mindedness. Single-family offices and alternative wealth-planning solutions, such as trusts or insurance solutions, can also provide a holistic platform to consolidate assets and manage risk. By embracing uncertainty and adapting to the new norm, affluent families can uncover new opportunities and thrive in the Bani world.

images.alt_text: The current confidence in the market may yet be disrupted by several events.
Benjamin Graham describes the market as a voting machine in the short run and a weighing machine in the long run.
Sustainable investing can be a way to bring family members across generations together for a common purpose.
Trust-based philanthropy relies on donors’ confidence in the probity, intentions and capabilities of recipients.

site_title: Chipmaker Cerebras Systems picks Citigroup for IPO
summary: Cerebras Systems, a semiconductor startup, has chosen Citigroup as the lead bank for its initial public offering (IPO). The company is targeting a listing in the second half of 2024 and may seek a valuation above $4 billion, following its 2021 funding round. This comes as several tech companies have recently filed for IPOs, including Reddit and Astera Labs. Cerebras raised $250 million in a series F financing round in 2021, valuing it at over $4 billion, and is advised by Alpha Wave Ventures, Abu Dhabi Growth Fund, and G42.

site_title: Dyna-Mac order book swells to record S$896 million
summary: Dyna-Mac, an offshore oil and gas contractor, has achieved a record S$896 million net order book with new contract wins, marking its largest-ever contract win. The project deliveries are expected to stretch to 2026. The new orders are not expected to have a material impact on the group's earnings per share and net tangible assets for the current financial year. Dyna-Mac's recent capacity expansion and upgrading allows for further optimization of its productivity, following an 84.7% increase in H2 net profit in FY2023.

images.alt_text: Dyna-Mac's offshore floating production, storage and offloading (FPSO).

FILE PHOTO: Workers marry the body structure with the battery pack and the front and rear sub frames as they assemble electric vehicles at the Lucid Motors plant in Casa Grande, Arizona, U.S. September 28, 2021.  REUTERS/Caitlin O'Hara
Brent futures for June delivery settled up US$1.50, or 1.7 per cent, at US$88.92 after touching a peak of US$89.08.

site_title: US factory orders increase solidly in February
summary: US factory orders increased 1.4% in February, rebounding from a 3.8% drop in January, as demand for machinery and commercial aircraft boosted manufacturing. Orders for commercial aircraft rose 24.6%, while machinery orders increased 1.8% due to a surge in mining and oil field machinery. Shipments of manufactured goods also rose 1.4%, while inventories increased 0.3%. The increase marks a turnaround for manufacturing, which had struggled after 525 basis points of interest rate hikes since March 2022.

images.alt_text: Job openings, a measure of labour demand, edged up 8,000 to 8.756 million on the last day of February.

site_title: Seatrium bags S$350 million worth of contracts
summary: SEATRIUM has secured S$350 million worth of contracts for repair, upgrade, and conversion works by end-2025. The contracts were awarded to its wholly owned subsidiary, Seatrium Repairs and Upgrades, with scheduled commencement in the second quarter of 2024.

images.alt_text: Seatrium yard

site_title: Vietnam biotech firm Gene Solutions set to raise US$70 million to chase big dreams in the region
summary: Vietnamese biotech firm Gene Solutions is set to raise US$70 million in Series C funding, aiming to expand its market share in the region. The company, founded in 2017, already operates in five Asean economies and offers affordable genetic testing products, including a non-invasive prenatal test (NIPT) that costs US$60. Gene Solutions seeks to capture half of the region's market share by 2029 and is establishing a cancer research centre in Vietnam, focusing on novel technologies such as immunotherapy.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's Gene Solutions boasts a portfolio of more than 30 genetic testing products in the fields of obstetrics, paediatrics, and oncology.
Vietnam’s VinBrain gives healthcare sector a leg-up with AI-infused solutions

site_title: Taylor Swift officially declared a billionaire by Forbes
summary: Taylor Swift has been officially declared a billionaire by Forbes, joining the three-comma-club with an estimated wealth exceeding $1 billion. The 34-year-old singer-songwriter has achieved numerous records, including the first billion-dollar tour, four Grammy Awards, and being named Time Magazine's Person of the Year. Her significant real estate portfolio includes homes in New York, Beverly Hills, Nashville, and a coastal mansion in Rhode Island. Swift is set to release a new album, "The Tortured Poets Department," on April 19.

site_title: US Steel union rejects Nippon Steel’s appeal for takeover support
summary: The US Steel union, representing employees of US Steel, has rejected Nippon Steel's draft agreement to gain support for its proposed $15 billion takeover of the US company. The union cited that the agreement does not provide a meaningful basis for resolving the ongoing dispute, despite Nippon's commitments to not lay off employees and defend US Steel against unfair foreign trade. The union is open to meeting with Nippon Steel officials to discuss the transaction's status.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Seatrium, OCBC, Dyna-Mac
summary: Seatrium secured S$350 million worth of contracts to be completed by end-2025, including upgrading liquefied natural gas carriers into floating storage regasification units. OCBC is exploring a redevelopment of its Chulia Street property, with JLL appointed to identify a potential partner. Dyna-Mac secured several contracts, including a record-breaking S$896 million net order book with project deliveries until 2026. Trading halted on Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments due to an announcement, but shares of the group ended unchanged at S$0.001.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Wednesday’s open; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.7% to 3,224.2 points, following overnight losses on Wall Street. The decline was attributed to losses in Tesla and healthcare stocks, with Singtel losing 2.8% and Beng Kuang Marine down 1.7%. Banking stocks also fell, with DBS and UOB dropping 0.6% and 0.7% respectively. The losses followed a weak showing from European stocks, which closed 0.8% lower due to bank and healthcare drag.

images.alt_text:

Generic photo of SGX logo along Shenton Way on Feb 9 , 2024.

site_title: Fed officials say three rate cuts a reasonable baseline for 2024
summary: Fed officials now expect two or fewer rate cuts in 2024, a decrease from the initial projection of three rate cuts. This shift is due to disappointing inflation data at the start of 2024. Despite this, two officials still expect three rate cuts, with San Francisco Fed president Mary Daly labeling the initial three-rate cut projection a "reasonable baseline."

images.alt_text: Jerome Powell indicated the February report did not undermine the Federal Reserve's baseline outlook.
Productivity has been growing at a surprising clip, allowing the US economy to grow fast without adding to price pressures.
Interest expenses, which includes reserves balances at the Fed’s reverse repo operations, nearly tripled to US$281.1 billion in 2023

site_title: ‘Singapore Solution’ tax scam: Swiss executive spared jail time
summary: A Swiss executive, Daniel Walchli, was sentenced to no prison time for his role in the "Singapore Solution" tax scam, which involved helping US taxpayers hide over $60 million in assets. Walchli pleaded guilty to a single count of conspiracy to defraud the US in 2021 and was sentenced on April 2, 2024, after serving brief time in custody. The scheme, which ran from 2008 to 2014, used secret accounts in other countries to evade US tax authorities. Walchli admitted conspiring with Privatbank executives to help favored clients maintain secret accounts.

images.alt_text: gavel, justice, symbol

site_title: US office vacancy rate nears 20% to set fresh record, Moody’s says
summary: US office vacancies reached a record 19.8% in the first quarter, according to Moody's, as tenants continue to downsize with the hybrid work model. The sector has been battered by the interest rate hiking cycle and the evolution of offices, with winners and losers determined by proximity to mixed-use neighborhoods and public parks. Moody's notes that other sectors, such as multifamily, are seeing positive signals, but it's unclear when vacancy rates will peak due to lease rollovers and shifting expectations for Fed monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Two stalled sales in London’s office market are a sign of its stultified nature, amid higher interest rates and concerns around a trend towards hybrid working.
For London's prime properties, which account for the top 10 per cent of rents, rates are forecast to grow by 2.9 per cent this year.
The best buildings are those that focus on wellness and amenities, and are well-located, Morgan Stanley's Hochfelder said.

site_title: EU regulates global sustainability ‘rules of the road’
summary: The European Union has proposed a Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive (CSDDD), a sustainability regulation that will apply to companies with over 1,000 employees and a net worldwide turnover above €450 million. The measure will require firms to document compliance with human rights and environmental standards, including child labor, and transition to a low-carbon economy. The EU aims to set global "rules of the road" for corporate sustainability, amid criticism from some business groups and NGOs, who argue the measure will add undue burdens and undermine global competitiveness.

images.alt_text: The European Council and parliament will hold negotiations later this month on moving forward with CSDDD.
The EU will support businesses and developers in their efforts to prepare for the new AI rules.

site_title: Citigroup claims New York attorney general’s online fraud suit is ‘misguided’
summary: Citigroup has asked a judge to dismiss a New York attorney general's lawsuit alleging the bank has inadequate online security measures to prevent consumer fraud. The bank claims the Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) governs electronically-initiated fund transfers, including ATM transactions, but not wire transfers. Citigroup argues that the suit is a "misguided attempt" to rewrite federal law and that the proper forum for consumer protections is Congress, not a courtroom. The bank claims it has robust countermeasures to combat online fraud and will continue to protect customers.

images.alt_text: Banks are unwinding some of the hiring they did during the pandemic when technology deals were red hot.
The latest reshuffle finalises Citi’s new structure and is part of a broader goal to trim its global workforce of 239,000 by 20,000 over the next two years.
At Citigroup, the cuts come as chief executive officer Jane Fraser is in the middle of initiating a massive restructuring of the banking behemoth
The company has employed 239,000 employees in 90 countries as at December 2023.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dragged down by healthcare; German inflation data in focus
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell 0.8% on Tuesday, its lowest point in a week, due to a decline in healthcare shares and rising eurozone bond yields. German inflation eased slightly in March, with Commerzbank analysts predicting a rise in the coming months. Energy stocks gained 2.5% on increased oil prices, while basic resources rose 1.8% due to strong metal prices. Individual movers included SSAB down 6.1% and Superdry plummeting 55% after its CEO announced he wouldn't make an offer for the company.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 ended 0.2 per cent up, closing a week that was marked by four range-bound sessions ahead of a holiday extended weekend.

site_title: Government gave grace period to 44 housing projects facing ABSD deadline within 2021 to 2023: Lawrence Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced that 44 residential projects, accounting for 12% of housing projects, were granted a sales timeline extension from 2021 to 2023 due to the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) deadline. The extension is considered on a case-by-case basis.

images.alt_text: The revised ABSD remission scheme will apply to projects on residential land acquired on or after Jul 6, 2018.
The move to lower the clawback rate for ASBD will give developers more flexibility on sales.

Budget 2024 tackled immediate cost-of-living worries for households and businesses, while also laying out plans to strengthen Singapore’s economic competitiveness, support young families, and help workers to stay relevant.

site_title: Oil settles up on supply threats, hits 2024 highs during session
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, with Brent futures reaching a 2024 high of $89.08 a barrel due to supply threats from Ukrainian attacks on Russian energy facilities and escalating conflict in the Middle East. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures also surged, touching a peak of $85.46 a barrel. The attacks on Russia's refineries and high petrol and diesel fuel stocks in Russia have raised concerns about potential supply disruptions, prompting re-calculation of US oil balances.

images.alt_text: Brent futures for June delivery settled at US$87.42 a barrel on Monday, up about 42 cents, or 0.5 per cent, from the April 28 settlement price for the June contract.

site_title: Amazon pulls plug on cashierless system in US grocery stores
summary: Amazon will remove its cashierless Just Walk Out technology from existing US grocery stores and won't feature it in new locations, starting later this year. The system, which used ceiling-mounted cameras and shelf sensors to track items, will be replaced as the company remodels existing Fresh stores. Amazon will continue to license the technology to other retailers and keep it in smaller stores in the UK. The move comes after the company scaled back its ambitions for the Dash Cart, which initially relied on cameras to identify items.

images.alt_text: In a move to attract startup customers, Amazon now allows its cloud credits to cover the use of models from other providers including Anthropic, Meta, Mistral AI, and Cohere.
An Amazon data centre under construction near homes in Stone Ridge, Virginia.

site_title: Alibaba makes second biggest ever quarterly share repurchase worth US$4.8 billion
summary: Alibaba Group has repurchased US$4.8 billion worth of shares in the quarter ended March, its second-largest share buyback after increasing the plan by US$25 billion in February to appease investors concerned over its growth prospects. The move comes amid declining Hong Kong shares and growing worries over earnings, per-user spending, and deteriorating Chinese consumption, which has led to a loss of market share to rivals such as PDD and ByteDance.

images.alt_text: The project is in early trial stages, and aims to develop a rocket that can carry up to ten tonnes of cargo in a 120 cubic metre container, says rocket maker Space Epoch.
Cainiao is the logistics backbone of founder and now 67 per cent owner Alibaba – a figure which would have dropped to somewhere above 50 per cent after listing.
FILE PHOTO: Cainiao's logo, Alibaba's logistics unit, is seen at the warehouse in Wuxi, Jiangsu province, China October 26, 2020. Picture taken October 26, 2020. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
Alibaba has been trimming its investment portfolio of late.

site_title: OCBC said to be exploring redevelopment of iconic Chulia Street property
summary: OCBC Bank is exploring the redevelopment of its iconic Chulia Street property in Singapore's central business district. The bank has appointed JLL to identify a potential partner to undertake the redevelopment, which is expected to include office, retail, and hospitality components. The project may be carried out under the Urban Redevelopment Authority's Strategic Development Incentive scheme, which aims to spur redevelopment of commercial properties in strategic areas. OCBC is expected to retain ownership of the asset post-development, and the project's success could lead to greater incentives from the authorities.

images.alt_text: OCBC said its net profit rose 27 per cent on year to S$7.02 billion for FY2023, crossing the S$7 billion mark for the first time.

site_title: Huawei plans lowest dividend payout per share since 2019
summary: Huawei's parent company, Huawei Investment and Holding, plans to pay a cash dividend of 1.5 yuan per share, the lowest since 2019. The company will pay 77.095 billion yuan (S$14.4 billion) in dividends to current and retired staff. This move comes as the company continues to operate despite US sanctions restricting its access to US technology. The dividend payout is based on approximately 51.3 billion shares outstanding.

site_title: Biden, Xi spoke by phone to manage tension, with top US officials to visit China
summary: US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping held a telephone conversation on April 2, managing tensions between the two nations. The direct interaction was the first since a November summit in California, where a thaw in tone was observed. Top US officials, including Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, will soon visit Beijing to further address tensions and explore areas of cooperation. The conversation aims to balance pressure on China with a willingness to work together, amid ongoing rivalry between the world's two largest economies.

images.alt_text: The rules seek to halt shipments to China of more advanced artificial intelligence chips designed by Nvidia and others.
Foreign direct investment represents only 3 per cent of total investment in China, but it has been falling for two consecutive years.

Liu Jianchao, of the International Department of the Communist Party of China, stresses that the world needs civilizations to engage in conversation, not to clash, at the FutureChina dialogue event on Mar 27. PHOTO: BUSINESS CHINA
In November, Xi told US business leaders in San Francisco that China is ready to be a partner and friend of the US, and there is plenty of room for cooperation.
The US Treasury Department says the sanctions are on Wuhan Xiaoruizhi Science and Technology as well as on two Chinese nationals.

site_title: Mastering wealth: The strategic advantage of discretionary portfolio management
summary: Discretionary portfolio management, a bespoke investment strategy tailored to individual investors' risk appetites, timeframes, and objectives, offers a holistic solution by combining strategic asset allocation with professional stewardship. This approach allows investors to delegate day-to-day portfolio oversight, providing a strategic advantage in wealth management. By stepping back from direct involvement, investors can focus on long-term goals while professionals manage the portfolio, ultimately leading to a more effective investment strategy.

images.alt_text: scale, balance, world

site_title: Renault's Ampere starts development of new electric Twingo
summary: Renault has started engineering work on a new, more affordable electric Twingo model, targeting production in two years to counter intense competition from Chinese EV makers. The new Twingo will feature 20% fewer parts, using generic components and parts from suppliers, to reduce costs. This move aims to stave off pressure from Chinese rivals, who have cut development time for new vehicles to an average of 2.5 years.

images.alt_text: The new Renault Twingo eletric car is presented on November 15, 2023 in Boulogne-Billancourt. (Photo by Miguel MEDINA / AFP)
The stronger cash position and margin growth are the latest sign that the carmaker’s turnaround under chief executive Luca de Meo is bearing fruit.

site_title: Build purpose into your wealth to strengthen your legacy
summary: Sustainable investing is gaining popularity among ultra-high-net-worth individuals (UHNWIs) and affluent families as a way to bring family members together for a common purpose and strengthen their legacy. A study estimates that new green industries could be worth $10.3 trillion by 2050, creating opportunities for UHNWIs to invest in sustainable options and mitigate risks. Integrating environmental, social, and governance considerations into wealth portfolios can help safeguard and enhance wealth over the long term, positioning affluent investors as leaders in driving transformative change.

images.alt_text: While the attributes of a Bani world may seem daunting at first glance, with the right mindset, affluent families can navigate the challenges to uncover new opportunities.
The current confidence in the market may yet be disrupted by several events.
Benjamin Graham describes the market as a voting machine in the short run and a weighing machine in the long run.
Trust-based philanthropy relies on donors’ confidence in the probity, intentions and capabilities of recipients.

site_title: In Washington, they’re all economic nationalists now
summary: The Biden administration has taken steps to adopt a more nationalist and protectionist economic agenda, reversing its predecessor's commitment to free trade policies. The administration has backed legislation to force the sale of TikTok, opposed Japan-based Nippon Steel's bid for Pittsburgh-based US Steel, and asserted the importance of US ownership to protect America's technological secrets and boost domestic companies. This shift in policy reflects the "new Washington consensus" that prioritizes tariffs and subsidies to support domestic industries and reverse the decline in American manufacturing power.

images.alt_text: The Japanese company has been in talks with the USW, a labour union key for Biden and Trump in the upcoming November elections and which so far was opposing the deal.
The logos of Nippon Steel Corp are displayed at the company headquarters in Tokyo, Japan March 18, 2019. Picture taken March 18, 2019.  REUTERS/Yuka Obayashi
US Steel is based in Pittsburgh in the key battleground state of Pennsylvania, which Joe Biden won in the 2020 election and will fight Donald Trump for again this year.
TikTok intends to exhaust all legal challenges if the latest US legislation targeting the app becomes law.

site_title: BYD hands back top EV seller title to Tesla after Q1 sales decline
summary: BYD, China's largest electric vehicle (EV) maker, reported a 43% decline in Q1 2024 sales to 300,114 units, handing back the title of world's biggest EV seller to Tesla after winning it last year. Tesla's sales declined 20.2% to 386,810 units, following a slowdown in the Chinese market where local rivals led by BYD initiated a price war. Despite the decline, Tesla maintains its global clout, and both companies expect a slowdown in Chinese EV sales growth this year.

images.alt_text: People walk past the logo of BYD at the Everything Electric exhibition at the ExCeL London international exhibition and convention centre in London, Britain, March 28, 2024.  REUTERS/Peter Cziborra
BYD, which overtook Tesla to become the world’s largest EV producer in late 2023, saw sales jump 46 per cent year on year to 302,459 vehicles.
BYD aims to sell 500,000 vehicles overseas this year, more than double last year’s total, and one million units in 2025, chairman Wang Chuanfu says.
Net profit totalled 8.67 billion yuan (S$1.6 billion) in the fourth quarter, on a 15.1 per cent jump in revenue to 180.04 billion yuan.

site_title: Trust-based philanthropy the Asian way
summary: A growing number of high-net-worth individuals in Asia are shifting to trust-based philanthropy, a model that relies on donors' confidence in the probity and capabilities of recipients. This approach involves providing unrestricted funding to non-profit organizations, eliminating lengthy grant applications and extensive reporting requirements. Practitioners conduct upfront due diligence to align missions with giving strategies, allowing NPOs flexibility in fund allocation. In contrast to "philanthrocapitalism," which advocates discipline and managerial practices, trust-based philanthropy enables NPOs to adapt and respond to shifting contexts, with a focus on impact rather than metrics.

images.alt_text: The current confidence in the market may yet be disrupted by several events.
While the attributes of a Bani world may seem daunting at first glance, with the right mindset, affluent families can navigate the challenges to uncover new opportunities.
Sustainable investing can be a way to bring family members across generations together for a common purpose.
Benjamin Graham describes the market as a voting machine in the short run and a weighing machine in the long run.

site_title: Intel discloses US$7 billion operating loss for chipmaking unit
summary: Intel disclosed a US$7 billion operating loss for its chipmaking unit in 2023, a significant increase from the previous year's US$5.2 billion loss. The company expects to break even on an operating basis by 2027 and has outlined a business turnaround plan, which includes spending US$100 billion on new chip factories and expanding its manufacturing services to compete with rivals TSMC and Samsung Electronics. Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger attributed the losses to past "bad decisions," including the use of expensive extreme ultraviolet machines.

images.alt_text: Intel logo is seen near computer motherboard in this illustration taken January 8, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Trial over US$1.8 billion fraud at Malaysia’s 1MDB opens in Switzerland
summary: Tarek Obaid and Patrick Mahony, PetroSaudi executives, have gone on trial in Switzerland for allegedly embezzling US$1.8 billion from Malaysia's 1MDB sovereign wealth fund. They will plead not guilty, according to their lawyers. The case is linked to Jho Low, an advisor to former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, who is accused of orchestrating the embezzlement operation. The trial marks the latest development in the ongoing 1MDB scandal, which has garnered international attention and sparked numerous investigations worldwide.

images.alt_text: The looting of the 1MDB investment fund by officials in Malaysia after Goldman helped it raise money spawned a multibillion-dollar scandal and probes across continents.

FILE PHOTO: Motorcyclists pass a 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) billboard at the Tun Razak Exchange development in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, February 3, 2016. REUTERS/Olivia Harris/File Photo/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Ex-Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng and his lawyer Marc Agnifilo leave the federal court in New York, U.S., May 6, 2019. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon/File Photo
Najib is expected to be released in August 2028, six years after he began serving his sentence.

site_title: GXS disburses over 100,000 loans in first year, aims to double it in six months
summary: GXS Bank has disbursed over 100,000 loans in its first year under the FlexiLoan product, targeting gig workers and underserved segments. The digital bank is using data from ecosystem partners Grab and Singtel to provide credit scores and onboard customers deemed difficult to serve by traditional banks. The product offers flexibility, allowing customers to draw down approved amounts and pay interest only on the amount used, resulting in savings of S$4 million in interest. GXS aims to double loan disbursals to over 200,000 in the next six months and expand to the mass and mass-affluent segments.

images.alt_text: Grab and Singtel have laid out plans for a further capital injection in the third quarter of this year.
Grab’s profitability push will require its financial services and digital banks, such as GXS Bank, to fire on all cylinders.
(From left to right) GXS chairman Hsieh Fu Hua, Datuk Johan Merican, GXBank CEO Pei Si Lai and Datuk Zaiton Hassan, chairperson of GXBank, at the public launch of GXBank.

site_title: Dwindling BNPL numbers show tough reality even as accreditation deadline passes
summary: Several "buy now, pay later" (BNPL) service providers in Singapore have struggled to stay afloat despite an accreditation deadline, highlighting the challenges faced by the industry. Five BNPL providers, out of eight initially available, successfully obtained accreditation, but many others have dropped out due to rising costs and market conditions. The Monetary Authority of Singapore estimated BNPL usage at less than 1% of credit and debit card payments in 2021. The industry's sustainability is now uncertain, with market conditions proving to be the true test for BNPL players.

images.alt_text: Indonesian tech company GoTo is preparing to launch a BNPL product with social media platform TikTok.
Shopee is looking to expand a slew of services to attract a younger demographic to shop on its platform.
BNPL player Atome has seen its CEO leave for GoTo Financial, as players retreat and refocus away from BNPL.

site_title: Bitcoin sinks on ebbing Fed rate-cut bets and cooling ETF demand
summary: Bitcoin fell 7.4% as much as its largest intraday decline since March 19, trading around $65,400, amid cooling demand for US exchange-traded funds and ebbing bets on Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts. This decline comes as investors curb wagers on Fed rate cuts, bolstering Treasury yields and the dollar, and follows a 10% drop since its peak in mid-March. The cooling crypto rally is attributed to lingering US price pressures and the impact of changing views on the Fed's monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The retreat adds to signs that a steep crypto rally, including a Bitcoin jump to a record high, has lost some impetus as April begins.

site_title: From pool to corporate world: Time is right for Schooling to make career change
summary: Swimming coach Vincent Poon identified 7-year-old Joseph Schooling as a "special boy" in 2002. Schooling's natural talent and dedication led to him becoming a world-class swimmer. Now, at a career crossroads, Schooling is considering a transition from the pool to the corporate world. Poon believes the time is right for Schooling to make this change, citing the swimmer's strong work ethic and adaptability. Schooling's experience as a coach and his passion for sports may translate well to a corporate role.

images.alt_text: Schooling is now a founding partner at Swaen Schooling Capital, along with investment banker Cliff Go and serial entrepreneur Ben Ling.
Olympic gold medallist Joseph Schooling has called time on his career.

site_title: Olympic gold medalist Schooling enters VC space
summary: Singaporean Olympic gold medalist Joseph Schooling has announced his retirement from competitive swimming to pursue a career in venture capital investing. He is now a founding partner at Swaen Schooling Capital, alongside investment banker Cliff Go and serial entrepreneur Ben Ling. The firm focuses on early-stage investments in impact and sustainability, sports and wellness, and tech, with no announced investments to date. Schooling had previously invested in a mental health startup, and his venture capital venture aims to explore new passions and challenges.

images.alt_text: Swimming coach Vincent Poon (right) knew Joseph Schooling was a "special boy" from the start.
Olympic gold medallist Joseph Schooling has called time on his career.

site_title: US job openings little changed in February; quits edge up
summary: US job openings remained steady at 8.756 million in February, while hiring increased 120,000 to 5.818 million. The number of workers resigning rose 38,000 to 3.484 million. Economists anticipate three rate cuts this year, with financial markets predicting the first reduction in June. The unemployment rate is forecast to remain unchanged at 3.9%.

images.alt_text: The ISM says its manufacturing PMI increased to 50.3 last month, the highest and first reading above 50 since September 2022, from 47.8 in February.
Consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, jumped 0.8 per cent last month.
FILE PHOTO: Warehouse workers deal with inventory stacked up to the ceiling at an ABT Electronics Facility in Glenview, Illinois, U.S. December 4, 2018.  REUTERS/Richa Naidu
Though consumer confidence had been generally improving in recent months, still-high prices and soaring borrowing costs are weighing on Americans’ purchasing power.
Orders for durable goods, items ranging from toasters to aircraft meant to last three years or more, rose 1.4 per cent last month amid increases in transportation equipment and machinery orders.

site_title: Toyota reports 20% jump in first-quarter US auto sales
summary: Toyota Motor North America reported a 20% increase in first-quarter US auto sales, selling 565,098 vehicles in the period. The surge was driven by demand for affordable sedans, crossovers, and pickup trucks. The RAV4 crossover saw a 47.4% sales jump, while electrified vehicles, including hybrids and EVs, rose 74% to 206,850 units. These sales helped modernize long-running nameplates like the Land Cruiser and Prius models.

site_title: PC, console growth to lag pre-pandemic levels as gamers clock in fewer hours: report
summary: PC and console gaming revenue growth is expected to remain below pre-pandemic levels through 2026 due to declining playtime. Average quarterly playtime fell 26% from 2021 to 2023, and is expected to drop another 10% in January. This trend is attributed to weaker gaming release schedules and industry consolidation, with publishers cutting staff and scaling back operations. Key games like Fortnite and Roblox continue to thrive with their games-as-a-platform model, capturing 27% of all playtime last year.

images.alt_text: Game companies have been coping with layoffs, mergers and product cancellations.
The two teams Tencent has acquired involve one Shenzhen-based studio working on an action game and another East-China-based studio working on an anime game.

Apple and Epic Games, the creator of Fortnite, have been in a legal battle since 2020, when the gaming firm alleged that Apple‘s practice of charging up to 30 per cent commissions on in-app payments on its iOS devices violated US antitrust rules.
EA had forecast fourth-quarter bookings below estimates in January.

site_title: Poor nations are writing a new handbook for getting rich
summary: Developing countries, which account for 85% of the world's population, are facing challenges in maintaining economic growth. The traditional model of industrialization, which lifted hundreds of millions out of poverty, is no longer effective due to technological advancements, shifting supply chains, and rising political tensions. Automation and higher education requirements are limiting job creation, and many emerging countries are facing increased competition. Alternative models, such as service jobs and industrial policy, are being explored, but their effectiveness is uncertain. Experts warn that broad-based, large-scale, and sustainable growth is becoming increasingly difficult to achieve.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Garment industry workers block a road during a protest demanding a wage raise, in the Mirpur area of Dhaka, Bangladesh, November 12, 2023. REUTERS/Mohammad Ponir Hossain/File Photo
Migrant workers’ reluctance to return to the big factory hubs that account for about a third of the world’s manufacturing output is exacerbating long-term structural problems in China’s labour market
Bangalore’s attractiveness as a tech and engineering hub has driven up the rising cost of doing business, while manufacturing firms in particular are jostling for space.
The UN’s Global Development Index shows that 20 years of steadily narrowing inequalities between wealthy and poor nations is reversing.
US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen attends a session as part of the G20 Leaders' Summit at the Bharat Mandapam in New Delhi on September 9, 2023. (Photo by Ludovic MARIN / POOL / AFP)

site_title: Singapore’s PMI up a tad in March as region-wide factory activity improves
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector showed a modest improvement in March, with the purchasing managers' index (PMI) edging up to 50.7, marking the seventh consecutive month of expansion. The linchpin electronics sector, driven by robust global semiconductor demand, posted a faster expansion at 50.8. This improvement aligns with regional trends, with most economies recording growth in March. Experts attribute the uptick to a temporary Chinese New Year blip and expect a brighter outlook for the second quarter of 2024, driven by electronics growth and sustained demand for AI memory chips.

site_title: Understanding the mechanisms of greed and fear in markets
summary: Investors can capitalize on market trends by understanding and riding the waves of "Greed" and "Fomo" behaviors. Greed drives investors to hold onto stocks despite losses, while Fomo prompts them to enter a downtrend after it has gained momentum. By recognizing these patterns, investors can make informed decisions, such as selling during a market retreat or buying after a pullback. For example, Fomo investors can profit from the Shanghai Index's breakout, while Greed investors should be cautious of the Nikkei's uptrend due to its potential for reversal patterns.

images.alt_text: Investors should embrace the BOJ's policy pivot as a sign that the country's struggle with deflation is finally ending – a change that has positive implications for the economy.
Foreign investors have piled into the Nikkei 225, but there is still no compelling evidence that Japanese institutions and local investors are convinced.

site_title: Tesla sales fall short of estimates in first drop since 2020
summary: Tesla delivered 386,810 vehicles in the first quarter of 2024, falling short of analysts' estimate of 449,080 deliveries, marking the company's first year-over-year sales drop since 2020. The decline was attributed to factors including high interest rates, consumer demand, and production issues. Shares plummeted 5.5% to $165.54, with the stock down 33% this year. Despite this, Tesla reclaimed its title as the world's largest electric vehicle seller, surpassing China's BYD.

images.alt_text: Sotheby's Motorsport will offer a Tesla Cyberbeast electric truck for sale at an online auction beginning Apr 2.

site_title: World Bank set to issue up to US$1 billion in debut hybrid note this year
summary: The World Bank plans to issue up to $1 billion in a debut hybrid note on capital markets this year, following the African Development Bank's successful sale of a hybrid capital note in January. This move aims to boost lending and maximize balance sheets to help developing economies cope with crises, including climate change. The World Bank will be only the second multilateral lender to issue such an instrument.

images.alt_text: Mount Fuji and buildings in the Shinjuku district are reflected on a table at an observation deck in Tokyo, Japan. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

site_title: Saudi Aramco to expand huge gas plant as global demand surges
summary: Saudi Aramco awards US$7.7 billion contracts to expand the Fadhili gas processing facility in Saudi Arabia's Eastern Province, increasing its capacity to 4 billion cubic feet per day from 2.5 billion. The expansion aims to tap the kingdom's vast and under-developed gas resources as global demand surges, driven by countries seeking cleaner-burning fuels and alternative suppliers. Saudi Arabia has significant gas reserves, including the 200 trillion cubic feet Jafurah field, which will supply the domestic market and be used to produce blue hydrogen.

images.alt_text: Signage above the Saudi Aramco booth on day two of the Abu Dhabi International Petroleum Exhibition and Conference (ADIPEC) in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, on Tuesday, Oct. 3, 2023. The annual strategic energy conference runs from Oct 2-5. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

site_title: US: Wall St falls at open as health insurers, Tesla weigh
summary: Wall Street fell at the open on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 310.58 points, or 0.78%, to 39,256.27. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, hurt by losses in health insurers and Tesla. Investors await comments from Federal Reserve officials and more economic data.

site_title: Singapore to prescribe list of regulatory fees not subject to GST
summary: Singapore will prescribe a list of government fees not subject to Goods and Services Tax (GST), with an initial list to be published in April. Fees not prescribed in the list will be subject to GST, including those not currently taxed but should be. The government will absorb GST charges until end-2025, minimizing the impact of the change. The move aims to address wrongful GST charging on 18 regulatory services and ensure parity in tax treatment.

images.alt_text: The amount of GST wrongly charged to individuals and non-GST registered businesses adds up to about S$1.5 million a year, said the Ministry of Finance.

site_title: Amazon offers free credits for startups to use AI models including Anthropic
summary: Amazon has expanded its free credits program for startups to cover the costs of using major AI models from providers including Anthropic, Meta, Mistral AI, and Cohere. The move aims to boost Amazon's AI platform Bedrock's market share. The program, which has offered over $6 billion in credits since the past decade, is part of Amazon's $4 billion investment in Anthropic, allowing the AI model to use AWS as its primary cloud provider.

images.alt_text: An Amazon data centre under construction near homes in Stone Ridge, Virginia.
Anthropic is tied up with multiple big tech companies, including Google, which joined a US$450 million round of financing last May led by Spark Capital.

site_title: As great powers tussle, opportunities rise in emerging market debt
summary: Emerging markets are poised to play a pivotal role in the global economy as the US and its rivals compete for influence. Investors can find attractive yields in emerging market hard-currency sovereigns, with potential for double-digit returns. Disinflationary trends and reduced supply chain reliance on China also unlock value in foreign exchange and corporate bonds. A diversified investment strategy, focusing on resilient investment-grade and higher-quality bonds, can drive better outcomes, particularly with the macro story of high inflation fading into the rear view.

images.alt_text: TSMC, which makes integrated circuits for various products, is a good example of a company outside China that is vital for the digital revolution.

site_title: WeWork predicts US$8 billion in rent savings after bankruptcy ends
summary: WeWork, a coworking company, predicts US$8 billion in rent savings after its bankruptcy case ends, with nearly 150 locations to be abandoned and leases rewritten on 150 others. This reduction of about 40% in rent will be achieved through shrinking its real estate portfolio. WeWork has finished negotiations on 90% of its portfolio and is working on the remaining 10% to maintain its presence in buildings. The company's progress comes as it faces a proposal from co-founder Adam Neumann to buy back the company, which is at odds with a previous deal with SoftBank Group and existing creditors.

images.alt_text: The receivership comes as WeWork retrenches following its US bankruptcy filing last year.
The beleaguered company needs the funds mainly to pay rent on office spaces used by its customers.

site_title: Lego billionaires’ cash pile grows as portfolio swings to profit
summary: The Kirkbi group, owner of the Lego empire, reported a 5.9% rise in profits to 11.3 billion kroner (S$2.2 billion) in 2023, driven by a turnaround in its investment portfolio. The entity's total assets declined 1.4% to US$23.5 billion, with Sofie Kirk Kristiansen, a great-granddaughter of Lego's founder, selling shares worth close to US$1 billion for private investments. The group's investment activities swung to a profit of 3.66 billion kroner in 2023, with fixed income and real estate portfolios showing strong returns.

images.alt_text: Lego has expanded its position as the world’s No 1 toymaker, growing consumer sales 4 per cent in 2023 when the overall market contracted about 7 per cent.
Lego Fortnite is part of a larger strategy by Epic to create more virtual worlds where gamers can socialise and play.
Kirkbi's assets have swelled to about 166 billion kroner, mainly driven by rising profits at Lego, which has grown to become the world’s largest toy company.

site_title: German manufacturing contracts sharply in March
summary: Germany's manufacturing sector continued to contract in the first quarter of 2024, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 41.9 in March from 42.5 in February. Weak demand and factory job losses contributed to the decline, but surveyed businesses expressed optimism about growth prospects in the next 12 months, particularly in the second half of the year.

site_title: German inflation slows further as ECB readies June rate cut
summary: German inflation slowed further in March, with consumer prices rising 2.3% annually, down from 2.7% in February. This easing supports expectations of the European Central Bank's interest rate cut in June. Food costs drove the slowdown, while price gains accelerated in Italy and Spain. A broad weakening of inflation suggests the ECB can prepare for a rate cut in June, with Eurozone data expected to show a dip to 2.5%. However, underlying inflation concerns persist due to labor-market resilience and wage gains.

images.alt_text: Weak demand contributed to further factory job losses and a sustained draw-down of pre-production inventories.
The office said the number of unemployed grew by 4,000 in seasonally adjusted terms to 2.719 million.
Retail sales decreased by 1.9 per cent compared with the previous month in real terms.

site_title: The tech giants are eating the chatbot kings
summary: Tech giants like Microsoft and Google are acquiring and licensing foundation models from startups like Inflection, further concentrating power in Silicon Valley. However, open-source AI firms are gaining momentum, offering a better alternative. French startups like Mistral and Hugging Face are providing free access to AI models, allowing entrepreneurs to customize and inspect the technology. This shift could lead to more innovation and a more democratic AI landscape, as open-source models are more likely to be improved and made safer through community involvement.

images.alt_text: The unusual deal resembled an “acqui-hire” – but without an acquisition.
Pricey chips : The costs of doing business are too high for AI startups to survive on their own.

site_title: US dollar hits 5-month high while jawboning supports yen
summary: The US dollar reached a 5-month high against the yen on April 2, driven by stronger-than-expected economic data and reduced expectations for a June rate cut. The dollar index rose to 105.1, while the euro fell to its lowest level since mid-February. Japanese officials, fearing intervention, slowed the dollar's gains, and the yen traded flat at 151.67 per dollar. The Swiss franc hit its lowest level since November, and China's yuan fell to a 4½-month low.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Other major retail banks to introduce ‘money lock’ by mid-2024; activated for 78,000 accounts so far
summary: Singapore's "money lock" feature, which allows customers to set aside funds to prevent digital transfer in case of account compromise, has been activated on over 78,000 accounts and protects over S$6.6 billion in savings. The feature, launched by DBS, OCBC, and UOB, aims to mitigate losses from scams. By mid-2024, other major retail banks will join, and the government plans to implement the Shared Responsibility Framework for phishing scams later this year.

images.alt_text: Launched by the local banks in November, the feature helps to mitigate losses if a customer’s digital access to bank accounts is compromised.
Customers who wish to access locked-up funds in an existing account will need to personally visit a DBS/POSB branch to verify their identity before they can withdraw or transfer the funds.
Generic photo of OCBC signage
DBS customers can soon enable the digiVault function on their existing bank accounts, without needing to open a separate account.
OCBC and UOB customers can lock their savings from Thursday; DBS is rolling out a locked account by Dec 7.

site_title: Tesla Cyberbeast heads to auction in first test of resale value
summary: A Tesla Cyberbeast electric truck is set to be sold at an online auction by Sotheby's Motorsport starting April 2, with a starting bid of $75,000. The vehicle, which is the first to be offered at public auction, is expected to easily surpass the manufacturer's suggested retail price of $99,990. The no-reserve auction format allows the vehicle to sell at any price, potentially leading to a sale price above $100,000. The sale is seen as a test of the resale value of the Cyberbeast.

images.alt_text: In China, Tesla is struggling to keep pace with BYD, which became the world’s top-selling EV maker at the end of last year.

The logo of NIO seen on an EL6 car model is pictured at the NIO House, the showroom of the Chinese premium smart electric vehicle manufacture NIO Inc. in Berlin, Germany August 17, 2023. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse
The Chinese company’s existing partnership with Ford Motor will be the model for similar cooperation with other US carmakers, the report says.
Tesla is up against increasingly stiff competition in China, not only from homegrown competitor BYD but a raft of other EV manufacturers churning out more affordable, tech-laden vehicles.

site_title: Singapore hotels’ average room rate rises in February as tourist arrivals inch higher
summary: Singapore hotels' average room rate rose 6.7% to S$298.47 in February, driven by an increase in international tourist arrivals, which edged up to 1,436,571. China overtook Indonesia as the top source of visitors, with 326,967 arrivals, and India dropped out of the top five. Hotel room revenue and occupancy rate also increased, with RevPAR rising 14.2% to S$247.70.
