The growth is attributed to seasonal effects from the Chinese New Year and the implementation of a Singapore-China mutual 30-day visa-free scheme.

images.alt_text: Hotel average room rates were mixed across categories in January, with the luxury, upscale and mid-tier segments recording sequential increases, but the economy segment rate falling.
Indonesia is the largest source of tourists to Singapore in January, followed by China, Australia, Malaysia and India.

site_title: China’s ICBC to provide 300-billion yuan in tourism financing
summary: China's Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) signed a cooperation pact with the culture and tourism ministry to provide 300-billion yuan in financing to boost the nation's tourism sector. This move aims to stimulate tourism investment and spending, which has been a rare economic bright spot despite sluggish consumer spending. Tourism trips in China saw a 93.3% increase last year, with spending reaching 4.91 trillion yuan, a year-on-year increase of 140.3%. The partnership will focus on key tourism-related construction projects and support agencies in several Asian cities.

images.alt_text: ICBC's profit of 363.99 billion yuan (S$67.9 billion) slightly exceeded an estimate of 359 billion yuan in a poll of 19 analysts.
Authorities are struggling to arrest a slowdown in China’s property market, which saw new home sales last month tumble 34.2 per cent from a year earlier.
The Fed fines ICBC’s New York branch US$2.4 million for its “unauthorised use and disclosure of confidential supervisory information.

The rating action for financial institutions including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China is primarily driven by the change in outlook to negative from stable on the government’s credit ratings, according to Moody’s.

site_title: HDB flat rents rose 10% in 2023, stabilising from 35% surge in 2022: Indranee
summary: HDB flat rents in Singapore rose 10% in 2023, stabilizing from a 35% surge in 2022, according to Second Minister for National Development Indranee Rajah. The increase was attributed to the recovery of non-resident rental demand following the opening up of border restrictions in 2022. This marks a significant decrease from the 5% average year-on-year increase in 2021.

images.alt_text: When it comes to renting, 4-room HDB flats and 2-bedroom condo units are the most popular among tenants.
Resale volumes and prices book marginal improvements in February from the month before.
Luqman Hakim, chief data and analytics officer at 99.co, says the price growth in February 2024 is "much more modest" compared to the previous month.

site_title: Singapore stocks track regional gains on Tuesday; STI rises 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.4% to 3,247.72, tracking regional gains, with gainers outnumbering losers 332 to 247. The top gainer, Wilmar International, closed up 2.3%, while shares of Best World International rose 4.1% after announcing a selective capital reduction. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also ended the day higher, with DBS adding 0.8%, OCBC up 0.6%, and UOB gaining 0.7%.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.6 per cent to 39,566.85, while the broad-based S&P 500 shed 0.2 per cent to 5,243.77 on Monday.
Best World says it will take no further action relating to the Mar 21 requisition letter.

site_title: Indonesia’s economic diplomacy set to maintain course under Prabowo
summary: Indonesia's president-elect Prabowo Subianto is set to maintain the country's economic diplomacy with China, prioritizing alignment with Beijing's development strategies and fostering strategic cooperation. Following his meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping, Prabowo pledged to maintain stronger ties with China, focusing on infrastructure, security, and poverty alleviation. Analysts expect Prabowo to continue Indonesia's balance between supporting the US and China, keeping tensions in check as they rise. This approach is seen as a continuation of outgoing President Joko Widodo's policy, which has raised bilateral relations with China to the highest level in history.

images.alt_text: On a monthly basis, consumer prices rose 0.52 per cent, reflecting rising demand during the Islamic holy month of Ramadan, which started on March 12 in the country, the statistics bureau said.

site_title: Bank of China says net interest margin will continue to face pressure
summary: Bank of China's net interest margin (NIM) is expected to face significant pressure this year due to reduced benchmark lending rates and existing mortgage rates. The bank aims to reduce high-cost deposits and control costs from deposit interest rates. Following similar trends, other Chinese lenders have posted shrinking NIMs, with ongoing property sector risks a concern. Experts suggest there's room for further cuts to benchmark lending rates this year.

site_title: Chinese EV makers post strong showing in March after slow start
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) makers reported strong sales in March, with BYD jumping 46% year-over-year to 302,459 vehicles. Other Chinese automakers, Li Auto, Nio, and Xpeng, also saw double-digit sales gains. Tesla, despite being the world's largest EV producer, is estimated to deliver 449,080 vehicles in the first quarter, down 7% from the previous quarter. The robust performance of Chinese brands comes after a quiet start to 2024, with discounts and subsidies offered by competitors.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi has advised potential buyers of its sedan that they could face wait times of four to seven months, a sign of strong interest.
Xiaomi built a Beijing factory capable of producing 200,000 cars annually before it had regulatory approval to start manufacturing in China.

Mini EVs being charged on a street in Liuzhou, in China's Guangxi province. These tiny vehicles weave through traffic in southern China, their cheerful designs bringing a touch of colour to the EV revolution in the country.
BYD aims to sell 500,000 vehicles overseas this year, more than double last year’s total, and one million units in 2025, chairman Wang Chuanfu says.
Nio expects to deliver around 30,000 vehicles in the first quarter of 2024, compared with its prior forecast of 31,000 to 33,000.
Net profit totalled 8.67 billion yuan (S$1.6 billion) in the fourth quarter, on a 15.1 per cent jump in revenue to 180.04 billion yuan.

site_title: UBS pledges US$2 billion in new buyback plan starting this year
summary: UBS Group has announced a new US$2 billion share buyback program starting April 3, 2024, with the goal of exceeding pre-acquisition levels by 2026. The program, initially set for two years, will begin after the merger with Credit Suisse in the second quarter. This follows the bank's announcement in February to boost cost-saving goals and confirm profitability targets through 2026, despite posting two consecutive quarterly losses.

site_title: Blackstone eyes US$300 million IPO of India diamond certification firm
summary: Blackstone is exploring a $300 million initial public offering (IPO) of the International Gemological Institute (IGI), a diamond certification firm, amid booming Indian stock markets. IGI, acquired by Blackstone in May 2023 for $570 million, is the world's largest independent lab for testing and grading diamonds and other gemstones. The IPO deal has been led by investment banks Morgan Stanley and Kotak, with Blackstone seeking a valuation of up to $3.5 billion.

images.alt_text: The Blackstone headquarters in New York, US, on Monday, Jan. 8, 2024. Blackstone Inc. released earnings figures on January 25. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg
The Blackstone headquarters in New York. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: US home insurance premiums may hit a record this year
summary: US homeowners insurance premiums are expected to reach a record high of $2,522 by the end of 2024, driven by intensifying natural disasters, rising reinsurance costs, and higher fees for home repair. The average premium is a 6% increase from last year and follows a 20% rise over the past two years. States prone to severe weather events, such as Florida, are expected to see significant increases, with premiums rising by 7% in Florida to $11,759. The rising cost of insurance is making housing costs more unpredictable, with some experts warning that the highest-risk areas may become uninsurable.

images.alt_text: The new paper treats heat waves as distinct weather patterns that move along air currents, just as storms do.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, April 2, 2024 (Ep 34)
summary: Hong Kong shares rallied on strong Chinese factory data, while Isetan Singapore shares surged 147.5% after a proposed privatization announcement. UOB will cut One account interest rates effective May 1, with DBS and OCBC maintaining similar rates. The Singapore stock market opened flat, with the STI remaining unchanged.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Tuesday.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers

Tokyo-listed Isetan Mitsukoshi is looking to take Isetan Singapore private by fully acquiring all the shares it does not own, ending the departmental store operator’s four-decade run on the Singapore bourse
The reduced interest rates will come into effect on May 1, and are applicable to all new and existing UOB One accounts.

site_title: UK factories report first growth in nearly 2 years
summary: The UK manufacturing sector reported its first growth in nearly 2 years, with the S&P Global/CIPS UK Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 50.3 in March, up from February's 47.5. This marks the first time the survey has exceeded the 50 threshold for growth since July 2022. The growth is attributed to recovering demand in the UK home market.

images.alt_text: Commuters pass the Bank of England (BOE) in the City of London, UK, on Tuesday, Jan. 23, 2024. The Bank of England is being urged to end its bias toward further interest-rate hikes or risk undermining its own credibility, in what’s likely to be a tricky communication challenge for Governor Andrew Bailey. Photographer: Jose Sarmento Matos/Bloomberg

site_title: MAS tightens grip on digital payment token service providers with new user protection measures
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched new measures to regulate digital payment token (DPT) service providers, aiming to combat money laundering and terrorism financing. The updated Payment Services Act will impose user protection and financial stability-related requirements on DPT service providers, including provisions for custodial services, cross-border money transfers, and asset protection. Entities must notify MAS within 30 days and submit a licence application within six months to continue activities temporarily. Failure to comply will result in cessation of activities.

images.alt_text: OCBC, UOB, DBS, Citibank, HSBC and Standard Chartered are participating financial institutions on MAS' new Cosmic platform in its initial phase.
All retail banks with a full banking licence and finance companies are members of the Deposit Insurance Scheme, which protects a depositor's money up to an aggregate limit of S$100,000 per depositor.
Ant International hopes to leverage its ecosystem to help MSMEs improve the accuracy of their sustainability reports.
Beyond the upcoming meeting in April, economists remain split on the central bank’s moves for the rest of the year.
The Bill will expand provisions that allow for the transfer of evidence between MAS, the police and other law enforcement agencies.

site_title: Singapore must not view residents and foreigners as ‘zero-sum game’ for jobs: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Tan See Leng emphasized the need to remain open to complementary foreign labor to meet the demands of the growing economy and businesses, despite the country's slowing resident workforce growth. He stated that locals will have better job opportunities and wages if businesses have access to "complementary foreign talent." The minister stressed that a zero-sum game approach would be misguided, and that thriving businesses with foreign talent will lead to more job creation and improved wage outcomes.

images.alt_text: Employers’ increased flexibility and openness to a wider talent pool has made them better able to fill vacancies, resulting in the proportion of harder-to-fill spots trending down, says MOM.
The ratio of job vacancies to unemployed persons, at 1.74, has been rising since March 2021 when it was 0.96, indicating a “moderately tight labour market”, said MOM.

site_title: 5 classical music albums you can listen to right now
summary: Classical music experts recommend five albums to listen to, including Julia Perry's Violin Concerto, a collection of Aaron Copland works conducted by Copland himself, and a programme of songs by Black composers. The album features the Experiential Orchestra under conductor James Blachly and violinist Curtis Stewart. This recording aims to revive Perry's works, which fell into obscurity after her death in 1979. The album is part of recent efforts to revive the music of underrepresented composers.

images.alt_text: Technology has transformed the music industry, making it possible for anyone to create music on a phone, tablet or laptop.
Hybe, based in Seoul, has been releasing more English songs for K-pop bands and promoting artists including Jung Kook in the United States.
Madonna has additionally taken on acting, film directing and various business ventures over the years.
UOB says credit card applications among 25- to 29-year-olds are up four percentage points from Jun 21 to Jul 7

site_title: KPMG’s 40 years auditing for one asset manager is plenty, thanks
summary: KPMG has audited Aberdeen Asset Management (Abrdn) for nearly 40 years, first starting in 1983, despite the company's repeated assurances that the long-standing relationship does not compromise auditor independence. Abrdn's latest annual report highlights the relationship, which began after the company merged with Standard Life in 2017. Critics argue that the lengthy tenure undermines the company's ability to push for governance improvements, and regulators are urging Abrdn to tender its audit every 10 years to ensure independence.

images.alt_text: The case against turning the big four into a biggish eight is far from open and shut, not least as the commercial logic of the split is in many ways getting more compelling.
Long auditor-client relationships a threat to independence

site_title: Can Japan’s stock market scale new highs?
summary: Japan's stock market has reached a new all-time high of 40,888.43, surpassing its previous peak in 1989. The Bank of Japan's interest rate hike signals an end to deflation, boosting the economy and encouraging wage growth, which in turn promotes economic growth. Higher wages also motivate domestic investors to explore riskier investments, such as equities, supporting equity prices. The monetary environment remains supportive of Japanese equities, with the BOJ maintaining an accommodative stance, and long-term structural drivers like corporate reforms and the revival of Japan as a semiconductor powerhouse driving growth.

images.alt_text: Foreign investors have piled into the Nikkei 225, but there is still no compelling evidence that Japanese institutions and local investors are convinced.
Rapidus is teaming up with researchers at IBM as well as its own experts in nanotechnology and materials to close the gap with TSMC in cutting-edge fabrication technology.

The yen has been on a downtrend despite the Bank of Japan’s decision last month to end eight years of negative interest rates, as traders interpreted its dovish language as signalling that the next rate hike will be some time away.

site_title: Baltimore disaster again highlights fragility of global logistics chain
summary: A catastrophic event occurred when the Singapore-flagged cargo ship Dali hit the collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore, Maryland, resulting in deaths and significant economic damages. The incident highlights the fragility of the global logistics chain, which has been exacerbated by recent disruptions such as the near-closure of the Suez route and drought conditions affecting the Panama Canal. This event serves as a reminder of the vulnerabilities of "just-in-time" logistics, underscoring the need for improved supply chain resilience.

images.alt_text: Having AI on the bridge might help vessels avoid collisions, but manning levels and fatigue are big issues that need addressing.

site_title: Eurozone factory downturn deepens in March
summary: Eurozone manufacturing activity contracted further in March, with the Eurozone manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dipping to 46.1 from 46.5 in February. Demand continued to fall, but optimism improved, with the output PMI rising to 47.1. The contraction marked a 21st month below the 50 mark, which denotes growth. Despite factories cutting prices at the fastest pace since November, new orders fell for a 23rd month. The European Central Bank may welcome news of easing inflationary pressures, which could help bring inflation back to target.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign outside the European Central Bank building in Frankfurt, Germany October 27, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo
The recovery was uneven with a strong rebound in services activity offsetting a more severe downturn in manufacturing.

A worker standing at a construction site in Vienna. There is no denying that lists of the top global technology companies, the world’s top universities, or semiconductor manufacturing capacity, tend to show Europe falling behind.

A worker moves equipment and materials on a cart at the factory of Schuko H. Schulte-Sdhoff GmbH, a manufacturer of extraction systems for the the craft and industrial sectors, in Bad Laer, Germany, on Friday, May 26, 2023. Without a major shift, Germany’s labor force will shrink dramatically in the coming years, undermining economic growth, boosting inflation pressures and posing especially tough challenges to the manufacturing firms like Schuko that are the backbone of Europe's biggest economy. Photographer: Ben Kilb/Bloomberg

site_title: Crypto’s memecoin fervour stalls as bets on Fed rate cuts recede
summary: Crypto's speculative fervour has stalled as bets on Fed rate cuts recede. The US market's challenging monetary policy path has led to a decline in smaller digital assets, with coins favored by meme-traders such as Pepe and dogwifhat experiencing significant drops. Bitcoin has shed 6% since reaching a record high in mid-March, and its value has fallen by 1.5% from the prior trading session. The decline is attributed to investors curbing wagers on looser Federal Reserve monetary settings, posing an obstacle for speculative markets like crypto.

images.alt_text: Competition for crypto traders in South-east Asia’s second-biggest economy is heating up, with both Binance and Kasikornbank making moves to grab market share from Bitkub in the past six months.
The BlackRock USD Institutional Digital Liquidity Fund invests in cash, US Treasury bills and repurchase agreements.
The approval of spot Bitcoin ETFs have helped push a more favourable view of the cryptocurrency among Singapore residents according to a survey by crypto exchange, Independent Reserve.

site_title: World Bank raises Sri Lanka's growth forecast to 2.2% for 2024
summary: The World Bank has raised its forecast for Sri Lanka's economy to 2.2% for 2024, a 50 basis point increase, following a faster-than-expected recovery from its worst financial crisis in decades. The country secured a $2.9 billion IMF bailout, which helped stabilize its economy. The forecast also expects growth to strengthen to 2.5% in 2025, with modest recoveries in reserves, remittances, and tourism. However, the poverty rate is expected to remain above 22% until 2026, with households impoverished by high inflation and losses in wages and employment.

images.alt_text: China, the world’s and Sri Lanka’s biggest sovereign creditor, pledged to support the island nation to take forward its debt restructuring plan during Sri Lankan Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena’s visit to Beijing last month.

Signage at a China Petroleum & Chemical Corp. (Sinopec) gas station in Hong Kong, China, on Thursday, March 21, 2024. Sinopec is scheduled to release earnings on March 24. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg
A view of Colombo Port shows the red and white gantries of the South Asia Gateway container handling terminal in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Monday, Jan. 29, 2007.

site_title: Germany's BMW, India's Tata Tech to jointly develop auto software
summary: BMW and Tata Technologies have formed a 50-50 joint venture to develop automotive software for automated driving and dashboard systems. The partnership will operate in Chennai, Bengaluru, and Pune with 100 employees. Tata Technologies, a unit of Tata Motors, will provide engineering and technology services to auto, aero, and heavy machinery firms, while BMW will utilize its manufacturing plant in Chennai and engines supplied by Force Motors. The venture aims to enhance BMW's software capabilities, with no disclosed financial details.

images.alt_text: The pricey ownership rights are the result of a quota system that controls the number of autos allowed on the nation’s streets, helping limit congestion and pollution, through the twice-a-month bidding process.

site_title: UK shop inflation tumbles in another positive sign for rate cuts
summary: UK store inflation has dropped to its lowest level in over two years, falling to 1.3% in March, as supermarkets compete to lure shoppers with low prices. Food price inflation eased to 3.7%, its lowest since April 2022, amid a 10th consecutive month of decline. The findings suggest slowing headline inflation, raising hopes for interest rate cuts. However, retailers face increased cost pressures, including higher property taxes and minimum wage, which could put progress on reducing inflation at risk.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England is closely watching to see whether higher wages will stoke inflationary pressures, potentially delaying interest rate cuts.
Forming closer trade ties with countries outside the EU was touted by Brexiteers.

Britain's latest GDP figures will be disappointing for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, who has been accused by the opposition Labour Party – far ahead in opinion polls – of overseeing “Rishi’s recession”.

site_title: Best World shareholders withdraw requisition notice
summary: A group of Best World shareholders withdrawing its requisition letter, seeking to table six resolutions regarding the company's dividend policy, directors' pay, and other matters, has withdrawn its notice. The letter, served on March 21, called for an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to consider the resolutions. Best World will take no further action relating to the letter "at the present time" and will instead consider the concerns and reserve the right to issue the requisitions again in the future.

images.alt_text: Best World Q4 profit up 231% at S$12.3m; proposes 2-for-1 share split
In a bourse filing, Best World said it intends to obtain approval for the selective capital reduction at an extraordinary general meeting.
Best World's net profit jumps in Q1

site_title: RBA to switch to new system for monetary policy implementation
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has decided to transition to a new system for implementing monetary policy, which will involve ample reserves and full allotment repurchase agreements. This decision aims to strike a balance between operating with a smaller balance sheet and reducing financial stability risks. The new system will be similar to those used by the Bank of England, European Central Bank, and Swedish Riksbank. The RBA expects to see increased cash market activity and potential pressures in other money markets, but expects banks to respond by borrowing more at OMO repo auctions.

images.alt_text: australia home housing Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg
Most economists now believe the RBA is done hiking – and that the next move will see rates move down.
The RBA has estimated less than 1 per cent of all housing loans are 90 or more days in arrears and less than 2 per cent of high-leveraged borrowers are in arrears.

site_title: Japan stock market needs buy-in by domestic institutions, investors
summary: Japan's stock market is heavily reliant on foreign investors, who have driven the Nikkei 225's performance. However, domestic institutions and local investors remain unconvinced. The Bank of Japan's recent interest rate hike, the first in 17 years, aims to combat deflation and boost wages, which have stagnated for over 30 years. The move is expected to encourage Japanese corporates to increase capital expenditure, driven by higher consumer spending and a competitive yen. This could mark a historic shift, potentially lifting consumer spending and prices in a sustainable manner.

images.alt_text: Nikkei 225 Stock Average’s jump above 40,000 to all-time highs has led to Japanese individuals betting on more gains.

site_title: Hong Kong mall operator Lifestyle seeks up to HK$8 billion loan
summary: Lifestyle International Holdings, a Hong Kong mall operator, is in talks with banks to refinance a HK$6.95 billion, two-year loan backing a retail project at the Kai Tak development. The loan, if signed, would be in the HK$7 billion to HK$8 billion range. The company's flagship department store, The Twins, has faced delays since its original opening two years ago. Lifestyle International has about US$1.2 billion in loans and bonds due in 2024, amid Hong Kong's retail sector facing headwinds due to local departures and spending power declines.

images.alt_text: Developers are counting on the pickup in sales to reduce excess inventories that are keeping a lid on prices.

site_title: Vistara, co-owned by SIA, cancels over 50 flights as India’s aviation authorities keep tabs
summary: Vistara, a co-owned airline by Singapore Airlines, has cancelled over 50 flights and delayed around 160 as it grapples with a pilot shortage. The airline is expected to cancel up to 70 flights on Tuesday. The shortage has led to an increasing number of pilots reporting sick, protesting a revised salary structure ahead of the merger with Tata-owned Air India. India's civil aviation ministry is monitoring the situation and has asked Vistara to submit daily information on flight disruptions to ensure passenger facilitation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Vistara passenger aircraft taxis on the tarmac at Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport in Mumbai, India, May 29, 2023. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo
An United Airlines Airbus A319 taxis in Chicago International Airport (ORD) in Chicago, Illinois on January 18, 2024. (Photo by Daniel SLIM / AFP)
China Southern’s international route network has to date recovered to 80 per cent of 2019 levels.

site_title: Former head of Chinese automaker JAC under investigation, anti-graft watchdog says
summary: Former chairman of Chinese automaker Jianghuai Automobile Group (JAC), An Jin, is under investigation by China's anti-graft watchdog for "serious violations of discipline and law." An Jin, who served as chairman for nine years, retired in 2021 after 46 years with the state-owned automaker. The investigation's details remain undisclosed, but the case has sparked concerns about the business operations of JAC, which partners with Volkswagen and Chinese electric car firm Nio. A spokesperson for Volkswagen said the investigation has had no impact on its business activities with JAC.

images.alt_text: Mahathir Mohamad on Nov. 1. Photographer: Sanjit Das/Bloomberg
A building under construction and owned by Van Thinh Phat group, chaired by tycoon Truong My Lan, in Ho Chi Minh City.
Former Malaysia Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin arrives to give a statement to the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) in Putrajaya, Malaysia March 9, 2023. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain
China’s economy is struggling to regain momentum as confidence has cratered among domestic consumers and international investors.
Muhammad Adlan Berhan faces several charges for criminal breach of trust according to Malaysia's Anti-Corruption agency.

site_title: Shares in Chinese developer Country Garden suspended in Hong Kong
summary: Trading in shares of Chinese property developer Country Garden was suspended in Hong Kong on April 2, pending the publication of its 2023 Annual Results. The move comes amid concerns over the stability of China's economy, which has been battered by a crisis in the country's property sector. Country Garden, one of China's largest developers, has incurred debts estimated at 1.36 trillion yuan and has defaulted on offshore payments. The suspension is the latest in a series of challenges faced by the company, which has also postponed its earnings report.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The company logo of Chinese developer Country Garden is pictured at the Shanghai Country Garden Center in Shanghai, China August 9, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
Country Garden's operations focus on smaller cities, which expand faster in good times but have been harder hit by the housing slump and economic slowdown.
Overall housing sales declined 6.5 per cent in 2023 from the previous year and 35.9 per cent from the industry high in 2021.
Country Garden expects to delay publishing the 2023 results beyond a Mar 31 deadline.

Kroll, the New York-headquartered financial advisory firm, is expected to conduct an independent business review of Country Garden before projecting a recovery rate for the developer’s creditors under a liquidation scenario.
Homebuyers in China are avoiding defaulted developers on concerns about their ability to complete housing projects.

site_title: UK house prices rise by most since Dec 2022
summary: UK house prices rose 1.6% in March compared to a year earlier, the fastest increase since December 2022. Despite economists expecting a 0.3% rise, prices actually fell 0.2% in March, the first drop since December 2023. The 1.1% increase in the first quarter is the fastest three-month rise since July 2022. This rise is attributed to increased activity after a weak period in 2023, but remains subdued compared to historic standards.

site_title: Asia: Hong Kong rally leads markets, traders assess Fed rate plans
summary: Hong Kong led Asian markets higher on Tuesday as traders returned from a weekend break, boosted by forecast-beating Chinese factory data. The data lifted hopes for China's economy, which has struggled since the lifting of zero-Covid measures. However, a stronger-than-expected US manufacturing reading and higher prices paid kept sentiment in check, sparking questions about the Federal Reserve's interest rate plans. Markets now expect about 65 basis points of rate cuts this year, lower than the Fed's guidance of 75 points.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.1 per cent to 7,902.80 by 0040 GMT, extending gains to hit a record high.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.6 per cent to 39,566.85, while the broad-based S&P 500 shed 0.2 per cent to 5,243.77 on Monday.

site_title: Shell back in court in landmark Dutch climate case
summary: Shell is defending itself in a Dutch appeals court after a landmark 2021 ruling ordered the oil giant to reduce its carbon emissions by 45% by 2030, as it was contributing to climate change. Environmental groups, including Friends of the Earth, accuse Shell of failing to implement the ruling, while Shell claims the case is ineffective in addressing climate change. The court is expected to deliver a decision within three months, which could have far-reaching consequences for Dutch business and employment.

images.alt_text: Pressure is mounting to scrap Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's signature climate policy.
The new paper treats heat waves as distinct weather patterns that move along air currents, just as storms do.
Japan has become a difficult market for companies that need green electricity to meet internal emissions targets and customer demands.

Flowing water from a melting iceberg in Scoresby Fjord, Greenland, August 12, 2023. Since 1990, melting ice in Greenland and Antarctica has slowed down the Earth’s rotation, a study found. This has delayed the need for a negative leap second until at least 2029.
Investing in companies that mitigate climate change can not only safeguard the tangible assets that HNWIs enjoy but also help preserve the assets for their heirs.

site_title: Foreign direct investment into China plummets to 23-year low
summary: Foreign direct investment (FDI) into China plummeted to a 23-year low of $42.7 billion in 2023, a significant decline from $177 billion in 2022. The decline is attributed to strict measures to control the Covid pandemic and growing geopolitical tensions with the US. Despite this, surveys indicate that investment confidence may be on the mend, with 50% of German businesses planning to increase investment in China and 5% more US companies considering the country a top three global investment priority.

images.alt_text: Economic data over the January-to-February period and a factory owners survey for March offer relief to Chinese policymakers seeking to convince foreign investors.
China is suffering from its own version of the “Solow paradox”: you can see a new technological age everywhere but in the productivity statistics.
Citi last week raised its forecast for China’s 2024 growth to 5.0 per cent from 4.6 per cent, citing “recent positive data and policy delivery”.
Recent indicators suggest a stabilisation in China, but overall gains remain tempered by the persistent fragility in the property market.

site_title: Freehold GCB site housing two bungalows in Caldecott Hill for sale at S$62.8 million
summary: A freehold Good Class Bungalow (GCB) site in Caldecott Hill, housing two bungalows, is on sale for S$62.8 million, translating to a land rate of about S$1,599 psf. The site, purchased in the 1960s by a prominent diamond merchant, has been rebuilt around 2000 and is located on a quiet cul-de-sac. The property is highly sought after by ultra-high-net-worth individuals and could be redeveloped into a single massive GCB or subdivided into two separate GCBs.

images.alt_text: Former Caldecott Broadcast Centre to be redeveloped into 15 leasehold GCB plots

site_title: Hong Kong a ghost town over Easter with record jaunts to China
summary: Hong Kong experienced a record 9.3 million departures in March, with 10% more residents leaving the city for Macau and mainland China during the Easter holiday. The city's bars, restaurants, and shopping hotspots were largely empty, with dining-in business estimated to have fallen 40% from last year. This year's Easter tourist arrivals in Hong Kong from mainland China and Macau plummeted 46% from 2019. The exodus underscores Hong Kong's struggles with an economic slowdown, weaker yuan, high rents, and limited entertainment options.

images.alt_text: Originally planned for opening two years ago, Lifestyle’s flagship department store The Twins at the eastern Kowloon area of Kai Tak has faced delays.
Developers are counting on the pickup in sales to reduce excess inventories that are keeping a lid on prices.

site_title: Hong Kong new home sales hit 11-year high after property curbs removed
summary: Hong Kong's new home sales surged to an 11-year high in March, with 4,170 transactions, more than 14 times the prior month's figure. The government's removal of property curbs in late February is credited with the pickup in sales, as developers aim to reduce excess inventories and boost prices. The increase in sales is seen as an encouraging sign for the property market, which has been struggling after the curbs were lifted.

images.alt_text: Secretary of State Antony Blinken says the Department of State is announcing that it is taking steps to impose new visa restrictions on multiple Hong Kong officials.
The city’s property developers are under pressure to offload their inventory, after the past year’s weak market led to the accumulation of unsold apartments.
By 2046, more than one in three Hong Kong residents will be 65 or older.

site_title: China topples US as South-east Asia’s favoured partner, survey shows
summary: China has surpassed the US as the top favored partner in South-east Asia, according to a survey of 1,994 individuals. China's popularity increased from 38.9% to 50.5% in 2024, with three out of four votes in Muslim-majority Malaysia, Indonesia, and Brunei. The survey attributes the shift to China's rising influence and the US's declining confidence, citing the escalating rivalry between the two nations. This marks a significant shift in regional dynamics, with China now the preferred alignment choice for South-east Asians.

images.alt_text: China is suffering from its own version of the “Solow paradox”: you can see a new technological age everywhere but in the productivity statistics.

site_title: Cocoa hits record even with hedge funds least bullish since 2022
summary: Cocoa prices reached a record high on Monday, with the most-active contract in New York rising 4.4% to $10,193 a tonne. Hedge funds have cut their bullish bets to the lowest in 17 months, as commercial traders played a key role in the rally. Despite a technical gauge showing prices may have skyrocketed too quickly, many analysts believe the market is not yet at its peak. The global supply deficit is expected to persist, with West African growers facing poor crops, and physical buyers may be driving the rally.

images.alt_text: Cocoa prices have more than trebled over the last year as disease and adverse weather pushed the global market to a third successive deficit.
Long the world's undisputed cocoa powerhouses, Ghana and Ivory Coast are both facing catastrophic harvests this season.
FILE PHOTO: An employee shows a Hershey's chocolate bar made in USA in the "American lifestyle" store in Berlin, Germany, August 13, 2018. REUTERS/Fabrizio Bensch/File Photo

site_title: Australia: Shares hit record high; RBA cautious on inflation
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index reached a record high of 7,902.80, driven by gains in mining stocks. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) minutes showed no discussion of interest rate hikes, maintaining caution on inflation. Mining giants like BHP and Rio Tinto advanced, while gold stocks rose 2.6% after record-high bullion prices. Energy stocks also rose 1.2% as oil prices increased.

images.alt_text: Prospects for US offshore wind remain uncertain due to inflation and supply-chain issues.
australia home housing Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg
Key tenants of the office building include the Australian Taxation Office and the Bank of Queensland.
China's tariffs on Australian wine, some of them as high as 218 per cent, will be lifted over the course of Friday.

site_title: Singapore stocks open flat on Tuesday; STI remains unchanged
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) remaining unchanged at 3,234.91. Losers outnumbered gainers 58 to 57, and 80.6 million securities worth S$39.6 million changed hands. Seatrium was the most traded counter, rising 1.2% to S$0.088. The US market's subdued performance influenced the Singapore market, following a mix of strong US manufacturing data and inflation worries.

images.alt_text: Japan’s Isetan Mitsukoshi looks to take Isetan Singapore private.

site_title: Gold holds ground as easing US Treasury yields lift appeal
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $2,250.26 per ounce on Tuesday, as US Treasury yields eased, lifting the appeal of zero-yield gold. The metal had reached a record high of $2,265.49 on Monday amid expectations of a potential interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve in June. US manufacturing data showed growth for the first time in 1.5 years, but employment remained subdued. Gold prices were also supported by weak inflation pressures in the US and mixed factory activity in Asian economies.

images.alt_text: Gold is one of market watchers' top picks, as they expect central bank demand to remain strong while the downside risks for the previous yellow metal are limited.
The US dollar was down 0.1 per cent against its rivals, making gold more appealing for other currency holders.

site_title: Shares of China Vanke slump after disappointing earnings, payout cut
summary: China Vanke shares plummeted 11.1% in early trading after reporting a 50.6% drop in 2023 core profit and no dividend payout. The company aims to boost cash flow by slashing debt and increasing income from non-property businesses. Investors have been dumping shares and bonds due to cash flow concerns, prompting a central government directive to help the company. Analysts expressed disappointment and cautioned on sustained underperformance due to contracted sales and earnings deterioration.

site_title: Thai same-sex marriage Bill passes first Senate reading
summary: The Thai Senate passed the first reading of a bill to legalize same-sex marriage, with 147 votes in favor and 4 against. The bill, which was approved by the lower house last week, now moves to the Senate for review. The legislation aims to make Thailand the first South-east Asian nation to recognize LGBTQ marriage equality, following in the footsteps of Taiwan and Nepal. Activists celebrate the milestone, with many expecting the law to be passed and become effective this year, potentially changing Thai society and inspiring further equality fights.

images.alt_text: The marriage equality Bill had the support of all of Thailand’s major parties and was passed by 400 of the 415 lawmakers present, with 10 voting against it.
The report may prompt the House of Representatives to push ahead with a bill to legalise casinos and other forms of gambling.

The Bill proposes a key fundamental change to the composition of a marriage, from “a man and a woman” to “two individuals,” and a change in the official legal status from “husband and wife” to a genderless “married couple.”
Wealth management is a people-centric business, and diverse teams are able to better understand and relate to the diverse needs of clients: Young Jin Yee, country head at UBS Singapore.

site_title: China Xiaomi’s market value soars by up to US$7.6  billion on EV launch
summary: Xiaomi's shares surged 16% on April 2 as the company's sporty electric vehicle, the SU7, drew strong interest. The vehicle's price tag of under $30,000 for the base model attracted buyers, with wait times of four to seven months expected. This led to a $7.6 billion increase in Xiaomi's market value. The launch marks Xiaomi's entry into China's crowded EV market, with the company positioning itself against Tesla's Model 3. Despite a forecast of significant losses per car, the launch is seen as a significant milestone for the electronics maker.

images.alt_text: The logo of NIO seen on an EL6 car model is pictured at the NIO House, the showroom of the Chinese premium smart electric vehicle manufacture NIO Inc. in Berlin, Germany August 17, 2023. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse
Xiaomi built a Beijing factory capable of producing 200,000 cars annually before it had regulatory approval to start manufacturing in China.
During Thursday's two-hour event, Xiaomi CEO Lei Jun made a jibe at Apple for dropping its car project and declared Xiaomi's EV superior to Tesla's Model 3.

A Xiaomi SU7 electric vehicle on display at one of the company's stores in Shanghai, China, March 26, 2024. With a year-long EV price war going on in China, reception for the SU7 will likely dictate Xiaomi’s stock momentum after a 22 per cent gain since a February low.

site_title: Tesla has Wall Street worried about how many cars it just sold
summary: Tesla's sales are expected to decline for the first time since the pandemic, with analysts predicting a 7% drop in deliveries to 449,080 vehicles in the quarter. The company's CEO, Elon Musk, recently slowed sales by requiring customers to take short drives to test the Full Self-Driving feature, which may have impacted sales. This decline is attributed to waning demand for electric vehicles and elevated interest rates, with some analysts predicting no growth at all in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: The logo of NIO seen on an EL6 car model is pictured at the NIO House, the showroom of the Chinese premium smart electric vehicle manufacture NIO Inc. in Berlin, Germany August 17, 2023. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse
The Chinese company’s existing partnership with Ford Motor will be the model for similar cooperation with other US carmakers, the report says.
Tesla is up against increasingly stiff competition in China, not only from homegrown competitor BYD but a raft of other EV manufacturers churning out more affordable, tech-laden vehicles.

site_title: McKinsey offering some staff nine months’ pay to leave firm
summary: McKinsey is offering some UK staff a unique deal: nine months' pay and career-coaching services to leave the firm. This move comes as the company has trimmed headcount, delayed start dates, and slowed hiring amid declining client demand. Eligible staff, primarily engagement managers and associate partners, can take the offer. The move aims to support staff in finding new careers, but those who decline may still have to depart immediately.

images.alt_text: Not long ago, the consulting industry looked indestructible. Now, however, growth has been soggy for this “Great Eight”, slowing to around 5 per cent in 2023.
Companies in industries from finance to technology to retailing are reducing staff amid a slowdown in demand and predictions of a looming recession.

site_title: Hot stock: Isetan Singapore jumps 147.5% on proposed privatisation after resuming trade
summary: Isetan Singapore's shares surged 147.5% on Tuesday after the company announced a proposed privatisation by majority shareholder Isetan Mitsukoshi. The counter rose from S$2.84 to S$7.03, just shy of Isetan Mitsukoshi's S$7.20 per share offer. This move marks the end of Isetan Singapore's four-decade run on the Singapore bourse, with the company to be taken private through a scheme of arrangement.

site_title: Carousell acquires luxury bag reseller LuxLexicon, expands presence in luxury segment
summary: Carousell has acquired luxury bag reseller LuxLexicon to expand its presence in the luxury segment, with an offline presence to complement its online channels. The acquisition is expected to aid in the growth of Carousell's luxury offerings, which have seen a 71% monthly growth in luxury bag listings over the last two years. LuxLexicon's founder, Florence Low, will continue to lead the brand, and the deal is seen as a "familiar playbook" for Carousell, which has previously acquired founder-led businesses in the recommerce space.

images.alt_text: From left to right: Carousell co-founders Lucas Ngoo, Marcus Tan and Quek Siu Rui.
While second-hand prices for brands such as Chanel may be lower than retail, resale prices have also adjusted upwards with recent demand.
Quek Siu Rui, CEO and co-founder of Carousell Singapore, says that the company has the support of long-term investors.
Carousell co-founder Quek Siu Rui admitted that he was too optimistic about the investment Carousell was making in hiring versus the platform's impact.

site_title: China Vanke gets first Hong Kong sell rating as pressure mounts
summary: China Vanke, a Hong Kong-listed property firm, received its first sell rating from Wall Street brokerages due to deepening liquidity pressure and slumping profits. JPMorgan Chase downgraded Vanke's shares to underweight, slashing price targets by more than 25%. The firm's credit ratings were cut to junk level by Fitch Ratings and Moody's last month. Analysts predict Vanke will avoid default due to government support, but warn that share prices will remain under pressure until liquidity eases, with the stock tumbling 88% from its 2018 high.

site_title: Japan approves 590 billion yen in aid to chip venture Rapidus
summary: Japan has approved up to 590 billion yen (S$5.3 billion) in subsidies for chip venture Rapidus, aiming to catch up with TSMC in cutting-edge fabrication technology. The additional funding will aid in buying chipmaking equipment and developing advanced back-end chipmaking processes. This is part of Japan's four-trillion yen plan to regain its chipmaking prowess, with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida targeting 10 trillion yen in financial support.

images.alt_text: Japan is already shouldering roughly half of the cost of the first TSMC factory in Kumamoto, with up to 476 billion yen in subsidies.

site_title: Thailand’s shift to promote electric commercial vehicles a boon for local assembly
summary: Thailand is promoting electric commercial vehicles through incentives for local manufacturers, with the goal of reaching 30% of local vehicle production as electric vehicles by 2030. The government offers tax privileges and financial assistance to companies that produce electric buses and trucks in Thailand, attracting local manufacturers such as Energy Absolute and Sakun C Innovation. This initiative aims to reduce dependence on imported EVs and support the country's broader goal of being carbon-neutral by 2050.

images.alt_text: Huawei's managing director and chairman of smart car solutions, Richard Yu, is expecting the unit to turn a profit from April.
During Thursday's two-hour event, Xiaomi CEO Lei Jun made a jibe at Apple for dropping its car project and declared Xiaomi's EV superior to Tesla's Model 3.

Mini EVs being charged on a street in Liuzhou, in China's Guangxi province. These tiny vehicles weave through traffic in southern China, their cheerful designs bringing a touch of colour to the EV revolution in the country.
Delta Electronics' eighth plant in Thailand will double its production of EV-related components.

site_title: South Korea inflation stays elevated, stoking price concerns
summary: South Korea's inflation remained elevated in March, surpassing forecasts at 3.1% year-over-year, with food prices leading growth. The Bank of Korea has maintained its benchmark interest rate at 3.5%, citing a desire for inflation to settle at the 2% range before policy easing. The outcome of the upcoming parliamentary election will influence President Yoon Suk-yeol's ability to implement his policy agenda, with policymakers focusing on measures to combat rising costs of living.

images.alt_text: Domestic demand has been weakening due to interest rates staying at elevated levels for a prolonged period.

FILE PHOTO: Trucks used to transport containers are seen at the Hanjin Shipping container terminal at the Busan New Port in Busan, about 420 km (261 miles) southeast of Seoul, August 8, 2013. Picture taken August 8, 2013. REUTERS/Lee Jae-Won (SOUTH KOREA - Tags: BUSINESS MARITIME)/File Photo
South Korea's industrial output index rose 3.1 per cent in February on a seasonally adjusted monthly basis, after a fall of 1.5 per cent in January, according to Statistics Korea.

site_title: First money laundering accused to plead guilty jailed 13 months
summary: Su Wenqiang, a Cambodian passport holder, became the first of 10 foreign nationals accused in Singapore's S$3 billion money laundering case to plead guilty, receiving a 13-month jail term. He was found guilty of two charges of money laundering involving assets of more than S$500,000, related to operating an unlawful remote gambling service in the Philippines and purchasing a Mercedes-Benz using criminal proceeds. The prosecution sought a 12-15 month sentence, citing general deterrence, but Su's lawyers argued for a 10-11 month sentence due to his cooperation with authorities and lack of targeted harm to Singapore.

site_title: Baltimore bridge collapse: Dali’s Singapore owner, manager file petition to cap compensation at US$43.6 million
summary: The owner and manager of the Singapore-flagged ship Dali have filed a petition to cap compensation for the collapse of the Francis Scott Key bridge in Baltimore at $43.6 million, the remaining value of the ship after repair and salvage costs. The companies claim the allision was not due to any fault or negligence, and they seek to invoke the Limitation of Liability Act, a US law that limits liability to the value of the vessel. Experts estimate "sizeable" compensation may be involved due to the extent of the damage and loss of life.

images.alt_text: The Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore partially collapses after a container ship runs into it.
The Francis Scott Key Bridge rests partially collapsed after a Singapore-flagged container ship ran into it in Baltimore on Tuesday.
The disaster is likely to result in industry-wide multi-billion-dollar insurance claims, which could make it the largest single marine insurance loss.

Initial reports indicate the nature of the Baltimore bridge incident is likely to fall within the scope of Protection and Indemnity coverage, which covers third party liability for vessels including damage to fixed or floating objects.

site_title: Don’t expect social media to save the news industry
summary: Meta, the social media giant, has announced it is ending payments to news publishers in Australia and Canada, citing that news is no longer a significant factor in drawing users to its platforms. The decision comes after a year of agreements with news publishers' collectives, which was meant to provide a lifeline for struggling local publishers. The move is seen as a blow to Australian news organizations, which relied on the payments to hire journalists and stay afloat. The number of daily active users on Meta platforms remains stable, suggesting that blocking news content is not affecting its bottom line.

images.alt_text: Meta is, however, not obligated to pay news publishers if it implements a ban that prevents users from reposting news articles

site_title: Xi’s cryptic bond comments hint at PBOC becoming more like Fed
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping's comments hint at the People's Bank of China (PBOC) adopting a more monetary policy approach like the US Federal Reserve, potentially involving buying and selling government bonds to regulate liquidity. The remarks, made in October, have sparked speculation about a policy pivot, with some traders believing Beijing may consider quantitative easing. However, economists caution that the actual timing and impact of such a move are unclear, and the PBOC may use bond trading as an additional tool to pump liquidity rather than stimulate the economy.

images.alt_text: The central bank has taken several steps to shore up confidence in an ailing economy.
The central bank is likely to cut the rate on its medium-term lending facility in the second and third quarters.
China’s central bank held a key policy rate in March while Chinese lenders maintained their benchmark loan rates.

site_title: Japan warns of action against excessive yen volatility
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki has warned of taking "appropriate action" against excessive yen volatility, as the currency continues its downtrend despite the Bank of Japan's decision to end eight years of negative interest rates. Suzuki stopped short of threatening decisive action, but emphasized the government's readiness to intervene. The yen has fallen to a 34-year low, with markets on alert for potential intervention by Tokyo, which has historically favored a weak yen to boost profits for manufacturers.

images.alt_text: Japan’s economy expanded an annualised 0.4 per cent in the final quarter of last year, narrowly averting a technical recession as robust capital expenditure offset weaknesses in consumption.
In the longer term, Masato Kanda, vice-finance minister for international affairs, suggests that more structural reform is vital to restore the yen’s attractiveness.
News of the meeting triggered a sharp rebound in the yen from a 34-year low of 151.97 hit earlier on Wednesday.

site_title: Olympic golden boy Joseph Schooling retires from swimming
summary: Singaporean Olympic gold medallist Joseph Schooling has announced his retirement from swimming at the age of 28. Schooling, who won a 100m butterfly gold in 2016, cited a combination of complacency, overthinking, and exhaustion as reasons for his decision. He will now pursue a career in venture capital and golf, crediting his parents and coaches for their support and guidance throughout his career. Schooling's legacy as a role model for young athletes will continue to inspire, with his Olympic gold medallist status cementing his place as Singapore's only Olympic champion.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Jacob Mahler celebrates after scoring the equaliser in his side's 2-2 draw with China at the National Stadium on Mar 21, 2024.

“It is not just to pay tribute to our sporting heroes. More importantly, it is a way for us to tell our stories to the future generations,” says swimming legend Patricia Chan of Singapore Aquatics’ newly announced Hall of Fame.

Teong said in a statement on Wednesday: “I would like to apologise to my family, my fellow swimmers and the Singapore Swimming Association. This is something I deeply regret doing, and as an elite athlete, I should have known better."
Singapore swimmer Joseph Schooling before the victory ceremony of the Men’s 100m Butterfly Finals during the SEA Games in Hanoi in May.
Lim was issued a stern warning by CNB under the Misuse of Drugs Act while Schooling has been referred to the Ministry of Defence (Mindef) to assess and take the appropriate measures.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Isetan Singapore, Best World, UOB
summary: Japan's Isetan Mitsukoshi is proposing to take Isetan Singapore private through a scheme of arrangement, offering S$7.20 for each target share, a 37.4% premium. Best World International's shareholders have withdrawn a requisition letter seeking changes to the company's dividend policy and directors' pay. UOB is introducing lower interest rates for its One savings account members, effective May 1, with revised tiered bonus interest rates ranging from 3 to 4.5%.

site_title: Trump’s media company raises going-concern doubts; shares tumble
summary: Trump Media & Technology Group posted a net loss of $58.2 million in the year ended December 2023, compared to a net profit of $50.5 million the previous year. The company raised going-concern doubts due to struggles to meet financial liabilities, citing substantial doubt that it will have sufficient funds to meet its liabilities. Shares fell nearly 18% on Monday after going public through a blank-cheque merger. The company expects to incur operating losses and negative cash flows from operations for the foreseeable future.

images.alt_text: Trump Media & Technology Group, which generated less than US$4 million in revenue for the first nine months of last year, was worth US$8.4 billion on Thursday, bringing — on paper — a massive windfall to its largest shareholder: Donald Trump himself.

Donald Trump, who unlike most US presidents rarely attends church except during public political events, has advertised the Bibles, which feature a cover embossed with an American flag, during what Christians call Holy Week.
Donald Trump, 77, has been rich all his life.

site_title: Biotech startup Auristone snags US$4 million in seed funding from Seeds Capital and Elev8
summary: Auristone, a biotech startup focused on epigenomics, has secured US$4 million in seed funding from Seeds Capital, Elev8.vc, and Genedant. The funding will be used to drive clinical collaborations and market adoption of its molecular profiling technology, EPI-CALL, which predicts treatment response in cancer patients. Elev8.vc's managing director, Aditya Mathur, sees epigenomics as the next frontier for precision healthcare, highlighting Auristone's unique approach. The funding will support the startup's expansion into new markets, including South Korea and Japan.

site_title: North Korea fires medium-range ballistic missile: Seoul
summary: North Korea fired a medium-range ballistic missile on Tuesday, according to Seoul's military, marking the third such test in 2024. The launch follows recent banned weapons tests, including a solid-fuel missile in March and a hypersonic warhead in January. The move comes less than two weeks after North Korean leader Kim Jong Un supervised an engine test for a new intermediate-range hypersonic missile.

images.alt_text: A new type of surface-to-sea missile Padasuri-6 which was test-fired toward the East Sea of Korea, at an undisclosed location in North Korea., Feb 14, 2024. North Korea fired a ballistic missile on Monday, Seoul’s military said.
South Korea's transformation from economic minnow to industrial giant owes much to its sprawling, family-run conglomerates known as chaebols.
The good news is that there are only nine countries with nuclear weapons, compared to the two dozen that Kennedy predicted by the 1970s

North Korea has said it now considers the South as an enemy at war and last year scrapped a military pact signed in 2018 aimed at de-escalating tension near the military border drawn up under a truce ending the 1950-53 Korean War.

site_title: Shein’s IPO quagmire in the West: An opportunity for Singapore
summary: Shein, a global fashion retailer, is facing challenges in its IPO bid in the US due to increased scrutiny from regulatory bodies and politicians. The company's ultra-fast fashion business model has raised concerns about its business practices and ethics, including a lack of transparency and compliance issues. Despite its global success, Shein's billionaire founder maintains a low profile, and the company publishes no financial data. As a result, the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is unlikely to approve Shein's IPO. In contrast, Singapore could be a more suitable location for Shein's IPO, given the country's more favorable regulatory environment.

images.alt_text: Shein has been subject to scrutiny from the US, with Senator Marco Rubio among those asking the SEC to block its listing.
Last May, a bipartisan group of US lawmakers urged the SEC to block Shein’s IPO until it verifies it does not use forced labour.
FILE PHOTO: People shop at the Shein Holiday pop-up shop inside of Times Squares Forever 21 in New York City, U.S., November 10, 2023.REUTERS/David 'Dee' Delgado/File Photo

site_title: For Trump, belief in God means votes and money
summary: US President Joe Biden, a lifelong Catholic, issued a proclamation on Easter, while challenger Donald Trump, who rarely attends church, compared himself to Jesus Christ in a series of posts. Trump's Easter message was marked by attacks on prosecutors and judges, and criticism of the US court system, but his Christian followers remained loyal. Trump reaped the political benefits of his faith, and his white evangelical supporters see him as the man for the job, with many crediting him with facilitating the conservative majority on the Supreme Court.

images.alt_text: Former US Senator Joe Lieberman died in New York City at the age of 82 “due to complications from a fall,” his family said in a statement carried by US media.
US presidential candidate Robert F Kennedy Jr. (right) announces his running mate Nicole Shanahan (left) in Oakland, California on March 26, 2024.

Donald Trump, who unlike most US presidents rarely attends church except during public political events, has advertised the Bibles, which feature a cover embossed with an American flag, during what Christians call Holy Week.
The decision eases an acute cash crunch brought on by Trump’s mounting legal expenses.
Green-energy and cannabis stocks briefly became market darlings as the odds of a victory for Joe Biden rose in 2020.

site_title: Citigroup cut US tech banker jobs during broad reorganisation
summary: Citigroup implemented a fresh round of job cuts in its US investment bank, affecting several senior bankers and junior roles in technology, media, and telecom coverage areas. The bank completed its planned restructuring, which aimed to eliminate 20,000 roles, and has already notified regulators of 430 planned layoffs. This move is part of the broader industry trend of unwinding pandemic-era hiring, as technology deals slow down. The cuts are expected to result in $2.5 billion in savings.

images.alt_text: The latest reshuffle finalises Citi’s new structure and is part of a broader goal to trim its global workforce of 239,000 by 20,000 over the next two years.
At Citigroup, the cuts come as chief executive officer Jane Fraser is in the middle of initiating a massive restructuring of the banking behemoth
The company has employed 239,000 employees in 90 countries as at December 2023.
Citi is probing at least two instances of alleged abusive behaviour by a senior banker against several subordinates on the industrials, energy and power team.

site_title: Thailand to widen 2025 budget deficit as it reworks handout plan
summary: Thailand plans to widen its 2025 budget deficit to stimulate a sluggish economy, with a potential increase of up to $14 billion. The government is considering funding a US$14 billion cash handout program through the state budget, rather than borrowing, amid concerns over inflation and fiscal deficit. The revised budget framework will allow for a wider deficit, with the goal of achieving fiscal balance by 2028. The move aims to revive a sluggish economy, which has faced sub-2% growth for a decade and is still recovering from the pandemic.

site_title: Microsoft-backed Rubrik’s IPO filing shows US$354 million loss
summary: Rubrik, a cloud and data security startup backed by Microsoft, has filed for an initial public offering (IPO) with Goldman Sachs, Barclays, Citigroup, and Wells Fargo & Co. as lead underwriters. The company reported a net loss of $354 million on revenue of $628 million for the year ended January 31, with subscription annual recurring revenue growing by 47% compared to the previous year. Rubrik's IPO could raise $500 million to $700 million, following successful IPOs by Reddit and Astera Labs last month.

images.alt_text: Reddit says that it and its investors are planning to sell 22 million shares for US$31 to US$34 each.
Reddit’s listing is closely watched as a bellwether of an IPO market in the midst of a tentative rebound from a two-year dearth of first-time share sales.
Microsoft makes an equity investment in Rubrik in 2021 in a round that valued it at US$4 billion.

site_title: Top capsule-toy maker Bandai bets on huge market outside Japan
summary: Bandai, a Japanese toymaker, plans to open over 80 new stores abroad, focusing on North America, to capitalize on the growing popularity of capsule toys. The company aims to triple its specialty shops for gashapon machines, which dispense surprise items in plastic capsules. With a 36% rise in the capsule-toy market to 61 billion yen in 2022, Bandai seeks to expand its business model globally to promote Japanese entertainment culture. The company's gashapon machines, popular in Japan, are also expected to do well abroad due to the growing popularity of Japanese anime.

images.alt_text: Lego has expanded its position as the world’s No 1 toymaker, growing consumer sales 4 per cent in 2023 when the overall market contracted about 7 per cent.
Mattel, which saw a Warner Bros Discovery film tied to its Barbie doll line become the biggest motion picture of 2023, says it expects the toy industry to decline in 2024.

site_title: Google agrees to delete web browsing data as it settles ‘incognito’ lawsuit
summary: Google has agreed to delete billions of records of user browsing activities as part of a settlement with a class-action lawsuit alleging it tracked people without their knowledge. The lawsuit claimed Google collected data from users in "incognito" mode, despite the browser's ability to turn off data collection. Google also made changes to its disclosures and agreed to allow incognito mode users to block third-party cookies for the next five years. The settlement provides "substantial relief" for plaintiffs and comes as Google faces multiple regulatory challenges amid rising concerns about data collection and use.

images.alt_text: EU industry chief Thierry Breton says the investigations should not be a surprise.
Google has pledged not to contest the facts as part of settlement proceedings, the French watchdog says.
Apple and Google have not decided on the terms of an AI agreement or finalised how it would be implemented.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly fall on inflation worries
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 0.6% to 39,566.85 and the S&P 500 shedding 0.2% to 5,243.77. The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.1% despite concerns over inflation, which rose 3.3% in the latest manufacturing data. The Federal Reserve's interest rate cut plan is under scrutiny, and markets await further inflation data to gauge monetary policy shifts.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JANUARY 19: Traders and media work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on January 19, 2024 in New York City. Stocks closed up over 350 points while the S&P 500 closed at an all-time high on Friday.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Demonstrators vow to ‘save Israel’ from Netanyahu in new protests
summary: Thousands of Israeli protesters gathered in Tel Aviv and outside the parliament in Jerusalem, demanding Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu quit amid a six-month-old war in Gaza, where over 32,845 have been killed. Demonstrators, including families of hostages held by Hamas, say Netanyahu must be forced out to save Israel, citing his failure to rescue them. The protests have united an anti-government movement and the hostages' families, putting pressure on Netanyahu's right-wing coalition, which has been weakened by the war. Netanyahu's supporters argue that this is not the time to change leader, but protesters say he is "using divisions to stay in power."

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Israeli national flags flutter at a business park also housing high tech companies, at Ofer Park in Petah Tikva, Israel August 27, 2020. REUTERS/Ronen Zvulun/File Photo

The display presents “the Gazan artistic scene in a new way”, which helps “to face the challenges and difficulties which artists and culture are confronting in Gaza amid the destruction and siege”, says board member Ehab Bessaiso.
Palestinians walk across the rubble of a collapsed building following an Israeli airstrike in the Zuwayida district of central Gaza, Feb 22, 2024.
Houthi followers at a "popular army" mobilisation campaign, in Sanaa, Yemen, Feb 7, 2024.
Gigi Coffee’s group CEO Marcus Low told ST that the chain has seen an uptick in sales.
Displaced Palestinians flee the war between Israel and Hamas in the northern Gaza Strip, walking to its southern section, Nov 26, 2023.

site_title: United Airlines faces overstaffing due to Boeing's delivery delays
summary: United Airlines faces staffing issues due to Boeing's delivery delays, impacting aircraft utilization this year. The airline is offering voluntary programs to reduce excess staffing, but details are not shared. Boeing's problems, including safety and quality issues, have reduced industry expectations for deliveries this year, complicating efforts to meet record travel demand. The airline industry is experiencing disruptions, with Boeing's CEO and commercial head retiring or stepping down, and the company facing regulatory scrutiny. This will likely lead to higher costs for United Airlines.

site_title:
New long-stay serviced apartments a boon 
to developers, a bane for private landlords
summary: Singapore is introducing long-stay serviced apartments with a minimum 3-month stay requirement, offering a new housing option for individuals and foreigners. This move is expected to benefit developers and increase competition for private landlords. Long-stay serviced apartments may attract tenants looking for stable, well-maintained living spaces, potentially reducing the need for individual landlords. Policymakers consider nudging ownership of long-stay serviced apartments to individual investors via listed Reits to democratize real estate ownership.

images.alt_text: Stay awhile: How long-stay serviced apartments may change the housing landscape

site_title: Australia home prices rise for 14th straight month
summary: Australia's home prices rose for the 14th consecutive month in March, with a 0.6% national increase, according to CoreLogic. Despite higher interest rates and cost of living pressures, an undersupply of housing relative to demand continues to drive up home values. Prices rose in all capital cities except Darwin, with Perth's housing market showing the highest growth at 1.9%. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to hold interest rates steady, and property analysts forecast a 5.0% rise in Australian home prices in 2024.

images.alt_text: Australia’s property market has remained strong despite the central bank’s 4.25 percentage points of policy tightening since May 2022.

site_title: Germany gives controversial green light to cannabis
summary: Germany has become the largest EU country to legalize recreational cannabis, allowing adults over 18 to carry 25 grams of dried cannabis and cultivate up to three plants at home. The law, which took effect on April 1, also permits the establishment of cannabis clubs where members can purchase up to 50 grams of cannabis per month. Despite concerns from health groups and police, the government argues that legalization will help contain the black market for cannabis.

images.alt_text: Thailand became the first country in South-east Asia to decriminalise cannabis, initially for medicinal use in 2021, then for recreational use in 2022.
Germany becomes the ninth country to legalise recreational use of the drug, which is also legal in some sub-national jurisdictions in the United States and Australia.

site_title: Oil up 1%, US WTI at 5-month closing high, market seen tight
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Monday, with US WTI futures closing at a 5-month high. Brent futures for June delivery settled at $87.42 a barrel, up 42 cents or 0.5% from the April 28 settlement price. The increase is attributed to expected economic growth in the US and China, tightening supplies due to Opec+ output cuts and attacks on Russian refineries, and market expectations of a tight market.

images.alt_text: SGX-listed palm oil companies have booked positive total returns this year, despite weaker crude palm oil prices and lower average selling prices on a year-on-year basis.
Gold is one of market watchers' top picks, as they expect central bank demand to remain strong while the downside risks for the previous yellow metal are limited.
US oil exports have set five new monthly records since Western nations began imposing sanctions on Russia in 2022.

site_title: Thailand’s biggest crypto exchange hiring advisers for 2025 IPO
summary: Thailand's largest crypto exchange, Bitkub, plans to go public in 2025 with an initial public offering on the Stock Exchange of Thailand. CEO Jirayut Srupsrisopa is hiring financial advisers for the listing, which aims to boost the company's profile and raise funds. The move comes as competition in the Thai crypto market heats up, with Binance and Kasikornbank expanding their presence. Bitkub's valuation is expected to rise as trading volumes on its platform increase, with the company planning to expand its workforce to 3,000 people by 2025.

images.alt_text: The new rules include clearly showing investment risks in advertisements and providing a balanced view of potential risk and returns, the SEC said in statement on Thursday (Sep 1).

Thailand's move to tighten cryptocurrency rules comes after its authorities were criticised for not acting promptly to protect investors at Zipmex (Thailand), a licensed cryptocurrency exchange that briefly suspended coin withdrawals.
Bitkub's coin is down about 85 per cent from its all-time high and was at about US$2.60 on Monday, according to CoinGecko.

site_title: Macquarie unit is leading US$50 billion investment in offshore wind
summary: Macquarie's unit, Corio Generation, is investing US$50 billion in offshore wind over the next seven years, despite uncertainty due to inflation and supply-chain issues. The investment will be made in US and European markets, with a focus on New York, New Jersey, Scotland, England, Taiwan, and Ireland. CEO Jonathan Cole cited the ability to see through the impact of spiralling costs and surging interest rates as a key factor in Corio's success, allowing it to secure the investment.

images.alt_text: Macquarie owns more than a 26 per cent stake in Cadent and is in early talks to sell a 5 per cent stake.
Nick O'Kane's renumeration for the year to March 2023 was A$57.6 million (S$50.5 million), up 59% from a year ago.

site_title: BT Tech In Finance: Preparing ourselves for retirement (Ep 4)
summary: Adrian Low, product manager of DBS digiPortfolio, shares tips on investing for retirement, emphasizing the importance of starting early due to rising living costs and aging population in Singapore. DBS' holistic approach to retirement planning includes its Retirement digiPortfolio, which caters to individuals' changing life stages. The podcast advises that anyone can invest in DBS' Retirement digiPortfolio, providing a secure retirement income solution.

images.alt_text: In retirement, staying invested and figuring out how much you can withdraw can be challenging.
Priya Kini, head of commercial banking, HSBC Singapore shares four key trends driving digital transformation for businesses.
Serene Koh from OCBC believes digital first doesn’t mean digital only.

site_title: Singapore listcos offer opportunities for investors to ride the commodities wave
summary: SGX-listed palm oil companies have booked positive total returns this year, despite weaker crude palm oil prices and lower average selling prices. Eight of the 22 active commodity stocks have achieved positive returns, with some trading at a discount to their book values. This shift in the industry may provide investors with solid returns in the near term, offering opportunities to ride the commodities wave.

images.alt_text: A man unloads the fresh fruit bunches from his car boot at a palm oil fruit collection centre for smallholders in Banting, Selangor, Malaysia, June 10, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain

site_title: US manufacturing recovering; raw material prices pose challenge
summary: US manufacturing experienced a rebound in March, with the ISM's manufacturing PMI rising to 50.3, the highest reading above 50 since September 2022. Production and new orders increased, while employment remained subdued due to layoffs and higher raw material prices. The sector's recovery is seen as a boost to the economy's growth prospects, but rising raw material costs may lead to goods inflation. Economists caution that interest rates may need to be adjusted in 2024 to address potential price pressures.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, jumped 0.8 per cent last month.

site_title: Commodities the asset class to watch amid looming rate cuts, macroeconomic uncertainty
summary: Commodities are expected to gain attention amid looming interest rate cuts and macroeconomic uncertainty.
