Gold is a top pick, with central bank demand remaining strong and limited downside risks. Commodities often serve as a diversification tool, with returns independent of equities and bonds. Analysts predict commodities will benefit from interest rate cuts, which may lead to weaker Treasury bill returns and a negative roll yield. Investors should keep a closer eye on the asset class as it serves as a buffer against macroeconomic shocks.

images.alt_text: SGX-listed palm oil companies have booked positive total returns this year, despite weaker crude palm oil prices and lower average selling prices on a year-on-year basis.
Long the world's undisputed cocoa powerhouses, Ghana and Ivory Coast are both facing catastrophic harvests this season.
FILE PHOTO: Cocoa pods are pictured at a farm in Sinfra, Ivory Coast April 29, 2023. REUTERS/Luc Gnago/File Photo
Bursa Malaysia-listed crude palm oil futures are up about 20.8 per cent this year as at Mar 4 at RM4,345 per tonne. This is the highest price CPO futures have reached in a one-year period.
Gold spot prices headed lower on Monday, hovering around US$2,149 per troy ounce as at 3.15pm or down 1.3 per cent week on week.
The US dollar was down 0.1 per cent against its rivals, making gold more appealing for other currency holders.
FILE PHOTO: Gold bars at the Austrian Gold and Silver Separating Plant 'Oegussa' in Vienna, Austria, March 18, 2016.   REUTERS/Leonhard Foeger/File Photo

site_title: Rakuten offers US$1.25 billion junk bond in return to US market
summary: Japanese technology firm Rakuten Group is issuing a $1.25 billion junk bond to pay down debt obligations. The company has been tapping financial markets to raise funds, following a $1.8 billion bond offering in January that yielded a record high yield for a Japanese firm. The new deal is expected to price later this week, with early discussions suggesting a yield in the mid-10% area. This move comes after credit markets signaled high repayment risk for the company, which has been struggling with debt.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Rakuten is pictured at the headquarters of Rakuten in Tokyo, Japan, May 15, 2019. REUTERS/Sam Nussey/File Photo

site_title: US dollar higher after manufacturing data lowers June rate bets
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.469% to 104.97, following data showing the US manufacturing sector grew in March for the first time since September 2022. The rebound ended 16 straight months of contraction, which accounts for 10.4% of the economy. Lower bets on the Federal Reserve cutting rates in June, following easing US prices, contributed to the dollar's increase. The yen hovered below 152 per dollar, keeping traders on edge over the threat of Japanese intervention, while the euro and sterling fell.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq open higher as softening inflation fans rate cut bets
summary: The S&P 500, Nasdaq Composite, and Dow Jones Industrial Average opened higher on Monday, April 1, 2024, as investors reacted to moderating US inflation. The S&P 500 rose 0.07% and the Nasdaq gained 0.11%, while the Dow Jones increased 0.00%. The early interest rate cut bets were fueled by the inflation data, but higher Treasury yields limited gains.

site_title: Formula One owners Liberty Media buy MotoGP for US$4.5 billion
summary: Liberty Media has agreed to buy MotoGP for $4.5 billion, acquiring approximately 86% stake from Spain-based owners Dorna. The acquisition, expected to be completed by the end of 2024, will expand Liberty's portfolio of live sports and entertainment assets. Long-serving MotoGP CEO Carmelo Ezpeleta will remain in his post, and Liberty will not be the first company to own both Formula One and MotoGP, following CVC Capital Partners' previous ownership of both series.

images.alt_text: epa11240622 Max Verstappen of Red Bull Racing in action during the Australian Grand Prix 2024 at Albert Park Circuit in Melbourne, Australia 24 March 2024.  EPA-EFE/JOEL CARRETT AUSTRALIA AND NEW ZEALAND OUT

site_title: India central bank reverts to multiple price auctions after 3 years
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has announced that it will revert to multiple price auctions for central government securities, effective this financial year, except for ultra-long duration bonds. This change comes after a review of market conditions, with the RBI citing a demand from market participants. The move aims to improve liquidity in securities and reduce concentration of ownership among large players. India plans to borrow 7.50 trillion rupees via bonds in the April-to-September period, 53% of its annual target.

images.alt_text: The RBI’s inflation targeting framework has helped to keep price pressures moderate, Prime Minister Narendra Modi says.

The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) logo is displayed on a gate at the central bank's headquarters in Mumbai, India, on Tuesday, April 1, 2014. Indiaâs central bank left its key interest rate unchanged as consumer-price inflation eased to a two-year low and the rupee strengthened, increasing scope to support growth ahead of national elections starting this month. Photographer: Vivek Prakash/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: Mastercard and Visa credit cards are seen in front of displayed Wirecard logo in this illustration picture taken June 26, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Taiwan ex-leader Ma leaves for China, likely to meet Xi
summary: Former Taiwan President Ma Ying-jeou left for an 11-day trip to China, where he is expected to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping next week. Ma's trip, his first to China since becoming a former leader, comes amid simmering tensions across the Taiwan Strait. Ma described the trip as a "journey of peace and a journey of friendship," and both sides are expected to strengthen exchanges and cooperation. Ma's visit has been met with skepticism by Taiwan's current president, Tsai Ing-wen, who has repeatedly offered talks with China but been rebuffed.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's central bank hiked the benchmark discount rate to 2 per cent from 1.875 per cent, where it has stood since last March.
FILE PHOTO: Cargo trucks work inside a container yard in Keelung, Taiwan, January 7, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Wang

site_title: Plethora of opportunities in Asia and emerging markets outside China
summary: Investors are shifting their focus from China to other emerging markets (EMs) in Asia due to growing geopolitical tensions and domestic politics. While China remains a significant market, its influence is waning, and EM ex-China is gaining traction. Key drivers of growth include the consumption promise, digitalisation, and global supply-chain diversification. Countries like Vietnam, Indonesia, and India offer opportunities, with Indonesia's resource-rich economy and innovative companies like Indian IT solutions providers expanding globally. The region's prospects are supported by better macro management, deepened capital markets, and digitalisation, making it an attractive investment destination.

images.alt_text: South-east Asia has so far been slow to adopt high-speed rail, despite plans in place for years by Vietnam, Thailand and others.
One option TSMC t is considering is bringing its chip on wafer on substrate (CoWoS) packaging technology to Japan, according to one of the sources who was briefed on the matter.
TSMC’s shares have surged more than 110 per cent from an October 2022 low.

site_title: US construction spending falls for second straight month in February
summary: US construction spending declined 0.3% in February, following a 0.2% drop in January, exceeding economists' expectations of a 0.7% rebound. Private construction projects remained unchanged for the second month, while single-family homebuilding rose 1.4% due to tight housing supply. Nonresidential and public projects declined 0.9% and 1.2%, respectively, led by a 2.5% drop in amusement and recreation projects. This marks the second consecutive month of decline in US construction spending.

images.alt_text: New home sales slipped 0.3 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 662,000 units last month, the Commerce Department’s Census Bureau says.

The figures indicate the resale market is breaking out of a protracted slump due to high mortgage rates that discouraged homeowners from moving and giving up a lower rate that they had locked in in the past few years.
Mortgage rates have fallen from an October peak near 8 per cent, but remain more than twice as high as they were in 2021.
Despite the hurdle created for many first-time buyers by higher mortgage rates, builders are cutting prices and offering other incentives to increase sales.
Builder sentiment has been improving so far this year, though it’s still well below prepandemic levels.
New listings have been rising, which could motivate more buyers to jump into the market.

site_title: UPS to replace FedEx as US Postal Service’s primary air cargo provider
summary: The US Postal Service has awarded a contract to UPS as its primary air cargo provider, replacing FedEx, which had held the position for over 20 years. The terms of the contract were not disclosed, but UPS described the award as "significant." FedEx's shares fell nearly 2% after announcing its departure, while UPS' stock edged lower. FedEx attributed its loss to the inability to reach mutually beneficial terms, citing a decline in payments from the postal service. The move is seen as a temporary setback for FedEx, which faces industry-wide demand slumps and unionized pilot issues.

images.alt_text: epa10904016 A UPS truck driver unloads boxes from a truck onto a dolly in Washington, DC, USA, 06 October 2023. The United States economy added 336,000 jobs in September 2023, according to a new jobs report - which far exceeded expectations. The Dow gained three hundred points after the jobs report was released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Unemployment in the US has now remained under four percent for the longest stretch since the 1960s.  EPA-EFE/MICHAEL REYNOLDS

The inquiry by India’s antitrust body began in Oct 2022 after  the Federation of Indian Publishers complained that DHL, FedEx, UPS and Dubai’s Aramex, along with
some domestic firms, were deciding charges together
and controlling customer discounts.
The Teamsters union representing US workers at United Parcel Service says UPS laid off roughly three dozen specialist and administrative workers at its Centennial hub in Louisville, Kentucky.

site_title: China’s forecast-beating economic data buys officials time to figure out fix
summary: China's economy has shown signs of relief with forecast-beating data for January to February, but analysts caution that this may not be sustainable. China's factory output, retail sales, and exports topped forecasts, but the government faces a "fork in the road" in achieving its 5% GDP growth target. Officials are putting faith in "New Productive Forces" to drive growth, but analysts question whether China can maintain growth and transform its economy at the same time. The property sector remains a concern, and investors want more details on the government's plans to address the debt crisis and boost domestic consumption.

images.alt_text: China is suffering from its own version of the “Solow paradox”: you can see a new technological age everywhere but in the productivity statistics.
Citi last week raised its forecast for China’s 2024 growth to 5.0 per cent from 4.6 per cent, citing “recent positive data and policy delivery”.
Recent indicators suggest a stabilisation in China, but overall gains remain tempered by the persistent fragility in the property market.

China should enrich its toolbox of monetary policies and the central bank should gradually increase the buying and selling of government bonds in its open-market operations, Xi was cited as saying in a book published this month.
Factory output and fixed-asset investment grew faster than expected in the first two months.
The loosely regulated exchanges had been set up over the years by local state-owned enterprises and were initially designed for local financial asset transactions.

site_title: Chills and growth
summary: South-east Asia startup funding fell 13% to US$816 million in Q1 2024, the lowest funded quarter in five quarters, according to Tracxn. Large deals of over US$100 million are missing, indicating late-stage investors are not interested in startups. However, early-stage funding grew 60.9% to US$526 million. Cross-border payment startups see regulation as a potential boon, but regulatory incidents, such as Nium's money laundering allegations, persist.

images.alt_text: Much of what fuelled BNPL players – big consumer incentives and an influx of cheap money – is gone now, writes Garage correspondent Claudia Chong.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, April 1, 2024 (Ep 33)
summary: Asian markets rallied on Monday as Chinese manufacturing activity rebounded, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 1.1% and the Hang Seng Index up 0.8%. However, Japanese stocks were weighed down by a weak yen. Meanwhile, Isetan Mitsukoshi, a Japanese retailer, is exploring a privatization of its Singapore unit, Isetan Singapore. The Singapore Stock Exchange Index (STI) rose 0.2% on the day.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 76 to 39.
In early Asian trade, Seoul, Singapore, Manila stocks rose while there were losses in Taipei and Jakarta.
Isetan supermarket in Westgate mall at Jurong East.

site_title: Sri Lanka optimistic about deal with bondholders soon
summary: Sri Lanka is optimistic about reaching a deal with bondholders to restructure approximately $12 billion in debt, a crucial step towards emerging from its worst financial crisis in decades. China, the country's largest sovereign creditor, pledged support for the debt restructuring plan during a visit to Beijing. The country has secured an agreement in principle with China, India, and the Paris Club nations, and now needs agreements with each of the bilateral creditors. State Finance Minister Shehan Semasinghe expressed confidence that Sri Lanka's growth will be over 2% in 2024.

images.alt_text: A view of Colombo Port shows the red and white gantries of the South Asia Gateway container handling terminal in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Monday, Jan. 29, 2007.

site_title: What are Singapore Depository Receipts and how do they benefit investors?
summary: Singapore investors can now directly invest in three Hong Kong blue-chip stocks via Singapore Depository Receipts (SDRs). The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched its second batch of Hong Kong SDRs in partnership with Phillip Securities, broadening thematic investment opportunities in AI, EV, e-commerce, and financials. SDRs allow investors to hold foreign shares without directly dealing with overseas exchanges, traded like local stocks in Singapore dollars. Benefits include lower fees and custody with the Central Depository, but investors should be aware of foreign-currency risk.

images.alt_text: A picture taken on October 30, 2021 shows tourists taking photos in front of James Bond Island in Phang Nga Bay northeast of Phuket on October 30, 2021 as the country prepares to welcome visitors fully vaccinated against the Covid-19 coronavirus without quarantine from November 1st. (Photo by Mladen ANTONOV / AFP)
SGX will collaborate with regional bourses to increase market connectivity, says SGX president Michael Syn.
The stocks selected appear to be of good investment grade, since all three Thai companies are constituents of the benchmark SET 50 index.
XX
Investors queueing at DBS Securities following Clob's closure, which left many retail investors stuck with worthless paper. The launch of SDRs promises to be a better experience.
CP All, which operates Thailand's largest convenience store chain through the 7-Eleven brand, is a popular "buy" option according to a Bloomberg poll of analysts.

Speaking to reporters at a briefing ahead of the launch, SGX’s head of equities and senior managing director Michael Syn said Thailand was a suitable pick for the SDRs because the country’s economy is “nothing like (Singapore’s)” in terms of the companies listed on the stock exchange.
SGX Group CEO Loh Boon Chye believes the overall business will be much stronger when markets turn more conducive.
Singapore, Thailand launch depository receipts linkage

site_title: Malaysia has enough data to push ahead with subsidy cuts: economy minister
summary: Malaysia's economy minister, Rafizi Ramli, announced that the country has collected data from over 11.55 million citizens, exceeding the initial target of 10 million, to support the plan to cut fuel subsidies. The data will enable authorities to target subsidies to those in need, with estimated annual savings of $1 billion to $2 billion. The government aims to limit subsidies on the cheapest form of petrol, with Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim under pressure to boost investors' confidence and stabilize the Malaysian ringgit. The Economy Ministry will present its plans to the Cabinet in April.

site_title: Vietnam seeking to learn from China with high-speed rail plan
summary: Vietnam plans to build a 1,545 km high-speed railway system with a potential price tag of US$72 billion, seeking to learn from China's experiences in technology, finance, and management. The project would be the country's first high-speed rail network, with a timeframe to be submitted to parliament for approval later this year. Vietnam's Minister of Planning and Investment visited China to discuss cooperation agreements, including on railways, during a visit by Chinese President Xi Jinping in December. The project aims to learn from China's developed railway industry and avoid past mistakes, such as Laos' high-speed system funded by Chinese loans.

images.alt_text: People at an HSR exhibition during the groundbreaking ceremony on the cooperation between Thailand and China on the Bangkok-Nong Khai HSR development in Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand.
An artist's impression of the Bandar Malaysia High-Speed Rail station in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
Indonesia launches the 142-kilometre railway line connecting the capital Jakarta to Bandung city in October.

site_title: Tesla China price hike meets slew of cuts from other carmakers
summary: China's automakers respond to Tesla's price hike with incentives, including Nio's 1 billion yuan ($186.4 million) for gasoline car drivers to switch to electric vehicles, and Xpeng's price cuts of up to 20,000 yuan. Chery Automobile also offers better trade-ins for used cars. The moves counter Tesla's price increase, which was intended to boost demand ahead of the first quarter sales. The competition in China's largest automobile market is intense, with Xiaomi also entering the market with its SU7 electric vehicle.

site_title: Japan’s Isetan Mitsukoshi looks to take Isetan Singapore private
summary: Japan's Isetan Mitsukoshi is considering taking Isetan Singapore private through a scheme of arrangement, with a consideration of S$7.20 per share, representing a 37.4% premium over the counter's highest closing market price in the past five years. The proposed acquisition will allow Isetan Singapore to exit the Singapore bourse, and the company believes this will be an opportunity for shareholders to fully exit their investment. The scheme is expected to result in Isetan Singapore becoming a wholly owned subsidiary of Isetan Mitsukoshi, offering greater flexibility and operational efficiencies for the company.

images.alt_text: Facade of Isetan Singapore outlet at Parkway Parade on August 13, 2021.
Outgoing chief executive Koji Oyama will take on an executive position in Isetan Mitsukoshi Holdings - the holding company for Mitsukoshi and Isetan department stores.

site_title: Singapore stocks end higher on Monday after positive China data; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose on Monday, April 1, 2024, following positive data on China's manufacturing activity. The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,234.89, up 0.3% or 10.88 points. The market gained momentum after China's manufacturing sector expanded in March.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended at 39,807.37, up 0.1 per cent and a new all-time high that lifted the index closer to 40,000 points.
Sembcorp Industries says it “continues to see attractive opportunities in the renewables sector”.

The plant, located on Jurong Island in Singapore, was the first independent power project to enter the Republic’s electricity market since the National Electricity Market was implemented in 2003. It has been operational since 2007.

site_title: Macau March casino revenue beats estimates, boosted by holiday
summary: Macau's casino revenue surged 53% in March, beating analyst estimates, to 19.5 billion patacas (S$3.3 billion), driven by a four-day Easter holiday in Hong Kong. The month's total was about 75% of the pre-pandemic level in March 2019. Despite rising tourist arrivals, per person spending weakened amid deteriorating consumer sentiment, putting pressure on casino operators' profitability this year.

images.alt_text: A parade in front of the St Paul's Ruins on the first day of the Chinese New Year in Macau on Feb 10.
Gross gaming revenue grows 400 per cent to 19.5 billion patacas (S$3.3 billion), according to data released by the Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau.
Hong Kong and Macau will be the first to get Zeekr’s right-hand drive models, with pricing yet to be determined.
Tourists from greater China are the main driver of Hong Kong’s branded retail and luxury goods market.

site_title: The US dollar is more armoured division than currency
summary: The US dollar's resilience is unmatched, with frequent predictions of its decline failing to materialize. Despite Japan's attempts to boost the yen and potential rate cuts by the Federal Reserve, the greenback remains the dominant currency. A recent paper by Steven B. Kamin and Mark Sobel argues that US dollar dominance is embedded in the global economic system, making it unlikely to decline. Instead, the duo suggests that the US itself poses a greater risk to the dollar's stability, highlighting the need for sound policies and maintaining global trust.

site_title: Money laundering accused, Su Haijin, slapped with 12 new charges for cheating IRAS, MOM, banks
summary: Su Haijin, a Cypriot national, faces 14 charges related to money laundering, cheating the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras), and the Manpower Ministry (MOM). He allegedly jumped from a second-floor balcony to evade arrest and is accused of conspiring to cheat the authorities, possessing around S$3.8 million in criminal proceeds, and making false representations about a company's financial statements. Su is set to plead guilty on April 4 and will remain in remand. The charges are part of a larger anti-money laundering blitz that has resulted in over S$3 billion in assets seized by the authorities.

images.alt_text: Various items seized or issued prohibition of disposal orders during the anti-money laundering raid., including cash, bottles of liquor and luxury items.
DBS registered four charges – generally referring to a form of security interest usually taken by a lender to secure repayment of a loan – on Aug 18, 2021, to Aiqinhai Investment.
Su Haijin faces one charge of unlawfully evading arrest and another charge of money laundering.
Wang Baosen was granted Cambodian citizenship on April 6, 2020.

site_title: Xiaomi’s EV buyers face up to seven-month wait for car, app shows
summary: Xiaomi is advising buyers of its SU7 electric sedan that delivery times could range from 18 to 30 weeks, with the standard model taking 18-21 weeks and the most expensive model taking 27-30 weeks. The company's app shows that pre-orders for the car hit 88,898 in the first 24 hours, with the first batch of 5,000 Founder's Edition cars sold out immediately. Xiaomi's Beijing factory, capable of producing 200,000 cars annually, is expected to meet strong demand for the vehicle.

images.alt_text: During Thursday's two-hour event, Xiaomi CEO Lei Jun made a jibe at Apple for dropping its car project and declared Xiaomi's EV superior to Tesla's Model 3.

A Xiaomi SU7 electric vehicle on display at one of the company's stores in Shanghai, China, March 26, 2024. With a year-long EV price war going on in China, reception for the SU7 will likely dictate Xiaomi’s stock momentum after a 22 per cent gain since a February low.
The company will on Thursday evening announce its official price range and start taking orders for the car, dubbed the SU7, with the SU short for Speed Ultra.

site_title: OpenAI to open new office in Tokyo as part of global expansion
summary: OpenAI plans to open its first office in Asia in Tokyo, marking the company's expansion into the region. The Japan office, set to open in April, will be the third international location after London and Dublin. This move comes as AI adoption is growing among Japanese companies, including SoftBank and Nippon Telegraph & Telephone. OpenAI aims to expand its Japanese language services and collaborate with the government on regulating AI risks.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei ends at 2-week low as new fiscal year begins
summary: Japan's Nikkei index closed at a two-week low of 39,803.09, down 1.4% from its previous close, on the first day of the country's financial year. Investors sold stocks to book profits, with chip-related stocks and Toyota Motor experiencing significant declines. However, the Bank of Japan's survey showed optimism in Japan's services sector reached a 33-year high, and big firms plan to increase capital spending by 4.0% in the financial year. The yen remained steady, and watchmaker Citizen Watch and calculator maker Casio Computer were the top performers on the Nikkei.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 1.10 per cent, or 449.41 points, to 40,313.32 in early trade on Thursday, while the broader Topix index gave up 1.02 per cent, or 28.56 points, to 2,770.72.

site_title: JTC names new members to its board, reappoints Tan Chong Meng as chairman
summary: JTC Corporation has appointed three new members to its board: Andrew Kwan from Commonwealth Capital, Aaron Beng from the Ministry of Defence, and Tan Chin Hwee from SGTraDex Services. Tan Chong Meng has been reappointed as chairman. The changes take effect on April 1, 2024.

images.alt_text: Generic image of JTC Summit building

site_title: Growth should be top priority for India’s central bank: Modi
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi emphasized the importance of economic growth for the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) over the next decade, prioritizing it alongside inflation control. The RBI's inflation-targeting framework has kept price pressures moderate, and Modi praised its banking system transformation. Modi urged the RBI to focus on "unique tools" to balance inflation and growth, while maintaining trust and stability. This comes as Modi seeks re-election and India's rapid growth of 8% in the previous fiscal year.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) logo is displayed on a gate at the central bank's headquarters in Mumbai, India, on Tuesday, April 1, 2014. Indiaâs central bank left its key interest rate unchanged as consumer-price inflation eased to a two-year low and the rupee strengthened, increasing scope to support growth ahead of national elections starting this month. Photographer: Vivek Prakash/Bloomberg
India has now signed four FTAs in quick succession since 2021 after a gap of about nine years where no agreements were inked.
Modi has made high growth and infrastructure development his key poll plank in his last two tenures and has promised to make India a developed country by 2047.
FILE PHOTO: Mastercard and Visa credit cards are seen in front of displayed Wirecard logo in this illustration picture taken June 26, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A worker walks past the logo of Reserve Bank of India (RBI) inside its office in New Delhi, India July 8, 2019. REUTERS/Anushree Fadnavis/File Photo
If approved, Paytm will be allowed to continue processing payments via India’s popular unified payments interface.

site_title: World Bank warns of slowing growth in East Asia amid China slump
summary: The World Bank has warned of slowing growth in East Asia amid China's economic slowdown, with forecasted GDP growth of 4.5% in 2024 and 4.3% in 2025, down from 5% in 2023. China's transition to a balanced growth path is proving difficult, with the need for stronger social protection, progressive taxation, and reallocation of public spending. Developing East Asia and the Pacific are expected to post steady expansion, with the Philippines, Vietnam, and Cambodia poised to grow above 5% in 2024 and 6% in 2025, while Thailand and Myanmar lag behind.

images.alt_text: Most factories across Asia reduced output and new orders last month at softer rates, according to the PMI surveys.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 1)
summary: Landed home prices in Singapore rose 3.4% in Q1, following a 4.6% increase in Q4. Private home prices in Singapore grew 1.5% in Q1, with volumes falling 20% compared to the previous quarter. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) launched a centralised digital platform to combat money laundering and terrorism financing. A money laundering accused was slapped with 12 new charges for allegedly cheating IRAS and MOM, while JTC Corporation appointed new members to its board and reappointed Tan Chong Meng as chairman.

site_title: South Korea factory activity contracts in March as weak domestic demand drags, PMI shows
summary: South Korea's manufacturing activity weakened in March due to slowing domestic demand, despite robust overseas sales. The PMI for manufacturers fell to 49.8, below the 50-mark separating expansion from contraction. Domestic demand has weakened due to interest rates staying at elevated levels, while export demand rose for the third month in a row, supporting the economic outlook. Despite this, manufacturers expressed concerns about the pace of economic recovery and reduced inventory levels.

images.alt_text: Elsewhere in the region, new share sales set to raise several hundred million US dollars are surfacing.

FILE PHOTO: Trucks used to transport containers are seen at the Hanjin Shipping container terminal at the Busan New Port in Busan, about 420 km (261 miles) southeast of Seoul, August 8, 2013. Picture taken August 8, 2013. REUTERS/Lee Jae-Won (SOUTH KOREA - Tags: BUSINESS MARITIME)/File Photo
South Korea's industrial output index rose 3.1 per cent in February on a seasonally adjusted monthly basis, after a fall of 1.5 per cent in January, according to Statistics Korea.

site_title: AI software startup Ailytics raises US$2.7 million in pre-Series A funding led by Tin Men Capital
summary: Singapore-based AI software startup Ailytics has raised US$2.7 million in pre-Series A funding led by Tin Men Capital. The company uses scenario-based AI-powered video analytics to improve operational safety and productivity in the heavy industry. Ailytics plans to expand its services to other markets and increase research and development efforts. Its proprietary solution provides real-time insights on unsafe acts, productivity metrics, and security breaches, suitable for construction sites and manufacturing plants. The funding marks Tin Men's 11th investment in a B2B tech startup.

images.alt_text: The project is in early trial stages, and aims to develop a rocket that can carry up to ten tonnes of cargo in a 120 cubic metre container, says rocket maker Space Epoch.
Rakuten Group and Rakuten Bank entered into a memorandum of understanding on the re-organisation, which is set to take effect in October, the companies said in statements.
Cybersecurity firm StealthMole intends to use its fresh Series A funds to expand across countries and sectors.

site_title: How Xi Jinping plans to overtake America
summary: China's leader Xi Jinping plans to boost the country's economy through the development of "new productive forces," a concept that refers to the application of science and technology to production. The goal is to upgrade traditional industries, break foreign strangleholds on existing technologies, and forge a new path in industries of tomorrow. To achieve this, China has increased spending on science and technology, with a 10% budget increase in 2024, and has set national targets to increase research-and-development spending and lift technology's contribution to growth. Despite these efforts, China's economic recovery has been muted and uneven, and the country's leaders are concerned about its dependence on foreign components, software, and equipment.

images.alt_text: Citi last week raised its forecast for China’s 2024 growth to 5.0 per cent from 4.6 per cent, citing “recent positive data and policy delivery”.
The latest figures show China’s industrial engine room may be the driver to help the government achieve its annual growth target of around 5 per cent this year.

site_title: China’s Xi hails ties with Indonesia during Prabowo visit
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping praised Indonesia during a meeting with president-elect Prabowo Subianto, stating that bilateral ties have entered a new stage of jointly building a community with a shared future. China has invested billions in Indonesian projects, and Xi expressed willingness to deepen strategic cooperation and promote regional and global peace. Prabowo, who has made his first visit to China since winning elections, expressed support for closer Indonesia-China relations and a continuation of President Joko's friendship policy. The visit comes as China navigates tensions with other South-east Asian nations over territorial claims in the South China Sea.

images.alt_text: Hugely popular but without a political party of his own, former Indonesia President Joko Widodo is seeking to install a key ally as head of Golkar, said four senior politicians, who include three senior Golkar officials who have direct knowledge of the matter.

Defence Minister Prabowo and his vice-presidential running mate Gibran Rakabuming Raka received more than 96 million votes, roughly 58.6 per cent of the total count and enough to secure a first-round majority.
Prabowo Subianto is most likely to become Indonesia’s next president after securing close to 60 per cent of the votes, based on quick counts.

site_title: Rakuten Group aims to integrate bank, fintech units
summary: Rakuten Group and Rakuten Bank signed a memorandum of understanding to integrate their fintech businesses by October, aiming to strengthen collaboration and customer acquisition across various areas, including online banking, credit cards, and securities. The integration will not affect Rakuten Bank's listing on the Tokyo exchange. This move is expected to enhance the group's competitiveness in the Japanese market and beyond.

images.alt_text: Rakuten Bank has been enjoying growth in its customer base thanks to the group’s reward point system designed to lock in users.
The firm is among a large batch of junk issuers tapping the market.
The move comes a year after Japan’s third-largest banking group bought about 20 per cent of Rakuten Securities and made a business alliance.
Rakuten has taken to publicly listing its more successful units to generate cash, listing its Internet banking business – Rakuten Bank – in April and applying to list its securities business in July.

site_title: BOJ’s stash of bonds is set to shrink for first time since 2008
summary: The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) bond holdings are set to shrink for the first time since 2008, with an estimated shortfall of 196 billion yen (S$1.7 billion) in the July to September period. This decrease is expected to pose a challenge to Japan's US$7.4 trillion bond market, which has been used to maintain low inflation. The BOJ's projected reduction in bond purchases, if realized, would likely lead to rising interest rates and increased yields, despite the central bank's stance to let the market decide bond yields.

images.alt_text: In Japan, except for startups and other exceptions, banks are banned from owning a stake bigger than 5 per cent in a company.
“Japan is experiencing a historical chance to make a full exit from deflation,” says Kishida at a news conference.

The Bank of Japan ended eight years of negative interest rates and other remnants of its unorthodox policy last week, making a historic shift away from its focus on reflating growth with decades of massive monetary stimulus.

site_title: Asian LNG imports jump to record for March on bargain buying
summary: Asian liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports surged to a record 24 million tonnes in March, a 12% increase from last year, driven by bargain buying from emerging nations such as China, India, and Thailand. This shift reduces LNG deliveries to Europe, where inventories are at a seasonal high. Lower LNG prices in Asia and Europe make it less attractive for reselling, prompting top importers to bring deliveries back to their domestic market. This trend is expected to continue, with more LNG flowing into Asia and less to Europe.

images.alt_text: Canada's Minister of Natural Resources Jonathan Wilkinson says the country's government "is opposed to using government money to fund inefficient fossil fuel subsidies".
Qatar is raising its annual LNG production capacity from the North Field to 142 million tonnes by 2030 from 77 million tonnes currently.
FILE PHOTO: A liquified natural gas (LNG) tanker leaves the dock after discharge at PetroChina's receiving terminal in Dalian, Liaoning province, China July 16, 2018.  REUTERS/Chen Aizhu/File Photo

site_title: China’s new home prices rise at fastest pace in over 2½ years, survey shows
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.27% in March, the largest increase in over 2.5 years, driven by supportive measures to prop up the crisis-hit property sector. This follows a series of stimulus and easing measures, including easing home purchase regulations in Beijing. However, total sales by value among 100 real estate companies plummeted 49.0% year-on-year, indicating a turnaround is not yet in sight. Experts suggest that market sentiment may start to repair in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: The value of new home sales from the 100 biggest real estate companies is down about 46 per cent from a year earlier, preliminary data shows.
Overall housing sales declined 6.5 per cent in 2023 from the previous year and 35.9 per cent from the industry high in 2021.
China’s home price declines deepened in February in both new and used home segments, underscoring the challenge for authorities to salvage the beleaguered market.

site_title: Digital Core Reit acquires additional 10% interest in Osaka asset for 7.7 billion yen
summary: Digital Core Reit has acquired an additional 10% interest in a data centre in Osaka, Japan for 7.7 billion yen (S$68.9 million), following a share purchase agreement with Mitsubishi Corporation. The data centre has 114,940 square feet of net rentable space and a 95% occupancy rate, leased to leading global cloud providers. The acquisition is expected to be distribution per unit-accretive and net asset value-neutral.

images.alt_text: 信托在洛杉矶的数据中心，估价为5780万美元。（Digital Core REIT管理公司提供）

site_title: London losing out on new job listings for head office staff
summary: London is losing out on job listings for head office staff, with 41% of open roles being London-based, down from 50% pre-pandemic. Businesses are shifting traditional jobs outside the city due to high living costs and remote working trends. The trend towards regionalisation is evident, with the North of England and the Midlands gaining jobs, and Manchester positioning itself as the capital of the North. The findings pose a challenge to Mayor Sadiq Khan's bid for a third term, and may impact the UK's stagnant economy.

images.alt_text: Two stalled sales in London’s office market are a sign of its stultified nature, amid higher interest rates and concerns around a trend towards hybrid working.

site_title: China’s Chery offers tax breaks, subsidies on some combustion vehicles
summary: China's Chery automaker has announced cash discounts of up to 15,000 yuan on select combustion models, including the Arrizo 8 high-performance edition and off-road SUV Discovery 06, to combat the country's cutthroat auto market. The incentives include purchase tax breaks, trade-in subsidies, and auto finance discounts. Eligible models include the Tiggo 9, Tiggo 8 Pro champion edition, and Tiggo 8 Plus, with limited-time purchase tax giveaways, trade-in subsidies of up to 20,000 yuan, and auto finance discounts of up to 5,000 yuan.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed after US inflation data, China figures give boost
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday following US inflation data and Chinese factory activity. The Dow and S&P 500 ended at records, while Seoul, Singapore, and Manila stocks rose, while Taipei and Jakarta lost ground. China's manufacturing sector showed signs of recovery, with a 50.8 reading in March, fueling hopes that the economy may have bottomed out. The US Federal Reserve's Jerome Powell said the inflation data was "in line with expectations" and decision-makers were on track to hit their two percent inflation target.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 76 to 39.

site_title: China criticises US tightening of chip export rules
summary: China has criticized the US for tightening rules on semiconductor exports, calling it a "serious obstacle" to trade and cooperation. The US rules, revised last week, aim to limit China's access to US artificial intelligence chips and chipmaking tools, citing national security concerns. China's Commerce Ministry said the move harms Chinese and American companies' legitimate rights and interests, while expressing readiness to strengthen mutually beneficial cooperation and promote global semiconductor industry stability. The US has already barred exports to China, affecting companies like Nvidia and AMD.

site_title: China Southern Airlines to add 17 international routes
summary: China Southern Airlines announced plans to add 17 international routes, including Amsterdam, London, and Tehran, in an effort to boost international travel this year. The airline's international route network has recovered to 80% of 2019 levels, and it aims to reach 85% by the end of the year. The new routes will be launched in the coming months before October 26, as China's aviation regulator expects 80% of pre-Covid international flights to reach China by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An Airbus A380-800 aircraft from China Southern Airlines lands at the Beijing Daxing International Airport that is under construction, during a test flight in Beijing, China May 13, 2019.   REUTERS/Stringe
China’s green light is a boost to the US planemaker, which has been hit by the fallout from a mid-air blowout of a cabin panel on a 737 MAX 9 jet operated by Alaska Airlines.

site_title: Asia’s factories paint picture of uneven recovery in March
summary: Manufacturing activity in Asia showed a mixed picture in March, with some countries, such as South Korea and Vietnam, experiencing contraction, while others, like Taiwan and Japan, indicated a recovery. Despite subdued global demand, Taiwan's factories reported their highest confidence in nearly three years due to signs of price and supply stability. China's Caixin manufacturing PMI rose to 51.1, its fifth straight month of expansion, suggesting the world's second-largest economy is gaining momentum.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO:  Workers direct a crane lifting ductile iron pipes for export at a port in Lianyungang, Jiangsu province, China June 30, 2019. REUTERS/Stringer

site_title: Emiratis battle to preserve dying art of Al Talli
summary: In the UAE, the traditional embroidery technique Al Talli is facing a decline due to the country's rapid modernization. Emirati women, such as Mariam al-Kalbani, are working to preserve the art by teaching young women the skill. Al Talli, which involves hand-weaving braided ribbons to adorn traditional clothing and bags, is recognized by Unesco as an Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity. Efforts are being made to document and promote the technique to ensure its survival for future generations.

images.alt_text: A drawing of an Emirati woman practicing Al Talli, a traditional local embroidery technique, is painted on a parking meter in Dubai on September 30, 2023. The art of hand-weaving braided shiny ribbons to adorn traditional clothing and bags is called Al Talli, and is on UNESCO's Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity list. But with the relentless pace of change in the United Arab Emirates, its days may be numbered. (Photo by Amanda  MOUAWAD / AFP)

site_title: UOB cutting One savings account rates; DBS, OCBC staying put for now on similar products
summary: UOB is reducing interest rates for its One savings account, citing long-term interest rate environment expectations. The revised rates, effective May 1, will range from 3 to 4.5% for balances between S$30,000 and S$100,000, with tiered bonus interest rates applicable for spending and salary crediting. This move comes ahead of anticipated US Federal Reserve rate cuts and is seen as a competitive response from UOB to rival banks DBS and OCBC.

images.alt_text: UOB's general insurance arm declared a final dividend of 8.5 Singapore cents per share and a special dividend of 4 cents per share for FY2023.
Japan is a sobering example of the dangers of ultra-low rates. Its disinflation cycle started in the 1990s and led to stagnant economic growth and poor investor sentiment that lasted decades.
The late Wee Cho Yaw left his mark in many areas including the property sector.
The loans were intended for purchasing 38 units in Marina Collection, a high-end waterfront residential enclave developed and sold by LMC, a subsidiary of Indonesia’s Lippo Group.

site_title: Indonesia’s March inflation rate at highest in 7 months
summary: Indonesia's inflation rate accelerated to 3.05% in March, the highest in 7 months, driven by rising demand during Ramadan. Consumer prices rose 0.52% month-over-month, with core inflation at 1.77%. The country's inflation target range is 1.5-3.5%, and analysts expect temporary inflation risks due to food subsidies and price controls. Despite this, Bank Indonesia is likely to keep interest rates unchanged for now, as the central bank waits for developments in the US economy and Fed rate.

images.alt_text: Freeport Indonesia, controlled by mining giant Freeport McMoran has called for the ban to be relaxed as its Gresik smelter would not be operating at full capacity by June.
Rept Battero Energy’s first overseas battery factory will be housed alongside Tsingshan’s existing operations in Weda Bay and could begin operating as soon as next year.
Indonesia’s outgoing leader Joko Widodo (left) will hand over the baton to incoming President Prabowo Subianto while Vietnam's President Vo Van Thuong (right) has resigned.
Cainiao is the logistics backbone of founder and now 67 per cent owner Alibaba – a figure which would have dropped to somewhere above 50 per cent after listing.

This photo taken on on February 14, 2024 shows Indonesia's presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto gesturing after casting his ballot to vote in Indonesia’s presidential and legislative elections in Bogor, West Java. Indonesian Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto was winning the archipelago's presidential election by a wide margin with half of all votes counted, the country's election commission vote tracker showed on February 16. (Photo by Yasuyoshi CHIBA / AFP)

site_title: Toyota’s Sato beats previous CEOs with first-year stock gains
summary: Toyota shares have doubled in the first year under CEO Koji Sato, outperforming the Nikkei 225 Stock Average by 60 percentage points. This is the largest gain since the merger of Toyota Motor and Toyota Motor Sales in 1982. Despite Tesla's 29% decline, Toyota's shares remain relatively undervalued with a price-to-earnings ratio of 11 times. Sato faces challenges in expanding corporate value in the rapidly changing automotive industry, including a safety scandal and inventory shortages. His second-year performance will be crucial in determining Toyota's future stock performance.

images.alt_text: Toyota Hilux could be ready by the end of next year.
The automaker is currently discounting almost every electric and hybrid car model it sells, as part of a marketing campaign declaring “electricity is cheaper than oil”.
Unions across industries, including automobiles, electronics, metals, heavy machinery and the service sector have all demanded hefty pay hikes.

site_title: China’s factory activity expands at fastest clip in 13 months: Caixin PMI
summary: China's manufacturing activity expanded at the fastest pace in 13 months in March, with a Caixin/S&P Global manufacturing PMI of 51.1, above forecasts. This marks the fifth consecutive month of expansion, driven by growing new orders and a 50-point rise in business confidence to an 11-month-high. Analysts say policymakers must roll out more stimulus to hit the 5% economic growth target, as a weak statistical base and a deep slump in the property sector remain major drags on activity.

images.alt_text: SAIC Motor hopes to cut 30 per cent of employees at SAIC-GM, 10 per cent at SAIC Volkswagen and more than half at its Rising Auto EV subsidiary, sources said.
In Japan, except for startups and other exceptions, banks are banned from owning a stake bigger than 5 per cent in a company.
The value of new home sales from the 100 biggest real estate companies is down about 46 per cent from a year earlier, preliminary data shows.
The latest figures show China’s industrial engine room may be the driver to help the government achieve its annual growth target of around 5 per cent this year.
During Thursday's two-hour event, Xiaomi CEO Lei Jun made a jibe at Apple for dropping its car project and declared Xiaomi's EV superior to Tesla's Model 3.
FILE PHOTO: The company logo of Chinese developer Country Garden is pictured at the Shanghai Country Garden Center in Shanghai, China August 9, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
During January-March 2024, money raised via China IPOs plunged two-thirds from a year ago to just US$2.4 billion.

site_title: Singapore shares climb at Monday’s open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose at the opening bell on Monday, mirroring gains in US and European markets. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 6.61 points or 0.2% to 3,230.62, with gainers outnumbering losers 76 to 39. Seatrium was the most heavily traded counter, rising S$0.001 or 1.3% to S$0.08. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS declining S$0.08 or 0.2% and OCBC rising S$0.07 or 0.5%. The rally followed Wall Street's record highs on Thursday, driven by expectations of interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: Keppel’s infrastructure division and Keppel Infrastructure Trust are proposing to amend and extend their capacity tolling agreement for the Keppel Merlimau Cogen (KMC) plant by 10 years.

site_title: US home prices jump by most in nearly two years in February
summary: US home prices surged by 1.2% in February, the largest monthly increase since April 2022, according to the Federal Housing Finance Agency. This marks a 7% year-over-year gain, the fastest since November 2022. The increase is attributed to low interest rates and limited home supply, prompting many homeowners to stay put rather than relocate or upgrade. The Fed's efforts to tame inflation may be hindered by the rising home prices, which contribute to imputed rents and stubbornly high inflation indexes.

site_title: MAS launches centralised digital platform against money laundering, terrorism financing
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched the Cosmic platform, a centralized digital platform to combat money laundering, terrorism financing, and proliferation financing globally. Participating financial institutions, including six major banks, will share customer information to identify suspicious activities. The platform will focus on three key financial crime risks in the commercial banking sector and will be used to prevent bad actors from using Singapore's banking network for illegal activities. The launch comes after the Financial Services and Markets Act 2023 was amended to set out the legislative framework for Cosmic.

images.alt_text: Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) logo

Singapore is introducing the Bill to comply with new requirements introduced in October 2020 by the Financial Action Task Force (FATF),  a global money laundering and terrorist financing watchdog of which Singapore is currently president.
Consumer price increases stayed largely flat in September, a week after the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) moved to ease monetary policy on the back of subdued inflation.

A survey conducted by the MAS found that financial institutions (FIs) in Singapore perceived money laundering risks as the fourth biggest risk, up from seventh place half a year ago, as of October this year.

site_title: World Bank cuts Thai growth to 2.8% on weaker exports
summary: The World Bank has cut Thailand's economic growth forecast to 2.8% for 2024, down from 3.2%, due to weak exports and a delayed budget. This is the second downgrade, following the central bank's reduction to 2.5-3.0% in February. Tourism and private consumption are expected to drive growth, with tourist arrivals projected to reach 90% of pre-pandemic levels. The government aims for a record 40 million foreign visitors this year, despite a "crisis" in the economy, with Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin proposing a US$14 billion handout to stimulate growth.

images.alt_text: The Thai economy unexpectedly shrank 0.6 per cent in the final quarter of 2023 from the third, with full-year growth at 1.9 per cent.
Thailand expects to earn more revenue than neighbouring countries that operate casinos and will also introduce a ‘sin tax’ that will be used for social benefits, Julapun Amornvivat told reporters.
Regulatory challenges for fintech players such as Wise could prove to be a blessing in disguise.
Thailand's manufacturing production index in February dropped 2.84 per cent from a year earlier, the industry ministry said on Thursday.

site_title: Mizuho will expand focus on M&A for smaller Japanese companies
summary: Mizuho Financial Group will invest in Japan Blue M&A Advisory (JBMA) to expand its mergers and acquisitions (M&A) business for small and medium-sized Japanese companies. The move comes as Japan's ageing population causes a shortage of successors for smaller businesses, with over 50% of company presidents older than 60. This investment is expected to address the under-served M&A needs of smaller companies, following a surge in corporate bankruptcies due to succession difficulties. Mizuho Securities and Mizuho Bank will jointly own JBMA, with Nippon Management Center holding more than 50%.

site_title: China state firm to sell 20 Shanghai office towers in downturn
summary: China's state-owned Shanghai Lujiazui Finance & Trade Zone Development is offering to sell about 20 office buildings in the financial hub, with prices starting at 30 billion yuan (S$5.64 billion). The sale is a response to the city's severe commercial property downturn, with office vacancy rates reaching 20.9% and rents plummeting. The move is expected to further weigh on the commercial property market, which has seen a 63% decline in sales deals in the first quarter. The sale is a rare pivot in strategy for the state landlord, which aims to boost income through both rent and sales.

images.alt_text: The real estate downturn affects the ability of some Chinese cities to lease land to developers, a key revenue source.

site_title: Gold hits record high on rising hopes for Fed rate cut in June
summary: Gold prices reached a record high of $2,256.09 per ounce after US inflation data showed moderation in February, boosting bets for a June interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. Spot gold rose 1% to $2,255.39 per ounce, while US gold futures gained 1.7% to $2,275.70 per ounce. Traders are pricing in a 69% probability of a rate cut in June, which could boost the opportunity cost of holding bullion.

images.alt_text: From a technical perspective, investors will have reasons to cheer, with gold expected to scale new all-time highs going forward.

site_title: Keppel Reit to acquire 50% interest in Sydney office building for A$363.8 million
summary: Keppel Reit has agreed to acquire a 50% stake in a Sydney office building for A$363.8 million. The building, located at 255 George Street, is home to key tenants such as the Australian Taxation Office and the Bank of Queensland. The acquisition is expected to generate a first-year yield exceeding 6% and distribution per unit accretion of 1.4% on a pro-forma basis.

images.alt_text: Koh Wee Lih, chief executive of Keppel real estate investment trust, emphasised the manager's core operating principles of prudent capital management, portfolio diversification, and taking the long view, especially in the face of uncertainty.
Keppel’s infrastructure division and Keppel Infrastructure Trust are proposing to amend and extend their capacity tolling agreement for the Keppel Merlimau Cogen (KMC) plant by 10 years.

site_title: What does hike in insurance coverage on bank deposits to $100,000 mean for you?
summary: Singapore's Deposit Insurance Scheme will increase its coverage limit from S$75,000 to S$100,000 for all retail banks and finance companies starting April 1, 2024. This change aims to restore the percentage of fully insured depositors to 91%, aligning with international norms. The increased coverage applies to Singapore-dollar denominated deposits, including savings, current accounts, fixed deposits, and monies under the Supplementary Retirement Scheme. Foreign currency deposits, structured deposits, and investment products are not covered. The increase is due to the growth in deposits since the previous limit change in 2019, and will be funded through premiums paid by member institutions.

images.alt_text:
CMG20220718-HengYY02/王彦燕/拍MAS金管局 [10,Shenton Way,S079117]

district in Singapore on July 18, 2022.
The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) building at Shenton Way.
