site_title: Sembcorp takes out offshore loan facility of 400 million yuan
summary: Sembcorp Industries signed a 400 million yuan (S$76 million) dual currency-denominated revolving credit facility with DBS (Hong Kong) for offshore funds. The facility has an initial three-year tenure and a two-year extension option, guaranteed by Sembcorp Utilities. The funds will be used for general corporate purposes, including refinancing, capital expenditure, and mergers and acquisitions in China. Sembcorp sees attractive opportunities in the renewables sector and notes that cash flows from its existing Chinese assets will fund its growth plans.

images.alt_text: Power generated from the project will be sold to SJVN under a 25-year power purchase agreement.

The project involves building and developing a large-scale integrated project involving 50 megawatts of solar capabilities and 14 megawatt-hour of battery energy storage in Nusantara, the future capital city of Indonesia.
Sembcorp Industries proposes a final dividend of 8 Singapore cents, bringing the total dividend for FY2023 to 13 Singapore cents.

site_title: HDB resale prices rise at a faster 1.7% pace in Q1: flash data
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore rose 1.7% in Q1 2024, the fastest pace in 16 consecutive quarters, according to flash data. Resale volumes increased 5.5% to 6,928 cases. Analysts attribute the growth to first-time buyer demand and increased HDB resale flat supply. Despite the higher pace, experts believe it does not signal an acceleration of public housing price inflation, citing government policies taking time to affect the market.

images.alt_text: Construction Site of HDB MacPherson Weave at Circuit Road (Top by 1 Mar 2026)
Luqman Hakim, chief data and analytics officer at 99.co, says the price growth in February 2024 is "much more modest" compared to the previous month.
HDB will offer about 6,800 flats in Jurong East, Kallang/Whampoa, Queenstown, Tampines, Woodlands and Yishun.

site_title: AI craze drives record quarterly foreign flows to South Korean stocks
summary: South Korean stocks saw a record quarterly foreign inflow of $12.2 billion in the first three months of 2024, driven by investors' frenzy over artificial intelligence (AI). This influx propelled foreign ownership of the Kospi index to 34.42%, the highest since 2021. Chipmakers like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, key players in the AI supply chain, attracted significant investment. Analysts expect continued foreign buying, with Goldman Sachs noting "light" ownership levels despite a recent $50 billion investment exodus.

images.alt_text: The rules seek to halt shipments to China of more advanced artificial intelligence chips designed by Nvidia and others.
US President Joe Biden is set to host Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida for an official visit to the US on Apr 10.

site_title: India, South Korea and Japan to stay busy with IPOs while China stalls
summary: Asia-Pacific initial public offerings (IPOs) fell to a 5-year low in Q1 2024, with a 46% drop in new share sales to $11 billion, the lowest quarterly tally since 2019. China's scrutiny of domestic new share sales and concerns over its economy led to a slowdown, while South Korea, India, and Japan are expected to stay busy with IPOs, with deals in South Korea, India, and Japan set to raise hundreds of millions of US dollars.

images.alt_text: SK Hynix recently forecast positive momentum in AI memory to extend into 2025.

site_title: Singapore’s private home price growth slows to 1.5% in Q1 as sales fall 20%: URA
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 1.5% in Q1 2024, driven by landed home prices, which increased 3.4%. Despite a 20% decline in sales volume, market resilience and elevated construction costs supported prices. Experts expect prices to stabilize ahead of new supply, with Knight Frank predicting prices may plateau in certain segments. Non-landed home prices in the Core Central Region rose 3.1%, while the Outside Central Region saw a 0.4% increase. Total transaction volume declined 20% in Q1, with foreigners accounting for 1.1% of buyers.

images.alt_text: Private home prices grew by 3.2 per cent in Q1 2023, after inching up 0.4 per cent in the previous quarter.

site_title: Keppel, KIT expect proposal to extend KMC plant contract to generate up to S$1.1 billion in cash flows
summary: Keppel and Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) have proposed a 10-year extension of the capacity tolling agreement for the Keppel Merlimau Cogen (KMC) power plant from 2030 to 2040, generating up to S$1.1 billion in long-term capacity payments. This will support KMC's refinancing and unlock value for shareholders. The operations and maintenance contract will also be extended by another 10 years to 2044, worth up to S$342.8 million. The proposed amendment is subject to shareholder and unitholder approval.

images.alt_text: Key tenants of the office building include the Australian Taxation Office and the Bank of Queensland.
Keppel's chief executive Loh Chin Hua said Keppel, which had its roots in the oil and gas industry, has made “significant progress” over the years to transform and adapt to the changing environment.
In May 2023, Keppel said it would transform itself from a conglomerate to a global alternative asset manager, with a target of S$100 billion in assets under management.

Koh Wee Lih, chief executive of Keppel real estate investment trust, emphasised the manager's core operating principles of prudent capital management, portfolio diversification, and taking the long view, especially in the face of uncertainty.

site_title: China’s SAIC aims to slash jobs at GM, VW ventures and EV unit, sources say
summary: China's SAIC Motor plans to slash 30% of employees at its joint venture with General Motors (SAIC-GM), 10% at its venture with Volkswagen (SAIC-VW), and over half at its electric vehicle unit, Rising Auto. The staff reductions are aimed at 2024, primarily through implementing stricter performance standards and offering payouts to lower-rated employees. SAIC's sales have fallen 16% in the first two months of 2024, and the company has recruited 2,000 new employees in the software and new-energy vehicle sectors.

images.alt_text: Huawei's managing director and chairman of smart car solutions, Richard Yu, is expecting the unit to turn a profit from April.
During Thursday's two-hour event, Xiaomi CEO Lei Jun made a jibe at Apple for dropping its car project and declared Xiaomi's EV superior to Tesla's Model 3.
The new Smart #1 electric cars are planned for a public launch on Apr 22.

Mini EVs being charged on a street in Liuzhou, in China's Guangxi province. These tiny vehicles weave through traffic in southern China, their cheerful designs bringing a touch of colour to the EV revolution in the country.
The EPA rule cuts vehicle emissions by 49 per cent by 2032 compared with 56 per cent under the initial proposal.

A Xiaomi SU7 electric vehicle on display at one of the company's stores in Shanghai, China, March 26, 2024. With a year-long EV price war going on in China, reception for the SU7 will likely dictate Xiaomi’s stock momentum after a 22 per cent gain since a February low.

site_title: South Korea export growth continues, supporting economic outlook
summary: South Korea's exports continued to grow, increasing 9.9% from last year, driven by rising demand for semiconductors and technology devices. Headline exports rose 3.1%, while overall imports decreased 12.3%, resulting in a trade surplus of US$4.3 billion. The growth supports policymakers' confidence in a robust first quarter economy, with South Korea serving as a bellwether for global commerce due to its dominance in memory chips and smartphones.

images.alt_text: South Korea's industrial output index rose 3.1 per cent in February on a seasonally adjusted monthly basis, after a fall of 1.5 per cent in January, according to Statistics Korea.
South Korea is currently considering several ways to beef up the reform plan, including tax incentives after the initial proposal fell short of market expectations.
Housing prices are a key barometer of risks for developers.

site_title: UK’s second biggest mortgage lender pulls offers over flood risk
summary: UK's second-largest mortgage lender, Nationwide, has stopped making loans on homes at high risk of flooding due to concerns about insurability. The company uses mapping technology to identify vulnerable homes and will decline to make loans on those deemed at high risk. This move is driven by the government-backed Flood Re programme's expiring mandate in 15 years, which may leave some homes uninsurable. Nationwide remains optimistic about flood risk management improving, potentially mitigating the impact on mortgage lending.

images.alt_text: Banks and building societies authorised 61,325 home loans, up from 60,497 in February and the most since September 2022.
The highest interest rates in 16 years and a surge in inflation over the past two years has drained consumer finances.
The Bank of England’s credit conditions survey published on Thursday (Apr 11) showed that lenders increased the availability of home loans in the first quarter after a rise in demand from borrowers.
UK renters are concentrated among younger generations and face a further squeeze.
Two stalled sales in London’s office market are a sign of its stultified nature, amid higher interest rates and concerns around a trend towards hybrid working.
For London's prime properties, which account for the top 10 per cent of rents, rates are forecast to grow by 2.9 per cent this year.

site_title: High Court dismisses bid by co-founder and CTO to liquidate Cake Group
summary: The Singapore High Court dismissed Chua U-Zyn's bid to liquidate Cake Group, a crypto firm, citing that the move was not an appropriate quick fix to his troubles. The court found no grounds to shut down the company, urging the co-founders to resolve their conflict with a careful approach. Chua had sought liquidation after disagreements with CEO Julian Hosp over layoffs, while Hosp had offered to buy him out in the past but the deal did not materialize. The decision allows Cake Group to continue operations, with Hosp celebrating the outcome on social media.

images.alt_text: Han Byung Joon started Silicon Box in 2021, together with industry veterans Sehat Sutardja and Weili Dai.

site_title: Boosted by name brand beers, Carlsberg sees higher sales
summary: Carlsberg reported a 4.4% increase in revenue to US$2.5 billion in the first quarter, driven by higher sales of its namesake brand, which grew 15% in China, India, Vietnam, and Ukraine. Sales of premium beers and non-alcoholic drinks also saw growth, with Tuborg increasing by 8% in China. The company maintains its full-year earnings outlook and expects organic operating profit to grow by 1-5%.

images.alt_text: Heineken, Carlsberg and Budweiser maker Anheuser-Busch InBev are among the beer companies that will benefit if good weather coincides with the Euro 2024 football tournament in June and July.

site_title: UK restaurants and bars cut hours as costs soar by £3.4 billion
summary: UK restaurants and bars are cutting staff working hours and opening hours to cope with a £3.4 billion surge in annual costs, with the sector's wage bill increasing by £3.2 billion and business rates adding £224 million. The sector's chief executive, Kate Nicholls, attributes the costs to a "tsunami of costs" including energy, food waste, and inflation, as well as the new National Living Wage. The Bank of England is monitoring the impact of higher wages on inflation, potentially delaying interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Britain's latest GDP figures will be disappointing for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, who has been accused by the opposition Labour Party – far ahead in opinion polls – of overseeing “Rishi’s recession”.
British consumer price inflation slowed to 3.4 per cent in February.
Public sector net borrowing, excluding state-owned banks, was £8.401 billion (S$14.4 billion) last month, down from £11.843 billion a year ago.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, KIT, Keppel Reit, Sembcorp, ComfortDelGro, Hatten Land
summary: Keppel's infrastructure division and Keppel Infrastructure Trust propose to extend their capacity tolling agreement for the Keppel Merlimau Cogen plant by 10 years, from 2030 to 2040, generating up to S$1.1 billion in long-term capacity payments. Keppel Reit acquires a 50% interest in a Sydney office building for S$321 million, expected to generate a 6% first-year yield. Shares of Keppel and Keppel Reit saw changes, with Keppel ending down 0.9% and Keppel Reit units closing 0.6% higher.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, advancers outnumber decliners 297 to 240, with 1.5 billion securities worth S$1.3 billion changing hands.

site_title: Gold holds steady as investors focus on US Fed meeting
summary: Gold prices held steady on Tuesday, set for a third straight monthly gain, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy decision and non-farm payrolls data. Analysts raised 2024 gold price forecasts due to simmering geopolitical woes, while interest rates remain steady at 5.25% to 5.5%. Bullion prices have gained 4.6% this month, with spot gold unchanged at $2,334.92 per ounce. Investors await the Fed's decision and non-farm payrolls data, which could impact interest rates and gold prices.

images.alt_text: Physical gold dealers in India charged premiums last week for the first time in nearly two months as a pullback in domestic prices lured buyers.

site_title: Xiaomi locks in over 75,000 orders for SU7 car, targets over 10,000 deliveries in June
summary: Xiaomi has secured 75,723 pre-orders for its SU7 electric sedan, targeting over 10,000 deliveries in June. The company aims to deliver over 100,000 units in 2024, setting a record for an electric vehicle startup. Xiaomi founder Lei Jun plans to keep the automotive business "100 per cent focused" on the Chinese market for the next three years. The company has already brought forward deliveries of the SU7, with the Pro models expected to start shipping by the end of May.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi’s SU7 enters a crowded China EV market with an attention-grabbing price tag – under US$30,000 for the base model, cheaper than Tesla’s Model 3 in China.
BYD, which overtook Tesla to become the world’s largest EV producer in late 2023, saw sales jump 46 per cent year on year to 302,459 vehicles.
Xiaomi has advised potential buyers of its sedan that they could face wait times of four to seven months, a sign of strong interest.

site_title: Star Entertainment chair Foster steps down, adds to management exodus
summary: Star Entertainment chair David Foster has stepped down, adding to an exodus of senior management at the casino operator. Foster took over as chairman in March 2023 and led additional executive duties after CEO Robbie Cooke and finance officer Christina Katsibouba's exits. Foster's departure comes at a time when the company faces a second inquiry into its Sydney casino operations, following a license suspension in October 2022. Anne Ward, an independent and non-executive director, will take over as chair, while the company seeks a permanent replacement for its chief executive position.

images.alt_text: Berjaya Corp’s founder Vincent Tan is one of the 50 richest in Forbes Malaysia list.
Last year, Crown Resorts agreed to pay a A$450 million (S$395.7 million) fine for breaking anti-money laundering laws.
MBS' revenue from hotel rooms grew 29.9 per cent to US$126 million in Q1 from US$97 million a year ago.
Genting is pledging to continue paying the state about 67 per cent of its slot machine revenue in taxes, an amount that includes administrative fees and other expenses.

site_title: GoTo narrows Q1 loss to 420 billion rupiah with TikTok deal, cost cuts
summary: GoTo Group narrowed its Q1 loss to 420 billion rupiah, a fraction of its 2.8 trillion rupiah loss last year, due to cost cuts and a deal with TikTok. The company's e-commerce segment turned cash flow positive after the deal, with 110 billion rupiah in e-commerce service fee revenues in February and March, expected to increase in future quarters. GoTo's core businesses of on-demand services and fintech also grew during the quarter, with adjusted Ebitda turning positive.

images.alt_text: DBS Research Group raised its target price on GoTo to 99 rupiah from 96 rupiah previously.

site_title: Japan’s service sector sentiment rises to highest in over three decades
summary: Japan's service sector sentiment reached its highest in over three decades, according to a central bank survey, boosting hopes for a fragile economic recovery. The survey showed a +34 reading for big non-manufacturers and +11 for big manufacturers, with manufacturers' sentiment soured for the first time in four quarters. The Bank of Japan will scrutinize these numbers in its next meeting, with some economists predicting interest rate hikes if wage hikes accelerate. Japan's economy expanded 0.4% annually in the final quarter of last year, narrowly avoiding a technical recession.

images.alt_text: In Japan, except for startups and other exceptions, banks are banned from owning a stake bigger than 5 per cent in a company.
Hostile bids, once shunned because they were seen as disruptive to Japan Inc’s collaborative ethos, are still relatively rare, but the frequency is increasing.
The project will be located 330 km off south-west Vietnam.
In the longer term, Masato Kanda, vice-finance minister for international affairs, suggests that more structural reform is vital to restore the yen’s attractiveness.
News of the meeting triggered a sharp rebound in the yen from a 34-year low of 151.97 hit earlier on Wednesday.

site_title: Time to tell the story: Zegna goes big at Milan Design Week
summary: Italian luxury menswear label Zegna marks the launch of its book "Born in Oasi Zegna" with multiple activations during Milan Design Week. The book tells the story of the brand's century-old societal and environmental commitments, from its founder Ermenegildo Zegna's pioneering vision to enhance his hometown and protect the environment. Zegna's third- and fourth-generation family members aim to share the brand's legacy and vertically integrated production system, which includes a 100 sq km nature reserve in northern Italy, Oasi Zegna, featuring over 500,000 trees.

images.alt_text: Born in Oasi Zegna is a beautifully-illustrated tome.

site_title: ‘Competition for talent’ a poor excuse to keep key executives’ pay under wraps
summary: Singapore's listed companies often cite "competition for talent" as a reason for not disclosing top management executive remuneration. However, regulators and investors scrutinize salaries, and SGX rules require disclosure of remuneration for top five key management personnel. Companies such as CapitaLand Investment and UOB-Kay Hian have cited "competition for talent" as a reason, but their explanations are not compelling. The article suggests that companies should be more transparent about remuneration to attract and retain talent, and that not disclosing remuneration raises questions about the company's financial health and competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of the interior and exterior of SGX

site_title: Fintech startup Qashier gets in-principle approval for major payment institution licence from MAS
summary: Singapore-based fintech startup Qashier received in-principle approval for a major payment institution licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The approval allows Qashier to offer safer and faster domestic and cross-border payments for businesses in Singapore and the region. The company plans to expand its offerings across South-east Asia and beyond, with a focus on helping businesses transition to the digital economy through its integrated point-of-sale and payment solution.

site_title: Tesla’s plan for affordable cars takes page from Detroit rivals
summary: Tesla plans to launch "more affordable" models by early next year, using current product lines rather than developing new ones. The strategy, similar to that of Detroit rivals Ford and General Motors, aims to make the company more competitive in the mass-market automotive market. Tesla had shelved plans for a long-awaited, new model expected to cost $25,000, instead opting to offer basic versions of the Model 3 and Y. The move has sparked praise from investors and analysts, but some question whether it will disrupt the traditional car-making industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tesla Chief Executive Officer Elon Musk gets in a Tesla car as he leaves a hotel in Beijing, China May 31, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Forget ambience, just get the pizza at L’antica
summary: L'antica Pizzeria Da Michele, a Singapore branch of the famous Naples eatery, delivers on pizza but falls short on ambiance. The restaurant's no-frills interior, crowded tables, and loud music create an uncomfortable dining experience. However, the pizza is a standout, with a soft, resilient crust and a confident spring in each bite. The base is ace, but toppings vary in quality. With a pedigree from Naples' best pizza joint since 1870, L'antica is worth visiting for pizza enthusiasts, but sacrifices must be made for a stress-free meal. Rating: 6.5.

images.alt_text: Roia's interiors have been nicely spruced up.

site_title: Gojek and ComfortDelGro Taxi to send untaken rides to each other’s platforms
summary: Gojek and ComfortDelGro Taxi have partnered to send untaken rides from one platform to the other, enhancing reliability and availability of rides during non-peak hours. Starting April 29, Gojek will dispatch untaken rides to ComfortDelGro's platform, and vice versa. This move aims to improve earnings for drivers and reduce waiting times for commuters. The partnership will also explore areas such as electric vehicles, ancillary revenue, and support services. The collaboration aims to benefit both drivers and commuters, providing a win-win situation.

images.alt_text: As part of the tie-up, the companies have agreed to provide Gojek users access to ComfortDelGro taxis via the Gojek app to help with the driver shortage.
Pixgeneric / generic pictures of gojek signage at the Taxi stand / pickup stand at Funan Mall Photo was taken on 30 September 2022.
Comfortdelgro will raise commissions for booked rides to 7 per cent, running counter  to what its ride-hailing rivals have done.

site_title: Too many property agents? Cap commissions on home sales
summary: Singapore's property market may benefit from capping commissions on home sales, rather than limiting the number of real estate agents. Currently, the commission rate can range from 1% to 3% and is negotiated between agents and developers. Capping the rate at 1.5% could reduce frictional costs, prevent market distortion, and encourage developers to focus on offering better fittings and lower selling prices. This could lead to efficiency gains and higher quality homes, ultimately benefiting buyers. The move could also help curb the growth in the number of property agents and alleviate labor market tightness.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Estate Agents Association inked a memorandum of understanding with 16 leading property agencies to adopt co-booking best practices.
Close to a third of the respondents who took part in the survey felt that there is an oversupply of property agents in the market.

site_title: SGX focuses on shareholder value as it proposes rules to facilitate shareholder-requisitioned meetings
summary: SGX Regulation (SGX RegCo) proposed new rules to facilitate shareholder-requisitioned meetings, aiming to create shareholder value. The proposed rules require listed issuers to assist with enabling shareholder-requisitioned meetings within 21 days of receiving a requisition notice. This move aims to address challenges faced by requisitionists, including difficulties in releasing announcements and documents, and disputes over the validity of requisition notices. The public consultation on the proposed rules is open until May 23, and SGX RegCo is working on other initiatives to improve shareholder value, including enhancing board effectiveness and encouraging market discipline.

images.alt_text: Boardroom battles where shareholders seek to propose resolutions to remove an existing director are always going to be acrimonious encounters.
SGListCos has been exploring improving investor relations capability as part of the solution for fair valuation and more trading.

While the requisition of a general meeting may be unwelcomed, boards should consider the merits of the proposals from the perspective of the issuer and its shareholders as a whole, said Tan Boon Gin, CEO of SGX RegCo.
Cordlife had called for a trading halt on Thursday. As at 3.10 pm, before the trading halt, the counter was trading down 6.3 per cent, or S$0.015, to S$0.225.
The Great Eastern logo on the facade of Great Eastern Centre located at Pickering Street on 4 Dec 2019.
Recent boardroom tussles involving SGX-listed companies have seen varying degrees of success for requisitioning parties, and not all cases are straightforward.

site_title: Hedge fund industry reaches US$4.3 trillion milestone in first quarter
summary: The global hedge fund industry reached a record US$4.3 trillion in assets at the end of the first quarter, driven by a 4.52% growth in hedge fund performance. The industry added US$16.6 billion in net new money, particularly to equity and event-driven strategies. This marks the sixth consecutive quarter of growth, with US$190 billion in added assets. Hedge fund managers took advantage of geopolitical risks and macroeconomic uncertainties to drive the growth.

site_title: Paradox of high interest rates and a resilient economy
summary: The US economy has defied expectations, growing at 3% in 2023 despite aggressive interest rate hikes. Several factors contribute to its resilience, including exceptionally stimulative fiscal policy, accommodative financial conditions, and a surge in household wealth. High interest rates have stimulated consumption, particularly among households with attractive savings yields, and have not slowed down interest-rate sensitive sectors such as residential housing and automotive. The Federal Reserve's "neutral" interest rate may be higher than 2.5%, and investors should consider diversifying into cyclical exposures and alternative assets to build resilient portfolios.

images.alt_text: The Fed created so much money during the pandemic that, by some measures, the excess has still not been fully absorbed by the economy.

IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva warns that a toxic mixture of weak productivity, a retrenchment in globalisation, and frequent bouts of geopolitical turmoil will drag growth down to paltry levels and, in so doing, sow the seeds of “popular discontent” with mainstream politics.
Bond buying is a tricky calculus for individuals, in part because the tiiming and number of rate cuts keep getting pushed back. That favours active management.

site_title: Taylor Swift, tortured poet, exorcises demons with new double album
summary: Taylor Swift releases her double album "The Tortured Poets Department", which debuted with a first 31 tracks at midnight on April 19, followed by an additional 15 tracks two hours later. The album, described as an "anthology of new works reflecting events, opinions, and sentiments," addresses her tumultuous personal life, including her relationships with Joe Alwyn and Matty Healy. The album marks Swift's ninth LP in five years, following the success of her Grammy-winning "Midnights" and re-recorded albums, and is expected to make waves in the music industry.

images.alt_text: (Clockwise from top left): Six vinyl variants of Taylor Swift's "Midnights" album= mahogany, moonstone blue, blood moon, lavender, jade green and love potion purple. For "Midnights", Swift's last studio album, a total of 35 physical products, including these six vinyl variants, were sold.
Victims are asked to pay upfront for the tickets, but once the payment is made, the scammers disappear.
No Doubt – the group fronted by Gwen Stefani – played together for the first time in 15 years on the second day of Coachella.
Taylor Swift performing  in Sydney on Feb 23.

site_title: Million-dollar analyst jobs at risk in China research pullback
summary: Chinese brokerages are retrenching after years of expansion due to a prolonged market slump and tightening regulations. Several senior analysts have resigned after rejecting pay cuts and stricter performance metrics. Brokerages are reducing costs by slashing bonuses, travel budgets, and meal allowances. The industry's reliance on trading commissions has led to a bubble in research analyst hiring, but this is now bursting. Analysts face increased scrutiny over the quality of their research, and the market's demand for equity research has weakened. The combined profits of Chinese brokerages dropped 20% in 2022, and the industry is expected to undergo a long and painful restructuring process.

images.alt_text: Global financial firms are seeking to reduce expenses amid a deal drought.

site_title: A voyage for all senses
summary: Silversea's S.A.L.T. (Sea and Land Taste) programme offers immersive culinary experiences on the luxury cruise line's small ships. The programme, led by former Saveur editor-in-chief Adam Sachs, combines onboard and off-ship excursions to showcase local cuisine and culture. Guests can participate in cooking classes, meet local chefs, and enjoy regionally-inspired menus. S.A.L.T. excursions and experiences are tailored to each destination, allowing guests to delve deeper into the region's soul and culture. The programme is available on Silversea's ships sailing worldwide, including the Mediterranean, Asia, Africa, the Caribbean, and more.

images.alt_text: Two pandas cuddling up at Wolong panda reserve.

site_title: Oil prices flat as economic headwinds counter Mideast supply fears
summary: Oil prices remained flat on Tuesday as economic headwinds countered concerns over Mideast supply fears. Brent crude futures settled 8 cents lower at US$90.02 a barrel, while US crude for May delivery fell 5 cents lower to US$85.36. Despite geopolitical tensions, markets appear cautiously optimistic, with investors awaiting the US response to Iran's attack on Israel. The Federal Reserve may need more time to achieve inflation confidence, and rising interest rates are expected to continue.

images.alt_text: Brent futures for June delivery settled at US$90.10 a barrel, down 35 cents, or 0.4 per cent on Monday.

site_title: Malaysia’s falling birth rates, ageing population to strain the economy
summary: Malaysia's fertility rate has plummeted from 4.9 children per woman in 1970 to 1.6 in 2022, a record low comparable to the US. This trend, combined with rising life expectancy, is expected to strain the country's economy, healthcare, and pension systems. Economists warn of a shrinking demographic dividend, increased dependency ratio, and potential old-age poverty crisis. To address these concerns, policymakers are urged to implement interventions, such as adjusting retirement age policies, establishing minimum income floors, and promoting family-building. The country's minimum retirement age remains at 60, while average life expectancy has increased to 74.8 years.

images.alt_text: Low fertility threatens to undermine South Korea’s economic future by shrinking its workforce and slowing consumption.
Singapore grew rich before becoming old.
The exterior of Jinxin Reproductive Hospital in Chengdu, in China's Sichuan province. Jinxin Fertility Group is expanding in South-east Asia with an investment in an Indonesian company.

site_title: Iwase – the Japanese town that time (nearly) forgot
summary: The Japanese town of Iwase, located in Toyama prefecture, has undergone a remarkable transformation under the vision of Ryuichiro Masuda, a fifth-generation owner of a sake brewery. Twenty-six years ago, Masuda launched an ambitious project to revitalize the town, which had been declining due to the akiya (abandoned house) phenomenon. He bought up houses, converted them into restaurants, ateliers, breweries, and bars, attracting top chefs, artisans, and foreign visitors. Today, Iwase is a thriving gourmet and cultural hub, boasting Michelin-starred restaurants, award-winning craftsmen, and a unique, sometimes unexpected, personality behind each restored house.

images.alt_text: Astana, the capital of Kazakhstan, under the evening sky.

site_title: China set to keep lending benchmark LPRs unchanged in April
summary: China is expected to keep its benchmark lending rates unchanged in April, following strong first-quarter economic growth data and a weakening yuan, which restricts the central bank's ability to ease policy. A Reuters survey of 30 market watchers found that all respondents expect both the one-year and five-year LPRs to remain unchanged. This decision comes as China's economy faces challenges, including a fragile recovery and mounting local government debt, but officials may be reluctant to introduce further monetary stimulus.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) building in Beijing, China, on Monday, June 26, 2023. China's consumer-driven recovery is showing more signs of losing momentum as spending slows on everything from holiday travel to cars and homes, adding to expectations for more stimulus to support the economy. Source: Bloomberg

To plug a capital shortfall, the five Chinese largest lenders this year have announced plans to issue as much as 440 billion yuan of TLAC bonds in total, with issuance of the bonds could be as soon as the second quarter this year.

site_title: Art and soul
summary: Japanese architect Kengo Kuma's design ethos is showcased through six products, reflecting his expertise with natural materials and traditional craft techniques. The Fu sofa combines zabuton-inspired design, the Yakisugi lamp features charred wood and molten glass, and the Goz rugs evoke the texture and aroma of traditional Japanese tatami floors. Limited edition pieces include the Kigumi table, Migumi chair, and Urushi collection, all highlighting Kuma's attention to detail and commitment to natural materials. These designs are now available for order from various brands, offering a glimpse into Kuma's innovative approach to furniture design.

images.alt_text: Keiji Ashizawa and honest design

site_title: Hundreds evacuated after Indonesia’s Ruang volcano erupts
summary: Hundreds of people in Indonesia's North Sulawesi province have been evacuated after the Ruang volcano erupted, spewing lava and ash clouds into the sky. The volcano, located on Ruang island, has raised its alert level to the second highest following multiple eruptions since Tuesday. Authorities have cleared the island, with most residents relocated to the nearest island, due to anticipated further eruptions. The eruptions were triggered by recent earthquakes, emitting "explosive hot clouds" as high as 1.8 km into the sky.

images.alt_text: A handout picture taken and released by Center for Volcanology and Geological Hazard Mitigation on April 17, 2024 shows Mount Ruang releasing hot lava and smoke in Sangihe Islands as seen from Sitaro, North Sulawesi on April 17, 2024. site_title: Even without war in the Gulf, pricier petrol is here to stay
summary: Oil prices remain high and are likely to rise further, driven by a combination of geopolitical risks and supply disruptions. Despite a potential escalation of tensions between Israel and Iran, oil markets are not expected to surge due to traders' expectations of a cautious response. Supply cuts by Opec+ are expected to continue, potentially reaching US$100 per barrel, and could lead to a deficit in the global market. Robust demand growth, driven by manufacturing activity, could offset some supply disruptions, but prices are expected to remain uncomfortably elevated.

images.alt_text: Brent futures for June were down US$1.01, or 1.32, to US$89.01 a barrel at 11.19 am EST (1619 GMT), while US crude futures for May were down 88 cents, or 1 per cent, at US$84.48 a barrel.
Deep losses in Asia carried over into European trading, but Wall Street’s main indices wobbled as corporate earnings season continued.

site_title: Keiji Ashizawa and honest design
summary: Japanese architect Keiji Ashizawa defines his philosophy as "not just good design, but honest design." He recently purchased a 20-year-old house in Yugawara, Japan, and renovated it to showcase his design style. The house features natural materials, gentle palettes, and streamlined volumes, creating a sense of refined calm. Ashizawa's design firm, Keiji Ashizawa Design, has also collaborated with Norm Architects on furniture brands like Karimoku Case and Blue Bottle Coffee. His openness to collaboration and focus on handcrafted materials have set him apart in the design industry.

images.alt_text: Architect Christopher Lee adopts a conceptually rigorous approach to the buildings he designs.
The texture and aroma of tatami floors of traditional Japanese houses inspires Kuma in the Goz collection of rugs.

site_title: Sichuan’s call of the wild
summary: In China's Sichuan province, the remote Tangjiahe National Nature Reserve offers a rare opportunity to observe rare wildlife, including the threatened golden takin and giant pandas. The reserve, with its mist-wreathed mountains and crumbling tombs, is home to 85 species of protected animals and is a natural habitat for wild giant pandas. Visitors can observe these creatures on guided hikes, but the reserve's remote location and harsh weather conditions make it a challenging destination, with only one accommodation option and basic facilities. Despite the challenges, the reserve offers a unique chance to see these iconic animals up close.

images.alt_text: People sitting along a river at a park in Chengdu, Sichuan’s vibrant 3,000 years-young capital.
Astana, the capital of Kazakhstan, under the evening sky.

site_title: Jewelled watches showcase artistry
summary: Bulgari, Van Cleef & Arpels, and Piaget unveil new, bejewelled timepieces showcasing ancient artisanal techniques. Bulgari's Tadao Ando x Serpenti captures the beauty of sakura season, while Van Cleef & Arpels' Lady Arpels Nuit Enchantee features a crystal cave scene with rough sapphires. Piaget introduces new versions of its iconic High Jewellery Aura in rosy hues, showcasing the brand's mastery of gem-cutting and gem-setting. These limited-edition watches demonstrate the artistry and craftsmanship of the luxury watch industry.

images.alt_text: The Oyster Perpetual GMT-Master II is the first such model in Oystersteel to sport a 24-hour graduated two-colour Cerachrom bezel insert in grey and black ceramic.
Mademoiselle’s Workshop – Musical Clock Couture Workshop is part musical box, part clock and part automaton.
Duometre Heliotourbillon Perpetual (front)
On the reverse face of Les Cabinotiers – The Berkley Grand Complication, the Gregorian perpetual calendar dominates.

site_title: An American prince wants to be president
summary: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a 70-year-old son of Robert Kennedy, is running for president as an independent third-party candidate, drawing attention from both Democrats and Republicans. As a lifelong Democrat, he initially sought to challenge Joe Biden for the party's nomination but switched to an independent bid. Kennedy's candidacy has raised concerns among Democrats, who fear he could hurt Biden's chances in the 2024 presidential election. Kennedy's supporters include those who distrust the federal government and have backed his anti-vaccine movement, while others are drawn to his outsider status and the Kennedy name.

images.alt_text: Trump’s queries about Kennedy suggest that the former president remains in the initial stages of his vice-presidential selection process.
US presidential candidate Robert F Kennedy Jr. (right) announces his running mate Nicole Shanahan (left) in Oakland, California on March 26, 2024.
Kennedy said in April he would challenge Biden for the Democratic nomination to run against the Republican nominee, expected to be former President Donald Trump.

site_title: Lee Hui Li: Empowering women, embracing change
summary: Microsoft's Lee Hui Li, managing director of Microsoft Singapore, advocates for diversity and inclusivity as cornerstones for innovation. She believes that embracing change and using her unique perspective to speak up has helped her ascend the leadership ladder. Lee promotes a customer-centric approach to bridge differences and advance together. She offers advice to women and minorities, including being confident in their minority status, taking on leadership roles without titles, and recognizing work-life balance changes. Lee is also excited about the transformative role of artificial intelligence (AI) in tackling social and digital divides.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Charmain Kwee of Eurokars.
Tan Min Lan heads the chief investment office, Asia-Pacific, at UBS Global Wealth Management.

site_title: Chengdu, city of charm and contrasts
summary: Chengdu, Sichuan's 3,000-year-old capital, has undergone significant transformation, balancing ancient history with modernization. The city is now home to a UNESCO-listed Bronze Age site, Sanxingdui, and a Hi-tech Industrial Development Zone with futuristic buildings. Taikoo Li, a restored heritage area, offers a mix of old and new, featuring luxury brands and exhibitions. The city's growth is evident in its international business hotels, including the Waldorf Astoria Chengdu, and its rise as a hub for finance and tech companies. Chengdu's unique blend of history and modernity makes it an exciting destination for adventure and exploration.

site_title: New Zealand inflation tipped to slow towards RBNZ’s target band
summary: New Zealand's inflation likely slowed to 4% in the first quarter, its weakest reading in nearly three years, due to high interest rates weighing on the economy. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) maintains its policy of keeping interest rates restrictive to control inflation, targeting 1-3% band. Economists predict the RBNZ may not cut rates until 2025, despite a minority expecting a pivot to easing in the second half of this year. The economy faces a risk of an extended recession, with manufacturing and consumer spending contracting.

images.alt_text: The expansion to Singapore and New Zealand's Enhanced Partnership, announced by (from left) Luxon and PM Lee, will focus on supply chains and connectivity.
FILE PHOTO: View of an entrance to the Reserve Bank of New Zealand in Wellington, New Zealand November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Lucy Craymer/File Photo

site_title: Quatre to the chase: An icon turns 20
summary: French luxury jeweller Boucheron is celebrating the 20th anniversary of its iconic Quatre collection, which combines four distinct codes from the house's archives to form a bold, genderless, and expressive design. The collection, launched in 2004, features innovative materials and craftsmanship, including Physical Vapor Deposition and Hyceram. Quatre has become a symbol of strength and protection, appealing to those who embody a certain character. The collection has expanded to include new pieces, such as XXL chokers and ultra-precious ring designs, and continues to be a trailblazer in the world of jewelry.

site_title: New Zealand holds rates, sees ongoing need for tight policy
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), held interest rates steady for a sixth consecutive meeting, maintaining the official cash rate at 5.5%. The decision aims to tame inflation, which remains above the 2% target at 4.7%. The RBNZ projects inflation will fall into the 1-3% target band by the third quarter this year and slow to 2% by the end of next year, with rate cuts not expected until 2025. The economy is in recession, with business and consumer confidence remaining weak.

images.alt_text: Central banks globally are focused on how quickly inflation is slowing and when they can begin easing.

site_title: Rolex – a sleek study of harmony and contrast
summary: Rolex unveiled its latest novelties at Watches & Wonders 2024, featuring new materials, colors, and textures. The new Oyster Perpetual GMT-Master II boasts a 24-hour graduated two-color Cerachrom bezel insert in grey and black ceramic, while the Oyster Perpetual Day-Date 40 features a "slate ombre" dial in 18-ct Everose gold. The Perpetual 1908 collection has been upgraded to the brand's most prestigious category, with a guilloche dial created by engine turning. Other new models include the Oyster Perpetual Deepsea, Cosmograph Daytona, and Sky-Dweller, each showcasing Rolex's commitment to evolution and uncompromising quality.

images.alt_text: Tudor unveils new line of Black Bay 58 watches
The Portugieser Eternal Calendar
The World Time Date Reference 5330G has a date display synchronised with local time, a feature that is totally new to the world-time model.
TAG Heuer – the master of chronographs excels again with three new creations
On the reverse face of Les Cabinotiers – The Berkley Grand Complication, the Gregorian perpetual calendar dominates.
Duometre Heliotourbillon Perpetual (front)

site_title: US investigators interview ship personnel in Maryland bridge collapse
summary: US investigators are conducting interviews with key personnel from the cargo ship Dali, which crashed into the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore on March 26, killing six people. NTSB chair Jennifer Homendy said investigators have spoken with the pilots, second officer, and US Coast Guard personnel. The investigation is examining the ship's electrical power system, circuit breakers, and fuel onboard, as well as the bridge's original design. A preliminary report is expected to be released in early May. The Senate Commerce Committee's top Republican, Senator Ted Cruz, is calling for federal funding to replace the bridge.

images.alt_text: This handout screegrab courtesy of the National Transportation Safety Board taken on March 27, 2024, shows part of the steel frame of the Francis Scott Key Bridge sitting on top of the container ship Dali after the bridge collapsed in Baltimore, Maryland, on March 26, 2024. A major bridge collapsed in Baltimore on March 26, 2024, blocking one of the busiest US commercial harbors, after a heavily laden cargo ship lost power and smashed into a support column despite desperate attempts to stop in time. Six people -- all members of a nighttime construction crew repairing potholes on the Francis Scott Key Bridge -- were missing and feared dead, according to officials and media reports. The fallen bridge is one of three highway routes traversing Baltimore Harbor – the two others are tunnels beneath the harbor – and handles 31,000 cars per day, or 11.3 million vehicles a year.

site_title: The man behind Masuizumi sake
summary: Ryuichiro Masuda, the mastermind behind Masuda Shuzo's premium Masuizumi sake, has taken his family's brewery to new heights. Founded in 1893, the brewery now produces over 30 distinct sake varieties, all made without added brewer's alcohol. Masuda's interest in Western customs and wine-making techniques has led to innovative collaborations with champagne houses and whisky distilleries. His flagship sake, Masuizumi Platina, is a nama junmai daiginjo praised for its freshness and elegance. A rare, 17% polished rice sake, denoted by two "Platina" words, is also highly sought after for its aromatic and ultra-clean taste.

site_title: Barry Callebaut jumps as volumes hold up despite cocoa price surge
summary: Barry Callebaut reported a 0.7% increase in first-half sales volumes, exceeding expectations, despite a surge in cocoa prices that have more than tripled over the last year due to disease and adverse weather in Ghana and Ivory Coast. The company's shares rose 8% and its CEO attributed the resilience to its competitive edge in sourcing cocoa beans. However, the company's earnings before interest and tax fell 40% to 178 million Swiss francs, missing analysts' forecast.

images.alt_text: Cocoa futures prices have more than doubled this year to cross US$10,000 a ton for the first time, before currently edging below.

Analysts warned that companies such as cocoa processors and chocolate manufacturers may have to reduce operating expenditure or raise prices of their products in a bid to try and offset the recent multifold spike in cocoa prices.

site_title: Trump hush money charges seen as serious by most voters: poll
summary: A majority of US voters (64%) consider the New York charges against Donald Trump for allegedly covering up hush-money payments to a porn star as "somewhat serious." The charges, part of four criminal prosecutions, could take a heavy toll on Trump's presidential campaign. Polls show that voters view other charges, such as electoral fraud and mishandling classified documents, as more serious. Trump's lawyers have tried to delay trials, but a judge rejected his request to delay the hush-money trial. The trials could impact Trump's personal finances and overall presidency.

images.alt_text: Trump Media & Technology Group posted a net loss of US$58.2 million in the year ended December 2023, compared with a net profit of US$50.5 million a year earlier.
Former President Donald Trump faces legal challenges in his 2024 campaign for president. But this has galvanised his supporters.

site_title: Your fast-food favourites, only better
summary: Restaurant Chain in Los Angeles has been recreating nostalgic American fast food dishes with meticulous attention to detail, inspired by its archive of vintage fast food. The restaurant, founded by actor BJ Novak, hosts themed dinners, including a "Pizza Haute" dinner that features a dupe of Pizza Hut's original pizza. Chain's menus change, sometimes combining brands, and the restaurant has become a popular spot, with a waiting list of 25,000 names. The restaurant's success has sparked debate about its intentions, with some viewing it as a celebration of nostalgia and others seeing it as a marketing stunt.

images.alt_text: The kitchen at Denny’s in the Jackson Heights neighborhood of Queens, in New York; the take-out orders were mostly from the Denny’s menu, but some were from the Burger Den and the Meltdown, two delivery-only brands that the chain owns.
Non-alcoholic drinks are all the rage now.
Quieter spaces are one example of how Starbucks is thinking about its cafes as it further expands around the globe.

site_title: Singapore’s top court to hear Credit Suisse fight to overturn US$743 million award to billionaire
summary: Singapore's top court will hear Credit Suisse's appeal to overturn a US$743 million award to billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili. The award was made after a lower court ruled that Credit Suisse's trust failed to safeguard Ivanishvili's assets, related to the actions of a rogue private banker, Patrice Lescaudron. Since the litigation began, Credit Suisse has been taken over by rival UBS Group. The bank's lawyers argue that the verdict poses significant legal issues, while Ivanishvili's lawyers claim supervisors should be held criminally negligent for failing to detect Lescaudron's subterfuge.

site_title: Rate cuts on the cards for South-east Asia once US Fed starts easing cycle
summary: South-east Asian central banks are expected to hold interest rates steady, awaiting the US Federal Reserve's next move in monetary policy. Thailand is likely to be the first to cut rates, with a modest 25 basis point reduction, if the Fed delays easing cycle. Economists expect the first rate cut to come in June, with cumulative cuts of 75 basis points by year-end. Bank Negara Malaysia, Bank of Thailand, and the State Bank of Vietnam are expected to maintain interest rates, while Bank Indonesia may follow the Fed's lead with rate cuts.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Thailand will review key interest rates next week.
Trade-reliant Vietnam's exports in March surge by 14.2 per cent from a year ago to roughly US$34.01 billion.
The decision was in line with efforts to maintain stability of the rupiah and control inflation, Indonesia's central bank governor Perry Warjiyo says.
Economists expect Bank Negara to keep rates steady at 3 per cent until the end-2024 or even longer.
The Thai baht has fallen some 5 per cent against the US dollar to a range of 36 per greenback.

site_title: Les Amis Group ties up with Michelin-starred Tokyo sushi eatery to open Singapore outpost
summary: The Les Amis Group has partnered with Tokyo's one-Michelin-starred Sushi Ryujiro to open a Singapore outpost, Sushi Ryujiro Singapore, in the former Aoki restaurant space. The restaurant will be opened on April 29 and will feature personal nigiri shaping by chef Ryujiro Nakamura for four days. This marks Nakamura's first overseas restaurant venture, which was planned after a previous partnership ended. The Les Amis Group had reached out to Nakamura after a shareholder dined at Sushi Ryujiro Tokyo and expressed interest in a potential partnership.

site_title: Make your cake and get help too
summary: A new baking studio, Home Baking Day, offers a "tablet-guided DIY baking studio" experience in Singapore, allowing customers to bake without the hassle of cleanup or prep work. The studio provides all necessary ingredients, equipment, and supplies, and staff cleans up after customers. Prices range from S$50 to S$95. Unlike other baking studios, Home Baking Day does not teach baking skills, instead offering a fuss-free space for customers to bake. The concept originated in Taiwan and has expanded to Hong Kong and Singapore.

site_title: BMW iX1 review: More show than go
summary: The BMW iX1, BMW's cheapest electric car, offers a refined and upscale interior with a digital user interface, but lacks excitement in its electric motor, which sends only 147 horsepower to its front wheels. It provides a calm and peaceful driving experience, but can feel sluggish by EV standards and lacks sound unless equipped with artificial whirring tones. The iX1 excels in providing refuge from daily stressors, with a comfortable cabin and advanced features. Its price, at S$261,888, is S$20,000 more than the basic X1, but its range of 474km and efficiency of 17.5 kWh/100km make it a viable option for those seeking a premium electric vehicle.

site_title: SingPost appoints ex-SMRT managing director as CEO for Singapore business
summary: SingPost appoints Shahrin Abdol Salam as its new CEO for Singapore operations, effective May 1, succeeding Neo Su Yin. Shahrin has over 25 years of experience in managing operations, strategic planning, and business development. His appointment follows SingPost's strategic review aimed at enhancing shareholder value and its plans to transition into a pure-play logistics player. The company also plans to reorganize into three business units and divest non-core assets, including its flagship development, SingPost Centre.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

Proceeds from the sale of SingPost Centre - that is if the divestment gets the green light from authorities and shareholders - will go towards paying off debt, funding investments and rewarding shareholders.
SingPost considers divesting S$1.1 billion SingPost Centre and floating Australian business
SingPost reported a dip in operating profit of 18.2 per cent for the third quarter of it financial year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Apr 2)
summary: Singapore will prescribe a list of government fees not subject to the goods and services tax (GST), with an initial list to be published at the end of April. Manpower Minister Tan See Leng emphasized the importance of not viewing residents and foreigners as a "zero-sum game" for jobs, while the owner and manager of the containership Dali filed a petition in the US to limit damages from the bridge collapse. Meanwhile, Singapore hotels' average room rate rose in February, and major retail banks will introduce the "money lock" feature by mid-2024.

site_title: Israeli startups raised US$3.1 billion since war began on Oct 7
summary: Israeli high-tech startups have raised US$3.1 billion in private investment since the war with Hamas began on October 7, with security technology firms accounting for one-third of the funds. Mergers and acquisitions activity has also been robust, totaling US$3.7 billion, with two deals worth nearly US$1 billion. Despite challenges, the Israeli tech sector remains strong, driven by attractive valuations and significant growth potential, according to Startup Nation Central.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Israeli national flags flutter at a business park also housing high tech companies, at Ofer Park in Petah Tikva, Israel August 27, 2020. REUTERS/Ronen Zvulun/File Photo

site_title: Turnaround by Bridgewater CEO hinges on wooing restless clients
summary: Bridgewater Associates, the world's largest hedge fund, is undergoing a turnaround under CEO Nir Bar Dea, who replaced Ray Dalio in 2023. The firm has made significant changes, including cost cuts and a major management shakeup, to revive its underperforming flagship Pure Alpha fund. The fund has rebounded 16% this year, but investors remain concerned about its historical lackluster returns and volatility. The firm has also faced legal action over the firing of 100 employees, including allegations of favoritism and age and sex discrimination.

images.alt_text: Multi-strategy funds deploy multiple teams to manage money across various investment strategies.
For international investors becoming increasingly skittish about China, the sudden trading restrictions give them one more reason to stay away.
The outlook for monetary policy will define future capital flows after billions of US dollars have poured in over the past year.
Hedge funds are now the most exposed they have ever been to European stocks relative to a global benchmark, according to Goldman Sachs Group data.

site_title: Boeing hit with whistleblower allegations, adding to safety concerns
summary: A Boeing whistleblower, engineer Sam Salehpour, has alleged that the company dismissed safety and quality concerns in the production of 787 and 777 jets, leading to engineering problems and shortcuts. The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is investigating the claims, which include Boeing using force to align production issues on the 777 jet. The allegations come as Boeing faces a full-blown safety crisis and has undergone a management shakeup. The FAA has met with Salehpour and plans to hold a hearing on the issue, while the US Department of Justice is also investigating whether Boeing violated a 2021 settlement related to the 737 MAX crashes.

site_title: PayPal enables PYUSD stablecoin for Xoom cross-border money transfers
summary: PayPal has enabled its Xoom cross-border money transfer service to use the PYUSD stablecoin for international remittances. PYUSD, pegged to the US dollar, allows customers to send funds abroad at a lower cost. This move builds on PayPal's goal to drive mainstream adoption of cryptocurrencies. The company's stablecoin was introduced last August, and it can be redeemed for US dollars and used to fund purchases and buy other cryptocurrencies. PayPal faces regulatory scrutiny, but the company plans to continue offering the stablecoin.

images.alt_text: Employees of PayPal Inc., exit the company's headquarters in San Jose, California, U.S., on Tuesday, Jan. 24, 2017. PayPal Inc. is expected to release earnings figures on January 25. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore proposes increased scrutiny of critical transport firms through legislation amendments
summary: Singapore proposes legislation amendments to increase scrutiny of critical transport firms, including increased controls on ownership, management appointments, and operations. The Transport Sector (Critical Firms) Bill aims to strengthen the resilience of key firms providing essential transport services, complementing the Significant Investments Review Bill. The Bill will designate entities in air, sea, and land transport, with penalties for breaches of controls. Implementation is expected in the second half of 2024, with the Bill's second reading scheduled for May.

site_title: Aspen to pay RM40 million to contractor Tialoc in global settlement
summary: Aspen Group has reached a global settlement with contractor Tialoc Malaysia, agreeing to pay RM40 million (S$11.4 million) to end a months-long dispute. The amount is below Tialoc's initial RM78 million claim filed in August last year for outstanding sums and financing charges. The settlement will be funded through sale proceeds from a piece of land held by Aspen's indirect subsidiary, Aspen Vision Development (Central), with Tialoc to receive 53% of the sale proceeds.

The writ, which was received on Aug 28, named Aspen Group, Aspen Glove’s directors, Aspen Vision All and KHTP Assets as co-defendants.

site_title: Catering to birds’ every whim to export nests for a delicacy
summary: In Indonesia's Borneo, a lucrative business has emerged as people build luxurious birdhouses to attract swiftlets, whose saliva-built nests fetch high prices in China. The birdhouses, often resembling prisons, are designed to mimic the birds' natural habitats, with features like ventilation holes and pools of water. However, the industry faces challenges, including the theft of nests, habitat destruction due to climate change, and government regulations that cut into the income of farmers. As a result, many birdhouses remain unused, and the swiftlet population is declining, threatening the livelihoods of those who rely on the lucrative export trade.

site_title: JPMorgan juices bets on the red-hot debt market in Sri Lanka
summary: JPMorgan Asset Management and T Rowe Price Group are investing in Sri Lanka's local-currency government bonds amid optimism for a restructuring deal on the country's defaulted global bonds. Sri Lankan dollar debt has surged 17% year-to-date, with the local debt market up 6% and the rupee strengthening 8% this year. A normalization of inflation, foreign reserves, and balance of payments is seen as positive for the onshore bond market, with investors attracted to the attractive yields and cheaper currency. Both portfolio managers expect the local debt to remain a buy despite the road to recovery taking time.

images.alt_text: China, the world’s and Sri Lanka’s biggest sovereign creditor, pledged to support the island nation to take forward its debt restructuring plan during Sri Lankan Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena’s visit to Beijing last month.

epa11022753 A vendor counts Sri Lankan rupee banknotes in the commercial hub of Colombo, Sri Lanka, 11 December 2023. The International Monetary Fund's executive board is slated to vote on 12 December regarding the release of approximately 330 million US dollars as the second tranche of the Extended Fund Facility program to Sri Lanka. In the preceding year, the IMF approved a three-billion-dollar Extended Fund Facility (EFF) to bolster Sri Lanka's economic strategies and reforms. Meanwhile, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) recently approved a 200 million US dollars concessional loan to Sri Lanka's government aimed at stabilizing the nation's financial sector in response to the economic crisis that arose in 2022 due to the suspension of external debt payments. Sri Lanka is experiencing its worst economic crisis in over seven decades as a result of a lack of foreign reserves.  EPA-EFE/CHAMILA KARUNARATHNE

site_title: Microsoft to separate Teams and Office globally amid antitrust scrutiny
summary: Microsoft will globally separate its Teams and Office products, selling Teams as a standalone offering for Enterprise customers, starting April 1. The move comes six months after unbundling the two products in Europe and Switzerland to address antitrust concerns. The European Commission has been investigating Microsoft's tying of Office and Teams since 2020. The new offerings will provide multinational companies with more flexibility in standardizing their purchasing across geographies.

images.alt_text: Microsoft and OpenAI are in the middle of the third phase of the five-phase plan.

site_title: Kid-focused tech startup myFirst picks Fu Yu as exclusive contract manufacturer
summary: Singapore-based kid-focused tech startup myFirst has appointed Fu Yu Corporation as its exclusive contract manufacturer. Fu Yu will provide a full suite of solutions to manufacture and assemble myFirst's products, including watchphones, cameras, and headphones. The S$15 million contract will support myFirst's major North American expansion and help drive growth, with plans to boost locations to 20,000 and expand into new markets. The partnership aims to enhance sustainability by using bio-rated materials.

site_title: A tale of two (island) cookbooks
summary: Two new cookbooks, "Island Life: Recipes from Nikoi & Cempedak Islands" and "Our Migrants’ Kitchen", have been launched in Singapore, showcasing the unique culinary traditions of private islands and migrant workers. "Island Life" features recipes from Nikoi and Cempedak islands, highlighting their sustainable and eco-friendly practices, while "Our Migrants’ Kitchen" shares stories and recipes from migrant workers from various countries, highlighting the importance of food in connecting with their families and communities. Both books aim to promote cultural exchange and appreciation of diverse culinary traditions.

site_title: World’s most powerful MRI scans first images of human brain
summary: The world's most powerful MRI scanner, Iseult, has successfully imaged human brains for the first time, reaching unprecedented precision levels of 10 times more than standard MRIs. The 11.7 tesla scanner, developed by France's Atomic Energy Commission, has allowed researchers to visualize tiny brain vessels and cerebellum details previously invisible to the naked eye. The technology holds promise for better detection and treatment of brain pathologies, including Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases, and could lead to more accurate diagnoses and targeted treatments.

images.alt_text: A volunteer takes part in a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) exam simulation on the Iseult Magneton 11.7 T MRI at the Neurospin facilities in the Paris-Saclay Alternative Energies and Atomic Energy Commission (CEA - Commissariat a l'energie atomique et aux energies alternatives) centre in Gif-sur-Yvette, on March 22, 2024. "Iseult", the world's most powerful MRI scanner, has delivered its first images of the human brain and is expected to provide a better understanding of its functioning and of certain neurodegenerative and psychiatric diseases. The technical feat is the result of a French-German partnership which has required more than 20 years of research. (Photo by ALAIN JOCARD / AFP)

site_title: RedDoorz brings in US$28.2 million after becoming cash flow positive in Q4 2023
summary: RedDoorz, a Singapore-based hospitality firm, has secured US$28.2 million from investors to achieve cash flow positivity in Q4 2023. The company, which operates under multiple brands, plans to expand into Malaysia. Founder and CEO Amit Saberwal attributes the milestone to improvements in unit economics and operating expenses optimization, as well as continuous supply growth through its multibranding strategy. This follows the company's previous break-even in Indonesia and the Philippines in 2022, and its decision to reduce properties in Vietnam due to the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Accredify aims to prevent scams and fraud in e-commerce, ticketing and news dissemination, says its CEO and co-founder Quah Zheng Wei.

site_title: Yellen, Premier Li express hope for US-China cooperation
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Chinese Premier Li Qiang expressed hope for US-China cooperation, citing the need for direct and open communication to move forward. Yellen noted that tough conversations are necessary, while Li emphasized China's desire to be partners, not adversaries. The two countries agreed to hold talks on balanced growth and tackling overcapacity, a US concern about Chinese government support to industries fueling production capacity. Yellen's visit also focused on engaging with local officials and addressing issues such as money laundering and the production of fentanyl.

images.alt_text: epa11263409 U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen (L) meets with Chinese Premier Li Qiang at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China, 07 April  2024. Yellen, who arrived in Beijing after starting her five-day visit in Guangdong province, one of China's major industrial and export hubs, said that talks will create a structure to hear each other's views and try to address American concerns about manufacturing overcapacity in China.  EPA-EFE/Tatan Syuflana / POOL

site_title: Why are champagne and fried chicken so great together?
summary: A new restaurant in Manhattan's Flatiron district, Coqodaq, is pairing Korean-style fried chicken with an extensive champagne list, capitalizing on the unexpected affinity between the two. The concept is not new, with other restaurants like Birds & Bubbles and Bubbledogs also combining high-end champagne with humble fried chicken. The author argues that wine should be matched to the occasion, not limited to traditional pairings, and that unexpected combinations can lead to delightful discoveries. This trend is part of a broader movement to break culinary conventions and celebrate the joy of wine for its own sake.

site_title: Lloyds bank says quarterly profits sink on higher costs
summary: Lloyds Banking Group reported a 29% drop in after-tax profit to £1.1 billion in the first quarter of 2024, citing higher operating costs that jumped 11% to £2.4 billion. The lender's net interest income also declined. Despite this, CEO Charlie Nunn stated that the group is delivering in line with expectations. The decline in profit is attributed to increased costs and falling net interest income.

site_title: Goldman’s UK gender pay gap reaches highest level since 2017
summary: Goldman Sachs' UK gender pay gap has reached its highest level since 2017, with a mean hourly pay difference of 54% between men and women. Women in the UK workforce earn about half what men earn, largely due to the under-representation of women in senior ranks. Despite efforts to improve representation, no woman has been appointed to a senior role at the company. Goldman's CEO, David Solomon, has set a target for women to comprise at least 40% of vice presidents by 2025.

images.alt_text: The Goldman Sachs & Co. logo is displayed at the company's booth on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., on Friday, July 19, 2013. site_title: Ares seeks to buy most of HK$10.2 billion loan for Hong Kong tower
summary: Ares Management, an alternative investment manager, has proposed buying a majority stake in a HK$10.2 billion loan backing luxury-property development The Corniche in Hong Kong. Ares is offering 95 cents on the US dollar for the syndicated loan, seeking to buy two-thirds of the loan. The proposal was discussed with banks on Monday, and the deal could take a few months to complete. The Corniche, developed by Logan Group and KWG Group Holdings, has struggled to sell units since 2023, with only five out of 295 units sold.

images.alt_text: The Corniche residential project in Hong Kong. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

site_title: Singaporean chefs make low-key fine-dining debut at Inicio
summary: Restaurant Inicio in Singapore's Thye Hong Centre serves generic mod-European fine-dining cuisine with a lack of personality and direction. The restaurant's isolated location and deserted atmosphere during dinner hours deter customers. Although the food is generally competent, it's too generic and predictable to make an impact. The kitchen team, comprising three Singaporean chefs, fails to showcase their talents, and the service is minimal. With a rating of 6, Inicio has potential but needs to bring life to its concept and connect with its target audience.

site_title: Swedish home prices extend gains as market shows signs of thaw
summary: Sweden's housing market showed signs of a thaw, with apartment prices rising 1.8% and detached houses increasing 1.1% in March, according to data from Svensk Maklarstatistik. Sales numbers also improved, with a 8% increase in home sales from last year's first quarter. The association's CEO attributed the gains to slowing inflation and expectations of a potential interest rate cut by the central bank. This follows gains in February, with single-family house sales rising 12% and flat sales increasing 7%.

images.alt_text: Residential apartment buildings in Stockholm. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg
